title: THAILAND MILITARY MAKING COMEBACK
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 31 After three years in eclipse, the militant right wing is suddenly reemerging in Thai society and politics.

title: British Journalist Reported Held by Ethiopian Rebels
description: LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 1 (Reuters)  The Sunday Times of London said today that Jon Swain, its correspondent missing in Ethiopia for more than six weeks, may be in the hands of the Tigre Popular Liberation Front, an Ethiopian guerrilla movement in Tigre Province.

title: BRITONS IN UGANDA MUST KNEEL TO AMIN
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 31 (Reuters)President Idi Amin issued a list of instructions today for Britons still living in Uganda, including one that would require them to kneel during an audience with the President.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market continued to decline last week in lackluster trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which has been falling almost steadily for the last three weeks from a 41month high of 1,011.21 set on July to a close of 984.64 on Friday, was down 6.27 points for the week

title: Matteawan State Hospital To Shut Down by April 1
description: New York State has decided to close the controversial Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane in Beacon and transfer most of the responsibility for handling mentally disturbed inmates to the Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: Mazes
description: What we're talking about here (rationally) are 60 savage trails with hundreds of tempting wrong turns. Sixty trails packed with hazardous adventure, terrifying thrills and narrow squeaks (or is that the sound of the eraser?) but always with the tantalizing possibility of a speedy triumph. (Can one not, after all, trust one's own eyes?)

title: Matilda Maguire Wed To William LeFevre
description: Matilda Bock Maguire of New York and Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to William M. LeFevre of New York. Justice of the Peace Joseph Bojorquez of Old Lyme performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Old Lyme.

title: Nancy Jo Eppler Bride Of John Howard Wolff
description: In the Fairmont Temple in Beechwood, Ohio, last night Nancy Jo Eppler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heinz Eppler of Cleveland, became the bride of John Howard Wolff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wolff of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Ray A. Soloff performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: One's first impulse as a conservative is to interpret Mr. Reagan's identification of Senator Richard Schweiker as his running mate as a terrible act of political expediency. as indicated by the fundamental and irreconcilable differences in their a priori views.

title: A Message of Necessity From Klein
description: MR. Chairman, ladies and gentlemen, I come before you this morning in connection with the issue of the Southwest Sewer District and the special report and I will attempt to make this as direct, as brief as possible. I would like to take just a couple of moments to reflect some chronology that has taken place and then make a recommendation. As you may be aware, yesterday, with Smith, Barney and others, I embarked on the program of sales of the bonds for the Southwest Sewer District, needed of course, to retire bondanticipation notes coming due in September, which was rolled over from May, and a bondanticipation note coming due in December, which was rolled over from July; those two aggregate $114 million; the initial effort at marketing bonds is $125 million to $150 million to provide for the retirement of those notes and working capital for the balance of 1976.

title: DELAY IN PAYMENT TO AMTRAK SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The Government's chief auditor has ruled that the Department of Transportation has no legal basis for withholding millions of dollars from Amtrak as a means of forcing the passenger train corporation to rent, rather than buy, the 245mile BostonWashington rail line.

title: Squander Captures Sorority
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31  Monmouth Park's Sorority Stakes is becoming oldhat with the Phipps family.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It really happened. I was sitting minding my own business in the Hurok pressroom at the Metropolitan Opera House, when Sallie Wilson, a ballerina of American Ballet Theater, came in. I saw her. I think I said something like, Hi Sallie, because she is a friend. Well, perhaps not a friend, an acquaintance. Someone I have known many years in a casual, but I always thought warm, Hi, Sallie fashion. Then suddenly I had a glass of Scotch thrown in my face. It was an odd thing.

title: WESTCHESTER STRIKE OF TEAMSTERS ENDS
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 31A threeweek teamsters strike against Westchester and Putnam County builders was settled tonight as teamster union members voted to accept management's offer and return to work.

title: Man Is Killed by Car While Asleep in House
description: ILLIOPOLIS, Ill., July 31 (UPI)William O. Elvin, 76 years old, was run over and killed by an automobile today as he slept in the bedroom of his rural home, state police said.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1  WALT DISNEY PRODUCTIONS, WORLD RIGHTS RESERVED

title: Aiken:
description: In 1928, H. L. Mencken described one of Calvin Coolidge's literary efforts as incomparably naive, earnest, eloquent and charming. Almost the same could be said of the diary of George Aiken, who was Governor of Vermont and later Senator. Aiken was certainly as acerbic as Coolidge. In 1972, he notices the President's righthand assistant, Henry Kissinger, who oozed conceit from every pore. And notes again that the thirst for publicity appears to be the overwhelming characteristic of Mr. Kissinger.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Brooks Brothers is moving to new quarters downtown.

title: American League
description: Sunday August 1. 1976

title: HEAD OF TASK FORCE CRITICAL OF CRITICS
description: Louis P. Wein, outgoing director of the Mayor's task force for emergency preparedness, charged Friday that high city officials had tried to discredit the task force's report that the city was unprepared to face a major disaster.

title: Born again politics
description: Is Charles Colson, famous dirty trickster and convert, a feigning Christian? I don't think so. I believe he may be the truest American Christian since Andrew Carnegiethe man Mark Twain took as the perfect specimen. If I had any doubts, they were dispelled at a Washington prayer breakfast for Christian law professors and students. The air was stickier than the buns, full of sweetJesus billings and cooings. A steady diet of this would try the nerves of anyone less entirely converted than Colsonwho not only billed with the best, and cooed biblically, but seeks out such gatherings with increasing, not lessening, devotion. It is an obstacle course to try the best skills at feigning.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Life ceased publication in 1972 but Time Inc its parent Corporation has found it profitable to revive the photographic magazine periodically in the form of a oneshot special report issue. The most recent version has a double  barreled theme, Remarkable American Women: 17761976. Some 1,250,000 copies were published to sell at $2 each and although they just started arriving at newsstands last week, some locations in Manhattan have already exhausted their allotments.

title: Fashion
description: Shetland sweaters are making a comeback, and the reason is clear. They're as classic as this fall's tweed, flannel and tartan clothes

title: What's Doing in the LOIRE VALLEY
description: THE SITE  Few regions in the world have assembled in a relatively small area so great a collection of architectural delights as the Loire River Valley south of Paris. During the Middle Ages the river was fortified with impressive town ramparts and crenellated castles. Then, by the time of the Rerjaissance of the 16th century, with a consolidation of territories, there was time for pleasure. The castles were enlarged and more attention was paid to decoration, exterior as well as interior, less to the thickness of walls and the width of moat. While the French kings enjoyed hunting and carousing in the benign valley, enhanced by excellent products of the soil (including, of course, wine), their courtiers were obliged to build their own castles and manors. The result is an extraordinary countryside dotted with castles. There are a score of famous castles, but another 100 or more scarcely known outside their own neighborhoodsnot to speak of the churches and fortified estates and fine old stone houses in villages and towns. There are any number of ways to visit the castle country: Detailed itineraries are available in guidebooks, and one is suggested below. But if you can afford the time, simply wander through the region, following a sign to a castle here, a church or monastery there and nearly everywherea vineyard free wine tasting.

title: The Death and Life of Bishop Pike
description: Since we have begun to focus with unusual intensity on the private lives and sexual troubles of our Presidents and Congressmen, it may be time and perhaps even more appropriate to give the same scrutiny to our ministers, priests and bishops. More appropriate because, in a way that is less true of secular leaders, the professionally religious man makes more claims for the sign value of his life. He tries to say, with St. Paul, As I imitate Christ, imitate me. But, paradoxically, humanity both intrudes on and becomes the vehicle of this imitation. In literature and in life the weakness of the whisky priest or libidinous pastor can heighten the force of the sign, for here is Paul's shattered vessel of clay struggling to allow God to accomplish his will, once again, in the unexpected way.

title: Pascaline Courau to Wed Sept. 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. Christian Courau of Paris hav,e announced the engagement of their daughter, Pascaline, to James Tomilson Hill 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hill Jr. of New York and Cotuit, Mass.

title: Amish Remain Unchanged as Lancaster County Grows
description: LANCASTER, Pa.Here in the heart of Amish country, the question remains, Will success spoil Lancaster County?

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: PROFITS, productivity and production provided the dominant news of the business world last week and captured wide analytical attention throughout the economic and the investment communities. In general, the reaction was highly favorable. Simultaneously, another development aroused considerable interest. It was the first formal and fairly specific insight into some of the economic philosophy of the Democratic Presidential candidate, Jimmy Carter, and of his chief economic adviser. Professor Lawrence R. Klein of the Wharton Schoolprovided by themselves in public statements. The reaction was mixed, as might have been expected.

title: International Labor Group Reports Courts Are Backing Women in Suits Against Job Discrimination
description: GENEVA, July 30Courts throughout the world are supporting women in their fight against job discrimination for reasons of sex, marital status or family responsibilities, according to a study by the International Labor Organization.

title: Cambodian Leader Describes Regime's Problems and Goals
description: BANGKOK, Thailand July 31 (UPI)Prime Minister Pol Pot of Cambodia has repotted that after 15 months of Communist rule, his country still has barely enough food, and serious problems. But he also talked of his country's modest goals and some achievements during the period.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The office of New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has again interceded on behalf of confused collectors. Last year his office cracked down on a Floridabased distributor (Italcambio, Inc.) for improper advertising of a socalled Cambodian gold coin. Now it has moved against a private mint for advertising a historic $20 gold pieceat a price of $20 plus $2 handling  that is in fact less than dimesized and contains less than $3 worth of gold. (In other words, it is a $20 gold piece only in its price.)

title: No.Amer.Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: One Hundred Black Men Intend to Make a Difference
description: CHARLES RUSSELL Jr., a publicrelations consultant, lives in Westbury. Dr. Jesse J. Pone, a resident of Old Westbury, is a physician who specializes in internal medicine. William Urquhart lives in Hempstead, where he owns a realestate business.

title: For Forbes, Far Hills Is Still Home
description: FAR HILLS FOR Malcolm Stevenson Forbes, the millionaire publisher of Forbes magazine, home could be a chateau in France, a palace in Tangier, a historic London mansion, ranches in Montana or Colorado, a Fifth Avenue townhouse or one or his retreats in the South Sea Islands.

title: The China Quake: No Death Toll Yet
description: A major earthquake, which caused death and damage not yet counted, has occurred in a densely populated part of China, confirming the predictions of that nation's scientists but also confirming the inadequate state of earthquake studies: Experts think they can tell the disasters are coming, but as a rule, not exactly when.

title: Glimpses of Lewis and Clark's Expedition
description: SEATTLE The Seattle Art Museum's Bicentennial observance is a tripartite celebration of the journey made by Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark through uncharted territory from the mouth of the Missouri River to the Pacific coast and back, the great adventure that established the claim of the United States to the Oregon Territory and opened the West to settlers and trade. As a voyage of discovery in 18036, the Lewis and Clark expedition was the most important since 1492 and until 1969, when astronauts landed on the moon. And as Willis F. Woods, director of the Seattle museum, points out in his introduction to the exhibition catalogue, Lewis and Clark had no preliminary test runs and no aerospace scientists and physicians constantly checking their every breath and able to control the speed and direction of their vehicletheir vehicles having been boat, horse and foot.

title: ...But Needs Strengthening
description: Having a firstrate professional at the helm of the Antitrust Division will be particularly important if new antitrust legislation, now working its way through Congress, is enacted this year. The Senate has already passed a hotly debated omnibus antitrust enforcement bill, sponsored by Senator Philip Hart of Michigan, an outstanding Democratic liberal, and by Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate Republican minority leader.

title: Italian Cabinet Meets
description: ROME, July 31 (UPI)Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti and his new minority Christian Democratic Government met for theri first Cabinet session today to fill the key posts of ministry under secretaries. The Cabinet chose 47 under secretaries during its 55minute session.

title: Munson's Batting Feats Earn Respect of His Fans and Foes
description: When President Ford saw Thurman Munson before the AllStar Game in Philadelphia recently, he remarked, I thought he was bigger.

title: Paperbacks
description: FORGETTING ELENA, by Edmund White. (Popular, $1.50.) A young man, waking up in a summer cottage full of older men, seeks to solve the mystery who he is: a first novel distinguished by its hard, gemlike style.

title: A Bright Golden Haze on the Island
description: MATTITUCK IT'S early harvest time on Eastern Long Island and throughout the North and South Forks, farmers are now bringing in the wheat and rye.

title: Kissinger Seeking Black American Support for the Administration's New Policy on Africa
description: BOSTON, July 31Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is attempting to build the widest possible constituency for his new Africa policy and has begun seeking support from influential black Americans.

title: Diversification Did Not Weaken Banks
description: Ralph Nader's report on banking contends that diversification by banks into other fields has weakened the industry. Basically the study concludes that the entrance into bankrelated activities (such as consumer loan companies, factoring concerns, mortgage banking, etc.) since the mid1960's has diverted managements from the basic business of banking, diminished the capital growth of the industry and brought about the largest loan losses since the 1930's. In other words, Mr. Nader feels that bankers have spread themselves too thin.

title: Simpson of Bills Is Expected to Retire This Week
description: This is the week that O. J. Simpson must make up his mind either to retire from pro football or to return to Buffalo and play for the Bills. It is expected to be retirement Tor Simpson at age 29 after seven seasons in the National Foot ball League.When he retired under somewhat similar circumstances a decade ago, Jim Brown was a year older and he had played nine seasons.

title: The Fire Island Plan Draws Mostly Cheers
description: OCEAN BEACH A NATIONAL PARK SERVICE proposal that could result in eventual condemnation of 300 houses on the primary sand dune along the Fire Island National Seashore drew sharp criticism last weekend at the first of a series of public hearings.

title: Imperial Oil's Ills: As Big as Canada
description: TORONTO  Imperial OilCanada's largest oil and natural gas company and 70 percent owned by Exxon Corporationis caught up in controversies that illustrate the difficulties confronting American business here at a time of surging Canadian nationalism.

title: Lye Hurler Killed, 16 Policemen Hurt In Battle in Harlem
description: Sixteen policemen were burned, five of them seriously, by buckets of lye, drain cleaners, ammonia and gasoline hurled by a man barricaded in a Harlem apartment yesterday during a siege that ended in a blaze of police gunfire that killed the assailant.

title: Prehistory Lives In Fields of Eire
description: The Irish can be infuriatingly casual about their national treasures. I had seen in a book a photograph of a particularly fine dolmena graceful stone structure built in prehistoric times as a tomband read that it was in Kilclooney, County Donegal, but no such place appeared on the map. The owner of the little hotel in Ballyshannon where I was staying with my husband and stepson knew the whereabouts of the dolmen, however. In fact, he said, he used to graze his cattle in the pasture where the dolmen stands, and the Stone Age monument came in handy as a hay barn.

title: F.B.I. SAID TO YIELD STOLEN RECORDS
description: DENVER, July 31  Some documents stolen three weeks ago from the Socialist Workers Party headquarters here were included among files in the Denver office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that were made public today, according to party officials who have studied the documents.

title: Miss Grady Wed to William Beehler
description: Margaret Ann Grady and William Rhoades Beehler were married yesterday afternoon in Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Sparta, N.J. The Rev. Charles C. Cassidy performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hazard Grady of Sparta. Her husband is a son of Elizabeth Baxter Beehler and William Henry Beehler Jr. of Baltimore.

title: BRIDGE
description: There is considerable room for argument about the rightful claimant to the title of the world's oldest bridge magazine, Americans can point with pride to The Bridge World which has appeared monthly since 1929. The British claimant is Bridge Magazine, which was found ed in 1926 by A. E. ManningFoster but which ceased publication during World War II and was not revived until 1949.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: One comes out of the new allblack version of Guys and Dolls singing the songs and singing the praises of Frank Loesser. Is there a richer, more harmonious and more American score in the modern musical theater? Was there a composerlyricist more adept at integrating words, music and character? Songs not only flow out of the Abe BurJo Swerling book but they flow into one another. For example, in Marry the Man Today, the longengaged Adelaide and Salvation Army Sarah weave their individual romantic laments into a universal tapestry about the plight of women at the hands of men.

title: The Nation
description: After five decades of virtual immunity from public criticism, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is in serious trouble from top to bottom. No one seems to think its survival is in jeopardy, but the F.B.I. that emerges from the current official scrutiny of its people and procedures will probably be a far cry from the venerated institution of crimefighters and gangbusters that J. Edgar Hoover made a part of American folklore.

title: Citibank Branch Is Robbed
description: The Citibank branch at 580 Second Avenue, at 32d Street was held up yesterday by two armed men who escaped in a goldcolored car with $3,000. Wearing stocking masks and brandishing revolvers, the bandits ordered the people in the bank not to move or sound an alarm. Then one of them vaulted the counter, pulled a yellow envelope from his pocket and stuffed the money into it.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: POLISH PRIMATE NEARS MILESTONE
description: WARSAW, July 31 (Reuters) Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, leader of Poland's 30 million Roman Catholics, marks his 75th birthday on Tuesday with no signs of giving up his long and shrewd defense of the interests of the church in this Communist state.

title: Miss Glass Has Nuptials
description: Katharine Woolley Glass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Glass Jr., of Farmington, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon in St. James' Episcopal Church, to Lawrence T. Dale 3d, son of Mrs. Dale 2d of Arlington, Va., and the late Mr. Dale. The Rev. Borden Painter performed the ceremony.

title: Olympic Summaries
description: Boxing

title: U.S. STUDY CAUTIONS ON PUBLIC FACILITIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Public facilities must be more carefully planned to reduce their potentially destructive impact on the nation's communities, the Council on Environmental Quality said in a report issued yesterday.

title: Villaflor Bout Approved
description: HONOLULU, July 31 (UPI) The World Boxing Association today gave its approVal for a world junior lightweight title rematch fight between Ben Vitiator of the Philippines the champion, and Samuel Serrano of Puertb Rico; The fight is tentatively scheduled for Sept. 15 in Manila.

title: Phillies Set Back Mets, 21
description: The silent bats and makeshift outfield of the New York Mets let down Jon Matlack again yesterday as the lefthander suffered a 21 defeat by the Phillies at Shea Stadium.

title: FORD STARTS POLL ON RUNNING MATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 31President Ford today began soliciting predictable recommendations on the perfect running mate. But what the President ultimately will decide, given the opportunity to name a VicePresidential nominee, was unpredictable.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: EGarner 2, C.Washingtn, Smalley. DPMinnesota 1. LOBOakland 8, Minnesota 11. 28Rudl 2, B.WIlliams, Bostack, Carew. HRB.Williams (10), Ford (1 3). S BHisle, Baylor, Lintz, M.Alexnder. SHisle. SFTenace.

title: ByrneDugan: Sparks Fly
description: THE heated political feud between Governor Byrne and State Senator James P. Dugan, the Democratic state chairman, is intensifying.

title: Modred and Fabled Monarch Win in Split Stakes on Grass
description: Mrs. Paul L. Hexter's Modred, a colt who seems to have found the road to riches on turf, and John M. Olin's Fabled Monarch, who has triumphed on dirt as well as on grass, were the victors in the two divisions of the Lexington Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Shipping/Mails Incoming
description: TOMORROW, AUG. 2

title: Challenges Delaying Changes in Zoning By Jersey Towns
description: Fifteen months ago, the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered Mount Laurel, a largely rural suburb of the city of Camden, to revise its zoning code to permit housing suitable for a wider variety of income and age groups.

title: The Viking Spirit
description: As the first robot researcher putters around on Mars while a companion robot prepares for a landing, IT becomes clearer than ever that the Viking program has dimensions extending beyond the technological marvel of a soft descent by a complex instrument package onto another planet that is millions of miles from Earth.

title: International Catholic Congress Opening Today in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 31The largest and most diversified body of Roman Catholics to gather in this country in half a century formally opens the church's 41st International Eucharistic Congress here tomorrow.

title: The Nation
description: The House of Representatives, which has looked less tolerantly at its members improprieties since the Wayne Hays affair, has voted to formally chastise a Representative found to have a conflict between his official duties and his personal financial interests. The reprimand was the lightest possible action the House could take.

title: Helsinki Accord and the Soviet Union: Effects on Human Rights Seem Mixed
description: MOSCOW, July 31The Helsinki declaration, signed a year ago by 35 heads of state, appears to have had a mixed effect on human rights in the Soviet Union.

title: Schweiker, Member of a Lonely Band
description: WASHINGTONWilliam S. Brewer, an uncommitted Pennsylvania delegate to the Republican National Convention, was deeply offended by Ronald Reagan's choice last week of Richard S. Schweiker, the liberal Pennsylvania Senator, as his prospective running mate. We don't need liberal Republicans, Mr. Brewer said.

title: NEW EASY RIDERS BIGGER JAZZ BAND
description: Bill Bissonette's Easy Riders Jazz Band, a New Orleansoriented group that flourished in Connecticut in the 1960's until Mr. Bissonette moved to California in 1968, was a loud, lusty, roughhewn group that often seemed more concerned with physical involvement than with fine musical points. A new version of the Easy Riders, formed last fall by Mr. Bissonette following his return to Connecticut, made its first appearance in a New York club Friday evening at Storyville, 58th Street and Madison Avenue, and proved to be a very legitimate descendant of the earlier Easy Riders.

title: Literary Figures Offer Plots and Quips
description: Leading lights of the American literary scene have summoned up a raft of recommendations for the sequel to Gone With the Wind, which Richard Zanuck and David Brown are now planning. Rhett and Scarlett are envisioned as everything from swingers who meet in a New York City singles bar to a populist politician (him) and a suffragette (her). A surprising number of writers interviewed, however, declined to speculate on the sequel simply because they had never read the book or seen the movie. This group includes John Barth, John Hawkes, Wilfred Sheed and Anita Loos I don't go to movies: I make my living from them). Brian Moore walked out on the film when he was a small boy in Belfast, and Elizabeth Janeway, who started the book in manuscript while working for the BookoftheMonth Club, shoved it aside in boredom after a chapter and a half. Paul Theroux, who had been exposed to GWTW only by hearsay, was willing, all the same, to hazard a guess at Part II. Many, of course, had both seen the 1939 classic and read the book, too. Here are recommendations from 15 prominent authors:

title: Stephen Hays Marries Ann Berninger
description: Ann C. Berninger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Frederick Berninger of Williamsville, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday afternoon to Stephen Houghton Hays, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Lansing Hays of Riverside, Conn., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y.

title: A Gold Medal for John, a Silver for Ben
description: MONTREAL, July 31 (AP) John Peterson captured the gold medal that eluded him in 1972, but his brother Ben had to settle for a silver in tonight's finals in Olympic freestyle wrestling.

title: South Africa Blacks Get Approval on Mass Meeting
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 31 (UPI)South Africa granted permission today for blacks to hold a mass meeting in the black township of Soweto following a week in which fires were set in 17 schools and pupils boycotted classes.

title: Proper Summer Care Is the Key to Poppy and Iris Bloom
description: Two of the best  loved flowers of springOriental poppies and bearded irisshould be attended to now. Unlike most perennials and bulbs that should wait for fall or spring care, these perennials require summertime planting for new rhizomes or division of thick overgrown clumps.

title: Farmers Turn to Pest Control in Place of Eradication
description: In fields and orchards throughout the country, a small but growing number of farmers are abandoning the heavy use of pesticides.

title: Friday's Fight
description: Los Angeles  Reuben Oliares, Los Angeles, outpointed Fernando Cabanalla, the Philippines, 10 rounds, bantamweights.

title: HUNGARIANS YIELD TO RISE IN PRICES
description: BUDAPEST, July 31 (Reuters)Twelve days after Polish workers rioted over higher food prices, forcing their Government to capitulate, Hungary enforced similar increases. Hungarians grumbled, but they paid up.

title: Engineer Is Slain by Burglars in Home
description: A 62yearold chemical engineer who could only speak in a hoarse whisper because of a throat operation for cancer was stabbed to death early Friday when he surprised burglars in the living room of his home on a quiet residential street in Plainfield. N.J.

title: To Laugh or Not to Laugh Is the Question of Measure for Measure
description: Among Shakespeare critics and scholars, Measure for Measure is known discreetly as a problem comedy. More directly, Shakespeare's last and thorniest comic work, which is due to open at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on August 4, might be called a problem child. Indeed, John Pasquin, the young director of the new production, sighs with almost parental weariness when asked to discuss the play. It's almost too complicated, he says, referring to the forthcoming production which will feature Sam Waterston, Meryl Streep and John Cazale.

title: Pragmatic Illusions
description: Nothing so illuminated John Kennedy's Presidency as its afterglow; no policy or program of his thousand days lingers as long as their unfulfilled promise. The contradictions are smoothed by the wash of nostalgia for a fallen leader. What remains in the popular political imagination are myths masking a mediocre record.

title: Cathy Sachs Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman Sachs of Irvington, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Cathy Diane, a Gouher College graduate, to Richard Elliott Rubin, a member of Phi Beta Kappa who expects to graduate next May from the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Rubin of Somerville, N.J. Mr. Rubin is executive director of Memorial General Hospital in Union, N.J. Mr. Sachs is a senior vice president of the Consolidated Electric Construction Company.

title: Viking Finds Mars Oxygen Is Unexpectedly Abundant
description: The Viking 1 landing craft has detected an unexpected abundance of oxygen and chemical activity in the soil of Mars, a finding that project scientists said yesterday could be either the first evidence of Martian life or a sign of unusually active oxidation processes.

title: Michigan Farmers Use Phone For Tips on Spraying
description: SPARTA, Mich.Royal Kline was worried about apple maggots, the tiny larvae of a fly that lays its eggs in the skin of apples, causing the fruit to ripen and drop prematurely.

title: Residents Come to Aid Of LyeSplattered Police
description: Convent Avenue between 127th and 128th Streets was thronged with shoppers. residents lounging on stoops or patronizing a bar, coin laundry or corner luncheonette when a police radio car pulled up before 12 Convent Avenue, a threestory rooming house.

title: Reagan, the High Roller
description: With only two weeks left before the opening of the Republican National Convention, Ronald Reagan has taken a major gamble, probably in desperation, to persuade the delegates) to the convention that he, and not President Ford, should get their nomination.

title: $1.2 Million Italian Robbery
description: FOGGIA, Italy, July 30 (AP) Six masked bandits armed with pistols and knives held up the Monte Uniti Bank and made off with jewels worth more than $1.2 million, the police reported. They said that in addition to the jewels. the robbers got about $19,000 in cash in the holdup yesterday.

title: F. J. Albetta Jr. Weds Miss Mayshark
description: Cassandra Benton Mayshark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Casimir Benton Mayshark of Sante Fe, N. M., was married yesterday morning to Frank J. Albetta Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albetta of Oyster Bay, L. I. Dharman Shakya, a Buddhist monk, performed the ceremony at the Zen Center in Rochester.

title: Dance: New Sylphide
description: The Romantic Danish choreographer August Bournonville saw the stuff of magic in a commonplace brace of characters like Effie and James. His triumph is in making us see that magic as well in La Sylphide, which details their comings and goings along with some mysterious highland creatures like Madge and the pylphide herself. Eleanor d'Antuono was the sprite and Fernando Bujones the benighted Scots man Friday evening in American Ballet Theater's production of the classic at the New York State Theater.

title: Red Sox, Goaded, Beat Yanks Twice
description: BOSTON, July 31Perhaps they were goaded by an editorial in this morning's Boston Globe that termed them a team without, pride and unembarrassed by their ineptitude. Maybe they were spurred on by a total of 55,436 fans who attended the daynight names. Whatever the reason, the longdormant Boston Red Sox awoke today and beat the New York Yankees, 42 and 64 at suddenlyhappy Fenway Park.

title: Fred Bauer Weds Christien Platten
description: Christien Ann Platten, and Fred Anthony Michael Bauer, a lawyer who will be with Coudert Brothers next month, were married yesterday. The Rev Robert Schmidt, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in Blue Bell, Pa., at the borne of Slats Platten, the bride's mother.

title: Article 3  No Title

title: For Those Who Leave, the Price

He is just the kind of person that Soviet officialdom cannot tolerate: temperamental, idiosyncratic, arrogant, impudent. Hardly the type to blend smoothly into the collective. Were he Russian instead of American, his bad manners would probably have kept him out of tournaments long before his talents could have been discovered.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: At a quarter to 2 on a rainy Friday morning not long ago, in Catch a Rising Star, a nightclub on First Avenue in the East 70's, there's no one in the place but me, 15 or so yawning patrons and a hopelessly amateurish young comediansinger named Kelly Rogers, who, in showbiz parlance, is bombing. Rogers, in fact, has been on for 10 minutes and has yet to get more than an isolated guffaw. Ahh, get off the stage, ya bum! A middleaged man shouts drunkenly from a back table. Thank you, thank you, says Rogers nervously. And now I'd like to give you my impression of every white person in Philadelphia. Rogers turns away from the audience and puts a rubber band around his head in such a way as to flatten his nose crookedly against his face. Now he turns back to the audience and does what is evidently supposed to be an imitation of a punchdrunk IrishAmerican fighter. In other words, he's suggesting that every white person in Philadelphia is Irish and a moron. Utter silence. And now, every black person in Philadelphia, Rogers goes on, turning briefly away from the audience and then back again to reveal himself with the rubber band still flattening his nose as he proceeds to do an imitation of a punchdrunk black fighter. Groans from the audience.

title: Jean McKeever Wed To David E. Weiskopf

title: FEDERAL SERVICES SUPPORTED IN POLL
description: WASHINGTON Juy 31 (AP)  The Federal Government ranked highest in a poll of public attitudes on value received from government jurisdictions. The poll also indicated heavy support for special Federal aid to troubled big cities.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 31 (AP)The Oakland A's dismissed today Harry Bright as Manager of their Tucson Toros farm club in the Pacific Coast League. Lee Stange, a former major league pitcher, was named to manage the team.

description: PRINCETON WHEN Elric J. Endersby met with the directors of the Princeton Historical Society six years ago, he thought he had landed a parttime job interviewing elderly residents for a project in oral history. The historical society, on the other hand, thought he was a volunteer.

description: ALBANY, July 30  The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, one of New York's biggest public utilities, has charged that the smallest city in the state is attempting to pirate away one of the utility's major industrial customers.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WHEN I was a kid growing up in New York City I got wet like other kids got wet in the summer with unscrewed fire hydrants, the hoses of friendly neighbors, showers made by embedding pipes attached to bathroom shower heads in concrete bases, and swimming pools in schoolyards and parks that were really uptothethighs wading pools.

title: A New Accent for Spartanburg
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.There's a Swiss consulate here. And an annual Oktoberfest. And a delicatessen that sells couscous and Wurzbune head cheese.

title: General Motors' Hard Line Is Assailed by Woodcock
description: DETROIT, July 31 (UPI)The United Auto Workers president, Leonard Woodcock, has assailed General Motors for what he said was a hard line bargaining stance on wages and benefits. He warned G.M. that it could become the union's 1976 strike target.

title: BUSINESS TAX LOSS IS CITED BY GOLDIN
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has estimated on the basis of an audit by his office that the city is losing more than $600,000 a year in revenues from 2,000 businesses that have failed to pay, the city's commercial rent tax.

title: Philadelphia Will Replace Suspended Garbagemen
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) The city All hire new trash collectors next week to replace those suspended because of a fourweek, sanitation workers' slowdown that has clogged sideivalks and gutters with garbage.

title: Park to Change
description: AN extraordinary assault by barge and crane on the rotting New Jersey shoreline behind the Statue of Liberty will begin tomorrow, heralding a massive harbor cleanup ordered by the Army Corps of Engineers. The first beneficiary will be the fledgling, harborside Liberty Park at the south end of Jersey City, opened in midJune as a 30acre overlook at the back of the statue, half a mile away.

title: PEOPLE
description: HE'S limping, but he's improving. That's the progress report from Budd Schulberg on Loh, the male swan that the author and his wife, the actress Geraldine Brooks, wrote about in their book, Swan Watch. Not long ago the Schulbergs noticed that Lohof Loh and Grin, the swan couple the Schulbergs befriended when they moved to their house on Aspatuck Creek in Quogue five years agowas limping and uninterested in Mr. Schulberg's handouts of bread and cracked corn. The author said that Dr. Thomas Pescod of the Hampton Veterinary Hospital had been called in to examine the bird. And although the cause of Loh's limp and general air of illness could not be found, vitamin and penicillin shots seem to be having a positive effect. While not looking out for Loh's welfare, Mr. Schulberg is at wont on a new book, about his childhood in Hollywood. If all goes well, hopes to finish it by the end of the year.

title: A Tranquil Coast
description: The jagged peninsula plunges into the chill waters of East Penobscot Bay some 120 miles northeast of Portland, Me. The coastal highway, U.S. 1, runs inland here behind the 30milelong peninsula, cutting it off from the motel, gasstation and friedclam belt. This is the East Penobscot Bay region of tranquil Down East villages. Isolated from the main coastal highway, It remains mercifully free of summer traffic, crowds and fiurlyburly.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: HOMEOWNERS who have backyard swimming pools, regardless of whether they are aboveground or inground, have to follow a definite watermaintenance program if they want to keep the water in their pool clean and invitinglooking and free of objectionable odors, cloudiness and algae growth.

title: Hot off the vine
description: The bulk of French wines imported to the United States are not, as myth may have it, fabulously expensive or of legendary and esoteric distinction. They are middlerange qualityappellation contriiide, as it is listed on the bottleand reasonably priced. Made in the vineyards of Bordeaux, Burgundy, the Rhone valley and other districts, these wines have long been popular with Americans for reasons of palate as well as purse. But gradually, with little public awareness, their character has been undergoing a significant change. For French winemakers, costs are up: Hand operations are almost prohibitively costly, and loansespecially since the wine scandals of the early 70'sare more expensive and harder to get. Economic imperatives, and the standardization they impose, are obliterating the unique characteristics that once distinguished these wines and made them memorable.

title: The Law And Fast Trial
description: THERE is a certain irony to the fact that the national debate on the scope of the right to a speedy trial has only begun in this decade. The origins of both the right and the concept date to the Assize of Clarendon in 1166 and the Magna Carta in 1215. The records of our national adoption of this right through its inclusion in the Bill of Rights depict an almost perfunctory acceptance. This lack of debate on the right to a speedy trial at the time of Constitutional ratification, has left us with no guidance and little understanding of the scope or nature of this right.

title: Pacific Islands to Get Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) President Ford today extended a federal disaster declaration for the northern Mariana Islands to include damage caused by Typhoon Therese, which struck July 13 in the Pacific islands. He previously announced a major disaster declaration June 17 in connection with Typhoon Pamela, Which struck the islands May 20. Federal aid will be made available to the islands.

title: FISHING
description: FLUKE fishing along the New Jersey shore has rebounded and should offer the best inshore action this week. Offshore, it may be the peak of the bluefishing seasonbut no one has figured out why the fish don't agree. Whether it be unusually cool waters, the abundance of bait, or simply the lack of a storm to stir things up, no one knows. The only certainty is that the bluefishing is not all it should be.

title: Judge Yields on Miners' Fines; Move Could End Strike
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 31A Federal judge who has been the focus of charges by coal miners that the courts have unfairly taken the mine owners' side in a dispute that has paralyzed the West Virginia coal industry said today that he would not impose fines and jail terms pending against the wildcat strikers if they returned to work in a reasonable time.

Last year, of the 121 breeds or varieties on the Amezican Kennel Club list, he was No. 111, with 77 recorded. So foxhound devotees were elated last Sunday at Providence, when William Fetner chose Gilbert and Wilma Beck's Ch. Brown's Fire Fighter, from Weston, Conn., for the silverware. The 4yearold has been shown 89 times and been best foxhound on 86 occasions but this was his first red, white and blue rosette

description: BELGRADE, July 31President Tito has harshly ??enounced the United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia as having initiated a campaign against Yugoslavia, according to remarks made public today.

description: $70 will get you a small single room for a week at one of the newest places to stay in the Hamptons, including all meals and the use of a swimming pool and three outdoor tennis courts. The facility is situated on 110 acres in the Shlnnecock Hills, just a fiveminute drive from Southampton Village, and it accepts guests by the week weekend.

title: Convention TimeSaver
description: Officials of the New York Convention Committee of the American Numismatic Association are predicting an attendance of upwards of 25,000 people at the A.N.A's 85th anniversary convention Aug. 2429 in the Americana Hotel. Many of these, of course, will be members; they have already received notification for advance (by mail) registration. However, nonmembers are equally welcome at the convention, and they, too, can take advantage of the timesaving mail preregistration. There is no charge, but everyone 11 years of age or older must register. Those who do not do so now will face long lines at the registration desk, especially on the opening day. The preregistration chairman is Emil Voigt, P.O. Box 164, Valley Stream, L.I., N.Y. 11581. The deadline is next Saturday, Aug. 7. The official A.N.A. convention program book and the special identification badgemedal (both for $3.50) can be ordered at the same time.

title: A Gazebo Can Be a Play House or a Living Room
description: They were the trysting places of Victorian lovers. In mystery novels, murder plots are hatched or unraveled in them. Chinese emperors and Renaissance doges contemplated their empires in them. Mark Twain was rumored to have invented Huckleberry Finn in one.

title: ART
description: LIKE scholarly pursuits, cultural activities in American universities used to be restricted to a ninemonth period. But in recent years there has been a growing tondency to keep school doors open all year, not only for academic endeavors, but also fr cultural events. Universities have become summer showcases for theater, art exhibitions, opera and dance.

title: When Regulators Enlist With the Regulated
description: WASHINGTON  When Newton Minow was chairman of the Federal Coinmunications Commission a decade ago, he blasted television as a vast wasteland. Today, as a partner in the Chicago and Washington law firm of Sidley & Austin, Mr. Minow sometimes represents CBS Inc., one of the principal occupants of the alleged wasteland. The firm's other F.C.C.regulated clients include broadcasters, cable television companies and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Paris Glorified the Peasant, Yes, but That's Not All
description: PARIS, July 31  Yves Saint Laurent pursued the luxurious peasant look more passionately than anybody else. But yards of bouffant taffeta skirts, propped out by petticoats, appeared even at such staid houses as Chanel. And Ungaro was almost as singleminded as Saint Laurent in his exposition of brilliantlycolored peasantinspired fashions. His collection is rated as second to Saint Laurent's by many viewers of the fall couture shows this past week.

Hart, Democrat of Michigan, and the staff of the antitrust subcommittee he chairs have been trying to push through Congress a divestiture bill that would split up 18 big vertically integrated oil companies into separate producing, pipeline and refiningmarketing companies.

title: A Lesson in Musical Love With Lili Kraus
description: FORT WORTH At the final notes of Schubert's Bflat major posthumous Sonata, Lili Kraus breathed an audible sigh. Putting her hand on the shoulder of the student who had performed the work, the renowned pianist said, I love this piece so very much, and I feel you do too. But, my dear, only in the Godhead can this work ever be as beautiful as it really is. You will, however, come closer to conveying its beauties if you can take the beautiful expression that was on your face while you played and put it into your hands. We must always reach inside ourselves and take the happiness or Oadness we find there and put it into our musical expression. Only then will a piece live.

title: Herbs to Cover The Ground In Shade or Sun
description: Sweet woodruff [Asperula odorata)is a deluxe groundcover for shady places. I'm surprised that gardeners don't make better use of it. The herb is dainty, only three to six inches high. Whorls or stars of pointed leaves encircle the slender stems, one above the other.

title: McLendon In Lead With 204
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 31 (AP)Mac McLendon charged in front with four birdies and then turned conservative today in protecting a onestroke lead over Lee Elder after 54 holes in the $200,000 Pleasant Valley Golf Classic.
