title: Shorter's Marathon: A Surprise Loss in the Rain
description: MONTREAL, July 31As soon as the gun went off, Frank Shorter said tonight, it started to rain, and I thought, Oh, God, I'm in trouble.  The 28yearold Shorter doesn't like to run marathons in the rain because, he says, it makes me stiff.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: AFTER more than six months, the State Department has responded to a demand by Representative Norman F. Lent, Republican of East Rockaway, for some kind of formal reaction to the Starstream incident.

title: Mr. Snoops the snob
description: While snooping around the Disney Studio on previous assignments, I had gotten to know Milt Kahl, a master animator who has also designed many of the characters in the Disney cartoons. In May 1973, Milt gave a guest lecture to the class I was teaching in the history of the animated film at New York City's School of Visual Arts and agreed to my request that he draw a poster to announce the event. In the poster, Milt caricatured both himself and me.

title: The Blood Scandal
description: MONTREAL, July 31The scientific scandal of the Olympics was as quiet as the flow of blood until Lasse Viren of Finland added the 5,000meter gold medal to his 10,000meter gold medal. He has got that extra blood in him, said Ron Dixon of New Zealand. Lasse Viren and other European distance runners are suspected of being strengthened by what is known as blood dopingthe removal of a pint of the runner's blood, then the return of that same blood perhaps two weeks later. In that time his body has compensated for its absence. The runner now has an extra pint of blood in his system. The extra pint provides extra stamina. When asked about the charges of blood doping, Lasse Viren played dumb.

title: The My Lai Massacre And Its Coverup
description: Among all the bloody battles of the war in Vietnam, the operation conducted by three companies of American troops against several hundred Vietnamese civilians at My Lai, in March 1968, will probably be remembered longest.

title: GARDENING
description: NEW JERSEY gardeners can have hardy longlived bulbs blooming in their outdoor gardens this fall if they like. The autumn bloomers are called the stepchildren of the hardy bulb clan for no other reason than that few people ever become acquainted with them since they must be planted in August or early September. Some will be available from local plant centers rather soon. Some must be ordered from plant specialists within a week or so. After this minor inconvenience, autumn bulbs are no trick at all: The flouters appear soon after planting and repeat year after year.

title: Plans, Promisesand GarbageKeep Coming
description: Swimming in the Hudson? In 1965, when Nelson A. Rockefeller was still pushing the notion that government could do everything, he predicted bathers in the river by 1970. In 1970 he said the Hudson would be pristine by 1975.

title: Investors Are Still Shy, So the Utility Asks Higher Rates
description: Charles F. Luce starts today his tenth year as chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company. It is not a particularly jolly anniversary for the head of the giant utility, even though its board of directors recently voted him a $40,000 pay raise and extended his original 10year contract for five more years.

title: Agency Says 100 Aircraft Crashed Carrying Narcotics
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reuters  More than 100 aircraft crashed in the last 12 months while trying to smuggle illegal drugs into the United States, the Drug Enforcement Administration has reported.

title: Washington Denies Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, July 31A State Department spokesman, acknowledging that we have seen news reports that President Tito has accused Ambassador Silberman of interferring in Yugoslav affairs, said today that he had the full confidence of the President and the Secretary of State.

title: Congressional Incumbents, Better Off, Still Not Happy
description: The Campaign Finance Act of 1974, the law that reshaped Presidential politics, has also imposed a new set of rules on candidates for Congress, who are just beginning to assess the impact on the financial freeforall that formerly attended Senate and House elections.

title: The Guest Word
description: Meyer Liben, who died in late December of last year, was a writer of a kind most of us don't believe exists, an unknown firstrate writer. His stories appeared for more than 30 years in magazines like Accent, Horizon, Quarterly Review of Literature, American Review, Commentary and the New Directions annuals, and actually he did have a following, but it was absurdly small and was probably confined to New York. Nine of his stories and a short novel were published in 1967 (Justice Hunger, Dial Press), and though the quality of the writing was often extraordinary the book passed unnoticed in the furor of the sixties. He left behind enough unpublished stories to fill two large volumes; there is at least one play, a batch of poems and the manuscript of a small book called New York Street Games.

title: TOWN CITES GAIN FROM TAX SHIFT
description: RAMAPO, N. Y., July 31 A Rockland County town that enacted tax reform by switching to 100 percent property assessment has discovered that the bitter cure works.

title: Income Tax May Face Snag
description: A Ta time when they had expected to be lounging on the shore, playing golf or tennis or fishing, New Jersey legislators will be back in the State House tomorrow trying to untangle the incometax snarl.

title: Miss Guerlain, George Talbot To Wed Sept. 11
description: Elisabeth Monique Guerlain, manager of the accessories department at Vogue magazine, and George Patterson Talbot, manager of video operations for ABC Sports, plan to be married Sept. 11 in Redding, Conn.

title: NANCY JACKSON ALLISON
description: Nancy Jackson Allison, a former department store executive, died yesterday at her home in. New Canaan, Conn. She was 62 years old.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  Lisca, Scuderis. S.S.C.O.A. time trials at Bridgehaniron (L.I.) Race Circuit. Re stration; 9 A.M.; qualifying: 1.M.2; races: 3 P.M.

title: ESSAYS ADVANCE FRESH AIR FUND
description: My name is Tammie Rambert. I'm told by my friends that I'm a very nice girl. I also like to explore places I've never heard of or seen before.

title: BUTTERFLY HUNT REVEALS SECRET
description: Scientists have just learned where monarch butterflies go every winter. Millions of them migrate from ail over the eastern United States and southern Canada to a tiny, wooded 20acre region in the mountains just north of Mexico City.

title: Walker Takes 1,500
description: MONTREAL, July 31The eight days of Olympic track ended today with glorious relay victories by both United States men's teams and sad defeats in the rain for Frank Shorter and Dwight Stones, two Americans favored for gold medals. Shorter won the silver medal for second place in the marathon, Stones the bronze medal for third place in the high jump, although shaken by a death threat.

title: WouldBe Mars Explorers Have Their Day
description: As Viking 1 and Viking 2 are doing their thing on and around the distant planet of Mars, here on earth model rocket builders from all over the country, are gathering at the 18th annual National Model Rocketry Championships which open today at Allentown College in Center Valley, Pa. At this gathering, which will continue through Friday, rocketry enthusiasts will be comparing notes, showing slides and films, looking at displays of new equipment exhibited by leading manufacturers of model rockets, and finally joining in competitions which will determine new national champions in each of three age divisions.

title: Drummer and Woman Friend Slain in Lobby on East Side
description: A 33yearold professional drummer and an 18yearold woman who was reportedly spending the night at his apartment were shot to death early yesterday in the lobby of the building, allegedly by the woman's friend, the police said.

title: The old Disney magic
description: BURBANK, Calif. Once upon a time, there was a group of talented artists in their 20's who couldn't get the jobs they had trained for because of a Great Depression that had come upon the land. So an architect and a radio writer and some painters and book illustrators and commercial artists took jobs at a little Hollywood cartoon studio that was still hiring because of the seemingly freak popularity of its shorts. In defiance of the Depression, the whole nation was singing Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf? along with the Three Little Pigs and cheering Mickey Mouse as a little David who toppled innumerable Goliaths.

title: Joseph M. Callahan Sr., 78, Hoosick N. Y., Fiber Broker
description: Joseph M. Callahan Sr., president of the J. M. Callahan Corporation, a fibers brokerage concern, of Hoosick, N.Y., died yesterday at his home in Hoosick. He was 78 years old.

title: The Spiritual Empiricist
description: Rudolf Bultmann exerted enormous influence on 20thcentury theology. He was the subject of both surpassing admiration and biting scorn largely on the basis of of a body of teaching and writing that stiffly challenged traditional assumptions and offered alternate means of understanding Christianity's central tenets.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Now, at the height of the outdoormusic season, may be a good time to point out that most outdoor music is a fraud. A comparatively genial and harmless fraud, as frauds go, but not to be excused for that. Outdoor music means amplification, and amplification means invariably that you the listener are having the wool pulled over your ears. Take a recent, unusually blatant example, which came to notice at the opening concert of Philadelphia's new 10,000seat Robin Hood Dell West amphitheater. Brahms's Double Concerto was being performed, with each of the soloists playing into his own microphone, ostensibly amplify the sound for the benefit of the thousands outside the covered pavilion itself.

title: GARDENING
description: HAVE you ever wished that you could store away a bit of summer until the middle of winter when it was really needed? While this may be wishful thinking, the owner of a home greenhouse can certainly come close to doing this very thing. The gardener who owns a greenhouse can experience many of the joys of summer gardening in the snug warmth of his greenhouse, even though the winter winds are cold and the snow lies deep on the ground.

title: The Reagan Gamble
description: A day or two after his surprise announcement that Richard Schweiker of Pennsylvania would be his choice for Vice President, Ronald Reagan put in a call to a Mississippi Republican delegate. The Mississippian said he was so shaken by the decision that he was thinking of switching his allegiance to President Ford.

title: Japanese Equestrians Relive Glory Days of 1932 Olympics
description: Halfway around the world in Tokyo, they still dream of the day in Los Angeles during the 1932 Olympic Games when Baron Takeichi Nishi rode Uranus to the gold menu in jumping. That was Japan's one moment ment in the sun in the equestrian jumping events in the Olympics. Uranus, who had been purchased in Italy in 1930, is buried at the Japanese Equestrian Center outside Tokyo.

title: DINING OUT
description: PICTURE a summer restaurant in a tiny village near the water. It is in an old house and there are some tables on the porch. Plants hang everywhere, lace curtains flutter at the windows and the dining room Is an airy white. So far, that describes The Cook. In these charming, informal surroundings the menu has enough variety to make return visits interesting. That is still The Cook.

title: World Team Tennis
description: FRIDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Headliners
description: John Lennon, the writermusician and former Beatle, has won a four year battle with United States immigration authorities. He will be allowed to remain here as a permanent resident alien, and to apply for U.S. citizenship in five years. Mr. Lennon's original residentalien application was rejected by an immigration judge because of his conviction in England in 1968 for possession of marijuana. Some Lennon supporters felt then that his antiVietnam war activities had prompted Government plans to deport him. But it was the same judge who ruled yesterday in Mr. Lennon's favor. The testimony of several prominent witnesses in Mr. Lennon's favor apparently made the difference. It's great to be legal again, said Mr.Lennon.

title: U.S.S.R. Drops Threat to Withdraw
description: MONTREAL, July 31The Soviet Union dropped plans to withdraw from the final two days of the Olympic Games today but again threatened to sever all sports ties with Canada unless the refugee status of a missing 17yearold Soviet athlete was resolved.

title: Street Fair on 72d Raises Funds to Aid Animal Liberation
description: West 72d Street went to the dogsand all other kinds of animals  yesterday, as the sevenyearold Animal Liberation Movement held a street fair to alert people to the desperate need of stray animals.

title: The Worst Intersections on the Island
description: IT would seem that the intersection has every traffic device known to man. There are hanging traffic lights, lefthand turn lanes, righthand turn signals, lefthand turn signals, stop signs, yield signs and four traffic islands. Yet the intersectionwhere Loring and North Bellmore Roads cross the Hempstead Turnpike was the scene of 43 accidents last year, making it the worst intersection in Nassau County.

title: Some Slick Ways of Handling the Worst Sea Polluter
description: MENTION pollution to the average Long Island bather these days and the mental image conjured up will most likely be one of several possible items that experts call a floatable.

title: The Church As Art Patron  Why It Doesn't Work
description: PHILADELPHIA As if a Bicentennial were not enough, Philadelphia is embarking on still another celebration. For the first week of August, the city will be host to the 41st Eucharistic Congress, which will present, among other events, an Exhibition of Liturgical Arts. The installation will contain more than 360 works by some 180 artists. Besides the usual liturgical objects and vestments, which comprise about twothirds of the show, there will be paintings, sculpture, drawings and printsmost of them contemporary and, surprisingly, 10 percent of them especially commissioned.

title: Building a Terrace: Part II
description: After the framework of redwood 2x4's has been assembled on the ground as described in last week's column on this page, the final step before mixing and pouring concrete into the open squares is to level the surface of the entire grid. For this a long straight board is used with a spirit level placed on top. The board is laid across the surface of the 2x4's to make certain the top edges of all are in line, and to see if the framework is level in both directions (unless a slight pitch of about 1 inch in 10 feet is desired to insure drainage).

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Even a OneEyed Referee Has 2020 Hindsight
description: In 1941, I was appointed a referee in the National Hockey League. Everybody on the board of governors knew I only had one eye but never said anything about it. I decided to ignore the matter, and everything moved smoothly until I crossed the Detroit Red Wines.

title: ARGENTINA SCORED ON ANTILEFT DRIVE
description: BUENOS AIRES. July 31Repression by Argentine security forces of leftwing subversives, involving many mysterious deaths and disappearances, is responsible for increasing friction between Argentina and foreign governments and international organizations.

title: Mary Keepnews to Wed
description: Mary Theresa Keepnews, daughter of Mrs. Lawrence W. Keepnews of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Keepnews, who was State Superintendent of Insurance, plans to be married to Declan Patrick Mansfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mansfield of White Plains. The bridetobe a senior at Smith College. Her fianc is entering his third year at Fordham University's Law School

title: Sunday Observer
description: First, everything had to have chlorophyll in it, then mint, then lemon, then herbal essence, and now everything from shampoos to swimmingpool cleaners has to have something called pH. Don't ask what pH is, and if you know, don't try to tell me. I'm too busy keeping up with life's changing necessities to have time for explanations.

title: In Memoriam
description: CANTORPeggy. Lovingly remembered'ELIZABETH and HARRY.

title: Against the Chorus, but for the Movement
description: Many young people in the last few years have started to accept a quite persuasive, but extremely dangerous, ideaone that many people in the right wing of this country dearly hope they will believe. This is the idea that something very special, once known as the Movement, is all over.

title: Vacancy at the F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON  If Wall Street can be said to dash off its gossip with gusto, it has nothing on the nation's capital. But on one juicy item, at least, Washingtonians will have to wait.

title: New England Nonfarm Jobs
description: BOSTON, July 31 (AP)There were 47,800 more nonfarm jobs in New England last month than in May for a total of 4,805,400 jobs, the United States Department of Labor reported. The department's Bureau of Labor Statistics here said nonfarm employment in the sixstate area has increased by 65,600 since June 1975.

title: E. 59th St. Farmers' Market Thrives
description: These are fantasticyou can't get beefsteak tomatoes like these at a supermarket, said Ruth Bergmann yesterday as she stood among the tomatoes, peaches, corn, cucumbers, plants and hundreds of people at the openair fruit and vegetable farmers' market that has been operating for the last three Saturdays on a lot across from the Roosevelt Island Tramway at 59th Street and Second Avenue. The market, known as Greenmarket, has attracted people from Park Avenue to Brooklyn. They come to squeeze the plums and taste the green apples, and they all seem happy about it., Some arrive at 7 A.M., before the farmers.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: L.I.R.R. TO SUSPEND SOME OPERATIONS
description: The Long Island Rail Road will temporarily suspend train service on its entire West Hempstead branch and portions of its Port Jefferson branch and main line next week for track renovation.

title: East German Wins the Marathon
description: Competition at the Montreal Olympics neared an end last night with an East German upsetting Frank Shorter of Boulder, Colo., in the marathon, a Polish high jumper taking the gold medal and John Walker of New Zealand winning the 1,500meter title. In boxing, five of the six Americans in finals won gold medals.

title: Adams Chronicles Spurring CollegebyTV
description: To a mother of seven children, the nice thing about taking a college course on primetime television is that the kids can come along to class in the living room. Ann Diehl of Lindenhurst, L.I., who is working toward a degree in business administration at the State University of New York in Farmingdale, found that to be an important dividend to the three credits she earned this past spring in Social Science 255.

title: Unveilings
description: DININDr. Alex. Memorial unveiling at Mount Judah Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y., on Aug. 8, 1976 at 12 noon on the grounds of Meyer Brotherhood. In case of rain, postponed until following Sunday.

title: Anniversaries
description: Gerard

title: T.J. Bonner Weds Priscilla J. Baer
description: Priscilla Jane Baer, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Baer of New York and Canadensis, Pa., and the late Mr. Baer, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas J. Bonner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Bonner of Philadelphia.

title: Personalities and politics
description: The opening has a familiar ring. After years in the field as a freelance. the narrator has repaired to a small college town, Instead of doing other people's work, he can finish a longpostponed project of his own. But that idyll is not to last. For there comes a can from The Family. Will he accept an assignment? There are requests you cannot refuse.

title: Bayi, Ill, Cancels Visit to Vancouver
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 31 (UPI)Filbert Bayi has canceled plans to race in Vancouver next week because of sickness it was announced today.

title: Preserving Brookhaven Town From Hunting
description: NOWHERE is the conflict of individual rights more evident than in the classic confrontation between hunter and nonhunter. The Brookhaven Town Board recently held a public hearing on a proposed ordinance regulating the hazardous discharge of firearms by hunters. In response to numerous requests from Brookhaven residents, civic associations and school groups, I introduced such legislation and presented it for a public hearing.

title: LAWOFSEA TALKS RESUMING AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31The slowsailing Law of the Sea Conference is to resume at United Nations headquarters Monday after a threemonth hiatus, with most delegates resigned to the belief that the new effort will also be inconclusive.

title: New House Panel on Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The House has created a special committee to coordinate the investigation of narcotics abuse and control now under way in seven House committees. The Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control would have no authority to draft legislation but would investigate drug trafficking and drug abuse.

title: Lebanese Rightists Block Palestinian Camp Rescue
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon July 31Extremist rightwing Christian commanders formally refused permission today for the Red Cross to enter the beleaguered Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar to evacuate the first of about 4,000 wounded civilians, most of them women and children.

title: ART VIEW
description: By an odd twist of fate, death came to two of our most illustrious photographers  Imogen Cunningham and Minor Whitealmost at the same time, but at opposite ends of the country, just over a month ago. Reading their obituariesprinted side by side, like entries in an encyclopedia, in The New York Times of June 26gave one a peculiar sensation. It was not only the sensation of loss, although that was certainly part of it, but also of pride and curiosity. What a lot of history is contained in these two careers, and what a lot remains to be learned about them! The socalled photography boom had arrived in time to elevate them to a new celebrity in the world beyond the photographic community that had long esteemed them, but not soon enough to give us a really comprehensive account of their work. With photographers, as with poets, there is a tendency to judge them by often reprinted anthology pieces. There is a tendency, too, to attribute consistency to a body of work that may contain a significant diversity, if not outright contradictions. We do better, I think, to begin with a recognition of their diversity.

title: Canadian Income Gap
description: OTTAWA, July 31 (UPI) The income gap between men and women in Canada increased in the period between 1970 and 1974, according to a Revenue Department survey. Incomes for men from 1970 to 1974 increased 68.9 percent compared with 62.2 percent for women. The average male income was $11,736 while the female average was $6,734.

title: Mr. Carter's Race should Take the Republicans' Measure
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.For Republicans in the South, 1976 promises to demonstrate just how much strength they have built after more than two decades of effort.

title: Creativity
description: At the outset of his long, carefully detailed and painfully earnest exploration of art and, to a lesser extent, scientific and philosophical discovery, Silvano Arieti takes account of a wellknown remark of Freud's: psychoanalysis can do nothing toward elucidating the nature of the artistic gift, nor can it explain the means by which the artist worksartistic technique. The disclaimer didn't prevent the master from continually prowling around the borders of the subject and making frequent sorties into its interior, nor does it appear to faze Arieti. Such professional doubts as he has steadily diminish in the course of the book, cropping up again only at a few points where mystery is simply too dense to penetrate: Unfortunately, the gap between appreciation of art and the psychology of esthetic pleasure is hard to fill.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Book publishing isn't such a gentlemanly business anymore. The pace of firings, hirings and musical chair playing has quickened at major houses which have, in rapid order, been merged wich or swallowed by Iarger publishing entities or by conglomerates.

title: Anne Butler Bride Of Carlos Baladron
description: Anne Margaret Butler of New York, a sales planner for Spain in the international department of Avon Products, was married yesterday to Carlos Vasquez Baladrn of Devon, Pa.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIt is not too early to contemplate the possibility of a significantthough not necessarily bitter clash between a future President Jimmy Carter and the Federal Reserve Board.

title: IOWA SMALL TOWNS GET BACK ON MAP
description: AMES, Iowa, July 31 CAP)Iowa's unincorporated towns have won a battle against the state. They are back on the map.

title: PEOPLE
description: JOINING the ranks of Marianne Moore, Carl Sandburg and Robert Frost as a winner of the Poetry Society of America's gold medal of achievement is A. M. Sullivan, who has homes in Montclair and Saxton Falls. Mr. Sullivan, who is 80 years old, says the Musconetcong, a winding tributary of the Delaware River that meanders through Warren County, has served as a lifelong inspiration to him. He marvels at it in one volume of his works entitled Songs of the Musconetcong, in which Mr. Sullivan observes:

title: Colts Defeat Browns As McCauley Stars
description: LINCOLN, Neb., July 31 (AP) Don McCauley rushed for two touchdowns and Howard Stevens scored on a 74yard punt return today as the Baltimore Colts gained a 210 victory over the Cleveland Browns in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: He talks big. But he delivers in the ring. He is Muhammad Ali, world heavyweight champion, and last year he made big promises to charity.

title: C. M. Norris Jr. And Gwen Parry Are Married
description: Gwen Parry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Malcolm Parry of Cos Cob, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Morgan Norris Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Norris of Philadelphia.

title: Giants:
description: The New York Giants don't know how good they are.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S a little early to tell yet, but the time may not be distant when a generation of comedians from east of the QueensNassau line will be doing routines about growing up on the Island, just as the graybeard comics recall their youth in Brooklyn or down on the farm.

title: Nuclear Estimate Down
description: VIENNA, July 31 (Reuters)Nuclear power will supply less than a third of the world's electricity at the end of the century, far less than had been expected, according to the Viermabased International Atomic Energy Agency. Nuclear plants now supply 5 percent of the world's electric power needs.

title: 5 Boxers For US. Hit Gold
description: MONTREAL, July 31Digging and blasting like prospectors who know exactly what they're doing, American boxers shook loose an avalanche of gold tonight in the Olympic finals at the Forum.

title: BRITONS FIND WAY TO BEAT AUSTERITY
description: LONDON, July 31Adversity in Britain, it is said, arouses a stoic facial posture, confined to upper lips, that expresses the country's determination to muddle through. But advertisity particularly personal economic adversity, also begets a creature that can greatly ease the muddling. It is known as the perk.

title: 7 Colombian Aliens Get 15 Years in Cocaine Case
description: Seven aliens from Colombia were each sentenced yesterday ??o 15 years in prison for copiracy to smuggle large amounts of cocaine into the United States from South Amer ica.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: The Region
description: New York City has gone to court to challenge a highly unusual inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the city's past fiscal practices, which have included overestimating tax revenues, borrowing in anticipation of receipts that purportedly never arrived and using bookkeeping gimmickry allegedly to disguise large deficits.

title: Brazilians Win Soccer Playoff
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 31Cruzeiro of Brazil, with a 32 victory over River Plate of Argentina in a playoff game last night, became the South American soccer club champion for 1976.

title: Two Democrats Vie in Missouri For Party Nomination to Senate
description: ST. LOUIS, July 31A milliondollar campaign by Representative Jerry Litton appears to have narrowed the wide lead once held by Representative James W . Symington in the race for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in Missouri's primary election Tuesday.

title: More Writers At Work
description: This is partly an act of reparation. A few years back, I wrote a somewhat lofty piece about the second collection of Paris Review interviews, suggesting that the information therein was neither better nor worse than Hollywood gossip. I was mortally sick by then of hearing about Hemingway's numbertwo pencils, and I felt they had about as much to do with literature as, say, whether Aldous Huxley slept in pajama tops or bottoms.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Education Department said it had filled all 175 additional monitor positions allotted to the federally financed Summer Food Service Program that provides two million meals, including 1.4 million lunches, a day to needy children in New York City. The monitors, added to a present force of 150, will be assigned to borough offices Tuesday to keep a closer check on the program in view of reported abuses at distribution sites, the department said. Contrary to reports that more applicants would be interviewed tomorrow, Harvey Rosenthal, the department's personnel director, said the new slots had been filled and no further applications are being considered.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: Science fiction visions of transportation are still very much in voguebut science fiction travel has reversed directions. Instead of going forward in time, it now goes backward.

title: Uproar Over Cockfight Ruffles Virginia Gentry
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 31A substitute police court judge here has ordered the trial of 11 Virginia gentlemen for engaging in an illegal cockfight, giving a new fillip to a summer diversion that has caused more uproar than the recent visit of Queen Elizabeth.

title: Few Jobs for Lawyers
description: HACKENSACK LATE last month 1,925 applicants, a record number, took the twoday New Jersey Bar Examination at three sites. If past performances hold, about 75 percent will be sworn in as lawyers next December.

title: AGREEMENT ENDS PLANE SLOWDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) An agreement was reached teday to end a slowdown by the country's air traffic controllers, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Taxation Without Rectification
description: THE Nassau County propertytax system is no worse and perhaps better than most in the state. As with all the systems, it is riddled with Inequities, of which the following from the latest survey by the State Board of Equalization, taken in 1973, are but a few:

title: Singlehanded Race Evokes Criticism
description: A race is over when all the boats are in. But apparently, the singlehanded transAtlantic race, which began unlike any other, will end that way, too. Although six boats had not arrived by week's end, the race officially was dedared over last Sunday in Newport, R. I., 50 days after 126 sailors left Plymouth, England. Those still at sea include three British yachts that neither have been sighted nor contacted by radio since the start.

title: 10 Quarter Horses In $368,784 Race
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS. N. M., July 31 (AP)  The second leg of quarter horse racing's. triple crown will be run toMorrow at Ruidoso Downs without the winner of the first of the three bigmoney races for 2yearolds.

title: Haughton Entry 1, 2 In Trot
description: YONKERS, July 31Steve Lobell, the heavy favorite in offtrack wagering, was an upset winner of the $200,204 Yonkers Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The. event was the first leg of the triple crown for 3yearold trotters. The other legs are the Hambletonian Sept. 4 and the Kentucky Futurity Oct. 8.

title: Tomato Taste Study Begun
description: DAVIS, Calif., July 31 (UPI) California growers are spending $60,000 to find out why storebought tomatoes do not seem to taste as good as those grown in backyard gardens.

title: Birds Do It, Cats Do It, Let's Play a Game
description: It was Sunday afternoon. Mankind was at play with its endless variety of rules and games. On the terrace a simpler game was at hand and it was a blood snort.

title: Science/Education
description: If the Viking lender, now incubating a number of Martian soil samples, produces evidence that life existsor has existedthere, it will be a turning point in man's understanding of his place in the universe. It will mean that life is not unique to the earth: having arisen on so seemingly hostile a planet as Mars, it must permeate the cosmos.

title: Preseason Football
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Running Clinic Set
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio. July 31 (UPI)Youngstown State University will hold a crosscountry running clinic featuring two distance runnersDave Wottle, a 1972. Olympic goldmedal winner and Tom FlemingAug. 17 in Beeghly Center.

title: Design
description: Nhumy and Adolph Leuthold, who are both avid gardeners, have one the more unusual rooftop gardens in Manhattan. It surrounds their sixroom penthouse apartment, and on it the couple cultivate a range of plantings, from kitchen herbs to camellias, orchids and flowering fruit trees. When the Leutholds Adolph, a Swissborn textile executive, and his Vietnameseborn wife, Nhumy, a fashion designerwere searching for a coop two years ago, they decided that a place to garden was more important than the layout of the rooms. We were looking for a country cottage in the sky, Mi. Leuthold says. The apartment they bought was ideal for them, although the 750 square feet of terrace was barren of plantings and the interior spaces hadn't been touched since the 1930's. For their garden, the couple trucked down from a Connecticut nursery new bricks and dirt for planting beds. They purchased weathered barn siding and beams to build not only the arbors but also a tool shed and an outdoor room equipped with both a bar and a hibachi. They also installed a separate greenhouse, where they grow orchids. The apartment's interiors needed patching and plastering more than major renovation. The Leutholds did create a new kitchen out two small maid's rooms. The completed interiors are a synthesis of many cultures. Spanish antique furniture mingles with Early American rockers and hooked rues. Victorian settees, French side chairs and Oriental porcelains and art works.

title: The intriguing matter of Mao's successor
description: Some time last year, Chairman Mao Tsetung wrote this poem to his comrade of many years, Prime Minister Chou Enlai. Chou died in January. Last month, a Chinese spokesman indicated in typical elliptical fashion that Mao himself is so enfeebled the Chinese people may never see him alive again. More precisely, the spokesman said that Mao's age is so advancedhe is 82that he would no longer meet visiting foreign leaders. But unless something extraordinary happens, that amounts to the same thing. For over the past five years, since Mao last appeared in public in 1971, the Chinese people have seen him only in photographs or television pictures taken during his talks with foreigners.

title: Montreal Landmark Burns
description: MONTREAL, July 31 (UPI)A fire gutted the famous bell tower of the historic Bon Secour Market in Old Montreal last night. Firemen said damage to the tower of the building, one of this Olympic city's best known landmarks, was extensive but that there were no injuries. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

title: Jets Bow, 1312; Suffer Injuries
description: ST. LOUIS, July 31The New York Jets returned to the football field tonight after their sorriest season. But the way they played against the Cardinals, losing by 1312 in a preseason game, it appeared that they had wiped the had memories.

title: A Young Pollster Plays Key Role for Carter
description: PLAINS, GA., July 31One day in early June when Jimmy Carter had tied up the Democratic Presidential nomination six weeks before the party's convention, his campaign manager, Hamilton Jordan, and his television and advertising consultant, Jerald Rafshoon, were giddy with pleasure and the taste of success.

title: Soviet Defense Minister Is Promoted to Marshal
description: MOSCOW, July 31 (AP) Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov has been promoted from general to marshal, the highest rank in the Soviet armed forces.

title: EMILY HRUBY WALL
description: Emily Hruby Wall, who taught for 46 years at Public Schools 21 and 130 in Manhattan, died last Tuesday at her home in Sudbury, Mass. Her age was 87.

title: Eileen Greene Married
description: Eileen Greene, daughter of Mrs. John R. FitzHugh of New Orleans and Thurston Green of Millbrook, N.Y. was married yesterday morning to Chester Alan Stentiford son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Stentiford of Saugus, Mass. The Rev. Charles White performed the Congregational ceremony in the Park Street Church in Boston.

title: Angolan Leader's Visit Gratifies Cuba as Happy Conclusion of War Intervention
description: HAVANA, July 31 (Reuters) The chant of Cuba, Angola United Will Overcome that greeted President Agostinho Neto of Angola on his visit here is likely to echo for a long time in Cuba.

title: Notes: Hotels Assail College Innkeepers
description: America's hoteliers and restaurateurs are upset about the growing number of colleges and universities across the country that are opening their idle dormitories and cafeterias to transient summer tourists. They claim that those taxexempt nonprofit institutions are guilty of unfair competition and demand that they put an end to the practice.

title: King Richard Petty Reigns Supreme With His Followers at Pocono Track
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 31 Like good wine, the charisma of Richard Petty travels well. Yankees tend to think that King. Richard, as he is affectionately known, reigns ony In Dixie, but a couple of hundred of his subjects proved otherwise this afternoon by milling around in the bot sun of Pennsylvania to have a little party for him.

title: FISHING
description: THE signs and portents are there: The full moon is creating extra strong tides and bait fish are being chased inshore. The only thing missing is the solid summer run of bluefish.

title: For young readers
description: These two books touch on the high and the low of the topography of the American West. Much of Death Valley lies below sea level while Mount Whitney, only about 50 miles to the west in the Sierra Nevada range, is the highest point in the original 48 United States. The juxtaposition might seem, in itself, merely a geographical oddity; but in reality the fact becomes mystery and grandeur. Having hiked a few Sierran trails myself, and made an Easter pilgrimage to the summit of Whitney (We done it for Jesus wrote someone on the rocks), and having once spent an entire winter in Death Valley, I had opportunity to sample both places, and did, and I tasted their qualities. In these two small books very little of that grandeur and mystery come across.

title: Doc Watson Plays Country With Son At the Bottom Line
description: Doc Watson and his son Merle do not seem to have changed much over the last few years, and neither has their music, which the elder Mr. Watson describes as country pickin. But the Watsons' eclectic approach to traditional guitar and banjo music still seems to he much in demand here. They packed the Bottom Line for their first show on Thursday evening;

title: Authorities Narrow the Motive in Kidnapping to Cash Ransom
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (UPI)The authorities said today that a cash ransom was the apparent motive in the kidnapping of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver in Chowchilla, Calif., on July 15.

title: Union Official Calls Hospitals Wasteful
description: A hospital workers' union spokesman said yesterday that rather than lay off employees, the Health and Hospitals Corporation should seek economies in what he asserted was the wasteful and inefficient affiliation program under which municipal hospitals buy physicians' services from either medical colleges or voluntary hospitals.

title: From 2 Percent of the Vote to 30 Percent in 10 Years
description: LONDONThe world knows very well that Great Britain is no longer great; it may soon learn that the United Kingdom is no longer united. Snorts of dissatisfaction from the country's geographical fringes have long been as noisy and querulous as those from the political fringes, but they have never been taken very seriously in a highly centralized state whose political life has been dominated by the twoparty system, at Westminster. Now all that has chanced. The defection from the Labor Party last week of two Scottish Members of Parliament brings the total number of parliamentary parties to nine. Nationalism has become the most potent force in British politics.

title: Disagreements May Be More Real Than Apparent
description: WASHINGTONIt has become fashionable in diplomatic and press circles to say that if Jimmy Carter were elected President, the main lines of his foreign policy would be about the same as that followed by President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. But if Mr. Carter's acts as President were to match his words as a candidate, the changes in policy as well as a style could be farreaching.

title: Subway Train Severs Legs Of Man Pushed Onto Tracks
description: A 50yearold recently arrived man from Guatemala who lost both legs after he was mugged and robbed Friday and then thrown before an oncoming subway train was reported in fair condition yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Patricia A. McSweeney Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. McSweeney of Suffern, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Anne, to Thomas Gerry Gallatin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gallatin of Manhasset T. T and Stuart. Fla.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater 3, 14

title: HARRISES' HEARING IS TOLD OF NOOSE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31A witness testifying at an extraordinary hearing on possible judicial and juror misconduct at the trial of William and Emily Harris testifed today that several jurors now deliberating a verdict witnessed a former prospective juror construct a hangman's noose in a central jury room weeks ago.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE NATION'S BALANCE OF TRADE showed a deficit of $377.3 million in June in contrast with a $395.6 million surplus in May. Oil imports jumped 34 percent in the month... Most major banks cut their prime rate from 7 percent to 7 percent.. The nation's mony supplycurrency in circulation plus checking account balancesrose by $900 million in the latest week to an average of $305.4 billion... The budget deficit for fiscal 1976 was the Treasury Department and Office of Management and $65.6 billion, or $10.4 billion below earlier estimates, says Budget.

title: There Was Once Money. Wasn't There?
description: The largely unheralded development of Electronic Funds Transfer Systems is moving a creditcardconditioned society toward a completely cashless environment; with severe repercussions for the American consumer.

title: And They're Off To Saratoga Again
Virginia Goett to Wed
description: The engagement of Virginia Mary Goett, daughter of Mr. an Mrs. Edward Goett 3d of Franklin Lakes, N.J., to Glenn J. DeSimone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. DeSimone of Bay Head, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A wedding in December is planned.

title: DATA ARE DISPUTED IN WIRETAP INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, accused the Justice Department today of giving either Congress or a judge incorrect information about the number of warrantless wiretaps conducted by the Government.

title: Why Do I Go Through The Torture of New York?
description: In the days of vaudeville, old troupers used to say, Any place outside of New York is Bridgeport. And today, the big city still carries that importance. It is the proving ground, the only place that counts in terms of making a reputation. But if the potential rewards are still great the costs are excruciatingly highso high as to prompt me to wonder if my returning to New York this week is a sign of masochism, stupidity, or the result of some vague illusion.

title: INVESTING
description: A ripple of speculative enthusiasm in the new issues market and the efforts of financially strapped conglomerates to raise capital by selling off subsidiaries is stirring new interest on Wall Street in buy outsthe private purchase and repackaging of companies whose owners for one reason or another want out.

title: It's Onward and Uptown For Hebrew Publishing
description: The Hebrew Publishing Company has been going strongalso sometimes weak for 75 years. Come fall it will leave its native Lower East Side and move uptown, leaving behind its architectural mishmash ht the corner of Delancey and Allen Streets.

title: Thomas Farrell Weds Dr. M. F. Healey
description: Dr. Maryanne Frances Healey, daughter of Mrs. Joseph M. Healey of Kearny, N.J., and the late Mr. Healey, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Frencis Farrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Farrell of East Orange. N.J.

title: Jersey CarBus Crash Kills Pregnant Woman, Injures 18
description: POMONA, July 31 (UPI)A pregnant woman was killed and 18 persons aboard a Philadelphia church bus were injured today in a carbus Collision at a foggy Galloway Township intersection, the police reported.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Initial signals from the biology experiment package on the Viking lander have indicated that microscopic life forms could exist on Mars. Jet Propulsion Laboratory scientists in Pasadena, Calif., said the indications could be due to nonbiological causes, but that a biological origin could not be ruled out.

title: POLITICS
description: AGROWING number of political leaders are unhappy with the state's primary election law, and foremost among them are President Ford and Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nomine??

title: Looking Back at Hiroshima Makes Uneasy Viewing
description: On August 31, 1946, The New Yorker devoted its entire issue to a booklength article by John Hersey in which he interviewed half a dozen survivors of our atomic attack on Hiroshima. If the article moved many readers, it displeased some, especially two of the most articulate literary intellectuals of the postwar period. Editorializing in his journal Politics, Dwight Macdonald said in October: The little people of Hiroshima whose sufferings Hersey records in antiseptic New Yorker prose might just as well be white mice, for all the pity, horror or indignation the readeror at least this readeris made to feel for them. ... Perhaps my feeling is simply that naturalism is no longer adequate, either esthetically or morally, to cope with the modern horrors.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Beauty and 6 Beholders
description: LAURA RILEY, who used to write for the Ladies' Home Journal, is now a freelance nature photographer and writer. Her credits include National Wildlife, Woman's Day and Sail magazine, and several exhibits. She lives with her husband, Bill, on an old farm in Hunterdon county, which the couple have turned into a wildlife sanctuary with discreet hiding places for photographing the activities of birds and animals.

title: Portland Gets Series
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 31 (AP) Portland has been chosen as the permanent site for the World Series of two girls divisions of Little League Baseball, Inc. Portland will be host to the girls softball in the 9 to 12 and 13 to 15 age groups. The games will be played Aug. 16 to 21.

title: J. F. Duffy Weds Miss Chamberlain
description: The marriage of Ellen Melissa Chamberlain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Fitzhugh Chamberlain of Chester, N.Y., to James F. Duffy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh B. Duffy of DeBary, Fla., took place yesterday afternoon in Goshen, N.Y.

title: Endpaper
description: Being a sampling of authentic communicationsserious, antic and mysterious  received by science news director John Noble Wilford during this summer's Academy of Applied Science/New York Times Loch Ness Expedition.

title: Patricia A. Banner To Wed in October
description: Patricia Ann Banner and Paul Lawrence Bindler, 1973 graduates of the University of Wisconsin, will be married Oct. 30.

title: Alison J. Smith Becomes Bride
description: The Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Alison Jeanne Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Smith of Roselle, N.J., to Pierre de Maret, son of Mrs. Henri de Sitter of Paris, and Daniel de Maret of Ottawa.

title: Ocean Liner Passengers Acquire Taste for Wine
description: Wine and water, as a rule, do not mix, except on ocean pleasure cruises, where appreciation of wine is a growing factor in enjoying life in the grand manner. One authority on this development is Douglas MacNeill, the leading wine steward aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth 2.

title: CHESS
description: BIEL, Switzerland  Kenneth Rogoff, my fellow United States representative at the Interzonal Tournament here, remarked after his stunning defeat of Grandmaster Jan Smejkal of Czechoslovakia, one of the pretourney favorites, If you want to do well in a tough competition such as this one, you have got to win your fighting games.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: In Defense Of Asparagus

title: ART
description: SOUTHAMPTON

title: JUDGE ENTERS PLEA FOR SOVIET AIRLINE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn has entered a plea of not guilty for Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, which has been charged with violating Federal laws by discounting tickets for flights between Paris and Washington.

title: Deaths
description: ARONSTEIN  Irving. Beloved husband of Anita and adored father of Debra, brother of Abbott and sister Wien Troltman. Funeral services Sunday, Aug. 1, 10 A.M., from Gariick's Funeral Home in Yonkers.

title: Public Open Spaces Aren't
description: On a quiet stretch of 52d Street near First Avenue stands one of Manhattan's more charming oases of greenery, a minipark at the foot of a 34story luxury apartment tower. Garden chairs and benches are placed on the grass and a cedar trellis provides shade when the sunlight is strong; at night at the area is well lighted.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GINSBERGDaniel. The family of Daniel Ginsberg sincerely thank their friends and relatives for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: Amid the Strife Emerge the Heroes and Heroines
description: MONTREAL, July 31They cost $1.5 billion to stage, they were opened by the Queen of Britain, they were saluted by Pope Paul VI and Leonid Brezhnev, they were attended by 9,000 athletes and 2.5 million spectators, they were abandoned by 30 countries and they were captivated by a 14yearold Rumanian girl who earned three gold medals and seven perfect scores.

title: October Bridal Being Planned By Priscilla Hill
description: Priscilla Baker Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Serge Jerome Hill of Bridgehampton, L.I., and DeWitt Loomis Alexandre Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexandre of Far Hills, N.J., plan to be married in October.

title: Programs Have Been Dropped or Reduced in Many Districts
description: Summer no longer necessarily brings summer school, In response to rising costs and inflation, unceasing demand for new school services and the steady depletion financial and tax resources with which to pay for them, more and more school districts in the metropolitan area have cut down on or eliminated their summer programs.

title: Corporate Moves: More Means Less
description: WHEN Philip and Mary Lefaivre moved to New Jersey from St. Louis in March so he could work in McGrawHill's corporate headquarters in New York City, they hoped the 20 percent raise that came with the move would give them a few more luxuries and a more satisfying way of life.

title: Nationalism Is Name of the Game at Olympics
description: MONTREAL , July 31As the curtain drops on the Games of the XXI Olympiad, this image emerges: Remove nationalism from the Olympics and there can be no Olympics. Let the purists moralize and the editorial writers agonize, but the sad fact isfor better or for worse  nationalism is what the Olympics are all about.

title: Serenity
description: Out where time sets its own pace, a kind of sweet serenity now possesses the land. The early rush for a place in the sun is over. The trend now is toward maturity. Grapes fatten on the vine. Early apples begin to blush. Wild blackberries ripen.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Jean Smithers Wed To Gary Williams
description: Jean Smithers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Sydney Smithers of Red Hook, N.Y., and Gary T. Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Williams of Groton, Conn., were married yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of the Holy Innocents at Bard College in AnnandaleonHudson, N.Y. The Rev. Frederick Q. Shafer officiated.

title: John Madison Camp 3d Weds Carolyn A. Threshie in Suburb
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carolyn Archer Threshie to John Madison Camp 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Camp Jr. of Franklin, Va. The Rev. Samuel E. Walker performed the ceremony.

title: Who Will Play Rhett and Scarlett In GWTW, Continued?
description: Los ANGELES Yes, of course, Hollywood has always been glad to follow a big success with a sequel, and the industry is currently awash in movies with Roman numerals in their titles, from Exorcist II to Jaws II. Yet the news of a sequel to Gone With the Wind still comes as a shock.

title: FILM VIEW
description: There haven't been so many pirate movies in recent years that one can easily dismiss as ersatz a film like James Goldstone's wellmeaning Swashbuckler, which stars Robert Shaw as an 18thcentury Caribbean pirate named Ned Lynch and features as his flagship an exquisite reproduction of Sir Francis Drake's Golden Hind, the vessel which Drake sailed around the world. The decline and fall into nearextinction of the oldfashioned adventure film is probably inevitable with the increasing sophistication of children who would prefer to see The Towering Inferno, Earthquake and Young Frankenstein to most of the children's films being turned out these days by the Walt Disney organization and others.

title: Mailbox: The Price of Olympic Glory Doesn't Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: The seats of my dinette chairs are covered with an orange colored vinyl material. Two of the chairs have marks that were made by a black ball point pen. I have tried several cleaners, but the marks are still there. Can you recommend anything that will take them out without removing the orange color?J.S., Riverdale, N. Y.

title: The Grasp of Consciousness
description: Jean Piaget, the renowned student of human growth who celebrates his 80th birthday on Aug. 9. has himself undergone a most unusual personal and scientific development. A child prodigy who published his first research paper at age 11, Piaget has realized a scientific career of unsurpassed fecundity. He has risked a number of sharp career shifts, turning to psychology only after receiving his doctorate in biology, later, in middle age, training himself in logic and physics. Internationally honored in his early 30's for his pathbreaking studies of children, he was for many years regarded as an anachronism, and only recently has regained a dominant position in the social sciences. Indeed, unlike most scientists. whose seminal contributions occur early, Piaget has made some of his most important discoyeries in recent decades, and astoundingly his feverish pace continues unabated. By his own example, this proud Swiss has confinned his country's capacity to spawn treative scientists as well as competent clockmakers.

title: The German Conquest
description: PARISOne of the most significant recent developments in Western Europe has been the agreement between British trade unions and the British Government to extend the socalled social contract between labor and employers for three more years, thus avoiding new strike waves and consequent new inflation.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Here's a little bit of a switch. Instead of a novel about the tensions between Jew and Arab, a subject in the literature of crime that has assumed the proportions of a minor industry, we have one about the tensions between Greek and Turk. The book is WITH EXTREME PREJUDICE by Berkely Mather (Scribner's. $8.95).

title: Bankers Get Nasty With Thugs
description: LOS ANGELESTwo bandits strolled into the PicoBronson branch of the Crocker National Bank here recently, flashed a gun, took $704 from a teller, and calmly walked out.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Dwight Stones, United States Olympic high jumper, earlier in the week said: In Las Vegas odds, I figure I would be about 109 to win. You could go broke betting against me. He finished third.

title: JACK FENKO, 54; PHOTO PROCESSOR
description: Jack Fenko, a leading photo processor who specialized in color printing, died last Tuesday, apparently of a heart ailment, at the New York University Medical Center. He was 54 years old and lived at 1450 Second Avenue.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Everyone Else Does It More Poorly, Says the First Tevye
description: With Zero Mostel once again pulling his weathered milkcart, Fiddler on the Roof is returning from its diaspora. Sixteen years after opening in New York, and four years after closing, the legendary musical is on its way home.

title: Elaine Mosheim to Wed
description: Elaine Ruth Mosheim, a special education teacher for the Summit (N.J.) schools, and Charles Vincent Gianola of Ridgefield Park, N.J., who teaches in Teaneck, N.J., plan to be married at the end of November. Their engagement was announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Mosheim of Syosset, L.I., parents of the brideto be. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Giancola of Hicksville. L.I.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The nation's death rate has declined to its lowest point ever, the Government reported today.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: For those who live in small apartments or homes which do not have the room for a regular darkroom, and for those who cannot spare the time to process prints in the usual manner, the stabilization method offers an ideal solution to the problem of making black  and  white prints at home.

title: Maybe It's Time to Break Up the Olympics
description: After Moscow in 1980, what? asks our Olympics worrying team. No one country can afford to hold the Games.

title: Dry Community Finds Well
description: STINSON BEACH, Calif., July 31 (UPI)Drillers have discovered a desperately needed reservoir of water at Stinson Beach State Park. The waterparched seaside community, where many homeowners have already run out of water, was told yesterday that the emergency well could provide 70,000 gallons of fresh water a day.

title: LETTER TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Alternatives to The Sewer Plan

title: The World
description: Kakuei Tanaka, who as Prime Minister of Japan was the influential political leader of the second largest economic power in the nonCommunist world, has been arrested and jailed for an alleged role in the international Lockheed bribery scandal.

title: Miss Tagle Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Walter Blakeley Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Brookline, Mass., announced the engagement of Mrs. Blakeley's daughter, Jacqueline Tagle, to Robert Grier Ralston, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Grier Ralston Jr. of Wilmington, Del. Miss Tagle is the daughter of the late Emilio Tagle.

title: Red Smith
description: Fields of Friendly StrifeMONTREAL, July 31The Gaines of the XXI Olympiad end tomorrow, and notra moment too soon. Another day or so of camaraderie and good will on the fields of friendly strife and somebody would wind up with a knife between his ribs. Up to now, this sweaty carnival has run smooth as the course of true love, if you don't count the angry withdrawal of 30 nations, cheating disqualifications, rumors of attempted bribery, political and ideological clashes. threats, bluffs, defections, charges of kidnapping and the use of forbidden steroids.

title: Food
description: There is scarcely an Italian restaurant in Manhattan, or in the rest of the country, for that matter, that does not list stuffed clams as a specialty among its appetizers. Most of those clams are banal, chewy and clumsily seasoned, predominant flavor being that of oregano. The best Italianstyle stuffed clams we've ever dined on anywhere are those of Luigi Nanni, a friend and the chefowner of Nanni's Restaurant, 146 East 46th Street, and II Valletto, 133 East 61st Street, in Manhattan. We recently spent some time cooking with Mr. Nanni in a kitchen in a private home in Nova Scotia. He made his stuffed clams and several other fish and seafood specialties. We dutifully recorded his ingredients, and on this page are the results: the clams, a soup made with clams, a fish soup, a dish of squid in white wine, and fried eels.

title: Characters With Knotty Problems to Solve
Miss Spenker Plans to Marry
description: Charlotte Joan Spenker and David Edwin Ball plan to be married in early September. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Spenker of Riverside, Conn.

title: Reagan to Schweiker to Ford
description: The extremely able, extremely aggressive andin many eyesextremely opportunistic former Governor of Texas last week endorsed Mr. Ford for the Presidency after lurking in the Republican shadows for many months in the apparent hope of emerging as a cornpromise candidate acceptable to both Ford and Reagan forces at Kansas City.

title: Rudolf Bultmann, 91, Dies; Was a German Theologian
description: MARBURG, West Germany, July 31 (AP)  Rudolf Karl Bultmann, the Protestant theologian and teacher, died here at the age of 91 yesterday, the dean of the theological faculty at Marburg University announced today.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE Great Swamp, like a great cathedral, imposes an immediate sense of hush. At the entrance, a little booth, which looked as though it should house an attendant, was empty. There was not a soul in sight. Just a great silence.

title: Taino Towers's Problems Laid to U.S.
description: A Congressional leader blames longterm mismanagement by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development for the critical problems threatening a suspended $45 million housing land communitydevelopment project in East Harlem.

title: NEW QUAKE ALERT ISSUED BY PEKING
description: PEKING, July 31 (Reuters)More warnings that another earthquake could strike were issued today to Peking's six million people, who have been camped in the city's streets since early Wednesday.

title: U.S. JUDGE HOLDS UP CUT IN FOOD STAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) A Federal district judge has refused to lift his preliminary injunction blocking the Ford Administration's new regulations for the food stainp program.

description: AT JAMESTOWN, R.I.

title: U.S. SAYS JORDAN BARS SOVIET ARMS FOR AIR DEFENSES
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Jordan has decided against turning to the Soviet Union for arms and is reported close to buying a $540 million airdefense system from the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Betty Quevedo Married
description: Mary Elizabeth Quevedo, known as Betty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Brady Quevedo of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Douglas John Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Hiller of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Book Ends
description: Canadian sunset. The announcement that Simon & Schuster had sold its Canadian paperback subsidiary, Simon & Schuster Canada Ltd., to General Publishing of Don Mill, Ont., apparently signals a further decline in this country's publishing empire to the north. Already, Time magazine has halted publication of its Canadian edition, in response to pressure from the colonials, and another American paperback firm with a Canadian subsidiary is finding itself under the gun.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: TV VIEW
description: An elderly man in Liverpool, England, recalls the thousands of ragged travellers as one step removed from animals. Another describes the 18day sea journey in steerage holds as something of a religious quest designed to test our worthiness of the Promised Land. Several men and women tell of their feelings of apprehension upon arrival, when anything from eye cataracts to being an anarchist could bar final entry. John F. Kennedy, a member of the most successful immigrant family of them all, is seen visiting a wildly delighted and charmed Ireland as President of the United States.

title: DINING OUT
description: WHAT is attractive about the Aston is the place itself, a charming old building, parts of which date back to 1780; the service, which is friendly and efficient, and the location, which is in the country but still close to big shopping centers and to the suburbs of western Essex and eastern Morris Counties.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: LENIENCY DECRIED IN BUSINESS CRIME
description: Strong disapproval of lenient sentences for white  collar criminals has been voiced by a top Federal prosecutor, who said that substantial prison terms could deter businessmen from committing crimes.

title: Robert Wilson's FiveHour Operatic Dream
description: AVIGNON Einstein on the Beach, which received its first triumphant performances this past week at the Theatre Municipal as part of the Avignon Festival, is both similar to and different from Robert Wilson's past theatrical creations. The main difference is that unlike Mr. Wilson's previous socalled operas, Einstein has a continuous, fivehour score by a composer of stature, Philip Glass.

title: Dorothy D. Giannone Wed in Westport
description: Dorothy Donnelly Giannone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Giannone of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Michael Mellquist of New York. He is a son of Mrs. James Waterman of Tacoma, Wash., and the late John C. Mellquist.

title: Adult Education Gets a C
description: THE educational opportunities available to Long Island adults, a mlange of programs offered by 560 separate institutions, are not reaching their potential because of a failure to coordinate the efforts and to provide the special counseling and services needed by adult students, according to a recently completed study.

title: Antitrust Lives...
description: Antitrust, said the late Prof. Richard Hofstadter of Columbia University, is one of the faded passions of American reform. Faded it may be, yet it never fades away. For, despite the disillusion of many liberal reformers and the disgruntlement of some conservatives, strong underlying forces keep antitrust alive as an essential element in the American polity and economy.

title: Loyer Ager Married To Charles C. Osbun
description: St. Mary'sontheHighlands Episcopal Church in Birmingham, Ala., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Loyer Lawton Ager, daughter of Dr. Law Lamar Ager of Birmingham and the late Mrs. Ager, to Charles Clapp Osbun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Mather Osbun of Centreville, Del.

title: CHARLES BRENNAND
description: SEATTLE, July 31 (UPI)The cellist Charles Brennand, member of the Philadelphia String Quartet, died of a heart attack Thursday while on a camping trip with his family on Vancouver Island in Canada. He was about 47 years old.

Dr. Eugene V. N. Goetchius of the Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge, Mass., performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: Manila Reviews Detentions With View to Partial Release
description: MANILA, July 31The martiallaw government is reviewing the records of its 4,600 detainees in preparation for granting temporary release to all but those accused of serious crimes, Under Secretary of Defense Carmelo Barbero has announced.

title: Humphrey Would Sell Nutrition by Billboard
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)Perhaps the Government should sell nutrition the way Burma Shave used to sell shaving soap, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, says.

title: HOUSE FORUM SET ON ACADEMY CODE
description: Sixteen members of the House of Representatives will bold an informal hearing Wednesday to explore what one of them said yesterday was the cadets' side of the West Point cheating scandal.

title: SCHOOLS ACCUSED ON CONTRACT BIDS
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, accused the Board of Education yesterday of ignoring, or circumventing, competitive bid requirements over the last 12 years to award $6.4 million in citywide school test contracts to Harcourt, Brace Jovanovich Inc., a leading publisher.

title: Pamela Hayling Wed to J. I. Hoffman
description: Pamela Louise Hayling, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Hayling of South Grange, N.J., and Oak Bluffs, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Joseph Irvine Hoffman Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hoffman of Charleston, S.C.The ceremony was performed in the garden of the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Leslie A. Hayling of East Chop on Martha's Vineyard, by Representative Andrew Young, Democrat of Georgia, who is also a Baptist minister.

title: Of Things To Come
description: To appreciate Frank Herbert's achievement in the Dune trilogy, which concludes with CHILDREN OF DUNE (Berkley/ Putnam, $8.95) you have to be a devotee of obsession. On the surface, the Dune books offer an unlikely combination of oldfashioned space opera, uptodate ecological concern and breathtakingly ecumenical religiosity. The space opera elements include a decaying galactic empire, heroes and villains of nearly superhuman power, and truly formidable monsters. The ecology centers around the planet Dune, which is one vast desert, yet which supports a population of remarkably disciplined human beings known as Fremen.

title: Gimcrack Blooms Amid the Smokies
description: More than eight million peoplehiking, camping or rumbling through the woods in lumbering motor homeslast year made the Great Smoky Mountains National Park the most visited park in the nation. At one time, until the late 1950's, the visitor could count on a minimum of commercialism outside the park. The people who lived in the valleys minded their own business, and the few hotels were simple and small. Back then the typical tourist attraction was a souvenir stand with a caged (and usually smelly) bear out back.

title: Doctor Warns of Effects From Some Herb Products
description: CHICAGO. Aug. 1 (UPI)Herbal cigarettes, teas and capsules may cause unpleasant mental and physical reactions, according to a report in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: U.S. Is Reported Preparing Proposal for Arms Talks
description: The negotiations on limitation of strategic arms, stalled since the last set of Soviet proposals in January, are moving again, Newsweek magazine reports in its current issue.

title: Realty Tax Lottery
description: A court decision that could compel Nassau County to pay up to $120 million in refunds to commercial property owners who have been overtaxed should help persuade local officials throughout the state that property tax reform is an action they no longer can afford to put off.

title: Coast Power Cutoffs Likely
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 (UPI)The Pacific Gas & Electric Company said today that sequential curtailments of power were very much a possibility in northern California in the next few months because of severe drought. A spokesman said the curtailments, involving entire neighborhoods, would last for at least one hour each day. The state's Public Utilities Commission authorized such blackouts on July 7.

title: Thousands View the Opening of Eucharistic Congress
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (Reuters)One of the largest religious gatherings ever held in the United States began here today with solemn services, ceremonial processions and the first of eight days of studies on hunger in the world.

title: SENATE DISCLOSES VIETNAM TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk, who helped make policy during the Vietnam War in the 1960's, told Congress in 1950 the Indochina War was is nationalist dispute, perhaps more of a political problem than a military problem, Senate records disclosed today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne has accepted a spot on Jimmy Carter's national campaign steering committee despite his earlier announcement that he would not accept the post. The position was offered to Mr. Byrne by Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. The Governor had rejected the idea last Wednesday, when James P. Dugan, New Jersey Democratic chairman, issued a press release suggesting that the Governor be appointed to the committee.

title: Syrian Premier Replaced By a Favorite of the Army
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 1President Hafez alAssad of Syria today abruptly accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Mahmoud alAvubi and named a retired general and close personal friend to succeed him.

title: 49 U. S. CITIZENS AND DEPENDENTS FLY FROM SAIGON
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 1  Fortynine United States citizens and dependents of Americansvirtually the last in Vietnamwere allowed today to fly from Saigon to Bangkok, ending more than a year of uncertainty about their fate.

title: 65 Killed as Rains Flood Colorado Recreation Area
description: LOVELAND, Colo., Aug. 1Tragedy marred Colorado's centennial celebration of statehood today as a flash flood along the Big Thompson Canyon 50 miles north of Denver took at least 65 lives.

title: 4 Are Feared Killed in Collapse of a Bridge Over Danube in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Vienna's 40yearold Reichsbrcke, a highway bridge spanning the Danube in the center of the Austrian capital, collapsed early today sweeping four people apparently their deaths and blocking river traffic on one of Europe's main waterways.

title: Screen: 'Obsession':Mystery Film by Brian De Palma at Coronet
description: For slightly more than half its running time, "Obsession" is an entertaining, romantic suspense film of slightly less than transcendental style, a movie conceived (but not executed) in the Hitchcock manner, scored by late Bernard Hermann with what sounds to be enough music to fill an average-sized cathedral and three movies.Brian De Palma, the director, and Paul Schrader, the writer, have made a mistake, I suspect, in allowing "Obsession" to be identified as an hommage to Hitchcock. It puts a needless strain upon them, and upon us, who thus come to expect something more complex, more terse and more stylish than the film they've made. To be blunt, "Obsession" is no "Vertigo," Hitchcock's witty, sardonic study of obsession that did transcend its material, which wasn't all that bad to start with.The Schrader screenplay, based on an original story by Mr. Schrader and Mr. De Palma, is most effective when it's most romantic, and transparent when it attempts to be mysterious. Constructing a satisfying mystery is like trying to make up a crossword puzzle that works in three dimensions. One little point doesn't work and the whole thing has to be done over.Hitchcock's plot aren't always that perfect, but when they aren't he's perceptive enough to know it, and magician enough to distract our attention in a way that is even more satisfying than the identification of logic.The plot of "Obsession" is such that you'll probably have figured out the mystery very early. No amount of subsequent red herrings can build up one's interest to its original peak. Instead of rising, it goes gently downhill to its climax.The film, which opened yesterday at the Coronet, requires a lot of exposition to get going, and it's a measure of the movie that the exposition is more entertaining, more moving than most of the drama that follows."Obsession" is the story of an ambitious young New Orleans businessman, Michael Courtland (Cliff Robertson), who, in 1948, meets and marries the object of his dreams, Elizabeth (Genevieve Bujold), a pretty, chic young woman who shares his success. In 1959, after a party celebrating their 10th anniversary, Elizabeth and their daughter are kidnapped and, apparently, killed when a police-backed rescue attempt fails.The movie then cuts to 1975, when Michael, more successful than ever but obsessed by his guilt for having failed his wife and daughter, makes a business trip to Italy, where, in a church that had been a favorite of Elizabeth's, he meets a young Italian girl who is the image of his dead wife. Like the James Stewart character in "Vertigo," Michael sets out to turn the Italian girl, Sandra (also Miss Bujold), into Elizabeth.Logic is not essential in a film of this sort, yet Sandra is such a sensible girl that one wonders how she can participate so wholeheartedly in this scheme of conscious self-deception. Another problem is a cosmetic one. The film, from opening credits until the end, covers almost 30 years, but Mr. Robertson, who otherwise gives one of his best performances, doesn't appear to grow older by a day. He looks serenely ageless in the eerie way of someone made up by a mortician.Miss Bujold, an extraordinarily intelligent actress as well as a beautiful one, also does not look her best, especially as the Italian girl. This is ironic since almost everything else in the film, shot in New Orleans and Florence by Vilmos Zsigmond, is seen through romanticizing eyes that deny all imperfections.There is another problem that is difficult to discuss without giving away the plot.
