description: At the age of 25, Julie Hayes wants to run away from home. I want to drive a taxi, she says to her psychoanalyst. I want to write a novel or a poem or a play. Julie has already failed as a wouldbe actress and now she feels she has no part to play in life. True, she is married to Jeff, whom she esteems, but in freeassociating on the couch, she moves from esteem to steamroller. A brilliant foreign correspondent, Jeff is so heavy with pertinence that he flattens her.

title: AVERAGE IS 6.91% ON NEW U.S. NOTES
description: The United States Treasury sold $2 billion of new threeyear notes yesterday at an average interest rate of 6.91 percent in a financing that reflected a strong demand for rities in the credit markets. The Treasury received more than $5.4 billion of tenders for the $2 billion note issue, the first installment of a threepart Fderal financing operation this week that may involve as much as $9 billion of new notes and bonds.

title: Frail Currency Union
description: PARIS, Aug. 3The Common Market's frail currency union, weakened last March when France removed the franc from the joint float, is coming under renewed pressure because of a decline in interest rates in the United States and the continued disparity of inflation, rates within Europe. Once again the strength of the West German mark is, causing troubles for the less robust partners, with Belgium the Netherlands and Denmark having difficulty in keeping, their currencies in line. Once, again pressures are building up on the West Germans to peg the mark higher within the currency bloc. But because of elections next Oct. 3 Bonn is resisting. A revaluation raises the cost of a country's exports, thus making them less com, petitive in world markets.

title: Bathurst Adds $20 To Newsprint Price
description: ConsolidatedBathurst Ltd. of Montreal, announced yesterday that the price of its 30pound weight newsprint for Canadian and United States customers would be increased by $20 a ton, effective Nov.

title: Urban Legislators Tour Farm Areas
description: ALLMUCHY, Aug. 3Is that the city that swatted you in the ?? with its tall? Barbara Hamik?? asked her 5yearold Michael.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hughes Empires' Leaders Meet to Untangle Affairs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3Those who have taken control of Howard R. Hughes's fortune, are meeting in Las Vegas this week to attempt to untangle the golden threads of his empire. The problems and the stakes are immense, with millions of dollars at issue.

title: Ballet: O'Neal in Pillar
description: Once upon a time, when the world was young and innocent, or at least younger and more innocent, the role of Hagar in Antony Tudor's somber masterpiece, Pillar of Fire, was among the most jealously guarded roles in the American dance repertory. Indeed, since Nora Kaye created the role in 1942, up until this season, and I could always be mistaken, I can only recall Sallie Wilson, Veronika Miakar and Natalia Makarova in the role, although the Swedish ballerina Mariane Orlando has danced the ballet in Stockholm.

title: Peking Residents settle Down Outdoors
description: PEKING, Aug. 3 (Reuters) The six million people of the Chinese capital may be sleeping in the streets for weeks or even months because of the fear of another earthquake. Western diplomats said today.

title: Lawsuit Charges Byrne With Fib on Income Tax
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 3 (UPI)John Morrison of Wycott, N.J., a lawyer, has filed a lawsuit against the new state income tax charging Governor Byrne had told a fib when he had said in his 1973 election campaign that he did not foresee the need for the levy.

title: Yesterday's Results at Saratoga
description: FIRST$8.000, cl. 2YO, 5

title: 2 Dead and 2 Hurt In Texas Shooting; Executive Accused
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 3 (UPI)Cullen Davis, a millionaire oil executive embroiled in a divorce case, fatally shot his 12yearold stepdaughter and a former college basketball star and wounded his wife and a 21yearold man, the police said today.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX REGAIN GROUND
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange rebounded yesterday, with the market value index !closing at 103.72, up 0.39, for the sharpest oneday gain in about three weeks. Bargain hunters may have been picking up shares, analysts said, after the recent sharp decline in prices.

title: World Team Tennis
description: MONDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Dividends Announced
description: IRREGULAR

title: Propane Tank Cars Derailed
description: DEFUNIAK SPRINGS, Fla., Aug. 4 (UPI)Three railroad tank cars loaded with propane. derailed today in the northwest Florida community of Mossy Head, forcing the evacuation of 100 residents. Fearing fire or an explosion, the Walton, County Civil Defense Director, Bill Schultz, ordered the evacuaton, and the state Highway, Patrol blocked off a twomile. segment of U.S. 90.

title: $5.3 Billion Transport Fund Is Sent to Ford by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a $5.3 billion transportation appropriation bill that puts a celling on highway construction projects.

title: BANK IN JERSEY SUES F.D.I.C. OVER LOSSES
description: NEWARK, Aug. 4 (UPI)A Jersey City bank sued the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today, charging the F.D.I.C. was negligent because it did not idiscoyer that its former bank president misapplied more than I.75 million in hank money.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: United Press International

title: SEOUL IS OFFERED NUCLEAR STATIONS
description: PARIS, Aug. 4The French Government is negotiating the sale of what would be South Korea's fifth and sixth nuclear power stations and has already agreed to guarantee credits to finance the units as part of efforts to strengthen commercial ties with the Asian nation and widen export markets.

title: HOUSING MEASURE IS SIGNED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Despite what he called some shortcomings, President. Ford signed today a bill that he said was a step toward assuring adequate housing for all Americans.

title: Pro Transactions
description: SAN DIEGO (NL)Acouired Tom Griffin, pitcher, from Houston and Placed Dan Spilnner, pitcher, on disabled list.

title: Mrs. Abzug Calls for More U.S. Help for Northeast
description: Representative Bella S. Ahzug said yesterday that without new Federal economic policies, the entire Northeast could become the new Appalachia of America.

title: SPENDING REVIEW BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4They Senate Government Operations Committee approved today legislation, applying to Congress, that would end nearly all Government spending programs unless each one was specifically approved again over a fiveyear review cycle.

title: Panel Backs Pact With Spain
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)  A resolution authorizing $1.22 billion to finance a military base treaty with Spain was approved unanimously today by the House International Relations Committee. The aid is in exchange for the use by United States forces of Spanish air and naval bases for five more years.

title: Wrangle Over Court Changes
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4Of all the changes in the New York State ??? System that the Legislature considered tonight, the one that would most I undamentally have altered the way the courts actually operates was the proposal dealing with the arcane subject of court administration. This proposal has been all but forgotten in the wrangle over the date when an amendment proposing the appointment of judges to the Court of Appeals would take effectdispute that ended early this morning when Governor Carey and political and judicial leaders agreed to combine three components of the court package into a single amendment, leaving the effective (late for the next Legislature to decide.

title: Red Cross Evacuates 243 More Wounded Civilians From Beirut Camp
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 4The Red Cross evacuted 243 more wounded civilians from the beleaguered Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar today.

title: Chess:
description: BIEL, Switzerland, Aug. 4 (AP)Mikhael Tal of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, defeated the Colombian international master Oscar Rojas Castro on Wednesday, taking the lead in the Biel interzonal chess tournament from Bent Larsen, the Danish grandmaster.

title: Senate Confirms 2 Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Senate today confirmed the nominations of Stephen Low of Ohio to be Ambassador to Zambia and Ignacio Lozano of California as Ambassador to El Salvador. No dissenting votes were cast.

title: 2 to Campaign on Bicycles.
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 4 (UPI) The United American Party's Presidential and VicePresidential candidates, Frank Taylor and Henry Swan, plan a bicycle campaign in the Northwest beginning Aug. 11. They told news conference yesterday that I they would travel in nine states.

title: CutRate Brokerage Service Is Proposed by Chemical Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Chemical Bank unveiled today its longhintedat plan to offer customers a cutrate stock brokerage service, but the idea quickly ran into opposition among Government officials responsible for investor protection.

title: Yankees, Brewers In Split
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4The Yankees continued to depend on the homerun ball in a doubleheader with the Milwaukee Brewers tonight, and the result was a split.

title: AUDIT SHOWS HAYS PAID JUDGE AS AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4An audit being made of the financial affairs of the House Administration Committee under the chairmanship of Representative Wayne L. Hays has found that he hired a former Representative as a committee consultant and paid him $30,000 although in part of his period of service he was a state judge in Montana.

title: 3 Held in Recent Slayings Of 2 Men in Central Park
description: Three suspectsan 18yearold woman the police described as a parttime discotheque dancer and two unemployed half brotherswere arrested yesterday on charges of murdering two men whose bodies were found July 27 in Central Park.

title: ARGENTINA PURGES MAJOR UNIVERSITY
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4Al military investigation of aca demic subversion has led to the arrest of 17 professors and a major purge at the national university at Bahia Blanca.

title: Kissinger, in London, Weighing A New Trip to Southern Africa
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is considering making another trip to Africa later this month as part of an intensified effort to persuade blacks and whites in southern Africa to agree on a negotiated solution for Rhodesia.

title: James M. Symes,79, Dies; Chairman of the Pennsy
description: James M.Symes, former head of the Pennsylvania Railroad and the man who initiated the line's 1968 merger with the New York Central, died on Tuesday at the Ridgecrest Nursing Home in Feasterville, Pa. He was 79 years old.

title: THIOKOL SEEKING YENTRON SHARES
description: The Thiokol Corporation said yesterday that it would make a tender offer for shares of the Ventron Corporation at $44 a share, or $8 more than the $36 a share offered in June by the French ElfAquitaine Group. Thiokol's bid would total about $13.2 million if it obtained the minimum of 299,500 shares it was seeking, or the bid can total $23.1 million if all of Ventron's 540,000 shares are tendered.

title: New Carter Staff Member
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Aug 4 (UPI)Rufus Youngblood the former Secret Service agent who shielded Vice Presi dent Johnson in the Dallas mo torcade in which Presiden Kennedy was shot to death or Nov. 22, 1963, has joined Jim my Carter's campaign staff. Mr living in Savannah, Ga., wil handle logistics from the Atlan to campaign office. The an nouncement was made here yes terday by Jody Powell, Mr Carter's press secretary.

title: The Proceedings fn the U.N. Today
description: Committee on seabed regive and machinery3 P.M.

title: Illegal Phone Calls by Prisoners Said to Cost New York $47,292
description: Inmates at the Queens House of Detention have made $47,292 in unauthorized calls throughout the United States and to Puerto Rico and Canada over a recent ninemonth period, according to an audit by New York City's Comptroller, Hardson J. Goldin.

title: Grambling on Probation
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 4 (UPI)The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics placed Grambling University on oneyear probation for refusing to participate in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball playoffs last season. The N.A.I.A. executive committee said the Louisiana college would be denied participation in all of its district, area and national events through Aug. 1, 1977.

title: Market Place
description: Would the small investor fare better if he stopped trying to pick his own stocks or even stopped having experts pick them for himand instead settled for the gains and losses chalked up by a leading market average?

title: Britain in Transition: I
description: LONDON, Aug. 4Taking the pulse of a society is a tricky business for journalists. But after two weeks of watching and listening here, I am convinced that Britain is in a better state than she has been for some time more confident, more unified, more realistic.

title: GOING Guide
description: DOUBLEHEADER The current ThursdaythroughSunday presentation of two hourlength plays, Daniel Owens's Emily T and Aishah Rahman's Transcendental Blues, at the Manhattan Theater Club marks the showcase's first transfer of material originatinr, in the workshop of the frederick Douglas Creative Arts Center in Harlem. The club is a thriving, multistage complex, whose shows include various levels of drama and musical entertainment. The new oneact plays, both concerned with black women, mark the center's most ambitious theater projects to date, performed by a cast of 15 players under Fred Hudson's direction.

title: POLICECALL TAPE IS HEARD IN TRIAL
description: A scratchy and indistinct tape recording of a call summoning the police to what proved to be a fatal shootout in a Black Muslim mosque in Harlem was played yesterday at the murder trial of Lewis 17X Dupree.

title: Delegate Shift Often Prompted by Local Political Maneuverin
description: Angered by Bronx Republican organization pressures on him after he switched from President Ford to the uncommitted status, Daniel Fernandez, a Bronx delegate to the Republican National Convention, is likely to jump to Ronald Reagan today when the Californian meets with New York delegates in Brooklyn.

title: Headed College in Carolina
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 4 Mr. Carmichael was elected president of Converse College, Spartariburg, S. C., in 1956. He resigned in 1960 to become board chairman of the Associates Corporation, which became a subsidiary of Gulf & Western Industries Inc., and in 1969 was elected to the Gulf & Western board of directors.

title: Security Tight as 3 Suspects in Mass Abduction Appear in Court
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., Aug. 4  The three suspects in the kidnapping of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver last month made brief court appearances today as police sharpshooters watched from nearby roofs and those entering the tiny justice court were searched.

title: Ali Workin On a Stevenson Bout
description: Through the leafy trees of Central Park, people were hurrying toward the Wollman Rink where a familiar voice in a boxing ring was shouting, I might call the exact round the clown will go down! In a blue shirt and dark blue slacks, Muhammad Ali was there yesterday to sell his Sept. 28 world heavyweight title defense against Ken Norton at Yankee Stadium, and also to sell medallions and prayer rugs. Silver medallions, he was shouting now. and prayer rugs for Muslims all over the world! Every knee shall bend, every head shall bow, every tongue shall confess that Muhammad Ali the bes'! He later pretended to spar with Jimmy Young, he jived with Earnie Shavers,  he even listed them as opponents after Ken Norton and George Foreman, but now, half an hour later, Muhammad Ali and his cast of dozens had crowded into the Elizabethan Room of the Marriott Essex House, when somebody asked his opinion of Teofilo Stevenson, the Olympic heavyweight champion.

title: CareerDay Seminars Attract 175 at Paramus
description: PARAMUS, Aug. 4A classroom is hardly the place to be on a bright summer's day, but that is where 175 youngsters from 35 towns in Bergen County were today. They were attending a Career Day program at Bergen County Community College here, sponsored by the area's Community Action Program.

title: Mystery Disease Search Is Pressed as 2 More Die
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 4Two more deaths were recorded here today as public health officials pressed their laboratory search for an unidentified organism they believe responsible for the deaths of 22 people so far who were associated with a convention in Philadelphia last month.

title: Issues in Hospital Strike
description: PARTICIPANTS: About. 18.000 nonprofessional hospital workers, members of Local 420. American Federation State, County and Municipal Employees, are on strike against New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the 16 municipal hospitals. Most of the employees are nurses aides and dietary and janitorial workers.

title: U.S. Moves for Dismissal Of Draft Evasion Charge
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 4 (UPI)United States Attorney David Russell asked today for the dismissal of a draft evasion charge against Fritz Efaw, a representative of Democrats Abroad who was nominated for Vice President at the Democratic National Convention last month.

title: 10th Veto Overridden
description: The House of Representatives gave President Ford his 10th veto setback by overriding his action to kill legislation on reform of coal leasing. Page 12.

title: PUBLIC HOSPITALS ARE HIT BY STRIKE BUT REMAIN OPEN
description: An 18,000member union or nonmedical workers, angered by layoffs in the fiscal crisis, struck all 16 municipal hospitals yesterday in the first systemwide walkout at New York City's public hospitals.

title: Israelis Arrest 25 Arabs
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Israeli security forces have detained 25 members of an Arab guerrilla group suspected of attacks in Israel and the occupied West Bank of the Jordan, an army spokesman said today.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: COLUMBIA HONORS JURISTS:

title: Harry Braverman, 56,a Writer On Marxist Economics, Is Dead
description: Harry Braverman, director of The Monthly Review Press and a writer on economic issues as viewed from a Marxist perspective, died Monday at his country home in Honesdale, Pa. He was 56 years old and also lived in New York City.

title: Nixon Papers Damaged After Drain Overflows
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)A clogged air conditioner drain overflowed last weekend and dampened 180 boxes of papers belonging to former President Richard M. Nixon. The papers were impounded by court order after the Watergate scandal. The contents of two boxes were damaged severely.

title: A Medical Detective Tackles Weird Case
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Aug. 4Hello, I'm Dr. Stephen Thacker with the Health Department, and I am part of the medical team investigating this weird disease.

title: Luck Helps in Buying Show Dog
description: Sometimes one just has to he lucky when buying a show dog.

title: Officer Recognizes Own Car as Thief Gets Into a Jam
description: Police Officer Ronald Caccippio walked up to a stalled car that was causing a traffic jam near the Queensboro Bridge in Long Island City yesterday morning, noticed that the blue car looked familiar, and then suddenly realized it was his own.

title: Carter Portrait Hung
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 4 (AP) Nearly two years after he left office former Gov. Jimmy Carter's, official portrait is now hanging in the State Capitol. The Carter family, busy campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nominee gave the State Building Authority the portrait last week.

title: Mrs. King Stars In Sets Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 4  The New York Sets defeated the Indiana Loves, 2723, in World Team Tennis before 1,912 fans at Nassau Coliseum tonight. Billie Jean King and Virginia Wade won the women's doubles finale, averting an overtime.

title: News Summary and Index
description: South African police opened fire at least twice when Soweto students challenged a security cordon as they headed for Johannesburg to protest the detention of students arrested seven weeks ago. A Johannesburg newspaper said police bullets caused at least three deaths, but the police commissioner, acknowledging 13 casualties, said the only known fatality was a black man with a broken neck. The students succeeded in barring most of the black suburb's commuters to Johannesburg. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: POLICE OPEN FIRE AS STUDENTS RIOT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 4The police opened fire at least twice today when students from the black suburb of Soweto attempted to break through a security cordon barring them from Johannesburg, where they planned to protest the detention of students arrested during rioting seven weeks ago.

title: Schreiber's Death is Laid To Hospital Clerical Error
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) Taft B. Schreiber. an executive of MCA Inc. and a Republican Party fund raiser, died as a result of a clerical error by a blood bank technician at the university of California Hospiital, a spokesman said today.

title: Bill on Flu Vaccine Insurance Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4A bill designed to end the impasse over insurance protection for flu vaccine manufacturers has passed a health subcommittee of the House of Representatives and goes tomorrow to the full House Commerce Committee.

title: HOUSE TO RECEIVE BILL ON NEW RIVER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The House Rules Committee voted today to give the full House a chance to vote on a bill to block construction of a clam on the New River after the bill's author apologized for suggesting that lobbyists had bottled. it up.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Aug. 4, 1976

title: Detroit Judge Told To End Segregation In 3 School Areas
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuitl, today ordered a Federal District judge in Detroit to find a way to desegregate three predominantly black Detroit school regions, involving 83,000 students, that were left virtually untouched by a previous desegregation plan.

title: Tangshan Quake Area in China is Toured by Premier
description: PEKING. Thursday, Aug. 5Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng is visiting the earthquakestricken city of Tangshan, the Hsinhua press agency reported last night. He expressed sympathy to the victims and urged them to restore industrial production and rebuild their homes.

title: Electronic Flagpoles Drawing A Congressman's Red Glare
description: The United States General Services Administration has been running electronic flagpoles up the flagpole, but Representative William F. Walsh of Syracuse is not saluting.

title: BRONX GARAGE HIT BY TEAM OF VANDALS
description: Six men broke into a newly built equipmentrepair garage in the Bronx last night and systematically destroyed between $250,000 and $500,000 worth of electrical installations in less than two hours, the Police said.

title: Mystery Disease Victims
description: PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 4 Following is a list of the persons who have died as a result of the mysterious flulike disease that affected some visitors to Philadelphia for the state American Legion convention in late July. The names. listed by date of death. were compiled by the State Health Department.

title: Bout to Be Investigated
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP)  The World Boxing Council said today that it planned an official review of a controversial superbantamweight fight, held Sunday between Yung Dom Kyun of South Korea and Rigoberto Riasco, after the referee for the bout, Larry Rozadilla, said he changed his decision to favor the Korean because of threats to his life.

title: Marvin C. Pollak, 68, Of New York Law Firm
description: Marvin C. Pollak, a senior pattner in the law firm of Pollak, Swartz, Stark & Amron, at 1133 Avenue of the Americas, died Tuesday in his home, 25 Sutton Place, after a short illness. His age was 68.

title: $100,000 in Gems Stolen From Dealer in New York
description: A diamond dealer carrying a case that he said contained $100,000 in loose polished stones was set upon in a midtown building by a thief who made off with the case, the police of the Midtown North Precinct reported yesterday.

title: SPENDING REVIEW BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Senate Government Operations Committee approved today legislation, applying to Congress, that would end nearly all Government spending programs unless each one was specifically approved again over a fiveyear review cycle.

title: Vatican Defrocks Italian Priest Who Joined Communist Party
description: ROME, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Vatican today defrocked a Communist Italian priest for disobedience in challenging papal primacy and favoring divorce and abortion.

title: Philadelphia Puzzle
description: Because American mortality statistics are normally low, it seems unlikely that chance alone can account for the tragic occurrence of 22 deaths and the hospitalization of at least 130 people among those associated with an American Legion convention in Philadelphia last month. Attention to this phenomenon has been heightened by earlier warnings of the possibility of a swine flu epidemic.

title: SCHWEIKER VOTES PUT IN NEW LIGHT
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 4Ronald Reagan and his running mate, Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania, took pains today to try to explain to Mississippi delegates that the Senator was not personally as liberal as his voting record in Congress might indicate.

title: TREASURY NOTES STIR BIG DEMAND
description: Bond prices continued to rise yesterday as the Treasury wound up its offering of 8 percent 10year notes, the centerpiece of its big tiveepart financing this week. While the results will not be disclosed until after 5 P.M. today, dealers in Government securities reported another great wave of demand for the new notes, possibly even heavier than in February when another highly popular 8 percent note issue was offered.

title: Propane Tank Cars Derailed
description: DEFUNIAK SPRINGS, Fla., Aug. 4 (UPI)Three railroad tank cars loaded with propane. derailed today in the northwest Florida community of Mossy Head, forcing the evacuation of 100 residents. Fearing fire or an explosion, the Walton, County Civil Defense Director, Bill Schultz, ordered the evacuaton, and the state Highway, Patrol blocked off a twomile. segment of U.S. 90.

title: Political Unknown is Victor
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 4 (AP)A political unknown who stumped the 25 counties of Kanses Fifth Congressional District, has apparently won the Democratic nomination to oppose veteran Representative Joe Skubitz in November.

title: Choice of Schweiker Appears to Keep Alive Reagan's Chances
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4When Ronald Reagan disclosed that he had chosen Senator Richard S. Schweiker as his proposed running mate, the Californian's chief strategist, John P. Sears, said the selection would temporarily make all hard tabulations of Republican delegate strength worthless.

title: Tennessee Goes to Polls Today To Pick Sen. Brock's Opponent
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 4Tennessee voters select tomorrow a Democratic nominee for the Unites States Senate to oppose the incumbent Republican, Bill Brock, in the November electon.

title: Mystery Disease Search Is Pressed as 2 More Die
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 4Two more deaths were recorded here today as public health officials pressed their laboratory search for an unidentified organism they believe responsible for the deaths of 22 people so far who were associated with a convention in Philadelphia last month.

title: POLICE OPEN FIRE AS STUDENTS RIOT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 4The police opened fire at least twice today when students from the black suburb of Soweto attempted to break through a security cordon barring them from Johannesburg, where they planned to protest the detention of students arrested during rioting seven weeks ago.

title: Soil Sampler on Viking is Balking Again
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 4The soilsampling boom on the Viking 1 landing craft stuck again last night. but project engineers said today that the device may have succeeded in delivering a sample to one of the vehicle's chemistry detectors.

title: Albany Ready to Approve Court Reorganization Plan
description: ALBANY, Thursday, Aug. 5 Both heu5.?s of the State Legislature, meeting late last night and into the morning in special session, gave first passage to a courtreorganization amendment to the state constitution that provides for appointment rather than election to the Court of Appeals, centralized administration of the state courts, and streamlined judicial discipline.

title: BANKS IN BRITAIN FACE NEW RULES
description: LONDON, Aug. 4The British Government took a small but precedentsetting step yesterday toward bringing its international banking community, the world's biggest and probably the least regulated under legislative control.

title: COUSIN OF HUGHES TO HEAD SUMMA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4William Rice Lummis, 47 years old, a Houston lawyer who is a cousin of the late Howard R. Hughes, was named chairman of the board of the Summa Corporation today.

title: Sudan Executes 81 For Coup Attempt Against Nimeiry
description: CAIRO, Aug. 4Eightyone people were executed at dawn today in the Sudan after being convicted of charges that they had participated in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow President Gaafar alNimeiry.

title: A Puzzling Portrait of Key Coast Kidnapping Suspect
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4  When 24yearold Fred Woods, the last to be arrested of the three young men charged with the kidnapping and entombment of 26 schoolchildren, was taken into custody in Canada a week ago, he was dressed, as a Canadian official put it, like an amateur cowboyhighheeled boots, faded brown denim suit and a rancher's hat saucily curled over long brown sideburns.

title: MALAYSIA SEEKS HIGHER OIL RETURN
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 4 The state oil companies of Indonesia and Malaysia, backed by their governments threats of nationalization, have begun to apply heavy pressure on international oil companies.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. (Radio  WMCA, 2:25 P.M.)

title: U.S. SEES EAST BLOC LAGGING ON RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)  The State Department said today that the Soviet Union and its East European allies had taken some concrete steps to implement the Helsinki accord but that there was little change in policies on human rights.

title: Status on the Wrist
description: Every so often, an accessory comes along that turns out to be instant status. Occasionally, as difficult as it may be to believe, the item becomes status even before it's arrived.

title: Refrain at Hospitals Is No Trouble So Far
description: Migdalia Hernandez. a staff purse in the 15th floor surgery ward at Bellevue Hospital, usually goes to work alone, but yesterday morning she took pains to be accompanied by three friends who also work at the hospital.

title: Stones Raises Mark In High Jump to 77
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 Dwight Stones got his dry runway at Franklin Field tonight, and he flew to a world record of 7 feet 7 inches in the high jump during the Bicentennial Meet of Champions.

title: Accounting Office Finds Local Abuse In Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Government has failed to head off discrimination and misuse of revenuesharing funds because it has relied on the states and localities to police themselves, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Josie O'Donnell Singing at Duplex; Comeback for Both
description: The Duplex, a small twolevel club at 55 Grove Street, just west of Sheridan Square, whose upstairs room was a busy showcase for new talent until it closed three years ago, reopened this week, picking up where it left off as a setting for new faces.

title: 10th Veto Overridden
description: The House of Representatives gave President Ford his 10th veto setback by overriding his action to kill legislation on reform of coal leasing. Page 12.

title: Lord Thomson Dies; Built Press Empire
description: LONDON, Aug. 4 Lord Thomson of Fleet, a Canadian who built a vast and influential publishing empire crowned by The Times of London and The Sunday Times, died this morning at Wellington Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: U.S. and Bonn Reach Tank Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4In a major step toward the longsought goal of standardizing weapons among the Atlantic allies, the American and West German Armies have agreed on, a common gun and engine for their new main battle tanks.

title: 37 Examine Trees in Test to Be Certified Experts
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 4Thirtyseven men, ranging in age from the middle 20's to late 60's peered at scores of trees and shrubs, scrutinized weeds and insects and submitted to a threehour written examination today in an effort to become certified tree exoerst in New Jersey.

title: Sudan Executes 81 For Coup Attempt Against Nimeiry
description: CAIRO, Aug, 4Eightyone people were executed at dawn today in the Sudan after being convicted of charges that they had participated in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow President Gaafar alNimeiry.

title: PARIS DEFENSE AIDE QUITS SPECIAL POST
description: PARIS, Aug. 4 (Reuters)Gen. Marcel Bigeard, who rose become an under secretary of state for defense in France, resigned from his post today saying he had finished the job he set himself 18 months ago.

title: City to Revoke License Of 68th St. Discotheque
description: Finding that the lullaby of Broadway had become a cacophony of discordant sounds that shook sleepless tenants, the city has revoked the cabaret license of a discotheque north of Lincoln Center.

title: PUBLIC HOSPITALS ARE HIT BY STRIKE BUT REMAIN OPEN
description: An 18,000member union of nonmedical workers, angered by layoffs in the fiscal crisis, struck all 16 municipal hospitals yesterday in the first systemwide walkout at New York City's public hospitals.

title: 4 NEWSMEN GIVEN JAILING REPRIEVE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4The California Supreme Court issued a stay today of a Fresno Superior Court judge's order that would have jailed indefinitely four newsmen on The Fresno Bee who have refused to disclose their sources for a 1975 article about municipal corruption.

title: Amex Stocks Rise For a Second Day; Counter in Decline
description: Shares on the American Stock Exchange moved up yesterday for a second session, and the Ilmarket value index closed at 103.87, up 0.15.

title: N.C.A.A. Trial Date Set
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 4 (UPI)The trial of a suit brought by two University of Alabama assistant coaches challenging a National Collegiate regulation limiting the size of coaching staffs has been set for Aug. 30. United States District Court Judge Sam Pointer set the date after meeting with lawyers for the N.C.A.A. and the two coaches, Dude Hennessey and Wendell Hudson.

title: Controversy Aroused in Israel By Talks With Rebel Lebanese
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 4 A disclosure that Israeli Army liaison officers have been meeting with rebel Lebanese Moslems allied to the Palestine Liberation Organization has stirred controversy here.

title: Metropolitan Brief
description: Daniel Foot, 39 years old, of 201 Linden Boulevard in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, was convicted in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn of murdering two women and assaulting a third in November 1975. In testimony introduced at the 11day trial, Mr. Foot was said to have fatallyshot, stabbed and struck with a hammer Audrey Myers, in her apartment at 1460 New York Avenue, and then to have turned on two visitors in the apartment, killing Paulette Virgo and injuring Eileen Hedlam. Mr. Foot, who has been placed in custody without bail pending sentencing Sept. 14, allegedly was an acquaintance of Miss Myers who tried to rob her after being let Into the apartment.

title: Black Leader Will Meet With Kissinger on Hiring
description: BOSTON, Aug. 4Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, said today that he would meet with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger in September to Suggest ways in which the national civil rights organization could help in the State Department's recruitment and upgrading of blacks and other minority group members.

title: Harris Jury is Out a 5th Day
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4The jury in the trial of William and Emily Harris, grappling with 22 possible verdicts on assault, robbery and kidnapping charges, began a fifth day of deliberations today without sending any word on its progress.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 4 (UPI) The dollar declined on most European money markets today while the price gold showed a substantial increase. Gold rose in Zurich from $111.65 an ounce to $113.35 and in London from $111.925 to $113.375. Dealers in London said gold was supported by an overall firmer trend in other commodity prices.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Crime Figures Moving to Pennsylvania
description: ST. DAVIDS, Pa., Aug. 4The Pennsylvania Crime Commission said today that organizedcrime figures were moving from New Jersey to Pennsylvania for illegal gambling operations because investigative procedures were tougher in New Jersey.

title: ANTIBRIBE UNIT PLANNED BY U.N.
description: GENEVA, Aug. 4The United, Nations Economic and Social Council agreed today to set up an intergovernmental group that would prepare an accord designed to prevent bribery and other corrupt practices by multinational companies.

title: CARTER PLEDGES CAMPAIGN UNITY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Jimmy Carter told a newly appointed Democratic campaign steering committee today that there would be no disharmony and no division of effort between his Presidential campaign and the national effort to elect Democrats to statehouses and Congress.

title: Politics of Cynicism
description: American voters have no way of casting a ballot for a Presidential nominee without automatically voting for his runningmate as well. Given that aspect of the electoral system, they have a right to expect a certain philosophical compatibility between the two men who head a party's ticket. They should be able to choose President who believes, say, in a totally freemarket economy, big defense and no public works programs for the jobless without having to vote for a Vice President who believes in an effective government presence in the marketplace, a reduction in defense spending and Federally provided jobs for the unemployed. After all, today's Vice President may be tomorrow's President, as four of the last six occupants of that office have demonstrated.

title: Low Bail Defended in Slayings Involving, Texas Oil Executive
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 4 (UPI) The justice of the peace who set bond at $80,000 for Cullen Davis, who has been charged with murder, said today the oil executive was drunk when he fatally shot two persons and wounded two others at his mansion and probably will never hurt anybody again.

title: Sadat, Spurring Output, Bars Strikes
description: CAIRO, Aug. 4President Anwar elSadat, a longtime union member, has told the Egyptians that strikes are not permissible. I advise you to give up spite and make love prevail, he said.

title: HOUSE, IN REVERSAL, VOTES URANIUM BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The House, on a vote of 193 to 192, reversed today an earlier vote and passed a bill providing Government aid so private industry could start producing enriched uranium as an additional energy source.

title: Japanese Leads by A Stroke
description: SUNNINGDALE, England, Aug. 4 (AP)Chako Higuchi of Japan carded a sixunderpar 68 today and took a onestroke lead after the first round of the European women's golf championship.

title: 0. C. Carmichael Jr., 56, Dead; Headed G.O.P. Finance Group
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 4 (AP)O. C. Carmichael Jr., former treasurer and finance committee chairman for the Republican National Committee, died here yesterday after suffering a heart attack while playing tennis. He was 56 years old.

title: NASSAU YOUTH DIES AFTER PRACTICE JOG
description: A 16yearold Nassau County youth collapsed during a football training session at New Hyde Park Memorial High School last night and died shortly afterward at Nassau Hospital despite efforts by firemen to revive him.

title: 308 Killed by Floods in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)A total of 308 people have been killed and 30 were seriously injured in floods and landslides in various parts of Nepal in the last six to seven weeks, Jog Mehar Shrestra, the Minister of Interior, told the National Assembly today.

title: 6 Basque Activists And 3 Communists Released in Spain
description: MADRID, Aug., 4 (AP)Three Spanish Communist leaders and six Basque nationalists were freed from prison today, the first effective day of King Juan Carlos amnesty for political prisoners.

title: Ballet: A Dream Debut
description: Awarded a shower, even a torrent, of flowers, Marianna Tcherkassky made a sort of dream debut in the title role of Giselle at the New York State Theater yesterday afternoon. Although Miss Tcherkassky, a 23yearold soloist with American Ballet Theater she has a Russian father, a Japanese mother and Andre Eglevsky as a godfatherdid once dance Gisclle in Washington earlier in the year, she was not scheduled to play the role in New York. Now she has not only made her New York debut but, because of injuries in the Ballet Theater company, she will also repeat the performance tonight.

title: Collegiate, $26.80, Victor As Copano is Disqualified
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 4The disqualification of the 65 Copano in the $23,000 first division enlivened the Eatontown Handicap on the grass at Monmouth Park today. After moving up in the last 16th of a mile to regain the lead under Mickey Solomone, Copano finished a nose in front of Collegiate. However, Copano was disqualified and dropped to second for having veered sharply on the Bright View Farm horse, ridden by Jimmy Edwards, in the last stride.

title: Alcoa Lifts Prices; Kaiser Acts Abroad
description: The nation's top aluminum producer, the Aluminum Company of America, has raised the domestic price of unalloyed aluminum by 4 cents a pound, to 48 cents, effective with orders placed today. The company said yesterday that appropriate adjustments would also apply on prices other types of its primary ingot product and to approximately 45 percent of its mill product line, or an average of approximately 7 percent.

title: U.S. Now Concedes It Discussed a Ban On Loans to Italians
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reuters)The United States consulted its European allies about cutting off economic aid to Italy if Communists were admitted to the Italian Cabinet, it was disclosed in a White House letter released today.

title: Riverside Girl Wins Riding Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 4Provincial Lady, owned and ridden by Wendy Brooks of Riverside, won two of the three classes, scoring 10 points and capturing the junior working hunter championship today at the Greenwich Riding and Trails Association horse show.

title: School Revision Plan Stirs Furor in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 2  A group of Roman Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland, seeking to overhaul the school system that has separated Catholic and Protestant children for 50 years, has stirred an angry debate that pits the Catholic hierarchy against British officials, Protestant clergymen and a strong group of Catholic parents.

title: Crude Oil Imports A Record in Week; Gasoline Sfock Up
description: Crude oil imports reached a record of 6.29 million barrels a day in the week ended July 30. the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 5.31 million barrels a week earlier and 5.10 million barrels a day in the week ended Aug. 1, 1975. The previous high for any single week was 6.23 million barrels a day brought into the country in the week ended June 11, 1976.

High School graduate who obtained a job as a printer for the school district because he had done so well in his printing classes will he arraigned in Federal Court in Brooklyn tomorrow on a charge of manufacturing counterfeit money, a Secret Service official said today.

description: The illegal strike of municipal hospital workers against the sick and a sick city is another tragic consequence of the persisting failure of public officials to uphold the state's Taylor Law, which was designed to prevent such potentially disastrous walkouts by public employees.

title: Gunmen Attack in Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 4 (Reuters)  Unidentified gunmen attacked the diplomatic missions of Nicaragua and Spain just before dawn today, killing one policeman and wounding another, the police said, A police spokesman said that the gunmen fled by car and no diplomats had been injured.

title: Albany Ready to Approve Court Reorganization Plan
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4The State Legislature, called into special session by Governor Carey, began debate late tonight on a reorganization plan for the state courts that includes centralized court administration, a fouryear state takeover of all local court costs and the appointment, rather than the election, of judges on the Court of Appeals.

description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  My people, the PimaMaricopa Indians of central Arizona, and our friends the Papagos and MohaveApaches, are in the midst of a desperate battle for enough water to survive as a people.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Northern Tier Pipeline Company of Billings, Mont., announced yesterday the completion of a study showing the feasibility of its proposed pipeline system for transshipping Alaskan crude oil to the Great Lakes area. The company has retained Kidder Peabody & Company as investment banker for the project, which is expected to cost $1.1 billion and take two years to build.

title: 'Alpha Beta' Details Marital Agonies
description: In a sense, it is not a movie. It is a filmed play and filmed plays are usually disastrous. The camera is a restless eye and its restlessness spreads like itching powder."Alpha Beta," a contemporary British play about a working-class marriage, is particularly unlikely as a movie. Its two characters confine themselves to a tiny kitchen and living room and spend three acts mutilating each other with words.But the film, which opened yesterday at the Quad II and Thalia Theaters, in a triumph in chains. The constrictions are a form of discomfort akin to hard seats in a basement theaer. The pennedin camera, the talking heads, are insufficient, but it is a relative insufficiency, like that of an opera performed in concert version.If the singers are good enough, the expedient works. And Rachel Roberts and Albert Finney are so extraordinary as the husband and wife that they make "Alpha," cinematic or not, a startling and wonderful experience.There is no real plot, only a theme. It is that the breakup of a marriage is not a way out, but a playing-out of a joint agony. Inevitable and murderous at the same time, each blow wounds assailant as well as victim.The passing of time is the dramatic device. "Alpha's" three acts, preserved in the film, take three stages of the breakup, each some five years apart.In the beginning it is five or six years into the marriage of Frank Elliot, a clerk in a produce-shipping company, and his wife, Nora. From the start, we know exactly where they are. Her hands move quickly, it is to be hoped, incompetently, pasting up hideous white wallpaper in their living room. He stands there stolidly sipping coffee, his incipient estrangement marked equally by his failure to offer her any assistance and to remove his raincoat. He is home from work, but the raincoat is unconscious evidence that he doesn't want to be.In this first act the despair is Frank's. He is trapped in their narrow life and as they bicker and recriminate he loathes himself for being unable to break out. In the second act he has made the break: They live together under an "arrangement" under which he is virtually a boarder, openly going out with other women. In the third act they are separated and he comes once a week to visit the children.The agony shifts back and forth. At the end of the first act, Frank, backed into the newly-wallpapered corner, howls at his entrapment. In the second act Frank plays at self-absorbed indifferences, Nora's outrage. Here it is Nora who howls, unable to bear having her husband physically present, but absent in every other sense.In the last act Nora sits like a stone as Frank, on his weekly visit, chatters compulsively and tidies up the slovenly mess that she has let the house become. The marriage is dead, but not the pain and as they talk there is a faint tenderness but no hope at all."Alpha" is unsparingly acute. It is also narrow. Nothing comes in or out the door except Frank E. A. Whitehead, the author, is isolating what may be a universal pain of marriage, but he leaves out the social context, the outside factors that may either help a marriage or destroy it move quickly. He also misses the fact that few people can be so searingly consistent in their suffering.It is the achievement of Miss Roberts and Mr. Finney to make "Alpha" more universal than it is. Mr. Finney is wrath, anguish, hesitancy and charm in one chunky, seedy package. Miss Roberts is even better: She makes classic tragedy out of this row-house misery. There is authentic pity and terror in the final silences that succeed her first-act flutterings and her second-act vituperation."Alpha" is a play forced onto the screen and we see the strain clearly. It didn't have to be a movie: It could, for example, be done quite naturally on television. But the fact is that "Alpha," Miss Roberts and Mr. Finney are here as a movie and that is the only way they can be seen. And they should be seen.

description: DETROIT, Aug. 4Newcar sales climbed 19.1 percent in the final third of July from last year, the four domestic auto companies reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his July 28 OpEd piece Expanding Our Ties With China, Presidential aspirant Ronald Reagan asserts that the Chinese share with us and Japan some common and complementary goals in the Pacific, and he purports to discern a present indirect Chinese message, namely that they want to explore with us and Japan an expanded relationship. And what would be the common goals fostering closer association between the United States, Japan and the People's Republic of China (P.R.C.)? Well, apart from trade, All three nations wish to bring stability to the region. Candidate Reagan develops the argument for fitting in with the presumed Chinese scheme of things: A broadened relationship could also serve to provide a barrier to Soviet expansionism. And he holds that, To take advantage of this Asian opportunity [as conveyed by the Chinese signals], we must regain credibility in Peking's eyes. Paradoxical as it may seem, this means honoring our commitments to South Korea and Taiwan.

title: Film: Early Wertmuller
description: Some authors tear up their juvenile work; others leave it for scholars. Lina Wertmller has become a fascinating though uneven movie maker, but the public resurrection of one of her first films, made 10 years ago, is probably a mistake."Let's Talk About Men," which opened yesterday at Loews Tower East, consists of four vignettes linked for no apparent reason by a sequence dealing with the efforts of a man who has inadvertently locked himself out of his apartment  without clothesto get back in.The vignettes, cast in the form of comedy, all seek to demonstrate with underlying anger different ways in which men abuse women. In their mordancy, and in some of their particular touches, there are reflections of things that Miss Wertmller would do later.The recognition of these things is of some interest, but not enough to make most people pay money to winkle or pay them out of a collection that is three parts bad and one part mediocre.In the first item, a profiteering businessman whose kittenish wife is a kleptomaniac, suddenly decides to make use of her proclivity when his deals turn sour. In the second, an aging knife-thrower is too vain to heed the pleas of his wifewho is also his badly scarred targetto get a new pair of glasses. The results are predictable.In the third vignette, a husband's insistence on treating his wife as a cretin stirs her to mutiny. He puts down the mutinywhich takes the form of a complex murder plotand thus, to his intellectual and erotic satisfaction, proves himself right.The humor of the first vignette is thin and predictable; the grotesquerie of the knife-throwing and murder-plot vignette is leaden and trite. Nino Manfredi overacts the man's part in each of them.In the last story, Mr. Manfredi is a farmer who spends the day woolgathering with his cronies while his wifeand theirsdo all the work. At night he comes home drunk and pleased with himself and, despite her reluctance, insists on coupling with her. The man's wastrel existence and his brutal subjection of his wife are similiar material, but Miss Wertmller does it with some liveliness, and Mr. Manfredi's performance is reasonably convincing.An occasional line shows some of the strength that Miss Wertmller developed later. The notion of the knife-thrower hacking up his wife's anatomy bit by bit simply because one day he has an extra drink, another day he decides to use his left hand, and so on, is grandly horrifying. Badly acted and poorly directed, it is no more than weird. In the first vignette there is a telling monologue by the tycoon who tells his wife what it would be like to be poor. "You will grow ugly, he says. "You will grow a mustache."The rating is PG. Possible reasons: two suggested but not demonstrated acts of sexual intercourse. One killing.

title: Tickets Still Available
description: The annual midsummer exhibition game between the Giants and the Jets will be played on Monday night Yankee Stadium, but there does not seem to be the interest in the event as in the past. The Jets, the host team, reported yesterday there were still about 14,000 seats unsold for the game, all at $9 each.

title: Michigan's Senate Race Pits Riegle Against Esch

description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J. Aug. 4Cindy Ferro of Forest Hill Field Club defeated Donna Young of Hopewell Valley, I up, to gain the semifinal round of the women's state amateur golf championship at the Somerset Hills Country Club today.

title: The Screen: 'Survive!'
description: Whatever majesty of spiritforged of ennobled will, faith and intelligence amid death and fierce adversityenabled the survivors of an Andean airline crash four years ago to endure against all odds is nowhere to be found in "Survive!" which opened yesterday at Loews State and Loews Cine theaters.The makers of this movie might be forgiven had the inextinguishable essence of humanity and the wracking issue of a survival that depended upon cannibalism eluded their talents. Artists for centuries have foundered on great themes that exceeded their grasps.But in the case of "Survive!" which is based not upon Piers Paul Read's bestseller, "Alive," but upon an account by Clay Blair Jr., nobody had aspirations beyond speed and commercialism. While the film based on Mr. Read's book is still to come, the suspicion is that its arrival will establish that "Survive!" has gotten here first with the least.Made in Mexico, "Survive!" is an irksomely dubbed film of rudimentary exposition with a sometimes tinny musical accompaniment, which attempts by aural flogging to accomplish what the script cannot: engage the intelligence or the emotions. The characters, most of them representing members of a college rugby team, are indistinguishable from one another by appearance or deed.Visually, there are unnecessary scenes of protruding viscera and the lancing of an infected leg. The first butchering of the dead extends beyond the time when its point has ben made. And later scenes, including a brief shot of a flayed corpse in the mountain snow, are wholly gratuitous.To say that "Survive" is a disasater movie is not to categorize it but to describe it.

title: KISSINGER PRESSES WORLD SEA PARLEY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.. Aug. 4 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, in a message to the president of the Law of the Sea Conference here, called today for rapid, responsible and cooperative progress of the global maritime talks.

title: At the Heart of it All is the Individual
description: LONDON Since time immemorial there have been arguments about the relative importance of the individual and the state. There is no doubt that in moments of desperate national crisis a people united behind a leader have willingly given up much of their individual liberty and have achieved great things. But the crucial moment always arrives when the people become disenchanted with the inevitable constraints they accepted during the crisis while the leader is inclined to remain determined that they are still essential for survival. And there may also be a difference of opinion about what constitutes a crisis in the first place.

title: CARTER SAYS G.O.P. WILL SELECT FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Jimmy Carter came to Washington today for a little skullpractice with his Presidential campaign staff, and talked optimistically and philosophically about the future.

title: News Summary and Index
description: South African police opened fire at least twice when Soweto students challenged a security cordon as they headed for Johannesburg to protest the detention of students arrested seven weeks ago. A Johannesburg newspaper said police bullets caused at least three deaths, but the. police commissioner, acknowledging 13, casualties, said the only known fatality was a black man with a broken neck. The students succeeded in barring most of the black suburb's commuters to Johannesburg. [Page 1, Column 1.]

description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4  The accidental death yesterday of Representative Jerry L. Litton, who had just swept to an upset victory in the race for nomination for the United States Senate, threw Missouri Democratic politics into temporary confusion today.

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Books of The Times
description: It had to happen sooner or later, as Theodore B. Taylor, the nuclear physicist, has warned us in John McPhee's The Curve of Binding Energy. A terrorist group gets hold of fissionable material as well as the technical skill to build nuclear devices, and it uses them to blackmail the world. Good thing then that the first time it happens is in Leonard Sanders's The Hamlet Warning, a doomsday thriller by the editor of the book review of The Fort Worth. StarTelegram. This way it hasn't really happened yet, but the threat of its possiblility seems even more dire than when Mr. Taylor, the physicist, warned that any competent physicist could bring it about.

title: Death of Missouri Winner Roils Democratic Politics
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4  The accidental death yesterday of Representative Jerry L. Litton, who had just swept to an upset victory in the race for nomination for the United States Senate, threw Missouri Democratic politics into temporary confusion today.

title: Clint Eastwood Aims at War Epic in  Josey Wales
description: Each time Clint Eastwood. in The Outlaw Josey Wales kills someone or is about to kill someone, or is on the verge of some other major policy decision, he spits. This is to establish the character.

title: Judge Accuses F.B.I. of Giving False Information to Socialists
description: A Federal district judge in Manhattan declared, yesterday that, the Federal Bureau of Investigation had provided false information regarding crucial aspect of a major lawsuit by the Socialist Workers Party against the F.B.I. and other Government agencies.

title: Keep it Clean
description: The Senate put in a good day's work when it beat back a major assault on one of the key proposals to strengthen the Clean Air Act. Intensive efforts by business and industrial lobbies failed to shake the conviction of roughly twothirds of the Senate that air still relatively unpolluted should remain that way. New plants that would significantly degrade air quality would have to locate in areas classified by the states themselves as appropriate, the classification depending on how much cleaner an area is to begin with than nat standards require.

title: Director of Hospital Walkout
description: Lillian Roberts, the former nurse's aide who is directing the hospital worker's strike here, spent most of its first day yesterday in her orange and brown, plantfilled office Woman in the News at 140 Park Place, answering telephone calls from reporters who always seemed to ask the same question:

title: 5 Options Cited for North U.S. As Canada Halts Oil Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Federal Energy Administration has concluded that at least five viable alternatives are available to supply the northern United States with oil as Canada cuts off its exports of the fuel.

title: LETITIA W. BROWN; HISTORY PROFESSOR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Letitia Woods, Profesor of American history and civilization at George Washington University and an authority on the history of Washington's black community, died of cancer yesterday at her home here. She was 60 years old.

title: Judge Orders Albany to Finance Erie Relief, but Ruling is Stayed
description: BUFFALO. Aug. 4 (UPI)In an unprecedented move. Justice Gilbert H. King of State Supreme Court today ordered New York State to provide temporary financing for Erie County's welfare system until Sep. tember.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4 Stanley Van Ness, the State Public Advocate, said today that he wanted New Jersey to spend some of the $309 million it expects from the Federal Public Works Bill to make it easier for handicapped people to use public buildings.

title: Headstart Community Chiefs Expand Fraud Charges to Consultants Pacts
description: The community directors of Headstart preschool programs, who have charged city administrators with fraud and mismanagement of their renovation funds, have expanded their criticisms to include consultant; contracts.

title: Senate Votes to Delete Benefits for Recyclers From Its Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Senate deleted from the tax bill tonight a proposed new tax benefit, amounting to hundreds of millions of dollars, for those who buy used materials and recycle them.

title: U.S. and Bonn Reach Tank Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4In al major step toward the longsought goal of standardizing weapons among the Atlantic allies, the American and West German Armies have agreed on a common gun and engine for their new main battle tanks.

title: Boats Save 4 in Plane
description: OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 4 (UPI)Four Harrisburg, Pa., men were rescued from Great Egg Harbor yesterday when their singleengine plane plunged into the bay during a landing attempt. The pilot, David Kireta, 18 years old, said wind currents had buffeted the plane and forced it into the water. Boats rushed to the rescue of Mr. Kireta and his companionsDavid Dodge, Gary Miller and Bruce Horning.

title: Bicentennial Barge is Popular Upstate
description: BRWERTON, N.Y., Aug. 4Half an hour after the chain across the gangplank had been let down to New York's Bicentennial barge this morning, almost 1,000 persons had boarded to view the exhibits, indicating once again that the barge is drawinc, a bigger percentage of the population in small communities along the Erie Canal than it did in New York City.

title: EDUCATION
description: EDUCATION

title: A Parisian Solution for Summer 76
description: PARISThanks to the heat wave that turned this city into an inferno through June and the first half of July, the women of Paris are swinging along the streets in the most comfortable, cool easy fashion anyone can remember.

title: WILLIAM RAYMOND JR.
description: William Raymond Jr., a retired partner in the stock brokerage firm of Chauncey & Company, 120 Broadway, died in a hospital in Peterboro, N.H., Tuesday. His age was 68.

title: CARTER SAYS G.O.P. WILL SELECT FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Jimmy Carter came to Washington today for a little skullpractice with his Presidential campaign staff, and talked optimistically and philosophically about the future.

title: Mets Koosman Subdues Expos, 40
description: The way the Mets and the Expos played the early innings of the game, it should have been yesterday's episode of television's General Hospital.

title: Ramirez, Dibbs Reach 3d Round at Net
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 4 (AP)Raul Ramirez of Mexico and Eddie Dibbs of Miami advanced to the third round of a $100,000 international pro tennis tournament today.

title: Fear of Crime is Hastening The Decline of Highbridge
description: Residents of the Highbridge section of the Bronx, who held high hopes for its preservation a few years back, seem now to have succumbed to a sense of resignation, a reluctant conclusion that the community's best days have ended for good.

title: Survey Finds Company Gifts to Charity Dipped as Profits Rose Between 197274
description: Corporate contributions to charitable causes declined between 1972 and 1974 as a percentage of domestic pretax net income, according to the latest survey by the Conference Board, even though profits in the same period rose by 37.3 percent.

title: The Mayor Goes to Harlem To Thank Good Samaritans
description: In a visit filled with emotion, Mayor Beame and the wives of four injured police officers went to Harlem yesterday to thank residents for the help they gave the men burned and nearly blinded by buckets of lye and ammonia thrown in their faces last Saturday.

title: Advertising
description: John C. Savage, 44 years old, who quit Norman, Craig & KummelNew York in 1970 as an executive vice president, is returning there as president. Thomas K. Myers, also 44, moves up to chairman, having been president for three years.

title: Connally Criticizes Carter As Vacillating Candidate
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 John B. Connally today called Jimmy Carter a maybe I would and maybe I wouldn't candidate and said that Ronald Reagan could learn something about acting from the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: Labor and Industry Teaming Up in Bangalore to Raise Output Under Mrs. Gandhi's Emergency Rules
description: BANGALORE, India, Aug. 1In this industrial city of two million in the southern highlands, leaders of industry and labor, militantly at odds until a year ago, are united now in praising the results of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's declaration of a state of national emergency in June 1975.

title: WNBCTV PLANS NEW TALK SHOW
description: Not for Women Only, the daily syndicated, series with Barbara Walters that has been in reruns since Miss Walters left NBC in the spring, will probably be replaced by a similar topical talk program in September, with Polly Bergen and Dr. Frank Field as hosts.

title: Music: Miss de Larrocha's Mozart
description: There are a few virtuoso musicians who are somehow able to establish an intimate connection with their listeners without hint of showmanship or flamboyance. Rachmaninoff had this power as a pianist, and so in our day has Andros Segovia, the solemn high priest of the guitar.

title: Linebacker Impresses Giant Coach
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 4The way the Giants offense and defense treat each other, this town is more like Peyton Place then the pastorally named home of the Reader's Digest.

title: Group E Hort Helps Crash Victim Get to a Burn Center in Rochester
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., Aug. 4A critically burned planecrash victim, a doctor and a nurse were flown from Westchester County Airport to a Rochester hospital today in a donated airplane acquired through the efforts of hospital personnel, county residents and an aircraft company.

title: Justice Marshall Will Get The Family of Man Award
description: The annual Family of Man Human Relations Award of the Council of Churches of New York City will be presented to Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court, it was announced yesterday.

title: C.I.A. CONSIDERED BIG LSD PURCHASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Central Intelligence Agency in 1953 discussed purchasing 10 kilograms of LSD, enough for 100 million doses and worth $240,000, for use in its drug experimentation with animals and human beings, according to newly released agency docurnents.

title: Plane Lands on One Wheel
description: MIAMI, Aug. 4 (AP)A National Airlines Boeing 727 carrying seven crew members but no passengers landed at Miami International Airport early today with one wheel stuck in the up position. officials said. There were no injuries. The flight originated at Kennedy International Airport in New York.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American stock exchange issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stockownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the followine:

title: Bridge
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 4 A young New York expert scored a convincing victory in the life master Pair championship here in the early hours of this morning, collecting his first national title.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Rangers announced yesterday that Phil Esposito, center, and Carol Vadnais, defenseman, had both accepted Invitations to compete for Team Canada in the upcoming Canada Cup international hockey series. They will report on Monday to the Team Canada training camp in Montreal for the sixnation roundrobin series that runs Sept. 2 through Sept. 17. Besides Canada, teams from the United States, Sweden, Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union and Finland are competing.

title: Train is Held Speeding Before Crash
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 4The crowded commuter train that crashed here last month was traveling at up to more than twice the posted speed limit at the time of impact, technical experts testified here today at public investigative hearings into the accident.

title: Phone Number Set Up For MedicalAid Calls
description: The Mayor's Emergency Contingency Committee set Up a special control center to receive calls about medical service during the strike.

title: CoalLeasing Reform Bill Enacted Over Ford Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)  The House gave President Ford his 10th veto setback to day by overriding his action to kill legislation on reform of coal leasing.

title: 3 Guilty in Bank Robbery
description: NEWARK, Aug. 4 (AP)A Federal jury has convicted three men in a $70,000 Sayreville bank robbery. Found guilty here yesterday were Clyde Parker, 29 years old, of Newark; Thomas E. Reese Jr. of East Orange and Marcus Sheffey, 37, of Old Bridge. Witnesses testified that the three robbed the Heritage Bank North of teller's cash at gunpoint in 1974 and fled in a stolen auto.

title: Utility Man Gives Orioles a Spark
description: Doug DeCinces (pronounced DeSinsay) lists among his hobbies golf, photography, refinishing antiques and breeding German shepherds.

title: HIRSCHFELD CITES HOUSING DELAYS
description: Abe Hirschfeld, the businessman who is one of five contenders for the Democratic Senate nomination, said yesterday that housing construction in New York City was hampered by government bureaucracy and urged public officials to let the builders go ahead and build.

title: STATE TAKEOVER OF COURT COSTS VOTED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5After a long night and day of partisan squabbling, the State Legislature passed a bill tonight that requires the state to assume all costs of county and city courts on a graduated basis over the next four years. Governor Carey signed the bill into law almost immediately.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Village Vanguard is one of the more senior jazz establishments in New York, still doing business downstairs at 178 Seventh Avenue South (AL 54037). It is not dedicated to pretension, just jazz. The decor is forgettable and there is no food worth mentioning. Drinks and jazz is what it offers. This weekend, Friday through Sunday, Art Farmer, the flugelhorn and trumpet virtuoso, will wind up a week's engagement at the Vanguard. Mr. Farmer, born in Iowa and raised in Arizona, has been working out of Vienna for eight years. On his guest stop here, he's onstage with the Roland Hanna Trio. Shows at 10, 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Admission: $4, plus a onedrink minimum per show (you can sit through as many shows as there are).

title: Publishing: Warhol Productions
description: ANDY WARHOL, the pop artist, film maker, author and man about Manhattan, is now going into publishing. An agreement was concluded between Mr. Warhol and Grosset & Dunlap whereby they will jointly publish books under the imprint Andy Warhol Books/ Grosset & Dunlap. Mr. Warhol will have a hand in writing and designing some of the books, which Grosset & Dunlap will then produce and distribute.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 5.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 207.4 from 212.8 last week.

title: Raga in the Cathedral, Dusk To Dawn
description: RAVI SHANKAR will begin playing raga very early tomorrow morning inside the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in a dusktodawn program of Indian music. As he brushes the strings of his sitar, producing the shimmering resonance so characteristic of his music, he will be celebrating an auspicious occasion, the 20th anniversary of his performances of Indian music in the United States.

title: Assembly Fails to Act on Rebate Bill, Leaving State Income Tax Inoperative
description: TRENTON, Aug. 5New Jersey's personal income tax law, approved by the Legislature last month and signed by the Governor, remained inoperative today after the Assembly failed to approve a plan for rebate of property taxes to tenants that would have activated the income tax.

title: Snappers, Caught Easily, Are Abundant
description: This is the time of year when the bluefish born offshore in June crowd river mouths, bays and estuaries in search of food and to escape larger predatory fishincluding their own parents.

title: FORD WILL DELAY FILLING NO.2 SPOT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The White House said today that President Ford would announce his choice of a running mate in the traditional way, waiting until he had been nominated for President at the Republican National Convention.

title: Sudan Executes 17 More in Coup Attempt
description: CAIRO, Aug. 5Seventeen persons accused of having taken part in the July coup attempt against President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan were executed by firing squad at dawn today, the Sudanese Government announced. Yesterday, 81 were executed and 210 persons are still on trial.

title: 17 Yugoslav Miners Killed
description: BREZA, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5 (AP)An explosion killed 1 miners 600 feet underground here early today, the official press agency Tanyug reported. Ten of the 101 miners who escaped were slightly hurt, doctors said.

title: Court Rules Japanese Military Is Legal
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5In the latest legal decision in Japan's longestrunning controversy, a High Court panel of judges ruled today that this country's maintenance of military forces is legal.

title: Jolley and Baeza End Their Ties After a Disagreement at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.. Aug. 5LeRoy Jolley and Braulio Baeza have finally decided to end their trainerjockey association. An exchange of words after yesterday's ninth race At the here led today to the breakup. Race Jolley reportedly Tracks was dissatisfied with the way Baeza had ridden Walnut Hill Farm's Latrobe, an evenmoney shot who had finished second after having held an early lead.

title: Sugar Prices Off Sharply On French Crop Report
description: Prices of sugar futures declined sharply on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, following a report about better  than  expected yields for French sugar beets. The October delivery closed at 11.84 cents a pound, down from 12.30 cents.

title: The Labor Scene
description: When the nation's coal miners struck for 24 days in 1974 before ratifying a contract that promised to push up wages and benefits by nearly twothirds over three years, much of the delay stemmed from rankandfile objections to the absence of a contract clause empowering locals to strike whenever a grievance wasn't being settled to their satisfaction.

title: As a Fashion Show, It Was a Good Party
description: They didn't show any clothes! exclaimed Lionel Lamer, a theatrical agent, who was one of the mob of 2,000 who turned up for a bash given by the men's clothing division of Yves Saint Latirent. It was twice as long as World War II. Mr. Lerner, a former Londoner, added that you could look in the windows of that city's Jermyn Street and see more men's fashions than appeared on stage.

title: Defendants in Mosque Shooting Ask Judge to Vacate Gag Order
description: Defense lawyers in the case of the 1972 Harlem mosque shooting said yesterday that the presiding judge's order prohibiting them from discussing the case with the press was unconstitutional and they asked him to vacate it.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Another attempt by black South African students to march the nine miles from the township of Soweto to hold a protest in front of Johannesburg police headquarters was halted yesterday when policemen fired over the heads of the marchers. Many adults joined in the march. One student was reportedly carried from the scene after the shots were fired, but the police denied that there had been casualties. Earlier, they confirmed reports that three blacks were killed during the disturbances in Soweto on Wednesday. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Court Reorganization Troubles Supporters and Opponents Alike
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5Last night, in the closeddoor Democratic caucus, Manfred Ohrenstein, the State Senate's minority leader, asked 20 or so of his colleagues if they favored the court reorganization package hammered out earlier in the day by Governor Carey and legislative leaders.

title: Greeks and Turks Approach a Crisis Again
description: ATHENS, Aug. 5Relations between Greece and Turkey have again approached the boiling point, this time over the dispatch of a Turkish research vessel into the Aegean Sea, which separates these two ancient enemies. Both countries seem reluctant to turn up the heat any higher but to prefer to keep the battle on a verbal level. In such an emotionally charged atmosphere, however, the danger of a mistake or miscalculation remains high.

title: How to Get There
