description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 6Police riot squads opened fire in Soweto today to disperse crowds of youths who roamed the black township attacking cars, buses and trains in a continuing effort to keep black workers from their jobs in Johannesburg.

title: Dance
description: The Nikolais Dance Theater continues on its genuinely merry way at the Beacon Theater through Aug. 15. For some reason the performances have a new vigor. The old works seem refreshed and the new ones have a sense of originality, rather than recycled oast ideas.

title: Gay Roberts Is Wed To Jack L. Green
description: Gay Roberts Hausfater was married yesterday evening to Jack L. Green, of New York, a vice president and director in international operations for International Creative Management.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
description: FIRSTS3,000, pace, mile.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)Alcohol may some day become a valuable fuel to help solve United States energy problems but production costs must first be greatly reduced, the oil industry said today. A new report by an American Petroleum Institute task force said the best use of alcohol as a future replacement for conventional fuel might be in powering stationary gas turbines. Alcohol might also be used as a substitute for gasoline in cars, it said.

title: Missing WitnessTurns Up In Hurricane Carter Case
description: A missing witness in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter triplemurder case voluntarily appeared at the Passaic County, N.J., Prosecutor's office in Paterson yesterday, and a warrant for his arrest was quickly dropped.

title: New York City Gets $102 Million In Community Development Aid
description: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development approved a $102.2 million grant to New York City yesterday under the 1974 Community Development Act.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Aug. 5, 1976 In bushels, 000 omitted.) Wed.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The New York Times/Jack Manning

title: LUNCH PROGRAM IS TERMED BIASED
description: Some black sponsors of the Summer Food Service for Needy Children charged yesterday that they were being unfairly penalized because of abuses by others. They asked a voice in next year's policy decisions regarding the program.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: FIRST GAME

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The speed limit will be reduced on the tracks near last month's fatal train collision in New Canaan, Conn., pending the outcome of state and Federal investigations. Starting Monday, all trains must stop at a yellow warning light on the approach to the New Canaan station and then finish the approach at no more than 5 miles per hour, the State Transportation Commissioner, James F. Shugrue, ordered. The yellow light, which will soon be replaced by a more sophisticated warning light, now limits the station approach to 15 m.p.h.

title: S.E.C. May End Need for Immediate Confirmation In Writing by Stockbrokers for Some Transactions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Securities and Exchange Commission may relieve stockbrokers of the requirement that they send customers immediate written confirmations of every transaction, its chairman, Roderick M. Hills, told a Senate Securities subcommittee today.

title: OPEC PLEDGES AID OF $800 MILLION
description: VIENNA, Aug. 6 (AP)Finance ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pledged today to take the necessary measures soon to provide 5800 million in assistance to developing countries.

title: L.I. Judge Remembers And 2 Suspects Suffer
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., Aug. 6 A Nassau County District Court Judge who helped pass a law two years ago when he sat on the Oyster Bay Town Council, got a chance to enforce that law early this morning.

title: Cabaret
description: Amidst the Greek, Israeli and general Mediterranean revelry that customarily prevails at the Sirocco, Aris San's GreekIsraeli restaurant and nightclub at 29 East 29th Street, a different note is currently being struck by Irene Raico. Miss Raico, who is 21 years old, was born in Zaire, in Stanleyville (when it was still the Belgian Congo) of a Congolese mother and a Greek father. Her parents took her to Greece when she was 8, so she has grown up in a Greek atmosphere but with an African heritage.

title: The Issue: Apartheid
description: When Secretary of State Kissinger told the Urban League this week that the risks of confrontation were rising in southern Africa and that time is running out fOr halting the escalation of violence in that area, he may not have anticipated how quickly events would underscore his assessment. He was referring primarily to combustible situations in Rhodesia and Namibia (SouthWest Africa), but portentous explosions came in South Africa.

title: LIGGETT IS TO BUY DIVERSIFIED CORP
description: The Liggert Group Inc., formerly Liggett & Myers Inc.. announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge the Diversified Products Corporation of Opelika, Ala., into Ligget t through an exchange of stock valued at about $26.3 million. For the merger about 760,000 shares of Liggett common would be issued in exchange for all the 1.6 million shares of Diversified. Upon competion of the merger, Diversified woul operate under its present management as a wholly owned subsidiary of the Liggett Group.

title: Beame Says U.S. Will Decide On Westway Route Before 77
description: Mayor Beame won a commitment yesterday in Washington from William T. Coleman, Secretary of Transportation, to try to accept or reject the city's proposal for a $1.1 billion West Side highway before the end of the year.

title: Carter Takes the Plunge And Nets Barrel of Fish
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 6Jimmy Carter drained a farm pond today, caught a barrel full of fish from it and dismissed a suggestion by the Vice President of the United States that he was ruthless.

title: Swedish Nurse Recalls Ordeals at Tell Zaatar
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6My husband and I were staying at his parents house when a rocket fell on us last June 13, Eva Stahl a 27yearold Swedish nurse who had been in an embattled Palestinian camp for 20 months, said in an interview today.

title: MARK EDGES UP; FRANCS WEAKEN
description: LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP)The West German mark edged upward against the dollar today on European currency exchanges, while the Belgian and French francs weakened.

title: Unusual Doctor and Bureaucrat
description: Dr. Leonard Bachman, the man directing the effort to identify the mystery illness that has caused 25 deaths in Pennsylvania, has established a reputation as an unusual doctor and an unusual bureaucrat. The 51yearold anesthesiologist is a medical activist who has managed to infuriate doctors and hospital administrators with his insistent demands that they join him in his efforts, as Pennsylvania Secretary of Health, to insure what he considers proper health care for all Pennsylvanians.

title: Mark Up
description: The West German mark edged upward against the dollar in Europe while the Belgian and French francs weakened. Gold prices rose but South African gold mining shares in London hit a threeyear low. Page 27.

title: Justice Department Opposes Veto Plan on Election Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) The Justice Department went to court today to challenge the constitutionality of the law allowing a single house of Congress to veto regulatioris proposed by the Federal Election Commission.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday said Agudath Israel sponsored a number of daycare centers. A spokesman for the organization said it was active in centers for the elderly and in education, but not in day care.

title: Gen. M. G. Baker Dead
description: Military funeral services were held yesterday at the Valley Forge Military Academy and Junior College for Lieut. Gen. Milton G. Baker, who founded the institution in Wayne, Pa., in 1928 and retired as supetintendent in 1971. His age was 79.

title: Sears Hails Reagan's Gains in Jersey
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 6John P. Sears, Ronald Reagan's national campaign manager, said today that he was delighted when four of New Jersey's 67 delegates to the Republican National Convention announced their support for Mr. Reagan last night.

title: Murder Trial Gag Order Puzzling to Other Judges
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice who this week limited press coverage of a murder trial has puzzled his colleagues on the bench and lawyers who regularly practice in criminal courts.

title: Nationalized Leyland Sputters a Bit More Smoothly
description: LONDON, Aug. 6At 11 A.M. each day a report is placed on the desk of Alexander Park, the 49yearold Yorkshireman who runs the sprawling British automotive colossus that makes Jaguars, Triumphs, MG's and Rovers. It's not a financial report that Mr. Park gets. It's a strike report.

title: Retiring New York City's Debt
description: A great many solutions have been made over the last year for bringing New York City back to financial health. Some have been useful, some not so helpful. But almost all of them overlook a key method of reducing the city's tax levy expense budget: New York City must begin retiring its debt.

title: NEW YORK STATE LOSES A WINDFALL
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6New York State, which expected a $22 million windfall from enactment of New Jersey's personalincome tax because of a provision repealing commuter taxes on New York State residents who work in New Jersey, will not get the extra money after all.

title: Soldier Sentenced to Life In Slaying on Army Base
description: FORT LEE, Va., Aug. 6 (AP) An Army man who had admitted he fired the shots that killed a fellow soldier here May 6 was found guilty of felony murder by his military judge today.

title: Dr. Willa H. Elton, 33, Of Lehman Faculty, Dies
description: Dr. Willa H. Elton, assistant professor of Spanish literature at Lehman College, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital following a long illness. She was 33 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: 90,000 COAL MINERS NOW IDLE IN STRIKE
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 3 (AP) More members of the United Mine Workers joined in a wildcat strike of coal miners today as union leaders called two meetings to discuss the spreading work stoppage and a Federal judge signed an order calling for arbitration.

title: Italy's New Government Wins A Vote of Confidence in Senate
description: ROME, Aug. 6The Italian Senate tonight voted confidence in the new minority Christian Democratic Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti. The Chamber of Deputies was expected to followsuit around the middle of next week enabling Mr. Andreotti's Cabinet to begin functioning.

title: Stavisky Bill Given Its Day in Court
description: Lawyers for New York City and the Board of Education, who are usually on the same side, were adversaries yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Sets Top Nets; Cabbie Beaten
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug. 6 Howie the Cab Driver lost, but the New York Sets won tonight and improved their World Team Tennis record to 2910, best in the league.

title: Catholic Women Protest Over a Mass for Military
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP)Symbolizing their dismay at a military mass here at the International Eucharistic Congress, 8,000 women stood silent in penetential prayer today for victims of war and the military system.

title: News Summary and Index
description: South African police riot squads opened fire in Soweto yesterday in an attempt to break up crowds of youths who roamed the black township, attacking cars, buses and trains in a continuing effort to keep black workers from their jobs in Johannesburg. On the third day of disturbances, the official toll was 4 dead and 30 wounded. A national police alert was ordered following reports of arson and stonethrowing from widely scattered other townships. [Page 1, Column 2.]

title: Opposition State Is Docile Since New Delhi Takeover
description: MADRAS, India  Nowhere is the docility with which the people of India have accepted Prime Minister. Indira Gandhi's 13monthold assumption of nearly full powers so striking as here in the state of Tamil Nadu, in the far south.

title: Three Named to Parole Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) President Ford announced today his intention to nominate three persons to serve on the United States Parole Commission. They are Curtis C. Crawford, a Silver Spring, Md., lawyer; Paula A. Tennant, a Burlingame, Calif., lawyer; and Dorothy Parker, a lawyer on the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Refugees.

title: Beyond the Hospital Strike
description: The strike of municipal hospital workers here is a nowin confrontation that has tragic implications extending far beyond the confines of this troubled city.

description: Ronald McDonald, the redwigged Clown who represents a certain hamburger chain, visited the West Side Branch of the Y.M.C.A. yesterday and taught 60 youngsters the art of clowning around.

title: A Movement to Oust Schweiker From Reagan Ticket Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Among some delegates, party activists and a few senators who are supporters of Ronald Reagan's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, there have been recent conversations about an effort to remove Senator Richard S. Schweiker from the Reagan ticket, Senator James A. McClure, an Idaho Republican and Reagan supporter, said tonight.

title: East Germany Apologizes For Fatal Shooting of Italian
description: EAST BERLIN, Aug. 6The East German Government apologized to Italy today over the killing of an Italian by an East German border guard yesterday morning at a highway crossing between East and West Germany.

title: Pro Transactions
description: NEW YORK (AL)Recalled Ron Guidry, pitcher, from Syracuse of the International League. Assigned Jim York, pitcher, to Syracuse.

title: Schweiker Reports New Delegate Gains
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6Senator Richard S. Schweiker said today that he and Ronald Reagan had picked up new commitments from an unspecified number of Republican delegates in his home state of Pennsylvania. But he steadfastly declined to name them.

title: 37 Die in Korea Landslide
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug, 6 (Agence FrancePresse)  At least 37 persons were killed today when a landslide buried a small temple on a mountain slope near Wanju. 120 tnilesi south of here the police ported. Twenty bodies have been recovered and the police believe more were buried under rocks that smashed the wooden structure where the people were praying.

title: Rice Price Supports Raised For the 1976 Crop by 3%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Final rice support prices for the 1976 crop have been raised 3 percent above preliminary rates announced in April, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

title: Post Faculty Panel To Weigh Charges Of Falsified Credits
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Aug. 6The president of the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University said today that a faculty review committee would be convened within a week to 10 days to decide how to deal with an alleged scheme in which faculty members were given credit for courses that they had never taken.

title: ANTHONY L. MELUCCI
description: Dr. Anthony L. Melucci, a chiropractor, of 2214 82d Street, Brooklyn, died Thursday in Veteran's Hospital, Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, after a heart attack. His age was 80.

title: 2 From L.I. Die in Accident
description: HAWTHORNE, N.Y. Aug. 6 (AP)  Two young motorists from Long Island were killed yesterday when their car struck two trees and burst into flames beside Interstate 287, near Harrison in Westchester County. The victims were identified as James Stone 3d, 19 years old, and Heidi Nystrom, 17, both of Massapequa. The police said young Stone had been driving the car.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6Tbe Lebanese civil war has gone on for 16 months. More than 20,000 people have been lolled and many more have been maimed. More than $2 billion in public property has been destroyed; the damage in private property is even greater. Former friends have become enemies and enemies friends.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State officials reported that two Rahway State Prison inmates had been charged with illegal possession of narcotics, including heroin. A state public information office Official said a third inmate had been charged with possession of contraband, specifically money, following searches of the cells of the three inmates by a special investigation unit of correction officers. The search Thursday allegedly produced three packets of heroin hidden in a deck of cards in the cell of Robert Harris, 27 years old, of Newark, and 20 packets of heroin, narcotics paraphenalia and about 200 as yet unidentified pills in the celly of Jerome J. Miller of Passaic. The third inmate, Thomas Mosley, 32, of Newwark, serving a maximum 25year sentence for murder, was charged with possession of $25. Cash is barred to inmates.

title: TREASURY SELLS $1 BILLION ISSUE

With this bond sale, the Federal Government's debt managers successfully completed $10.6 billion of intermediate and longterm borrowing this week to refund $4.5 billion of maturing securities and to raise $6.1 billion of additional cash to help finance the gap between the nation's income and spendine.

title: Energy Growth, It Is Argued, Does Not Lead to More Jobs
description: WASHINGTONRonald Reagan recently told the Detroit Economic Club that a shift to energyefficient small cars would cost at least 200,000 Michigan workers their jobs. The executive council of the AFLCIO has called for sustained energy growth in order to promote high employment, a dynamic economy, and a prosperous and satisfying way of life. Advertisements by major energy companies have repeatedly asserted that reduced fuel consumption would generate widespread unemployment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times on its July 22 OpEd page published an article by Gen. Sidney B. Berry, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, on alleged cadet cheating. The article seemed more interesting because of what it did not say than for what it said. But it raised the fundamental issue of Why?

title: Rumanian Asks U.S. Asylum

The officer, who was identified only as Vladimir Moisuc, was a crew member aboard the Mircea, one of the tall ships that visited the city last month.

Bill Britton, Greg Zorila, Dave Muraskin and Jerry Courville, who among them have won two Metropolitan, five Westchester and one New Jersey amateur titles, plus six Ike golf tourneys, became the semifinalists of the 74th annual Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship today.

title: Screen: Disney's 'Gus':Mule's Football Goals Aid Hopeless Team
description: The great mass of Walt Disney movies over the last dozen years are like airline meals. To be fair, they are like airline meals served on airlines that still make a little effort, providing a piece of fresh fruit, a tube of mustard to adorn the edible cardboard.The point is that both Disney movies and tray lunches at 20,000 feet have one thing in common. They are not experienced, at least by adults, for their own sake. Nobody, trying to pick a lunch spot, flies to London for the sake of the in-flight pressed meat or even the apple. Very few sane adults would go see even a decently average Disney film such as "Gus" unless they needed to build up moral leverage with an underage domestic pressure group."Gus," which opened yesterday at the Kips Bay, Festival and other theaters, is about a ludicrously incompetent football team. Some of the incompetencies, such as a pass receiver who looks the other way when the ball finally arrives, are pretty funny. Finally, the team owner hires a Yugoslav mule and its Yugoslav handler.The mule kicks field goals unerringly and the team gets to the Superbowl on the basis of field goals. This makes a man who has bet against the team very unhappy and he hires two criminals to get in the way. They get the mule drunk and kidnap first the mule handler and then the mule itself. It will destroy no potential spectator's sense of suspense to say that they fail.As I say, this is a decently average Disney film, with a few funny parts and other parts where you would agree to smile if you could. Where the movie tries the hardest, it fails the most, as in a terribly long and trite comedy sequence in a supermarket.There is a good performance by Edward Asner as the sulphuric team owner and a very good one by Don Knotts as his shrivelled chief coach.

title: Penn Central Transportation
description: The Penn Central Transportation had an income of $1.1 million in June, but expenses of $8.6 million left the net loss for the month at $7.5 million, its report showed yesterday. No comparative figures are available for the yearearlier period because last April 1, the company's major asset, the Penn Central Railroad, was turned over to a new corporation, drastically changing the nature of Penn Central Transportation's business. title: Sniping at Wounded Halts Evacuation at Beirut Camp

title: Regulating Regulations
description: The old adage had it that the law is what the Supreme Court says it is. A more modern and accurate version is that the law is what the bureaucrats say it is, until, and unless their version is challenged in the courts.

title: Certainly Not Another Franco But Not a Lenin, Either
description: PARISMadrid's Government has indicated to Santiago Carrillo, secretary general of the Spanish Communist Party, that it will very shortly decide whether he will be allowed to return openly and legally to Spain. He applied here this week for a Spanish passport. He was most courteously received by the Ambassador, although he and his party are still banned as illegal, but it was intimated a decision will probably be taken at a cabinet meeting Tuesday.

title: Dead Fliers Identified
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 7 (AP)  Officials released today the identities of two naval aviators killed when their F4 Phantom jet fighter crashed yesterday in the Gulf of Mexico. The crewmen were identified as Lieut. Thomas N. O'Connor of Virginia Beach, Va., the pilot and Lieut. Edward B. Carroll Jr., a radar intercept officer from Key West.

title: Plane With Marijuana Crashes After Gunfight
description: NORTH PORT, Ha., Aug. 7 (UPI)A man, angered when an airplane occupant started shooting at him, fired back with his shotgun, causing the plane to crash on takeoff last night. The authorities discovered the plane had been loaded with marijuana.

title: TESTS BY VIKING STRENGTHEN HINT OF LIFE ON MARS
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 7The latest test of a Martian soil sample aboard the Viking lander has turned up the strongest indication to date of biological activity on another planet, scientists announced here today.

description: The long Lincoln Center season by American Ballet Theaterthree weeks at the Metropolitan Opera House followed by six weeks at the New York State Theaterfinally came to an end last night. There were surprises right up until almost the last minute.

title: Teams Fit to Be Tied
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 7 (UPI)South Korea finally overcame Senegal, 76, today in an unusually lengthy soccer match lasting 130 minutes in the quarterfinals of the fifth World University tournament. At the end of the second half the teams were tied, 2.2, so accordance with the rules they played another 30minute period. The teams were still tied, 3.3, so they were given five penalty shots each. Again the teams performed equally, each making three of the five shots to tie, 66.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: LEONIA is a cozy square mile of 8,000 souls on a verdant slope overlooking the Overpeck Meadowlands, just about three miles inland from the George Washington Bridge. Leonia also enjoys the lopsided reputation in Bergen County of having a halfdozen liquor stores, but not one blessed bar.

title: Tinkertoying With the 20th Century
description: First, I am not a disinterested reviewer. Four of these chronicles were published in the Book Review, as Guest Words, during the period in which, for unspecified sins, I did time as editor. (Others appeared in The New Yorker, TriQuarterly, Antioch, Antaeus, Encounter, Translation and The Scotsman.) One of the advantages of being editorI can't, as a matter of fact, think of any otheris that yours is the only sense of humor that counts. I'm Captain Kangaroo, and it's my program. The staff was not amused, having Western civilization to worry about. Not a single reader troubled to write, in protest or approval. Let them butter their parsnips.

title: SmallTown Dogs Get the Word To Buckle UP
description: LEWISBORO, N. Y.  City dog owners, standing impatiently at one end of a leash night after night, sometimes have a fantasy about the suburbs: that they own a little place in the country, where the dog can roam wild and free, bounding through tall grass and living the way animals were meant to live.

title: PEOPLE
description: MOST people have heard of family publishing firms like the old Harper & Bros., Charles Scribner's Sons, P. J. Kenedy & Sons, and G. Putnam's Sons. But has anyone heard of the textbookpublishing firm of Thomas Horton & Daughters? Let it be known that Mr. Horton founded the operation, with the help of his wife Ann, and their daughters Lee Ann, Marcia, and Karen, in 1972, with one title, and by the end of this year will be offering 10 titles to colleges all over the country. Among those using Thomas Horton & Daughters textbooks are Rutgers, Seton Hall, and St. Peter's College in Jersey City. The Horton company, which operates out of the family home in Glen Ridge, offers books by several writers, including the nationally known economists, Milton Friedman and Paul A. Samuelson.

Its streets have borne the tread of Founding Fathers, its skies have been pierced by those very bombs bursting in air over Fort McHenry that inspired The StarSpanCad Bann:. For most of its 250 years, this city of just under million has lain in the shadow of bigger and betterknown neighborsPhiladelphia, 100 miles to the north; Washington, barely 40 miles south. But Baltimore is holding its head higher these days.

title: For Starters, Paddle Someone Else's Rig
description: FOR the family that is not prepared to rush into canoeingand that probably applies to mostthere are a growing number of comprehensive livery services that offer an introduction to some of the nation's most exciting waterways without any significant investment of money. One of them is run by Bob Trowbridge, who keeps about 500 canoes on the Russian River, just north of San Francisco. His phone number is 7075420598. He has arranged to have buses bring in canoeists from San Francisco in the morning, then meet them downstream at the end of the day. As one observer put it, the canoes begin as if they were waiting for the opening gun at Le Mans, but soon spread out for remarkably tranquil run down the river.

title: Browns Set Back Falcons, 317
description: STILLWATER, Okla., Aug. 7 (AP)Greg Pruitt ran 38 yards for a touchdown on Cleveland's first play from scrimmage and the Browns went on to a 317 victory over the Atlanta Falcons in a preseason game today.

description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 Nino Espinosa did what Tom Seaver couldn't tonight at Three Rivers Stadium as the Mets split a doubleheader with the Pirates.

title: DROUGHT EFFECTS SPREAD IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Aug. 7The prolonged drought, the worst in Europe in 250 years of record keeping, has become so acute in Britain that it is beginning to spread from the many arid farmlands to homes and factories.

title: Woman and Fiance Parted
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 7 I (AP)A Circuit Court judge in this Washington suburb sent a young pregnant woman to jail until she agreed to stop living with her fiance. Judge Paul D. Brown's order came yesterday in the case of Karen Ann Caudell, IS years old, who was in court to plead guilty in a petty larceny case. After three hours, she found another place to live, and was freed.

title: A Tourist Primer: Buying Art Abroad Is an Art in Itself
description: We all seek, on our trips to anywhere, some memorable object to take home, to enjoy long after the trip itself has become a nostalgic blur. Too often, memorable translates as a quaint yodeler's horn, a replica of an Ifugao tribesman's shield or a stool made from the foot of a rogue elephant.

title: Michael Kearns Sheila Culligan, Plan Marriage
description: Sheila Patricia Culligan and Michael J. Kearns, graduates of the University of Notre Dame, will be married in October. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Culligan of Franklin Lakes, N.J. Mr. Kearns is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Kearns of Sioux Falls, S.D., and Palm Springs,

title: The Revolutionary Ascetic
description: Bruce Mazlish is a prominent practitioner of the art of psychohistory. The trick in doing psychohistory is to get the proportions rightto trace the labyrinthine connections between personality on the one side and historical event and setting on tne otner, witnout reducing history to psychology or submerging mind and character in the subconscious. In one of his earlier studies, Professor Mazlish examined the deadly oedipal dance of James and John Stuart Mill. In another, he probed the secret life of former President Nixon. Now he turns to one of the most striking political character types of our time, the revolutionary ascetic.

title: Letitia M. Cox Has Nuptials

title: The Gospel and Mr. Hawk
description: LEXINGTON, Mass.Two decades ago, Thomas L. Phillips headed a military project, the Hawk system, for the Raytheon Company, of which he is now chairman and chief executive officer. It's still paying off. Raytheon in May got a $1.14 billion, fiveyear contract to supply Saudi Arabia the Hawk groundtoair missile systemone of the largest single defense contracts in the Middle East.

title: Book Ends
description: Zennis Anyone? According to Tennis magazine there are about 21.5million Americans over 15 who play tennis, and they spend in excess of a halfbillion dollars annually on clothes and equipment. Long before the nation entered the current tennis boom, publishers were producing books teaching the game, and back in 1903 the Book Review published reviews of three books on tennisor more properly lawn tennis, as it used to be called. Through the years publishers have signed up tennis stars to write books imparting their secrets to weekend hackers, beginning with Bill Tilden's The Art of Lawn Tennis in 1921, on through Suzanne Lenglen, Helen Hull Jacobs, Don Budge, Alice Marble, Jack Kramer and up to Billie Jean King. Ken Rosewall and other contemporaries.

title: Dr. Benjamin W Dies at 96; Taught at Columbia and Toronto

title: Power Failure in Maine
description: PRESQUE ISLE, Maine, Aug. 7 (AP)A mysterious power failure left residents of Aroostook County without electricity for about a halfhour today. The Maine Public Service Company said that the power went off at 11:23 A.M. and was restored 32 minutes later.

title: 5 TeenAgers Die in Crash
description: FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., Aug. 7 (AP)Five teenagers were killed early today when the car they were riding in crashed into a bridge abutment near here, the Whitemarsh Township police said. The victims were the driver, Michiel Klales; Teresa Patterson, Carl Reiner, John Dupont and Timothy Hummel. Officer Carl March said that the victims had been stopped by township police, for questioning but drove off at high speed.

title: PEOPLE; Meet the Stars ($10, Please)
description: MONTAUK MANOR was the scene last weekend for its annual GreeneryScenery Cocktail Party, at which 800 partygoers paid $10 each to meet 23 East End celebrities and contribute funds for the beautification of Montauk. The celebrities included Edward Albee, the playwright; Martin Gottfried, Clive Barnes and Craig Claiborne, the critics; Jimmy Dean, the singer, Elia Kazan, the directornovelist; James Lipton, Robert Alan Aurthur and Roger Caras, the writers; Balcomb Greene and Frank Borth, the artists; Martin Bregman, the film producer; Peter Beard, the photographer, and Dick Cavett, the comedian. Why am I here every year? asked Mr. Cavett. Because Bettie Duryea (the wife of the State Assembly minority leader, Perry B. Duryea) threatens to publish her diary it I don't show up.

title: Criminals At Large
description: When Lillian O'Donnell started her Norah Mulcahaney series, about five years ago, a real character was created. Norah, a young policewoman in the New York Police Department, was a handsome (not pretty), hardworking (not brilliant) cop who had to fight for everything she got and insisted on her rights. There was an air of realism about the Department and the City of New York and, indeed, the entire milieu. O'Donnell's work reads as good reporter's should: objective, logical, clear, accurate in presentation.

title: Fromm Composers At Tanglewood Represent Many Countries
description: The concerts of contemporary music sponsored by the Fromm Foundation at Tanglewood have long been an important part of the Berkshire Music Festival. The five days of concentrated newmusic performances start this year on Aug. 14 and represent a broad range of nationalities, including works not only by American composers but by two Greeics, an Italian, a Moroccan, a JapaneseAmerican, a Cambodian, a native of Edinburgh (Thee Musgrave) and a French American. This last is Betsy Jolas, the festival's summerlong composer in residence, who was born in Paris of American parents, educated in America and in France, and is now a professor at the Paris Conservatoire. Her D'un Opera de Voyage for chamber orchestra will be performed on Aug. 15, and two unaccompanied flute works on the following day.

title: The return of John Connally
description: HOUSTONIn the final days of July, as united and ebullient Democrats ordered their inaugural gowns, and divided and embattled Republicans staggered toward Kansas City, John Connally's wife, Nellie, laid down the law at their Picosa Ranch near Floresville. He could clean out tool sheds, fix squeaky doors, tend his luxuriant herd of Santa Gertrudis cattle, help his son, Mark, the ranch manager, plan the fall breeding program, but: No politics for three weeks. After all, politics had consumed her husband's life and kept him on the road for the entire past year.

title: Rizzo Recall Data Given
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) About 72 percent of the signatures on the petitions to recall Mayor Frank L. Rizzo are from registered city voters, according to partial figures released today hy the city board of elections. If the figures hold true, the recall movement should have al, least 152,000 valid signatures, 7,000 more than needed to force Mr. Rizzo to resign or face a special election.

description: MANHASSET, Aug. 7Clams from Manhasset Bay, an area that has been closed to private shelltishing for more than 10 years, are now being harvested and moved to Great South Bay. There they clean themselves of pollutants and axe used as breeding stock.

title: What's With O.J., Pete?
description: Stubbornly, the National Football League has hidden its Hope Diamond in a cave. O.J. Simpson won't play football this season unless Ralph Wilson, the owner of the Buffalo Bills, completes a trade soon with either the Los Angeles Rams or the Oakland Raiders, the only two teams to pursue the running back. It's unthinkable for the N.F.L. to be without Sports O.J. Simpson, its most spectacular performer of at his peak at 29 years The Times old, simply because owners are unable to agree on his value. As the commissioner, it is Pete Rozelle's responsibility to keep O.J. Simpson in football.

title: Geraniums Can Be Trained Into Decorative Trees
description: When the summer calendar rounds the corner and turns into August, a quiet sort of panic sets in. Gardeners realize there are only five weeks left until Labor Day and the growing season will start sliding into a slow decline. The days are numbered for those lovely geraniums in the window boxes, on the terrace and out in the flower borders.

description: ON Jan. 13 I filed legislation that would reinstate capital punishment in the State of New Jersey. Under my proposed legislation the death penalty would be reinstated for firstdegree murder, kidnapping, attempted assassination of the President, Vice President, other heads of government and for treason.

description: CRANSTON, R.I., Aug. 7 (AP) A disturbance at the Adult Correctional Institution here tonight was brought under control by riotequipped policemen two hours after it began.

title: CHESS
description: Of the various functions a second is expected to carry out  analyzing adjourned game positions, casing the opponent's repertoire, making sure that his principal shows up at the right time for every sessionthe most difficult and most important is his help in choosing his principal's openings arsenal. Indeed, players in general try to get a second noted for wide opening knowledge, but a good second must also be able to adapt to his principal's predilections. The worst choice ever for a second was made by the great attacking player Alexander Alekhine in seizing upon the renowned genius of defense Salo Flohr. After Flohr had snorted for the 20th time at Alekhine's gambit ideas, there was nothing to do but throw him out.

title: Tevye Is Coming to Teaneck
description: THERE can be no excuse for boredom this summer in Teaneck, where the Recreation Department offered anyone who wanted it a chance to perform in Fiddler ort the Roof. Nearly 150 residents took advantage of the opportunity, and for the last six weeks they have spent every, night rehearsing scenes, building sets and sewing costumes.

title: The Girl That He Marries
description: Read it and weep. With unrelenting manic ferocity, this savage, sexist, hilarious romance A la Kafka demonstrates the truth of H. L. Mencken's assertion that to be in love is merely to be in a state of perceptual anesthesiato mistake an ordinary young man for a Greek god. Pursuers of ordinary men (is there some other kind?) can hardly afford to miss this cautionary tale.

title: The Schweiker Surprise Alters the Calculations
description: WASHINGTONThe verdict in the political community on Ronald Reagan's choice of Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania as his prospective running mate has been a curious one. In the first five or six days after the California conservative made his selectionsurely the most startling pick since John F. Kennedy chose Lyndon B. Johnsonthe almost universal conclusion was that Mr. Reagan had committed harikari. But since then, the verdict has softened, and some now give him an outside chance.

title: MONDALE TO SEEK VOTE IN 3 REGIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7When Senator Walter F. Mondale begins campaigning in earnest around Labor Day, his schedule is likely to emphasize his appeal to liberal voters and ethnic groups in the industrialized Northeast, the farm belt and the West Coast.

title: A Welfare Mother
description: When I first read Susan Sheehan's profile of a welfare mother in The New Yorker last fall, I was impressed by the sheer amount of journalistic dedication and hard work that had obviously been invested in her portrait of an individual mired in immobile poverty. On second reading, this piece seems to me to be a profoundly disturbing example of the way in which the best journalistic intentions can be thwarted by the barrier between reporters and people who do not hold the same values or enjoy a similar standard of living.

title: SANE Insanity Award Given Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI)SANE, the antinuclear war lobby, says it has presented its third Insanity Award to the Energy Research and Development Administration as a result of reports that the agency cannot find several tons of misplaced nuclear material.

title: Mushroom Hunts For Experts Only
description: Surpassed only by its close relative the truffle as a gourmet food, the mushroom has been used in thousands of recipes past and present. Books have been written explaining and extolling the fungi, but none, not even Robert Graves scholarly and poetic accounts of the phenomenon, has quite succeeded.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Widow. If you have the glums this morning, ponder for a moment the inspiriting story of Mrs. Warren Clark. A decade ago she was living in New York City's Stuyvesant Town when her husband dropped dead of a heart attack, leaving her with five children, including a yearold baby, and no insurance. A striking redhead with only a high school diploma and some TV modeling experience as her credentials, she set out to support her brood.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . tubing, a tractor trailer tube will cost you about $14, new, and $6, used. In New York City, both kinds are sold at General Tire, 835 11th Avenue, and VHE Standard Inc., 261 Delancey Street, in Manhattan, and LibenHansel Tire Corporation, 1732 Webster Avenue, Bronx. For rentals, one must go to tubing country. In Phoenicia, N.Y., the Four Seasons Sporting Goods store charges $3 a day for truck tubes and $2 for smaller models. In the Catskills, try the Camper Center, White Plains Road, Tarrytown. Arlington Sporting Goods has two locations in Poughkeepsie (on Main Street and on the Main Mall). In the Delaware region: Deer Park Sports Center, Port Jervis, and Barryville Kayak in Barryville. On Long Island, Extrasport Inc. in Halesite specializes in kayakers equipment. In New Jersey, Pineland Canoes, on State Route 527 in Toms River, stocks whitewater gear.

title: Headliners
description: By August of 1973 residents of St. Albans, Vt., were sufficiently disturbed by the influx of hippies into their town to hire Paul Lawrence, a police chief in a neighboring town, to work as an undercover narcotics detective. Mr. Lawrence got quick results: Within a year, he had made more than 100 arrests, and other communities were asking him to help with similar problems. But other law enforcemnt officials became suspicious of his methods, because so many of those arrested claimed they were framed, and because a disproportionate number of his arrests were for heroin possession, an unlikely drug of abuse in a small town in Vermont. An investigation resulted In Mr. Lawrence's arrest and conviction on perjury charges; he had in fact framed his defendants. He is now serving a four to eight year term. Last week, a special state commission recommended that those arrested in the 240 cases brought by Mr. Lawrence be pardoned.

description: SUNNINGDALE, England, Aug. 7 (AP)Chako Higuchi of Japan shot a par 74 today and won the European women's golf championship with a 72.hol.. total of 284. She was six strokes ahead of her nearest rivals, Kathy Whitworth and Sandra Palmer.

title: They Share His Views and Approve His Strategem;Reagan's Staff Is Politically Congenial
description: LOS ANGELES  In the beginning when the planning had been in memos with shortsentence paragraphs, and aggressive men with long lists of friends and contributors in Texas, Florida and North Carolina had argued that the winning of the Republican nomination for President was as simple as fielding a candidate, no one in the Ronald Reagan team advisers dreamed that the most harrowing period of the campaign would take place Just one week before the Republican convention.

title: Fashion
description: The latest styles in rainwear are made of sturdy rubber or shiny polyurethanematerials that are truly rainproof, not just waterrepellent. Whether coats or ponchos, the shapes are big and loose enough to go over warm layers when winter comes, and many of them are equipped with protective hoods. The colors are not traditional raincoat beiges but range from yellow to hot pink to mahogany brown. And this rainwear won't be at the cleaner's when the rains fall unexpectedly becaute it just needs to be washed off.

title: A Football Squeeze Play
description: For $100 million, New York has a new baseball field in Yankee Stadium. But the football field there would cause parents of Pop Warner youngsters to picket the place as too dangerous.

title: A HUGE WINDMILL TO BE BUILT BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Two Government agencies have announced plans to build a huge windmill with the potential to generate electric power for an estimated 500 homes.

title: Education
description: Within the next two weeks Governor Carey will name five members to a blueribbon commission whose task will be to recommend a future shape for higher education in New York State.

title: Paces to Richmond, Windshield Wiper
description: YONKERS, Aug. 7Windshield Wiper and Richmond turned in overpowering performances tonight in winning the $43,750 divisions of the Cane Pace Prep at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Food
description: The sale of the new crepemaking gadgets is undoubtedly an index of the popularity of crepes in America today. Although we like crepes as much as anyone, we prefer to use a handydandy, oldfashioned, standard crepe nan. which has fulfilled its function elegantly in French kitchens for, arbitrarily speaking, the past hundred years. One of the best crepe dishes we know is one we dined on a few short years ago aboard the S.S. France before she was taken out of service. The crepes are stuffed with veal and mushrooms and covered with a Mornay sauce. The recipe is that of our valued friend, Henri Le Hudde, for many years in charge of that late, lamented vessel's vast kitchen.

title: Through Detente's Looking Glass
description: SPETSAIS, GreeceRecent Soviet statements and earlier Soviet actions only recently made known indicate that Moscow is again cleverly trying to split a shaky NATO alliance by making the most of Western diplomatic mistakes.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE lineup of Mercedes and Cadillacs in the parking lot at La Petite Auberge on a recent Saturday evening indicated that this Bergen County restaurant attracted patrons accustomed to good things. The food and the atmosphere were, in fact, both good; for some reason, however, the two attractive dining rooms, with their handsome ladderback chairs, were half empty.

title: Trying to Make A Stalinist Sympathetic
description: LONDON

title: Separations
description: Marilyn Hacker's poems have a breezy, loquacious, bouncy toughness to them, ingratiating in spite of their faults. which very likely accounts in part for the two important prizes, the Lamont and the National Book,

title: Stones That Speak With Symbolism
description: No one really knows who first held a beautifully shaped natural stone in his hand and saw in its shape a resemblance to a miniature mountain, waterfall or small animal. But we do know that as far back as the reign of the Empress Suiko in Japan (AD 593628) Chinese visitors presented stones of rare shapes set on individual trays to their hosts.

title: South Korean City Flooded
description: SEOUL. South Korea, Aug. 7 (UPI)  Torrents of rain that flooded a provincial city with nearly seven inches of rain in aim hours swept away homes and killed at least 25 persons. 15 of them in a landslide that buried a religious service. The police said 23 persons were injured and about 250 families were driven out of their homes in Chunju, 125 miles south of Seoul.

title: Around the Island, a Sea of Wonder
description: A FEW hundred feat off the Long Island coast, the bluegreen water showed a barely perceptible bulge. Gaining speed, the bulge moved toward the beach, growing taller and thinner. Then, as friction from the sand slowed the bottom of the wave, its top, unhindered, curled forward and the whole water structure crashed into a foaming, seething mass that swirled and hissed along the beach.

title: The Nation
description: Jimmy Carter has given a clear hint that his approach in the presidential campaign will be an aggressive one. In a speech in New Hampshire, Mr. Carter castigated what he termed the NixonFord Administration for failure of leadership and called the Republicans a party of backwardness.

title: Shorthand Speed Test Routine for One Man
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. (UPI)J. Edward Varallo of Wilmington, Del., has won the national speed contest of the National Shorthand Reporters Association, retiring the cup awarded annually to the country's fastest shorthand reporter.

title: CUTS PROPOSED IN MENTAL HELP
description: ALBANY, Aug. 7Financially troubled counties throughout the state are planning sharp cutbacks in spending for community treatment programs for the mentally ill and retarded, a development that reverses a trend of the past several years and threatens to undermine a cornerstone of the Carey administration's mental hveiene nolicv.

title: Re: Tar on Floor, Australia on Ceiling
description: FOLLOWING is the text of a letter from an East Hampton landlord to a summer tenant who has returned to the city for a few days.

title: Hayes, Krakora Gain
description: John Hayes of Cos Cob, Conn., and Joe Krakora of Westfield, .N.J., yesterday reached the final of the Penn Summer Tournament Jamboree at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens. Hayes defeated Peter Bromley of Mount Kisco, N.Y., 63, 6.0: Krakora beat Dave Oberstein of Brightwater, L.I., 6.3, 46, 63.

title: The New Alchemists
description: The paired highvoltage poles stand stiffly all along the gentle Pleistocene hills of south Cape Cod bearing 115,000 volts in their stunted arms. At one point along their route, where a dairy farm once operated, nestles a cluster of odd little wood and fiberglass structures; a windmill with orange, red and yellow sails turns languidly in the breeze near a neatly tended garden patch. It is a pleasant, tinkertoy community. As one of its members says, You feel nice about it. You want to reach out and pat it.

title: COLEMAN ASSERTS BAR FAILS PUBLIC
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 7Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr. accused the organized bar today of having failed the American public by turning its back on people unable to afford highpriced lawyers.

title: A black conservative
description: Being a black conservative is perhaps not considered as bizarre as being a transvestite, but it is certainly considered more strange than being a vegetarian or a bird watcher. Recently a network television program contacted me because they had an episode coming up that included a black conservative as one of the characters, and they wanted me to come down to the studio so that their writers and actors could observe such an exotic being in the flesh.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Harris Jury Asks a Review. of Testimony
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7The jury in the trial of William and Emily Harris, now in its eighth day of deliberations, returned to the courtroom late today to listen once again to testimony about Patricia Hearst's role in the case.

title: Spain Reinstates Three. Professors Ousted in 1965
description: MADRID, Aug. 7Three distinguished educators who were dismissed from Spanish universities 11 years ago for political dissidence got their chairs back today under a decree published in the official bulletin.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE COURT OF THE STONE CHILDREN, by Eleanor Cameron. (Avon, $1.25.) Time, memory and dream merge when a girl meets a ghostchild in museum courtyard: this complex, finely crafted fantasy for children 10 and up won the 1974 National Book Award.

title: Ford Prepares Speech
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 7 (AP) President Ford worked today on the acceptance speech he hopes to give to the Republican National Convention, while aides were getting in touch with a group of persons he hopes will include his running mate. While White House officials declined to name those being asked if they were interested in the job, Senator Howard H. Baker .Tr. of Tennessee indicated that he was among them. Persons interested are asked to supply health and financial information.

title: My Reservations About That Indian Series
description: After years of being massacred by the media, the American Indian is now about to be killed with kindness. At least that's the dark suspicion of one with Indian blood in his veins who has viewed advanced screenings of a series of six halfhour programs called American Indian Artists, which began airing this past Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Lubauitch Group Marks the Release Of Former Leader
description: The Lubavitch Movement, the worldwide body of Hasidic Jews, last night observed the 50th anniversary of the release of its late spiritual leader from Soviet prison with special ceremonies at its international headquarters at 770 Eastern Parkway. Brooklyn.

title: J. A. Herrmann Jr., Miss Sarsfield Wed
description: Anne Day Sarsfield, who teaches third grade at the Town School, was married at the home of her godmother, Mrs. J. P. Stevens, in Gloucester, Mass., yesterday afternoon to John A. Herrmann Jr., a vice president of kulin, Loeb & Company, investment bankers. The Rev. Robert J. Macfarlane, an Episcopal priest and cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

description: Thomas Ostrom Enders, United States Ambassador to Canada, and Mrs. Enders of Ottawa, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Talcott Enders, to Philippe Gregoire MatsakosSguridis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregorios MatsakosSguridis of Paris.

title: California Court Upholds Newsrack Placement Law
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 (UPI) A newsrack placement ordinance challenged by the publishers of three sexoriented magazines has been ruled constitutional in a 2to1 decision by the State Court of Appeals.

description: Alice Mary O'Donnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. O'Donnell of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to Daniel Joseph Kiely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Kiely of Eastchester, N.Y. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien, president of the Fordham Preparatory School, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. He was assisted by Msgr. Leo W. Madden.

title: Corn
description: You can smell corn pollen from Connecticut to Oregon, in August. It is like no other fragrance in the world, and it predates European settlement here by untold centuries. For the next few weeks it will hang heavy over the land, but it was here when Rome was young.

title: Ford's Position Still Firm With Pennsylvania G.O.P.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7In one of the more interesting paradoxes of Presidential politics this year, Ronald Reagan's alliance with Senator Richard S. Schweiker has embarrassed both men and helped neither one here in Mr. Schweiker's home base.

title: Lisa Suzanne Panettiere Is Married
description: Lisa Suzanne Panettiere and Thomas Edward Zebrowski, both of whom are working for their master's degrees at Adeiphi University, were married yesterday in St. Patrick s Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I. The Rev. Ramon Joseph officiated.

description: Christine De Coster Moseley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Clark Moseley of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon at her parent's home, to Mark David Milloff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Milloff of Hollywood, Fla., and Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Frederick Bender of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien officiated.

title: Whither Thou Goest
description: This is a book about the dislocations suffered by a woman who followed her man who followed his dream which went bust. The uprooting of wives in service of their husbands careers is one of the oldest rules of the game. With 40 per cent of Americans changing squares every four years it is still the general rule, and suit not much of a game for women.

description: THE true test of flowering annual is its ability to withstand summer heat. As the late summer temperatures soar and rain falls more infrequently, some will stand out and others will fade away.

description: Clarence W. Slocum, who retired in 1965 as vice president of the Devoe Reynolds Company, died yesterday at Providence Hospital in Columbia, S. C., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

I., yesterday afternoon to Daniel Liam Mennis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Addi Mennis of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif. The Rev. Thomas Rausch performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel at the School of the Holy Child. of which the bride is an alumna.

title: NoHit Bid Fails ;,With 2 Out in 9th
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. (AP)Steve Luebber of the Minnesota Twins came within one strike of a nohitter tonight, then gave up two hits and a run to the Texas Rangers before Bill Campbell relieved and secured a 31 victory. The winning margin came on Larry Hisle's tworun homer.

title: Cruise Ship Recovering Popularity
description: Things are looking up for the port's cruise ship business. Data compiled by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and industry sources show that the

title: For Its Own Security, Israel Offers Lebanese Aid
description: JERUSALEMIt began as a trickle of anxious Lebanese villagers seeking medical attention south of the border. In the last few weeks, it has become a steady stream farmers with surplus crops to sell, villagers in search of food supplies and unemployed workers seeking relief from the privations of 16 months of civil war. Israel's good fence policy, as it has been dubbed, reached a creative highpoint last week when a Lebanese woman slipped through the welltrafficked hole in the barbedwire fence, checked into an Israeli Government hospital and a few hours later gave birth to triplets. The babies, one doctor said with a smile, have the option of Israeli citizenship by virtue of their birth here.

title: Interlude
description: The American electorate at the moment seems like the audience at a doublefeature picture show during brief intermission before the main attraction.

title: Nassau's FamilyPlanning Crisis
description: RECENTLY a study entitled Children Bearing Children was published by the Nassau Coalition for Family Planning. The authors, Dr. Emily Moore and Prof. Hugh Wilson, using statistics collected from national, state and county sources, showed a vivid picture of the crisis in health services related to family planning for young, sexually active women in Nassau County. For the period studied from 1971 to 1974, there was a rapidly rising incidence of pregnancies, abortions, outofwedlock births and premature births for teenage women 15 to 19 years old.

title: Rion Bercovici, 73, Headed Public Relations Concern
description: Rion Bercovici, a former newspaperman who retired five years ago from a public relations firm bearing his name at 507 Fifth Avenue, died Friday in his home at 159 East 33d Street. He was 73 years old.

title: POLITICS
description: AFTER winning the Presidential nomination, the first thing that. Jimmy Carter wanted to do in New Jersey was to isolate his campaign from the squabbling that has split the Democratic Party in the state. However, the Democrats only succeeded in turning Mr. Carter's first effort to superimpose peace on the party into still another political spat involving Governor Byrne and State Senator James P. Dugan, the state Democratic chairman.

title: SUDANESE TERM EXECUTIONS JUST
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 7The executions this week of 98 prisoners for an attempted coup against President Gaafar al  Nimeiry a month ago shocked the outside world. But here, they are seen as retribution.

title: S. T. Ackley Weds Pamela Canevari
description: In Our Lady of Pompeii Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday afternoon Pamela Mary Canevari, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Canevari of New York, was married to Steven Thomas Ackley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Thomas Ackley of Wrightwood, Calif. The Rev. Peter P. Polo performed the ceremony.

title: FISHING
description: FOR New Jersey fishermen this week, fluke should remain the best bet inshore, except along the northern beaches. In those areas, there has been a good run of weakfish.

title: Yorkie Named Best At Adirondack Show.
description: AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Aug. 7Neither rain nor mud could halt a courageous 51/4pound Yorkshire terrier at the Southern Adirondack Dog Club Show at Mohawk Mills Park today. The tiny toy was Ch. Trivar's Suds Sipper, owned by Morris Howard and Johnny Robinson of Potomac, Md., and it was the 2yearold's third top award in only 10 appearances in a ring.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNEMPLOYMENT IN JULY ROSE to 7.8 percent of the work force, from 7.5 percent in June. . . Citibank reported a rise in secondquarter profits of American corporations of 31 percent from the 1975 period to $15.76 billion.. . . Chemical Bank has proposed a controversial cutrate stock brokerage service that could save an investor 90 percent on his brokerage transactions. . . Installment credit outstanding rose in June to $166.64 billion from $164 billion in May. . . New car sales in July rose 15.7 percent from yearearlier levels to 738,780 units.. The 85yearold Abercrombie and Fitch Company, nationally known for its sporting goods, said It would file tomorrow morning for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws.

title: Life of the Condor
description: The history of a proposed Navy missile called the Condor is enough to make the strongest taxpayer weep and leave the most insistent optimist shaken by what it discloses about the process by which new weapons are sometimes promoted in Washington.

title: U.S. COURT GROUP ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The Administrative Office of the United States Courts, whose leadership is appointed by the Supreme Court, has a poor record in the promotion of women and members of minorities, as well as other personnel problems, according to a report by the Civil Service Commission.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The Viking I soil experiments have returned additional data from Mars that indicate microscopic life forms could exist on the planet. Scientists say there are a number of alternative explanations for the findings, but that the information does suggest at least the possibility of biological activity.

title: Robertson of Sounders Gives Warning on Players
description: Jimmy Robertson of the Seattle Sounders doesn't blame the players who kicked him and broke his leg two weeks ago; he blames the referees for giving playersthe freedom to News commit violence. As a result, of Robertson warnSoccer ed that if outbursts of violent play continued in the North American Soccer League, the league would lack the services of top English players.

title: US. Trackmen Win, Women Are Routed
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 7Arnie Robinson said he was scared, Edwin Moses called it too slippery for world records, and Dwight Stones declared he would never change his style in the high jump because of a few raindrops.

title: Rent Subsidy Plan Lagging But Backers Are Hopeful
description: I WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The Ford Administration's main vehicle for providing housing to needy families has, after nearly two years of existence, put only 33,000 families in houses.

title: 3 HURT IN EXPLOSION AT CARTER BUILDING
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 7An explosion of gasoline vapors at service station here owned by Jimmy Carter's brother, Billy, injured three young people slightly this evening and caused minor damage to the property.

title: Design
description: In October 1973 a Connecticut couple decided to build an indoor swimming pool heated by natural gas. One month later the energy crisis hit, and faced with the prospect of spiraling utility hills, they switched from gas to solar energy.

title: Correction
description: An item in The Review of Aug. I erroneously implied that the Russian novelist. Alehsandr Solzhenitsyn, voluntarily chose exile from the Soviet Union. Mr. Solhcentisyn was arrested and placed forcibly on a plane.

title: McBride of Cards Is Lost for Season
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP)Bake McBride of the St. Louis Cardinals will be lost to the team for the rest of the season because of a knee injury.

title: Everett 0. Fontaine, 84, Publications Director, Dies
description: Everett 0. Fontaine, former director of publications at the American Library Association in Chicago, died Friday in his home at Hudson View Gardens, 116 Pinehurst Avenue, after an illness of two months. His age was 84.

title: U.S. Junior Five Loses
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (AP)The American junior basketball team lost a second game to the Estonian Republic team, 8779, in Tallinn today. The Estonians won yesterday's game 8785.

title: A Critic's Valedictory: The Americanization of Modern Art and Other Upheavals
description: Seventeen is hardly what you would call a round number. It is a downright shapeless number for measuring spans of years, which we block out in units of 10, 25, and 100. But if you had come to The Times as art critic in September, 1959, and were leaving it as I am doing with these valedictory notes in August, 1976, then 17 would look very round to you indeed.

title: Colorado Paper Fills Post
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 7 (UPI)Rllen H. Schwartzell, associate director of the American Press Institute, has been named general manager of the Colorado Springs Sun newspaper. Mr. Swartzell, who will be responsible for the overall newspaper operation, was general manager of The Boston Herald American nine years before joining the press institute last year.

title: Soweto Is Calm After a Turbulent Week;
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 7The black township of Soweto remained peaceful today but police across South Africa stayed on the alert against a spread of the violence that has killed 8 people and injured at least 41 in the last four days.

title: Former Inmate Accused In Law Office Abduction

title: Making Movie Memories Pay

You see, there is currently a trend, among rock critics: only if you are genuinely bad, will they love you.
