description: FIRST QUARTER

title: Giammalva Paces 21's
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 11  Tony Giammalva of Houston was leading. Gary Plock Of Louisville, 61, 10, today when Plock retirel with a muscle spasm in his back. It sent Giammalva into tomorrow's semifinal of the United States Tennis Association's 21andunder tournament at the Merlon Cricket Club.

title: Edgar T. Higgins Is Dead at 70 A Leader in Consumer Finance
description: Edgar T. Higgins, a leader in consumer finance who was chief executive officer for the Beneficial Corporation, died Tuesday at SloanKettering Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Summit N.J.

title: For Southerners in New York City Carter's Rise Helps Them Walk Tall
description: Jimmy Carter's rise to prominence has given new status to Southerners living in New York City.

title: Strike in Hospitals Spurs City Hall Bid for Changes
description: The hospital strike last week increased the determination of the Beame administration to bring about major structural changes in the management of New York City hospitalsinchiding possible decentralization of operations  in a newly forged alliance with union members.

title: Farm Playhouse Is Also a Museum
description: You can watch Broadway revivals while sitting in old Pullman railroad chairs or on a surrey coach that horses once drew from Albany to Poughkeepsie. You can see Al Capone's 1927 Franklin sedan. You can visit a rustic turnofthecentury farm and soak in the atmosphere of the 1890's in a reassembled barbershop, pharmacy or funeral parlor. And you can take in a collection of Gay Nineties memorabilia.

title: Magazine Unit Begins Campaign
description: The Magazine Publishers Association, in an effort to attract more advertising dollars to the medium it loves best, will begin a campaing of its own next month aimed at the top management of clients and agencies.

title: New Machines Thriller Has Old Familiar Look
description: Ever since Sax Rohmer exploited fears of the yellow peril, the spy novel has thrived on a Manichean world view, positing an alien Them threatening and ultimately defeated by a domestic Us. But then along came the political relativism and moral ambiguity of writers like John le Carre and Len Deighton, who portrayed (more realistically some thought) the world of contemporary espionage as a sort of selfperpetuating game of nations manipulated by cynical, amoral bureaucrats on both sides.

title: Byrne Urges Ford to Delay Oil Drilling
description: Governor Byrne urged President Ford yesterday to talcc action that would delay drilling for oil off New Jersey.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: STOCKTON, Calif.Colley Saloma, 125 pounds, the Philippines, outpointed Artemio Jeronimo. 123. Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: TODAY'S PROS ABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at Minnesota (n.)Figueroa (14.6) vs. Bane (43).

title: Reform or Guile?
description: Among the proposals for changing the way Vice Presidents are nominated, a perfectly logical one, theoretically is that the Presidential candidates indicate in advance their respective preferences. Supposedly, this would give the delegates an additional insight into each wouldbe President's political philosophy and at the same time insure a compatibility of outlook at the head of the ticket. But former Governor Reagan's declared choice of Senator Schweiker has shown all too clearly that the innovation need show nothing at all about a candidate's philosophy and indicate no compatibility other than a jointly held passion to get elected.

title: Advertising
description: Don Durgin, one of the most recognizable names in broadcasting during the last two decades, has been dismissed as president of McCaffrey & McCall Inc. after a year in the post.

title: Steelworkers Extend Pact With four Can Producers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Delegates to the Unit Steelworkers Can Conference have agreed to extend their labor agreement with four major can producers to October 1977.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: Come the first hint of spring, we wait anxiously for the last frost day to set out our tender crops. A friendly race to harvest the year's first sweet corn inevitably arises between gardening neighbors. The fairweather vegetable garden suffers from a wellentrenched case of earlyitis. Then, once the lettuce has bolted in the summer heat and the firstintheground radishes have grown to proportions and texture more suitable for pulpwood than crunching, the produce patch rests on its owner's laurels.

title: CUBA ANGOLA FORCE NOW PUT AT 22,000
description: LISBON, Aug. 12A Cuban deserter has declared here that he did not volunteer to fight in Angola and that many other Cuban soldiers there were also defecting to South Africa.

title: People and Business
description: Reports have circulated this week that Warren E. Buffett, who has a reputation as one of the country's most astute investors, has taken perhaps a 10 percent or 15 percent interest in the Government Employees Insurance Company and had made the necessary filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. However, the S.E.C. said yesterday that it had not been notified of anyone taking a major position recently in GEICO.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday.

title: Walking Tour Information
description: Madison SquareThe World of Edith Wharton and George Templeton Strong, a walking tour sponsored by the Museum of the City of New York on Sunday begins at 2:30 P.M. at the Little Church Around the Comer (1 East 29th Street). Tickets are $2.00 for museum members and $3.00 for nonmembers and may be obtained from the guides before the tour starts. Reservations are not necessary. Tours are not cancelled unless weather conditions are exceptionally poor. For further information, call 5341672.

title: DRIVER FEE RISE DRAWS ATTACKS
description: MINEOLA; L.I., Aug. 12State Senator John D. Caemmerer, chairman of the Select Senate Committee on Transportation, and the New York State Autothobile Association today attacked, a glen by the State Department of Motor Vehicles to increase license renewal fees for drivers convicted of moving violations.

title: EDWARD J. SPARKS DIPLOMAT, IS DEAD
description: Edward J. Sparks, a retired career Foreign Service officer who held several ambassadorships, died at the age of 73 Wednesday in Santiago, Chile where he had lived since he retired in 1962.

title: Fish Stir in Storm's Wake
description: Hurricane Belle arrived just in time to salvage a fishing ???ason notable mainly for the lack of bluefish in the New york Bight. Whether the storm churned up the waters sufficiently to lure the blues north from southern New Jersey probably will not be known until the weekend once the seas calm.

title: Broadway
description: HARLES LUDLAM, the doyen of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, is writing a Broadway musical about Catherine de Medici. TOM Eyen, the author of The Dirtiest Show in Town, is writing a Broadway musical about New York. Molly Picon and Hans Conreid are coming back to Broadway in The Second Time Around, a sentimental comedy by Henry Denker. And a prolific Spanish playwright, Antonio BueroVallejo, may be making his Broadway debut with the sciencefictlonal The Basement Skylight. The sponsor of these diverse entertainments is Adele Holzer, who only last March threw in the towel, retrieved her checkbook and abandoned Broadway.

title: Business Records
description: VANTAGE PRODUCE SALES INC., 700 Exterior St., Bronx, Petitioners are D'arrigo Bros. Co. of New York Inc,: Algnagelberg Company Inc. and Fruit co Corp.

title: Music by the Ellington Band
description: Working with Alvin Ailey is very similar to working with the old man, said Mercer Ellington with a wry grin referring to his father, Duke Ellington, whose music will be played this weekend by the Duke Ellington Orchestra in the Ailey Celebrates Ellington series at the New York State Theater.

title: George Reavey, a Translator Of Russian Literature, Dead
description: George Reavey, a poet, publisher and translator of Russian literature, died last night of a respiratory illness in Gracie Square Hospital. He was in his late 70's.

title: About Real Estate
description: Two types of projects are in the forefront of such planning and construction activity as there is for Manhattan apartment houses at present.

title: Business in Italy
description: ROME  About the only thing Italians take seriously in August is their holidays. Entire factories close down, to the horror of some economists who insist that thousands of hours of productivity are lost by the practice. Businesses are halfdeserted and their telephones take an interminable time to be answered. At the chamber of commerce here, phones are answered promptly, but it is only a recorded message telling the caller to please try again after Aug. 23.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Rightwing Christians in Lebanon announced yesterday that they had captured the Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar. They had besieged the camp since midJune leftwing radio reported Palestinians as having said that handtohand fighting was still going on inside the camp, and witnesses said that thousands of civilians were streaming out of Tell Zaatar and surrendering to rightwing forces. The civilians were mostly women, children and old men. Few young men had apparently survived. Witnesses said that they had seen the bodies of 10 youths at the entrance to the camp. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: Today's Entries at Saratoga
description: Horses fisted In order of Post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: A Farmers Market in the City
description: Baskets heaped with glistening tomatoes, plump ears of corn and tawny peaches are perched in the backs of pickup trucks or on counters made of planks laid across overturned crates. Farmers stroll around the makeshift stalls, seeing that their produce is displayed fetchingly.

title: TWO LEGISLATORS ACCUSED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP)Two Massachusetts state Senators one the majority leader, were indicted today on charges that they extorted $40,000 from a New York consulting concern under threat of a harmful legislative committee report.

title: Poland, Long Exporter Orders Sugar Rationing
description: WARSAW, Aug. 12Poland normally one of Europe's leading exporters of sugar, will began rationing sugar starting next week, for the first time in a generation.

title: Ivan Melezh Is Dead at 55; Major Byelorussian Writer
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (Reuters) Ivan Melezh, one of Byelorussia's bestknown writers has died in Minsk at the age of 55: the press agency Tass reported today Mr. Melezh, who wrote in the Byelorussian language, won the Lenin Prize in 1972 for his novels People in the Swamp and The Breathing of the Storm, which describe transformations in the Byelorussian countryside after the 1917 revoIution.

title: The Labor Scene
description: Except for one brief interruption early on this country's labor movement has known only three top leaders in the 90 years since the formation of the old American Federation of Labor. Two of the federation chiefs, Samuel Gompers and William treen died ripe in years, still clinging to their scepters.

title: India State Is Leader in Forced Sterilization
description: BOMBAY, Aug, 7An Indian state with a population of 50 million has become the first political entity in the world to legislate population control by forced sterilization.

title: Kissinger Meets South African Envoy; Move on Disputed Territory Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger conferred today with the South African Ambassador would that South Africa would make a major declaration tomorrow on the crucial question of independence for SouthWest Africa.

title: Israel Awards Warner Rights for Film on Raid
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12An Israeli Government agency announced today that Warner Brothers had been chosen to make a film of the rescue by Israeli troops of more than 100 Israeli hostages held last month in a hijacked Air France plane at Entebbe Airport in Uganda.

title: First U. S. Prison in New York Is Planned
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12State and Federal officials disclosed here today that the United States will build a $19 million correctional institution  the first Federal prison to be situated in New York Stateon a 276acre site in Otisville, in Orange County near Middletown.

title: Clark Calls for a Negative Income Tax To Provide a Subsistence Level for All
description: Ramsey Clark yesterday proposed a negative income tax to eradicate the need for welfare and provide a subsistence level income for all and a tax on millionaires to finance tax credits and a savings program for working and middleclass people.

title: Outrage in Istanbul
description: The instructions given in Libya to the Palestinian gunmen who attacked passengers with grenades and tommyguns in the Istanbul airport Wednesday were simple: Kill as many Israelis as you can. Although their plan did include hijacking the El Al airliner bound for Tel Aviv, it evidently did not call for the usual tactic of seizing hostages for bargaining purposesjust gun down or blow up as many passengers as possible in retaliation for Israel's rescue raid in Uganda last month.

title: SYDNEY B. HUTTON
description: Sydney B. Hutton, a commercial rose grower, died Wednesday a Community Hospital, West Grove, Pa. He was 87 years old.

title: Raiders Opponents at Yankee Stadium
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 12 Perhaps there should have been a sign reading QUIET HOSPITAL ZONE.

title: Schlamme Evokes Weill Cabaret Style
description: This weekend, people with a passion for the bittersweet Songs of Kurt Weill and Bertold Brecht will be making their journeys of rediscovery to Reno Sweeney, where Martha Schlamme is aptearing with Alvin Epstein at 9 and midnight tonight wind tomorrow.

title: First U. S. Prison in New York Planned for Orange County Site
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12State and Federal officials disclosed here today that the United States will build a $19 million correctional institution  the first Federal prison to he situated in New York Stateon a 276acre site in Otisville, in Orange County near Middletown.

title: Management
description: HAMILTON, N. Y.At first glance, the peninsula jutting into glistening Lake Moraine could be a summer camp. Tidy white bungalows are sprinkled among the pine trees. Energetic softball games generate small dust storms on the nearby baseball diamond. There's a recreation room, a stereo lounge, water skiing and sailing.

title: How to Get There
description: The Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton is near the midpoint of Long Island, not a bad place to stop on the long trip to or from the Hamptons. To reach Brookhaven, get off the Long Island Expressway at Exit 68 and take the William Floyd Parkway north for a mile.

title: Army Still Unable to Find 225 Who Got LSD in Experiments
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) More than a year after the hunt began, the Army says it still is trying to locate 225 former military personnel who were given LSD In tests dating back at least nine years.

title: For Children
description: SING, BABY, SING, (1936; 87 minutes) with Alice Faye, Adolphe Menjou and the Ritz Brothers, noon, Saturday, and Easy Living, (1937; 91 minutes) with Jean Arthur, Ray Milland, Edward Arnold, noon, Sunday, at Films for Young People at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 535 Street. Museum admission, 75 cents for children 52 for adults, includes movies. 5567078.

title: Bond Prices Up as Index Gains a Bit
description: Bond prices continued to rise yesterday after a Government report that the wholesale price index registered only a small increase in July. The trendsetting $175 million Illinois Bell Telephone Company bond issue marketed Wednes8.25 percent began day at a yield of to sell somewhat more quickly and its underwriters reported the offering was close to the 50 percentsold mark by late afternoon.

title: Drop in Food Costs Slows Rise in Wholesale Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Wholesale prices, taken as a group, rose only threetenths of 1 percent in July, their smallest rise since March. But other aspects of the Labor Departmen's Wholesale Price Indek contained warnings that the inflation rate might worsen somewhat in the future.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: TheMorris County. Prosecutor said he'was investigating about a halfdozen cases of babybuyingplacethent of infants with adoptive parents by intermediaries, often attorneys, who accept an illegal fee for theirservices The target of this inyeitigation is not the pareitts, either adoptive or natural, said Prosecutor pcinald G. Collester Jr. It is the intermediaries. He said that the latter took an average of $1.000 to $3,000 to find infants out of state and arrange to place them without the use of an adoption agency.

title: Republican Show Stolen By Helms, Nondele gate
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 12 The man who has received the most attention in preconvention maneuvering among Republicans here is neither delegate nor a candidate but a granitehard conservative Senator from in North Carolina named Jesse A. Helms.

title: ARAMCO OIL OUTPUT NEAR PEAK IN JULY
description: The Arabian American Oil Company produced 8.7 million barrels a day of crude oil in July, the second highest production rate ever for Aramco which is owned by the Exxon Corporation, Texaco Inc., the Mobil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California. The Saudi Arabian Government owns 60 percent of Aramco's production and is negotiating for complete ownership.

title: DUFFY EXPRESIDENT PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: Donald M. Klock, former president of the DuffyMott Company, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a Federal indictment that charged him with fraudulently obtaining $400,000 lof the company's funds and failing to report it as taxable income.

title: Ailey A Duke And 3 Kings
description: THE PREMIERE of an Alvin Ailey ballet to the last music composed by Duke Ellington speeches by Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr., a guest appearance by American Ballet Theater dancers and the premieres of five works by five young black choreographers all these events will take place this weekend at the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater's extraordinary Duke Ellington festival at the New York State Theater.

title: 3 Auxiliary Officers Reportedly W atched Policemen's Beating
description: Three auxiliary police officers are being investigated by the Police Department on charges of failing to assist three uniformed policemen who were being pummeled by an irate crowd as they attempted to issue summonses for doubleparking in front of a coffee shop in Astoria, Queens.

title: Shuffling
description: A centipede, the many legs will go straight away a way and cut

title: OffDuty Officer Kills Man In a Melee Near Stadium
description: An offduty police officer leaving the JetsGiants football game at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night, shot and fatally wounded a man while breaking up a melee, the police reported yesterday.

title: Futures Traders Shaken By Federal Investigators
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12Traders in commodity futures, long accustomed to attacks from farmers for low market prices and from consumers for high food costs, have developed thick skins. But now even they feel a nagging disquiet over potentially more damaging attacks by Federal investigations into their trading operations.

title: Carolina Experiment on Medicaid Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12An unusual experiment using private enterprise to hold down costs in the Federalstate Medicaid program ended in red ink yesterday when North Carolina and a private company, Health Application Systems, mutually terminated their $200 million a year contract.

title: TOP WEEKEND FILMS
description: FRIDAY

title: BOTSW ANA ACCUSES RHODESIAN TROOPS
description: GABERONE, Botswana, Aug. 12 (Reuters)The Botswana Government said today that Rhodesian troops had crossed the border into Botswana three times last week and had questioned and harassed five black Africans.

title: DRUG COMPANIES PREPARE VACCINE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Flu vaccine manufacturers have told the government that they will start immediately to put their large supplies of bulk vaccine into final form for distribution and uses a Federal official said today.

title: CONRAIL REPORTS A LOSS NARROWER THAN ANTICIPATED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12Conrail lost $34.4 million in its first three months of operation the Governmentsponsored railroad system announced today.

title: Train Hits a Car and Beer /Soup /Fish Fly
description: PARIS, Aug. 12 A 1936 Citron automobile with a worn tire stalled in the rain on a stretch of railroad tracks in northeastern France on the night of March 18 while a freight train sped toward it at 65 miles an hour.

title: Inflation Outlook Leaves Stocks Mixed
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday in sluggish trading despite signs that the nation's inflationary trend had not worsened.

title: Ronee Blakley Singing At Village Club
description: A year ago, it looked as if nothing could stop Ronee Blakley. Her appearance as the troubled Barbara Jean in Nashville inspired a series offeature articles that made Bruce Springsteen's publicity look positively minuscule.

title: New Kennedy Library Plan Released
description: A new design for the longpostponed John F. Kennedy Presidential Library, now due to be built on a site overlooking Boston Harbor in the city's Dorchester section, was made public yesterday, with little fanfare.

title: OMER POOS
description: Omer Poos, a Federal district judge who was appointed in the Eisenhower Presidency died Wednesday in a Hillsboro hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Corn Output Estimate Is Cut 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Department of Agriculture reduced its forecast of corn production by 6 percent today but it said this year's output would still be the largest on record.

title: Ramtown Players to Give. White House Production
description: The Ramtown Players, 51 youngsters from Howell Township in Monmouth County, will entertain White House visitors today with an original 60minute production entitled, Salute to America.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: There are parents who remember the loneliness of learning piano by the numbers in some isolated corner of the house until the numbers were printed indelibly on their brains (onetwothree onetwothree twoonetwo three oneone) while the piano was lost forever. They don't want their children to be losers, too.

title: Whitney Young Game to Return to Stadium
description: After two years in Shea Stadium, the Whitney M. Young Jr. Memorial Football Classic, sponsored by the New York Urban League, is moving back into Yankee Stadium this year, on Saturday. Oct. 30, at 2 P.M.

title: Royal Dutch Profits Rise; Other Corporations Report
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of companies, second largest global oil producer, reported yesterday profit increases of 176 percent in the second quarter and 56 percent in the first half.

title: Nassau Opening
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 12 Senator Buckley received an enthusiastic welcome tonight at the official opening of the Buckley headquarters for Nassau County.

title: Pippin Standby Sings
description: Much of the success of New York's cabarets in recent years has come from their use of performers from the Broadway musical theater. In most cases, these were veterans who had not appeared locally for some time. The Ballroom, 458 West Broadway, is currently trying a different approach in using the musical theater as a source, presenting Dean Pitchford, a young singer who is the standby for the title role in Pippin, at the Imperial Theater and who has also appeared in Godspell.

title: Pennzoil's Duval Unit Sells Its Canadian Mine
description: The Pennzoil Company announced In Houston yesterday that its Duval Corporation subsidiary had sold its Canadian potash mine In Saskatoon to the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan for $128.5 million. Terms called for a payment of $118.5 million in cash and a $10 million promissory note bearing a 9 percent interest rate.

title: Environment Party to Seek Listing on New York Ballot
description: The Environment Party formed last month, announced yesterday it would seek a line on the New York State ballot for the November general election.

title: Reagan Resists Financial Disclosure
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12Ronald Reagan, now in the final stretch of his party's nominating process, continues to resist the postWatergate pressure on Presidential candidates to make broad disclosures of their personal financial affairs.

title: The Buckley Caper
description: Senator Buckley's possible lastminute entry as a Presidential candidate appears to be more sensational than significant. There is, of course, always a chance that the Republican convention, weary of a deadlock between President Ford and Governor Reagan, will turn to the fresh face of the New York conservative; stranger things have happened in conventions. But on almost every count the episode looks like a tactical byplay.

title: Kepone Discovered In Fish on Market Along East Coast
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 12 (AP)A sampling of fish by the Federal Government in East Coast markets has turned up evidence of contamination by the pesticide ingredient Kepone, an official of the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: Questions and Answers on Flu Vaccine Program
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The swine influenza vaccination program signed into law today by President Ford will make the vaccinations available to all Americans at no charge. Following, in question and answer form, are details about the program, provided by Mike White, a public information officer in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's swine flu office.

title: G.O.P. Platform Unit Deletes Nixon's Name
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Aug. 12The only reference to former President Richard M. Nixon in the draft of the Republican platform was deleted early this Morning as a subcommittee tidied up the wording of proposed planks on foreign policy.

title: Third Person Dies Of Sniper Wounds In Wichita Attack
description: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 12 (UPI)A third victim of a downtown sniping attack died today while a teenage suspect told the police why he went to the top of the tallest building in Kansas and opened fire on unsuspecting drivers and pedestrians.

title: Contracts in Silver Futures Increase With Crop Report
description: Silver futures contracts which often follow the lead of grain prices, rose yesterday in anticipation of the Government's crop report which was issued after the close.

title: STRIKING MINERS GOING BACK ON JOB
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 12 (AP)Thousands of Appalachian coal miners began returning to work today in the first major break in a wildcat strike that the industry says has cost the nation more than $130 million in lost production.

title: CLASHES CONTINUE NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 12Armed policemen and stonethrowing demonstrators continued to battle tonight in Cape Town's black townships, where at least 27 people have died in two days of the most violent confrontations since antiGovernment rioting broke out two months ago.

title: Secret Gardens Where You Can Dine
description: Secret Gardens Where You Can Dine

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: A number of local Puerto Rican and other Latin American groups have gotten together to sponsor the first Festival de Teatro Popular Latinoamericano, which is winding up this weekend at the New York Shakespeare Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, near Astor Place (6776350). The festival has brought in 80 people or so who work in little theater groups in nine Latin American countries as well as others from Puerto Rico, California and New York. They do works that they themselves have written and are in the nature of people's theater. What you will see is theater of today almost entirely in Spanish. Tonight a group from Colombia; tomorrow, a Mexican unit; Sunday, performers from Puerto Rico. All performances at 8 P.M. Admission: $2.50.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Rightwing Christians in Lebanon announced yesterday that they had captured the Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar. They had besieged the camp since midJune leftwing radio reported Palestinians as having said that handtohand fighting was still going on inside the camp, and witnesses said that thousands of civilians were streaming out of Tell Zaatar and surrendering to rightwing forces. The civilians were mostly women, children and old men. Few young men had apparently survived. Witnesses said that they had seen the bodies of 10 youths at the entrance to the camp. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: Art People
description: GERMANS are big on history, as everyone knows. Karl Stein on Monumenta Germaniae, Ranke on the Reformation. Burckhardt on the Renaissance trailbeaters, one and all.

title: A Rare Sight in August: Party for 600
description: August. It's a month of dog days and doldrums, the time when many notable New Yorker wouldn't be caught dead in Manhattan, because everyone who is anyone is supposed to be in the Hamptons or the South of France.

title: M'DONNELL SET FOR DEVELOPING JET WITH FRENCH
description: PARIS, Aug. 12McDonnell Douglas of the United States and Aerospatiale and DassaultBreguet of France have agreed in principle to develop and market a mediumrange jetliner for the 1980's. The potential market for such a plane has been estimated at $10 billion.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: It's Mostly a Tour in a Gilded Age
description: So wrote George Templeton. Strong on April 2, 1850. The Museum of the City of New York's Sunday Walking Tours, now in their 17th year are dedicated to the same contemplation of the city's buried history, both personal and public. This Sunday, the museum will follow in Strong's footsteps with its Jour Madison SquareThe World of Edith Wharton and George Templeton Strong.

title: 3 Cleared, 3 Guilty In San Quentin Case
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 12  Three of the defendants in he 16month murderconspiracy trial of the socalled San Quentin Six were acquitted today while a fourth was convicted of murder. The two remaining defendants were found guilty of lesser charges.

title: Weiskopf Takes Lead In P.G.A. by Shot on 65
description: BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 12 Tom Weiskopf, who has not played really well in the last seven weeks, turned the opening round of the Professional Golfers Association championhip today into a personal triumph by shooting a dazzling 65, five under par for the supertough Congressional Country Club. At one point he stood at six under par.

title: Foster Belts Two As Reds Win, 83
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP)George Foster Hit two home runs and Joe Morgan and Johnny Bench one each today as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Chicago Cubs. 83.

title: CARTER CRITICISM IGNORED BY BUSH
description: PLAINS. Ga., Aug. 12With a smile and a hearty handshake, Jimmy Carter welcomed George Bush to his home here today only a few hours after the Director of Central Intelligence as one of the unsuccessful politicians President Ford had dumped into an important Government position.

title: In Memoriam
description: DAVIDSONJoseph Elias, August 11, 1951 Beloved father and grandfather lovingly remembered. Ethel and Fran.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Turkey to Ask Death for 2 Guerrillas After Attempt to Hijack E1 A1 Jetliner
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 12 (Reuters)Two Palestinian guerrillas will face the death penalty in a Turkish court on charges stemming from their attack at the Istanbul airport after a vain attempt to hijack an Israeli airliner, a state prosecutor said tonight.

title: New Madagascar Leader
description: TANANARIVE. Madagascar Aug. 12 (Agence FrancePresse) The President of Madagascar. Didier Ratsiraka, today named his former Education Minister Justin Rakotoniaina, as new Prime Minister. The previous Prime Minister. Col. Joel Rakotomalla, was killed in a helicopter crash last month.

title: IncomeTax Tables Ready For Mailing to Employers
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12State tax officials made preparations today for mailing income tax withholding tables to more Than 150,000 employers in New Jersey as a result of the ssembly's approval late last night of the final components of the income tax package.

title: REPORT ON RELIGION SKIRTS SOVIET BLOC
description: GENEVA, Aug. 12 (AP)A report on religious freedom submitted to a meeting of the World Council of Churches today made little mention of the treatment of religions in the Soviet Union and the Communist countries of Eastern Europe council sources said.

title: Banjos to Duel Fiddles to Vie At Seaport
description: THE SOUTH STREET Seaport will ring with fiddle and banjo music tomorrow and Sunday when bluegrass and oldtime country music pickers from around the Northeast will converge for the fourth annual New York City Bluegrass and Old  Time Country Music Band Contest and Crafts Fair.

title: $2 Bill Is Having a Deuce of a Time
description: So far, at least, the $2 bill is a flop. What is worse, this is the second time it has flopped.

title: Security Termed Lax
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 12Israeli officials said today that Arab guerrillas were exploiting the laxity of security checks on transit passengers in international airports. They called for international cooperation to tighten supervision.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: Toronto 6, Boston 2. Chicago 2, San Jose 1. Rochester 2, Tampa Bay 1.

title: From Yale Drama to Fanatic Nun
description: HER name is Meryl Streep, as in streak. As in streaking to the top, as she has been doing ever since she first hit New York last September, fresh out of the Yale Drama School.

title: Records Bergonzi Sings.
description: For 25 years, Carlo Bergonzi has pursued a soikd but comparatively quiet career as one of the outstanding Italian tenors of his generation. In the 1950's he was somewhat overshadowedby the more flamboyant personalities of Mario del Monaco and Franco Corelli while during the last 10 years Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti have tended to upstage him.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Rise Shown For Supply Of Money
description: The nation's money stock, by both principal definitions, rose during the week ended Aug. 4 the Federal Reserve reported lyesterday.

title: Through the Atom With Bus and Camera
description: Sounds serious, almost forbidding. Not exactly the ideal weekend spot. But tomorrow and every Saturday through the end of August, the public is invited to visit Brookhaven National Laboratory's 5,000acre campus, picnic on its grounds, roam through a nuclear reactor, try out a pair of mechanical hands and find out through exhibits films and lectures, what goes on at Brookhavenone of the nation's leading scientific research laboratories.

title: French Franc Penetrates Barrier of 5 to the Dollar
description: PARIS, Aug. 12 (AP)The French franc dropped through a psychologically important barrier of five to the dollar and reached a 30month low today in hectic banktobank trading.

title: At the Movies
description: P EOPLE SEE an actor at the ballet, and right away he's a ballet freak, says Walter Matthau in a wounded voice. I happen to play the horses once in a while, so naturally that makes me a racetrack habitu.

title: PLATFORM PANEL OPPOSES JOB BILL
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 12 The Republican Platform Committee, sharpening its differences with the Democrats for the fall campaign although its Presidential nominee is still in doubt, adopted with little opposition today planks opposing two key Democratic programsa job bill and compulsory national health insurance.

title: 1975 Salary Gains Listed For Securities Salesmen
description: Brokerage house salesmen dealing with small investors earned an average of $23,540 last year while similar salesmen dealing with big financial customers earned an average of $40,649, the Securities Industry Association reported yesterday.

title: CLASHES CONTINUE NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 12Armed policemen and stonethrowing demonstrators continued to battle tonight in Cape Town's black townships, where at least 27 people have died in two days of the most violent confrontations since antiGovernment rioting brake out two months ago.

title: Greenwood Beats Naberin in Freestyle
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP)  Mark Greenwood swimming seventenths of a second faster than he ever had in the 200meter freestyle, finished in 1 minute 52.21 seconds tonight and upset John Naber, the Olympic fourgoldmedal winner in the Amateur Athletic Union national swimming championships.

title: 3 Cleared, 3 Guilty In San Quentin Case
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 12  Three of the defendants in he 16month murderconspiracy trial of the socalled San Quentin Six were acquitted today while a fourth was convicted of murder. The two remaining defendants were found guilty of lesser charges.

title: Commodities Index Rose During the Latest Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrhal materials rose to 207.6 from 207.4 last week.

title: Elton John Fans Given Help on Ticket MixUp
description: Elton John fans wild ordered concert tickets from Rigby Enterprises but never received them may get substitute tickets from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Colorado Flood Toll Is 98
description: LOVELAND, Colo., Aug. 12 (UPI)Deputies searching the hulks of cars and trucks smashed by the flooding of the Big Thompson River on July 31 said today that eight more bodies had been recovered from mud and debris in the 35milelong canyon, raising the flood death toll to 98. The latest victim to be identifed was Greg Harmon, 18 years old of Keokuk, Iowa.

title: The Fall of Tell Zaatar
description: In many ways, Tell Zaatar was symbolic of the Palestinian plight in the Middle East. A heavy fortification in the midst of an industrial suburb, home away from home for a whole generation of displaced peoples; nothing in the Tell Zaatar refugee camp held out any promise of a better life for the tens of thousands who lived there.

title: Five Named to Arts Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)  President Ford announced today the appointment of three persons to the Commission of Fine Arts and reappointed two other members. He appointed Frederick Doveton Nichols, professor of architecture at the University of Virginia; Victorine dupont Homsey of Wilmington Del., and Eli Jacobs, a New York investment banker. He reappointed Edward Stone of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D. C.

title: WITNESS WAVERS AT MOSQUE TRIAL
description: The partner of a policeman fatally shot in 1972 at a mosque in Harlem stepped down from the witness stand yesterday at the murder trial of Lewis 17X Dupree and walking through the packed courtroom of spectators, pointed to a man seated in the third row as having been present on the day of the shooting.

title: About a Certain Municipality in Missouri
description: The two schools of thought about the true character of Kansas City agree that it is not what you thought it was. One school of thoughta school that includes virtually all of the most progressive businessmen, the leaders of city government, the board members of the Chamber of Commerce, and of course, the New York publicrelations firm hired to transform their feelings into slogansholds that Kansas City IS not the cow town you thought it was but the glamour city of the seventies. The other school of thought a school consisting of me  holds that Kansas City is not the glamour city of the seventies you thought it was if you swallow such slogans, but a cow town, and all the better for it.

title: Elderhostel: An Intellectual Summer Tonic for Both Young and Old
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. School had ended, and the students, aged 60 to 80, were sitting around the cafeteria table at the University of Bridgeport evaluating the week's experience. They were participants in Elderhostel 76, a program offered to about 1,000 older people at 21 New England colleges this summer.

title: Seeger to Mix Wine and Clear Water
description: This Sunday afternoon on the slope of a grassy natural amphitheater that leads down to the banks of the Hudson River from the cobbled streets of a recreated old wine village in Highland N.Y., there will be a folk music festival  picnic to which all of us are invited.

title: Siegel Ousts Letcher
description: STRATTON, Vt., Aug. 12 (AP)  Steve Siegel of Teaneck, N.J., beat thirdseeded Cliff Letcher of Australia today in the second round of a $10,000 tennis tournament. Siegel, the New Jersey state champion, breezed past Letcher, 62, 60.

title: Airport Laxity
description: However remote the prospects for international action against terror and hijacking, there are still security measures individual governments can takeought to have taken long ago. The Palestinian terrorists were able to carry hand luggage containing grenades and guns into Istanbul airport because they had evidently not been subjected to any security check between Libya and Rome.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX UP MORE SLOE AS FOOD DECLINES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Wholesale prices, taken as a group, rose only threetenths of 1 percent in July, their smallest rise since March. But other aspects of the Labor Departmen's Wholesale Price Index contained warnings that the inflation rate might worsen somewhat in the future.

title: $8.40 Nalee's Knight First By a Nose on Saratoga Turf
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y. (AP)  Mrs. George M. Humphrey's Nalees Knight cleverly ridden by Patrick Day, held off Cesar P. Kimmel's Trumpeter Swan to win the $25,000 The Axe H Purse at Saratoga today before a crowd of 18,015. Nalees Knight, a 5yearold son of Round Table, won by a nose and Trumpeter Swan ridden by Jacinto Vasquez, finished half a length in front of Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Splitting Headache ridden by Robyn C. Smith.

title: U S. Is Planning to Relax Rules For Mothers Seeking Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Government today plans to relax the rigid requirement that mothers applying for welfare must help in identifying the father of the child and collecting child support payments from him.

title: 10 Workmen Killed by Explosion At Refinery Near New Orleans.
description: CHALMETTE, La., Aug. 12 (AP)Ten workmen were killed tonight when an explosion ripped through an oil refinery tower in this New Orleans suburb, the authorities reported.

title: Stein Charges State Is Bilked On Lunch Plan, and Is Disputed
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday that a network of sponsors of the Summer Food Service Program for needy New York City children was systematically bilking the state out of millions of dollars, and was immediately disputed by one of the sponsors he criticized.

title: Price Fixing In Meat Laid To Packers
description: DES MOINES, Aug. 12 (AP)Iowa Beef Processors Inc., the country's largest meat company, and three other meat packers have been named in a lawsuit charging conspiracy to fix meat prices.

title: American Exchange Prices Ease as Volume Dips
description: Easing prices and lower votume marked trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The market value index closed at 103.62, off 0.18, and the volume sagged to 1.6 million from 1.9 million on Wednesday.

title: World Team Tennis
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Joseph Beder, 76, Zionist; Was Mayor in Palestine
description: Joseph Beder, a New York textile executive who was mayor of a town in Palestine in the 1930's, died Monday at his home, 150 West End Avenue. He was 76 years old.

title: Chris Evert and All That Money
description: Standing on the 107th floor with New Jersey behind her and New York Harbor on her right, Chris Evert announced plans for a series of women's tennis tournaments backed by the ColgatePalmolive Company with $800,000 in prize money. In addition to a $200,000 Colgate Inaugural in Palm Springs, Calif., in October, $600,000 in yearend bonuses will be distributed to top players ranked by a point system keyed to major championships around the world. The purse for the Inaugural is the richest in women's tennis so far.

title: Title A.A.U. Swim Summaries
description: Women's 200Meter Freestyle1, Klm Peyton David Douglas S.C., 2 minutes 3.01 seconds; 2, Brenda Bomb, Suburban S.C. 2:03.82; 3, Wendy Sas:Noll, Central Jet A.C.. 2:04.31; 4, Rebecca Permit, New Zealand, 2'04.85; 5. Kathy Heddy.. Central Jersey A.C., 2:04.90; 6, Karen Rooser, De Anza S.C., 2:05.40; 7, Stephanie Elkins Indianapolis S.C., 2:06.60; 8, Nancy Hudak, Suburban S.C., 2:06.73.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: World Series Adds dh Rule
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 12 With a tiebreaker vote by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn the designatedhitter rule was approved today for use by both teams in all games of this year's World Series. After that, it will be used in alternate years.

title: Opera: Mother of the Mesas
description: VIRGIL THOMSON'S The Mother of Us All seems to grow in stature with each passing yearor perhaps it has been a great opera all along and we are just beginning to realize the fact. This is certainly the impression left by the Santa Fe (N.M.) Opera's wonderful new production in the company's home city of a work that has always been popular with small opera groups since it was first performed at Columbia University in 1947. For some inscrutable reason it has never been staged before by one of our major companies.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Seeks Funds for Boycott Case
description: The financially troubled National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will soon begin a major fundraisng drive to post a bond of more than $1.5 million with a Mississippi court, the association's board chairman Margaret Bush Wilson, said yesterday.

title: Students Raise City's Cash Flow
description: Working under a $25,000 grant and at no cost to the city 17 top accounting majors at Baruch College, part of the City University of New York, have increased New York City's cash flow by $38 million over the last two months.

title: Bomb Scare at Heathrow
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (UPI) Thousands of airline passengers were evacuated from Heathrow's Terminal 3 today and flights were delayed about 45 minutes after an airline bag suspected of containing a bomb had been found. Bombdisposal men set off a small charge to blow the bag open. The contents were found to be harmless.

title: Giants Tired of Waiting for Summerell Jets Facing Their 2d Game in 3 Nights
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N., Y. Aug. 12Maybe it's just as well that Craig Morton played almost the entire game against the Jets last night and will have to rest when the Giants meet the Oilers in Houston on Saturday night.

title: THREE FOUND GUILTY IN VAULT ROBBERY
description: PROVIDENCE R.I., Aug. 12 (AP)A Superior Court jury that had been sequestered for 79 days delivered guilty verdicts today against three of six men accused of roles in the Bonded Vault Company robbery.

title: Mets Fall; Frazier Rehired
description: The Mets chose a glum occasion yesterday to announce some good news for Joe Frazier. Five minutes after the San Diego Padres defeated Tom Seaver and his teammates, 30, at Shea Stadium the Mets said Frazier's oneyeag contract as manager had, been extended through the 1977 season.

title: Antiques
description: AS IF THERE WERE NOT enough criteria for evaluating American Presidents, there is now an opportunity to add to the list one morethe manner which the Chief Executives set their tables. By this criterion, Rutherford B. Hayes and Chester A.. Arthur would be among the nation's most memorable Presidents, while Abraham Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt would be eminently forgettable. A chance to make your own evaluation is available through Sept. 5 at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, where the Smithsonian Institution's traveling exhibition service is presenting a show Presidential china from George and Martha Washington to Gerald and Betty Ford.

title: Pro Transactions
description: METSExtended Manager Joe Frazler's contract through 1977.

title: Court Rules That Nadjari Exceeded Limits on Case
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn ruled unanimously yesterday that Maurice H. Nadjari the former special state prosecutor, had had no jurisdiction to prosecute a retired Brooklyn Civil Court judge, Fred G. Moritt.

title: Restaurants
description: ONSIDERING THE DUST and turmoil of traffic, dining at a sidewalk cafe in New York can be anything but a felicitous experience. But a garden is something else again. Protected from noise and turmoil by the walls of houses that surround them, the city's secret gardens are often lushly green oases, offering comparatively fresh, chlorophyllfiltered air and the magical stageset glimmer of lights of nearby apartments twinkling through ailanthus trees.

title: Some Music Schools
description: Because of the vast number of teachers and schools offering instruction in music, recommendations of friends can be important before choosing. The names of some schools are widely known, but the schools vary widely. To indicate that variety, here is a partial list of schools in Manhattan that offer preinstrumental classes for children of nurseryschool age and somewhat older and also provide instruction in instruments.

title: Jobless Benefits Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)  About 5.4 million Americans received unemployment insurance benefits in the week ending July 24a decrease of 35,000 from the previous week. The number was also down from the 6.5 million total of a year earlier.

title: French Franc Plunges
description: The French franc penetrated an important psychological barrier of five to the dollar and hit a 30month low of 4.99905.0010. Page D5.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor With the election coming up, it would be highly desirable to air all views on what American foreign policy should be. With dtente suffering from criticism and declining in appeal, both at home and abroad, it is indeed high time to call for a new guiding concept that will give clear direction to U.S. policy.

title: Court Rejects I.T.T. Bid In Hartford Holder Suit
description: A United States District Court judge has rejected a proposed settlement of a shareholder suit against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation over its 1970 acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A cab driver who allegedly ran down two firemen Tuesday, injuring one seriously, has been identified as Eduardo Guerra, a former Cuban Air Force officer who deceived the American radar screen and landed his Russianmade MEG jet at Homestead Air Base in Florida in 1969. That flight caused officials concern because former President Richard M. Nixon's plane was being refueled just yards from where the Cuban landed. Now Mr. Guerra has been booked oncharges of assault, reckless endangerment, attempted escape, criminal possession of a weapon and obstruction of governmental administration. Mr. Guerra is currently on probation for a $161 grocery store robbery.

title: 17 Metals Ruled Out in Test For Legion Disease Cause
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 The Center for Disease Control in Atlanta said today that 17 metals had been excluded as possible causes of the mysterious legionnaires disease that has killed 27 persons in Pennsylvania.

title: Students Raise City's Cash Flow
description: Working under a $25,000 grant and at no cost to the city 17 top accounting majors at Baruch College, part of the City University of New York, have increased New York City's cash flow by $38 million over the last two months.

title: P.B.A.WILL APPEAL WORK SCHEDULES
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday that it would file an appeal today with the Office of Collective Bargaining seeking to overturn the decision of an impasse panel calling for new work schedules.

title: 3 States Said to Woo Amex for Late 1980's
description: Formal presentations from three statesNew York, New Jersey and Connecticutare uder preparation in an effort to woo the American Stock Exchange, industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Greece, in U.N., Cautions Turkey on Aegean Moves
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 12Greece accused Turkey in the Security Council today of provocative acts in the Aegean Sea and warned that a mere accident might suffice to lose control of the situation.

title: BEIRUT CHRISTIANS TAKE TELL ZAATAR AFTER LONG SIEGE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12Rightwing Christians announced today that the Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar had fallen to their forces, which had the camp under siege since midJune.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT IS NO SECRET that James A. Pike was at times in his life an adulterer, an alcoholic, a heretic, a twotime loser at marriage, a frequenter of dubious seances and a public liar. His first wife went off with another man; his second wife locked him out of his official residence; his son and mistress committed suicide, and a daughter attempted it.

title: How to Get There
description: To get to the Mahopac Farm Playhouse, take the Henry Hudson Parkway north until it turns into the Saw Mill River Parkway. Follow the Saw Mill to the Hawthorne Circle north of White Plains, to the Taconic State Parkway, exiting at Route 6 going east.

title: Landmark In Margate Is Restored
description: MARGATE, Aug. 12Lucy the Elephant, for nearly a century a tourist attraction in this Atlantic County resort, today received a new howdah, or canopied seatwhich will be used as ion.

title: Connors And Vilas Advance
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors advanced to the third round, anal secondseeded Guillermo Vilas gained the fourth, or quarterfinal, round today in the $157,000 national clay court tennis championships with straightset victories.

title: Hundreds of Embittered Palestinian Refugees From Tell Zaatar Camp Gather at School in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12 (Reuters)Hundreds of Palestinian refugees from the Tell Zaatar camp assembled by the truckload at an empty school in southwestern Beirut today.

title: GOLDIN CRITICIZES A RENTAL BY CITY
description: The city is paying more than $1 million a year to rent a 500,000squarefoot warehouse in Queens that is nearly 50 percent larger than necessary Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

title: Woman Who Quit Job To Get State Benefits
description: A young Long Island woman who quit her job on West 42d Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, because she was frightened by several incidents in which she was accosted by men in the area, has been ruled eligible for $46 a week unemployment insurance.

title: Business Briefs
description: The nation's mutual savings banks had a net deposit inflow of $350 million during July, acording to preliminary statistics issued yesterday by the National Association Mutual Savings Banks. This was a strong increase over June's $55 million inflow, and the second highest for the month after the $414 million inflow in July 1972.

title: WestEast German Talks On
description: BONN, Aug. 12 (Reuters)Erich Honecker, the East German leader, and Gunter Gaus of West Germany met in East Berlin today in what was seen as an attempt to ease strained relations between the two states. The meeting followed consultations between Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and Mr. Gaus yesterday.

title: Box Scores and Standings
description: Friday, August 13, 1976

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: ARGENTINA BESET BY ARREST QUERIES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12A United States diplomatic protest over the isolation in which an arrested American priest is being held here reflects a complaint by many Argentines who cannot find out where and why their children or relatives are under arrest.

title: State G.O.P. Chiefs Denounce Buckley For Presidency Bid
description: New York Republican leaders reacted angrily yesterday to a conservative effort promoting Senator James L. Buckley for the party's Presidential nomination. They contended that it was essentially a lstop Ford move.

title: To the Cloisters They Wend
description: Medieval knights will hold jousts, troubadors will perform and squires and princesses will dance and frolic in the cobblestone courtyard of the Cloisters Museum in Fort Tryon Park tomorrow afternoon.

title: Soviet Finance Aide Dies
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (UPI)Ivan 1. Fadeyev, longtime Finance Minister of the biggest of the Soviet Union's 15 constituent republics, died on Tuesday, the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya said today. He was 70. Mr. Fadeyev served from 1949 to 1973 as Finance Minister of the Russian Republic. He was in retirement at the time of his death.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: WNEWTV (Channel 5) has chosen the summertime when the competition is easy to introduce the series that promises to be the jewel of its new schedule, Fall of Eagles. A sumptuous production of the British Broadcasting Corporation, it has been sold here to commecrcial television rather than to the Public Broadcasting Service and has its premiere Sunday. Otherwise, this weekend is mildly saturated with news specials previewing the Republican National Convention in Kansas City which Monday.

title: Jazz Band Helps Bergen Jail Inmates Beat Time
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 11  Man the joint is jumpin'

title: SHERMAN G. DRAKE
description: Sherman G. Drake, a former president of Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, died Wednesday irr New York Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Trgnton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12 Governor Byrne and one of his appointees to the State Board of Public Utility CornAnatouers disagreed today over how implementation of any new system of energy retes should be handled.

title: Railroad Freight Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.2 billion tonmiles, 1.4 percent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 432,524 cars, 4 percent below last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was 5.9 percent above last year.

title: RUBBER WORKERS REACH AGREEMENT
description: Top negotiators for the United Rubber Workers and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company have reached an understanding on basic economic issues after five days of intensive talks in Washington.

title: Tornado in Florida Leaves One Dead and Seven Injured
description: LARGO, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP) A tornado churned through a mobile home community of retired people late today, killing a woman and injuring at least seven other persons, the authorities said.

title: Decline in Bank Robberies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that the number of bank robberies declined in the fiscal year that ended last June 30 but 32 lives were lost in the robberies. Seventeen of those killed were bank robbers, the bureau said. Six were law enforcement officers, five were bank guards, three were bank employes and one a customer.

title: Hynes Asks Jail Sentences For WhiteCollar Crimes
description: MINEOLA, LI., Aug. 12Charles J. Hynes the New York State special prosecutor for nursing homes called today for stricter penalties, including jail sentences, for whitecollar defendants convicted of crimes.

title: Four Killed in Drag Race
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (UPI) Four teenagers from suburban Lakewood were killed today when their pickup truck crashed into a tree during a drag race with a van. The victims were James Brunner 18 years old; Susan Popovic 19, Patricia Koz, 16 and Myral Cash, 17.

title: Market Place
description: Considering the great public interest in the DowJones industrial average, the an3%0=cm:tient seemed mysterious.

title: STATE G.O.P CHIEFS SCORE BUCKLEY BID
description: New York Republican leaders reacted angrily yesterday to a conservative effort promoting Senator James L. Buckley for the party's Presidential nomination. They contended that it was essentially stop Ford move.

title: ELDERLY COUPLE SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: A 74yearold Brooklyn man and his 82yearold wife were found bludgeoned to death in their Borough Park apartment last night, the apparent victims of a burglar who had bound and gagged them before murdering them in the home they had shared for 40 years.

title: STRIKING MINERS GOING BACK ON JOB
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 12 (AP)Thousands of Appalachian coal miners began returning to work today in the first major break in a wildcat strike that the industry says has cost the nation more than $130 million in lost production.

title: 3JUDGE COURT USE FOR U.S. CASES CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12President Ford signed today a measure that restricts the cases in which threejudge courts will be impaneled, thus reducing the workload of the Federal judiciary.

title: Notes on People
description: Vice President Rockefeller swore in H. Guyford Stever yesterday as the White House science adviser, reviving an office that was discontinued in the Nixon Administration. President Ford told guests at the Cabinet Room ceremony that his interest in science and technology began with his first Congressional term a ouartercentury aeo.

title: ETHIOPIA REPORTS 2 FUGITIVES SLAIN
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Aug. 12 (Reuters)Two former members of Ethiopia's ruling Military Council, fugitives since an antiGovernment plot failed last month, have been executed lby the newly created People's Militia, a council statement said.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWNEW, 7:50 P.M.)

title: The Paradox In Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 12The paradox of the 1976 Republican National Convenden is that Gerald Ford appears likely to be nominated, but that almost everything else seems to be largely out of his control.

title: Calloway: Improvising for 70 years
description: During the 40's they used to say I had 40 suits and 40 pairs of shoes. It ain't true.OF MINNIE THE MOOCHER & ME. By Cob Calloway and Bryant Rollins. 282 pages. Crowell. $9.95.

title: ITT Reznor Lifting Prices Of Heating Products 5%
description: ITT Reznor, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday in Mercer Pa., that it would increase prices on all heating products by 5 percent, effective Sept. 1.

title: 2 GUNMEN ASSAULT HEAD OF POLAROID
description: WALTRAM, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP)  A man who assaulted the president of the Polaroid Corporation in a suspected kidnapping attempt has been identified by witnesses as a fugitive from an indictment in a series of New England bombings, the police said today.

title: MORGAN EVANS, 72 ARBITRAGE EXPERT
description: Morgan D. Evans, an authority on arbitrage who specialized in this field of securities trading at White Weld & Co., died of a heart ailment on Tuesday in his apartment in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 72 years old.

title: Police Seize Peddlers Merchandise In New Crackdown in New York City
description: A 19yearold  call him Steve, he said  was selling threeinone dolls flip Red Riding Hood's dress and you get Grandmother, and flip Grandmother and you get the Big Bad Wolf.

title: RUBBER WORKERS REACH AGREEMENT
description: Top negotiators for the United Rubber Workers and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company have reached an understanding on basic economic issues after five days of intensive talks in Washington.

title: The Pop Life
description: JOAN MORRIS, a mezzosoprano, and William Bolcom, a pianist (and, in other contexts, a firstrate composer), have just released a record on Nonesuch called Vaudeville, Songs of the Great Ladies of the Musical Stage that is a sequel to their 1974 disk, After the Ball, a Treasury of TurnoftheCentury Popular Songs. Both records are not only most enjoyable in themselves, but also document a key link in the chain of popular music back through the decades.

title: People in Sports
description: Phil Sellers of Rutgers agreed to terms with the Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association yesterday. The terms were not disclosed.

title: BEIRUT CHRISTIANS TAKE TELL ZAATAR AFTER LONG SIEGE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12Rightwing Christians announced today that the Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar had fallen to their forces, which had the camp under siege since midJune.

MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516), 747.0500: SUF. FOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT 12031 3487767.

title: Yankees Crush Twins, 125
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn. Aug. 12  The Minnesota Twins introduced a gimmick to their games tonight. They placed boxes around Metropolitan Stadium and invited fans to fill them with suggestions. Then they gave their fans a ton of ideas by allowing 16 hits and committing five errors as they lost to the Yankees, 125.

title: British Steel Output Off
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (UPI)Steel production in Britain in July averaged 367,000 tons a week, 15.17 percent below the average for June, the stateowned British Steel Corporation said today.

title: Alaska Pipeline Finishing Date in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12(AP) Welding deficiencies along the TransAlaska Pipeline are being resolved, but it still is not known whether the inspection and repairs will delay the completion date, Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe said today.

title: Tom Driberg Dies; Scholar and ExM.P. Was Controversial
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP)Tom Driberg, a controversial former Member of Parliament collapsed in a taxi and died at London hospital today. He was 71 years old.

title: Wrong Equation
description: Attorney General Edward H. Levi, while speaking before the American Bar Association this week, deplored the current level of public debate. Unfortunately, his contribution on that occasion did little to raise that level.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: Distributor Finds Business Is Key To Film Making
description: Early in the 20th century, when such movie producers as Louis B. Mayer, Irving Thalberg and Samuel Goldwyn were getting started, they were businessmen first and artists second. But most wouldbe producers today enter the business as successful actors agents or screenwriters. The aspirant presents a major studio with a project he hopes will fit management's idea of what the public is looking for so that the studio will back him with, say, $1 million. If he gets the money, he may founder through inexperience and never produce again. One who hasn't foundered is Robert IC. Shaye 37yearold New York film distributor who believes in the old technique of learning business methods first and then becoming a producer.

title: $400 Million U.S. Transit Aid Awaiting Jersey Accord on Use
description: NEWARK, Aug. 12Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman said today that the Federal Government was ready to make $400 million available for mass transportation in northern New Jersey as soon as state and local officials agreed on its use.

title: Bridge:
description: The American Contract Bridge League employs about 85 persons, mainly at its headquarters in Memphis.

title: Taking Measure
description: MEASURE FOR MEASURE by Shakespeare. Directed by John Pasquin setting and costumes by Santo Loguasto; lighting by Martin Aronstein; music by William Penn; production supervisor, Jason Steven Cohen; production stage manager, Frank Bayer. Presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival, Joseph Papa, Producer Bernard Gersten, associate producer. At the Delacorte Theater, West 81st Street Central Park.

title: WINSTON HIBLER A DISNEY WRITER
description: Winston Hibler, who produced many films and television shows depicting animal life for Walt Disney Productions, with which he had been associated since 1942, died Sunday at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank Calif. He was 65 years old and lived in Glendale, Calif.

title: PEKING IS RAZING DAMAGED HOUSES
description: PEKING, Aug. 12As if by some sort of signal, hundreds of Chinese civilians and army men have begun widespread demolition and reconstruction work in China's capital during the last two days.

title: Greenwich: An Outdoor Sculpture Museum
description: Greenwich, Conn., an affluent suburban community has mounted something of a treasure hunt. Judiciously placed around the town, in lush green parks overlooking streams and harbor, along gracious treelined streets and bustling boutiquelined thoroughfares, are firstclass works of modern sculpture living with the town.

title: PLATFORM PANEL VOTES TO ENDORSE EQUAL RIGHTS PLAN
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 12 The Republican Platform Committee, in an emotional battle that could set up the party's first convention floor fight, voted tonight, 51 to 47 to endorse the equal rights amendment.

title: Screen: 'Futureworld':Science-Fiction Robots in Dominant Roles
description: "Futureworld" is a film about robots and, evidently, for robots. It is as much fun as running barefoot through Astroturf.A sequel to "Westworld," the film once again deals with a skeptical reporter who uncovers dirty doings in a great pleasure garden of the future known as Dlos.If they pay a great deal of money, people can go to Delos (by Laker Airways, apparentlya dubious plug in view of what eventually happens there) and live a fantasy life in one of its sections. These are devoted respectively to recreating the Old West, the Middle Ages and space travel. Robots looking exactly like real people provide a variety of services: sex, for instance, or convincing-looking Indians or knights for the clients to kill.In the earlier film the reporter discovered that some defect in circuitry was causing the robots to kill the customers. In "Futureworld," which opened yesterday at showcase theaters, the same reporter, Chuck Browning, goes back and discovers something far worse: a plot to use the facilities of Delos to get control of all the important people in the world.Browning and his sidekick, Tracy Ballard, go to Delos, accompanied by a planeload of important prospective victims: a Russian general, an Arab sheik, an influential Japanese. The latter plunge into the fun  the Russian imagines himself a czarist general, the Japanese, a knight-in-armor-with-camerawhile Browning and Ballard investigate the plumbing.After lots of running and hot-breathed pursuit the pair discover what the viewer discovered at least a half-hour earlier: that all these world-leader types are being killed and look-alike robots are being returned in their place. This, as one scientist explains, allows them to be operated by remote-control in the interests of world peace and reason.It is all the most ordinary kind of hardware science fiction, full of computers and empty of thought. It features miles and miles of tubes and pipes and valves and as Tracywho otherwise mostly says "Let's get out of here"intelligently observes: "It is about as exciting as a visit to the waterworks."As the manager of the place, Arthur Hill mugs sleek villainy. Blythe Danner, as Tracy, and Peter Fonda as Chuck have absolutely nothing to do. Starring in "Futureworld" must be the actor's equivalent of going on welfare.The film is rated PG. Parents are advised that there is nothing offensive in it. Offensiveness would help.

Revenues were $7.14 million and expenditures were $9.41 million.

description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 13 (Reuters)A threeman commission of inquiry, set up by the Government to investigate allegations that Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands received large bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, has reported its findings to Prime Minister Joop den Uyl.

title: Platform Panel Supports Ford Foreign Policy View
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 13The Republican Platform Committee approved tonight a party document generally supporting President Ford's foreign policies and containing conservative planks aimed at pleasing his rival, Ronald Reagan.

title: Ailey: More Ellingtonia
description: Alvin Ailey's celebration of Duke Ellington continues at the New York Theater at Lincoln Center. It is an impressive enough salute to an American jazz composer who has given an enormous amount to American music.

title: EDWARD L. RHETT
description: Edward L. Rhett, a retired Time Inc. executive, died Monday at his Dennis, Mass., home. He was 64 years old.

title: Opera: Figaro, Egisto at Santa Fe
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 13 The Santa Fe Opera is essentially an ensemble company that shows itself to best advantage in works requiring teamwork rather than the services of one or two superstars. This season's brilliant new production of Virgil Thomson's panoramic view of 19thcentury America The Mother of Us All, is an excellent case in point.

title: U.S. HALTS LICENSES FOR NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced today that it would temporarily stop issuing fullpower plant operating licenses while its staff assessed the environmental impact of fuel reprocessing and waste management associated with plants.

title: 5 IMPORTED CARS TO RAISE PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) Five manufacturers of foreign automobiles have agreed to raise their prices in the United States in response to findings that they were selling cars in this country more cheaply than at home, the Treasury Department announced today. The action will mean higher prices for American buyers of imported cars made by Volkswagen Volvo, Saab, Renault and Ford of West Germany, which makes Canris.

title: Connors Triumphs Over Meiler
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug, 13 (UPI)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors overcame three set points against him in the first set and rallied for a 75, 63 victory over West Germany's Karl Meiler today to reach the quarterfinals of the $157,000 national claycourt tennis championships.

title: East Germans Bar Protest From West
description: BONN, Aug. 13East German border policemen prevented hundreds of West German students from crossing to West Berlin by bus today for a protest against the wall that sealed the division of the city 15 years ago. A number of others were able to get through, however.

title: U.S. Fidelity Considering A Bid for Richmond Corp.
description: The Richmond Corporation, a holding company for large insurance organizations, said yesterday that the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company was showing serious interest in making a bid for Richmond. Warren Merger M. Pace, president News of Richmond, said that while no firm offer was in hand U.S.F.&G.'s interest appeared to involve a consideration in excess of that initially offered by the Continental Group Inc.

title: Air of Indifference
description: After a fouryear study, State Controller Arthur Levitt has issued a report on New York City's air pollution control programs which strongly confirms what environmentally concerned citizens have long contendedthat city and state officials show little interest in cleaning up the city's air, especially when it means inconveniencing motorists, who are the worst polluters.

title: 2 Rubber Worker Panels Back Pact to End Strike
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 13An economic settlement that would increase wages and benefits by P.20 an hour over three years was approved here today by two top committees of the United Rubber Workers.

title: Turks Take 2 Palestinians To Reenact Airport Attack
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 13 (Reuters)  Two Palestinian guerrillas were taken amid strict security measures to the Istanbul Yesilkoy airport today for a reenactment of the unsuccessful attempt Wednesday to hijack an Israeli airliner.

title: SOVIET GRANTS VISAS AT A HIGHER RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI)  The Soviet Union is slightly increasing the number of exit visas granted to Jews going to Israel and is issuing substantially more to West Germany and the United States the State Department said today.

title: Blues on Oboe by Yusef Lateef Enhanced by Barron, on Piano
description: One of the more fascinating jazz experiences is hearing the blues played on oboe by Yusef Lateef. The instrument, with its wry, plaintively singing quality is an ideal vehicle for the blues and Mr. Lateef, a superb technician and a musician with deep sure jazz instincts, is a disciplined and expressive performer. He concluded his first set at the Bottom Line Thursday evening with an oboe version of In the Evening, When the Sun Goes Down, building a performance charged with tremendous intensity that brought the cheering audience to its feet.

title: Preseason Football
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Geeland 41, N.Y. Jets 17. New Oelimes 21, Buffalo 14.

title: Amex MGIC Options
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday it had asked for authority to begin options trading in the MGIC Investment Corporation. This would bring to 59 the number of options traded on the Amex.

title: REP. FLOOD LINKED TO A LUXURY TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI)  Representative. Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and his wife took a fiveday cruise on the liner Queen Elizabeth 2 and stayed at luxury hotels  at the expense of taxpayers on what was supposed to be an official trip to Europe last year, it was reported today by ScrippsHoward newspapers.

title: Haig Talks With Juan Carlos
description: PALMA DE MAJORCA, Spain Aug. 13 (Reuters)Gen. Alexander M. Haig, commander of NATO forces, met with King Juan Carlos here today. General Haig said after the 25minute meeting that he and the King had discussed security in the Mediterranean.

title: BROWN U. NAMES PRESIDENT TODAY
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. Aug. 13Brown University will name Dr. Howard R. Swearer, president of Carleton College in North field, Minn., as its 15th president tomorrow ending a long effort to fill the post.

title: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT IN GULF GAS DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) A Federal Power Commission judge recommended today that the Justice Department investigate the Gulf Oil Corporation and a naturalgas buyer, the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Houston, for possible criminal conspiracy.

title: Port Said Is Bustling With Activity Again
description: PORT SAID, Egypt, Aug. 7 The renewed economic activity at this raffish old Suez Canal port includes some fleshly pursuits.

title: Where There's a Child in Trouble There's Usually a Marriage in Trouble
description: Mommy always buys you all the nice clothes! Steven shouted angrily at his sister. Pointing his finger directly into Kathy's face, he narrowly missed her nose.

title: OCEAN OIL LEASES OFF LI, ENJOINED
description: The Federal Government was enjoined yesterday from carrying out the first sale of oil and naturalgas leases in the Atlantic Ocean, which had been scheduled for next Tuesday.
