title: Harrises to Be Shifted to Berkeley Next Month for Arraignment on Charges in the Hearst Kidnapping Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14Emily and William Harris, convicted of kidnapping, robbery and auto theft this week, will be turned over to Berkeley officials next month to face arraignment on charges of kidnapping Patricia Hearst, according to the Alameda County authorities.

title: Apartments for Site of Blast
description: After standing vacant for more than two years following a massive gas explosion, a 24story office building near the United Nations is being gutted and converted into a luxury apartment tower.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Nearly a century after Louis E. Waterman conceived of the fountain pen, and some 30 years after it was driven into nearoblivion by the ubiquitous ballpoint, his splendid invention is once again finding favornot only as a quality writing instrument but as a popular collectible.

title: Kathryn Kuehn Bride of Medical Student
description: Our Savior Lutheran Church in South Windsor, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Kathryn Strider Kuehn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul G. Kuehn of South Windsor and Stonington, Conn., to Charles David Noll, son of Mrs. Charles A. Noll of Lancaster, Pa., and the late Dr. Noll, The Rev. Ronald Erbe and the Rev. Harold Burkhart, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Final Yearling Sales Total $2,241,000
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 (UPI)The annual FasigTipton yearling sales ended last night at Saratoga with the auction of 59 horses that brought $2,241,000, for an individual average of $37,983. Nine horses went unsold.

title: Anorphan's Tale
description: Among a small but articulate and intellectual group of Jewish novelists in America, there has recently emerged a striking concern with religion. While a few choose to fly over the guru's nest, the more serious and eloquent of these writers have turned their attention to traditional Judaic, teachings. seeking to connect personally with an Orthodox mode of Jewish ethical identity largely ignored by the older Jewish American novelists like Saul Bellow and Bernard Malamud. Jay Neugeboren's new novel is the most recent example of that pilgrimage, and it raises some interesting questions about the fictional value of this midrashic trend away from an obsession with the alienated self (as Cynthia Ozick expressed it in the Book Review of March 21) and toward an affirmation of the kingdom of God.

title: If a Tornado Strikes
description: With even brief warning time, most people can take simple precautions to protect themselves from the destructive action of a tornado. Here are safety rules recommended. by the National Weather Service:

title: PARTY RIVALS POSE THREATS TO MIKI
description: TOKYO, Aug. 14Prime Minister Takeo Miki, beset this week by renewed efforts within his own LiberalDemocratic Party to oust him, has repeated his intention to stay in office to pursue the Lockheed bribery scandal, oversee basic political reforms and lead the governing party into national elections this fall.

title: J. W. Muchmore Marries Miss Hallett
description: Patricia King Hallett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Erwin Bruce Hallett of Convent Station, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to John Williams Muchmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry George Muchmore of New Vernon, N, J.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Kin Platt used to do nice, relaxed drawing for the old New York Herald Tribune. Now he writes nice, notsorelaxed mysteries featuring a private eye named Max Roper. Roper specializes in cases involving sport figures. In the past, he has solved mysteries having to do with horse racing, tennis and, if memory serves, ice hockey. Now comes THE BODY BEAUTIFUL MURDER (Random House, $6.95), which puts the reader into the highly competitive world of body building and weight lifting.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: IT was late on a Thursday, and Representative Lester L. Wolff, Democrat of Great Neck, was still waiting. A news release had been written at his office and had been ready to go for days. Each night, a Wolff aide had had to scratch off that day's date in a hope for better things tomorrow. Speaker Carl Albert already had taped a television report with Mr. Wolff, hailing the Congressman's success.

title: LIVES BRIGHTENED BY FRESH AIR FUND
description: Sometimes the Fresh Air Fund can lead people to spend more than a summer in the countryside.

title: DINING OUT
description: A GREEK restaurant belongs in Port Jefferson. People stroll along the waterfront or browse in little shops in a new marketplace area until quite late on warm summer evenings, as they do in towns on the shores of the Aegean. With the Bridgeport ferry coming and going, boats docking in the marinas and its closeness to several North Shore summer communities, it is a busy place these days.

title: Rush It
description: Speed is the spur for the fastmoving courier business, especially with the Postal Service's tortoiselike reputation. As big business it's less than three decades oil, but includes nine international and national companies plus 100 smaller regional operations. Among the biggest are the Banker Utilities Corporation, Loomis, United Clearing, Wells Fargo and American Courier.

title: Rail Outlook Brightening
description: AMTRAK, the national rail passenger system, and the Federal Railroad Administration have some major improvements on tap for New Jersey as the Northeast edges toward highspeed train service. The Jersey improvements, scheduled as part of a $1.9 billion upgrading of the WashingtonNew YorkBoston Northeast Corridor over the next five years, include:

title: Dr. William C. Wright with old scrolls. Left, modern microfilming
description: TRENTON F OR those who would trace the arrival of Dutch or Scottish settlers in New Jersey or the early days of the American Revolution, the expansion of the state archives in the last three decades has been nothing short of remarkable and has been described by scholars as a find.

title: The Ballet: Black Kings
description: The major New York premiere of the Ailey Celebrates Ellington season at the New York State Theater was given by the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater Friday night. It was Mr. Ailey's latest work, Three Black Kings, to, of course, Ellington music, which like much of Mr. Ailey's recent output seems rather stronger on spectacle than in invention.

title: Judith McGeehan Wed
description: In the United Methodist Church of Babylon, L. I. yesterday afternoon Judith Ann McGeehan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. McGeehan of West Islip, L. I., was married to John Boller Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Henderson of Rochester. The Rev. Jack E. Savage performed the ceremony.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Arts and Leisure Guide

title: Long Island/This Week
description: COLD SPRING HARBORPaintings by Sondra Lee, through Sept. 11; Sundays, 1 to P.M., Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Harbor Gallery, 43 Main St.

title: Ford's New Choice For T.V.A. Board Faces Opposition
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 14President Ford's nomination of Thomas L. Longshore, a 44yearold official of the Alabama Power Company, to fill a vacancy on the threemember board of the Tennessee Valley Authority appears to be running into trouble, as did the President's first nominee, James Hooper of Mississippi.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The legionnaire's disease that has killed at least 24 people remains mysterious, and scientific investigaLors are now concentrating their efforts on two approaches, one broadgauged, the other narrow. In addition, one particular location, the Bellevue Stratford hotel in Philadelphia, headquarters of the American Legion convention from July 21 to 24, has now fallen under special investigation, according to the Pennsylvania secretary of health.

title: Maria Shrady to Wed Bonn Consul
description: The engagement of Maria Theresia Shrady to Bernd von Waldow of Bonn, son of Gisela von Waldow of Reinbek. West Germany. and the late Friedrich von Waldow, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Shrady of Monroe, Conn.

title: Rumsfeld Recuperating; Spends a Quiet Night
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld spent a quiet night at Bethesda Naval Hospital following surgery yesterday for removal of an apparently noncancerous limy on his thyroid gland, a pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Attack on Feeney Obscures Issues
description: When baseban club owners and top officials scattered after their annual summer meeting in Phoenix on Thursday, they knew they had a lot of unfinished business on their handsbut they had no idea that a bizarre announcement by one of their oldest members was about to give the public a distorted and incomplete impression about their real concerns.

title: FeinsteinThe Cultural Powerhouse on the Potomac
description: Want to stay your baby, the cable stated, and authorize you to negotiate 1977 U.S. tour. It was from Dieter Graefe, the manager of the Stuttgart Ballet, and was addressed to Martin Feinstein, executive director for the performing arts at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C. The wording of the cable was both flip and authoritative. Its breeziness, however, symbolizes a fresh wind of change blowing in the field of concert presentationsone which appears to be strengthening the importance of Washington, D. C. in the cultural affairs of the United States. And that could have considerable significance for opera, symphony and ballet patrons.

title: Soviet Urges Restraint
description: ATHENS, Aug. 14 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has urged Greece and Turkey to exercise the utmost selfrestraint in their dispute over territorial rights in the Aegean.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WESTHAM PTON THE fun of shopping in the Hamptons is that you can do it in sun gear, tennis gear or golf gear, at leisure, in a wandering way, in the morning, the eveningand even on Sunday.

title: BUS LANE'S FUTURE DIMMER ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, AUG. 14One of the Federal Government's principal experiments for promoting bus travel and car pooling, to cut urban traffic and air pollution, was halted suddenly this week. Whether it could be revived seemed highly, problematical.

title: Bringing in the Left Hand to Audit the Right
description: In recent years, most publicly owned companies have complied with a Securities and Exchange Commission request to set up audit commutes by drawing on outside members of their boards of directors.

title: YUGOSLAV EXILES IN BELGIUM AFRAID
description: BRUSSELS, AUG. 14 A series of murders, threats and kidnappings has created a climate of fear and suspicion in the small community of antiTito exiles here.

title: Robber Slays Woman, 21, In West Side Apartment
description: A 21yearold woman was shot and killed by a masked robber who forced his way into a West Side apartment last night.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: KANSAS CITY, MoUnless Republicans camp out in the stockyards, where the convention starts tomorrow, they will have a hard time leaving this city without treading on ground owned or developed by the J. C, Nichols Company.

title: Joseph Gross Weds Miss McConnell
description: In St. Anastasia Roman Catholic Church in Douglaston, Queens, yesterday morning Maureen McConnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McConnell of Douglaston, became the bride of Joseph Gross, son of Mrs. John Hubert of Riverhead, L.I.,and the late Walter Gross.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: This has to have been the most remarkable season in New York's dance history. We've been treated to our native companies: the Joffrey, of course, New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theater, the Pennsylvania Ballet, the Eliot Feld Ballet. And their all the great modern  dance companies: Martha Graham, Alwin Nikolais, Paul Taylor, Merce Cunningham, Alvin Ailey (who even now is at the New York State Theater), Murray Louis. And that is not even to mention the vast, diverse selection of dance events that are not yet on what might be called a Broadway level. What's more, there have been all the visiting companies: a casual band of Russians organized by Igor Moiseyev, Britain's Royal Ballet, the Royal Danish Ballet, the National Ballet of Canada. And then there have been all the visiting guest artists. It has been a great dance year.

title: Roberts and Nadjari Clash at Cornell
description: ITHACA. N. Y. Aug. 14Justice Burton B. Roberts of the State Supreme Court charged here today that corruption in the state's court system existed only in the wild headlines of the media and In the minds of young and inexperienced prosecutors.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Amateur photographers are like hunters. They try to capture life as they see it in front of the camera. But the advertising photographer must create the scene that he will photograph and try to make it look natural.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)  A 257Yearold Washington man scaled the spiked ence in front of the White House today the fourth time in two year's but was captured quickly once he readied the lawn inside, a Secfer Service spokesman said.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust has taken title to the leaseholds, in lieu of foreclosure, on three Manhattan apartment buildings that had been controlled by Hyman Shapiro, the developer who has been unable to complete several large residential towers here and in Fort Lee, N.J., in recent years.

title: Kinnon Jones, L. V. Farrar Jr. Have Nuptials
description: The marriage of Kinnon Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Jones of Mount Kisco, N. Y., to Louis Vollers Farrar Jr. son of Mr. Farrar of Katonah, N. Y., and Emily Farrar of Weston, Vt., took place in Bedford, N. Y., yesterday afternoon. The Rev. John Morris performed the cerethony in St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: What were described as four Spanish  speaking pirates boarded a crippled sailing sloop, the Feisty. off Colombia last July 18 and killed two Americans, Bobby Fisher and Wayne Dahling, both of Miami. Two other Americans survived. The Coast Guard called it a case of piracy.

title: While Everyone Awaits Dr. Carter
description: WASHINGTONForeign policy in this city now mostly living in the future. It is as if the diplomats, Administration officials, Congressmen and their aides and wouldbe Democratic officeholders have already bought stock in a Carter victory.

title: Miss Roemer Becomes Bride
description: Victoria Lane Roemer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Conrad Roemer Jr. of WinstonSalem, N. C., was married last night to Dr. Alfred James Cianfloceo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel James Cianflocco of Erie. Pa.

title: U.S. PLAYING DOWN PACT WITH TAIWAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14President Ford and leading members of his Administration, in prepared speeches and in presentations to Congress, have made no mention of the United States defense treaty with Taiwan for over a year.

title: ENCOUNTER
description: I first visited San Remo in 1955 as a 21yearold sailor aboard a Navy destroyer called the Robert K. Huntington. Shortly after we entered port, the officer who was to be in charge of a Shoes.) Patrol detail started to search the ship for someone fluent enough in Italian to serve as interpreter.

title: J. D. Quinn 3d, Eileen Garrity Have Nuptials
description: Eileen Garrity, daughter of Magistrate John Barnard Garrity of the thrited States Southern District of New York. and Mrs. Garrity of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to Joseph Dennis Quinn 3d, son of Judge Joseph D. Quinn Jr. of the New York Satte Court of Claims, and Mrs. Quinn of Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Fighting raged yesterday in the suburbs east of Beirut and heavy shelling was reported between Moslem and Christian villages on the main BeirutDamascus highway. Rightist Christians and leftist Moslems alike appeared convinced that the next big battles, following the fall of Tell Zaatar, would occur in the upper Matein district, about 30, miles east of Beirut, and in the hills southeast of the city. Witnesses at Tell Zaatar reported looting and said Christian militiamen had been replaced by demolition crews with bulldozers to remove the rubble of 52 days of siege and level the site. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Pro Football Training Camps Time of Anguish for Players
description: Although they may seem so on the outside because of the continuing banter at the practice fields, in the dormitories and cafeterias, pro football's training camps are not carefree, happy places. The currents of inse curity run deep because so many fall by the wayside in the final month before the regular season begins. The insecurities breed boredom, frustration, selfreproach, fear for job or for body.

title: Bush Means Without Class
description: In the years the Yankees dominated baseball, many adjectives were applied to them, not all complimentary. Depending on where the critic stood, they were mighty, arrogant, gifted, proud, magnificent, supercilious, splendid, smug, stately, pompous or grand. How can you root for the Yankees? an actor asked. Ifs like rooting for United States Steel. But nobody ever called them bush. Not then. Not until now. In a game with the Orioles in Yankee Stadium, a decision at first base went against the home team and the home fans booed.

title: Partition a Reality
description: BEIRUT, Aug., 14 (AP)The leader'of Lebanon's largest Christian militia said today that after 17 months of civil war between Christians and Moslems, partition has be come a reality.

title: A U.S. Nuclear Sub Visits Australia After Ban Is Lifted
description: PERTH, Australia, Aug. 14 (UPI)An American nuclear submarine, the first to visit Australia since the Government lifted a ban on the entry of nuclearpowered warships to Australian ports two months ago, arrived today at the Cockburn Sound Naval Base, 15 miles south of here.

title: Park Is Calling for New Talks Between Koreas
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 14 President Park Chung Hee is calling for renewed negotiationsbetween South and North Korea on the territorial division of the country.

title: They See the Bureaucracy as an Insatiable Octopus
description: They See the Bureaucracy as an Insatiable Octopus

title: New Rules On Tunas Debated
description: LIBERALIZED regulations for the taking of Atlantic bluefin tuna. which were introduced earlier this season by the National Marine Fisheries Service, took effect yesterday, but the rules have professional charterboat captains and sportsmen operating along the Jersey Coast angry and frustrated.

title: The Last Round
description: The Republican convention opens tomorrow with its main business unresolved, a rarity in American politics. Though the betting favors Gerald Ford, his contest with Ronald Reagan for the Republican nomination is as close as it ever has been.

title: Slain Paris Gunman Linked To Attempt to Kill de Gaulle
description: PARIS, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The police have identified a gunman killed during a foiled holdup as one of the men who participated in the most serious attempt ever made on the life of de Gaulle.

title: War on Cancer: The. Deadly Fight
description: THE CANCER ATLAS, published in 1975 by the National Cancer Institute, showed that for a large number of different cancers the State of New Jersey, as a whole and many counties within the state ranked significantly above the national average over the 20year period from 1950 to 1970.

title: Soviet Squad Leads Final
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (AP)Alex Metreveli and Teimuraz Kakulia of the Soviet Union defeated Balacz Taroci and Peter Seke, 1210, 60. 64, today to give the Soviet squad a 21 lead over Hungary in the Davis Cup European Zone A tennis final in Tbilisi, Soviet. Georgia, Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported.

title: Death Penalty Revival Voted
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Massachusetts House has approved legislationreinstating capital punishment for 11 categories of first degree murder. Lawmakers said the bill, passed Thursday, compiled with guide lines established in last month's United States Supreme Court ruling on capital punishment. However, it was doubtful that it would satisfy last December's stricter State Supreme Judicial Court ruling on the same subject.

title: Julie Preston Is Bride
description: Julie Macon Preston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Macon A. Preston of Rochester, was married there yesterday to Thomas Edward Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Smith, also of Rochester. The ceremony was performed in $t. Paul's Episcopal. Church by the Rev. William H. English. The couple are students at Monroe Community College, where the bride's father is an instructor in computer sciences.

title: Rwanda, Blockaded by Uganda, Short of Supplies
description: KIGALI, Rwanda Aug. 14 (UPI)Four million people are packed into this beautiful mountainous land in central Africa, making it the most densely populated country in Africa.

title: Bay Mare Wins Title At Monmouth Show
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 14 Five days from now, Leslie Buchanan will pack her bags and head for Southern Seminary, a junior college in Buena Vista, Va.

title: New Brown President Met by Faculty and Strikers
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 14 (AP)Dr. Howard R. Swearer, the new president of Brown University, arrived at the Ivy League school's campus here today and was greeted by university officials and striking employees.

title: Paperbacks
description: FATHERS AND CHILDREN, by Michael Paul Rogin. (Vintage, $4.95.) An attempt to use neoFreudian principales in analyzing Andrew Jackson and his reduction of the American Indian: a atimulating if not completely convining new look.

title: Jones, With Relief, Registers No. 19 as Padres Rout Expos
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 14 (AP) Randy Jones picked up his 19th victory tonight, with relief help from Butch Metzger, as the San Diego Padres defeated the Montreal Expos, 72.

title: Follmer, a Competitive Battler, Mellows for TransAm Today
description: You surely remember George Follmer, the driver who has been competitive in more different forms of motor racing than just about anyone, save for the late Mark Donohue.

title: Policy Reviews Proposed for Ford's New Science Aide
description: Recommendations for a series of policy reviews that could lead to basic changes in the nutrition of millions of people, in the conduct of Federal regulatory agencies and in many other fields have been submitted by two blueribbon committees formed last fall by President Ford.

title: Paris Hotels Used by Arabs Are Plagued by Fires
description: PARIS, Aug. 14Five Paris hotels have been destroyed in Ale last two months by fire that killed 26 persons and inlured many more.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: EVERY summer, a bunch of people involved with the arts and what they would be likely to call media descend on the East End of Long Island and act like natives. This season, one of them was asked by a reporter about her plans for the Fourth of July. She said that she was going to another celebrity's house to watch fireworks, and that she guessed that everyone else on the Island was doing the same thing.

title: A Tangle of Disgruntlement.
description: NASSAU COUNTY'S landlords denounce it as unjustified and destructive and insist it should be phased out. Their tenants generally feel it is very justified but currently inadequate and should be strengthened. Neither side has got its wish.

title: BLACK GROUPS PRESS FOR TEACHING JOBS
description: A coalition of black groups in the city and Representative Shirley Chisholm have called upon the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare to withhold further Federal funds to New York City schools until the city's Board of Education developed an affirmative action program.

title: Picture Credits
description: 167SUNDAY TIMES/DONALD McCULLIN

title: Burns and Charming What Do They See In Each Other?
description: George Burns sends a verbal billetdoux to Carol Chaning: You're a big little girl full of show business, he says with a grin, puffing away tempestuously on an El Producto cigar. And it spills over. That's why you're so damn funny to me.

title: Dance: Louis Johnson
description: Every choreographer does an old reliable at some point in his career, and When Malindy Sings is that ballet for Louis Johnson. In his career he has many good works to his credit, but this one's blend of folksiness and show business is a dependable crowd pleaser that looks as if it will go on forever.

title: Summer Job Program Arouses Hope and Criticism
description: Wearing sneakers and bouncing on the balls of his feet. Benjamin Ross returned from lunch, entered the connective tissue laboratory at Queens Hospital Center, slipped into his long white lab jacket and began assembling slides, pipettes, serum and buffer mixtures in preparation for doing a latex fixation.

title: Connors, Solomon Advance
description: INDIANAPOLIS. Aug. 14 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors survived a sluggish start. and overpowered Eddie Dibbs to win, 64, 63, tonight and advance to the semifinals of champion, Mandel Orantes of Spain, 62, 46, 64.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Questions about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered here.

description: Today  United States Auto Club Trenton 200 and 50mile midget race at Trenton (N.J.) International Raceway. Midget race at 1 P.M. 200mile charnpionship race at 4 P.M.

description: The 25th Amendment to the Constitution, ratified in 1967, made three separate and fundamental changes in the American Presidency. The first.

title: Panel's Proposal to Merge State U. and City U. Causes New. Disagreement
description: A debate has developed between the State University and the City University over a suggested merger of the two systems as a solution to the City University's continuing financing problems.

title: 5 IN SENATE RACE PRESS CAMPAIGNS
description: City Council President Paul O'Dwyer, who is in a fiveway race for the New York Democratic nomination for United States Senator, accused the Republican Administration in Washington yesterday of taking a diabolical position on unemployment.

title: 125 Cape Cod Nudists Defy Beach Ordinance
description: NORTH TRURO, Mass., Aug. 14 (UPI)With about 1,000 persons watching, 125 protesters stripped today to celebrate the second annual NudeIn at the Cape Cod National Seashore.

title: Chilly Scenes Of Winter
description: As gratified readers of The New Yorker know, Ann Beattie Is the best new writer to come down that particular pike since Donald Barthelme. Now many of her stories for that map tine, and a handful of others, have been collected in Distortions, and the stories and her first novel have been issued by a blatantly commercial publisher. What's more, the novel is a BookoftheMonth Club selection. The New Yorker, Doubleday and B.O.M.C. comprise a puzzling manage, surely, but a meaningful one: Beattie is a writer for all audiences.

title: Irony Behind Those Big Oil Profit Gains
description: It may seem peculiar for a security analyst to feel gloomy just after his industry reports earnings gains 25 percent above last year's, as the oil companies have done in the second quarter recently ended.

title: Food Prospects
description: The Department of Agriculture's August grain crop forecasts suggest that the United States will reap another series of bumper harvests this year. Even though the estimate for corn is somewhat lower than was projected last month, the outlook is still for a record harvest, and thus for an abundance of livestock feed. The latest wheat estimate is 3 percent higher than last month's, placing it only 2.percent below last year's record crop. The soybean outlook is relatively poorer than the expected corn and wheat harvests12 percent below last year'sbut this would still make the 1976 soybean harvest the third largest in history.

title: Miss Hoenemeyer Wed to Student
description: Mary Lynn Hoenemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Hoenemeyer Jr. of Madison, N. J., and North Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday morning to Thomas Burke O'Conor, son of Mrs. Daniel J. O'Conor Jr. of New Vernon, N. J., and the late Mr. O'Conor.

title: Dolphins Defeat Eagles
description: MIAMI, Aug. 14 (AP)Bob Griese and Don Strock, quarterbacks, combined for three touchdown passes tonight to lead the Miami Dolphins to a third straight exhibition victory in the National Football League, 2416 over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: The Moral Question Boycott The political question The Practical Question
description: Etic Bentley, playwright and critic, calls on his colleagues in theater and music to boycott next week's prestigious Shiraz festival as a protest against repression in Iran. An African nation protests the presence of New Zealand in the Olympics because its Government is supposed to have encouraged a rugby team's tour of South Africa despite its apartheid polity, and more than twodozen African nations pull out. Intellectuals the world over, following the lead of JeanPaul. Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir, refuse to have anything to do with UNESCO because or what they regard as arbitrary and unwarranted sanctions. What is the point? Are these boycotters right in doing what they're doing? What do they accomplish?

title: Members of the Delegation
description: The 17 delegates are, for the most part, middleaged men who hold either party or public office. There are two women among the Nassau delegates and one of them is the only black member of the Island's delegation.

title: Rambling Willie Sets Mark and Wins Pace
description: YONKERS, Aug.,14Rambling Willie paced to a world record for a mile and a quarter tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The 6yearold bay gelding turned in a 2:29 2/5 clocking en route to a threequarter length victory in the $35,000 second leg of Yonkers summer series.

title: Books: Was That All There Was to Revson?
description: FIRE AND ICE, THE STORY OF CHARLES REVSONTHE MAN WHO BUILT THE REVLON EMPIRE, by Andrew Tobias, William Morrow and Company, New York, 282 pages, $10.

title: Something for Nothing
description: The lure of something for nothing has often led consumers of all varieties into adventures of every description. But in no field have the offers been more frequentor more temptingthan in travel. Two writers who recently took the lure report here on their very different experiences one good, one bad.

title: Social Announcements
description: Stephen and MadeIon happily announce the birth of Erica's brother, Gabriel David, on Aug. 11, 1976. Proud granadparents are Karel and %Florence Sokoloff and Harry and Gertrude Kesselman.

title: Fashion: Paris report
description: A couple of weeks ago Yves Saint Laurent revised current fashion trends. He showed a spectacular haute couture collection that was immediately compared in impact to Christian Dior's New Look of 1947.

title: Spread of Kepone Is Posing a LongTerm Danger in Chesapeake Bay
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Chesapeake Bay faces longterm environmental dangers as contamination from the pesticide Kepone spreads throughout the estuary, according to the chairman of a Government study group.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THESE days, when we find ourselves oppressed by the lowliest of bureaucratsthose people in license departments, any license department; newly promoted clerks, and just about everybody else who regards his public position as equivalent to being in the trenches defending against that publicwe must rejoice in even our smallest victories.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY TELLS OF CHANGES
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that none of the subway service cuts to take effect on Aug. 30 will lengthen the waiting time between trains by more than one or two minutes at any time of day or night.

title: The Truth of Your Art Is in Your Imagination
description: The advertisement in several West Coast newspapers several weeks ago was small and relatively inconspicuous. It read: Stella Adler will conduct classes in Basic Acting Technique, Scene Class, Advanced Scene Class, commencing June 15 for six weeks.

title: Music

title: LUIGI GORINIDIES; MICROBIOLOGIST. 72
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 14 (UPI)Luigi Gorini, an awardwinning microbiologist who battled the rise of Facism in Italy during World War II, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: EUES PLAGUING COMMUNIST BLOC
description: WARSAW, Aug. 10If there is ever a revolution against Communism, a Pole remarked with annoyance, it will be started by someone who had to stand in line too long.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE FAMILY ARSENAL, by Paul Tberoux. (Houghton Mifflin. $8.95.) Intelligent, absorbing thriller with higher ambitions about a group of random revolutionaries in London.

title: FISHING
description: FISHERMEN have waited all summer for a good storm to mix up the water and prompt some bluefish action. Well, they got the storm. Whether Hurricane Belle had the desired effect on bluefish should start to be seen this week once the waters and the baitfish settle down.

description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 14Despite the narrow lead everyone concedes him for the Presidential nomination, Gerald Ford has been placed in a threeway bind by the proposed rules change that would require him to name his running mate in advance.

title: Tunisia Aims for Foreign Investment
description: TUNIS  Tunisia is a capitalist island in a socialist sea.

title: Tree Peony Expert Shares Some of His Trade Secrets
description: Louis Smirnow has been having a love affair with tree peonies most of his adult life. He grows them, grafts them and sells them to customers all over the world.

title: Legion Sickness Adds Philadelphia Hotel to Search
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 14Federal epidemiologists investigating a mysterious disease that has killed 25 people in Pennsylvania have added the name of the Bellevue Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia as part of their new criteria for identifying cases of the disease, according to a statement issued here today by the Pennsylvania Health Secretary, Leonard Bachman.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: First novelist. Back in 1973 Harvey Bernhard, the movie producer, phoned David Seltzer with an offer he couldn't refuse. The Exorcist was then breaking box office records. Would Seltzer create the story line and write the script for another film in the same spirit?

description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Aug. 14 (AP)Antonio Garrido of Spain slashed eight strokes off par with a 63 today to extend his lead to five strokes after the third round in the $42,000 German open golf championship. His total is 195.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on clean air amendments of 1976. which passed, 78. to 13, Aug. 5.

title: U.S. Archeologist Lost For 8 Days in Canada
description: CORNER BROOK, Canada, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Royal Mounties are searching for a 22yearold archeologist from Washington, D. C:, who has been missing for eight days in an area of Labrador populated by polar bears and described as so bleak it's called the land God gave Cain.

title: Giants Are Sharp In 3014 Triumph
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 14 The Giants showed tonight that playing two games in four nights was exhausting, but their fatigue didn't set in until the second half of their National Football League preseason game against the Houston Oilers.

title: Inquiry Begun on Official Version of Fatal Shooting in Bronx by a Policeman
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office is investigating reports that the offduty police officer who shot and fatally wounded a man near Yankee Stadium last week was intoxicated and that he ignored pleas by the man not to shoot.

title: Dancer's Life: Starving Herself While Keeping Her Strength Up
description: There are two schools of thought about dancing. The first, the danceishell or Red Shoes school, holds that the sensitive young girl who goes into ballet is certain, after a life of torn muscles and bruised bones, to end in madness or suicide, just as Moira Shearer did in the movie The Red Shoes. Even worse awaits the sensitive lad.

title: Meadowbrook Wins
description: OLD WESTBURY, Aug, 14Ted Shapiro scored four goals and Bill Matheson contributed three as the Meadowbroolk polo team defeated Jericho, 76, today at Hickox Field. Jeff Rossler. and Harvey. Rhein shared scoring hopors for Jericho with three goals each.

title: T. T. Carrington And Miss Ware To Wed in Fall
description: Genevieve Merrill Ware, coordinator of historic preservation at the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington, plans to be married there on Sept. 25 to Timothy Teall Carrington, Washington correspondent for Securities Week, a McGrawHill publication. The ceremony will take place in Grace Episcopal Church, Georgetown, where Miss Ware is a member of the vestry.

title: LEVITT CITES CITY ON REALTY TAXES
description: New York City has failed to remove from its tax rolls thousands of properties on which it can never hope to collect real estate taxes, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt declared yesterday.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONWhen two people as far apart on the political, spectrum as Jimmy Carter and William. E. Simon both say that a thing should be done, and both draw a huge affirmative response from the public, there is a natural tendency to conclude that a national consensus exists on the matter and that it will, indeed, be done.

title: Mrs. Ochmiansky Becomes a Bride
description: Adelina Ochmiansky, widow of Vladimir Ochmiansky of Leningrad and Paris, was married at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon to Chauncey G. Parker 3d, son of Mrs. Luis Bolin of Washington and the late Mr. Parker Jr. Canon Walter D, Dennis performed the ceremony, assisted by Canons Harold R. Landon and William A. Johnson.

title: The Signs
description: The urgency that was midsummer begins. to relax. You see signs of it in the trees, at the roadside where uncut grass ripins seed heads, in fields and pastures. Early goldenrod gleams in the fencerows where wild asters begin to take the place of daisies and blackeyed Susans.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: There is no doubt that the present complex and costly welfare structure is grossly inadequate on many counts and cries out for reform; that under the present structure, localities are hardpressed financially; that fathers are encouraged to desert so their families can survive; that those who are marginally employed are penalized. We agree with these points in Robert Sellers article, Can We Afford the Welfare System? [Opinion Page, July 4], but we differ strongly in attitude and remediation.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The national swine flu immunization program, delayed for weeks because drug manufacturers were unable to get liability insurance, is under way again because of an unusual law, passed by Congress at the urging of President Ford. It provides that all suits for damages arising under the program are to be filed directly against the Federal Government, not against other program participants, whether state agencies, corporations or individuals.

title: Yanks Beat Twins, 54; Mets Win From Reds
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 14 Except for Manager Billy Martin who broke his thumb, the Yankees have reacted to this road trip as if Kansas City and Minnesota were the spas of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Hot Springs, Ark.

title: Queen of Cow Towns Embraces Republicans
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14The cattle trains are gone and Jesse James's descendants went on to sell fine china and furnishings, but Kansas City, despite its present sophistication, is still the proud and beautiful Queen of the Cow Towns.

title: Reagan
description: In a recent nationally televised speech, Ronald Reagan came out against discriminationthat is, discrimination against white people.

title: PEOPLE
description: It's hard to keep up with the multitaceted Nishan J. Najarian of Convent. Now director of the East Asia Summer Institute and assistant director of the Counseling Center at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison, he has been named to the board of trustees at Drew University in Madison. A 1955 Drew graduate, Mr. Najarian holds a divinity degree from New York University and is studying for a doctorate in religion at Drew. As an undergraduate political science major, lettered in soccer, fencing and tennis, and in the early 1960's he was a tennis professional. Then he served as a Methodist missionary in Taiwan, and, while pastor of a Brooklyn church, moonlighted on the tennis and soccer coaching staffs at Drew. In recent years, Mr. Najarian has been president of Asia Consultants Associates, a private firm. He also found time to marry the former Lilian Gardner Eken, and they have two children.

title: Miss Ender First in Balloting
description: Kornelia Ender, the East German swimmer who earned four Olympic gold medals, was named winner yesterday of secondquarter balloting for the Haig and Haig Woman Athlete of the World Trophy.

title: FIGHTING STEPS UP IN BEIRUT SUBURBS; LONG BATTLE SEEN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 14Fighting raged last night and today in the suburbs east of Beirut, and heavy shelling was reported between Moslem and Christian villages on the main BeirutDamascus highway.

title: What's Doing in NIAGARA FALLS
description: TWIN CITIESOn both sides of the Niagara River are cities mimed Niagara Fails. The larger is Niagara Falls. N.Y., with a population of 85,000. Niagara Falls, Ontario, has only 67,000 permanent residents but a more ??? business district filled with was museums, pizza parlors, souvenir shoos and tall observation towers.

title: Growing up the hard way
description: On Thursday night, July 15th of this year, in front of millions of Americans, Ron Kovic, a young Vietnam veteran in a wheelchair, seconded the nomination of a Vietnam draft resister as the Democratic Party's candidate for Vice President of the United States.

title: Ford Signs Energy Bill, Lifts Some Oil Price Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)President Ford signed the energy bill into law today, keeping the Federal Energy Administration alive, providing incentives to conserve energy, and lifting price controls on nearly 15 percent of the oil produced in the United States.

title: Stanley Sisters in a Double Ceremony
description: Dolores Gray Stanley and her sister Mary Elizabeth Stanley, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Percy Stanley of Short Hills, N. J., became brides yesterday afternoon at a double wedding in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Ithink I'll stop feeling sorry for playwrights. Altogether. I've felt sorry for them in stages over the years, adding a tear or two each decade because it was cleareach decadethat the going was getting tougher. You see, playwrights have always faced one particular. hazard. As ??? Hart used to point out, the fact that a Man has just written a successful, thoroughly workable, play doesn't tell him one single thing about writing his next.

title: PASSMAN IS UPSET IN LOUISIANA RACE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14 (AP)Jerry Huckaby, a 35yearold dairy farmer, upset veteran Representative Otto P. Passman in Louisiana's Democratic Congressional primary today.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Cincinnati Reds conclude their series against the Mets today with a 2:05 P.M. game in Shea Stadium. Tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday nights at 8 o'clock, the Texas Rangers meet the Yankees in Yankee Stadium. On Friday and Saturday nights at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M. the California Angels play the Yankees there.

title: Putting the Teacher's Role in Perspective
description: MORE has been wrought by the State Legislature in recent weeks than just strapping a reluctant electorate with an income tax. It has brought to the surface and exacerbated tensions that already exist between the schools and the communities which they serve. Since a large part of a citizen's tax dollar goes for the schools, it may be natural that these tensions should exist.

title: FORD TO BE PUSHED: BY REAGAN FORCES ON RUNNING MATE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14 Ronald Reagan's aides passed the word to key delegates today that the main thrust of their attack on President Ford at the Republican National Convention would be an attempt to force him to name his VicePresidential choice sooner than he wants to.

title: Schweiker Bids for Votes Of the 76 Black Delegates
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14 Senator Richard S. Schweiker pleaded with black delegates today to support the ReaganSchweiker ticket in next week's Republican National Convention, a contest so close that small blocks of delegates increasingly are seen as pivotal.

title: Jackie Robinson in Philadelphia: No Brotherly Love
description: I remember Branch Rickey, the Old Man, telling me to pick up an extension telephone in his Brooklyn Dodger office less than a week before weJackie Robinson and the other players to whom I acted as confessor. valet and nursemaid as the team's traveling secretarywere to make our first road trip of 1947.

title: Letters
description: No doubt my avid perusal of sciencefiction literature has slanted my outlook, but it appears there is an extremely subtle movement afoot to eliminate middle aged and elderly people!

title: The Lives of Roger Casement
description: To those who knew and admired him, Sir Roger Casement represented the Edwardian era's genteel knight errant; he was handsome, passionate, daring and dedicated. Joseph Conrad, not a bad judge of character, met him briefly in the Congo: Made the acquaintance of Mr. Roger Casement, which I should consider as a great pleasure under any circumstances and now it becomes a positive piece of luck. Thinks. speaks well, most intelligent and very sympathetic. Others, less fond of him, saw another side; from their perspective he was corrupt and despicable, at best a fool, at worst a moral degenerate. B. L. Reid (author of a Pulitzer Prizewinning biography of John Quinn) purports to see a bit of both in Casement, the ostensibly great and the pathetically grim, and it is the strange combination of the two that he attempts to unravel for us in this new study.

title: American Cyclist Wins
description: SILVERSTONE, England, Aug, 14 (UPI)Steve Baker, a 23yearold American, marked his first appearance on the Silverstone circuit by trouncing the opposition today in the first leg of the John Player 750cubiccentimeter motorcycle grand prix.

title: Ronald Reagan's Quiz Kid Economist
description: Martin Anderson is the only fullfledged economist in the inner circle of Ronald Reagan's campaign staff. During last week's battle over the Republican platform in Kansas City, the 41yearold economist was one of two Reagan people serving as liasion with the Party platform committee on a wide range of issues, foreign and domestic.

title: Miss Brown Is Wed To Law Student
description: Deborah Lynne Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wayne Brown of Manhasset, L. I., was married in Birmingham, Mich., yesterday, to John Joseph Schrot Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schrot of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Alexander A. Kuras performed the ceremony in Holy Name Roman Catholic Church.

title: UNEXPECTED WOES SLOW BEM PLAN
description: The Beanie administration has run into unexpected difficulties in framing a new strategy for rebuilding the city's troubled economy and in finding a new administrator to lead the program.

title: Man Stabs Woman to Death, Then Drowns Fleeing Arrest
description: After reportedly stabbing his woman friend to death near their home at 19 West 137th Street, Leroy Pass, 45 years old, was chased by a transit patrolman four blocks to the Harlem River where Mr. Pass jumped in and apparently drowned.

title: The Talk of Kansas City: Who'll Be Ford's Choice?
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14  As the rumor mill had it, John B. Connally was supposedly down, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. fading, Senator Robert Dole emerging and William W. Scranton rising. But the VicePresidential rumor mill here actually was a treaumill.

title: Notes: U.S. Tourism Agency Is Urged
description: In a resolution passed unanimously at the recent National Conference of Lieutenant Governors. Congress was urged to consolidate all Federal tourist agencies and programs into one and to develop a nationally coordinated tourism program. The lieutenant sovernors, meeting in Newport, R. I., decided to set up their own tourism committee, headed by Lieut. Gov. George Nigh of Oklahoma, to work toward implementing the resolution. The wording of the resolution fell short of a suggestion by the vice chairman of Holidays Inns, William B. Walton, that a Cabinetlevel Federal department of tourism be established.

title: Frances Collins Is Wed To George Stillman Jr.
description: Frances Ellsworth Collins, daughter of Phyllis Dillon Collins of Far Hills, N. J., and Mark McCampbell Collins of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to George Schley Stillman Jr., her classmate at Middlebury (Vt.) College.

title: Not to Mention the Fashionable AntiFashion Crowd
description: Professor Konig, a German sociologist, may be right about fashion, but getting even people in the business to admit it these days is like trying to get a definitive Republican delegate count. Because one of the taboos of which Professor Konig speaks is what Tom Wolfe, the cultural journalist, calls the antifashion taboo.

title: Lebanon: The insane war
description: BEIRUT. In the soft Mediterranean mornings, it is quiet in the Manara section of Beirut, which sits on a high bluff overlooking the flat, molten sea. The quarter takes its Arabic name from a blackandwhite lighthouse that used

title: What They Are Saying
description: Bruce Jenner, Olympic decathlon champion, who has an offer to play the lead in a Superman movie: I'll have to Dee the script, though I think I can identify with the part.

title: W. H. Cleckner 4th Weds Miss Cusack
description: Pamela Cusack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Cusack Jr. of Pelham Manor, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. William Henry Cleckner 4th, who is serving with the Army's 82d Airborne Division at Fort Bragg, N. C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cleckner 3d of Camp Hill, Pa.

title: 5,000 TV Sets Called Faulty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) More than 5,000 color television sets imported from Japan emit excessive radiation and must be repaired, according to the Foodand Drug Administration. Ownets of the 19inch models manufactured in 1973, 1974 and 1976 by the Victor Company of Japan Ltd. will be notified by mail where to take their sets for free replacement of a substandard circuit board, the F.D.A. said.

title: Christine Perry Wed to Lawyer
description: Christine Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Stoddard Perry of New Canaan, Corm., and New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Russell Eriksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Viben Peter Eriksen of Huntington, L. I.

title: Linda Diethelm Wed in Alabama
description: Linda Lane Diethelm, a staff nurse at the New York Hospital, and William Long Holman, who is in his third year at the Cornell University Medical College, were married yesterday afternoon in Birmingham, Ala.

title: The fastest diet?
description: Sandra Scott of Brooklynn, Ohio, a suburb of Cleveland, remembers what she had for dinner on March 21st: Soup broiled fish, tossed salad, a roll and butter, applesauce cake and a Cup of tea. Recalling a meal eaten months ago is something most people cannot do, but Miss Scott has a special reasonshe hasn't eaten since.

title: Priests Held by Ecuador Leave Quito After Release
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 14 (AP)Most of the 37 foreign Roman Catholic prelates ordered out of Ecuador left the country today after being detained by the military government for what it called subversive activities.

title: Views of America as a New Home
description: HUNTINGTON IN late 19thcentury Texas, Elizabet Ney must have been seen as something of a kook, She not only spoke English with a German accent (she had fled her native land at the outbreak of the FrancoPrussian War) but she also helped spearhead the development of communes, wore unusual clothes inspired by the ancient Greeks and engaged in a most unorthodox activity: the pursuit of social equality for women.

title: STANLEY J. HARRIS
description: Greensboro, N.C., Aug. 14 (UPI)Stanley J. Harris Sr., credited with organizing the first Boy Scout troop in the United States, died yesterday. He was 93 years old.

title: ERROR IN NEBRASKA FORCES A TAX RISE
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 14A $43 million error in revenue estimating made in April forced the Nebraska State Board of squalization and Assessment to increase state sales and income tax rate this week.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Boating Insurance Coverage Should Be Evaluated
description: Marine insurance speciallsts were deluged with calls last week from boatmen requesting new or increased coverage. But once Hurricane Belle's path was forecast, the

title: Lisbon Train Toll Rises to 5
description: LISBON, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The death toll in last night's train crash in asuburb of Lisbon rose to five today when one of the injured died in a hospital. Officials there said 11 of the 50 hurt in the collision of the trains at Amadora were still in serious condition.

title: How Best to Safeguard Fire Island's Dunes?
description: THE sand dunes of Fire Island resisted the fury of Hurricane Belle's fullmoon supertide. Luckily, Belle danced by quickly and didn't erode the dunes this time with sandgouging northeast gales.

title: Bonnie Pell Is a Bride
description: At the South Huntington (L. I.) Jewish Center last night, Bonnie Hillary Pell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Coleman Pell of Deer Park, L. I., became the bride of Ira Philip Lisogorsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Lisogorsky of Brooklyn.

title: POLITICS
description: THE political revolution of the last decade produced drastic changes in the New York delegations to the Democratic National Conventions of 1968, 1972 and last month. Largely because of the influx of antiVietnam War activists and the changes they forced in the Democratic Party rules and procedures, many of the cigarsmoking, potbellied professional politicians who traditionally dominated national conventions have been replaced by women, young persons, insurgents and nonprofessionals.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This is a good time to work on lawns following the deluge: feed, sod, seed and keep them trimmed. Last call to plant cabbage, broccoli, beets, carrots, salad crops for late harvest. Check roses again for black spot and mildew; use fungicides such as phonon or benomyl.

title: STAMPS
description: The red, white and blue of the Stars and Stripes are symbols to mark 200 years of American independence on commemoratives from two nations in whose creation the United States played a vital role. Symbols are among the facets of Bicentennial issues from abroad that make up one of the great omnibus issues of the year.

title: J. P. Stevens: Labor's Bid Domino

title: Petras Karvelis, a Founder Of Lithuania Republic, Dies
description: BADENBADEN, West Germany, Aug. 14 (Reuters)Dr. Petras Karvelis, one of the founders of the independent Republic of Lithuania after World War I, has died here at the age of 79.

title: Optimistic Gal 1st; Adios to Ranger
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14In a blazing performance that was a throwback to some of the victories she had posted in achieving a sevenrace winning streak earlier in her career, Mrs. Bertram R. Firestone's Optimistic Gal made a runaway of the $80,925 Alabama today.

title: CHESS
description: BIEL, Switzerland  Ever since the Hastings 1895 international tournament, won in magnificent style by the great American player, Harry Nelson Pillsbury, the force of the Queen's Gambit has been taken for granted. No one now would defend against it as his opponents did, especially after he revealed his profound strategic concept that White's kingside attacking chances far outweighed Black's queenside pawn majority.

title: FISHING
description: FISHERMEN have been waiting all summer for a good storm to stir up the waters and, hopefully, prompt some bluefish action. Well, they got the storm. Whether Hurricane Belle had the desired effect on the blues should begin to be seen this week, once the waters and the bait fish settle down.

title: Lightning Thrust Scores
description: MIAMI, Aug. 14 (AP)Lightning Thrust broke the Calder track record as he caught Hall of Reason at the sixteenth pole and scored a three quarter length victory today in the $29,250 Grassland Handicap.

title: U.S. PLEA IS DENIED IN SOCIALIST SUIT
description: Government lawyers have lost a move to dismiss claims by the Socialist Workers Party for millions of dollars in damages for alleged wrongdoing by the Federal Bureaul of Investigation.

title: Many in Upstate Bugle Corps Suffer Heat Exhaustion
description: WALDEN, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) Scores of teenage members of a drum and bugle corps were suddenly sickened with cramps and nausea today after they marched in a local Bicentennial parade.

title: Botswana Reported Ready To Introduce New Currency
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Aug. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)Botswana will take a new step out of the influence of South Africa later this month with the introduction of a new monetary unit to replace the South African rand, economic sources have disclosed here.

title: PEOPLE
description: Maybe your idea of a summer vacation is swimming, sunning and all that jazz. For Bob Fosse and Robert Alan Aurthur it's just All That Jazz. They have been spending their time in Mr. Fosse's home in Quogue, writing All That Jazz, a movie that Mr. Fosse will direct and Mr. Aurthur will produce for Paramount Pictures. It's a film with music, according to Mr. Aurthur, who also says that it's a highly personal story about real people. And some of those real people will play themselves. Which real people are they? On that question, Mr. Fosse and Mr. Aurthur are maintaining a conspiracy of silence.

title: Bomb Kills 8 Boarding Train in Egypt
description: CAIRO. Aug. 14At least eight persons were killed and 51 injured in Alexandria this morning as a bomb exploded in a train being boarded by workers and farmers bound for Aswan.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding Stephanie Harrington's weird review of Betty Friedan's book, It Changed My Life, (July 4), it seems to me that all the paranoia is on the other footnamely, Harrington's.

title: A Museum Exhibition of Politics
description: CENTERPORT POLITICAL controversy seems as far away from the peaceful Vanderbilt museum here as the moon and the stars. But in fact, the Moon and the stars showed tip several years ago when the museum opened a new planetarium; this year, a multilevel political controversy arrived.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Nassau County police said they had solved 14 burglaries in Plainview and Bethpage, L.I., during the last two months with the arrest of four teenage boys. The youths, detectives said, had stolen several thousand dollars in cash, jewelry, rifles, ammunition and houehold items. Only a small amount of the loot has been recovered. The police said more arrests were expectd.

title: Goldin Says City Lags in Collecting Its Water Bills
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin reported yesterday that his auditors had discovered a number of costly leaks in the collection of water bills by the city.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: WINDOWBOX ANTS (Aug. 1) E.R.N., New Haven, Conn transplanted flowers from their garden to an apartment window box Wand with then transported a colony of ants. He wondered if the ants will be destroyed by the cold weather or if the colony will survive to next summer. We checked with Prof William L. Brown entomologist at Cornell University who said that the answer depends on the particular kind of ant. It is not likely that winter will kill the colony. The best solution would be to scoop the soil out of the window boxes at the end of the growing season and spray a household insecticide into ft, mixing well, or baking the soil in the oven at a low temperature for about an hour to sterilize it.

title: Kathy Maxwell Is Wed to Dr. Hicks
description: Kathy Maxwell, daughter of Alice Maxwell of Phoenix, Pa., and H. Lee Maxwell of Louisville, Ky., was married yesterday morning to Dr. Edward Livingston Hicks, a Philadelphia psychiatrist.

title: Connally Cool to Ford Job
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14 John B. Connally said tonight that he would not accept the job as President Ford's campaign manager if asked.

title: At Stake in Kansas City
description: What happens at a major party convention is bound to be significant to the future of the country, but the convention opening tomorrow in Kansas City threatens to have a more immediate impact on the future of the Republican Party.

title: Music Notes: Taking a Gamble On the Weather
description: How do you pick the best weeks for an outdoor festival, gambling on good weather? If you are Leonard dePaur, producer of Lincoln Center OutofDoors, which starts this Tuesday, you fall back on your experience as a pilot. Mr. dePaur flies in his spare time, and turned to standard aviation weatherchart publications to deter mine, six years ago, that the late August/early  September period has the best norain record. The charts paid off; dePaur points out, with a knock on wood, that there have been remarkably few rainouts since the festival started in 1971. Which doesn't mean that outdoor music isn't a hazardous occupation. This year, with occasional spectacular explosions of noise emanating from the reconstruction of Avery Fisher Hall, dePaur has, as he says, been making deals with the construction people not to deliver the sheet metal during a tender passage in Mozart.

title: Miss Dusault Becomes Bride
description: Cynthia Ann Dusault, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen John Dusault of Barrington, Ill., and Skaneateles, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard F. Strup, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Strup Jr. of Lawrenceville and Stone Harbor, N. J.

title: Does This Insurance Company Have an Identity Crisis?
description: There have been times over the last five years or so when it looked as though the Continental Corporation was going through an identity crisis.

title: Elizabeth Lane Is Bride
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Josephine Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Dennis Lane of Washington and Norwalk, Conn., to Bret Anthony Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Brown of Potomac, Md., took place yesterday evening in the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation In Washington.

title: 2 TeenA gers Held in Murder Of an Elderly Brooklyn Couple
description: Two teenage youths were arrested by the police last night in the murder Thursday night of an elderly couple, Joseph and Angelina Tucci, in their home in the Bay RidgeBorough Park section area of Brooklyn.

title: Pool Pros Hear Cue in Jersey
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 14Despite the buffeting of Hurricane Belle and the competing lure of beach and boardwalk, professional poolpocket billiards to the fastidioushas taken up residence this week in this seaside resort. Peter Margo of Staten Island is a founder of the new organization. His typical accouterments include white suit, white shoes and a $150 snakeskin cue case holding a $600 madetoorder cue.

title: M. S. Snyder, Medical Student, Is Engaged to Bettina C. Bryan
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Johnson Bryan of Locust Valley, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bettina Clara Bryan, to Michael Sheldon Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Vreeland Snyder of Greenwich, Conn. a December wedding is planned.

title: Melodies of Neil Diamond Still Popular After Hiatus
description: Neil Diamond began a threenight, soldout stand at the Forest Hills Stadium in Queens on Friday. In so doing, he not only reopened the 14,400seat openair facility at the West Side Tennis Club for pop concerts after a fiveyear hiatus but he also was returning to the city of his birth for his first concert here since Oct. 20. 1972.

title: Knick, Ranger Tickets Available
description: Madison Square Garden reports that some season tickets are available for Knickerbocker basketball and Ranger hockey games.

title: The Region
description: The hurricane that passed through the New York metropolitan region last week, though severe, created far less destruction than had been feared, in part because every one saw it coming and prepared for it fully and in part because it had lost some of its power before it arrived on the shore of Long Island.

description: In this one the President is Jewish, but why? The plot doesn't hinge on secret treaty with Israel or anything like that. Maybe the Plotatron, scanning the numberless Washington novels of the past couple of years, found it was a shtik that hadn't been used yet.

title: Aircraft Sales Surge
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)Sales of general aviation aircraft topped the $1 billion mark for the first time in 1975 as manufacturers delivered 14,057 planes to civilian buyers, the Aerospace Industries Association of America reported over the weekend.

title: Losers Waste an 84 Lead
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 15  The Minnesota Twins 98 victory over the Yankees today might sound like a fish story because it was one the Yankees let get away. But unlike fish stories, it is no exaggeration to say the Yankees lost it by inches.

description: There was a surprise ending to the 1944 film Dragon Seed, with Katharine Hepburn, Walter Huston and Turban Bey, for the WCBSTV audience yesterday afternoon. description: Horses listed In order of past Positions

description: QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 15 (UPI)An airliner with more than 50 people aboard disappeared in the mountains of Ecuador today on a domestic flight from Quito to the southern city of Cuenca.

description: One of every three food dollars now is spent away from home and the National Restaurant Association estimated the ratio will be one to two by 1980. The association noted that during this decade the 1E to 34yearold groupthe biggest fast food addictswill increase another 9 million to 68 million.

description: Welcoming speeches by Mayor Charles B. Wheeler Jr. of Kansas City and Gov. Robert F. Bennett of Kansas.

description: In the wake of the big trade between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles on June 15, Manager Earl Weaver of the Orioles elevated Wayne Garland to a spot in the starting pitching rotation. It has turned out to be one of Weaver's best moves.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15This is a Democratic city, Harry Truman's town.

description: The Cosmos got permission from their coach to stay up past their bedtime to watch a television show from Portland, Ore., on Saturday night.

title: Complex Bacardi Empire Tries Collective Leadership
description: MIAMI, Aug. 15Jose M. Bosch retired about two months ago after running the Bacardi rum empire for 32 years. It may take more than one man to succeed him.

title: Jockey Club Seeking Better Horse Identification
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15  Governor Carey provided one of the lighter touches today at a serious Jockey Club conference dealing with horse identification. The Governor revealed that he had been named for an uncle who many years ago was a betting commissioner.

title: President Predicts Victory
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15  President Ford exuberantly predicted victory tonight as he arrived here for his showdown with Ronald Reagan. But still, despite his incumbency and months of furious campaigning, he was not entirely sure of it.

title: Portugal Slum Dwellers Moving Into New Homes
description: ALGES, Portugal, Aug. 9The women and children by the public fountain pointed ceremoniously to the heap of stones, boards, tin and broken glass as if it were a national monument.

title: Patriots Fall, 1614, To Packers
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP)The kicking of Chester Marcol and a touchdown pass from Carlos Brown to Steve Odom enabled the Green Bay Packers to beat the New England Patriots, 1614, tonight in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: Surrogate Candidate Says Patronage Is for Friends
description: Bernard M. Bloom, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn surrogate, says that if he is elected he will give court assignments at his disposal to all my friends who are qualified and competent.

title: The New Middle East
description: In slow and painful steps these past months, two of the old constants in the dangerous Middle East equation have been reduced to nullity. The secular democratic state Lebanon and the Palestine Liberation Organization are, as a practical matter, no longer functioning elements in world affairs. Each preserves its shell, available to be reused, but only through the grace and favor of outside forces.

title: Jane Blalock Playoff Victor
description: WHEELING, W. Va., Aug. 15 (UPI)  Jane Blalock putted 35 feet to within inches of the first extra hole on her third shot and then sank the ball for a par 4 today that defeated Pat pradley in a playoff for the $7,000 top prize in the $50,000 Wheeling Classic. Miss Bradley bogeyed the hole.

title: Watson Takes Austrian Grand Prix
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 15 (UPI)John Watson of Britain drove a Penske to an unexpected victory today in the Austrian Grand Prix. The Formula One race was without Niki Lauda of Austria, the world champion and overall leader this year, and the Ferrari team. Watson's time was 1 hour 30 minutes 7.86 seconds.

title: Bombings in Sardinia
description: LA MADDALENA, Sardinia, Aug. 15 (AP)Nine cars belonging to United States military personnel in northeast Sardinia and on this island off Sardinia were firebombed and destroyed, United States officials reported today. No injuries were reported in the bombings, which occurred late yesterday.

title: Man Held in Slaying of 2
description: FALL RIVER, Mass, Aug. 15 (AP)  A Fall River man, Paul Monast, 34 years old, has been arrested for the slaying of his father and brother, who or parently died today from blows from a hatchet, the police said. The victims were identified as Calixte Monast, 71, and his sae, Lionel, 45.

title: Nancy Litchfield Wed
description: Nancy Ann Litchfield and Steven Francis Thane were married yesterday afternoon in the White Plains Prebyterian Church by the Rev. Donald D. M. Jones. Their parents are Mr. and Mrs. Kendall D. Litchfield of White Plains and Mr. and Mrs. Ernest F. Thane of Heath, Mass. The bride's father is superintendent of the New York School for the Deaf in White Plains and Mr. Thane's father owns a dairy farm in Heath.

title: MOROCCO FINDING SAHARA A STRAIN
description: RABAT, Morocco  The triumphant mood that surrounded Morocco's assumption of control in the Spanishheld Sahara in February has given way to exasperation as Moroccan forces continue to fend off attacks by guerrilla groups and defense needs strain financial resources.

title: Ban Placed on a Fund to Defend Cadets
description: The Military Academy at West Point has prohibited cadets not implicated in the widespread cheating scandal from withdrawing money from a special student fund to help the legal defense of those cadets who have been found euiltv.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 15 (AP)Mozambique troops attacked a border post 120 miles northeast of here with mortars and rockets today, killing two Rhodesian policemen, security forces said.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15 . They were like mismatched bookends at opposite ends of a long shelf.

title: Israeli Justice Chief Is Opposed to Death In Terrorist Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Haim J. Zadok, Israel's Minister of Justice, strongly opposed today the use of capital punishment against terrorists. He stressed that decisions regarding the punishment of terrorists must be guided by cool judgment rather than by emotional reaction.

title: Meetings on Platform End in Harmony Despite Earlier Mistrust and Hostility
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15 Starting last June, the staffs of the Republican Platform Committee began putting the first words on paper with the aim of trying to write a party document that could satisfy both President Ford and Ronald Reagan.
