title: Johncock Wins Race At Trenton
description: TRENTON, Aug. 15  Gordon Johncock, who lost this race last spring by nine seconds because he ran out of gas, made up for that misfortune this afternoon when he won the rainshortened 200mile event for Indytype cars at the Trenton International Speedway.

title: Upstaters Try New Theory Of CapitalLabor Relations
description: DUNKIRK N.Y.Like bathers dipping their toes into unfamiliar waters, government employees and public officials in the westernmost county of New York State are testing a new way of conducting their labormanagement relations.

title: The G.O.P.: All Wings and No Body
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15The Republican Party was the moon to the Democratic sun when Samuel Lubell described The Future of American Politics.

title: Paula B. Weiss Becomes Bride
description: Paula Beth Weiss and Robert William Goldberg, students at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, were married yesterday morning in Temple Israel of Staten Island in the St. George area.

title: P.G.A. Golf Put Off
description: The final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship was postponed yesterday because of lightning, a thunderstorm and heavy rain and will be played today. Charles Coody led after three rounds with a 207. Details, page 41.

title: 2 Found Hanged at Rikers, 5th and 6th Suicides of '76
description: Two more inmates of the Men's House. of Detention on Rikers Island were found hanged in their Cells yesterday, the Department of Correction reported. They were the fifth and sixth suicides reported at the facility this year and came a week after another young inmate killed himself there.

title: Sales of Flags Rise
description: American flag sales in this Bicentennial year are expected to reach the neighborhood of $60 million, which would be about three times the 1975 sales figure, according to reports from various manufacturers released over the weekend.

title: Fibak, Connors In Final
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 15(AP)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors won five straight; games in the second set today, choking off a rally by Harold Solomon to score a 62, 75 victory and advance to the final of the $157,000 United States clay court tennis tournament.

title: World Team Tennis
description: New York 29, Indiana 26 (overtime). Boston 27, Cleveland 21. Los Angeles 30. Golden Gate 21. Pittsburgh 24, Phoenix 23. San Diego 24, Hawaii 19.

title: Helen L. Haberman Wed to M. L. Deitch
description: Helen Liebman Haberman of New York and Chappaqua, N.Y., widow of Phillip W. Haberman Jr., a lawyer, was married here yesterday afternoon to Morton L. Deitch of New York, a widower and senior partner in the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Levan.

title: Beame Scored for Failure On CostSaving Programs
description: The Beame administration was chided yesterday by State Deputy Comptroller Sidney Schwartz for assertedly failing to follow up on 27 specific suggestions intended to ease the city's financial plight by reducing costs, increasing revenues or improving services.

title: Libya Denies Responsibility
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 15 (Reuters)Libya tonight denied that it was responsible for yesterday's bomb blast in an Egyptian train and said President Anwar elSadat of Egypt might be engineering such incidents as an excuse for domestic repression.

title: New Head at Brown U. Howard Robert Swearer
description: The stately brick mansion on Power Street in Providence that is reserved for Brown University's president will be occupied early next year by a man who says he prefers the word challenge to the word problem. If that is the case, Howard Robert Swearer, named Saturday to serve as Brown's 15th president, should find his new post a challenging one.

title: Currier & Ives Originals to Be Displayed This Week
description: When they started out in 1834, Currier & Ives billed themselves as publishers of cheap and popular pictures.

title: Mrs. Abzug Gets Ovation By Black Trade Unionists
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug won a standing ovation yester day morning after speaking to a gathering of the Black Trade Unionists Leadership Commit tee of the New York City Central Labor Council in Glen Cove. L.I.

title: Red Smith
description: Sparky Anderson was sitting halfdressed in the visiting manager's office in Shea Stadium, chatting about this and that, when some movement out in the Reds clubhouse caught his eye and he broke off in midsentence. Is that Skinner? he asked, and hastened out to join his players while Tom Skinner, who conducts chapel meetings for the Washington Redskins, performed that service for the Reds. Most professional football and baseball teams have these nondenominational religious sessions before Sunday games. When the meetings broke up, George Foster held Skinner in private conversation for a long few minutes. He is deeply religious, Anderson had said earlier of the Reds left fielder, but he doesn't talk about it. He lives it. I don't. Most guys don't, but George does. If word of this gets around the major leagues, some of baseball's sinners may be mending their ways soon, for George Foster's way of life is obviously the right way for a 27yearold outfielder, or one of 47. Going into his last New York appearance of the season yesterdayunless he plitys in Yankee Stadium in OctoberFoster was hitting 329 with 27 home runs and leading the majors with 106 runs batted in. That sort of thing can give religion a good name.

title: Mizerak Gains
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 15sSteve Mizerak of Edison, N. J., defeated Jim Rempe of Scranton, Pa., 150104, tonight and moved into the final of the $50,000 World open pocketbilliards championship at the Convention Hall.

title: E.E.C.'s Trade Deficit Increased in Quarter
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 15 (Reuters)The European Economic Community's trade deficit was up by $4.8 billion in the first four months of this year, compared with the same period last year, the E.E.C. Commission said in a report released today.

title: Today's Entries at Saratoga
description: Today's Entries at Saratoga

title: Not Since 1884 Has an Incumbent Been So in Peril
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15Not since Chester A. Arthur was denied renomination in 1884 has an incumbent President come as close to repudiation by his party as Gerald Rudolph Ford will come in Kansas City this week.

title: TV Schedule
description: The only television network that has announced full gaveltogavel coverage of the Republican National Convention is NBC. Most of the proceedings will be broadcast on CBS, but the network is calling its coverage comprehensive because it may cut away for local newcasts.

title: SAMUEL KILBOURN
description: Samuel Van Dusen Kilbourn, vice president of the African Metals Corporation and a past president of the Mining Club of New York, died of a brief illness yesterday at his home on Prospect Avenue in Darien, Conn. He was 61 years old.

title: Republicans Unable to Avoid the Symbols of Watergate
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15They've gone about as far as they could go. San Clemente is 1,589 miles west. Washington is 1,043 miles east. Still the Republicans cannot elude the symbols, at opposite ends of the continent, of the memory they came to the heartland hoping to erase.

title: To Kansas City
description: As recent hosts to a Presidential convention, New Yorkers will wish Kansas City well as it welcomes the Republican delegates and alternates today for a week of historical scrapping. We wish that the Missouri city could expect as harmonious a gathering as New York enjoyed. Unanimity on the Presidential nomination may. make for a subdued convention, but it leaves the delegates more time and energy to explore the host city and fosters a generally relaxed spirit.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STAR TREK Tonight at 8 o'clock, if you go to a sectionedoff area in front of the American MuseumHayden Planetarium, near 81st Street off Central Park West, a setup of six telescopes, with a crew of amateur astronomers at your elbow, should provide some new glimpse and insights into the starry world above, an area now in prominent focus in the news.

title: The Atmosphere Cools
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15 Oddly enough, there has been little fizz so far in the fight for the Republican Presidential nomination. As President Ford and Ronald Reagan each ar rived for the climactic stage of their long struggle their competing forces already had established, however tentatively, a tone more of friendly rivals than of bitter opponents.

title: New Set of Experiments Are Planned for Viking
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 15 (UPI)  Viking I's biology instruments were turned off today while scientists planned another series of experiments designed to find life on the cold, dry Martian surface.

title: Networks Face an Opportunity and a Risk
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15The last time a national political convention was as closely contested as the gathering of Republican faithful promises to be here this week, there were only 15 million television sets in the land.

title: Guadeloupe Volcano Expected to Erupt; 72,000 Evacuated
description: POINTEAPITRE, Guadeloupe, Aug. 15French authorities ordered the evacuation of the 72,000 people living in the area around La Soufrire volcano today after experts said that it could erupt within hours.

title: A Light Outdoor Festival
description: Lincoln Center's OutofDoors festival of music, theater and dance begins tomorrow at noon and runs through Labor Day, featuring 67 individual and group Performers.

title: NEW TAX INCREASES ISRAELI PRICES 5.1 %
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 15 (AP)A controversial new tax pushed prices up 5.1 percent in Israel in July, the biggest price increase this year, the Statistics Department said today. Prices have risen 14.4 percent since January.

title: BLACK GROUPS PRESS FOR TEACHING JOBS
description: A coalition of black groups in the city and Representative Shirley Chisholm have called upon the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare to withhold further Federal funds to New York City schools until the city's Board of Education developed an affirmative. action program.

title: Advertising
description: Any American advertising agency that goes all the way to the Soviet Union's Republic of Georgia to shoot a television commercial had better have a good reason for doing so. Martseller Inc. had the reason, and it went.

title: President Predicts Victory
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15  President Ford exuberantly predicted victory tonight as he arrived here for his showdown with Ronald Reagan. But still, despite his incumbency and months of furious campaigning, he was not entirely sure of it.

title: COLOMBO MEETING OF THIRD WORLD IS OPENING TODAY

description: The final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship was postponed yesterday because of lightning, a thunderstorm and heavy rain and will be played today. Charles Coody led after three rounds with a 207. Details, page 41.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15 The Republican National Convention's Rules Committee today defeated two proposals to reform the process by which the party's VicePresidential candidates are selected.

title: Human Error Caused Explosion That Killed 12 at Louisiana Refinery, Union Official Says
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 15The explosion in a Tenneco Oil Company refining tower that killed 12 men Thursday resulted from a human error, according to the head of the union to which 10 of the men belonged.

But barefoot strollers on the main street are thinking only of the heat. White clouds hang low on the nearby, peaks like puffs of steam, promising another summer shower in a few hours.

description: Lovers and Other Relatives is a poorly reheated Italian sex comedy.

Shope drove 150 miles from his home in Saltitlo, Pa., with four legionnaire friends to Philadelphia for a few days of festivities at the state American Legion convention. There, for four days, they slept in the same hotel room and were together for nearly all of the convention activities.

title: Meryl Newman Bride of Philip Cedar
description: Meryl F. Newman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Newman of North Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Philip M. Cedar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Cedar of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbis Joel Zion and Edward Schecter performed the ceremony in Temple Israel in Lawrence.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Leaders of the more than 80 nonaligned nations gathered over the weekend in Colombo, Sri Lanka, for the opening today of a fourday conference. Many of the kundreds of delegates said that this was a time of transition for the 20yearold movement. chief topic will be a new international economic order that would seek to narrow the gap between poor and rich nations. Among the heads of state attending the conference are President Tito of Yugoslavia and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India. Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations has been invited as a special guest. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Korvettes Is First To Open on Sunday Since Blue Law Died
description: Korvettes opened 14 of its 20 stores in the New York City area yesterday, the first major department store chain to operate on Sunday since the state's traditional blue laws were set aside last June by the New York State Court of Appeals.

title: 57 Recoup Losses And Get Diplomas From High School
description: August is an unusual month for a high school graduation, but 57 young men and women who seemed headed for certain scholastic failure three years ago marched across the stage of Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium last night to receive their diplomas.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Communications Commission said it had seized $10,000 worth of Citizens Band equipment from illegal radio stations in New Jersey that were jeopardizing vital police, fire, rescue, and aircraft communications. The commission said United States marshals and F.C.C. agents from Maryland, Pennsylvania and New York moved in with search warrants at seven New Jersey locations last month in a major crackdown on the illegal operations. Stations were shut down after searches in Wayne, ParsippanyTroy Hills, Upper Saddle River, Paterson and Whippany, the commission said.

title: Shah Frees 307 From Jail
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 15 (AP) Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has granted amnesty to 307 prisoners convicted by army courts to mark the 50th anniversary of the Pahlevi dynasty, a spokesman for the courts announced today. No details were given on the released prisoners, but terrorists, saboteurs and armed robbers are among those tried by military courts.

title: Some Faces on the Convention Podium
description: Permanent chairman of convertion  59yearold House minority leader  maintains close ties to President Ford, whom he succeeded in 1973 as ranking House Republican in the party's smoothest such transition in 35 years  an 11term member of Congress from Arizona  chairman of the Republican Platform Committee in 1972  chaired the House Republican Policy Committee from 1965 to 1973. fought early efforts for impeachment but finally called for the resignation of President Nixon in 1974. supported Federal action to prevent a New York default in 1975. early this year his name headed a dirty dozen list of House members, a rating based on voting records on ecological issues published by Environmental Action Inc., a lobbying group  was floor manager for fellow Arizonan, Barry Goldwater, in latter's successful convention fight in 1964 for the Presidential nomination  member of the House Appropriations Committee  has also served on Education and Labor and Interior and Insular Affairs committees between 1953 and 1959. a 1938 graduate of Kanas State University, received law degree from Harvard Law School in 1941.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A man who said he had been an Army marksman menaced a former woman friend with a starter's pistol and then kept authorities at bay in Levittown, L.I., for four and half hours by threatening to kill himself and police officers with an M1 carbine, the Nassau County police said. The suspect, identified as Jeffrey Turkell, 32 years old 8 Swirl Lane, Levittown, finally heeded the police pleas to surrender. No shots were exchanged. According to a police spokesman, Lisa Manrosh, 19, of 68 17th Street, Jericho, had arrived home and parked her car at 3:55 A.M. when she was grabbed from behind by Mr. Turkell. When the woman screamed, Mr. Turkell then put a gun to her head and fired one shot, the spokesman said, but she said she felt no pain and continued to scream and attracted the attention of two neighbors.

title: Opera: The Rigors of Salome and La Traviata

If an opera company does not have a remarkable singing actress to cope with the rigorous demands of either Salome or Violetta, it's best to do something else.

description: To the Editor: We agree with you (editorial Aug. 6) that cooperation is necessary for the resolution of our differences with Turkey. Greek politicians have repeatedly stressed that Greece and Turkey have to live peacefully together. To this end, Greece proposed to Turkey the conclusion of a nonaggression pact which Turkey rejected. It will be helpful to the achievement of neighborly coexistence if certain misconceptions, some. of which are apparent in your editorial, are clarified.
