description: Political opponents challenging City Councilman Samuel D. Wright for control of the Democratic Party in central Brooklyn won a round in court yeslterday when Mr. Wright's handpicked candidate in the 54th Assembly District was disqualified from the Sept. 14 primary on the ground that he did not meet the state's residency requirements.

title: Wavering Delegates Find a Place in Sun
description: KANSAS CITY. Mo.. Aug. 17On the bulletin hoard of the press room being used by the corps of White House reporters here, there was a list of members of President Ford's Cabinet who are standing by to give interviews, with space for the correspondents to fill in their preferred Cabinet members and times.

title: Procter & Gamble Curbs Costs and Expands Earnings
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's largest maker of soaps and detergents, reported yesterday profit increases of 33 percent for the fiscal fourth quarter, ended June 30, and 20 percent for the full fiscal year.

title: Charges Flying in State Dispute On an Education Aide's Benefits
description: The chairman of the New York State Pension Commission lobbed a potentially explosive charge yesterday at the president of the New. York City Board of Education, only to see it apparently diffused before it could even hit the target.

title: Cosmos Win, 20, At Shea
description: The New York Cosmos matched the physique and endurance of the Washington Diplomats at Shea Stadium last night and won, 20, because Pel was on their side and because Shep Messing, their goalkeeper, came up with key elves at critical situations.

description: There is no going back to the desert island, once the rescue ship has come. But sometimes, maybe, the formerly marooned castaway is caught for a moment longing for deserted beaches and jungles where hibiscus, and not crabgrass, flourish.

title: South African Police Use Tear Gas Against Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 17 (Reuters)Policemen used tear gas to break up a demonstration of black high school students today in continuing racial violence in South Africa.

description: RALEIGH, N. C., Wednesday, Aug. 18Lieut. Gov. James B. Hunt defeated three major opponents for the Democratic nomination for Governor in primary voting in North Carolina yesterday.

title: Coffee Futures Soaring; Brokers Cite Hoarding
description: The price of a pound of green unroasted coffee beans soarea to an historic high of $1.606 yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, foretelling even higher prices at the supermarket.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the most popular teams in the recent Spingold Knockout Championships in Salt Lake City was a foursome composed of Peter Pender of San Francisco, Harlow Lewis of Wynnewood, Pa., Eric Kokish and I'eter Nagy of Montreal. Their impeccable deportment might have served as a model for some other experts, and their performance was on an equally high level. They defeated a series of strong teams to reach the semifinal, and were somewhat unfortunate not to go further.

title: L.O. and Leftists Recruiting For Coming Battle in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17The Palestine Liberation Organization and its leftist and Moslem allies have begun to recruit men in preparation for a major battle in the eastern mountains.

title: CATHOLIC UNIT BARS AID TO EITHER PARTY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)  The Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States will not endorse either political party in November's election but will speak out clearly on issues such as abortion, Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin said today.

description: Their second honeymoon lasted for only a month and then Jake Scott and Don Shula fell out again. This time Scott, twice an allpro safetyman for the Miami Dolphins

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Wednesday, Aug. 18President Ford. took a solid grip on the Re publican Presidential nomination last night with a dramatic and decisive victory over Ronald Reagan on a crucial test of strength.

title: FORD SAID TO PLAN TALK TO REAGAN
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 After meeting with close political advisers for two days, President Ford seems most likely to choose Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee or William D. Ruckelshaus as his running mate, sources close to the President said today.

title: Rockefeller Steals a Reagan Flag as the Passions Rise
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 Lightheartedly, Vice President Rockefeller stole a Reagan for President sign from a North Carolina delegate on the floor of the Republican Convention tonight.

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17A radical suggestion is making the rounds of baseball's inner circles: let the Houston Astros and the newlyformed Toronto Bluejays switch leagues.

title: Don Buckey Feels Void on Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 17 When Don Buckey woke up this morning, he found himself on a football team without his brother for the first time.

title: Mistrial Is Declared In DrugMaker Suit
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 17 (AP) A mistrial has been declared in the Federal Government's suit against five drug manufacturers seeking some $203 million in damages for alleged price fixing.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford won a key test vote over Ronald Reagan at the Republican National Convention as the President's delegate majority continued to mount and the first signs of defeatism appeared in the Reagan camp. Last night's victory for Mr. Ford came as his supporters turned back a move by the Reagan forces that would have required Mr. Ford to name his running mate before the Presidential nomination tonight. Ford supporters had denounced the proposed rules change as a desperate act of political opportunism. [Page 1, Columns 48.]

title: Dr. DiMaio Is Cleared For City Medical Post
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, yesterday advised the Mayor's office that he saw no obstacles to the appointment of Dr. Dominick J. DiMaio as Chief Medical Examiner, a post Dr. DiMaio had filled in an acting capacity after the retirement of Dr. Milton HeIpern in December 1973.

title: VIETNAM OFFERS AMITY TO THE U.S.
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 17 (AP)Vietnam offered a hand of friendship to the United States today at the conference of nonaligned nations after North Korea and Panama assailed the American presence in their two corners of the world.

description: New York City's director of leasing, who handled transactions committing the city to pay $87 million a year in rents, was arrested yesterday on charge of soliciting and accepting a gratuity of $3,000 from a real estate agent.

title: TV: Lively Convention
description: In television, timing is very nearly all. CBS News made an error Sunday afternoon with a live Special Report covering. Ronald Reagan's arrival in Kansas City, Mo. In the New York area, the report preernpted the final 10 minutes of Dragon Seed, starring Katharine Hepburn. Just as Walter Huston and Aline MacMahon, playing Chinese peasants in noticeably heavy eye makeup, were preparing to leave for the hills to continue their fight against the Japanese invaders, Walter Cronkite appeared on screen to announce that the Reagan arrival was imminent.

title: Reagan's Forces Prevail On Foreign Policy Plank
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Wednesday, Aug. 18The Republican National Convention, moving toward adoption of a conservative party platform, approved early today an effort by supporters of Ronald Reagan to criticize the Ford Administration's foreign policies in directly.

title: Tanaka Leaves Prison on $690,000 Bail
description: TOKYO, Aug. 17  Kakuei Tanaka, the former Japanese Prime Minister who is accused of acepting a $1.6 million bribe from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, was released on bail here this afternoon.

title: Japan Bank Intervenes to Hold Yen at 290 to the Dollar
description: TOKYO, Aug. 17 (UPI)The Bank of Japan intervened in the Tokyo Foreign Exchange market today to keep the yen's price from rising above 290 to the dollar.

title: Marxist Road to Rome
description: ATLANTA  The Italian people, whose wide variety of genius has never included a talent for selfgovernment since old Roman days, have now devised an extraordinary, ramshackle system to help their nation out of its terrible crisis. This is no less than the formation of a government which excludes the Communist Party from all its ministries but which depends wholly upon at least tacit Communist support to get anything at all done.

title: HOSPITAL WILL OPEN IN THE NORTH BRONX
description: The North Central Bronx Hospital, which has stood empty since its completion three years ago, will open on a limited basis this Friday to provide outpatient services, according to Dr. John L. S. Holloman, president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

description: Monmouth Entries

title: Mindanao at a Glance
description: GeographyMindanao, a 36,380squaremie island the second largest in the Philippines. This island, at the southern end of the Phiippine Archipelago, has vast uncultivated areas, abundant forest resources and largely untapped mineral reserves. Mindanao has two large cities: Davao, with a population of 400,000 and Zamboanga, with 200,000. More than a third of the population of two million is Moslem, and the island has been a center of Moslem insurgency.

title: Thieves Again Strike a French Bank Via Sewer
description: PARIS, Aug. 17 (AP)Exactly four weeks after what was called the bank robbery of the century in Nice, thieves using the same method tunneled into a bank in the heart of Paris and escaped with cash and jewelry from 191 safedeposit boxes, the police said today.

title: Guadeloupe Villagers Flee Blast in Volcano
description: POJNTEAPITRE, Guadeloupe, Aug. 17 (AP)Several thousand more villagers streamed from their homes on this Caribbean island today, after an explosion deep in La Soufriere volcano last night sent shockwaves 20 miles.

title: Indian Paper's Independence Imperiled
description: CALCUTTA, India  The Statesman, the last of India's English language nation! dailies not yet completely dominated by the Govenment, is under intense Government pressure.

description: Gertrude Levy Conn of Hampton, Va., widow of Ellis Conn, was married yesterday morning to L. Reyner Samet of New York, where the bridegroom practices law. Rabbi Sherman P. Kirschner performed the ceremony at the Cascades Waterfalls restaurant, part of the Williamsburg (Va.)Restoration.

title: New York Delegates Shut Out Both Sides' Celebrities
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17The New York delegates went for the Greta Garbo award today. They wanted to be so much alone that they slammed their doors on both President Ford's celebrated caucus team and Ronald Reagan's campaigning movie stars.

description: TORONTO, Aug. 17 (UPI) Hans Pohman wore down fifthseeded John Newcombe tonight and scored the first major upset in the $155,000 Canadian open tennis championship.

title: Cautious Party Welcomes Buckley Back
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 Senator James L. Buckley; was welcomed hack to the fold today, somewhat gingerly, by his New York Republican colleagues after his weeklong and futile national fling.

title: HORACE W. PETERS A RETIRED LAWYER
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., Aug. 17Horace White Peters, a retired lawyer, died Sunday in the Maine Medical Center in Portland after a long illness. Mr. Peters, who had lived at Ram Island Farm here for many summers was 67 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Terrorism not only threatens the standards of civilized people, Sir Harold Wilson said in Washington yesterday, but can result in a lurch toward neoFascism in which the neo is less discernible than the Fascism. Sir Harold, the British Prime Minister until his resignation in March, spoke at the convention banquet of Hadassah. The women's Zionist organization presented the Labor Party leader with its Henrietta Szold Award, which is named for the Hadassah founder and carries a $1,000 honorarium.

title: Caesarean: A Husband Plays Role
description: Standing at the head of the operating table, the man in surgical gown, cap and mask bent over the patient and whispered something in her ear. She smiled. One would have thought the man was a doctorthe anesthetist perhaps. But he was the woman's husband, and he was reassuring her while the doctors were preparing her for a Caesarean delivery.

title: Triangles Top Sets In Playoff
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17Mrs. Billie Jean King is considering a return to singles competition on the women's pro tour, and the New York Sets could have used her presence tonight after a 2625 loss to the Pittsburgh Triangles in the opening match of the World Team Tennis Eastern Division playoffs.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17It wasn't as glamorous as he had thought it would be.

But if reggae is to survive its fad appeal and find a permanent niche on the North American music scene, it will have to develop North American roots.

title: Case of 5 Girls Charged In Beating Is Open to Public
description: NEWARK, Aug. 17 (AP)In an unusual move, court proceedings against five teenage girls charged with beating and robbing a woman in downtown Newark have been opened to the public.

title: Days of Wine and Lawsuits

Jiminy Crickets! he said. And now they're getting Horace! Toots knew from merry experience that the arrival of his friend Horace Stoneham, then owner of the Giants, would not diminish San Francisco's preeminence. Horace no longer owns the Giants but his enthusiasm for gracious

title: Soviet Nuclear Tests
description: The attention given to Russia's two underground nuclear explosions in July that may have exceeded somewhat the 150kiloton limit of its newbut, as yet, unratified treaty with the United States has far more to do with domestic and international politics than with defense. No significant military advantage could accrue to the Soviet Union from such a technical violation of the spirit of the treaty, which Moscow denies has occurred.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The proposed merger of the Anaconda Company into the Atlantic Richfield Company is being studied by the Federal Trade Commission, but the nature of the investigation is not clear.

title: EXAIDE APPROVED F.B.I. BURGLARIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17W. Mark Felt, a former associate director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he had approved in 1972 the commission of two burglaries by bureau agents engaged in domestic intelligence investigations.

title: I.C.C. Approves Reform Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17After a quarter of a century of consideration, a divided Interstate Commerce Commission today announced approval of a compromise plan aimed at improving its enforcement practices, which have been criticized for concentrating on insignificant cases.

title: Betty Ford Bests Nancy Reagan on Applause Scale
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17Nancy Reagan used to be an actress. Betty Ford used to be a dancer. Footwork paid off tonight and Mrs. Ford won the second round in the applause battle with Mrs. Reagan.

title: Mystery Disease Takes 26th Life as New Tests Further Lessen Likelihood That a Virus Is Its Cause
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 17Scientists reported today new test results further reducing the likelihood that a virus caused the mysterious disease discovered among participants in the Pennsylvania American Legion convention.

title: US. Is Pressing Moscow On GrainShip Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The United States has protested to the Soviet Union that not enough Americanowned and manned ships are being used to carry grain to the Soviet Union.

title: People in Sports
description: Chub Feeney, president of the National League, said yesterday in San Francisco he had no intention of leaving his post and believes he has done a good job. In his first response to criticism leveled by August A. Busch Jr., the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, after the league meeting in Phoenix last week, Feeney called for cooler heads to prevail if the owners take up the issue of his tenure at their next meeting.

title: Santa Fe Opera Is Still Blossoming at 20
description: SANTA FE, N.M. Aug. 14 The Santa Fe Opera, sometimes known as the miracle in.the desert, is 20 years old this summer and it is thriving. When John Crosby began producing opera on the site of his 10 acre San Juan ranch five miles north of Santa Fe in 1957, he looked upon the enterprise as a small experiment. The theater was a tiny One seating an audience of only 480, the company conSisted of 65 members, the season lasted barely six weeks.

title: Reagan's LateHour Pleas Put Stress on Electability
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17Ronald Reagan worked feverishly today to convert delegates at the Republican National Convention here in an 11thhour effort to overtake President Ford's apparently commanding lead for the Presidential nomination.

title: NEW ROME MAYOR WANTS VATICAN TIE
description: ROME, Aug. 14  Rome's City Hall is on the Campidoglio, a magnificent public square designed by Michelangelo. Across the Tiber River stands the Vatican, home of the Sistine Chapel and other great works by the same master.

title: Issues and Debate
description: The honor code at the United States Military Academy is deceptively simple: A cadet will not lie, cheat or steal, nor tolerate those who do. It is a statement of a principle that has guided West Point cadets since the Academy first opened in 1802.

description: Dividends

title: SOYBEANS AND OIL DECLINE TO LIMITS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP)Soybeans, soybean meal and oil and oats futures fell the allowable limits for one session today, and all wheat and two oats deliveries set new cm lows.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (UPI)The International Weight Lifting Federation disclosed today that Dr. Arnold Beckett, head of the International Olympic Committee's medical commission, would conduct a second series of drug tests next week to determine if two division winners will lose their, Olympic gold medals. The champions who face disqualification if urine samples prove positive a second time in tests to be held in Montreal on Aug. 22 and 23, are Valentine Khristov, a Bulgarian heavyweight, and Zbigniew Kacmarek, a Polish lightheavyweight. A similar fate awaits the lightweight silver medalist, Blagoi Blagojev of Bulgaria.

title: OILLEASE AUCTION HELD AFTER DELAY; $3.5 BILLION IS BID
description: The first sale of oil leases off the Atlantic coast was held last night in the Statler Hilton Hotel in Manhattan after a tense allday wait before Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court decided to allow the bidding.

title: Mine Inspection Academy
description: BECKLEY, W. Va., Aug. 17 (AP)A $20.6 million academy to train the nation's mine inspectors was dedicated today by the Secretary of the Interior, Thomas S. Kleppe, and Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. The new National Mine Health and Safety Academy can accommodate 600 students on its 40 acre campus.

title: Hoses to Act as a Bergen Water Main
description: NEW MILFORD, Aug. 17A thousand Hackensack Water Company customers in New Milford and Teaneck will get their water through rubber hoses starting early next month until early November.

title: Third Ford Delegate. Reported Getting Bribe Offer to Switch
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 The number of President Ford's Illinois delegates who said that they had been offered bribes to switch to Ronald Reagan. increased to three today. But Mr. Ford's leaders in Illinois refused to give the names of two of them or to provide any details about when the at leged bribes were offered or where.

title: 2 From Paris Get Tip From Beame On Fiscal Affairs
description: After spending more than two hours yesterday with New York City officials in a study of the city's governmental structure, two French officials were asked if they had learned anything useful. Mayor Beame interrupted:

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times

title: Palestinian Groups Fight For Survival in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17After 16 months of involvement in the civil war in Lebanon and two and a half months of confrontation with Syria, the Palestinian guerrilla movement is fighting for survival.

title: Cost of Tall Ships Visit
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 17 (UPI)  City Manager Paul Steinbrenner has sent Gov. Philip W. Noel a bill for $59,645, requesting that the state reimburse Newport for services it provided during the Tall Ships Bicentennial visit.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Nonaligned Parley Improvises Its Vitality
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 17As the speeches by prime ministers and presidents droned on at the leaders' conference here this week of 85 nations calling themselves nonaligned, some of the hottest backstage chitchat in this steamy little seaport concerned the antics of the North Koreans.

title: Peace Corps Veterans Step 10 Years Into the Past
description: Mete is no going back to the desert island, once the rescue ship has come. But sometimes, maybe, the formerly marooned castaway is caught for a moment longing for deserted beaches and jungles where hibiscus, and not crabgrass, flourish.

title: HENRY SCHWEITZER, PHYSICIAN, WAS 97
description: Dr. Henry George Schweitzer, one of the oldest living graduates of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died yesterday at the estchester Square Hospital in the Bronx. He was 97 years old and lived with his son and daughterinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Schweitzer, in Pelham, N.Y.

title: Court Rules That City College Used Reverse Bias in 74 Plan
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that the City College of New York had used intentional racial discrimination to increase the number of blacks and Puerto Ricans who had been accepted for a special program to train students to become doctors.

title: Judge Bars Fund Raising By CORE in New Jersey
description: NEWARK, Aug. 17 (UPI)The Congress of Racial Equality has been barred from soliciting funds in the state or spending Contributions already raised in New Jersey.

title: Egypt Holds 3 Libyans
description: CAIRO, Aug. 17 (UPI) Authorities arrested three Libyan agents today on charges of having panted bombs in a Nile Delta bus station and an Alexandria train last June, police sources said.

title: A Day at the Races: Track Is Fast but Pigeons Are Slow
description: Never turn a funloving pigeon loose in New York City without a chaperon.

title: Beth Gettenberg Wed To Sandy Herskowitz
description: Beth Gettenberg and Sandy Herskowitz were married yesterday evening at the Sands Beach Club in Atlantic Beach, LI., by Rabbis Yaakov Kaminetsky and Ralph Pelcovitz.

title: 5 GRAIN OFFICERS ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 17Four former or present vice presidents of Cook Industries Inc. were charged by a Federal grand jury here today with conspiring to cheat foreign customers, for the company's benefit, by shortweighting ships loaded at Cook's local grain elevator.

title: High Kepone Levels Found in Chesapeake Fish
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency reported today that bluefish and other seafood in the heavily fished waters of the Chesapeake Bay had been found! with up to 10 times the accept able level of the pesticide Kepone.

title: PUBROCK MIXED WITH LIVELY JAZZ
description: The twonight double bill at the Bottom Line that opened Monday interestingly juxtaposed two radically different approaches to popular music. Ian Matthews, the headliner, produces extremely clever, progressive rock of a technically accomplished, jazzish sort. Graham Parker, the opener, is a British pubrock equivalent to the rhythmandblues primitives who have flourished here of latemusicmaking so rough that playing in tune and in time would amount to betrayal.

title: Nettles Clout Sinks Rangers
description: Oscar Gamble kneeled in the ondeck circle. He was to be the second batter in the ninth inning of a 11 game and it was very likely that he wanted the chance to bat. After all, he had just erupted from a twoweek slump and he might have wanted to hit all night.

title: Only Light Damage Is Reported In Latest Chinese Earthquake
description: PEKING, Wednesday, Aug. 18 China's second strong earthquake in less than three weeks, which struck the southwestern province of Szechwan Monday evening, apparently inflicted only light damage in a sparsely populated area.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne yesterday signed into law four components of New Jersey's personal income tax package, including the measure that reinstates the commuter tax on residents of New York and Pennsylvania. That tax was repealed when the income tax was signed into law on July 8.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Over the objections of New York City and two upstate utilities, the State Public Service Commission has promulgated regulations requiring that new homes meet minimal standards of insulation before utilities can hook up the buildings electrical services.

title: Budapest Science Aide Dies
description: BUDAPEST, Aug. 17 (UPI)Tibor ErdeyGruz, president of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, died yesterday, the press agency M.T.I. reported today. He was 74.

title: Japan's Watergate?
description: Americans are naturally tempted to describe as Japan's Watergate the astonishing events that led to the jailing and now the indictment of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka on charges of taking bribes for fixing purchases of Lockheed aircraft. A more original Japanese politician prefers Pearl Harbor as a symbol of the affair's potential impact on the Tokyo political scene.

title: $67.5 Million Rate Rise Urged for Upstate Utility
description: ALBANY, Aug. 17 (AP)A Public Service Commission exminer yesterday recommended a $67.5 million rate increase for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, less than onethird the amount sought by the utility.

title: Quakein Philippines Leaves 1,744 Dead
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Aug. 18The earthquake that struck the southern island of Mindanao early yesterday has left 1,744 people dead and 2,094 missing, according to the disaster control center here.

title: Palestinian Groups Fight For Survival in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17After 16 months of involvement in the civil war in Lebanon and two and a half months of confrontation with Syria, the Palestinian guerrilla movement is fighting for survival.

title: MAX GOODMAN
description: Max Goodman, a certified public accountant here for more than 40 years, died Monday at the North Shore University Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Great Neck, I.. I., and Miami Beach.

title: MARVIN W. VYE, ACTOR, DIES AT 63
description: Murvyn Wesley Vye, j r., the actor who originated the role of Jigger in the Broadway production of the musical Carlouse], died of natural causes yesterday in Pompano Beach, Fla., according to the police, there. He was 63 years old.

title: Renee Richards Will Refuse To Take Sex Test for Tennis
description: Dr. Renee Richards said last night she would not take the sex test required to qualify for the United States Open tennis championships.

title: MRS. ABZUG URGES RESOURCES BANKS
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug suggested yesterday that the Federal Government establish regional resources banks to help create and finance new industries.

title: About New York
description: Back in 1967, in his memoir Making It, Norman Podhoretz let the world in on a dirty little secret: New York intellectuals want to be rich powerful and famous

title: Looking Backward
description: In their appearances, Vice President Rockefeller and Senator Goldwater strove to transcend the rancor of the past and the rivalries of this convention. Twelve years ago, these two men were heroesand villainsto the respective factions at the bitter San Francisco convention. Now both are supporters of President Ford, and their remarks were veined with sentimental reminiscence and ideological abstractions rather than charged with personal ambition or political passion.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times

title: British Aide, W arning on Prices, Finds Drought Situation Grave
description: LONDON, Aug. 17Frederick Peart, the Minister of Agricul ture, after a two day tour of English farms affected by drought, said here tonight: I can't remember ever seeing anything like this. The situation is very grave.

title: Fidrych of Tigers Wins 14th As Kimm Gets First Homer
description: With the help of the first major league home run by his favorite batterymate, Bruce Kimm, Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, Detroit's sensational rookie, won his 14th game last night, a 32 decision over California's Frank Tanana that drew the. largest crowd for a night game in Detroit in six years, 51,822.

title: Hope Harding Davis, 61, Writer and Artist in Maine
description: LINCOLNVILLE, Me., Aug. 17. Hope Harding Davis, a writer and artist, died in her home Aug. I. Miss Davis, who was 61 years old, had taken her own life, a medical examiner ruled.

title: About Education
description: College catalogues traditionally include basic information about courses, current tuition and admission requirements. They do not, however, normally include other types of factual datasuch as the success that graduates have in obtaining jobsthat could be helpful to prospective students in deciding which college to attend.

title: Pickets Assess the Impact of N.L. Industries Strike
description: SAYREVILLE, Aug. 17A handful of pickets sat by the side of the road leading to the N.L. Industries plant today and discussed the latest developments in one of the state's bitterest labor disputes.

title: Advertising
description: This is the time of year when football publications spring up left and right to appeal to the American male's interest and involvement in the sport. Among the types that have appeared, and disappeared, are newspaper supplements, tout sheets and magazines.

title: Foreign Service Union Votes To Oust Conservative Leader
description: WASHINGTON,Aug. 17 (UPI)Diplomats at the State Department voted overwhelmingly today to remove from office the president of their trade union after a stormy and sometimes violent hearing.

title: Decision on Rules To Leave Nominee Free to Maneuver
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 The first attempt by a national political party to impose any restrictions on a Presidential candidate's method of choosing his running mate was defeated tonight by the Republican National Convention.

title: Good Samaritan or Victim? A Perplexing Question
description: Was he trying to protect himelf when he drew a gun on two armed robbers, or was he trying to save the lives of two companionsmen believed to be the only witnesses, besides his murders, to his nowdisputed actions?

title: Kresge and Penney Show Profit Rises
description: The S. S. Kresge Company, the nation's biggest discountstore chain, reported yesterday a 41.2 percent increase in earnings for the second fiscal quarter ended July 28, and a 66.5 percent increase for its halfyear period.

title: Byrne Reinstates Commuter Taxes
description: TRENTON, Aug. 17Gevernor Byrne today signed four components of the state's personal income tax package, including a measure that reinstates the commuter tax on residents of New York and Pennsylvania.

title: William Redfield Dead at 49; A TV, Stage and Movie Actor
description: William Redfield, who started a 40year acting career when he appeared in 1936 at the age of 9 in the Broadway musical Swing Your Lady, died yesterday at St.. Clare's Hospital lof a respiratory ailment complicated by leukemia. He was 49 years old and lived at 888 Eighth Avenue.

title: Mississippians Oppose Reagan on Vice President Plan
description: KANSAS CITY. Mo., Aug. 17 After days of indecision on their convention tactics, the Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, operating under its unit rule, voted, 30 to 0, tonight against Ronald Reagan's effort to force President Ford into art early disclosure of his choice for Vice President.

title: Suit Seeks to Put McCarthy On the Ballot in Missouri
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 (AP)A suit has been filed in United States District Court to place Eugene J. McCarthy, the former Democratic senator from Minnesota, on the Missouri general election ballot as an independent candidate for President.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Paris Opera Tackles Logistics, Too
description: PARIS, Aug. 15Forty giant trucksized containers, holding 2,000 cubic meters of scenery, hundreds of costumes, wigs, and masses of other paraphernalia, are going to New York by sea for the Paris Opera's grandiose( first visit to America.

title: Abortion Plank Is Fought By Republican Feminists
description: KANSAS CITY. Mo., Aug. 17 Republican feminists here organized unofficially  and unsuccessfully, as it turned outto strike the antiabortion plank from the party platform this evening. They were also bracing themselves against a rearguard attack on the platform's endorsement of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

title: City Cultural Affairs Chief Foresees Money Battles
description: Two months into his job as New York City's new Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, Henri Claude Shostal is already seeing the possibility of some fights over money.

title: Israeli Official Disavows Any Blockade of Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 17ADefense Minister Shimon Peres denied today that Israel had intervened in the Lebanese civil war by stopping ships sailing to or from Moslem controlled southern Lebanese ports.

title: Delegates Debate Bid to Force Ford To Disclose Choice
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 Supporters of President Ford and Ronald Reagan joined battle tonight for the first time in the Republican National Convention over a change in party rules that could decide the outcome of their contest for the Presidential nomination.

title: JAMES CARNEY
description: James Carney, who served as an assistant district a?? in the Bronx for six years, died Monday at a nursing ?? in Woodcliff Lake, N.J, He was 71 years old.

title: Delighted Ford Says Victory on Rules Points to His Nomination on First Ballot
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Wednesday, Aug: 18President Ford said early today he was delighted with his victory in a procedural test of strength with Ronald Reagan and believed that the results were an indication of how the Presidential balloting would go later today.

title: INVESTMENT BANK OFFERS GEICO DEAL
description: The financially beleaguered Government Employees Insurance Company said yesterday that a major investment banking firm had offered to purchase and reoffer to the public any of the new preferred shares authorized on July 23.

title: On the Defensive
description: Two years after Richard Nixon's resignation, the Republican Party remains in a shocked, distracted postWatergate mood. The ordinary Republican delegate to this week's convention in Kansas City had no more inside knowledge of the NixonAgnew scandals and feels no more responsibility for them than the ordinary Democrat but there is no escaping the burden of shame and guilt that Watergate bequeathed to the G.O.P. The opening speeches to this convention in various ways reflected this mood and tried to pull the delegates out of it.

title: A Late V.F.W. Parade Keeps Fifth Ave. Awake
description: Thousands of Fifth Avenue residents, their sleep disturbed by the bands and bagpipes and reportedly the beer bottlethrowingof a war veterans parade that lasted till about 12:45 A.M. today, swamped the switchboards of police stations land Mayor Beame's office with irate complaints.

title: Mets Bow to Dodgers, 43, Despite Early 3Run Lead
Finding a Solution to Unemployment
description: The key issue in the Presidential campaign this year promises to be the economy. Both sides agree that the job question will be at the center of the debate, but the problem is that no one is exactly sure how the American economy can put all those who want to work into meaningful employment. The economics profession just doesn't know as much about this issue as it should, said Jerry J. Jasinowski, Jimmy Carter's policy coordinator for economics.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford's delegate count mounted steadily as Ronald Reagan, despite the first signs of defeatism in his camp, began a lastditch fight for the Republican Presidential nomination. Mr. Reagan's partisans demanded a rules change requiring Mr. Ford to disclose his running mate; Ford backers denounced the move as a desperate act of politcial opportunism. The day brought Mr. Ford 10 additional delegates 10 more than the 1,130 required for nomination. The New York Times calculated that only 79 remained uncommitted. [Page 1, Columns 48.]

title: 3State Delegates Line Up for Ford in Crucial Test
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.. Aug. 17 The New York, New Jersey and Connecticut delegations lined up tonight behind President Ford for a crucial test of strength on the floor of the Republican National Convention.

title: Thrifty L.B.J. and Tearful Brezhnev Are Described in Memoir by Brandt
description: BONN, Aug. 17 (Reuters)Candid portraits of famous world political leaders are given by former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany in his memoirs being published here.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TWO PLUS TWO The Grenadier has added jazz. In a new cabaret policy of summer entertainment geared for autumn, the East Side restaurant has installed a pair of contemporary jazz exponents, Richard Sussman at the piano and Michael Bocchicchio on the bass, both shifting uptown from the Boondocks, the jazz lair in West Greenwich Village.

title: Dow Up 6.57 as Market Awaits Ford Nomination
description: Wall Street's growing belief that Gerald Ford will win the Republican Presidential nomination helped the stock market register its third consecutive advance yesterday in accelerated trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at its high for the day, 999.34, up 6.57 points.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHERE THE MONEY WAS. By Willie Sutton with Edward Linn, 339 pages. Viking. $10.

title: Controller and I.R.S. Auditor Indicted on Bribe Charges
description: A former auditor for the Internal Revenue Service was indicted yesterday on charges of taking bribes from businesses he was auditing, including a $350 gold watch from the Manhattan jewelry store of Van Cleef & Arpels. The controller of the jewelry store also was indicted.

title: U.S. Control of Boston School Upheld on Appeal
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit ruled today that an order placing radally troubled South Boston High School in Federal receivership was justified to protect black students.

title: Mrs. McIngvale Retains Crown
description: DECATUR, Ala., Aug. 17 (AP)Cynthia Potter McIngvale of Dallas successfully defended her crown on the women's onemeter springboard in the Amateur Athletic Union national outdoor diving championships today.

title: City Reports A Slight Dip In Food Cost
description: The cost of meat and potatoes dropped 1.6 percent while the overall cost of feeding a family of four in New York City last week declined 0.1 percent below the previous week's level, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Betty Ford Bests Nancy Reagan on Applause Scale
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17Nancy Reagan used to be an actress. Betty Ford used to be a dancer. Footwork paid off tonight and Mrs. Ford won the second round in the applause battle with Mrs. Reagan.

title: In Which Mr. Buckley and Mr. Cohen Discuss Principles
description: In 1859, Abraham Lincoln stood before members of the young Republican Party in Chicago and said:

title: Species: Grouper
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.The grouper is a hardy migratory species. In the winter, it lurks in the crevices of the city, toughening up for the summer pilgrimage to Long Island.

title: CRASH KILLS WIFE OF SENATOR GARN
description: SUNOL, Neb., Aug. 17 (AP) Hazel R. Garn, wife of United States Senator Jake Gern of Utah, was killed today when her car overturned near this western Nebraska town, the state police said.

title: Miss Shaw Wins, 1 Up, In First Round of Golf
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP)Dale Shaw of Canada built a 4 up lead on the front nine today and held on for 1 up victory over Beth Daniel of Charleston, S.C., in the first round of the 76th United States women's amateur golf championship.

title: Anderson Carter
description: KANSDS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17About a year ago, when Ronald Reagan's campaign for the Republican nomination was still in its gestation stage, Anderson Carter con fided to his political mentor and good friend, F. Clifton White, that he had made up his mind to work for the Californian.

title: Forego Assigned 136 Pounds for Jersey Race
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 17Lazy F. Ranch's Forego, Horse of the Year in 1974 and 75, is reportedly set to compete in the $100,000 added Amory L. Haskell

title: Carter Watches the Convention and Confers on Energy Policy
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 17jimmy Carter said today that he had watched segments of last night's Republican National Convention proceedings and added with a grin: They talked about me more than the Democrats did.

title: Ford and Carter Are Asked To Speak at Legion Parley
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 17 (AP)President Ford and the Democratic Presidential nominee, Jimmy Carter, have been invited to address the 58th annual national convention of the America Legion, which is expected to attract 25,000 people to the Seattle area beginning Friday.

title: OILLEASE AUCTION HELD AFTER DELAY; 1$35 BILLION IS BID
description: The first sale of oil leases off the Atlantic coast was held last night in the Statler Hilton Hotel in Manhattan after a tense allday wait before Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court decided to allow the bidding.

title: Interest Rates Set On Federal Bonds Lowest Since April
description: Interest rates on shortterm Federal agency bonds were set yesterday at their lowest levels since April, and taxexempt note yields declined to their lowest levels of 1976. The corporate bond market, however, declined in price, pushing yields higher there for the first time this month. An investment banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb & Company, meanwhile, set terms on $367 million of bonds guaranteed by the ExportImport Bank for the National Power Corporation of the Philippines, the first public offering by a foreign issuer of such longterm debt backed by the United States Government. The bonds are priced to yield as much as 8.25 percent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a physician in a municipal hospital and currently president of its medical board, I must respond to your unrealistic editorials: Strike Against Recovery and Hospital NonSolution.

title: An Overview of Underwear: If's More Than Fluff or Lace
description: Wither underwear? At a time when the bra has followed the slip, which followed the girdle, into that great lingerie limbo, perhaps never to return, at least not in our lifetime, at such a time does it make sense to invite prominent women leaders to a lunch and fashion show celebrating 200 Years of Women's Undergarments.

title: What Will Ford Do?
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17The Republicans apparently want to slug it out with the Democrats, but it's fairly clear now that President Ford has won the nomination, and they now have a different problem. In their opening convention speeches, they concentrated on the past, attacked Jimmy Carter as an inexperienced hypocrite, denounced the economics and morals of the Democratic Congress, and paraded their oldtimersfrom All Landon to Barry Goldwaterbefore the TV cameras.

title: Ford Sign Stirs Up Texans
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17 (UPI) A banner supporting President Ford was placed briefly on a wall beside the Texas delegation, which supports Ronald Reagan, on the floor of the Republican Convention today. But it was removed immediately when the Texans protested and hundreds of delegates began chanting, We want Reagan.

title: About Real Estate
description: HOLMDEL, N.J.Its the height of the harvest at the fruit and vegetable farms of New Jersey these days. For the price of a peach at a roadside stand the visitor can hear about the lot of the busy vendors of the farmers produce and of the farmers themselves.

title: Performers, Spectators Enjoy a Day For Festival
description: It was the kind of day that could make you want to dance or sing  or watch others dance or sing  and around Lincoln Center yesterday, people were doing all those things.

title: Celebration and Protest Combined by Youth Unit
description: Zomar the Great balanced a lawn mower on his chin. then six metal chairs, then David Bell. age 9.

title: Tate Criticized On New Purchase
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP)The Tate Art Gallery has been criticized again for spending an estimated $900 of the taxpayers money for a 7 foot 10 inch blue plaque with the worts starlit waters painted a foot high on it in green and with an orange fishnet draped over it.

title: Safe Driving Pays
description: New York's budget crunch has led to an eminently sensible and fair way to finance the state's driver safety clinics and other programs for delinquent drivers.

title: Goodbye to Classic Cookery
description: At first glance, it looks much like any other pizzabytheslice joint in the city, cleaner and more orderly, perhaps, but still a narrow corner luncheonette with the usual counters and stools, dispensers of paper napkins, and shakers full of oregano, dried red pepper flakes and, alas, garlic salt. But the Famous Ray's Pizzanot to be confused with the three or four other unfamous Rays around townrepresents a bona fide Horatio Alger success story, Italian style.

title: FORD GAINS EDGE OVER REAGAN; BAKER OR RUCKELSHAUS LISTED AS LIKELY CHOICE FOR NO. 2 SPOT
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17.  President Ford's delegate count mounted steadily today as Ronald Reagan, despite the first signs of defeatism in his camp, began a lastditch fight for the Republican Presidential. nomination.

title: BESSIE CENTENNIAL BEAM
description: RIVERTON, Iowa, Aug. 17 (AP)Bessie Centennial Beam's life spanned America's second century. Mrs. Beam, who died yesterday at a rest home, was horn in this southwestern Iowa community on July 12.

title: Chiefs' Matuszak Ailing
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17 (AP)John Matuszak, a defensive end for the Kansas City Chiefs, was released from a hospital today after doctors determined he was suffering from low blood sugar, a Chiefs spokesman said.

title: Market Place
description: The moderation in interest rates has worked lately to the benefit of such interestsensitive stocks as those of consumer loan companies, utilities and insurance concerns.

title: Vicious Gangs of Youths Spread Fear in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Aug. 17When I grew up, said a small, muscular 21yearold loitering around a store on Detroit's East Side, we had it out with our hands. Maybe we'd steal a car and go for a ride.

title: WINE TALK
description: Sebastiani Vineyards made something of a sweep in the wine judging at the Los Angeles County Fair earlier this month. The results disclosed that Sebastiani wines took eight gold medals, five of them in the important red table wine class.

title: Amex Prices Slip On Light Turnover; Counter Is Mixed
description: Prices declined in light trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and closed mixed in moderate trading on the overthecounter market.

title: Landmark Rating Is Given To Towers Nursing Home
description: The vacant Towers Nursing Home, at Central Park West and 106th Street, was designated an official city landmark yesterday and is expected to be converted into a funeral home.

title: SOUTH AFRICA LINK TO ISRAEL GROWS
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 17 Israel's diplomatic and commercial ties to South Africa have increased dramatically in recent months in a strengthened relationship between the two countries that reportedly includes the sale of Israelimanufactured military equipment.

title: Hitler Watercolors Stolen on Ferry
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters)  Two watercolors by Hitler were stolen last month from a car trunk on a ferry crossing the English Channel, insurance agents disclosed today.

title: Teamster Is Sentenced
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UPI)David Kaye, chief steward and business agent for Teamsters Union Local 714, was sentenced in Federal Court today to two years in prison on a 74count conviction for labor racketeering. Judge Alfred Y. Kirkland of United States District Court also sentenced Mr. Kaye, 62, to an additional three years on probabtion.

title: NEW INDICTMENT CITES MONSERRAT
description: Joseph Monserrat, who is scheduled to face trial Sept. 1 on charges of official misconduct, was named yesterday in two new counts alleging con flict of interest while he served as president of the New York, City Board of Education.

title: Viking Team, Pressed to Supply News, Sees Itself Practicing Instant Science
description: PASADENA, Calif.  The scientists involved with the Viking project here are finding themselves conducting instant sciencethe public disclosure of findings as soon as they are made, a procedure contrary to the customary careful and deliberate evaluation conducted by scientists in most fields.

title: Badillo, in a Tough Race, Fighting for Political Life
description: Representative Herman Badillo is fighting for his political life in a heated primary campaign against City Councilman Ramon S. Velez for the Democratic nomination for the 21st Congressional District seat in the South Bronx.

title: HOUSING STARTS OFF 9.2% IN JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The number of new houses started in July fell 9.2 percent, the Government reported today, indicating that the weak recovery so far in the housing industry has yet to gain any strength.

title: Police Monument Rededicated
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 17An eightandahalffoot statue of a uniformed policeman, resplendant once again in polished bronze after having been twice stolen and demolished within the last 15 years, was rededicated here today as a memorial to the deceased members of the Jersey City Police Department.

title: Vicious Gangs of Youths Spread Fear in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Aug. 17When I grew up, said a small, muscular 21yearold loitering around a store on Detroit's East Side, we had it out with our hands. Maybe we'd steal a car and go for a ride.

title: The Program For Today
description: KANSAS CITY. Mo.. Aug. 17Following are highlights from the tentative program for the Republican National Convention session beginning tomorrow at 8 P.M.

title: G. & W. TO SELL ITS CANNON STOCK
description: The Cannon Mills Company said yesterday in Kannapolis, N.C., that it had agreed to buy from Gulf and Western Industries 362,800 shares of Cannon Mills common stock at $22 a share for about $8 million. A spokesman for Gulf and Western said that the company was selling the stock back to Cannon owing to the fact that the textile company had rejected Gulf and Western's proposal to buy up to 20 percent of Cannon for investment purposes only.

title: Snag Arises on Consent Forms In Federal Flu Vaccine Drive
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 17  The Government may have to scrar more than 60 million patient consent forms printed for use in the national influenza vac. tine program this year.

title: Research Libraries Set New Winter Schedules
description: Winter hours at the research libraries of the New York Public Library will begin on Sept. 7. The central building at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street will be open from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. on Tuesdays and from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays. The building, previously closed Sundays and Mondays, will now be closed Sundays and Thursdays.

title: EXAIDE APPROVED F.B.I. BURGLARIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17W. Mark Felt, a former associate director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he had approved in 1972 the commission of two burglaries by bureau agents engaged in domestic intelligence investigations.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books

title: $30,000 BONDS HELD BY M.A.C. DIRECTOR

title: 'Billy Joe' Leaps From Southern Romance to Dirge:The Cast
description: "Ode to Billy Joe" is a movie to lament. Its authors have ruined it. To say so is praise as well as regret. You ???can only ???ruin something that has some quality to begin with, and for more than half ??? ???length this Southern country romance has a quite individual kind of life and ???shrewdness.This first part also has its flaws. Sometimes it is cute where it's supposed to be funny, and sometimes it is soft where it's supposed to be lush. It is too heavily apparent that the director is pleased with what he's doing, and his breath all but fogs the camera. But he has some reason to be pleased, if only he would step back a little. Instead, after an hour or so, he steps forward, grabs his movie with both hands and sinks it.A decade ago the singer Bobby Gentry brought out a song about a Mississippi De???a bo??? called Billy Joe ???McAllister who jumped off a Tallahatch???e River bridge and died. The song was oblique: It didn't say why he jumped. It ???hinted at but didn't specify a relationship between Billy Joe and the g??? singer/protagonist. Tens of thousands teen-agers sta???ed up late arguing the gaps.Max Baer, the director, has extended the song into a two-hour film. Its virtue lies in the setting-out of the two characters  Billy Joe and a girl named Bobbytheir timid and then more demanding courtship, the families, the rural background. Its failure comes when Mr. Baer tries to stuff these two, with all their liveliness and appeal, into the song, and invents an answer to the mystery that is grotesquely out of keeping with the life he has established up to then.The story develops in a perfectly familiar and conventional way. Bobby is the daughter of a hard-working cotton farmer, a strict, religious man saved from dourness by a wary charm and a ghost of humor. These lea???ening characteristics save him from ???being simply a stock figure. Here, as in other places, the writing is ???partly responsible, and so is the impressive acting of the character, played by Sandy McPeak.Bobby is courted by a neighbor boy, an eager, grandiloquent, charming youth who seems to sprout in all directions at once "He keeps popping up and introducing himself," Bobby's father complains, and at another point, when Billy Joe has come up after church in touching finerya ginger suit and white shoes, "they look like he's been kicking vanilla ice cream".The young people are tormented by their pull toward each other. Again, Mr. Baer's writing and the ability of the two actors make it something more than a sentimental clich. There is an apt balancing of love and lust.The two collide with each other, with the grownups around them, with the traditions of their setting. The setting is splendidly done at times, overdone at others Mr???. Baer and his cameraman have captured heat, the sheen of perspiration on the skin, the oppressive greenery, the blue-black stormclouds of the Delta country. They work dramatically as well as pictorially.This first part develops with an attractive balance of humor, sympathy and perceptive characterization, marred but not invalidated by sentimentality and excessiveness. Glynnis O'Connor, as long as the lines allow, is rebellious, thoughtful and funny as Bobby. Robby Benson, playing Billy Joe, manages his boisterous, wooly-headed role with great charm.But Mr.Baer wants to get the song in, and so Billy Joe has to jump off the bridge. The reason given for his doing so is, as I say, totally arbitrary and without any logical or emotional relation to what has gone before. It drains all the momentum from the film and turns it into ridiculous melodrama.And after all this comes a long, fatuous epilogue in which Bobby explains that she will keep the real reason for Billy's jump a secret, so as not to spoil the legend. What legend? He has only just finished drowning. The movie drowned some time earlier.The movie is rated PG Some of the scenes between the lovers are explicit, though emotionally rather than physically. In addition, the rating may rest on the discussion of the particular sexual problem that led to Billy ???Joe's jump.

title: REPORTERS LOSE BID TO PROTECT RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  News reporters have no special protection under the First Amendment that would require Federal investigators and telephone companies to tell them when the investigators have subpoenaed their tollcall records, Federal District Judge June L. Green ruled yesterday. Attorneys for the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press and a number of individual reporters had argued that the longdistance toll records could be used to determine an investigated journalist's sources. The organization and reporters had sued the American Telephone and Telegraph Company two years ago, contending that the release of the records to investigators hampered their attempts to gather news.

He was 47 years old and lived in Penfield, a suburb of Rochester.

description: For Kakuel Tanaka, former Japanese Prime Minister, his first day of freedom since July 27 proved to be a fishbowl existenceeven more public than that of his own goldfish. Released on ball on bribery charges in the Lock heed aircraft scandal, the 58yearold politician spent yesterday at home meeting with aides and receiving hundreds of phone calls and telegrams of support

title: Dow Off 4.33 as Traders Take Profits After Gains
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell back to close below the psychologicaly important 1,000 mark yesterday although early in the session it had pierced it ??? the 11th ??? this vear At the end of ??? it stood at 99501 ??? ??? points.

title: GLENN M'INTIRE, 78; EXAIDE AT BOWDOIN
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Aug. 18Glenn R. McIntire, retired as sistant treasurer of Bowdoin College, a former state legislafor and a leader in church and civic affairs, died today in his home after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Mrs. King Helps Sets Tie Playoff, 1 to 1
description: ??? Aug ??? Billie Jean King is back Maybe not tournament tough ??? but enough to beat Evonne Goolagong in wom??? singles tonight and force a showdown between the New York Sets and Pitts burgh T???angles for the ??? ??? Division title in World learn Tennis

title: Indirect Utility Billing Is Barred in Future New York State Housing
Ambro Ranger Gets Post 3 for Pace
description: Top thoroughbreds hardly ever are asked to compete in two Major races only a week apart. With harness horses, it's part of the game. Despite their strenuous efforts last week in the Adios Stake, Armbro Ranger and Keystone Ore will go at it again Saturday night in the $200,000 Cane Pace at Yonkers. This is the first leg of pacing's triple crown for 3yearolds, and the one, two finishers in the $124,141 Adios are the big wheels of the division.

title: Carter Sees Permanency In Floating Money Rates
description: PLAINS Ga. Aug. 18 Jimmy Carter today called floating currrency exchange rates a permanent fixture of the international monetary systern and indicated no desire tto return fixed rates. travelled to Plains on a threehour bus ride from Atlanta

title: Violence Can Flare Quickly at the Front Line in Korea
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 19The immediate area around Panmunjom, where two American soldiers were killed yesterday, has been the scene of so many violent incidents since the armistice that ended the Korean War 23 years ago that It is the only part of the Korean peninsula still officially designated a combat zone by the United States

title: 3 Men Casing a Store Were Secret Service
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Aug. 18 (UPI)Three men in business suits walked into Jaccard's Jewelry in Crown Center yesterday and stood waiting, surveying the area.

title: CHRYSLER IS WARNED BY U.A.W. ON FUNDS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers told the Chrysler Corporation today that if it expected a peaceful contract settlement It must provide $37.5 million to pay back the layoff fund. which the union said had been mismanaged.

title: Intermedco Receives an Offer To Buy All Its Common Stock
description: Intermedco Inc announced in Houston yesterday that it had received an offer from an undisclosed company to acquire all of ??? common stock for a cash price of $7 50 a share for a total of about 5 million

title: Dance: Ailey Swings Into the Classics
description: To an extent It was business as usual for the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater on Tuesday night. It was opening the second and final week of its Lincoln Center season, which has been called Ailey Celebrates Ellington.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATION CLEARS REP. YOUNG
description: WASHINGTON, AUG. 18Justice Department investigators have been unable to establish that any part of a $26,000 yearly salary paid by Representative John Young, Democrat of Texas, to his former secretary was provided In return for the woman's services as his mistress.

title: A Garage Worker Is Killed During Bombing in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 19 (UPI)Four men burst into a garage today, shot and killed an employee and left a bomb that destroyed the building and injured a policeman and a British officer.

title: TOUR WAS ENDING FOR U.S. OFFICER
description: OMAHA, Aug. 19 (AP)Capt. Arthur G. Bonifas was looking forward to returning home from Korea in about two weeks.

title: ARTHUR W. ARDIZONE
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (UPI) Arthur W. Ardizonc, retired business manager of The Cleveland Press, died last night at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Ardizone, 71 years old, suffered a stroke 10 days before. Surviving are his wife, Mitzi, and two sons, Richard and William.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review of the film Ode to Billy Joe in The Times yesterday, a reference was made to Max Baer as the author of the screenplay. Mr. Baer was the director; the screenplay was written by Herman Raucher.

title: Four in Jewish Defense League Held in 2 U.N. Mission Attacks
description: A leader of the Jewish Defense League and three other persons affiliated with the militant organization were charged yesterday with participating in a conspiracy that allegedly included shooting into the Soviet Mission to the United Nations and the Soviet residential complex in the Bronx.

title: People in Sports
description: The Boston Celtics may have a problem of communications during the next Naticinal Basketball Association season. Arriving on Monday to try out at the Celtics rookie camp in Marshfield, Mass., will be Drazen DalipaRic of Yueoslavia.

title: Exploring McKim's Manhattan
description: Si monumentum requiris circumspice: if you seek his monument look around.

title: Night Train To Trenton
description: Stay awake, pack a breakfast and get to Penn Station by 12:30 A.M. Sunday so you can make the 1:10 A.M. special ConRail train to Trenton. The train will make a stop in Newark at 1:25 A.M. and will arrive in Trenton at 2:33 A.M. There, Mayor Arthur Holland, the Trenton Historical Society and the Victorian Society will be your guides on a fourhour walking tour of Trenton.

title: Gold, Dollat Show Gains In Europe
description: BRUSSELS. Aug. 18 (UPI)Currencies of the joint European float came under acceler ated pressure today, but gold recovered slightly from yesterday's depressed level. The dollar also rose a bit. Gold rose to $109.375 in London from $108.50 yesterday and to $109.35 in Zurich from $10&65. Dealers attributed the decline yesterday to the gold sale planned in September by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Parents of Karen Anne Quinlan Present Check From Magazine Money to Bishop
description: MORRISTOWN, Aug. 19The parents of Karen Anne Quinlan presented a $10,000 check today to Bishop Lawrence B. Casey of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson, representing part of the $25,000 they will receive for the sale of exclusive interviews to The Ladies Home Journal.

title: Exiled Dalai Lama Still Reigns but Rules Only a Few
description: DHARMSALA, India  It is only a fivemile drive over a breathtaking succession of mounting hairpin curves from lower Dharmsala to upper Dharmsala, but on arrival a visitor has the feeling of having left India behind. The upper town is the capital of another, a mythical, country.

title: HEATING OIL SUPPLY AHEAD OF LAST YEAR
description: Coming into the closing weeks of the summer, the nation's supplies of home heating oil are considerably ahead of last year, while stocks of gasoline also continue to be in advance of 1975 levels.

title: Theater: Strindberg in Search of Himself
description: SATAN! Antichrist! Womanhater! Playwright! The epithets tumble freely, perhaps too freely, in Charles Nolte's A Night at the Black Pig. This is a play about August Strindberg, in which the author is subjected to a psychodrama about his ambivalent lovehate life.

title: Jerseyan Guilty in Stabbing
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y. Aug. 19 (UPI)William J. Meegan, 28 years old, of Jersey City, was sentenced in Sullivan County Court yesterday to three and a half to seven years in prison on his guilty plea to seconddegree attempted manslaughter. He had been arrested in 1974 in the fatal stabbing of Peter Rivera and also had been accused of setting fire to Mr. Rivera's trailer home in Swan Lake.

title: Nonaligned End Meeting With Warning to the Rich
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Friday, Aug. 20  The conference of nonaligned leaders ended early this morning with the adoption of a stinging warning to the world's rich nations that they must yield more of their wealth to a new economic order.

title: Foreign Films This Weekend
description: Big cities are mines, but most people move around them on catwalks. They travel their particular series of routes; they touch a particular set of bases. New Yorkers may be more experimental than most. There are those who conscientiously visit one new restaurant each week, who work their way down the Off Off Broadway listings, running aground somewhere between a community college production of Peer Gynt and a concert version of I Puritani on West 74th, Street.

title: Dr. Willard Cole Rappleye, 84, Columbia Medical Leader, Dies
description: Dr. Willard Cole Rappleye, former dean of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and the guiding spirit in the growth and development of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, died yesterday at his home, 31 East 79th Street. He was 84 years old.

title: Advertising
description: They've got an awful lot of potatoes in America and millions of Americans like theirs mashed. Millions of Americans also prefer buying convenience, foods rather than starting from scratch with the fresh vegetable.

title: City Gets Right to Buy State Electricity
description: The Board of Estimate gave final approval yesterday for New York City to begin buying all electric power for its municipal needs from the Power Authority of the State of New York instead of from the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Tally on Vice President
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 19Following is the rollcall vote tonight on the first ballot at the Republican National Convention for the nomination a VicePresidential candidate:

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 19Although the Democratic primary for Governor is still about a year away, two potential rivals for the officeGovernor Byrne and Joseph A. Hoffman, Commissioner of Labor and Industryhave begun sparring.

title: Vermont Project Lagging
description: MONTPELIER. Vt., Aug. 19 (AP)  Vermont's Bicentennial Steam Train, once hailed as the state's top Bicentennial project, may be coming to a grinding halt. The Legislature's Joint Fiscal Committee voted 5 to 3 (today not to authorize additional borrowing for the deficitridden train. The Spirit of Ethan Allen, now $809,000 in debt, was concieved two years ago as part of a rail loop, around the state.

title: F.D.A. Asks Curbs On Use of Darvon To Fight Its Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration has recommended that strict Government controls be placed on the distribution of Darvon, a widely prescribed painkiller whose abuse can cause dependence or death, a spokesman for the agency said tonight.

title: CANDIDATES BUSY IN FIVEWAY RACE
description: Three of the candidates for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York campaigned upstate yesterday, while the fourth was shaking hands with New Yorkers in Florida and the fifth sought votes in New York City.

title: White Shoes of Oilers Shelved for Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 19So you want to hear about Billy White Shoes, says Joe Fields.

title: REPORT ON BANK STIRS AN UPROAR
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday rejected a proposed acquisition by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the nation's eighth largest bank, citing financial difficulties at the New York bank. After the announcement produced an uproar in financial circles, the board issued a late afternoon statement declaring Bankers Trust sound.

title: ROBERT D. LEITER, C.C.N.Y. ECONOMIST
description: Dr. Robert D. Leiter, a professor of economics at the City College of New York since 1944 and an author of books on economics and labor, died yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 263 West End Avenue and was 54 years old.

title: VIGUERIE WILL SEEK 3D PARTI NO. 2 SPOT
description: KANSAS CITY. Mo., Aug. 19 (UPI)  A conservative fundraiser and theoretician, Richard A. Viguerie, announced today that he would run for the VicePresidential nomination of the American Independent Party, which he said would be on the ballot in 45 states.

title: Bank Loans in Canada Fall
description: OTTAWA. Aug. 20 (Reuters) Chartered bank general loans fell $64 million to $46,273 billion in the week ended Aug. 11, the Bank of Canada said. The Canadian dollar liquidity ratio at the chartered banks was 7,6 percent, unchanged from the previous week.

title: Papers Sell TV Stock
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 19 (UPI) Separation of ownership of the Minnesota Star and Tribune newspapers and the WCCO radio and television stations was announced today in a joint stock sale.

title: EDMUND B. SPAETH
description: Dr. Edmund B. Spaeth, an ophthalmologist and plastic surgeon, died Wednesday in the Chestnut Hill Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 86 years old.

title: BOTH SIDES RAISE KOREA READINESS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 19 Both North Korea and the United States announced steps today to increase the readiness of their military forces on the Korean peninsula in the wake of the killing of two American officers in the demilitarized zone yesterday but there were no overt signs of increased military activity.

title: Business Records
description: Pelition Filed By:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review of the film Ode to Billy Joe in The Times yesterday, a reference was made to Max Baer as the author of the screenplay. Mr. Baer was the director; the screenplay was written by Herman Raucher.

title: Egypt Warns Libya to Close Its Consulate in Alexandria
description: CAIRO, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Egyptian Government has ordered the Libyan consulate in Alexandria closed in order to insure the safety of its employees.

title: Ferrari Appealing A Victory by Hunt
description: PARIS, Aug. 19 (UPI)Ferrari, the Italian motor racing firm, has protested the first place awarded to a McLaren driver, James Hunt of Britain, in last month's Formula One British Grand Prix, the International Sports Commission said today.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: The DoleMiller Parallel and Gerald Ford
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 19 President Ford has chosen the most distinguished Republican VicePresidential nominee since William E. Miller (Spiro T. Agnew being one of two official Republican nonpersons). In fact, the DoleMiller parallel is striking, and this nomination may well produce about the same result as the other.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Data Transmission Company, a unit of the Wyly Corporation, will cease operations, a spokesman for Wyly said yesterday. In an application filed with the Federal Communications Commission, the company said that its board had decided to terminate all employees other than those required for actual transmission of data and to commence the orderly phaseout of its datatransmission services.

title: SCIENTISTS STUDY SITE FOR VIKING 2
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 19 (UPI)  Scientists discouraged by the rocky Martian terrain beamed to earth by Viking 2's cameras may look slightly northeast for a clearer area to set down their second Mars spacecraft.

title: Fire in Fallsburgh Razes Hotel, Sends 275 Into the Night
description: A fire routed 275 guests and staff members and destroyed the 35yearold Olympic Hotel in rural Sullivan County in the Catskills early yesterday, but no one was seriously injured.

title: Damp Spring Brings Bug Influx
description: New Jersey homeowners are experiencing an infestation of termites, carpentet ants and Japanese beetles this summer that exterminators, entomologists and gardeners say is the worst since 1969.

title: Bomb Demolishes a Car In Lesson for Policemen
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, Aug. 19Preceded by three warning hoots of a fire siren, a 1968 Rambler station wagon was legally blown up by a bomb under its front seat today as a classroom lesson to police and fire officers in how to investigate criminal bomb blasts.

title: A THIRD S.I. YOUTH CHARGED IN ATTACK
description: A 20yearold youth has been charged with burglary, criminal ??? and menacing in connection with the attack late last Saturday night by two carloads of, white men on the home of a black family in the Willowbrook section of Staten Island.

title: Badillo Wins Support, but He Is Unable to Reciprocate
description: The complex nature of interrelationships in New York City politics was illustrated yesterday when Representative Herman Badillo won the endorsement of a rising Assemblyman from East Harlem, but found he could not return the favor.

title: Notes Bought to Help State Bring a Profit for Pensions
description: The major pension fund for New York State employees, which came to the state's rescue earlier this year by buying notes that the private financial market did not want, ar ranged yesterday to resell the notes to an eager financial market that now wants them enough to give the pension fund a profit on them.

title: Options Board Criticized On a TapeRacing Rule
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange is being privately criticized by executives of a number of leading brokerage houses for proposing a rule to outlaw a littleknown industry practice called tape racing, Wall Street sources disclosed yeaterday.

title: The Dance: Ailey's Blues Suite
description: There are two works that have always been intimately associated with the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater. The first, of course, is Mr. Ailey's Revelations, which has been featured on so many of the company's programs and has ended so many of its celebrations. The second, Blues Suite, which was in fact created earlier and is now almost 20 years old, made its first appearance this season at the New York State Theater on wednesday night.

title: IISSINGER AIDES DENY MEMOIRS BID
description: Aides to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger denied yesterday a published report. that the Secretary was offering his, memoirs to publishers for $2 million and for promises of a chartered jet aircraft, secretaries and a research staff.

title: DELEGATE FOR FORE IS ONLY ABSTAINER
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 19 The distinction of being the one delegate of 2,259 to abstain from last night's vote that nominated President Ford fell to John J. J. Walsh Jr. of River Forest, ??? through a series of accidents.

title: Industry Scores U.S. Version of Whitefish
description: If whitefish has to be smoked by the standards laid down by the Food and Drug Administration, it will be inedible by human New Yorkers.

title: SUITS AGAINST HAYS OPPOSED BY THE U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to, dismiss three private suits. against Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, and his onetime secretary, Elizabeth Ray, that seek to recover any Federal money Miss Ray may have received without working for it.

title: Prison Reform Being Pressed by Liddy
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 19G. Gordon Liddy, who is serving a prison term for his part in the Watergate burglary four years ago, appears to be making substantial progess on prison reform from the inside.

title: REPORT ON BANK STIRS AN UPROAR
description: U.S. Cites Bankers Trust's Financial Difficulties but Later Terms It Sound

title: Sponsors Sought for Vote Drive
description: Now that both major parties have selected their Presidential candidates, it's time to think about getting out the vote on Election Day. William H. Genge, president of Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove, the Pittsburghbased agency, has done just that and is getting the ball rolling on a program called Pull for America.

title: Carter Pays Debt and Keeps Profile Low
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 19While the Republicans tried to make peace with each other in Kansas City today, a smiling and serene Jimmy Carter went to a picnic.

title: And 2 Contrasts in Style
description: The subway series of free outdoor concerts will continue in the boroughs this weekend with the Bronx and Brooklyn being treated to the talents of two conductors whose styles are as different as, say, the formidable New York Yankees of the 1950's and their onetime interborough rivals, the freewheeling Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: Restaurants
description: IT IS DIFFICULT to remember any other sixmonth period during which New York has had so large a spate of new restaurants, some elaborately and expensively done, others simply and inexpensively put together by their proprietors. Two contrasting cases in point are covered below, each with an entirely different appeal, one chic and glittering, the other simple and homespun.

title: Roads in Miami Flooded By a Tropical Depression
description: MIAMI, Aug. 19 (AP)A strengthening tropical depression that lingered near Key West dropped heavy rain on south Florida today, spawned a waterspout and generated winds of up to 60 miles an hour.

title: COMPANY PLEADS TO KEPONE CHARGE
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Allied Chemical Corporation pleaded no contest today to 940 criminal charges of discharging pesticide wastes from the production of Kepone into the James River.

title: Money Coming to Restore A LivedIn Art Form in Bronx
description: Noonan Plaza, a deteriorating wesern Bronx apartment complex that has been hailed as one of the most important Art Deco buildings in the world, was financially rescued yesterday.

title: PROTECTION URGED FOR ROME BUYERS
