He was sentenced to contribute 60 days of free community service with an organization approved by the court. The public service work was ordered by Judge Hamilton Gaydso in return for removing the drug and weapon charges from Gillian's police record.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FINE PRINT One of the 21 surviving copies of the original Declaration of Independence is on display in the Bicentennial Flag section of Grace Plaza, Avenue of the Americas and 43d Street. Printed in Philadelphia by John Dunlap on July 4, 1776, the document can be seen Monday through Friday from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. until Sept. 3.

title: For Better Prisons
description: Governor Carey's recent announcement of a plan to add immediately 500 new beds to the capacity of the state prison system appears to be a promising first step toward the resolution of an operational crisis in the system.

title: Toll Collectors Get Raise
description: WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Aug. 20 (AP)Toll collectors, maintenance workers and mechanics on the Garden State Parkway have signed a new contract giving them an 18 percent pay increase over the next three years. The New Jersey Highway Authority ratified the contract yesterday. Under the first phase of the new pact, all employees receive an increase of 50 cents an hour retroactive to July 1.

title: F. J. KOUCHAKJI RAREART DEALER
description: Fahim Joseph Kouchakji, a dealer of rare art whose collection once included the Great Chalice of Antioch, died Thursday in Shendaken, N. Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dance Troupes to Run 55th St. Theater
description: After several months of internal dispute about the future of the City Center 55th Street Theater, the City Center of Music and Drama and four major dance companies have agreed on a plan for the dance companies to manage and book the house for one year, beginning Sept. 1.

title: Corporate Profile
description: LONDON, Aug. 20The Burmah Oil Company, which has come under scrutiny for possible fraud in the United States, is one of those big, old British companies that blossomed with the Empire, and then, long after the Empire had collapsed, built one of its own.

title: NEW PACT SOUGHT FOR DOCKER UNION
description: A threeyear contract coverling ocean port dockworkers from Maine to Virginia will be scrapped because of an appealate court ruling that invalidated a key clause governing container shipments.

title: Indianapolis Busing Plan Blocked by Justice Stevens
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens today blocked lower court orders requiring that 6,533 black children be bused from Indianapolis to predominantly white schools in surrounding Marion County.

title: JACOBSEN SPARED PRISON SENTENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) Jake Jacobsen, the former lobbyist, was sentenced today to two years probation for his part in a milk price scandal in the Nixon Administration.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Dr. John S. Marr, director of the city's Bureau of Preventable Diseases, was incorrectly quoted in The Times yesterday as having said that commercially prepared gefilte fish was preferable to the homemade variety because of the danger of contamination in the latter. Dr. Marr's warning actually was directed against the common practice of tasting the raw freshwater fish for flavor before the gefilte fish was cooked.

title: Mr. Oh and Mr. Ruth
description: Sometime in the next few weeks, a baseball player JapanhalfChinese, halfJapanese and allMel Ott in batting stylewill hit the 715th home run of his career. And when he does, the secondranking power hitter in the history of the old American game, right up there behind Henry Aaron, will be Sadaharu Oh, the Babe Ruth Japan.

title: Notes on People
description: R.D. Smith of Toccoa, Ga., succeeded Thomas C. Walker of New London, Conn., as Commander in Chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars yesterday at its convention in New York City.

title: South African Apartheid: Questions and Answers on System and Chances for Change
Majestic Light Faces Honest Pleasure in the Travers
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20When LeRoy Jolley starts sounding like a Sundayschool teacher, as he did today on the eve of the $108.400 Travers Stakes, don't ignore his horse in the big race. It's only when Jolley's troops are getting around that the trainer sometimes loses his cool. When they're training and racing like champions, he relaxes.

title: 5 ROBBERS GRAB $35,000 FROM CAR
description: Five men jumped out of two panel trucks yesterday morning and robbed three people of $35,000 that was intended for a checkcashing concern, the police reported.

title: DOLE AND MONDALE WILLING TO MEET IN DEBATES ON TV
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 20 With the two Presidential candidates already committed to debate, Senators Robert J. Dole and Walter F. Mondale said today that they would be willing to meet in what would be the first nationally televised debates between VicePresidential candidates.

title: Coleman Foresees Concorde Landing at Kennedy Airport
description: PARIS, Aug 20 (Reuters) Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. said in a radio interview broadcast today that the trial period for the AngloFrench supersonic Concorde jet was proving sucessful and that the airliner would probably land in New York after the Presidential elections.

title: Test for Kepone Not Made On Fish in Massachusetts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 20 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had not tested fish from Massachusetts waters for Kepone, a potentially dangerous pesticide.

title: Dole in Emotional Return to Russell, Kan.
description: RUSSELL, Kan., Aug. 20 The experience of growing up in small, friendly towns like Russell is much romanticized in the United States.

title: Singles Field Cut to 22
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 20 About 25 women players were dropped or withdrew from the Tennis Week Open because of the presence of Dr. Renee Richards, according to Gene Scott, the tournament director.

title: Maine Ballot Requires James E., Not Jimmy
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 20 (AP)James E. Carter, not the familiar Jimmy Carter, will be the name of the Democratic Presidential candidate listed on Maine's ballot in November.

title: Despite Mistakes, Mondale's Tour Is Termed a Success
description: HIBBING, Minn., Aug. 18 Speaking before members of the United Automobile Workers Union in Black Mountain, N.C., last Sunday, an uncharacteristically fidgety Walter F. Mondale used the word shortly when he meant earlier.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value linkable to the capital shares of dualpurpose Investment companies It close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount of premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of this capital shares.

title: ANKER WOULD CUT FREE PUPIL RIDES
description: A change in Board of Education policy that would mean the end of free transportation for 113,500 public and nonpublic school pupils and higher fees for 63,400 other youngsters who receive reducedfare Privileges has been proposed by School Chancellor Irving Anker of New York City.

title: Argentine Extremists Kill 46 in Two Mass Murders
Utica Mayor Raises Age Of Girl by Proclamation
description: UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP) Mayor Edward Hanna of Utica, believing idle hands are the devil's workshop, turned 9yearold Thira Huffman into a teenager with a stroke of his pen.

title: RESERVE DEBATED ITS JULY TARGET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee at its July meeting debated the seemingly technical but important issue of how wide a target band to establish for the key Federal funds interest rate for the month ahead, it was disclosed today.

title: HOME WHERE 5 DIED PASSES STATE TEST
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 20 (AP)The director of nursing home inspections for the state said today that investigators had found no violations of state law at a nursing home where five elderly patients died early this month, apparently from heat stroke.

title: Dibley Service Fastest in Town
description: Although he felt he didn't have his best serve available yesterday, Colin Dibley of Australia was still speedy enough to win the National Fast Serve tournament, sanctioned by the National Tennis Foundation, at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. Oueens.

title: Proposed Fining of Principal Assailed
description: A $3,500 fine recommended against a Queens high school principal who refused, over orders by the Board of Education, to readmit a student he had suspended because of alleged disciplinary problems drew sharp criticism yesterday.

title: The High Cost of Neglecting the Oceans
Yonkers Directed by Arbitrator To Rehire LaidOff Teachers
Soviets to Try 3 Americans On HeroinSmuggling Count
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (Reuters) Three young Amricans arrested by the Soviet police for having tried to smuggle 83 pounds of heroin through the country are to stand trial in Moscow City Court next Tuesday, informed sources said today.

title: Pandora's Lunchbox
description: The alleged abuses in the Federallyfunded New York summer school lunch program are gradually assuming the dimensions of the earlier nursinghome ripoffs. A grand jury has looked into the charges of wasted and dumped food, rigged bidding, kickbacks from food vendors, and even the illegal use by adults of food destined for children. Federal indictments are expected.

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: Friday, Aug. 20, 1976.

title: Jets Seeking Elusive Goal
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20The time for talking nicely while losing is nearing an end for the New York Jets.

title: Kidde's U.S. Lines Says It Finds Signs Of Illegal Rebates
description: United States Lines Inc. announced yesterday that a special committee appointed by its directors had found indications of illegal rebates to shippers.

title: LEBANON DEADLINE IS SET BY SYRIANS
description: BEIRUT, Aug. 20The Syrians were reported today to have set Sept. 15 as a final deadline for interArab contacts on Lebanon to produce effective results, failing which they are expected to order their forces to move to bring the 16 month civil war to a decisive end.

title: London Painter and Restorer Admits Flooding Art Market With Forgeries
description: LONDON, Aug. 20Tom Keating, a 59yearold painter and picture restorer, confessed in a letter in The Times of London today to have flooded the market with imitations of work by Samuel Palmer, the 19thcentury landscape painter, and other famous artists.

title: DELEGATES LEAVE WITH MUTED HOPE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 20 Delegates to the 31st Republican National Convention streamed out of Kansas City today, exhilarated by the drama of last night's concluding session but profoundly worried about the next 73 days.

title: Detroit Is Tightening Its Curfew In Effort to Combat Youth Gangs
description: DETROIT, Aug. 20 (UPI) The City Council tightened its curfew ordinance today in an effort to combat youth gang violence.

title: MiddleClass Blacks Return to Harlem
description: While many blacks think of Harlem only as a place characterized by overcrowded tenements, garbagefilled streets and a high crime rate, a small but growing number of black middleclass families have been moving into the area in the last three or four years.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY WIN JULY; FOOD RISE SMALL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Consumer prices rose in July at about the same pace as in other recent months, with inflation now running steadily at a yearly rate of 5 to 6 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A West Point Burial Is Planned For U. S. Officer Slain in Korea
description: Capt. Arthur G. Bonifas, one of the two American officers slain Wednesday by North Korean soldiers in Korea's demilitarized zone at Panmunjom, will be buried with military honors next Tuesday at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

title: TWO SHOT AT SHOW IN SCHOOL IN QUEENS
Like It or Not, West German Town Can't Escape Wagner's Ghost
News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 21, 1976

title: Those Sentinels of City Blight: Abandoned Buildings
description: For some people an undesirable neighbor is one who plays the phonograph too loudly or hammers pictures into a wall at 3 in the morning. But Pat Prantera on the Lower East Side, Mae Lilly in Harlem and Joseph Richardson of OceanHillBrownsville in Brooklyn have undesirable neighbors that are far more menacing  ravaged, abandoned, wideopen buildings.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Yonkers Results

title: Siamese Twins Separated
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Aug. 20 (UPI)Siamese twin girls born July 14 were successfully separated today by a team of doctors at the University of Texas Medical Branch. The twins, Charlotte Marie and Paulette Marie Jones, were listed in satisfactory condition. The 5weekold infants had been Joined at the chest and abdomen.

title: TEXAS OILMAN HELD IN MURDER OF TWO
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 20 (UPI) The police rearrested Cullen Davis as he was boarding his private jet and jailed, him without bond on capital murder charges in the slaying of his stepdaughter and his estranged wife's lover, the district attor ney's office announced.

title: East German Pastor, a Foe Of Reds, Sets Himself Afire
description: HERLESHAUSEN, West Germany, Aug. 20 (AP)A Protestant minister in East Germany set himself afire in front of his East German church to protest the Communist Government's repression of young people, witnesses said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: All caves have their own personalities, the authors tell ussome open and inviting, others stark and demanding. The same, of course, could be said for books. There are books that solicit the reader like signs tacked on barns in Tennessee (See Ruby Falls86 miles), offering gushy guided tours on the subject matter, making the reader do nothing more strenuous than follow the literary guardrail.

title: Ford Shares in Dole's Warm Welcome Home to Kansas
description: RUSSELL, Kan., Aug. 20  President Ford identified the Republican campaign ticket with Washington today as he and Senator Robert J. Dole paid a sentimental and political call on the Senator's hometown.

title: 2 Nations Ordering A Boycott
description: The national teams from Indonesia and the Philippines have been instructed by their Governments to withdraw from participation in the Federation Cup tennis tournament if teams representing South Africa and Rhodesia compete. The tournament is scheduled to begin tomorrow in Philadelphia.

title: Deputy Named in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 20 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Ian D. D. Smith of Rhodesia has appointed Finance Minister David C. Smith as his deputy, it was announced here tonight. The position had been vacant since the beginning of the year when John J. Wrathall became the country's second President.

title: Dancer Aims for Big Payoff
description: YONKERS, Aug. 20Stanley Dancer, the harness racing tycoon from New Egypt, N.J., is hoping tomorrow to account for the richest payday of his notable career.

title: Reds Win on Homers, 43
description: George Foster, who leads the National League in runs batted in, and Johnny Bench, nine time an allstar performer, hit solo home runs to power the Cincinnati Reds to a 43 triumph over the Chicago Cubs in Riverfront Stadium last night.

title: Prices in New York City Area Increased 0.3 Percent in July
description: Consumer prices in the New York CityNortheastern New Jersey area increased in July by threetenths of a percent, after adjustment for seasonal changes, compared with a fivetenths of a percent increase nationally, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.5% IN JULY; FOOD RISE SMALL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Consumer prices rose in July at about the same pace as in other recent months, with inflation now running steadily at a yearly rate of 5 to 6 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The Institute of Preventive Medicine, a medical diagnostic center formerly of West New York, has opened new and enlarged quarters in Lyndhurst and is inviting companies with 100 or more employees to have them receive inoculations there against swine flu. The cost is $3 for each inoculation.

title: Yonkers Candidate Appeals Adverse Ruling on Petitions
description: YONKERS, Aug. 20 (UPI)A candidate seeking the Democratic nomination in the 23d Congressional district, covering parts of Westchester County, including Yonkers, and the North Bronx has appealed judge's decision that took him off the Liberal Party line, campaign aide said today.

title: ATTENDANTS BACK T.W.A. AGREEMENT
description: Flight attendants at Trans World Airlines ratified a new contract yesterday, averting a strike threatened for midnight.

title: Manhattan's Council Members: United in Singlehood for Now
description: If your image of the domestic life of politicians includes a spouse, two children, a cat and a dog and a little house with a white picket fence, forget it.

title: Two Plead in Extortion
description: BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP)Two Massachusetts state senators pleaded not guilty today to charges that they extorted $50,000 from a New York consulting firm in connection with a state investigation of that firm. Senators Joseph J. C. DiCarlo, Democrat of Revere, and Ronald McKenzie, Republi can of Burlington, entered their pleas before United States Magistrate Rudolph Pierce, who set bail for both men at $1,000 without surety.

title: Heir to Chip Fortune Reports Kidnapping; 2 Men Are Arrested
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., Aug. 20 (UPI) John H. Scudder, 63 years old, a member of a wealthy potato chipmanufacturing family, said that he escaped yesterday from two kidnappers who planned to hold him for $250,000 ransom.

title: Reagan Hints New Party If Carter Wins Election
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (UPI) Ronald Reagan said on his return to California today that conservative Republicans should think about forming a third party if Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, is elected in November.

title: ANKER WOULD CUT FREE PUPIL RIDES
description: A change in Board of Education policy that would mean the end of free transportation for 113,500 public and nonpublic school pupils and higher fees for 63,400 other youngsters who receive reducedfare privileges has been proposed by School Chancellor Irving Anker of New York City.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY. AUGUST 21. 1976

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A young father and his two small children died yesterday when fire swept through their home in the Middle Village section of Queens shortly before 3:30 A.M. The police identified the victims as Dennis Mallon, 26 years old; his son, James, 2, and daughter, Kim, 1. Mallon's wife, Marian, 24, was reported in fair condition at St. John's Hosptal with seconddegree burns. A fire official said that the blaze, 7550 Metropolitan Avenue, was reported at 3:37 AM. and was brought under control at 3:53 A.M.

title: DOLE AND MONDALE WILLING TO MEET IN DEBATES ON TV
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 20 With the two Presidential candidates already committed to debate, Senators Robert J. Dole and Walter F. Mondale said today that they would be willing to meet in what would be the first nationally televised debates between VicePresidential candidates.

title: Prized Theological Library Sold To Emory U. for $1.75 Million
description: Packed snugly in 10,000 sturdy cartons and loaded aboard moving vans, one of the nation's most prized collections of theological literature is being shipped this month from dusty shelves in New England to a new home in the Deep South.

title: Tract for S. I. Amusement Park Wasn't Appraised, Official Says
description: Opponents of a proposed Staten Island amusement park won a court round yesterday after introducing testimony at variance with City Hall assertions about an appraisal of the property.

title: Pecci Upsets Ramirez At Toronto by 76, 76
description: TORONTO, Aug. 20 (UPI) Victor Pecci, a 20yearold Paraguayan, became the latest upset victor in the Canadian open tennis championships, defeating Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 76, 76, today.

title: Pattern in Futures
description: Silver futures prices have been following the lead of soybean futures with such regularity for the last year or so that traders often speak of parallel movements. Page 32.

title: Ford Shares in Dole's Warm Welcome Home to Kansas
description: RUSSELL, Kan., Aug. 20  President Ford identified the Republican campaign ticket with Washington today as he and Senator Robert J. Dole paid a sentimental and political call on the Senator's hometown.

title: Ford on the Attack
description: President Ford's acceptance speech was a masterful political performance. Combined with Governor Reagan's brief, skillfully delivered postscript address, it brought the Republican National Convention to a rhetorically effective climax.

title: Reunified Vietnam Asks for Admission To United Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20  The Communist Government of a reunified Vietnam applied today for membership in the United Nations.

title: Third World Speaks Out
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 20Representatives of the generally improverished and underdeveloped southern half of the world went away from Colombo today united in a new mood of determination to get a larger share of the kind of life that Americans take for granted. It simply is not fair, they declared in speeches. in conversations and in an angry and anguished final communiqu, that the rich nations are so rich and the poor nations are se poor.

title: 2 KEN ARRESTED IN POLICE SLAYING
description: NEWARK, Aug. 20 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation and other authorities announced tonight the arrest of two suspects in the fatal shooting of Patrolman John W. Snow of Newark during the robbery of a checkcashing service in Kearny last Friday. A third man was also being sought, they said.

title: Athens Court Rules Against Extradition Of a Berlin Fugitive
description: BONN, Aug. 20  After an Athens court refused today to extradite a West German fugitive charged with terrorist acts, a West German Government spokesman here said that the refusal showed that the whole question of terrorism has to be approached on a new international level.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 20 (UPI)The dollar rose on Continental money markets today in a generally steadier market. The price of gold eased slightly on bullion markets from a lack of demand. It fell 20 cents in Zurich to $109.15 and was down 50 cents in London to $108.875.

title: Dynamics Stock Falls Sharply
description: The shares of the General Dynamics Corporation plummeted 8 points to close at 50 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. It was their first day of trading following the disclosure of legal problems for the company involving more than $1 billion in shipbuilding contracts from the Burmah Oil Company of Britain.

title: TEACHERS GROUP ENDORSES BUSING
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Aug. 20A longstanding division within the American Federation of Teachers over how strong a stand to take in favor of busing to achieve school desegregation reappeared today as the group adopted a resolution that some within the organization considered too moderate.

title: Sets and Gaters Will Play Today
description: OAKLAND, Aug. 20 (AP) The New York Sets, led by Billie Jean King, invade the Oakland Coliseum tomorrow to start a threeoffive series with the Golden Gaters for the World Team Tennis championship.

title: Rebuff to Bankers Trust Reversed Earlier Backing
description: The proposed Bankers Trust New York Corporation acquisition that was rejected Thursday by the Federal Reserve Board because of the bank's financial troubles was approved routinely late last year by the New York State Banking Department.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: DOTTIE HITS SOUTH CAROLINA; Workmen struggling to secure a World War II Hellcat fighter on the deck of the aircraft carrier Yorktown, now a naval museum, as

title: Intruder Kins 3 in Family
description: LINCOLN, III., Aug. 20 (UPI)  An intruder killed a farmer, his wife and one of their teenage daughters last night in their home, and a young house painter was charged today with the slayings. The authorities said the victims apparently were stabbed to death while another daughter and a friend who escaped from the house tried to summon help. Michael Edward Drabing, 21 years old, of Lincoln was arrested at midday and charged in the case. Bail set at $3 million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Restructure the Nation's Economy

title: COURT ORDER TO BAR PROTEST OF APLANT
description: CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 20 (AP)The Public Service Company of New Hampshire was granted a temporary injunction today prohibiting unauthorized persons from entering the site of the Seabrook nuclear power plant, a spokesman for the company said.

title: French Concern Seeking Control of CertainTeed
description: The CertainTeed Corporation of Valley Forge, Pa., announced yesterday that Compagnie de St. GobainPontaMousson, which owns 41 percent of CertainTeed, wanted to acquire voting control of the company. With 13 million CertainTeed common shares outstanding, the French company would need an additional 1.3 million shares to achieve control. At yesterday's closing price of 17 on the New York Stock Exchange, this would require an investment of about $22.58 million.

title: No News From Prague
description: There has been little news from Prague for almost eight years. Life goes on, of course. An unwary visitor might even think that everything was normal.

title: Plan for SouthWest Africa Attacked
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20The United Nations Council for Namibia today rejected a plan, sponsored by South Africa, for the independence of SouthWest Africa by the end of 1978.

title: Yanks Lose, Martin Fumes
description: Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, gets steamed when his team loses. Last night, at the Stadium, Billy Martin was steamed.

title: South African Blacks Get New Concession on Homes
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 20 The South African Government announced a new concession to urban blacks today, but followed up the move with tough speeches suggesting that the basic conditions of life for the country's 18 million blacks were unlikely to undergo any fundamental change.

title: Black Nations Want South Africans Out Of Atomic Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20A large group of black African countries led by Nigeria is seeking to eject South Africa from the International Atomic Energy Agency, United States officials said today.

title: TRAVIS WALSH DIES; EDITOR IN OKLAHOMA
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 20 (AP) Travis Walsh, managing editor of The Tulsa Daily World for seven years, died yesterday of cancer. He was 52 years old.

title: N.F.L. Sues Over Lottery
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 20 (AP)The National Football League filed suit today to block Delaware's plans to legalize gambling on professional football.

title: 5 Hurt in Gas Truck Mishap
description: FLINT, Mich., Aug. 20 (AP) A tank truck carrying liquid propane gas went out of control on an Interstate 69 over pass and crashed onto Inter state 75, spreading flames and debris in front of oncoming traffic. Five persons were critically burned. The truck driver, Donald Swofer, 34 years old, of Lexington, was one of them. The others were Thomas Tobian, 40, of Montclair, Del.; two sisters, Loucretria Gearing, 44, and Alichia Gearling, 17, of Grand Blanc, and Helen Palmer, 29, of Flint.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In pounds sterling per metric ton)

title: Rowdies Eliminate Cosmos
description: TAMPA, Aug. 20There will be no championship laurels for Pele and the New York Cosmos this year. They were eliminated from the North Soccer League playoffs tonight by the Tampa Bay Rowdies, who stood up to their name at times and won convincingly, 31.

title: Book Calling ExHolyoke Head a Lesbian Is Assailed
description: Some alumnae of Mount Holyoke College are buzzing about a forthcoming biography of Mary Emma Woolley, the college's president from 1900 to 1937.

title: 'Gumball Rally' Is Film That Loses Own Race
description: When the code word "gumball" is passed by a rich young man, two housewives, two stage Englishmen, one Italian Lothario, one bugeyed motorcyclist a couple of Texans, a girly-magazine model and other assorted types converge upon a New York garage."The Gumball Rally," which opened yesterday at the Rivoli, Eastside Cinema and other theaters, opens with a familiar effort at comical mystery. It goes mildly well until the mystery is revealed about a quarter of an hour after the movie starts. All those people are meeting to see which pair can drive a car fastest, in disregard of speed limits and other traffic regulations, from New York to California.After they all start off, and once you get used to the rather handsome speeding-car effects, which is soon, the movie seems to be nothing but one long exhaust pipe. There is only so much that can be done with scenes of cars passing each other.Some diversions are attempted. The Italianpainlessly played by Raul Juliakeeps stopping to seduce pretty women that he spots along the way. The housewives stop to be seduced. A lot of policemen show up at various points, and all make amiable fools of themselves.People who pay money to see this effort to find knee-slappers in the 55 mile-an-hour speed limit will also make amiable fools of themselves.The movie is rated PG, for parental guidance. Despite the seductions, all but unseen, it should be harmless for any child who has not had a parent, brother or sister killed or injured in a highway accident.

title: China Extends Ties
description: HONG KONG, Aug 20 (Reuters)China and the Central African Republic formally reestablished diplomatic relation today, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported.

title: Residents Near Yankee Stadium Say City Reneged on Renovation Promise
Argentine Extremists Kill 46 in 2 Mass Murders
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20Two mass murders of 46 people were carried out today, apparently by rightwing extremists in reprisal for the assassination of a retired armygeneral. The bodies of 23 men and 5 women, and two mutilated corpses were found early today in a pasture near Pilar, about 25 miles northwest of this capital. They had been killed by machine gun and their bodies blown up with dynamite.

title: Soybean Futures Prices Gain As Concern Over Heat Rises
description: CHICAGO. Aug. 20 (AP) Higher temperatures over the central portion of the country influenced buying in soybeans, meal and oil today on the Chicago Board of Trade, but grain futures failed to attract much buying interest.

title: 419,000 Abortions in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 20 (Reuters)More than 419,000 abortions have been carried out in India since the laws on abortion were liberalized four years ago, the Government said in a statement in Parliament.

title: Hollywood Losing Glamour Image As Tawdriness Replaces the Tinsel
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 20 In a seemingly relentless search, the summer tourists head down Hollywood Boulevard these days. Most converge on the courtyard of the old Grauman's Chinese Theater and their eyes immediately shoot downward, searching for the names and symbols of celluloid heros and heroines of the past, and a Hollywood that really does not exist anymore.

title: Identity of Foul Globs In Suffolk Is Revealed
description: MONTAUK, LI., Aug. 20For the last four days, tens of thousands of mysterious, foulsmelling globs have been washing up on a I2mile stretch of South Shore beaches in Suffolk County, from Moriches Inlet to Quoque.

title: Louisville Teaching Staffs To Be Integrated by Sept. 1
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 20 (UPI)All teaching staffs in the Jefferson County school system will be racially integrated by the time classes open Sept. 1, according to a report submitted to Federal District Judge James Gordon.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: For People in the Know, There's an Offbeat Restaurant Row
description: If 11 restaurants of quality in one block can add up to a Restaurant Row, then that's what 58th Street between Second and Third Avenues has become.

title: U.S. ASKS AMENDS BY NORTH KOREANS
Carter Says Ford Fails To Check Nation's Drift
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 20  Jimmy Carter tried out today what may be the principal themes of his Presidential campaign, accusing the Ford Administration of having allowed the nation to drift without a goal or purpose and saying that the voters' choice was between new leadership in the White House or no leadership.

title: Miss Whitworth Leads Berg Classic by 2 on 66
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 20 (AP) Kathy Whitworth shot a courserecord 66 today, overcoming 93degree heat and high winds, and took the firstround lead in the $55,000 Patty Berg Golf Classic.

title: One Set of Twins Remains in N.F.L.
description: The Buckey brothers act was broken up last week when the Jets cut Dave, the quarterback, while retaining the other twin, Don, the wide receiver. Are there any twin brothers playing in the National Football League? Yes, and one was in the news last week. The Houston Oilers traded Ronald Reed Saul, a guard, to the Washington Redskins for three of George Allen's future draft choices, one in 1977, one in 1978 and one in 1979.

title: Four Americans: a broadcaster, two very rich men, an evangelist
description: In 1930 the power at The Literary Digest was R. J. Cuddihy, a fervid teetotaler. He sponsored a radio newscast by Floyd Gibbons, who in addition to being enormously popular with his audience was one of New York's more formidable drinkers. Something less than cordiality developed as Gibbons would show up in Cuddihy's board room. unbutton his shirt, head for the water cooler with the announcement, Well, boss, your big boy broadcaster was out on one hell of a toot last night. Meanwhile young William Paley, head of the fledgling Columbia Broadcasting Company, was yearning to bring the newscast, a highly valued property, to his network. A vague phone call went to Lowell Thomas. Arriving still wondering what it was all about, Thomas was taken to a microphone and told by Paley, When you hear the buzzer, start talking. Talk 15 minutesI don't care about what. Executive wheels churned. On Sept. 29, 1930, Gibbons was out, Thomas was saying, Good evening, everybody on the newscast, and the longest continuing run in broadcast history was under way.

title: Effect of Drugs To Aid Athletes Studied by U.S.
description: Minutes after his secondplace finish in the Olympic Marathon at Montreal, Frank Shorter was asked whether he might be tempted to try for a gold medal at the 1980 Olympics in Moscow.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Performing and acting have a lot in commonacting is, in part, performingbut there is an important distinction. The essence of performance is delivering a blow. The essence of acting is receiving it. Listening, registering, reacting: these are the heart of stage acting. Never mind the soliloquy; actors must deliver them, of course, but what we remember of actors is not so much the winds they create as the wind they bend to. That is why Hamlet is such an ungrateful role; he reacts to nothing except a ghost and his own insides.

title: CARTER TO STRESS CAMPAIGN IN AREAS OF FORD STRENGTH
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 21  After opening his Presidential campaign with a Labor Day speech in Warm Springs, Ga., Franklin Roosevelt's favorite retreat, Jimmy Carter plans to focus his pursuit of the White House on states where President Ford seems strongest, an aide said today.

title: Trend Toward the Ordination of Women by Anglicans Impedes Unity, Pope Tells Archbishop
description: ROME, Aug. 21 (AP)The Vatican newspaper has published an exchange of letters between Pope Paul VI and the Archbishop of Canterbury in which the Pope says the trend toward women priests in the Anglican faith is an obstacle to unity between the churches.

title: What's Doing in CAMBRIDGE, MASS.
description: STREET LIFEHarvard Square, a small section of Cambridge, is undeniably the city's most colorful, bizarre. and frenetic spot. Young women in halters and jeans or lace overblouses and granny skirts walk hand in hand with their bearded boyfriends in Indian shirts. The heterogeneous parade of youth  Harvard and Radcliffe students, townies, dropouts, members of the counterculture is joined by professors, postgrads, staid New England residents, tourists. The sounds of vehicular traffic cannot drown out the impromptu sidewalk concerts by guitar and recorder players and the spiels of peddlers hawking their wares. Harvard Square's side streets are as fascinating as those of European town.

title: Maine Imperils Hall Race
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 21 (UPI)At least 4,000 names on nominating petitions for Gus Hall, Communist Presidential candidate have been ruled invalid, Mark Gartley, Maine Secretary of State, said yesterday. The decision could keep Mr. Hall off the November ballot since he has filed 12,786 signatures and 10,918 were needed to qualify for the election. Mr. Gartley said his investigation showed that many signers of the petitions were unregistered voters.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: L AZY streams emptied into this sea, carrying with them silt washed down from the highlands together with the remains of plants and animals. These remnants, now fossilized, tell us that ours was once a tropical climate, with palms, cycads and tree ferns. Great saurians wallowed and fought around the shores of the shallow sea, and the ancestors of the birds flapped huge leathery wings among the giant horsetails of the carboniferous forest.

title: BRIDGE

title: New strains of lifeor death
description: Early in July, the 10man City Council of Cambridge, Mass., at the urging of some concerned Harvard scientists, voted to ask Harvard University to halt temporarily the construction of a new $500,000 laboratory for specialized genetics .research. This move on the part of the Mayor and other local elected officials against the scientific decisions of the university was unprecedented, but so was the dramatic reason for itthe fear that the biologists, who propose to tamper with the genetic apparatus of microorganisms, would create a new Andromedalike strain that might escape their control and spread an incurable disease to the population.

title: Informed Consent
description: The requirement of informed consent before a patient is subjected to invasive medical procedure has become a major legal tenet and has figured in growing numbers of medical malpractice cases. This was precisely why Congress, in voting to have the Federal Government accept initial liability responsibility in the swine flu vaccination program, insisted that the informed consent provision be fully met. To that end, Congress asked that the appropriate Government form explaining the vaccination's risks and benefits be reviewed by the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biological Research.

title: New Haven Rail Line Ordered To Start 7Step Safety Program
description: WETHERSFIELD. Conn., Aug. 21 (AP)Connecticut has ordered Conrail to begin a sevenstep safety program on New Haven line commuter trains, in the wake of the New Canaan crash last month that claimed two lives and injured more than 30. The program, which is to be implemented immediately, includes a plan to make it easier for passengers to open railcar doors in an emergency.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Have you ever noticed how quick we are to rat on Shakespeare? Like Hollywood screenwriters, Shakespeare is approximately as good as his last production, and if the last production of, say, As You Like that you saw was a real bummer, you're apt to say to yourself, though not out loud, Well, Hamlet and Othello okay, but that one was written after too prolonged a binge at the Boar's Head. Confess it, you will. It doesn't matter how many times you have seen a particular play work. It's the latest mounting that lodges in your head, wiping out virtues that one another actor or director has earlier displayed for you, and it'll take a brand new, freshly discerning job on the textmaybe six or eight years from nowto restore your faith the play proper. Unfair, unfair, but that's human nature for you, always capable of instant exasperation.

In economic terms, this translates into an intellectual concern with inflation and an emotional response to unemployment. This year, the issues of prices and jobs seem as fundamental as ever as President Ford and Jimmy Carter set out to woo the voters. But strategy could be altered by what appears to be a more conservative national mood.

There is general agreement that new approaches should be triedprepaid legal services programs along the line of Blue Cross, for example, and increased use of paraprofessionals for standardized legal tasks. But there is no agreement on precisely what individual lawyers, and the organized bar as a whole, should be reauired to do.

title: Red Smith
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21 A friend who is attached to horse racing and other good things like music and books and steam railways says that every now and then he encounters someone who says, I've never been to a race track in my life, and I don't know whether I would enjoy it. His reply never varies. Don't try it at Aqueduct, he says, or Charles Town or Belmont, much as I like that track. Some August when you're up around the Adirondacks, drop into Saratoga. ]t will save you a lot of trouble, because if you don't enjoy racing there, you won't enjoy it anywhere.

title: A political and personal confession
description: Julius Lester has written about himself in a way other, more canny autobiographers manage to avoid. Not since Norman Podhoretz's Making It, have I seen a confessional memoir which, while suffused with vanity, at the same time deliberately exposes so many small unflattering aspects of its author. The confessional form, after all, for the most part remains a literary conceit that allows the writer to disclose only that self which he has reason to put on view at the time. Norman Mailer, for example, handles the confessional business with enormous care, making sure that we will find him attractive and charming despite his demonsalthough in real life his charm is not always that evident.

title: Black Sun
description: In the 1920's, some people, especially his wife Caresse, thought Harry Crosby a poet, but now The Oxford Companion to American Literature knows as little of him as A Literary History of the United. States. What fame he has achieved he earned largely through his final act. Keats once said that he was half in love with easeful death. Harry Crosby was wholly in love with it and he consummated his affair with it in 1929 when at the age of 31 he calmly Shot his married girlfriend and then himself in a ninthfloor apartment of the Hotel des Artistes on West 67th Street in New York. For once the tabloid headlines got it right: Tragedy and Disgrace. What brought this rich, brave, drunken, selfcentered neurotic to this pass and what it all as to do with literature is the burden of Geoffrey Wolff's fascinating biography.

title: Speed Limit in Moscow Reducing Traffic Deaths
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (Reuters) The number of road deaths fell by almost 20 percent in Moscow after a speed limit of 60 kilometers (37 miles) an hour was relmposed earlier this year, according to the August issue of the Soviet road safety journal.

title: New Patching Material

Once pressed into place, this black, rubberlike tape will stick permanently to seal out water, dirt and air.

title: Meyers to Have Surgery
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 (UPI)Dave Meyers, a forward for the Milwaukee Bucks, will undergo surgery on his left knee within the next 10 days in Los Angeles, according to a spokesman for the National Basketball Assotion team. Meyers suffered a minor fracture of the patella or kneecap last November. Meyers will be out of action for at least three months.

title: Auto Race to Bigelow
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 21 (AP)Tom Bigelow, despite driving without brakes for nearly the entire race, won the Tony Bettenhausen Memorial 100mile race for championship dirt cars today at the Illinois State Fairgrounds. Bigelow was followed by Johnny Parsons of Speedway, Ind., in second place. Billy Cassella of Weirton, W. Va., finished third.

title: H L. Hunt
description: By Stanley H. Brown. Illustrated. 217 pp. Chicago: Playboy Press. $8.95.

title: Toy Poodle Best In Newtown Show
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., Aug. 21 Merrill Cohen had his first bestinshow judging assignment today and chose a white toy poodle, Ch. Chrisward AOK of Aririch, at the Newtown Kennel Club event on the Fair Grounds, for the 6pounder's first top award.

title: Joy Jones Bride Of Z.W. Carter
description: Joy Vida Jones, an associate with the New York law firm of Wien, Lane & Malkin, was married yesterday morning to Zachary Warren Carter, an assistant United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

title: Twins Top Fidrych On 4 Runs in 10th
description: DETROIT, Aug. 21 (UPI)Mark Fidrych hit Dan Ford with a pitch with the basesloaded and two out in the 10th inning today that forced in the decisive run and carried the Minnesota Twins to a 73 triumph over the Detroit Tigers. The Twins added three runs in the rally.

title: Celebrity Tennis Players in the Zoo
description: For the last few years, the National Broadcasting Company has been assigning me and a camera crew to cover each renewal of the Robert F. Kennedy procelebrity tennis tournament at Forest Hills. Each time, the assignment has come as a surprise to me. Usually, I cover sports.

title: Conservationists Give Carter High Marks and Ford, Low Ones
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21If environmental concern won elections, there would be no need for a November runoff between Jimmy Carter and President Ford.

title: 6 Killed in 2Car Crash
description: LEXINGTON, S.C., Aug. 21 (UPI)Six persons were killed tonight when two cars collided head on And burst into flames on the road over the Lake Murray Dam. The authorities said the bodies were burned beyond recognition, and none of the victims had been identified.

title: Karl Stange Weds Elisabeth M. Wert
description: Elisabeth Metlar Wert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lee Wert, and Karl Friedrich Stange, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hugo Stange, were married yesterday in Princeton, N. J., where both families live.

title: Architecture surveyed
description: Architectural history is generally written as an examination of a particular style, or as a study of the architecture thathas been built at a particular place. Although a number of monographs have explored specific kinds of buildings such as railroad stations and apartment houses rather than styles or periods, never had a scholar attempted to review the history of architecture entirely in terms of such building classifications until Sir NikolausPevsner, the eminent scholar of early modern architecture and author of the exhaustive Buildings of England guidebook series, delivered a series of lectures at the National Gallery of Art in 1970 entitled A History of Building Types. The present book is an expanded version of these talks.

title: LETTERS
description: Banks

title: 4 Companies Are Related
description: Today's American automobile industry descends from two men and two companies. Henry Ford founded the Ford Motor Company. William Crapo Durant founded the General Motors Corporation, and before Mr. Durant was driven from the company two G.M. executives quit rather than keep working for him: Walter Chrysler who founded the Chrysler Corporation; and Charles Nash who then made the Nash car. The old Hudson company merged into Nash in 1954 to form American Motors.

title: Clashes in North Reported By Christians in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 21New fighting has flared in northern Lebanon, with Christian forces reporting success.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: The Domestic International Sales Corporation (DISC) was set up under the Revenue Act of 1971 for the specific purpose of providing a facility to encourage export sales of American manufactured products. The incentive program gives the American exporter a 50 percent tax writeoff on the proceeds of export sales.

title: Lefrak City Reports Progress In Resolving Project's Problems
description: The owners and tenants of Lefrak City are continuing to make progress in stabilizing conditions in the huge housing complex in Queens that has been troubled by rapid racial change and physical deterioration, according to the city's Human Rights Commission.

title: Can Congress at last control
description: money tree?

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The greatest show on earth is about to open in New York. Greatest, that is, if you are a numismatista fancier of coins, medals, paper money and the like. This show (and the old circus superlative extravaganza can be readily applied to it) is the 85th national convention of the American Numismatic Association. It officially opens to the public, members and nonmembers alike, the day after tomorrow, Tuesday, at 11 A.M., in the Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets, just a few blocks north of the Times Square area. There is no admission charge, but registration is required for security reasons.

title: No Divorce, But Brazilians Find a Way
Connecticut to Return to Automatic Toll System
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 21 (AP)The State Department of Transportation is switching back to automatic collection equipment at some highway toll booths to relieve traffic congestion.

title: WEST POINT CITES FOUR AS CHEATERS
description: The United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., has upheld allegations against four more cadets who were among 200 students implicated in a cheating scandal that has shaken the institution.

title: Barbara Cory Bride of Spencer Knapp, Law Clerk
description: The marriage of Barbara Ellen Cory, daughter of Paul Russell Cory of New York and Mary Holbrook Cory of Singer Island, Fla., to Spencer Richard Knapp took place yesterday afternoon in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Attics, Repositories of the Past, Are Themselves Passing
Hope Hathaway Cudahy Bride Of Westbrook Metzman Pegler
description: Hope Hathaway Cudahy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Cudahy of Omaha, was married there yesterday afternoon to Westbrook Metzman Pegler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur James Pegler 2d of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Wayne Selsor performed the Protestant ceremony at the Cudahy home.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Dave Stockton, the new Professional Golfers Association champion, is known as scrambler. Most players would resent the reputation. Stockton relishes it

title: Joseph Durso
description: This is no time to distract you from the rise of the Yankees, the reappearance of tennis at Forest Hills or the return of the horses from Saratoga next week. But the football season, which waits for neither time nor tide nor World Series, is upon us again. So we have worked up this little scouting report before the kids start embarrassing questions like: Why do they have ribbons on the goal posts this year?

title: Presidential Campaign
description: Now that the two major parties have decided on their Presidential tickets after the seemingly endlessand exhaustingpreconvention campaigns, the American people have just ten weeks left to make up their minds on the fateful choice of national leadership for the next four years. That choice will depend both on the way the electorate sizes up the two principal candidates, and on the way the respective candidates propose to handle the great political, economic and social questions affecting this country's future.

title: Proxy Tally
description: Stockholders concern about the Arab boycott and corporate political skullduggery made the 1976 proxy season the busiest ever, says a Washington group researching social issues for institutional investors.

title: Meetings This Week By City Council Panels
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council Committees this week:

title: Transit Worker Vote Set
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 (UPI)  The city's 1,700 bus, trolley and cablecar drivers will vote tomorrow whether to accept a new pay package that would increase their wages 57 cents an hour. Local 250A of the Transport Workers Union of America, had threatened to walk off the job at 12:01 a.m. yesterday unless the city's Board of Supervisors accepted its demands. The board approved a pay and fringe benefit package, which included raising salaries to $7.46 an hour from $6.89.

title: Afghan Talks With Pakistani
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 21 (Reuters)President Mohammad Saud of Afghanistan, making his first visit to Pakistan in 20 years, held talks today with Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto on building friendly relations between their countries.

title: China's Quake Enhances Stature of Premier Hua
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 21For all the suffering that last month's earthquake brought to parts of north China, it may have had one positive effect. It seems to have helped consolidate the position of Hua Kuofeng, the relatively unknown party administrator who was unexpectedly picked as Prime Minister last spring to replace the late Chou Enlai.

title: TV VIEW
description: On Saturday night at 8 o'clock ABC will be taking a cool look at professional footballand all football in this country is professional, from the Pee Wee Division of the Pop Warner little league to Mean Joe Greeneso this is probably an occasion for yet another 1,000word psychogram on the swamp fevers of fandom; the brutalization of play; the stylizing of aggression; the estheticizing of ligament tears; the ontological significance of Howard Cosell; the fabricating of myth and the ritual reenactment of primal passions said to be associated with the encounter of Ram and Bear, Eagle and Lion, Cowboy and Redskin, Viking and Saint, Dolphin and Jet, Oiler and Steeler, Giant and Brown; or the surly ennui of the crowd at Elaine's now that New York teams smell up the amphitheaters built for them by taxpayers who worship a god who wears cleats on the soles of his pantyhose. In other words, here is an opportunity to be the first on one's block to write an article deploring whatever it is one no longer cares about.

title: What's Wrong at the Trade Commission?
description: WASHINGTONWhat has slx heads, costs the taxpayer $11 million dollars and isn't doing its job?

title: Westchester Architecture Being Recorded in Photos
description: Westchester County's architectural heritage from the late 17th century to the present is being recorded this summer, building by building, by the Westchester Landmarks Project to commemorate the Bicentennial.

title: SLAYINGS PLAGUE ARGENTINE JUNTA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug.21 The mass murder of suspected guerrillas by rightwing terrorists in Argentina has produced a wave of revulsion that puts pressure on the military regime to impose effective control over all armed groups.

title: McNairs Win at Net
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 (UPI)  Thirdseeded Fred and Bruce McNair of Chevy Chase, Md., upset topranked Stephen and Dek Potts of Washington, 76, 61, in a hardfought semifinal match today at the national fatherson claycourt tennis championships. The McNairs advanced to the final tomorrow afternoon against secondseeded Eldon and Brad Rowe of San Diego, who ousted Oscar and Jim Harper of Altadena, Calif., 64, 64.

title: A Correction
description: Because of a production error, the two stars symbolizing the rating of Deno's in Port Jefferson were omitted from this column last week.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Dolores

title: Nassau Policeman Is Wounded While Questioning 2 Suspects
description: A Nassau County police officer was shot in the stomach and critically wounded yesterday morning, apparently with his own gun, as he attempted to question two men outside warehouse in New Hyde Park.

title: Still August
description: It always seems to catch us by surprise, that day when we know that summer is not endless, that autumn is just over the hill or up the valley. It follows a night of unexpected coolness, and we hear the katydids scratching at the dark. First katydids, and they miss a few notes; but they persist, and the old saying echoes once more in our memory: Six weeks from first katydid to first frost.

title: Japanese Now Are Noticing Their Scandals
description: TOKYOIt is as stylized a performance as any Kabuki or Noh play ever was. Daily, the television cameras carefully chronicle in color the comings and goings of the Political bosses of Japan's ruling LiberalDemocratic Party.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Aug. 1 issue of this column the author, Richard Busch, was incorrectly identified. He is features editor of Popular Photography magazine.

title: LAKES MAY CLOSE FOR WINTER AGAIN
Dody Phinny Bride of Lathrop Gates
description: Dody Scott Phinny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Phinny of Fremont, Mich., was married yesterday afternoon to Lathrop Mead Gates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton H. Gates of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Edwin M. Ward, headmaster of the Salisbury (Conn.) School, performed, the ceremony in the Lindsey Chapel of the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: State Luring Foreign Capital
description: TRENTON THE number of foreignowned companies operating in New Jersey has increased dramatically in the last 10 years, making this the leading state in the nation in terms of investments from abroad, according to Joseph A. Hoffman, Commissioner of the Department of Labor and Industry.

title: English Team Wins Golf by Two Holes
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Aug. 21 (AP)England won the Double Diamond matchplay team gulf championship today, beating Gary Player's Rest of the World team by two holes.

title: Future Is Bright for the Folly Theater in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Folly Theater, which has gone through about as many tense moments as the characters in an Agatha Christie thriller since it opened in 1900, appears to have been saved.

title: When the Family Moves, The Garden Can, Too
description: When we moved last year from Montclair, N.J., to a village southwest of Buffalo, I faced a harsh truth: You can't take a garden with you. Nor would It have been ethical to remove most plantings from a property we'd sold.

title: 5 in Kansas Family Drown As a Motorboat Capsizes
description: GIRARD, Kan., Aug. 21 (UPI) An 18footlong outboard motorboat capsized today on Lake Farlington north of this southeastern Kansas town, downing five members of one family and injuring five other persons. The victims were identified as Ora C. Large, 65 years old; his wife, Hazel, 58; Annette Large, 7; Sherry Wirt, 7, a stepdaughter, and Ronald W. Large, 10, all of Pittsburgh.

title: LEVITT SAYS CITY LOSES TAX SUMS
A Famous Festival Flirts With Greener Pastures
description: The American Dance Festival, based at Connecticut College since 1948, has kept New England's sleepy towns alert this summer.

title: Hard Times Linger for the. Island's Building Industry
description: IN 1973, the five largest industrial construction companies on the IslandReckson Associates, Marcus Associates, Krinsky Enterprises, Nicholas Racanelli Associates and VIP Industrial Parkobtained permits to build about 3.5 million square feet of industrial space. In 1974 the same group got permits for about 2.5 million square feet.

title: Notes: Free Vacations For High Rollers
description: Free air transportation plus free hotel rooms and meals in vacation resorts are available to gamblersprovided they have plenty of money to wager. Casinos in the Caribbean, Las Vegas and Monte Carlo will pick up the gamblers tabs because it pays them to entertain high rollers who are prepared to lose at the tables. If the gambler gets lucky, he flies home with his winnings, and no bills.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED ON TICK INFECTION
description: The New York City Health Department alerted the public yesterday to be on guard against two unusual and possibly fatal infections transmitted by ticks. It said several cases of the infections had recently occurred on Long Island.

title: Krishna Captures Title for Jumpers
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 21 Julie Miller Bodek's Krishna turned in a strong performance today to win the amateurowner jumper championship at the Fairfield County horse show.

title: Road America Will Conduct Handicap Race Next Sunday
South African Blacks Denounce Regime
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 21 The leaders of South Africa's tribal homelands, representing nearly half the country's 18 million blacks, said today that the reaction of Prime Minister John Vorster's Government to the unrest in black townships showed that the only language they were prepared to listen to was violence.

title: Lisa Rutstein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Rutstein of Harrington Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Beth Rutstein, to Jack Langer. son of Mr. and Mrs. Moritz Langer of Fort Lee, N.J. A December wedding is planned.

title: The World
description: The level of protest by South Africa's black majority continues to rise. Last week three developments appear to have changed qualitatively the nature of the current confrontation:

title: HARTFORD GIRL CUTS ARMS BEFORE CROWD
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 21 (UPI)A girl slashed her wrists and forearms and then rushed to the steps of Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church holding a razor to her throat last night as a jeering crowd of 300 applauded and threw bottles at her.

title: ExWife Says Dole Is a Perfectionist
description: SYLVAN GROVE, Kan., Aug. 21Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican nominee for Vice President, is described by his former wife of 23 years, Mrs. Lon Buzick, as a man of Reaganstyle political ideology and Carterstyle work habits.

description: On Wall Street, of course, campaign promises are simply more grist to the stock market mill. And the Argus Research Corporation, for one, not only refuses to believe but also finds In disbelief a reason to be bullish:

title: Field Complete
description: Despite the long and intense struggle between the contenders for its Presidential nomination, the Republican National Convention has managed to restore a semblance of unity to the party in the process of selecting nominee.

title: Miss Muhlfeld, Sculptor, Bride Of Peter Bell
description: The marriage of Katherine Amoret Muhlfeld to Peter Buchanan Bell of Washington took place yesterday in Englewood, N. J., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bearss Muhlfeld, parents of the bride.

title: Rice Paper: The Appeal Grows
description: The first thing that might be said about shopping bags, or carryalls, or totes, or callthemwhatyouwill, is that there are enough of them around. It's hard to walk two feet without being sideswiped by a superstatus Vuitton, Gucci or Mark Cross, or by a runofthemill canvas or straw, or even, if one isn't careful, by the plain paper bags handed out like confetti by stores and political candidates.

title: And Commerce Department Help
description: Of all the departments in Washington, one of the most overldoked and underemphasized is the Department of Commerce. In part this is because business is often on the defensive. As a result, a job in the Department of Commerce is not regarded as a prestigious assignment by either the assignors or the assignees.

title: Tom Mix's StandIn Looks Back
description: ELMWOOD PARK THE ancient train rattles through a mountain pass. Along the roof of one of its wooden cars runs the dauntless hero of cowboy movies, Tom Mix, with his pistol swinging in one hand, his 10gallon hat set firmly on his head. And then he leaps, almost effortlessly, from one car to another, pursuing a fleeing gang of robbers.

title: Owners Should Avoid Obesity in Pets
description: After many years of practicing veterinary medicine, said Dr. William Kay, chief of staff of the Animal Medical Center in New York, I've observed that very oftenoverweight pets are owned by overweight people.

title: PEOPLE
description: The new medical director for the Abraham & Straus string of 10 department stores is Dr. Walter J. Wiechetek of Bayonne. A recent graduate of the John Hopkins School of Public Health and Hygiene in Baltimore, Dr. Wick, as he is known, is 31 years old and the youngest medical. director in A.&S.'s centurylong history. He'll design healthcare systems for employees of the chain's stares, including those in Paramus. Woodbridge and the one under construction at Eatontown. Dr. Wick also hopes to squeeze in some research work at the Ruteers Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: Bengals' Air Attack Is Threat to Vikings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 21 (AP)The Minnesota Vikings hope to shake off a sluggish preseason start tomorrow in their first home game of the year against an explosive, unbeaten Cincinnati team with a streamlined look.

title: Eugenie Latchis Bride of Film Producer
description: The marriage of Eugenie Latchis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Latchis of Dublin, N.H., to Robert Hellyer Silverthorne of Washington, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Henry L. Silverthorne of New Haven, took place yesterday afternoon in Dublin. The Rev. Owen Thomas performed the ceremony in the Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.Among the delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention here this last week were:

title: Many in Soviet Take Up Knitting for Profit to Supply People in Arctic, but Regime Does Not Like It
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 21It was not the clack of knitting needles but the ensuing rustle of ruble banknotes that disturbed the Soviet authorities. A craze for knitting has swept the foothills of the Northern Caucasus, motivated less by pride of craftsmanship than by hunger, for profits.

title: B'NAI B'RITH LEADER ACCUSES A RUSSIAN
description: The head of the 500,000 member B'nai B'rith has sharply criticized a prominent Soviet lecturer and writer as promoting uninhibited antiSemitism in his Governmentsponsored activities.

title: 4th HELD IN KILLING OF A TAVERN OWNER
description: A fourth suspect was arrested last night in connection with the kidnapping and murder of Filberto M. Orfilia, a Queens tavern owner whose body was found last Thursday in Gowanus Bay in Brooklyn.

title: Bonn Air Checks Pay Off
description: BONN, Aug. 21 (Reuters) Policemen at West German airports found 241 guns and more than 5,000 other weapons during routine checks of passengers luggage during the first Six months of this year, the Interior Ministry reported.

title: Fight for Water in West Grows
description: DENVER, Aug. 21The battle over water in the semiarid West, a battle that began when white men first started permanent settlements here, is fast reaching a critical stage that will determine the future of the dry sections of the region.

title: Enlisting Artists As Designers For the Theater
Burton and a British Model Are Wed by Arlington Judge
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 21 (AP)Richard Burton and Susan Hunt, a British model, were married here this afternoon.

title: The Gift of Inner Healing
description: A year ago, at one of Ruth Carter Stapleton's evangelistic meetings, not many in the audience would have known she was Jimmy Carter's sister. Now everybody knows that it was Mrs. Stapleton who opened her brother's eyes to his need for rebirth.

title: ExTokyo Transport Chief Arrested in Lockheed Case
Rockefeller Subdued and Forlorn as Convention Drew to Close
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 21Vice President Rockefeller was as forlorn a figure as a multimillionaire Vice President can be amidst the New York delegation in the closing hours of the Republican National Convention. The usually ebullient and animated Mr. Rockefeller was a somber island in a sea of high spirits as President Ford and his running mate, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, made their acceptance speeches.

title: Kahn Plays Shakespeare Straight
description: Over the past ten years, Shakespearegoing audiences in England and America have grown accustomed to seeing productions that have offered less and less of Shakespeare, and more and more of directors ideas of what Shakespeare is about. In the 1960s, Peter Brook's spectacular, acrobatic A Midsummer Night's Dream, Clifford Williams allmale staging of As You Like It for Britain's National Theater and Joseph Papp's counterculture carnivals at the New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park all set the pace for Shakespearean outings in which the director, rather than the bard, had a field day.

title: THE CHIEF AWARDS
description: Maclay TrophyTori Dent, Westport, Conn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: President Ford yesterday declared four counties in New Jersey as disaster areas as a result of storms and flooding caused this month by Hurricane Belle. The storms and flooding caused extensive public and private property damage.

title: Mary Breglio Has Nuptials
description: Mary Lou Breglio, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Breglio of Wantagh, L. I., was married yesterday morning to Andrew Covert Coronios, son of Ruth C. Ruby of Shaf lsbury, Vt., and the late Dr. James D. Coronios.

title: Abduction Acquittal Denied
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 21 (AP)  Federal District Judge William C. O'Kelley refused yesterday a defense motion for a directed acquittal for William A. H. Williams, who is being retried for the 1974 abduction of Reg Murphy, a newspaper executive. Mr. Williams is accused of extorting $700,000 from the Atlanta Constitution after Mr. Murphy's abduction.

title: East Orange Effort Is Set In PoliceCar Bomb Inquiry
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 21, (UPI)Mayor William S. Hart of East Orange has ordered police official to set up a special detective team to join Federal and state lawenforcement officers in their inquiry into the firebombing of a police patrol car here.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 0.5 percent in July matching the June increase, the Labor Department said, bringing the Consumer Price Index to 171.1 percent of the 1967 average. Gasoline, used cars, medical care and transportation costs pushed July prices up, though meat prices were lower. . . Corporation profits in the second quarter rose by $1.4 billion or 1.8 percent to an annual rate of $81.1 billion, the Commerce Department said. It said also gross national product rose an annual rate of 4.3 percent instead of 4.4 percent estimated last month, compared with a growth rate of 9.1 percent in the first quarter. Inflation in the second quarter was at a rate of 5.1 percent instead of 4.7 percent originally estimated.

title: The Republicans Drew Larger TV Audience
description: Ten million more people watched the Republican National Convention in Kansas City. Mo., last week than watched the Democratic National Convention in New York in July, according to NBC television estimates based on Nielsen ratings released yesterday.

title: He Brings It Back Alive On TapeFrom Exotic Lands
description: The chanting of 40 Tibetan monks is a cavernous, impenetrable drone, a wall of sound. Using a secret, difficult technique termed onevoice chording, each monk produces three notes simultaneously to form a chord. The resultant tantric ritual chant is primal and awesome, sounding at first like a swarm of angry bees and then like a landing approach to the Ultimate Note. Occasionally the rigorous, centuriesold text of the chant is interrupted by martial blasts of huge trumpets and a tintinnabulation of bells and gongs. The effect of the chant on the listener is a feeling of centering and serenity, and a connection with an endangered species of religious mystery. The soothing, hypnotic power of the chant reminds the listener that in folk culture the musician is magician, and viceversa.

title: 2 Updated Publications Offering List of Agencies That Aid Public
description: Agencies that assist people with financial, health and housing problems are listed in uptodate versions of two community service publications being distributed by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York. Both pamphlets are free.

title: Jimmy Walker's City Hall
description: In the summer of 1926the first year of Jimmy Walker's administrationI was an 18yearold reporter coming over from Brooklyn by trolley to cover City Hall, and the jewel box designed by McComb and Mangin in 1803 was one of the loveliest buildings I had ever seen. In the 50 years since, the building has changed little, but the atmosphere has changed a lot. These days City Hall is filled with men with long faces who work long hours meeting unending crises. It was not always thus. As an eyewitness, I can testify that half a century ago the city may have had problems, but they hadn't yet fought their way into the seat of city government.

title: MUSIC LETTER
description: Elton John

title: Ford's General for the Economic Front
description: WASHINGTON  Now that Gerald R. Ford has won his party's nomination, the battle for the Presidency has finally been joined. The major battlefield seems destined to be the economy and specifically the record of Alan Greenspan, the Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. As the lines are drawn, three possible ways of looking at the matter emerge.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Medical researchers at Rockefeller University have developed a new blood test that is expected to improve the treatment of diabetics.

title: Part Way in Namibia
description: A multiracial conference representing eleven tribal or ethnic groups in Namibia (SouthWest Africa) has announced plans for bringing that territory to independence from South Africa. Ten years ago, these proposals would Nage been hailed even by black African governments as a breakthrough. The plans call for dismantling apartheid, pulling Namibia together as a unitary state with safeguards for minorities and setting up a multiracial central Government that would aim at independence by the end of 1978.

title: GARDENING
description: ANYONE who has driven through Pennsylvania on Interstate 80 can only have been impressed by the green carpet of plants clinging to the rocky hillsides and road cuts in the mountainous areas. This carpet is further enhanced in midsummer by a sprinkling of flowers in shades of white, pink and lavender. The carpet is a ground cover, crown vetch.

title: A mystery and a romance
description: There is a special debt we owe them, a debt to Chandler, Hammett and Cain. They excised pointless ornamentation, moved their stories forward with a spare, ruthless vigor and so superimposed the realities we already knew with characterizations we could believe, that they achieved a dreadful, and artistic, inevitability.

title: Round 2 in the OffshoreOil Bout
description: IN a Manhattan hotel last Tuesday, a battle played out against a background of ecological concern and economic planning moved a step closer to its climax.

title: Historians Voting on an Inquiry Into Yale's Barring of Aptheker
description: The Organization of American Historians began last week a poll of its 12,000 members on whether to investigate the Yale University history department. At issue is the charge that the department may have damaged the reputation of a member of the profession in opposing the appointment last year of Dr. Herbert Aptheker as a visiting lecturer at a seminar at Davenport College, a part of Yale University. Dr. Aptheker is a wellknown Communist.

title: 3 Are Dropped On Finnish Sextet
description: HELSINKI, Aug. 21 (AP) The coach of Finland's national hockey team dismissed three men today, including Lasse Mononen, a professional, from the squad that will play in next month's Canada Cup international tournament.

title: Sheilah Tilbrooke Is Married to James H. Cloud
description: Sheilah Margaret Tilbrooke and James Henry Cloud were married yesterday in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Edward J. Howley performed the ceremony, and the bride's cousin the Rev. Stanley W. Hosie assisted.

title: Guest Observer
description: Today is my 49th birthday, and these few paragraphs are meant for all those planning committees around the country which are already at work trying to come up with something nice for me on the occasion of next year's semicentennial.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Sloan's Supermarkets has signed a 25 year lease for a 12,500 squarefoot store on Roosevelt Island at an aggregate rent of more than $1 million.

ART VIEW
description: Victorian India In Focus

title: Linda Goddard Married
description: Linda Alden Goddard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Goddard Jr. of Duxbury, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to William Edward Brown, son of Col. George A. Brown of the New Jersey National Guard and Mrs. Brown of Sea Girt, N.J. The Rev. Stephen W. Turrell performed the ceremony in the Pilgrim Congregational Church in Duxbury. The Rev. William Gaudet, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted.

title: Mrs. Grasso Names Black As Superior Court Judge
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 21 (UPI)Gov. Ella T. Grasso yesterday appointed the first black Superfor Court judge in the history of Connecticut.

title: Locklear Is a Yankee With an Unusual Past and Future
description: Gene Locklear is (A) the only major league baseball player who is a fullblooded Indian, (B) the only major League baseball player who has done a painting for the White House, (C) the only major league baseball player whose first time at bat for the Yankees resulted in a $1,000 fine for the team, (D) none of the above, (E) all of the above.

title: Plains Language From Truthful James
description: PLAINS, Ga.Jimmy Carter is a shrewd politician and honest enough candidate to acknowledge that foreign policy is likely to be a relatively lesser issue in his campaign to replace Gerald Ford because the lines aren't clearly drawn there and as a result domestic factors are bbund to be more important.

title: Rally in Park Shows Ways To Cut Rape
Janet McN. Hester Is Married To Campbell Thornton Gerrish
description: In the Princeton University Chapel yesterday, Janet McNaughton Hester was married to Campbell Thornton Gerrish in a Protestant ceremony performed by Dean Ernest Gordon. The bride is a daughter of Dr. James McNaughton Hester, rector of the United Nations University in Tokyo and former president of New York University, and Mrs. Hester of Tokyo, Princeton and New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Gerrish of Rye, N.Y.

title: England's Wild White Cattle
description: Ah, the peaceful lowing of a herd of English cattle. You pause in your evening stroll down the lanes of eastern Northumberland and gaze over the hedge at the meadows which curve, sweet and green, around Chilllrigham Castle. There, just where the setting sun has made the grass glow like hot emeralds, is a herd of about 60 head. They chew the cud lazily, swinging their tails in approved bovine fashion.
