Then you notice something strange. Can they beyou peer more closelysurely they're not . . . white?

title: Connecticut Wins Regional Baseball
description: NUTLEY, N.J., Aug. 21 (AP) Darryl Oaks hit a homer over the centerfield fence in an extra inning today to give Forestville, Conn., the championship of the Eastern Regionals Little League baseball tournament with a 21 victory over Staten Island, N.Y.

title: U. S. World Cup Team Starts Colorado Training Tuesday
description: The United States World Cup team, which hopes to bring prominence to this country in the world of soccer, will start training Tuesday in Colorado Springsfor its games against Canada and Mexico starting late next month. Walt Chyzowych, the coach, has invited 24 players, all American citizens, and plans to invite a handful more at the conclusion of the North American Soccer League playoffs. Chyzowych said that part of the preparation would include a tour for a series of matches in Ecuador, Peru and Colombia.

title: N.Y. Yacht Club Drops Anchor in Maine
description: CHRISTMAS, COVE, Me., Aug., 21Scott Lindbloom's aunt who lives down the point phoned him in the morning, to tell Scott, age 13. that about 25 boats, big ones, were in sight and heading for Christmas Cove. Scott jumped into his outboard to check out his aunt's hallucination end found she was more than right. By late afternoon, not 25 yachts but 50 had crowded into this beautiful cove, a typical Maine gem two fjords east of Booth Bay Harbor.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Research and Development Put at $38.1 Billion in'76
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) Spending for research and development in the United States is expected to reach $38.1 billion in 1976, an 8 percent increase over last year, according to the National Science Foundation.

title: 40 Hopatcong Families Lack Water Despite New Supply
description: HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 21 (UPI)Two Hopatcong water companies have been linked, but about 40 families in the community still do not have water. The linkup between the West Shore Water Company and Lake Hopatcong Water Company, made yesterday, was ordered in an effort to end the Sussex County community's water crisis, which began this summer.

title: Efforts Being Spawned to Insure Survival of Atlantic Salmon in Canada
description: BAIETRINITE, QuebecLike a timorous mother, Canada is gingerly holding hands with the fascinating but potentially explosive problem of how to deal with the Atlantic salmon.

title: Bodies of 2 Americans Are Flown to California
description: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 21 (UPI)The bodies of the two United States Army officers killed in the demilitarized zone in Korea arrived here today.

title: Yacht Racing Canceled
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Marriage Set By Miss Farah
description: Jeannette Farah, daughter of Mrs. Antoine Farah of Amman, Jordan, formerly of Beirut, Lebanon, and the late Mr. Farah, and Charles Jackson Bird, a candidate for a master's degree from the American University in Beirut, plan to be married Sept. 18. The ceremony is scheduled for St. John's Episcopal Church in Essex, Conn., where the future bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Bird, live.

title: STORMIN' NORMAN, SUZY IN WRY BOOGIE
description: New York has not seen anything quite like Stormin Norman and Suzy, who are appearing through next weekend at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street. Stormin Norman, whose real name is Norman Zamcheck, inlays a spare, jabbing style of boogie piano and writes wryly distinctive songs which seem to exist in the present, the 1920's and several other time frames at once.

title: The Strike Is Settled, but Money Problems Remain Very Real
description: In New York City's huge network of hospitals, public and private alike, the color of red no longer suggests blood. Red is the color of ink.

title: Home Style
description: A screwdriver is inexpensive. But an electric saw is not, and may be needed only once or twice in a house's lifetime.

title: British Group to Investigate Assassination of Trotsky
description: LONDON, Aug, 21 (Reuters) Britain's Trotslcyists are setting up an investigation into the assassination 36 years ago of Leon Trotsky.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: With two engines our plane will take off like a jackrabbit, says a Boeing official. Their four  engine model acts more like a lead duck.

title: George Fowler Dead at 55; Official of Hurok Concerts
54 CeaseFires Have Not Stopped the Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon A statement made recently by Pierre Gemayel, the leader of the Phalange Party, Lebanon's largest Christian politicomilitary organization, seriously raised the question of partitioning the country between the Moslems and Christians, after 16 months of civil war.

title: Land Law a Challenge
description: OFFICIALS of communities across the state are working feverishly to determine what changes they will have to make to conform to the new Municipal Land Use Law that went into effect Aug. 1.

title: On The Middle of the Journey
description: In a culture devoted to systematic forgetting, it is remarkable that any book should last beyond the few months bookstores can keep it on their shelves. Yet, as either a quixotic. act or a sign that the book has kept its bold on at least some memories, two publishers have, recently reprinted Lionel Trilling's The Middle of the Journey almost 30 years after its first appearance. (It is available in a cloth edition from Scribner's for $8.95 and in a paperback edition from Avon for $3.95.)

title: Fuming Over the Flicks
description: DISSATISFIED with the long runs, limited selections and high prices at the two movie theaters in town, a number of Princeton residents have banded together to form the Princeton Moviezoers Protest.

title: Keystone Ore Sets Cane Pace Mark
description: YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 21In the fastest trip ever registered by a 3yearold pacer at Yonkers Raceway, Keystone Ore captured the $200,000 Cane Pace tonight before the meeting's largest crowd, 24,458. Keystone Ore was clocked in 1:57 1/5 for the mile.

title: Nordic Ministers Support Aid to African Nationalists
description: COPENHAGEN, Aug. 21 (Reuters)The foreign ministers of Norway, Sweden, Finland, Iceland and Denmark have ended a twoday meeting here with a strong condemnation of South Africa and a calla for international support for black nationalist guerrillas in Rhodesia.

title: Victoria Etzler Married to James Ross
description: The Altamont Inn in Millbrook. N. Y.. was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Victoria Faith Etzler. daughter of Kay Etzler of Pleasantville, N. Y., and the late C. David Etzler, to James M. Ross, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman C. Ross of AnnandaleonHudson, N. Y.

title: GiantSteeler Scoring
description: Attendance, 50,199.

title: Miki Meets With Chief Critic in Tokyo, But Is Unsuccessful in Party Unity Bid
description: TOKYO, Aug. 21  Prime Minister Takeo Miki conferred again today with his chief political critic and challenger, Takeo Fukuda, in an unsuccessful effort to patch up the political split that widened this week, within Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

title: Bangkok Students Riot Over Return Of ExStrongman
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 21 Rioting broke out in downtown Bangkok today between rival groups of students as the controversy over the sudden return a week ago of a former Thai military strongman continued to deepen.

title: Miss Hollerith, Nathan Laffoon Wed in Michigan
description: Catharine Louise Hollerith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hollerith Jr. of New York and Harbor Springs, Mich., was married in Harbor Springs yesterday afternoon to Nathan Powell Laffoon, son of Polk Laffoon 3d and of Emily Allen Laffoon, both of Cincinnati.

title: The Mall In the City: No More Sure Bets
CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, the at a glance box in last week's issue concerning J. P. Stevens & Company referred to two quarters ended in May 1976. The quarter ended May 3 should have been placed in the year 1975.

title: HOUSING INSURER SUED IN BIAS CASE
description: The National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing has joined the owners of 10 New York City apartment buildings in a $3 million damage suit charging an insurance company with racial discrimination.

title: INVESTING
description: Don't sell on strike news is a Wall Street admonition that investors apparently took to heart in the case of the nation's tire makers.

title: The Four Faces of Jan Buttram
Monsoon Rains in India Kill 30; Threaten Capita
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 21 (Reuters)  About 30 people died in monsoon floods in Uttar Pat desh state in the last 48 hour as overflowing rivers and cant devastated parts of northern and central India.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayGreat Barrington K.C. allbreed and obedience, Butternut Basin, Route 23, Great Barrington, Mass.; 1,301 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: FiveDay Nassu Show to Attract Leading Riders. in the. East
description: The Nassau County event, one of the dwindling number of Class A. horse shows in the metropolitan area, will be held Wednesday through Sunday at, the C. W. Post College show grounds in Greenvale, L. I. Virtually every leading ,jumper and hunter in the East will be present for the five days of competition, culminated by the, $10,000 added Nassau County Grand Prix at 2 P.M. on Sunday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Aug. 21 (AP)David Pearson, the winner of six of eight races at Michigan International Speedway since 1972, will start on the pole position in tomorrow's Champion 400 Grand National stock car, race by virtue of a sizzling recordbreaking qualifying run. Pearson zoomed around the highbanked twomile oval today in his white and red Wood Brothers prepared Mercury at an average speed of 160.875 miles an hour, almost three m.p.h. faster than the record he set in 1974.

title: Two Elementary Views On Working With Nature
What They Are Saying
description: Larry Bowa, Phillies shortstop, tells the technician before Xrays are taken on an injured ankle: I'm 0 for 3 in this room [three previous fractures] and I better leave here 1 for 4 or I'll break the machine. The Xrays were negative.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In the complicated web that is THE HAMLET WARNING by Leonard Sanders (Scribner's, $7.95), a terrorist group gets possession of an atom bomb. But that is not the terrorist group that occupies a major part of the book. Sanders, going to the immediate future, postulates a dictator in the Dominican Republic and. a Marxistoriented countergroup ready to start its revolution. A shadowy group in Europe, taking aavantage of the situation, plants a bomb in the unhappy country. This bomb will be followed by one planted in an American city if the United States Government does not meet certain demands.

title: American Motors Has an Egg but Boxes Are in Style
description: DETROITThere may be nothing wrong with American Motors that an oldfashioned riproaring industry slump couldn't cure.

title: U.S. Embassy in Saigon Declared a Monument
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)The former United States Embassy in Saigon and the old Presidential Palace have been classified as historical monuments by the Ministry of Culture here.

title: DR. S. S. WANDERMAN
description: Dr. Seymour S. Wanderman of 12 West 72d Street, a physician in New York for more than 50 years, died yesterday morning in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 81, years old.

title: Carol A. Gosling Bride of Lawyer
The Nation
description: Democratic Representative Otto E. Passman of Louisiana, a pillar of conservativism in Congress for 30 years, has been unexpectedly defeated in a primary election by a political newcomer. Mr, Passman's age, 76, and recent allegations that he misused his political influence are thought to have contributed to his defeat.

title: Rediscovering Queens in Its Time Of Quiet Racial Transformation
High Rating Is Given to Doctors, Engineers and Teachers in a Poll
WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Jimmy Carter and his advisers have been supplying important new evidence in recent days on the crucial question of what would be likely to happen to Government spending in a Carter Administration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Vacation Communes

title: Will success spoil The Bird?
description: Mark Fidrych is a looselimbed, openmouthed, wideeyed youth with a rheumy look, a rockstar hairdo and the body kinetics of a nervous bird. At the age of 22, he has flitted happily and eagerly into the world of baseball  without seeming to know where he is  and is causing a mild sensation. This is occurring even though the world of baseball, more preoccupied with the players threats of anarchy and their solemn money madness, is not quite sure of what to make of him. He's flakier'n hell, says one of his teammates on the Detroit Tigers. He's either the most refreshing thing to come into sports in 20 years or the biggest con man in 50 years, says another Fidrych watcher and a third, a Washington newspaperman, asserts that, given the history of the game, it followed that, in time, we would wind up with the clinically insane pitcher.

title: Abduction for Money Denied
description: KEY WEST. Fla., Aug, 21 (AP)William A. H. Williams. charged with extortion in the 1974 abduction of Reg Murphy, a newspaper editor testified today that he had only wanted Mr. Murphy to recd an antiSemitic leafet and publish purported Federal Bureau of Invesligation files an members of Congress. Mr. Williams. accused of extorting $700.000 from the Atlanta Constitution after .Mr. Murphy's abduction, testified that the idea of a ransom was Mr. Murphy's.

title: Food
description: A Chinese picnic? Why not. Traditional Chinese dishes can easily be served chilled rather than hot. The ones on this page have been selected to provide a combination of flavors. The beef is simmered in a sauce typical of Shanghai and is served like a sandwich in a simplified version of a Chinese steamed bun. Then comes fried chickenChinese style, of course followed by a cold broccoli salad and a spicy greenbean dish from Szechwan. Chilled white wine and fresh fruit complete a lovely endofsummer feast.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: TrafficSafety Training For Families Is Urged

title: Campaign Gets Off to an Early Start In WeickerSchaffer Race for Senate
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 21For most political candidates, Labor Day is when campaigns traditionally start, but not for Lowell P. Weicker and Gloria Schaffer.

title: Anne Baudino Becomes Bride
description: Anne Denise Baudino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Baudino of Bethesda, Md., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married in Bethesda yesterday afternoon to David Ketcham Holton. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Holton of Essex Falls, N.J.

title: Lazar Dinsky, Yiddish Poet And Labor Organizer, at 85
description: Lazar Dinsky, a Yiddish poet who had been active in organizing fur workers here, died Friday in the Long Island Jewish Institute for Geriatric Care, New Hyde Park, L. I., after a long illness. He lived at 16347 130th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, and was 85 years old.

title: Miss Murphy, B.I. MacKinnon Wed in Suburb
description: Elizabeth Lee Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Murphy of Bronxville, N.Y., and Stratton, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce Ian MacKinnon. who does biochemical research for W. R. Grace & Company in Columbia, Md.

title: Manager of Reagan Campaign Wins Respect by Performance
Making Ice While the Parties Last
EXCONVICT RIGHT TO BALLOT SOUGHT
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Aug. 21The 30yearold Attorney Generalelect of Arkansas hopes to make the state the first in the country to restore the right to vote to all convicted felons who have completed prison or probation sentences.

title: . . . South African Retreat
description: South Africa's white rulers have reacted in contradictory ways to the black protests and riots that have claimed more than 250 lives in two months. They have promised a new deal for blacks living in the segregated townships near the major citiesmodest reforms aimed at meeting longstanding grievances. But they have at the same time arrested many of the leaders with whom they will have to discuss any reforms.

title: National Affairs
description: DETROIT, Aug. 21 (UPI)Scores of specially trained policemen prowled the streets again today to enforce a tough city curfew that apparently was succeeding in curtailing the city's recent youth gang rampages.

title: A Buoyant Ford Relaxes at Resort
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 21Buoyed by his nomination victory, President Ford took time out today from his tiring political schedule to start a relaxing weekend at this resort in the Rockies.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Fisher Hall and its immediate vicinity look like a disaster area. Outside where the entrance used to be is a collage of wooden and steel scaffolding, sheets of plywood, mounds of broken cement, piles of sand, stacks of cinderblock, trucks and workmen. That's outside. Inside . . . well.

title: The Promise Of the Coming Dark Age
description: We are currently in the midst of a slight epidemic of guide books to the future, from the elegant diagnostics of J. K. Galbraith to the abstract traceries of Robert Nozick. L. S. Stavrianos, emeritus professor of history at Northwestern, adjunct professor at San Diego, has now added his say. Of all the prognostications and prescriptions published in the last year or two, only Stavrianos's, in my opinion, is worth the paper it is printed on. He has crammed into a mere 211 pages a wealth of facts, ideas and wisdom. His book, like all human products, has its flaws, but these should not be allowed to obscure the importance of its message.

title: Softball Weathers Storm of Infancy
description: On May 28, professional softball for women made its debut amid hopesand fears for its survival in a sports world clouded by recent financial failures. Now the 120game regular season is drawing to a close. The 10 team league of the International Women's Professional Softball Association has encountered added problemsbattling bad weather in the East, for examplebut fears are being overshadowed by plans for an enlarged league next season.

title: Carter Seeks to Establish Close Ties With Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Jimmy Carter, more than any Presidential candidate in recent years, is courting the allegiance of Congress before the November elections by going to unusual lengths in aiding Democrats seeking election to Congress. At the same time, he is discreetly soliciting the cooperation of key committee chairmen and party leaders on Capitol Hill.

title: STATE TUITION AID FINAllY GOING OUT
description: ALBANY, Aug. 21 (AP)State officials say they have cleared up the computer snarls that had delayed for weeks the delivery of scholarships and financial aid to thousands of anxious college students.

title: 200 Stage Protest At Gracie Mansion Over Cat Research
description: More than 200 demonstrators picketed in front of the American Museum of Natural History and then marched across Central Park to Gracie Mansion to continue their protest against the use of live cats in sex experiments at the museum.

title: DANCE VIEW; Are We Looking To the Future?
description: The other day there was a celebration in London commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Ballet. Rambert. The anniversary also celebrated a ballet, the very first ballet, by Frederick Ashton called The Tragedy of Fashion. It took place at the Lyric Theater, Hammersmith. It was part of a revue called Riverside Nights, and it was not only the beginning of Ashton's career, Dame Marie Rambert's company (and that woman is still as lively as a cricket and as smart as a poet at the cheerfully active age of 88), but also the beginning of a movenient I wrote about a few Sundays ago. It was the move away from the international companies to the national companies.

title: A Drive for Black Voters Is Starting in 13 States
Arabesque
description: Intelligent, well  wrought, written with a genteel sensibility that filters what is essentially highlycharged romantic Sturm and Drang through a veil of English reserve, this is one of those novels which you pick at random from the shelf of a beach house and find yourself reading straight through on an overcast summer day.

title: The Region
description: Further litigation notwithstanding, drilling for oil off the East Coast of the United States now seems all but a certainty. After months of delay, the first leases were sold last week for drilling off the Atlantic. Still further delay, however, is possible  even likely.

title: Now the Candidates Must Go In Search of the Electoral Votes
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.Whatever else he did with his selection of Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, President Ford said a good deal about the sort of campaign he intends to conduct this fall. Republican professionals had been saying all week that the choice would be full of signals, and it was.

title: Therese Thaler Wed To Richard E. Lynch
description: In the Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday morning, Therese Marie Thaler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Thaler of IrvingtononHudson, N.Y., became the bride of Richard Enwright. Lynch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Lynch of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Normand J. Godin performed the ceremony.

title: A FOSTER HOME FOR WED HORSES
description: DAMASCUS, Md., Aug. 21Millard Oland seems more the fatherly type than a farmer or rancher, but lately he has had to be a little of all three.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Federation Cup
description: Australia 3, Rumania 0 (Evonne Goolagong defeated Virginia Ruzlci, 62, 60; Kerry Melville Reid defeated Florenta Mihai, 63, 62; Mrs. Reid, Dianne Fromholtz defeated Miss Ruzici, Miss Mihal, 4.6, 6.2, 76). Sweden 3, Japan 0 (Ingrid Bentzer defeated Naoko Sato, 64, 7.5; Helene Anliot defeated Kioymi Nakagawa, 62, 62; Miss Anliot, Marie Wikstedt defeated Michiko Saii. Mutsuke Matshishima, 60. 60.

title: TV Spotlights the Magic of Piaf and Garland Tonight
description: They don't make them like that any more. Socrates was saying the same thing, more or less, about Aeschylus. If nothing else, the observation is taken as an unmistakable signal for creeping age. Yet, as indicated by two programs on Channel 13 this evening, the possibility of some truth being wedged in the complaint cannot be ruled out entirely. The separate and in many ways inimitable subjects for tonight are Edith Piaf and Judy Garland.

title: Vikings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 22 (AP)Fran Tarkenton threw a 32yard touchdown pass to Sammy White with 24 seconds left to give the Minnesota Vikings a 23 17 National Football League exhibition victory today over the previously unbeaten Cincinnati Bengals. The pass completed a 74yard drive in seven plays.

title: A Widow's Plight
description: The poignant plight of Sus McCready, a Danish immigrant whose husband was murdered while his application for permanent resident status for her was pending, threw light on bureaucratic problems that cause great pain to many people seeking to find a legal home in the United States.

title: Coast Abduction Victims Honored at Home
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., Aug. 22The 10 cheer leadermajorettes were resplendent in deepred mock Indian outfits. Both local bands played bouncy marching music.

title: Dance: An Ailey Finale
description: There are two Donald McKayles, one a successful Broadway choreographer who chooses to have a hit at selected intervals and the other a concert dance choreographer whose works are lovingly tended by others. Alvin Ailey has been such a custodian, and this weekend showed Mr. McKayle's Games. and Rainbow Round My Shoulder at the State Theater.

title: Commodities
description: After a hiatus of three and a half years, the Kansas City Board of Trade, a key wheat market, plans to resume trading in sorghum for future delivery on Sept. 1. At present there is no futures market for this grain.

title: Dutch Government Is Grappling With Report on Lockheed Bribes
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 22 (Reuers)A secret report into allegations that Prince Bernhard took bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has left the Dutch Government with the dilemma of how to deal with the findings without provoking Queen Juliana's abdication, according to informed sources here.

title: It Hit 94 No Record but No Comfort
description: The city was a cauldron yesterday as the 94degree temperature brushed a record set 60 years ago.

title: JetOiler Scoring
description: V.Y. nous. FIRST QUARTER

title: Stanford Bows in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP)The Moscow State University waterpolo team, the No. 2 squad in the Soviet Union, defeated Stanford University, 5.2, today in the Americans' first appearance in the U.S.S.R., The teams meet again tomorrow.

title: OPEC Officials Gather
description: VIENNA, Aug, 22 (UPI) Economic experts of the world's major oilexporting nations arrived in Vienna today to discuss oil prices that one official said must go up. The weeklong conference was scheduled to open tomorrow morning. A spokesman for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said the delegates would make preparations for a meeting of oil ministers Dec. 15 in Qatar to review price policy.

title: A Bittersweet Journey to Vietnam
description: PARISMy eleventh visit to Vietnam since October, 1945 turned out to be both a voyage of discovery and a return to the past.

title: Riddick Wins in Italy
description: AVEZZANO, Italy, Aug. 22 (UPI)Steve Riddick of the United States won the men's 100 meters today atthe third Avezzano international track and field meet.

title: Yvonne Drouillard Wed to Floyd Braun
description: Yvonne Marie Drouillard and Floyd Clifford Braun, graduates of the University of Arizona, were married yesterday by Rabbi Abraham Klausner in the penthouse of Hayden Hall, a residence for the New York University School of Law on Washington Square West.

title: Rockefeller's Impending Retirement to Signal End of Golden Era for New York State Republicans
Bridge:
description: The summer Swiss teams championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association went into its final session at the New York Hilton Hotel last night, with 20 teams surviving from an original entry of 42 teams.

title: Limit on Breast XRays
description: The National Cancer Institute will issue new guidelines suggesting limits on the use of Xray techniques in the detection of breast cancer in women between the ages of 35 and 50. Page 12.

title: Robbers of China Bank Seem to Be Folk Heroes
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 22 If reports from recent travelers in China can be believed, the police are still looking for an armed gang that held up a bank some time ago and escaped with the equivalent of more than $100,000.

title: U.S. Price Agency Notes Rises in 2 Key Chemicals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Government's inflation monitoring agency said today that sizable increases in the prices of two key chemicals early last year came despite low production, relatively stable costs and sizable profit marginsfactors that usually translate into level or lower prices.

title: Deena Rosen Bride Of Peter Hoagland
description: Deena Beth Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Rosen of Forest Hills, Queens, was married last evening to Peter Millard Hoagland, son of Mrs. Joseph C. Hoagland Jr. of Washington and the late Mr. Hoagland.

title: North Korea Leader Calls DMZ Incident Regretful
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Kim II Sung has termed as regretful the incident that led to the slaying by North Korean guards of two American military officers last week. He said both sides should take steps to insure that such incidents did not recur.

title: Americans See Sarkis
description: BEIRUT, Aug. 22 (AP)Mr. Houghton and Mr. Mack conferred today with Presidentelect Sarkis and made an appointment to meet tomorrow with President Suleiman Franjieh, Christian officials announced. The American diplomats set up headquarters in a seaside hotel on the outskirts of Junieh, 12 miles north of the line that divides Beirut and Lebanon into Moslem and Christiancontrolled areas.

title: Terrified at Her Debut
description: I was completely terrified, Miss Bachauer recalled of her American debut at Town Hall. The piano seemed two miles away when I went on stage, and I thought I would never reach it.

title: Advertising
description: The first year in business for an ad agency is often the most difficult, as many new agencies have discovered over the years. It is particularly difficult when the shop's first big client leaves the state without paying its bills.

title: Burma, in Shift, Requests World Bank's Assistance
description: RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 17 The foiling of a military plot against President Ne Win, bombthrowing incidents in this capital and the arrest of a group of alleged Communist opponents are recent outward signs of mounting pressures on the former general's 14yearold military regime.

title: ExMilitary Strongman Leaves Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 21 With little more fanfare than when he arrived a week ago, Thailand's former military strongman flew out of Bangkok into exile again today, ending the most serious threat yet to the fourmonthold coalition Government of Prime Minister Seni Pramoi.

title: REPORT PREPARED ON HANDICAPPED
description: BORDENTOWN, Aug. 22 A woman confined to a wheelchair today began preparing an indepth report that will outline the needs of the handicapped and recommend legislation and other governmental action that could help ease the plight of New Jersey physically and mentally disabled.

title: Gina Bachauer, 63, Piano Virtuoso, Dies Before Concert Appearance in Athens
description: ATHENS, Aug. 22 (AP)Gina Bachauer, the pianist, collapsed and died of a heart attack today shortly before she was to appear with the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington at the Athens Festival. She was 63 years old.

title: Pele Voted Most Valuable Player
description: Pele, the star forward of the New York Cosmos, has been selected as the most valuable player this season in the North American Soccer League. The selection was made by the players in balloting conducted by The Sporting News. He will receive his award and a new Toyota Corolla in Seattle on Thursday, two days before Soccer Bowl76, the championship game.

title: Blacks in South Africa Urged to Strike
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 22 Pamphlets circulating in black townships throughout South Africa have urged workers to begin a threeday strike tomorrow in support of antiGovernment demonstrations that have swept the townships for the last two months.

title: Vacation Near End, Mondale Rests Before Northern Trip
description: HIBBING, Minn., Aug. 22 (AP)Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential candidate, ended up his last full day of vacationing at Lake Dewey today, shielded from visitors and the press.

title: Preseason Football
description: YESTERDAY'S GAME Minnesota 23, Cincinnati 17.

title: Adirondack Wilderness Is Focus of LandUse Controversy
V. N. Druzhinin, Leader Of Partisans in Ukraine
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (UPUI) Vladimir N. Druzhinin, a muchdecorated partisan leader during World War II and former Ukrainian government official, died Friday after a long illness, the newspaper Pravda Ukrainy has announced. He was 69 years old.

title: Doubling Transit Use in Cities Found Unlikely to Lessen Autos
description: If the number of transit riders in the nation's cities were doubled, the use of automobiles in urban areas would be reduced only marginally, the Regional Plan Association reported yesterday after an extensive, $165,000 study of the effectiveness, practicality and relative cost of modes of public transportation.

title: Jobless Aid Goes to Many Who Evade Employment
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 There is a construction worker here who drew $104 a week in state unemployment benefits while building his own homeand regularly turning down jobs to work at his trade.

title: A Relative of Betty Ford Says She Lost $60,000 in Court Fight
description: LUDINGTON, Mich., Aug 22 (AP) A sisterinlaw of Betty Ford says that she has lost $60,000 in a legal battle with a utility company, despite assistance from President Ford's counsel.

title: Dr. Parker P. Heath Dead; Ophthalmologist, Was 84
description: Dr. Parker P. Heath, emeritus professor of clinical ophthalmology at Harvard and a past president of the Ophthalmology Society, died Saturday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 84 years old.

title: Goldin Audit Cites Pension Illegalities
description: A number or New York City employees have been receiving disability retirement benefits illegally, according to an audit released yesterday by the office of Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: TRUST PORTFOLIOS ADD BASIC STOCKS
description: Bank trust departments, the largest managers of money for institutional investors and wealthy persons, continued to be net buyers of basic industry stocks and net sellers of forther glamour issues in the second quarter of 1976.

title: Carter Flies to California To Try Campaign Themes
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22  Jimmy Carter arrived in California today to begin sounding some of the themes of the coming campaign in a state that he expects will be closely contested in the November Presidential election.

title: Horace T. Cahill Dies at 81; Bay State Official, Judge
description: QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 22 (AP)  Former Lieut Gov. Horace T. Cahill, a retired Superior Court justice, died yesterday in City Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: SENATE HOPEFULS IN FIRST DEBATE
description: Interrupting each other on camera and grimacing off camera as their opponents spoke, the five Democratic candidates for. United States Senator from New York argued yesterday over welfare reform, political labels and their own comparative chances of winning in November.

title: NO FOREIGN LINKS TO FUGITIVES SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Justice Department prosecutors have seen no evidence that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's search for fugitive members of the Weather Underground organization was motivated by the group's purported links to hostile foreign governments, sources close to the department's investigation of the bureau said today.

title: SENATE HOPEFULS IN FIRST DEBATE
description: Interrupting each other one camera and grimacing off camfi era as their opponents spoke, the five Democratic candidates for United States Senator from New York argued yesterday over welfare reform, political labels and their own comparative chances of winning in November.

title: Foster Upsets Viren
description: GATESHEAD, England, Aug. 22 (UPI)Brendan Foster, Britain's only track and field medalist in the recent Olympics, upset Finland's Olympic champion, Lasse Viren, to win the twomile event at the Gateshead track meet today.

title: French Vineyard Sale To U.S. Bayer Vetoed
MATHIAS BIDS FORD SIGNAL MODERATES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Moderate and progressive Republicans are awaiting a signal from Vail, President Ford's Colorado vacation home, to join his fall campaign, Senator Charles McC. Mathias of Maryland said today.

title: Sousa to Be Inducted Into the Hall of Fame
description: John Philip Sousa, who was to the march what Johann Strauss Jr. was to the waltz, will be memorialized tonight at the Kennedy Center in Washington with a Marine Corps Band concert marking his induction into the Hall of Fame for Great Americans.

title: Vilas Faces Fibak In Canadian Final
description: TORONTO, Aug. 22 (UPI) Topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina defeated Jaime Fillol, of Chile, who played unaware of a death threat against him, and Wojtek Fibak of Poland beat Brian Fairlie of New Zealand today in the semifinals of the $155,000 Canadian open tennis championships.

title: Social Service Post for New York City Restored and Filled
description: In a new state welfare reorganization, Martha S. Lewis, a longtime social worker, has been named to a reinstated post of deputy state commisaioner of social services for metropolitan New York City. Dr. William Steibel has been appointed deputy commissioner to head the $3.5 billion statewide Medicaid program.

title: FORD'S AIDES SAY DOLE WILL ASSUME BIG CAMPAIGNROLE
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 22President Ford will reportedly attempt to retain the White House by spending most of his time in Washington as the nation's leader, by demonstrating knowledge of government in debates with Jimmy Carter and by focusing the Republican Presidential campaign on the major industrial states.

title: Victoria Murray Bride of David Brand
description: Victoria M. Murray, associate director of development and editor of the alumni newspaper at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to David A. Brand, a doctoral candidate at Adelphi's Institute of Advanced Psychological Studies.

title: Burma, in Shift, Requests World Bank's Assistance
description: RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 17 The foiling of a military plot against President Ne Win, bombthrowing incidents in this capital and the arrest of a group of alleged Communist opponents are recent outward, signs of mounting pressures on the former general's 14yearold military regime.

title: New York Labor Unions Are United Against Buckley, but Divided on Support for Other Senate Candidates
description: In New York's senatorial campaign, organized labor appears to be united on only one goal  the defeat of Senator James L. Buckley.

title: LEWIS P. JONES
description: Lewis P. Jones, manpower director in the New York City's Model Cities Administration, died of cancer Friday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Queens. He was 58 years old and lived at 6115 97th Street, Rego Park, Queens. Mr. Jones grew up in Coupland, Tex., and was gradu ated in 1939 from Morehouse College in Atlanta.

title: SetsGaters Series Continues Tonight
description: The New York Sets and the Golden Gaters of World Team Tennis meet tonight for the second match of their threeoffivegame championship series at the Oakland Coliseum. The Sets won the first match, 3123, on Saturday, to lead the series, 10.

title: Paris: Paintings of Hantai And Masson Are Shown
description: PARISOn Oct. 15, the National Museum of Modern Art will relinquish the wing that it occupies in the once grandiose, now dilapidated Mussolinian palace on Avenue du PresidentWilson to move into its new quarters at Beaubourg, leaving to its fate the Municipal Museum of Modern Art, which will continue to occupy the other wing. By a lucky coincidence, the last days of the cultural cohabitation of state and city have been marked by two major exhibitions whose concurrence not only repairs a double injustice but also sheds light on a fundamental yet neglected aspect of contemporary art: The dazzling survey of Andre Masson's drawings on the municipal side and the retrospective of the work of Simon Hantai on the national side.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOW HEAR THIS The OutofDoors Festival at Lincoln Center tonight at 8:15 is featuring a novel instrumental event that should be of special interest to organ fans and music lovers who appreciate clear, penetrating sounds. This is the swan song of the largest touring organ in the world. At its console an hourlong recital of classical selections will be presented by Leonard Raver, a teacher at Juilliard and Yale who occasionally performs as organist with the New York Philharmonic.

title: SPECIAL U.S. AIDES ARRIVE IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 22 Two American diplomats arrived in the rightistheld port of Junieh today in a move that is believed here to indicate growing concern in Washington about the trend toward the partition of Lebanon between Christians and Moslems.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 23, 1976

title: FORD'S AIDES SAY DOLE WILL ASSUME BIGCAMPAIGN ROLE
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 22President Ford will reportedly attempt to retain the White House by spending most of his time in Washington as the nation's leader, by demonstrating knowledge of government in debates with Jimmy Carter and by focusing the Republican Presidential campaign on the major industrial states.

title: Seoul Critical of Reply
description: Special to The New York Times

title: 75 Jump By Wszola Tops Stones
description: WARSAW, Aug. 22 (UPI) A Polish Olympic gold medalist, Jacek Wszola, won the high jump when he cleared 7 feet 5 inches today in an exciting competition with America's worldrecord holder, Dwight Stones, at an international track and field meet.

title: Carter Flies to California To Try Campaign Themes
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 22  Jimmy Carter flew to California today to sound some of the themes of the coming campaign in a state that he expects will be closely contested in the November Presidential election.

title: Flood Toll Could Reach 170
description: LOVELAND, Colo, Aug. 22 (UPI)  A missing persons list released today indicated that the final death count in the Big Thompson River flood could reach at least 170. Four bodies recovered from the flood debris in the past twc days increased the known casualty count of the July 31 flood to 123.

title: Carter Calls Killings Deliberate Murder
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 (AP)Jimmy Carter today called the killings of two American Army officers in Korea deliberate murder and said that President Ford appeared to be taking appropriate steps to deal with the incident.

title: U.S. Envoy Denied Asylum to Suspect
description: RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 17 On the evening of July 2, a frightened man turned up at the entrance to the compound where the American Ambassador, David L. Osborn, lives and asked for political asylum. He is in prison today and facing trial for his life.

title: Queen's Cup Won Bengals By Steere Yacht Lose to
description: ISLESBORO, Me.. Aug. 22 David Steere's Yankee Girl, from Hyannisport, Mass., one of those wellconceived yachts of the late 1960's that preceded the racingoriented International Ocean Racing rule, today won the Queen's Cup, a trophy that is one of the gems of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise.

title: Barbara Reader Wed To David H. Gelernter
description: At the Progressive Shaari Zedek Synagogue in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, Barbara Reader, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Reader of New Hyde Park, L. I., was married to David Hillel Gelernter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Gelernter of Setauket. L. I.

title: Robbers of China Bank Seem to Be Folk Heroes
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 22 If reports from recent travelers in China can be believed; the police are still looking for an armed gang that held up a bank some time ago and escaped with the equivalent of more than $100,000.

title: Winning Has Jets In Tune
description: The pugnacious left guard of the Jets, Randy Rasmussen, was feeling sorry early yesterday for anyone standing in front of him.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Government's Plan to Reduce the Cost of Drugs It Buys for Medical Programs Is to Begin This Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Government's pioneer program to reduce the $3 billion It spends annually on drugs for children, the aged and the poor is to begin this week, provided there is no unfavorable court ruling.

title: Top Detroit Policemen Reported Under Scrutiny in Drug Payoffs
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22  This city's mounting attention to street crimes was diverted by reports that several top officials of the Detroit Police Department were under investigation by Federal law enforcement authorities for possible involvement in narcotics payoffs.

title: Behind the Debates
description: President Ford has dramatically announced his readiness to debate his opponent on television, and Jimmy Carter has accepted the challenge. Thus, no obstacle stands in the way of the first series of TV debates history between an incumbent President and a challenger from the opposing party. In the memorable broadcasting debates between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon 16 years ago, neither candidate was in the White House.

title: Shane's Hydroplane Wins Red Bank Race by 2 Feet
description: RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP)  Stewart Shane of Havre de Grace, Md., defeated Jack Van Denman of Oceanport, N.J., by two feet today in the Governor's Cup invitation race of the 37th annual East Pointe national sweepstakes regatta.

title: Donald Townley, 78, Dies; Retired Corporate Officer
description: Donald C. Townley, retired vice president in charge of the foreign division of the American Home Products Corporation, died Saturday in the Candlewood Valley Care Center in New Milford, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived on Lake Waramaug in Warren, Conn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 20monthold child fell to his death from a broken window in his 13thfloor Harlem apartment yesterday, the police reported. The child, identified as Carl Jones, crawled through the broken lower portion of a window in the apartment at 225 West 129th Street. His mother, Dorine Jones, and his twin brother were in different rooms in the apartment when the incident occurred at 10:20 A.M., officials said. The window, which had bars on the outside, was closed, but the boy was apparently able to pull himself through the broken portion.

title: Reagan's One Campaign Regret: The Lack of Time Spent in Ohio
BUDDY TATE, AT CLUB, LEADS BASIE TRIBUTE
description: Jazz is turning up in some unlikely places these days. At the Club Sanno, for example, a Japanese restaurant that is squeezed between two topless joints on 53d Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. From Monday through Friday, Club Sanno is a private Japanese club. But on Saturday evening it is open to the public, and the public gets, along with a Japanese menu, American jazz.

title: Jones Bid for 20th Foiled by Mets, 10
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 22Jon Matlack had to get the final out with the bases full today to lock up a 10 victory for the New York Mets over the San Diego Padres and Randy Jones, who once again failed to get his 20th victory.

title: FUEL EVAPORATION OF CARS TO BE CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Fuel evaporation from automobiles and light trucks is to be reduced by 70 percent below current levels beginning with 1978 models, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today.

title: Stars and Stripes Forever Stirs All
description: There are those critics and musicians who will look you in the eye and state that John Philip Sousa's The Stars and Stripes Forever is the greatest piece of music ever written by an American composer. They are only half joking. American composers from Dillings to Copland and George Crumb have written music that is deeper, more ambitious, more serious in purpose, much closer to Kant's definition of the sublime. But no American composer has written a piece that is more perfect in itself, or that has become so identified with the national spirit.

title: It Hit 94  No Record but No Comfort
Phyllis Heisler Miss Gordon Wed to S. F. Reed 3d
description: Phyllis Amy Heisler and Glenn S. Gerstell, who graduated this year from the Columbia Law School, were married yesterday afternoon at the St. RegisSheraton. Cantor Edward Heisler, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony.

title: Iran Rejects Oil Embargo
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  Iran will not support resolutions of the conference of nonaligned states calling for an embargo on oil exports to France and Israel, a foreign ministry spokesman said today. The conference, held last week in Sri Lanka, called for the embargo, charging that France and Israel persistently violated United Nations resolutions against supplying arms to South Africa.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: As a child of the South (and one who has not infrequently been described as having corn meal mush in his mouth) we felt notably secure in stating recently that grits, that celebrated Southern cereal, constituted a plural noun. We staunchly defend this opinion; but we do feel moved to give the opposition a moment of selfdefense.

title: Susan Flanagan Is Wed to John Sharkey
description: Susan Alethea Flanagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Flanagan of Glen Cove, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Kevin Sharkey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Sharkey of East Norwich, L. I.

title: Liberty and Community
description: Underneath the weary rhetoric in Kansas City, the chestpuffing and the obsession with Jimmy Carter, the Republicans had a real theme. It was individualism: the moral and economic power of the individual when free of government restraint. President Ford spoke of the pioneer vision  of free men and free women enjoying limited government and unlimited opportunity.

title: Vesper Eight Captures National Rowing Crown
Bicycle Check Up Drawl Big Wheels To Central Park
description: What do you do when your bicycle seat is too high, your handlebars are too low, your rear brakes don't work, your chain is too tight and you have a flat tire?

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Is the longstanding United States private and voluntary system of establishing product standards and the accompanying system of laboratory certification for safety and performance, a device for fostering monopoly and keeping the better mousetrap from the market?

title: Trading in Sorghum
description: Futures trading in sorghum will be resumed on the Kansas City Board of Trade, an important wheat exchange, on Sept. 1, after a hiatus of three and a half years. The coarse grain is used almost exclusively as livestock feed. Page 36.

title: PAPER HAS CONNALLY REJECTING G.O.P. JOB
description: DALLAS, Aug. 22 (UPI) John B. Connally declined a request by President Ford last week to become chairman of the Republican National Committee, The Dallas Times Herald reported today.

title: Complacency on Oil
description: Pledges of American energy independence by 1980 1985 resounded from the Nixon White House less than three years ago as the country reeled under the impact of the Arab oil embargo, and long lines at gas stations briefly became a daily trial for millions of Americans. With the embargo and empty gas pumps only fading memories, there seems little public awareness that the United States is more dependent than ever on Middle East crude oiland therefore more vulnerable to Middle East oil embargo threats. The situation is likely to get worse as the current business recovery continues.

title: Gloria Swanson Settles Suit Backing Single Taxpayers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)  Gloria Swanson has agreed to pay 35 cents on the dollar to settle a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over alleged discrimination against single taxpayers. David R. Shelton, a tax lawyer and longtime friend of the actress; said today.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 22The leaders of the New Jersey Tax Revolt Association plan to continue their fight against the state income tax.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: New York City's Leasing Policies

title: Federation Cup Opens With Pickets, No Boycott
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 About 75 protesters, black and white, mostly 20 to 30 years old, demonstrated in front of the Spectrum against the inclusion of national teams from South Africa and Rhodesia as the Federation Cup tennis tournament began today.

title: Dole Believes He Was Nominated to Span G.O.P. Gap
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  Senator Robert J. Dole conceded today that he felt he had been chosen as the Republican VicePresidential nominee not to broaden President Ford's base of support among voters but to try to bridge the gap between those who were strongly for Ford and those who felt strongly about Reagan.

title: State Panel, Citing Racism and Harassment, Calls Comstock Prison Volatile
description: The State Commission of Correction has issued a report on the Great Meadow Correctional Facility at Comstock, N. Y., calling it the most volatile among several potentially explosive institutions in the state.

title: Minnesota Forest Fire
description: GRAND MARAIS, Minn., Aug. 22 (AP)  The United States Forest Service battled a forest fire spreading out of the wilderness Boundary Waters Canoe Area of northeastern Minnesota today. The fire was about 40 miles northwest of Grand Marais on the shore of Lake Superior.

title: Cancer Institute Proposes Limits on Breast XRays
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22In a new set of guidelines on the use of Xray techniques in the detection of breast cancer, the National Cancer Institute will recommend this week that the Xrays not be used routinely on women between the ages of 35 and 50 unless they show specific symptoms or are otherwise classified as high risk.

title: Victim of Ship Fire Found
description: DESTREHAN, La., Aug. 22 (UPI)Coast Guard rescuers boarded the charred wreck of a 700foot freighter in the Mississippi River today and found the body of a machinist killed in a fire that burned out the ship yesterday. The body of another missing crewman was recovered yesterday in the machine room near where the fire started. Positive Identification of the victims had not been made.

title: Battle of Long Island Victory Made British Underestimate American Forces
description: Under an angry red sun on Aug. 27, 1776, British dragoons and light infantry swept around the American left flank, the. Hessians in the center went in with the bayonet and the Battle of Long Island, one of the most complex and significant of the Revolution, was won.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: F.B.I. agents in Denver have arrested a 23yearold New York man wanted in connection with an armed robbery in which a Newark police officer was killed earlier this month. Ted Rosack, special agent in charge of the Denver office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said Allen R. Roller of Staten Island was taken into custody without incident at Stapleton International Airport while he was purchasing an airline ticket for Gillette, Wyo. Mr. Rosack said Mr. Roller, who was unarmed when apprehended, had been sought in the Aug. 13 killing of Police Officer John W. Snow, a 23year veteran of the. Newark force, who was killed by a single gunshot blast in the neck while delivering $47,000 in cash to the Hi Way Check Cashing Agency in Kearny. He surprised the two gunmen who had just robbed the agency of $4,000. After shooting Officer Snow, the suspects reached inside his patrol, car, grabbed an attach case containing cash he had transported from the First National State Bank in Newark and fled in a car.

title: A Loyalist Farce Added Insult to Injury
description: Perhaps inspired by General Howe's easy conquest of the rebellious Colonists in the Battle of Long Island, some loyalist polemecist was quick to turn to his pen that August of 1776.

title: Books of The Times
description: George Dangerfield's study of AngloIrish relations begins with the Act of Union of 1800, skims in 40 pages over the famine and repression under British rule in the 19th century, then skids to a hait before plunging into the stream of events that crested in the Easter Rising of 1916, the highwater mark of 20thcentury Irish history. The brutal Black and Tan occupation that followed, the serpentine negotiations that ended in Lloyd George's last hat trickthe Treaty of 1921and the treaty's aftermath of civil war seemingly bring to an end the English presence on the stage of Irish history

title: Miss Whitworth Takes Berg Golf
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 22 (UPI)Kathy Whitworth's 12foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today wrapped up a twostroke victory over Sandra Post in the $55,000 Patty Berg golf classig with a 73 for a sevenunderpar total of 212. The victory gave Miss Whitworth a total of 76 professional victories and increased her career winnines to $784,766.

title: Vickie, a Greyhound, Judged Best at Great Barrington
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 22A brindle and white greyhound, Ch. Grey Roc Winged Victory, triumphed today near the ski slopes of Butternut Basin in the Great Barrington Kennel

title: SEOUL ADAMANT OVER DISSIDENTS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20 The heightened tension in the Korean demilitarized zone that followed the ax slayings of two American military officers is not expected to help the human rights situation here.

title: Jersey to Test a Program to Preserve Agriculture and Open Space in State
An Oriental Addition to Fifth Avenue
description: The ethnic economic tides that have washed Fifth Avenue in recent years, leaving their imprint in the form of branches of Italian boutiques and book stores, outposts of foreign airlines, and skyscraper habitats for petrodollar plutocrats, have left one of their latest marks on the block between 43d and 44th Street in the form of the Zen Oriental Book Store.

title: Jobless Aid Goes to Many Who Evade Employment
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 There is a construction worker here who drew $104 a week in state unemployment benefits while building his own homeand regularly turning down jobs to work at his trade.

title: About New York
description: Mere civilians are not allowed to wander around the laboratories of the American Museum of Natural History, where they experiment on cats. But many people are angry about those experiments. And, as is usual when people are angry, what we have is not a dialogue; we have communication by sandwich board or emotional neon sign.

title: Surge in Driving Costs Laid to Cars, Not Fuel
description: Although Americans have reduced their driving to the lowest levels in a quarter of a century, their annual spending for motor vehicles rose more than $100 billion in the last three years, according to a study by the Hertz Corporation.

title: Mangione Is Heard With His Big Band At Concert in Park
description: Chuck Mangione has developed a repertory, made up largely of his own compositions, for his 22piece orchestra in which big ensemble sounds rise and fall over edgy, insistent rhythms, occasionally complemented by an attractive melody. It is an outgrowth of the academic bigband jazz style that is based on Stan Kenton's performances but with more color, shading and melodic imagination than either Mr. Kenton or the other academic bands usually get.

title: Terrorism Charged to Cubans In Testimony by Miami Police
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Militant proCastro and antiCastro Cuban groups in the Miami area are engaged in terrorist activities both in and outside the United States, according to testimony given before a Senate subcommittee and released today.

title: Jets Statistics
description: INDIVIDUAL LEADERS

title: Last Day of Camp: A Sentimental Farewell to Summer
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.Regardless of the sun's relationship to the earth, the day that camp ends, summer is gone. And the season's end is marked with conspicuous sobbing and long faces by youngsters across the land.

title: Schools in Dallas District to Open Today With Extensive Desegregation Program
description: DALLAS, Aug. 22 (AP)The Dallas School District will open the new school year tomorrow with an extensive desegregation plan that was produced by a private volunteer group and that educators hope will be a model for the nation.

title: TRANSIT PACT VOTED FOR SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 (AP)  San Francisco's 1,800 hansit workers voted tonight to accept a wage and fringe beirefit offer, thereby averting a threatened strike that could have shut down other city services as well.

title: Syrians Agree to Proposal For Druse Families to Meet
Kubitschek, ExPresident Of Brazil, Dies in Crash
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 (AP)Juscelino Kubitschek de Oliveira, the former president who built Brazil's inland capital of Brasilia, was killed in an automobile accident on the RioSo Paulo highway tonight. He was 73 years old.

title: Politics of Water Grips All in West
description: DECKERS, Colo.Bill and Nancy Benight live about 20 miles south of Denver. Their land alongside the South Platte River could be inundated some day by a reservoir.

title: Tax Protest a Gauge of West Bank's Deeper Tensions
description: NABLUS, Israeli  occupied West BankCareful, sirs, the elderly Arab said, pointing the other morning to this sunbaked town's casbah. The young are disturbing.

title: Doubling Transit Use in Cities Found Unlikely to Lessen Autos
description: If the number of transit riders in tile nation's cities were doubled, the use of automobiles in urban areas would be reduced only marginally, the Regional Plan Association reported yesterday after an extensive, $165,000 study of the effectiveness, practicality and relative cost of modes of public transportation.

title: Turks Begin Drug Factory
description: AFYUN, Turkey, Aug. 22 (Reuters)Turkey began laying the foundations today of a factory to make morphine and other Medicinal drugs from the poppies that once produccd llicit opium destined for addicts of Europe and the United States.

title: Investors of Many Kinds Study ClosedEnd Funds
Seven Democrats on West Side Spending Summer Fighting to Succeed Blumenthal
description: Seven West Side Democrats are spending the summer in a typical West Side Democratic activityfighting each other for the chance to succeed Albert H. Blumenthal in the State Assembly. And in typical West Side fashion, the views of the candidates are so similar and the careers of several of them so entwined that the race seems less a political campaign than a contest among siblings over who gets the family business.

title: Gas Leak Forces Evacuation
description: JAMESTOWN, R.I., Aug. 22 (AP)Fire officials evacuated about 200 persons from a quartermilesquare area here when a truck containing 1,700 gallons of liquid petroleum gas sprang a leak. Fire officials were alerted to the leak about 5 P.M. yesterday, and the evacuees were returned to their homes about four hours later after the truck had been drained.

title: The Day LeRoy Was Waiting For
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 One of the most memorable athletic contests since Dempsey and Firpo was the 93d Travers Stakes in 1962 when Jaipur and Ridan went flat out, hell for leather, head and head through every stride of the mile and a quarter with Jaipur winning by a nose. LeRoy Jolley, the trainer of Ridan, felt the sting of that defeat for 14 years, but when consolation came it cured all hurts. Honest Pleasure, who had disappoined Jolley more bitterly than any other horse since the tempestuous Ridan, not only spreadeagled his field in the 107th Travers yesterday, he did it with as gaudy a flourish as Saratoga has witnessed, running the distance faster than the fastest had run it here in 113 years. The Travers winner has his name inscribed on the Man o'War Cup, a gold replica goes to his owner along with the purse ($65,040 this time), and there are trophies for the trainer and jockey. These are attractive trinkets, but money gets spent and trophies tarnished. The satisfaction of a job superbly done will be LeRoy's as long as he lives.

title: 200,000 IN ENGLAND AT STONES CONCERT
description: KNEBWORTH, England, Aug. 22 (AP)Some 200,000 rock fans trekked home today after a 16hour pop music festival billed as possibly the final concert by the Rolling Stones.

title: Critic's Notebook: G.O.P. And Tanglewood in Tune
description: A convention is a convention. The delegates and observers at last week's Festival of Contemporary Music of Tanglewood did not wear funny hats and blow horns, but they fooled nobody. They were conventioneers in disguise. There was an odd similarity between this fiveday gathering of prominent academics, established avantgardists and bright  eyed young performers and what was taking place simultaneously in Kansas City.

title: Measured Response
description: Three days after North Korean guards brutally assaulted and killed two American officers supervising a treepruning operation in the demilitarized zone, allied forces returned Friday and cut down the tree which had been obstructing the view of a United Nations Command post.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Stuck Wins in Italy
description: MISANO ADRIATICO, Aug. 22 (UPI)Hans Stuck of West Germany, driving a MarchBMW, won the Santa Monica Cup Formula Two automobile race today. He finished 10 seconds ahead of Arturo Merzario of Italy, the runnerup. Stuck covered the 108.4 miles, in 1:02.04 at an average speed of 104.5 m.p.h.

title: Adirondack Wilderness Is Focus of LandUse Controversy
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.Three years after it started to administer a complex land use plan designed to preserve the Adirondack Mountain wilderness, the Adirondack Park Agency is the focus of a bitter controversy among local residents, landowners, public officials and environmental groups.

title: Gullikson Wins at Net
description: Special to The New York Times

title: John A. Treat Is Dead at 64; Better Business Bureau Aide
description: John Alexander Treat, a vice president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc. in New York City, and a descendant of Robert Treat Paine, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, died Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. His age was 64.

title: R. A. Di Salvo Marries Margaret Poole
description: Margaret Ann Poole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas W. Poole of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Rosario Antonino Di Salvo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Di Salyo of New York.

title: Agency Proposes Help for the Frail Elderly
description: HACKENSACKThe Family Counseling Service Inc., whose chief goal for 76 years has been strength to families, has come up with a proposal in which the agency would be a surrogate family for the frail elderly.

title: Orioles Win on Jackson's Slam, Then Lose, 73
description: In his nine years with the A's in Kansas City and Oakland, Reggie Jackson hit only one grandslam home run. Yesterday, however, he got his third grand slam as a Baltimore Oriole, batting as a pinchhitter in the ninth inning. The clout snapped a 22 tie to give the Orioles a 62 victory over the White Sox in the first game of A doubleheader at Comiskey Park in Chicago.

title: Judith Berek Has Nuptials
description: Judith Berek, director of legislative and professional programs for the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees, was married at her home in Brooklyn yesterday to Thomas Speer Walther, associate director for special projects for the United Hospital Fund of New York. Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg perfiotmed the ceremony.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT BRENTWOOD, L.I.

title: Armored Breakthrough
description: After a quartercentury of efforts to standardize weapons, the 12 NATO armies in Europe still have kinds of closerange weapons, 6 shortrange missiles, 7 mediumrange missiles and 5 longrange missiles. At sea, NATO navies employ 36 types of radar, 8 kinds surfacetoair missiles and 40 varieties of heavy, guns.

title: Syria Casting a Big Shadow as Lebanon Battle Looms
North Korea Leader Calls DMZ Incident Regretful
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  President Kim Il Sung has termed as regretful the incident that led to the slaying by North Korean guards of two American military officers last week. He said both sides should take steps to insure that such incidents did not recur.

title: Dale Elyse Weinstock Bride of David J. Pine
description: Dale Elyse Weinstock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Weinstock of Hewlett, L.I., was married yesterday evening to David Jay Pine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Pine of Manhasset, L.I.

title: SouthWest Africa Group Says Israelis Fight There
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 22 (AP)The militant SouthWest African People's Organization asserts that Israel is helping South Africa in military operations in SouthWest Africa, or Namibia, and says it is expecting help from both Cuba and the Soviet Union to step up the guerrilla war there.

title: WILLIAM GEER SR. OF TIME INC. DEAD
description: William D. Geer Sr., publisher of Fortune magazine from 1942 to 1948 and associate publisher of Life magazine in 1950, died Friday of a stroke at his home in Gilsum, N.H. He was 70 years old.

title: Bell System Ponders judge's View Urging Scrutiny but Not a Breakup
description: A 535page mimeographed document containing a landmark examination of the world's largest commercial enterprise  the Bell telephone systemhas been simmering on the desks of the American communications industry for three weeks.

title: Varo Stock, Blazing a Trail, joins Big Board but Stays on Amex, Too
description: The first trade when the New York Stock Exchange opens today will be the purchase by Samuel T. Yanagisawa, chairman of Varo Inc., of 100 shares in his company. The purchase will be in keeping with a longstanding tradition for stocks newly listed on the Big Board. But an even more important tradition will be broken.

title: Limit on Breast XRays
description: The National Cancer Institute will issue new guidelines suggesting limits on the use of Xray techniques in the detection of breast cancer in women between the ages of 35 and 50. Page 12.

title: Spanish Questioning Role of the Forces of Order
description: MADRID, Aug. 22The fatal shooting of an 18yearold leftist by the Civil Guard has dramatized a problem worrying many Spaniards: how to control what the people here call the forces of order.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Washington Hails New York Cabbies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Taxi! Taxi! Anyone need a taxi? How about a ride to New York!

title: A Pianist With Power
description: In many respects, Gina Bachauer was a female Arthur Rubinstein. Her playing had much the same kind of a joie de vivre, sweet and controlled romanticism. Bachauer was an unknown when she made her first trip to the United States in 1950. She made her debut in Town Hall and it took just about five minutes for her to electrify the audience and the few music critics who were present.

title: Law Firm of Ruckelshaus, ExHead of E.P.A., Made 178 Contadts With Agency for Clients in 18 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The law firm established by William D. Ruckelshaus, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, got in touch with officials in tliat agency more Clan 178 times for 20 different clients in 1974 and 1975.

title: John F. Bianchi, the Prosecutor In Reilly MurderCase, Dies at 54
description: John F. Bianchi, the prosecutor of Peter A. Reilly, who was convicted of murdering his mother but who, with the efforts of Arthur Miller, the playwright, and others, subsequently won an order for a new trial, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday while playing golf near his home in Canaan, Conn. He was 54 years old.

title: Switzerland Expels Russian And Rumanian for Spying
description: BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 22 (Reuters)Switzerland has expelled a Soviet diplomat and a member of the Rumanian Embassy staff for spying, the Justice and Police Ministry announced today.

title: KOREA VICTIM TO GET WEST POINT BURIAL
description: HIGHLAND FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP)The body of Maj. Arthur G. Bonifas, one of two United States Army officers killed by North Korean soldiers in Korea's demilitarized zone, arrived here early today prior to burial at nearby West Point on Tuesday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Disaster Assistance Administration plans to set up an office near Atlantic City to aid four New Jersey counties that suffered damage from Hurricane Belle. President Ford declared Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May Counties a disaster area last week, making them eligible for Federal funds. A spokesman for the agency said that Government and volunteer agencies would offer temporary housing, smallbusiness loans, agriculture aid, special unemployment compensation, tax refunds and personal financial help.

title: European Flavor In a Jewelry Shop
description: It's just as well Martin Shapiro and Albert Sonsino have a flair for languages. Their jewelry shop, Ordiam, situated as it is in Rockefeller Center, tends to attract visitors from abroad, so Mr. Shapiro, originally from Tel Aviv, and Mr. Sonsino, who is from Alexandria, Egypt, often find themselves conducting business in French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, German, Hebrew or Arabic instead of in English.

title: Loeb. Rhoades in New Move
description: LONDON, Aug. 23 (Reuters) The United States investment and brokerage firm Loeb, Rhoades & Company, said it planned to set up an international investment banking company based here. The group said it would initially emphasize underwriting, trading of Eurobonds and syndication of Euroloans, and aims to develop a full range of international financial services.

title: Suspension of Reality
description: Politics is supposed to be the art of the possible. That definition may fit the activities of politicians in policymaking places. For the rank and file, such as ideologically committed delegates to political conventions or the campfollowers of wouldbe candidates, politics might be more accurately described as a chase after the impossiblea glorious flight from reality.

title: Animal Medical Center Seeks to Cure Fiscal Ills
REBELS ON CORSICA BOMB A WINE DEPOT
description: GHISONACCIA, Corsica, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  Sixteen militant Corsican nationalists blew up a wine depot last night to mark the first anniversary of a clash with the police in which two persons died.

title: RHODESIA BLACKS FORM NEW PARTY
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 23 (Reuters)A new black Rhodesian nationalist party has been formed and one of its leaders says it is ready to reopen constitutional talks with the Government if guerrilla leaders are allowed to attend.

title: Higher Increases Predicted In Early '77 Food Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)Retail food prices in the first half of next year may be 3 to 4 percent higher than they were in the first six months of 1976, the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Decoy Is First Witness at Start of Rep. Howe's Trial on Sex Charges
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 23 The sex solicitation trial on Democratic Representative Allan T. Howe began today with speedy selection of a jury and the testimony of a police decoy prostitute that the Congressman had on June 12 offered her $20 for the performance of two specific sexual acts.

title: Chief Rival in Party Bids Miki Quit Before Election
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (Reuters) The chief rival of Prime Minister Takeo Miki within the ruling LiberalDemocratic. Party called today for the resignation of Mr. Miki before general elections, which must be held by Dec. 9.

title: Syrians, Saudis Sign Pact
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 23. (AP)  The Governments of Syria and Saudi Arabia signed an agreement last night to establish a joint company for investment in agriculture and industry.

title: Samuel Brookfield, Partner In Manhattan Law Firm
description: A memorial service for Samuel L. Brookfield, senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Webster, Sheffield, Fleischmann, Hitchcock and Brookfield, was held yesterday at Christ's Church in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Wendell Phillips, rector, and Episcopal Bishop J. Stuart Wetmore officiated.

title: MISS HEARST HELD BAFFLED BY ACTS
description: I can't believe I said those things about my father. The statement is attributed to a crying Patricia Hearst, the kidnapping victim turned fugitive who in taped messages during her flight is believed to have called her father Adolph, a corporate liar and a pig.

title: SEALAW PARLEY IS AT AN IMPASSE
Peanuts: From Carver to Carter
description: Jimmy Carter has accomplished a lot. The Georgia farmer has done what countless public relations experts and millions of dollars have been struggling to do for decades: He has rescued the peanut from obscurity.

title: GRAND JURY OPENS KIDNAPPING INQUIRY
description: MADERA, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)A grand jury began investigating today the kidnapping on July 15 of 26 children an their school bus driver at Chowchilla, Calif.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 24, 1976

title: Amex and Counter Down as Trading Rises
description: Prices fell sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in heavier trading.

title: South African Low Growth
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The South African economy experienced relatively low growth, an unfavorable balance of payments and a still too high rate of inflation in the twelve months ended June 30, the reserve bank said today in its annual economic report.

title: Soweto's Blacks Succeed In Johannesburg Boycott
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 23 Young black demonstrators in the black township of Soweto stoned buses and trains today as they attempted to force compliance with a threeday national strike among black workers on whom the economy of whiteruled South Africa depends. Police shot and killed one black youth and wounded at least six others.

title: RISE IN SPENDING FOR SCHOOLS VOID; 3.500 FACE OUSTER
description: In a victory for the Beame administration, a State Supreme Court justice yesterday declared invalid the controversial StaviskyGoodman Law, which was designed to require an increase in education spending in New York City by as much as $150 million.

title: Dynamics Denies Aides Sold Stock On Insiders' Data
description: David S. Lewis, chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, denied yesterday that any executives of the company sold stock in the company during the last eight months on the basis of inside information that problems existed in a tanker construction program.

title: Boston in a Business and School Partnership
description: BOSTON The Give A Damn buttons and billboards that marked the business community's nationwide campaign for innercity involvement in the 1960's have largely disappeared, but something of that spirit has been rekindled around the Boston school system.

title: Alfred Jaretzki Jr., 83, Lawyer Who Aided Investment Act, Dies
description: Alfred Jaretzki Jr., a retired partner in the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell and an expert on investment companies, died Saturday in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 895 Park Avenue.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: THE SOUND OF MUSIC: Visitors to the V.I.P. car of the Freedom Train, in Port Newark until tomorrow, gathered around Ronald Hine as he operated vintage player piano.

title: Workmen's Board Member
description: ALBANY, Aug. 23 (UPI) Ernest R. Latham of Rockville Centre, L. I., has been named to the Workmen's Compensation Board, Governor Carey's office announced today. Mr. Latham, 51 years old, is a former member of the board and a former referee. His appointment to the $35,250ayear post is subject to confirmation when the State Senate returns in January. A lawyer and a journeyman plumber, Mr. Latham is former counsel to Plumber's Local No. 1 and is secretary of the State A.F.L.C.I.O. Workmen's Compensation Committee, the Governor's office said.

title: Canada Drafts Plan To Relax Bank Rules
