description: OTTAWA, Aug. 23American and other foreign banks will be permitted to offer full banking services in Canada for the first time under proposed changes in the Bank Act and related legislation, outlined by the Government in a white paper today.

title: Chess:
description: MONTILLA, Spain, Aug. 22 After four rounds of the Torneo del Vino here in the Don Gonzalo Hotel, International Master Ricardo CaIvo of Spain leads with 3 points.

title: DR. JOHN D. PINTO
description: Dr. John D. Pinto, chief of staff of the Westerly (R.I.) Hospital, died there Saturday of cancer. He was 55 years old.

title: Soweto's Blacks Succeed In Johannesburg Boycott
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 23 Young black demonstrators in the black township of Soweto stoned buses and trains today as they attempted to force compliance with a threeday national strike among black workers on whom the economy of whiteruled South Africa depends. Police shot and killed one black youth and wounded at least six others.

title: Fire in New Hospital
description: A smoky fire broke out on the sixth floor of the Lincoln Medical Center in the Bronx around 11:30 last night, but was quickly brought under control, fire officials reported. A spokesman for the new hospital at East 149th Street and Morris Avenue said the cause of the fire was under investigation. There were no reports of injuries and the hospital said that its patients had not been affected. The spokesman declined to give further details, pending the inquiry.

title: JOHN S. DIEKHOFF, SCHOLAR, 70, DIES
description: Dr. John Siemon Diekhoff, a Milton scholar and a distinguished educator, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital, Cleveland. He was 70 years old and lived in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: U.S. Softens Its Reaction To North Korea Regrets
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The State Department softened its reaction today and said that the message received from President Kim II Sung of North Korea expressing regrets about last week's incident in the demilitarized zone was a positive step.

title: Presidential Science
description: The Senate's confirmation of Dr. H. Guyford Stever as science adviser to the President reestablishes a relationship that had been scuttled when President Nixon abolished the Office of Science and Technology whose successive chiefs had advised Presidents since the late 1950's.

title: RISE IN SPENDING FOR SCHOOLS VOID; 3,500 FACE OUSTER
description: In a victory for the Beame administration, a State Supreme Court justice yesterday declared invalid the controversial StaviskyGoodman Law, which was designed to require an increase in education spending in New York City by as much as $150 million.

title: Carter Defends Congress And Assails Ford's Vetoes
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23  Jimmy Carter bluntly responded today to President Ford's recent attacks on Congress by accusing him of irresponsible, shortsighted vetoes that he said have contributed to needless human suffering.

title: 10,000 Coal Miners Strike
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 23 (AP)Executives of the United Mine Workers met today to decide how to deal with a wildcat strike involving the state's 10,000 coal miners. The strike began earlier in the day after seven workers from one union local were suspended for 18 days because of their activities in another wildcat strike early this month, according to the union. The union was urging the miners to return to work.

title: Korean Achilles' Heel
description: The murder of two American officers at Panmunjom last week has provided a grim reminder of what the 41,000 United States troops still stationed in Korea are standing against in that divided country. They are there to deter another attempt at forceful reunification by a dogmatic Communist regime in the North that remains violently unpredictable.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala

title: Protectionism Exposed
description: When the United Auto Workers last year protested that heavy unemployment among its members stemmed from the dumping of small foreign cars in the American market at prices lower than they were sold at home, the Treasury launched the biggest investigation ever staged under the antidumping act. Before it ended, 28 auto makers in eight countries were studied.

title: Oyster Bay Harbor Jittery After Shark Sightings
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 23 Just about anything floating in the harbor here today old tires, beer cans, a piece of driftwoodlooked like a shark fin.

title: Appeals Court Upholds School Busing in Louisville
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (UPI) Nine days before the start of school, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit approved today the same courtordered busing desegregation plan for the schools in Louisville, Ky., and suburbs that set off violence there a year ago.

title: 4 Saved Off Jersey Shore
description: BRADLEY BEACH, N.J., Aug. 23 (UPI)Four persons were rescued yesterday as a 28foot pleasure boat began to sink about a mile and a half off the New Jersey Shore, the Coast Guard reported. Among those rescued was John Hill, 24 years old, of Linden, whose father, Police Capt. Howard Hill of Linden, died last September when he suffered a heart attack while boating off the Jersey coast.

title: Bodies of Two Recovered
description: ONAWAY, Mich., Aug. 23 (UPI)  Divers recovered the bodies yesterday of two students at the Walter and May Reuther Education Center who had drowned some 20 hours earlier while swimming in Black Lake. The victims were identified as Ron Sanders, 28 years old, of Orange, N. J., and Conrad Kirkoldy, 22, of Philadelphia. Both had attended the education center on scholarships from the United Auto Workers.

title: McDonnell Douglas Halts Plans for a DC10 Engine
description: LONG BEACH, California, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has dropped plans for now to develop a longrange DC10 with a Rolls Royce engine, a spokesman for the company said today.

title: Japan Grain Forecast Down
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (UPI)The agricultureforestry ministry has estimated Japan's grain production this year at 349,600 tons, down 12 percent from last year.

title: Placards an Old Sign to Rhodesian Tennis Team
Andre Lanskoy, 74, Artist; Influenced by Chagall, Klee
description: PARIS, Aug. 23 (AP)Andre M. Lanskoy, a Russianborn artist who was a follower of Marc Chagall, died in his studio here yesterday, officials said today. He was 74 years old.

title: Filipino Soldier Slain
description: MANILA, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Gunmen believed to be Moslem rebels ambushed an army truck north of Zamboango, in the southern Philippines today, killing one soldier and wounding five, military sources said here tonight.

title: Gold
description: By The Associated Press

title: Auto Workers Union Is Expected to Name a Target Company Today as Contract Negotiations Step Up
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23Contract negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the nation's major automobile manufacturers are expected to step up here tomorrow with the naming of a target company by the union's 26member International Executive Board.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it was establishing a $20 million reserve during the third quarter to reflect an estimated loss on the possible sale of two British food companies.

title: Judge Michael H. Sheridan; On Bench in Pennsylvania
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Aug. 23 (AP)  Federal District Judge Michael H. Sheridan died today of an apparent heart attack. He was 64 vears old

title: Dutch Queen Discusses Lockheed Investigation
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 23 (Reuters)Queen Juliana of the Netherlands returned home from Italy today to face a mounting constitutional crisis following a Government investigation of allegations that her husband, Prince Bernhard, took bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Company to promote its sales.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 23 (UPI) Team America concluded two weeks of intensive practice today before leaving for Quebec City and three exhibition hockey games preparation for the sixteam, nineday Canada Cup series that opens Sept. 2. Other teams in the series, the first its kind in professional hockey, are Team Canada; Czechoslovakia, the world champion; the Soviet Union, the Olyrifpic champion; Sweden, which will be bolstered by the in elusion of its pro players, and Finland.

title: BIG BOARD LEADS IN VAN VOLUME
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange began competing yesterday in making a market in the same stock to show stockbrokersand their customers that each would provide the better market.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Preseason Football

title: SOL NODEL, ARTIST AND ILLUMINATOR
description: Sol Nodel, an artist and illuminator, died Sunday of a heart attack while visiting in Miami. He was 63 years old and lived at 639 West End Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Ferrari Returns to Grand Prix Circuit
description: MARANELLO. Italy, Aug. 23 (AP)The Italian Ferrari racing factory decided today to resume participation in Formula One championship races, reversing an Aug. 5 decision to stay out through the year.

title: CAR PARKER FACES MARIJUANA CHARGE
description: A New York City employee picked the wrong time and parked his car in an area reserved for vehicles of the city's Investigation Department. It resulted in the arrest of the 26 yearold employee and another man on charges of illegal possession of four pounds of marijuana.

title: FORD IS STRESSING POLITICS AND PLAY
description: VAIL Colo., Aug. 23President Ford's election campaign strategy, which aides have said calls for him to underline his incumbency through highvisibility White House activities, evidently will have to wait until next week to commence.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23  A state computer that rounded off dollars and cents incorrectly when computing state employees salary increases has been caught by a pocket calculator.

title: Lunch Sponsors in 75 Inquiry Still Involved in 1976 Program
Fox Film Picks D.D.B. For $6 Million Account
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation has appointed Doyle Dane Bernbach as its agency for both domestic and major foreign market ads. The account, which represents more than $6 million worth of billings, will be handled by D.D.B.'s Los Angeles office.

title: Tax Debacle
description: Conferees from the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee are about to begin the laborious task of reconciling two markedly different tax bills, one passed by the House of Representatives last December and the other by the Senate in August. The House bill was a modest victory for liberal tax reformers; the Senate measure is the usual fruitcake full of sweet things for the special interests that have good connections with certain members of the Finance Committee.

title: Patients Defend Physician Charged in Hepatitis Cases
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23  More than 50 patients of Dr. Peter D. DeMarco gathered at the State Capitol today to demand that the Camden physician be permitted to continue injecting them with a compound he manufactures.

title: Youth, 17, Captures 3 Sprints
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 23 (UPI) Keith Brown of Baltimore took individual honors at the National Junior Olympics that ended today by becoming the first athlete in the 10year history of the event to win three gold medals.

title: Taming Szechwan Food In Hashbrown Country
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont Twicecooked pork, tempura and bagelsto name just three of the more exotic itemsare starting to warm hearts and stomachs in meatandpotatoes country.

title: Miss Greer Leads Field
description: Special to The New York Times

title: P.U.C. Examiners Favor Telephone Rate Increases
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23Telephone rate increases and new directory assistance call charges were recommended today for New Jersey Bell Telephone by two hearing examiners of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioner, who also proposed a special discount rate for the poor and the elderly.

title: State Sues Poultry Farmers on Migrant Labor Abuses
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23The Department of Labor and Industry sued poultry farmers in Hunterdon and Salem Counties today, charging illegal exploitation of employees.

title: EDWARD A. PRETTYMAN
description: Edward A. Prettyman, a band conductor and music teacher in Baltimore, died Saturday of cancer at the North Charles General Hospital there. He was 73 years old.

title: SHIFT WILL ADD TO CON ED BILLS
description: Private customers of the Consolidated Edison Company will see a new cost added to their electricity bills in the fall when the City of New York and other public entities drop out as Con Edison customers and begin to buy their power from state sources.

title: Valentino Fans Mark Anniversary of Death
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 23, (Reuters)A thousand Rudolph Valentino fans, including one old veiled woman reviving the legend of the mysterious woman in black packed into a narrow marble mausoleum today to mark the 50th anniversary of the silentfilm star's death.

title: BANGLADESH TRYING A DUTCH JOURNALIST
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 23 (Reulers)Peter Custers, a Dutch freelance journalist and development aid worker detained by the Bangladesh authorities since last December, was due to be tried by a special martial law tribunal in Dacca today, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: Sylvan, Gottfried Gain
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Continental Raises Dividend
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, holding company for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, increased its quarterly dividend yesterday to 60 cents from 58 cents a share, payable Nov. 1 to holders of record Sept. 30.

title: Mr. Chase's Convention WrapUp
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif.  During Rocky's speech, delegates had been celebrating the Year of the Pig and Mardi Gras at the same time. Worse still, contagion grew to epidemic proportions when a pretty girl walked in on Jake's plea for the less fortunate; the less wise. It was Jerry's turn.

title: Oil Shale Program Of U.S. in Colorado Suspended for Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe, at the request of oil companies involved in the project, suspended for one year today the Government's prototype oil shale development program in Colorado.

title: 2 Soviet Players in Lead Of the U.S. Chess Open
description: FAIRFAX, Va. Aug. 23 (AP) Grandmasters Anatoly Lein and Leonid Shamkovich of the Soviet Union, with 6 points each, are tied for the lead in the United States Open Chess Championship being held at George Mason University here.

title: CORRECTION
description: The names and affiliation of three medical researchers who contributed to diabetes research were inadvertently omitted from an article in The Times on Thursday. They are Dr. Anthony Ceram!, Dr. Robert L. Jones and Ronald J. Koenig, all of Rockefeller University.

title: Carter Tells Film Stars About Poverty in South
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (UPI)  Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, told leaders of the entertainment world about going 200 yards from his Georgia home and finding people so poor that they could not afford a doctor.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mary Bass Is Wed to A. C. Newlin
description: Mary Carson Bass Gibson, widow of George Rollings Gibson, was married yesterday afternoon at her summer home in Amagansett, L. I., to A. Chauncey Newlin, a widower and a senior partner in the New York law firm of White & Case.

title: SHIFT WILL ADD TO CON ED BILLS
Davis, the Wayward Jet, Welcomed Back by Holtz
description: Steve Davis, the prodigal halfback, returned yesterday to the Jets training camp, admitted he made a mistake when he went AWOL on July 20 and was welcomed back by Coach Lou Holtz.

title: and a Science Court
description: The importance of science in the shaping of public policy is underscored by increasing interest in the idea of a science court to help decide controversial issues whose technical factors may be beyond comprehension by laymen. Dr. Stever has indicated interest in the concept. As Presidential science adviser he will play a key role in the ultimate decision whether such a court should be experimentally established.

title: JOYCE ILLIG DIES; WEEKLY COLUMNIST
description: Joyce Illig Bohn, who wrote a weekly column on book publishing for The Washington Post, died Sunday of a heart attack at her home, 201 East 79th Street. She was 36 years old.

title: Sets Beat Gaters, Lead in Series, 20
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 23 Blasting off to a 121 lead in the first two sets, the New York Sets took an iron grip on the World Tennis championship tonight by beating the Golden Gaters, 2921, for a 20 lead in the threeoffive series. All the remaining matches will be played on New York's home court, the Nassau Coliseum, on Friday, and, if necessary, next Monday and Tuesday.

title: Shapp Promotes Philadelphia By Moving Into Legion Hotel
description: PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 23 (UPI)Gov. Milton J. Shapp, seeking to change the bad name he said Philadelphia had received since the mysterious legionnaire disease, checked into the Bellevue Stratford Hotel today, which was the headquarters for the state American Legion convention.

title: Los Angeles Bus Drivers And Mechanics On Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (UPI) Bus drivers and mechanics today went on strike for the second time in two years against the country's fourthlargest mass transportation system, forcing 760,000 commuters to find other means of transportation.

title: Helping New York
description: Wallie Simpson looked around the enormous, sparsely furnished old classroom and said, As you can see, as new school we are starting from scratch and there are many things we simply cannot afford.

title: People in Sports
description: Finding themselves loaded with talented young running backs, but decimated by injuries to linebackers, the Miami Dolphins waived the speedy 30yearold Eugene (Mercury) Morris, their second leading career rusher, yesterday and disclosed they had asked Nick Buoniconti, a 35yearold linebacker, to come out of retirement.

title: House Will Confer With Senate For Compromise on Tax Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The House agreed today to meet with the Senate in an attempt to compromise their differences on tax legislation for the fiscal year 1977, including proposals to permanently extend current tax cuts for individuals and businesses.

title: Follower of Rev. Moon Falls to Death
description: A 23yearold member of the Unification Church plunged to his death early yesterday from the 22d floor of the New Yorker Hotel.

title: Drugs Are Linked To Slaying of Five In St. Louis Suburb
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (UPI) The slaying of five persons in a quiet, predominantly black suburb in north St. Louis County may have been related to the sale of narcotics, the police said today.

title: DOW IS OFF 2.58; 4TH STRAIGHT DIP
description: The stock market dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive session with the Dow Jones industrial average off 2.58 points to 971.49, its lowest close in almost three months. In the last four sessions, it has tumbled 27.85 points.

title: Average Yields Decline At Treasury Bill Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Highway Projects Planned for Year In New York City
description: Long stretches of Union Turnpike in Queens, Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn and Eastchester Road in the Bronx are among the major resurfacing and rehabilitation projects in its current program, the New York City Highways Department said yesterday.

title: Papp Halves New Season at Beaumont
Oyster Bay Harbor Jittery After Shark Sightings
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 23 Just about anything floating in the harbor here today old tires, beer cans, a piece of driftwoodlooked like a shark fin.

title: PRISONERS STAGE STRIKE AT ATTICA
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Aug. 23  Most of the inmates at Attica prison refused to leave their cells today in a peaceful protes, against conditions and to press for negotiations with the state on a list of nine demands.

title: Cadets Are Shaken by OneYear Expulsion Plan
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 23  Cadet Stephen Ferris snapped out of a fitful sleep at 6 o'clock this morning with the realization that this Would be the most fateful day of his life.

title: OPEC Experts Weigh Prices Of Oil at Closed Talks in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Experts from oilexporting countries today began a week of studies here that could bring the world closer to a new rise in oil prices.

title: No Notice Of Big Brother
description: Republican oratory at Kansas City. and the Republican platform adopted at the national convention seemed to leave no doubt at all that the Grand Old Party and the FordDole ticket were opposed to big government. But are they? A leisurely perusal of the platform confirms one man's memory of most of the oratory; there was no opposition in Kansas City to the biggest government of allgovernment by snoops, spooks, taps and plumbers.

title: No Mars Life Signs Reported in 2d Viking Test
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)A Viking 1 instrument looking for organic material on Mars found nothing in a second test that would indicate life forms had been there in the past, a project biologist said today.

title: EGYPTIAN PLANE SEIZED BY ARABS, THEN RECAPTURED
description: CAIRO, Aug. 23An Egyptian airliner with more than 100 people aboard was seized by Arab guerrillas this morning shortly after takeoff from Cairo but was recaptured by Government commandos this afternoon at an airport in southern Egypt.

title: EGYPTIAN AIRLINER SEIZED BY ARABS
description: whereupon he was allowed to land at Luxor.

title: Notes on People
description: Clyde J. Wingfield, 45 years old, president of Baruch College since 1971, is going to the University of Miami Nov. 1 as provost and executive vice president for academic affairs. His resignation is the first among presidents of the City University's nine senior colleges since the full onset of the university's financial crisis.

title: JENO KENESSEY
description: BUDAPEST, Aug. 23 (AP) Jeno Kenessey, composer, has died at the age of 71, the official Hungarian press agency reported today.

title: Gold, Down $2.40, Closes At Its Lowest in 32 Months
description: Prices of gold bullion were sent to their lowest levels in 32 months yesterday by dispirited traders on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: New Tiger Shows Label Doesn't Fit
description: Good field, no hit. That succinct scouting report on the desk of any major league club's general manager usually was the kiss of death to the ambitions of many minor league players.

title: Foreman to Fight Dennis Sept. 17
description: George Foreman, former heavyweight boxing champion, will fight the undefeated New England champion, Dino Dennis, in a 10round bout in Miami Beach on Sept. 17, Don King, the promoter, announced here last night.

title: LAW ISSUE RAISED ON CARTER DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The televised debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter, as planned by the League of Women Voters, may be illegal under the new campaign law.

title: AMAX UNIT RAISES PRICE OF A METAL
description: The Climax Molybdenum Company, a division of Amax Inc., announced yesterday a 10 percent increase in the price of molybdenum, exclusive of the cost of containers.denum is used principally in production of regular and stainless steel and as a catalyst in the petroleum industry. The increase, effective immediately, is a result of heavy capital expenditures required to increase the supply of molybdenum, the company said. Climax cited the $400 million it spent in construction of the Henderson mine in Colorado and $34 million for pollution control and facilities at conversion plants and minesite reclamation.

title: Brazilian Shoe Exports Are Forging a Market in U.S.
description: NOVO HAMBURGO, Brazil, Aug. 18Ten years ago, a local shoe manufacturer, Claudio Strassburger, took a suitcase of samples to New York in a quixotic attempt to convince United States shoe salesmen of the Merits of Brazilian footwear.

title: James Olds Dead; Found Rats' Brains Hard Pleasure Site
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)Dr. James Olds, a behavioral biologist credited with the discovery of pleasure centers in the brains of rats, died accidentally on Saturday while swimming in the ocean on a vacation at Laguna Beach. He was 54 years old.

title: PRISONERS STAGE STRIKE AT ATTICA
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Aug. 23  Most of the inmates at Attica prison refused to leave their cells today, in a peaceful protest against conditions and to press for negotiations with the state on a list of nine demands.

title: LAW ISSUE RAISED ON CARTER DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The televised debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter, as planned by the League of Women Voters, may be illegal under the new campaign law.

title: Luna 24 Is Back With Moon Soil Sample
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (Reuters) The Soviet Union announced today that it had brought back to earth the first sample of soil from the moon's mysterious and previously unexplored Sea of Crises.

title: Lunch Sponsors in 75 Inquiry Still Involved in 1976 Program
description: Nearly all of the nonprofit organizations that have been under Federal investigation for suspicion of fraudulent activity in the 1975 Summer Food Service Program for children in New York City are now sponsors of food distribution sites in the 1976 program, according to state and Federal documents.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SUIT AGAINST MS.
description: A $1.7 million Federal lawsuit brought against Ms. magazine by one of its founders has been dismissed, the magazine announced yesterday.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The Ford Administration is engaged in protracted and intricate negotiations with more than a dozen nations to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. At the same time, critics of these efforts have become more vocal, charging that the Administration's nonproliferation diplomacy is too little and too late.

title: 50 Patients Ask Continued Treatment By Doctor Charged in Hepatitis Cases
description: TRENTONAug. 23More than 50 patients of Dr. Peter D. DeMarco gathered at the State Capitol today to demand that the Camden physician be permitted to continue injecting them with a compound lie manufactures.

title: Old Salts Anchor At a New Harbor
Francis Maguire, 64, Dies; A Poet, Lyricist and Actor
description: Francis T. Maguire, a poet, lyricist and offBroadway actor, died Saturday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, First Avenue at 23d Street. He was 64 years old and lived at 121 Clinton Street.

title: Books of The Times
description: I have been trying to decide whether Ann Beattie's stories are good, or only fashionable. After some painfulit was painfuldeliberation, I came to the conclusion that they are both, but that she could, and ought to, make them better.

title: Ousted Cadets Offered Chance to Reapply After a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  Secretary of the Army Martin R. Hoffmann intervened today in the West Point cheating scandal by offering guilty cadets who have been ousted the chance to reapply for admission after a oneyear period of reflection, preferably on active service as enlisted men.

title: S.I. Children's Museum a Community Affair
description: Small bands of 9 to 12 yearolds have been roaming Staten Island this summer, making sculptures on the beaches or constructing Bedouin villages out of string And cloth in the parks. The hub of all this activity is a dusty storefront on Beach Street in Stapleton. In the window a giant brown paper sign, painstakingly lettered and colored, by Mary Beth Pryor, 9, and Tish Hockenberry, 8, announces to the world: The Children of Staten Island Have a Museum.

title: For Sale: Lincoln's Farm, At $5 Per Square Inch
description: SPRINGFIELD, Illinois, Aug. 23 (Reuters)Abraham Lincoln's farm is for saleone square inch at a time.

title: Burma Shuns Aid in Repairing Devastated Shrines
description: PAGAN, Burma  With painful slowness, while monsoon torrents continually wash away mortar, exposing ancient temples to the danger of collapse and threatening to crumble irreplaceable wall paintings 800 years old, Burma is setting about the repair of its unique royal city of Pagan.

title: G.M. REVAMPING IN JERSEY URGED
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) Some 300 General Motors dealers in New Jersey, charging the state has too many G.M. car outlets, have threatened to call for a Congressional investigation unless the company agrees to restructure its franchise network.

title: Rubin Carter Facing One Less Charge
description: The Maryland State's Attorney's office has decided not to press charges against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter on an assault  and  battery complaint filed by the former chairman of his defense committee.

title: Only a HoHum Murder
description: The gangsters Sam Giancana and John Roselli who were associated with the C.I.A. in a scheme to dispatch Fidel Castro have now both been murdered after discussing their C.I.A. enterprise with the United States Senate, and the police have pronounced the incidents ganglandstyle killings.

title: Hose Votes Ban on Output Of PCB's Within 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 23The House voted tonight to ban within three years the manufacture of PCB's, a class of chemical that has been linked to cancer and birth defects, water pollution and the contamination of wildlife.

title: Knick, Ranger Executives Get Ears Full of Fans' Opinions
description: It pays to advertise.

title: SENATE RATIFIES COFFEE AGREEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 23 (UPI) The Senate, by a vote of 75 to 0, today ratified an international coffee agreement and extended through 1978 a treaty governing foreign wheat sales.

title: Bilker Gets 5Year Term
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23 (UPI) Arthur H. Rushforth of Havertown, Pa., who admitted he had devised an elaborate scheme to bilk life insurance companies of more than $350,000, was sentenced today to five years in prison by Judge Vincent J. Biunno in Federal District Court.

title: Ousted Cadets Offered Chance to Reapply After a Year
Syria Says Several Are Held In Bombings in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 23 (AP)  Syrian officials Said today that several terrorists had been arrested in connection with a wave of bombings in Damascus and would almost certainly be hanged after, a court martial. Those arrested were believed to be radical Palestinians.

title: In the Lush Southern Sudan, Reconstruction Is a Slow Process
description: JUBA, the Sudan, Aug. 17 At dusk the vultures retire to huddle in the treetops 40 feet above the terrace of the Juba Hotel. The hawks still circle listlessly in the torpid currents rising up from the foliage.

title: DARA AND WILSON AT THE TIN PALACE
description: Olu Dara, the trumpeter, and Phillip Wilson, the drummer, performed as a duo at the Tin Palace on Sunday, and although the spare instrumentation did not seem to hold much promise, the music was remarkable.

title: For Stores, It's the Year Of the Face Lift
description: A young New York couple walked into Bonwit Teller recently, took one look at the store and walked out to find out if they were in the right place. To their shocked eyes, it looked more like a subway stop than a Fifth Avenue store.

title: Glowing Tribute, $5, Scores on Spa Turf
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP)Rokeby Stable's Glowing Tribute won the 38th running of the $54,850 Diana Handicap on the turf at Saratoga today, breaking alertly from an outside post position and leading all the way.

title: Cab on Curb Scatters Strollers at City Hall
description: A lurching taxicab with an allegedly tipsy driver mounted a curb outside City Hall yesterday and sent pedestrians scurrying for safety before bumping to a halt a few feet from the southeast corner of City Hall.

title: U.S. Softens Its Reaction To North Korea Regrets
House Votes Ban on Output Of PCB's Within 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The House Voted tonight to ban within three years the manufacture of PCB's, a class of chemical that has been linked to cancer and birth defects, water pollution and the contamination of wildlife.

title: Animal Medical Center Seeks to Cure Fiscal Ills
description: After an operation that took almost three hours, a team of doctors stared intently at a set of Xrays that showed a fractured leg they had repaired. They had attached to the bone a stainless steel plate that would enable the patient to walk immediately, before the break was healed.

title: Mrs. Abzug's Pace Is Hectic in Westchester
description: YONKERS, Aug. 23Representative Bella Abzug's day of campaigning for the Democratic Senate nomination began this morning with taping radio program in Westchester County, during which she told interviewers she was running for the Senate because the voters deserve the best.

title: White Parents in Yonkers Planning Separate School
EGYPTIAN PLANE SEIZED BY ARABS, THEN RECAPTURED
description: CAIRO, Aug. 23An Egyptian airliner with more than 100 people aboard was seized by Arab guerrillas this morning shortly after takeoff from Cairo but was recaptured by Government commandos this afternoon at an airport in southern Egypt.

title: An Early Bird Gets Herself a Name
description: LYNDHURST, N.J., Aug. 23George Woertz's first pigeon came home at 12:44 PM., landing with a sudden thump on the platform outside the loft where she and 74 stablemates live. She looked a little groggy as she took a few steps and disappeared through a trap door toward the food and water inside the loft. Woertz had been waiting for his racers since noon in yesterday's heat wave, relaxing in a deck chair alongside the loft on the roof of his backYard garage. Now he quickly slipped a rubberband countermark off the first finisher's leg, inserted it into a sealed clock and turned the handle that would record the bird's precise arrival time. In the first race of her life, the 4 monthold future champion had just flown 117.3 miles from Lime Ridge, Pa., the startingpoint for a youngbird competition involving 500 novice contestants from 39 lofts in the Lyndhurst Homing Pigeon Club.

title: NEW CANCER TEST CALLED LESS RISKY
description: A new Xray machine that will be marketed soon may greatly reduce the amount of radiation used in detecting breast cancer. The Associated Press reported today.

title: Burleson Player of Week
description: Rick Burleson, the Boston Red Sox shortstop, who was moved into the leadoff spot, responded with 17 hits and a 472 average last week an won unanimous selection as the American League player of the week, President Lee MacPhail announced yesterday.

title: 2 AT THE TIMES GET SENIOR EDITING JOBS
Beirut Attack Repulsed, Moslems Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23 Rightwing Christian militiamen reportedly struck into Moslemheld western Beirut today, and Palestinian and Lebanese Moslem reinforcements were rushed to the area by truck and jeep.

title: Paul Jankowski, U.N. Aide Who Served in Congo, Dies
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23Paul Jankowski, a Polish official of the United Nations who was its spokesman in Leopoldville, now Kinshasa, during the Congo crisis early in the 1960's, died at Cabrini Health Care Center, 227 East 19th Street, yesterday. He was 64 years old and had been ailing for some time.

title: TRW to Redeem Debentures
description: TRW Inc. said yesterday it would redeem on Oct. 1 all of its outstanding $345,000 principal amount of 4 percent subordinated debentures due Aug. 1, 1982, at 100 percent of their principal amounts plus accrued interest at $8.13 for each $1,000 principal amount to the redemption date. Interest on the debentures will cease to accrue after Oct. 1.

title: Major League Leaders
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE BATTING

title: WALTER KRINSKY
description: Walter Krinsky, president of the Neil A. Walters Realty Corporation in Mineola, L.I., died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Woodmere, L.I. He was 51 years old.

title: Samuel M. Hacker; Of Federal Agency For Mediation, Dies
description: Samuel M. Hacker, for 16 years a commissioner of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, died yesterday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 19 Stuyvesant Oval.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: Advertising
description: With most new purchasers of color television sets today already owners of one, how does a manufacturer advertise to reach this market?

title: Koala Bears Require Forest of Eucalyptas
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 23 (UPI)  Australia's Bicentennial gift to the United States, six koala bears, have required the planting of 30,000 eucalyptus trees at the San Diego Zoo to provide a continuing supply of food.

title: Uniform U.S. Index Offered to Measure Air Pollution Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The 35 largest cities in the United States use at least 14 different scales for measuring air pollution, so a Federal panel today offered a single new index for the nation.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the country's top women players led a team of young experts to victory in the summer Swiss team championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday night.

title: Aerospace Contracts, Put at $1 Billion, Hinge on Debate Over Space Shuttles
description: Potential aerospace contracts valued at about $1 billion are hanging in the balance as officials in Washington debate the completion of the nation's space shuttle program.

title: U.S. Confident Armies in Korea Are Prepared to Handle Any Attack
description: Planning and operation officers in the Defense Department are confident about the United States military position in South Korea and the capabilities for early and powerful reinforcement in the event of war.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, Aug. 23, 1976

title: TV: 2 British Shows Carry On Wacky Tradition
description: For all their supposed reserve, the British are a curiously giddy lot when they wrestle with television comedy. They have developed a strain of uncompromising wackiness that goes back at least as far as the goon show, a tidy bundle of lunacy that began on radio with Spike Milligan and Peter Sellers. In ironic turn, a good many of the British roots might be traced to earlier years of American film, to the routines of Chaplin, Keaton, Laurel and Hardy, the Marx Brothers, even the Ritz Brothers.

title: Sunday Opening List At Korvettes Grows
description: In an expansion of its Sunday operations, Korvette, the second  largest retailer in the metropolitan area after R. H. Macy and Company, opened 22 of its 23 stores on Sunday to good reaction and solid business, the company said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: The names and affiliation of three medical researchers who contributed to diabetes research were inadvertently omitted from an article in The Times on Thursday. They are Dr. Anthony Cerami, Dr. Robert L. Jones and Ronald J. Koenig, all of Rockefeller University.

title: ALAN A. WELLS
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Postal Unit Plans Inquiry on Profit In Land Purchase
description: MIAMI, Aug. 23 (AP) A United States Postal Service official says that an investigation will be opened into the agency's purchase of a sixacre building site for $575,200 just four days after the seller bought the same property for $350,000.

title: Quake Aftershocks Felt in Philippines And in Szechwan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (UPI)The second strong earthquake in two days jolted Szechwan Province in south central China today and the Philippine Islands experienced a major aftershock of the Aug. 17 quake that left 8,000 persons dead or missing.

title: U.S. BLACKS MEET ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A delegation of black Americans urged Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today to communicate to South Africa in the strongest terms America's opposition to the racial policies thax have led to several weeks ofrioting and more than 250 deaths.

title: SOYBEANS CLIMB ON LACK OF RAIN
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) The lack of forecast rainfall and continuing high temperatures, strongly influenced higher prices for soybean and grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

title: Business Briefs
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 23 (UPI)Bank employees in Ireland today ended their eightweekold strike that had closed the country's four major commercial banks. A spokesman for the 10,000 striking employees said they were prepared to resume work tomorrow.

title: Crash Kills Jersey Youth
description: OLD BRIDGE, N. J., Aug. 23 (AP)  A 17yearold English town youth, Rich Keiahor, was killed today when the car in which he was riding ran off a road here and hit a tree, th police said. They withheid the name of the driver, who was injured in the crash, and said the accident was under investigation.

title: WEEKEND BOXING
description: BUENOS AIRES, ArgentinaVictor Galindez, Argentina, outpointed Billy Douglas. Columbus, Ohio. 10 rounds, light heavyweights.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Unusual night hearings will be held next month when the state's Public Service Commission begins hearing testimony on the Consolidated Edison Company's request for $250 million increase in electric rates. The commission chairman, Alfred Kahn, said yesterday that hearings would open at 7:30 P.M. on Sept. 22 in the 44th floor hearing room at 2 World Trade Center in New York City. Mr. Kahn said late last year that the commission would break tradition by ordering night hearings in a Long Island Lighting Company electricrate case, but he noted that he would not routinely schedule afterhour hearitigs in all cases.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 24, 1976

title: SOUTH AFRICAN, AIDE DENIES STATEMENTS
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 23 Justice Minister James T. Kruger said today that he was quoted out of context over remarks he was reported to have made last week about the status of S'uth Africa's black population.

title: MADDOX IS RUNNING FOR WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)  In a tiny hotel press room, crowded with reporters, television technicians and backers from the rightwing Liberty Lobby, Lester G. Maddox announced today that he was running for President again.

title: Government and Corporate Bonds Up; TaxExempt Market Is Unchanged
description: Prices improved slightly yesterday in quiet trading in the Government and corporate bond markets. The taxexempt market was unchanged in equally quiet trading.Facing a particularly light week insofar as new offerings are concerned, credit market participants are not looking for any pronounced changes. As the Continental Bank in Chicago noted in its weekly letter: Lethargic credit demands and a stable, moderate Federal Reserve policy in recent weeks indicate there will be little change in interest rates in the immediate future.

title: WILLIAM O. MOSS
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Aug. 23 (AP)William O. Moss, owner of MileAway Farm, a horse training and breeding operation and home of the Moore County Hunt, died yesterday at his weekend cottage at nearby Lake Surf. He was 73 years old

title: Six Killed in Auto Crash
description: BALSAM LAKE, Wis. Aug. 23 (UPI)Six persons, including four members of Minnesota family, were killed yesterday when two cars collided head on and burst into flames on U.S. 8 southwest of Balsam Lake.

title: Market Place
description: Disney's just hit a new low! a stockbroker sang out in a midManhattan boardroom Friday.

title: Labor Talks at Music Hall Intensified
description: Intensive negotiations were held yesterday and last night between Radio City Music Hall and its Rockettes in an effort to reach a contract agreement that would forestall a threatened shutdown of the theater.

title: Forest Fire Eludes Control
description: GRAND MARAIS, Minn., Aug. 23 (AP)About 400 firefighters made little progress today in trying to contain a forest fire that was burning along a 10mile front in extreme northern Minnesota. A wind of 15 miles an hour was hampering the firemen. The blaze has burned more than 2,165 acres. The authorities said the fire, which started Saturday, was probably caused by lightning.

title: Sun Oil Increases Price of Distillates By Centa Gallon
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had increased the price of all grades of distillates by  cent a gallon in 17 Eastern states and the District of Columbia. Theproducts involved include Nos. 1 and 2 fuel oil, diesel fuel, heating oil and kerosene. The company said also it had increased the retail price of heating oil by 0.4 cents to 0.5 cents a gallon.

title: Asked to Close Buren
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Libya asked Egypt today to close its diplomatic bureau in Benghazi, Libya's joint capital with Tripoli, the official press agency ARNA said. The move was in retaliation for Egypt's decision to close the Alexandria bureau of the Libyan diplomatic mission in Egypt the agency said.

title: British Cabinet Meets on Drought Threat
description: LONDON, Aug. 24  Prime Minister James Callaghan called an emergency Cabinet meeting today as the country's worst drought on record threatened to disrupt the economy. There were predictions that workers in some industries faced layoffs or a threeday work week.

title: Two Companies Fined by Goldin For Lag on StreetLight Repairs
description: The two private companies that maintain New York City's street lights have been penalized a total of $738,000 by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin after an audit found that they were not making timely replacements of burnedout and broken lights and were tardy in other repair work.

title: GOODYEAR AGREES ON LABOR ACCORD
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP)  The United Rubber Workers and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reached a tegtative agreement today on a threeyear contract providing a 36 percent wage increase.

title: Pastore Bars Move To Help Networks On Carter Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Senator John O. Pastore, who sponsored the bill that cleared the way for the 1960 debates between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon, declined requests today from two television networks that he sponsor a similar bill this year.

title: $1 Million Overtime Fraud Laid to Elevator Repairers
description: Nearly a third of the employees of the New York City Housing Authority's elevator repair division were accused yesterday of cheating the city out of more than $1 million a year in fraudulent overtime claims.

title: Currency Study Includes Everything but Wooden Nickels
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Nobody's suggested wooden nickels, but short of that almost anything is fair game for studies of the size, shape and denomination of the currency of the future.

title: STRIKE AND TALKS CO ON AT ATTICA
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 24The strike at Attica prison entered its second day today with most inmates remaining in their cells as their appointed leaders met throughout the day with correction officials in an effort to reach agreement on several lists of demands.

title: 3 Americans on Trial in Soviet Plead Guilty to Heroin Charge
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24Three Americans pleaded guilty in Moscow court today to heroin smuggling in an incident marking the latest phase of a Soviet crackdown on narcotics traffickers who have been using Moscow as a transit point from Asia to Western Europe.

title: POLL SHOWS SLIDE IN CARTER MARGIN
description: The first public opinion poll to be released since the close of the Republican National Convention shows Jimmy Cartier with a 9point lead over President Ford, considerably narrower than the lead of 30 points or more that he was found to have immediately after he won the Democratic nomination last month.

title: Consumer Unit Fights Bid To Redefine Word Meat
description: A Department of Agriculture proposal to redefine the word meat to include pure fat and a mixture of crushed bone and bits of flesh was condemned yesterday by a consumer group as an attempt to adulterate the food supply in order to enrich the meat industry.

title: MTH AFRICAPLAN TO FREE TERRITORY CRITICIZED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The State Department said today that the latest move by South Africa to grant SouthWest Africa independence by the end of 1978 was a step in the right direction, but that it did not go far enough to meet American and United Nations demands.

title: Citizens Band Incidents Lead to the Jailing of 2
description: Incidents involving the operation of citizens band radios have resulted in the jailing of two upstate men, one on a charge of manslaughter, the other of allegedly using racial slurs and vulgar, obscene language.

title: A's Win and Gain As Royals Falter
description: The outspoken Oakland A's have been saying all along that the Kansas City Royals would fold under the pressure of the division race in the American League's Western Division.

title: New Seattle Club Named Mariners
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 24 (AP)The city's American League baseball expansion franchise got a name today  the Seattle Mariners.

title: L.I. Atom Plant Hearing Begins on Subdued Note
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 24In marked contrast to the emotional public hearings that preceded the approval of Long Island's first nuclear power plant, hearings into a proposed second plant got under way in relative calm today.

title: GRAINS ARE DOWN ON PROFIT TAKING
Higher Saudi Production Held Key to Supply
description: The world may be heading for a shortterm oilsupply shortage as well as a significant increase in prices within the next year, according to a study by the London office of Walter J. Levy, the influential oil economist.

title: Report Disfavors Ford's Plan for Synthetics; G.A.O. Suggests Importing More Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24A Congressional agency suggested today that importing more oil might be a better national policy than enacting Administration proposals for Federal financial aid to highcost privately owned synthetic  fuel projects.

title: Restored Homes Bring New Look to Old Newport, R.I.
description: NEWPORT, R. I.Some years ago, so the story goes, Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, was having tea with Mrs. Katherine Warren, founder of the Preservation Society Newport County. Miss Duke was interested in doing some preservation work of her own, bid she was concerned about overlapping with the existing organization. Finally, she turned to Mrs. Warren and said, All right, Katherine, you take the 19th century and I'll take the 18th,

title: Guam Governor Signs Law Protecting News Sources
description: AGANA, Guam, Aug. 24 (AP)  Gov. Richardo Bordallo of Guam signed into law today a bill guaranteeing that newsmen will not have to disclose their confidential sources.

title: No.Amer.SoccerLeague
description: SEMIFINAL ROUND Toronto 2, Tampa Bav 0.

title: Bass Is Interim Director
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 24 (AP)  James Bass, swimming coach at Tennessee State University, has been named interim athletic director, effective Sept. 1. He will hold the post until a replacement is found for Howard Gentry, who has announced his retirement, effective Aug. 31.

title: POWER AUTHORITY IS FOUND HEALTHY
description: The Power Authority of New York State is in strong financial health, as shown by increasing net operating revenues despite continued low rates for its electricity and despite its annual early repayment of debt, according to State Comptroller Arthur Levitt.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Improving U. S. Policy Methods
description: PLAINS, Ga.Jimmy Carter doesn't pretend the foreign policy planks of either political party represent mandates laying down an international program to be followed by the next elected President. He contends: No administration can completely adopt the platform drawn up by its party. After all, I didn't control the Democratic platform committee. I cannot blindly accept all of it.

title: Go North, Young Franchise
description: Red Smith

title: In New German Attitude on Family Life, Many Couples Decide to Forgo Children
description: BONN, Aug. 24.Theo and Agnes Rohl, both 35 years old and in perfect health, are childless. They work, take frequent vacations and are used to living well.

title: LIVELY SOUL PLAYED BY AVERAGE WHITES
description: The Average White Band's name, while assumed in jest, raises serious questions. As the rock writer Stephen Holden recently pointed out, the idea that it takes only an average white band to play convincing soul music is both offensive and inaccurate. In point of fact, the Average White Band is not entirely white, although six of its seven members are Scotsmen. Nor is it average. In fact, it is one of the tightest, bestsounding performing bands purveying urban street funk.

title: Sales of Cars Flat In Middle of August; Short Supply Cited
Gantt, Punter, 4 Others Are Cut Loose by Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 24 Greg Gantt, who kicked the ball more than 2 miles in two seasons with the Jets, but not far enough, was one of five players cut by the National Football League team today.

title: Prices Off on Amex And Counter List In Modest Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished lower yesterday in moderate trading.

title: About New York
description: Keeping this column warm while the first team is away doing whatever first teams do during the dog days of August in Sag Vineyard or Martha's Hampton means answering a lot of strange telephone calls and opening a lot of strange mail.

title: Rep. Howe Guilty in Sex Case At 2d Trial in Salt Lake City
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 24 Representative Allan T. How was found guilty today in his second trial on charges of soliciting sex acts for hire from two Salt Lake police decoys. A jury of five men and thred women took less than onehalf hour to reach its verdict following a twoday trial in the court of second District Judge Bryant H. Croft.

title: Wrong Suspension
description: Secretary of the Army Martin Hoffmann, in responding to the West Point cheating scandal, has proposed that cadets guilty of cheating be allowed to reapply for admission to the Military Academy after a year's reflection, preferably while serving as enlisted men in the Army. This suggested relaxation of the automatic expulsion rule that is traditionally invoked against any cadet found in violation of the Honor Code has instantly been attacked as inadequate by the accused cadets and their Army lawyersand with good reason.

title: Rites for Two Officers Slain in Korea Held at West Point and Columbia, S.C.
description: WEST POINT, N. Y, Aug. 24 Maj. Arthur G. Bonifas was buried here today with full military honors six days after his murder by North Korean soldiers in a demilitarized zone and seven days before he was to have returned home to his wife and three children.

title: About Real Estate
description: Communal organization among American homeowners cannot be called something new, but it is spreading at a growing rate.

title: Israel Praises Egypt For Recapturing Airliner
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 (UPI) Israel today issued rare praise for Egypt and the courageous Egyptian commando raid that freed passengers from a hijacked jet in Luxor yesterday.

title: McCarthy in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 24 (AP)Eugene J. McCarthy brought his independent Presidential campaign to Hartford today. The former Democratic Senator from Minnesota needs 15,000 petition signatures by Monday to appear on the November ballot in Connecticut. This morning he toured downtown Hartford.

title: Restored Homes Bring New Look to Old Newport, R.I.
description: NEWPORT, R. I.Some years ago, so the story goes, Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, was having tea with Katherine Warren, founder of the Preservation Society of Newport County. Miss Duke was interested in doing some preservation work of her own, but she was concerned about overlapping with the existing organization. Finally, she turned to Mrs. Warren and said, All right, Katherine, you take the 19th century and I'll take the 18th.

title: SENATE UNIT BARS NOMINEE TO T.V.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)The Senate Public Works Committee again rejected today a Presidential choice to fill a vacancy on the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Man Lost in River Plunge
description: BRIELLE, N.J., Aug. 24 (AP) Authorities failed to recover the body of a 20yearold Point Pleasant man, James H. Wells, who jumped off the VictoryMemorial Bridge into the Manasquan River here today. The police said that Mr. Wells and a companion were crossing the bridge when Mr. Wells decided to jump, saying he had always wanted to try it.

title: Advertising
description: Borden Inc., the nation's 57th largest national advertiser, will spend around $50 million for advertising in 1976. But this year's total will include a project that it has never attempted before and that surpasses previous efforts of this kind.

title: People in Sports
description: Denis Potvin, the New York Islanders allstar, had a very busy day yesterday. First the 22yearold winner of last season's Norris Trophy as the best defenseman in the National Hockey League took part in a morning workout with Team Canada. Then he flew to New York with his wife, Debbie, to sign a fiveyear contract with the Islanders. After a quick lunch at a news conference at Gallagher's to mark the occasion, he flew back to Montreal. From there he was to go to Quebec City, where Team Canada was scheduled to play an exhibition against USA rast night.

title: U.S. Friends Worried About Writer Held in Ghana
description: Dr. Kofi Awoonor, a writer of world stature, is currently being tried in his homeland of Ghana for harboring the alledged ringleader of an antigovernment plot. Five persons have already been sentenced to death.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PLAN TO FREE TERRITORY CRITICIZED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The State Department said today that the latest move by South Africa to grant SouthWest Africa independence by the end of 1978 was a step in the right direction, but that it did not go far enough to meet American and United Nations demands.

title: Brazil's Man of Vision
description: The death in an auto crash of Brazil's Juscelino Kubitschek de Oliveira at 73 removes from the Latin American scene not only one of the more colorful political figures of recent times but a man of formidable accomplishments. Against heavy opposition and even ridicule, President Kubitschek doggedly pursued his dream of moving Brazil's capital into the interior600 miles west of Rio de Janeiro.

title: JAWORSKI TELLS OF PLEA BY NIXON
Giants Deal Dawkins, Tackle to Oilers
description: PLEASANTVILLE. N.Y., Aug. 24He had led the Giants in rushing the last two years but Joe Dawkins was expecting it when Coach Bill Arnsparger told him today, we got you a job.

title: California Enacts a Law to Control Development Along 1,000Mile Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24A sweeping law for permanent control of development along California's 1,000mile coastline was enacted by the California State Legislature last night after eight months of arduous political haggling.

title: South Korea Disappointed At U.S. Handling of Crisis
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 24 South Korean officials and many ordinary South Koreans indicated today that they were confused and disappointed by the Ford Administration's handling of the current crisis in Korea.

title: Unified Vietnam Makes Diplomatic Gains
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 24 The first phase of Vietnam's fencemending with its neighbors seems to be over, and Hanoi is waiting to reap some of the rewards, both tangible and intangible, from its conciliatory policy.

title: Miki Defies Party's Call for His Ouster
description: TOKYO, Aug. 24More than twothirds of the parliamentary members of the governing LiberalDemocratic Party met today and unanimously called in effect for the ouster of their own party leader, Prime Minister Takeo Miki.

title: JAIL ATTACK STAGED, CARTER'S KIN SAYS
description: VACAVILLE, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP)  The jailed nephew of Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, arranged to be attacked in an attempt to get a transfer out of the California prison system, the prisoner said in a letter published today.

title: Napoli and 8 Guilty of Operating $35MillionaYear Betting Ring
description: James V. Napoli Sr., long identified as a leading underworld figure, and eight confederates were convicted yesterday of operating a $35millionayear policy and horse race gambling operationreportedly one of the largest in the nation.

title: FundRaising for Noncandidates Is Being Studied by Elections Unit
Music: Chamber Society Fairy Tales
description: The works that Schumann wrote in the last three years of his life while he struggled with terminal insanity are fascinating for their flashes of high musical quality, though so uneven that they would he painful if heard very often. The Violin Concerto is one of these products of those mad years, which, because of its suggestion of classical construction, can seem especially confused and distressing.

title: $1 Million Overtime Fraud Laid to Elevator Repairers
description: Nearly a third of the employees of the New York City Housing Authority's elevator repair division were accused yesterday of cheating the city out of more than $1 milliona year in fraudulent overtime claims.

title: They Won't Be Missed
description: The curtain is now descending on the Congressional careers of F. Edward Hebert and Otto E. Passman of Louisiana and Wayne L. Hays of Ohio. It would be satisfying if one could give a warm sendoff to men with a combined total Congressional service of 94 years. Unfortunately, to do so would only heap hypocrisy on the monuments to the arrogant abuse of power that these three careers on Capitol Hill have built.

title: Cloward Riflery Victor
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 24 (UPI)James K. Cloward of Seattle won the Wimbledon Cup trophy today in the final stages of individual competition in the national highpower rifle championships, firing a 299 with 21 center Xring hits of a possible 300 points. Marine Staff Sgt. Lawrence D. Pool, a member of the Marine Corps rifle team, won the Farr Trophy, awarded to the shooter using a firearm currently used by the United States Armed Forces.

title: Big TaxExempt Offerings Begin Slowly
description: The taxexempt credit market, facing an estimated $1.6 billion in new financings in the next 30 days, moved slowly yesterday on several new offerings. Elsewhere in the creditmarkets Government and corporate obligations extended Monday's price gains. The largest offering in the taxexempt sector was California's $75 million of school building aid bonds, rated triple A. The bonds, won by underwriters headed by Citibank, were reoffered to yield percent in 1977 to 5.5 percent in 1996. The bonds were reported to be sold down to a balance of $35 million late yesterday afternoon.

title: 8 Tied in U.S. Chess Open
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Aug. 24 (AP) Eight contenders were tied for first place following the eighth round in the United.: States Open Chess Championship. Grandmasters Anatoly Lein and Leonid Shamkovich of the Soviet Union were tied with Grandmasters Walter. Browne, William Lombardy and Pal Benko and Masters Charley Powell, Elliott Winslow and John Fedorowicz.

title: Cultural Voucher Plan Lures Community Groups
description: A modest yet revolutionary experiment called the Cultural Voucher Program is bringing some of the city's leading cultural institutions into working relationships with organizations representing New York's communities.

title: WINE TALK
description: TENIECULA, Calif.  First it was the wine named after, his wife. Then there was the fuss over the Queen's lunch. Then it was all that television and press coverage.

title: Hirschfeld Asks Repeal
description: Abraham Hirschfeld called yesterdayfor repeal of the section of the New York State Banking Code that permits savings and commercial banks to invest some of their deposits in mortgages out of the State.

title: Blumenthal Case Revived by Prosecutor
description: Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor for nursing homes, yesterday appealed the diSmissal of his indictment of Assembly Majority Leader Albert J. Blumenthal, presenting documents that he asserted fully proved the charges of bribery and perjury.

title: Clark Again Proposes Agency to Aid Impoverished Middle East Countries
description: Ramsey Clark, insisting that lasting peace will never come to the Middle East while the population of most Arab countries are impoverished and illiterate, yesterday proposed the creation of a Mideast Development Authority to which the United States would contribute up to $2 billion a year, mainly to improve life in the poorest Arab nations.

title: Zulu Character Reflects Proud Past
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 24The harsh reaction among Zulus in Soweto to harassment by young demonstrators was characteristic of the forecfulness that once gave them dominion over much of South Africa.

title: Inmate in Sydney Bout
description: SYDNEY, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Lou Hurst, an Australian middleweight boxer, was knocked out in the second round of a fight tonightand then returned to his prison cell. The 26yearold is serving a 16year sentence for armed robbery. It was the first time a prisoner has boxed in public in Australia. Hurst earned $40 for the bout.

title: People and Business
description: Janet Hart yesterday was named director of the Office of Saver and Consumer Affairs of the Federal Reserve Board. She is the first woman ever appointed head of a division at the Federal Reserve.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: A survey conducted during the last several months for the California Citizen Action Group included these questions:

title: Wright's 68 Leads Met Open by Two
Rizzo Recall Bid Rejected; Court Appeal Is Planned
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24The city commissioners rejected today the recall movement against Mayor Frank L. Rizzo on grounds that more than half of the 211,000 petition signatures gathered against him were invalid.

title: Alexander H. Uhl, Long a Newsman, Dies in Spain at 77
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Alexander H. Uhl, a longtime reporter and cofounder of Press Associates Inc., a labor news service, died today in Madrid. He was 77 years old.

title: FRANZ M. MEYER
description: Franz W. Meyer, a former partner in the Berlin banking firm of Meyer Brothers, which was liquidated after Hitler came to power, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 97 years old and lived at 910 Fifth Avenue.

title: Look Who's Taking Over the Family Business These Days
description: Sons traditionally go into their fathers businesses, although it often entails strong urging on Dad's part. But now so many daughters are asking, even coaxing, to join their fathers that John A. Smith & Daughter may become no more unusual than John A. Smith & Son.

title: U.S. Says It Won't Deport Danish Wife of Slain Actor
Big Crimes Rising Faster in Towns Than in the Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Serious crime is increasing at a faster rate in rural America and the smaller towns than it is in the big cities, according to a Federal Bureau of Investigation report that found an overall one year increase of 10 percent. The report was issued today.

title: STRIKE AN TALKS GO ON AT ATTICA
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 24The strike at Attica prison entered its second day today with most inmates remaining in their cells as their appointed leaders met throughout the day with correction officials in an effort to reach agreement on several lists of demands.

title: Flood Death Toll Now 126
description: LOVELAND, Colo., Aug. 24 (UPI)Search teams reported the discovery yesterday of two more victims of the Big Thompson Canyon flood, pushing the tional 93 persons are listed as the disaster to 126.

title: AUDIT FIRMS BACK S.E.C. IN DISPUTE
description: Coopers & Lybrand and Arthur Young & Company, two major accounting firms, filed court briefs yesterday siding with the Securities and Exchange Commission in its dispute with Arthur Andersen & Company, a third big auditing firm, over how accounting rules should be written.

title: British Cabinet Meets on Drought Threat
description: LONDON, Aug. 24  Prime Minister James Callaghan called an emergency Cabinet meeting today as the country's worst drought on record threatened to disrupt the economy. There were predictions that workers in some industries faced layoffs or a threeday work week.

title: 17 More Whales Dead On Beaches in Florida
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP)The discovery of 17 more whales, beached and dead in an isolated area off southwest Florida, has deepened the mystery of a series of recent strandings on the Gulf Coast.

title: JULIANA RETURNS IN LOCKHEED CASE
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 24 Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard resumed their vacation today after a day of talks with the Prime Minister on the growing constitutional crisis over allegations that the Prince accepted bribes amounting to $1.1 million from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Daredevil Rescued From Brink of Falls
description: The Niagara Gazette/Associated Press

title: Pan AM's Net at $68 Million In 7 Months vs. 75 Loss
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday a net income for July of $17.9 million, or 23 cents a share, against $19.2 million, or 31 cents a share, earned in the year earlier month.

title: Ford Wants the Debate to Start Soon
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 24President Ford, seeking a tactical advantage in the first Presidential campaign debates since 1960, proposed today that Jimmy Carter agree to begin their facetoface confrontation in about two weeks.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 24  The total number of building permits issued for new residential units in New Jersey rose slightly between May and June following two months of decreases, according to Joseph A. Hoffman of the Department of Labor and Industry.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Soviet, Czechoslovakia Pull Out of Cup Tennis
News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1976

title: TV: 2 New CBS Shows
description: They reversed the time slots. Forget political campaigns, cheating at West Point and the new increases in electric bills. The fact is that CBSTV has taken two new fourweek series, which begin this evening at 8, and flipflopped their scheduling.

title: Paul W. Caine, 36, Architect, Killed in Arkansas Crash
description: Paul W. Caine, an architect, was killed Monday night in the crash of a twinengine Beechcraft plane near Little rock, Ark. He was 36 years old and lived in St. Louis.

title: Phone Number Is Given For StormAid Queries
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 24 (AP)Federal and state disaster officials said today that no damage was too small to qualify for disaster aid resulting from Hurricane Belle's sweep through Cape May, Atlantic, Ocean and Monmouth Counties.

title: Illegal Sewing Homework Is Found on Rise in State
description: TRENTON, Aug. 24William J. Clark, assistant commissioner of the Department of Labor and Industry, said in an interview today that North Jersey was experiencing a rebirth of illegal industrial homework.

title: Connors and Borg Advance
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 (UPI)Jimmy Connors, in his first appearance at Longwood Cricket Club since winning in 1973, outlasted Steve Krulevitz, 75, 64. today in a firstround match of the $125,000 United States pro tennis championships.

title: DRIVE TO REGISTER BLACKS IS OPENED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24A bipartisan drive to register millions of blacks who have never voted before, which was opened here today by a broad coalition of labor and civil rights groups, could turn out to be a political bonanza for Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and Democratic candidates generally.

title: INSPECTION OF CABS GAINS IN COUNCIL
description: A new system to inspect taxis three times a year for safety and antipollution measures was set up yesterday when the City Council Finance ComMittee voted out a bill to establish 42 privately operated inspection stations throughout New York City.

title: Public Advocate Supports Utility Rate Cuts for Poor
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 24The New Jersey Department of the Public Advocate, the consumer's specialinterest representative in the state government, today supported lower utility rates for the poor and the elderly but contended that such a program should be combined with incentives for energy conservation.

title: Israel Devalues Its Pound
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Israel tonight announced a 2 percent devaluation of its pound against the dollar. The Israeli pound will be valued at 8.25 to the dollar, down from the current 8.08.

title: Groups of Zulus Battle Demonstrators in Soweto
description: JOHANNESBURG, Wednesday, Aug. 25  Zulu vigilante groups armed with clubs and knives clashed violently with young demonstrators in Soweto last night amid growing indications of a backlash against a campaign of harassment that has kept more than twothirds of the black township's labor force away from jobs in Johannesburg for two days.

title: Guilt Denied in 7 Killings
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP)  A former custodian charged with killing seven persons in a college library shooting spree pleaded not guilty today in Superior Court and was ordered to stand trial Nov. 15. Edward Charles Allaway, 37 years old, is charged with seven counts of murder, two of assault with a deadly weapon and two of attempted murder in the July 12 shootings at California State University at Fullerton.

title: Rights Panel Finds That Desegregation Works, but Chides Ford on Busing Stance
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 24The Civil Rights Commission charged today that the Ford Administration had undermined peaceful desegregation of the nation's schools by its antibusing stance.

title: Soviet Astronauts Back Home Safely After 50Day Trip
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP)Two Soviet astronauts returned safely to earth today after spending nearly two months aboard the orbiting Salyut 5 space station, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported. The news service said that the general condition of Cmdr. Boris Volynov, 41 years old, and Flight Engineer Vitaly Zhalobov, 39, 'is satisfactory.

title: DOW DECLINES 8.56 WHEN RALLY FAILS
description: Stock prices dropped sharply, yesterday in moderate trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average off 8.56 points to 962.93, its low for the session.

title: Omaha System Approved
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for The Eighth Circuit affirmed today a federally ordered plan for resegregating the Omaha school system.

title: WALTER S. BARTON
description: Walter S. Barton, a retired vice president of the RoyalGlobe Insurance Companies, died on Aug. 18 at his home in Whitefield, N. H. He was 89 years old. He retired on Jan. 1, 1951, after a 39year career in casualty insurance. He leaves his wife, Elizabeth W. Barton, and a son Walter S. Jr.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Showdown on Toxins
description: We are literally surrounded by a manmade chemical environment. We continually wear, wash with, inhale, and ingest a multitude of chemical substances.From the report by the Senate Commerce Committee on the toxic substances control bill.

title: Duffley Gains Final Of Public Links Golf
description: Mike Duffley, a 210pound college sophomore from Woodhaven, Queens, led three rivals yesterday into the final of the New York City junior public links championship conducted by the Parks and Recreation Department in cooperation with Manufacturers Hanover.

title: ETHEL ROSSIN ASIEL, RACE HORSE OWNER
description: Ethel Rossin Asiel, philanthropist and owner of thoroughbred race horses, died yesterday at her home in the Carlton House, 680 Madison Avenue. She was 84 years old.

title: Bronx Mechanic Wins Final Lottery Drawing
description: ALBANY, Aug. 24 (UPI)James F. Greco, 29, years old, an elevator mechanic from the Bronx, won $125,000 today in the final drawing for the nowdefunct New York State Lottery.

title: Laotian Marxists Omit A Buddhist Observance
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug.24 (Reuters)The Marxist authorities of Laos omitted today the traditional commemoration of the Buddhist All Saints Day, the first time in 29 years that the anniversary had not been officially celebrated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On Clean Air, Energy and the Economy

title: Groups of Zulus Battle Demonstrators in Soweto
description: JOHANNESBURG, Wednesday, Aug. 25  Zulu vigilante groups armed with clubs and knives clashed violently with young demonstrators in Soweto last night amid growing indications of a backlash against a campaign of harassment that has kept more than twothirds of the black township's labor force away from jobs in Johannesburg for two days.

title: U.S. STILL SENDING B52'S OVER KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24American B52 strategic bombers continued to fly daily practice bombing missions over South Korea today as a show of force against North Korea while the United States diplomatic posture toward North Korea remained a focus of discussion here and in Seoul.

title: Sears Earnings Climb 25%, Buoyed by Insurance Gain
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company reported yesterday a 25 percent increase in earnings for the fiscal second quarter, ended July 31, and a 35.7 percent increase for the fiscal first half.

title: Runoff Seen Likely In Oklahoma Race For Albert's Seat
INQUIRY IS OPENED ON HOSPITAL FIRE
description: Fire Department and hospital officials are investigating suspicious fire that caused $100,000 worth of damage Monday night at the new Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.

title: SUDAN'S BIG COOP A HOPE FOR ARABS
description: WAD MEDANI, the Sudan, Aug. 18Omer Abdel Sid farms, 13 acres of cotton, with a little peanuts and sorghum on the side. As part of the largest farm under single management anywhere in the world, he is told when and what to plant, and if he resolutely disobeys he can be thrown off the land. Last year he made $2,00017 times more than the average Sudahe has no complaints.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Egypt and Libya Exchange Charges On Hijacking Plot
description: CAIRO, Aug. 24Libya and Egypt today accused each other of having planned the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner yesterday by three Arab gunmen.

title: BEAME NAMES HEAD OF HOSPITAL FORCE
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday appointed Morrell Goldberg, executive director of the Brookdale Medical Center in Brooklyn, as chairman of the new task force established to find ways of cutting costs in New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, without resorting to more layoffs.

title: CHARLES M. DUKE, 59, OF ARMY ENGINEERS
