description: Maj. Gen. Charles M. Duke, retired, who served as division engineer of the Army Corps of Engineers for the North Atlantic Division, died Saturday in a Fairfax, Va., nursing home. He was 59 years old.

title: Memorial Services
description: PHILBYMary (noo Glass), Memorial Service Community Church of Now York, 40 East 35th St., on Friday, Aug. 27, at 12 noon.

title: I.M.F. Alters Method of Gold Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The International Monetary Fund announced today that it would proceed on schedule with its next auction of 780,000 ounces of gold Sept. 15, but with a different auction technique.

title: MARGARET JOSTEN, A NIECE OF LEHMAN
description: Margaret F. Josten, a former opera singer, and collector of Impressionist paintings, died in her apartment at 944 Fifth Ave. nue yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Josten was 88 years old.

title: Desegregation Report
description: The Civil Rights Commission issued a report that charged that the Ford Administration, by its antibusing position, had undermined attempts to peacefully integrate the nation's schools. Page 21.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The State Department issued its official comment in Washington on the statement by a multiracial constitutional committee last week in SouthWest Africa setting goals for independence by the end of 1978. It called it a step in the right direction but decried the failure to set a date for elections in the territory, known also as Namibia, and the failure to include all interested parties. This referred to the SouthWest African People's Organization, a guerrilla group recognized by the United Nations as representative of the people of the territory. [Page 1, Col. 4.]

title: Legislator Drops Lulu And Post on Old Panel
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y.. Aug. 24 (UPI)State Assemblyman Andrew Ryan resigned today from a committee that he said had been out of business for two years and announced that he would return the $3,500 lulu that came with the job.

title: Switzerland Eliminated
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP)In firstround Federation Cup action today, Indonesia eliminated Switzerland, 30. Yolanda Sumarno, Indonesia's No. I player, scored a 62, 60 victory over Susi Eichenberger, and Loanita Rachman defeated Petra Delhees, 60, 61. All Sutarno and Elvia Nizarwan beat Miss Delhees and Monika Simmen in doubles, 62, 61.

title: U. S. Musicians Appear in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP)Two American music groups performed to a packed house of young Moscow workers last night. The groups, totaling about 80 young singers and musicians, were the New England Youth Ensemble Orchestra, from the Boston area, and the HardinSimmons University concert choir, from Abilene, Tex. They continue on to Riga and Leningrad, then go to Poland next week.

title: 2 More Unions Enter Music Hall Talks
description: Bargaining against a Sept. 1 deadline, representatives of the stagehands and musicians unions met yesterday and last night with the Radio City Music Hall management in an effort to reach agreements that would avert threatened permanent shutdown of the theater.

title: Arcadio II Scores by Nose. Over Blue. Times on Grass
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP)Hobeau Farm's Arcadio II, a Chilean import ridden by Ruben Hernandez, won the $25,000 True North Purse at Saratoga today before 15.262 fans.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)The dollar value of investments and loans made by foreign businesses to United States companies increased $4.3 billion last year, the Government said today. Total foreign direct investment in the United States by the end of 1975 amounted to $26.7 billion, the Commerce Department said.

title: Sound Stavisky Ruling
description: In declaring the StaviskyGoodmati Law invalid, State Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff has overturned a legislative act that ignored the city's fiscal plight which other measures enacted by the same Legislature have tried to remedy.

title: 14 Descendants of a Tory Return as Bergen's Guests
description: HACKENSACK, Aug, 24Fourteen descendants of a Tory whose lands were confiscated in 1780 by the state and given to a hero of the Revolution returned to Bergen County today for a Bicentennial visit.

title: Senate Rejects Bid To Bring Post Office Back to Government
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) The Senate rejected today a move to make the Postal Service an arm of the Federal Government again and then voted to subsidize the nation's mail service for another year.

title: Bridge:
description: New York players had one triumph, but only one, in the American Bridge Association's Summer Nationals in Washington last week: Bill Williams, Mary Moragne, Leonard Irish, Seymour Bibald, Jim Garcia, all New York, and Lee Pennington of Yonkers won the Swiss team championship.

title: Prices Decline in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 24 (UPI)1 Gold, at its lowest levels since late 1973, dropped almost $2 today in markets already nervous over the prospect of a third huge International Monetary Fund bullion auction next month.

title: Ullyot to Coach Owls
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 24 AP)Ron Ullyot, a sevenyear veteran player with the Fort Wayne Komets, was named today as coach of the Columbus Owls, also of the International Hockey League. The 30yearold Ullyot replaces Moe Bartoli, who will continue as Owls' general manager.

title: ARMY WON'T JOIN ILLNESS INQUIRY
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 24Experts in chemical and biological warfare from the Department of Defense have determined that not enough evidence exists for it to pursue its own investigation of the mysterious disease that has killed 26 persons in Pennsylvania, it was said officially today.

title: F.C.C. Nominee Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) President Ford's nomination of Margita White to a sevenyear term on the Federal Communications Commission ran into oppositon today at a Senate confirmation hearing.

title: Intellectuals of India Seem Demoralized by Curbs on Civil Rights
description: CALCUTTA, IndiaAfter 14 months of emergency rule and the suspension of most civil liberties, India's intellectual community appears demoralized and in disarray. Its mood ranges from acceptance of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's exercise of authoritarian power to total rejection, albeit in most cases whispered.

title: AntiAbortion Ad Funds Accepted by Dole in 74
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 24Federal election records on file here show that Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential nominee, accepted as a 1974 campaign contribution the cost of antiabortion advertisements that he said last Sunday he had disavowed.

title: Susan Saxe Taken to Boston
description: BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP)Susan Saxe, accused of murdering a Boston policeman six years ago, was taken today to a courthouse cell where she will be held until her trial Sept. 15. She was brought from a Federal prison in New York.

title: Ford Wants the Debate to Start Soon
About Education
description: At one community college in Michigan, student chefs prepare a gourmet meal that they offer in the cafeteria for just 50 cents more than the regular lunch price.

title: AUTO UNION PICKS FORD MOTOR CO. AS STRIKE TARGET
description: DETROIT, Aug. 24  The United Automobile Workers today picked the Ford Motor Company as the company to be struck at midnight Sept. 14 should no contract agreement be reached by then.

title: Baylor Names Thomas
description: WACO, Tex., Aug. 24 (AP) Roy Thomas, a former Tyler Junior College and Baylor University basketball star, has been named assistant coach at Baylor, it was announced today. He will serve as both a coach and a recruiter.

title: William E. Hawley, Actor In Films, Theater and TV
description: William E. Hawley, a stage, film and television actor, died Sunday at the Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Point Lookout, L.I.

title: LEGIONNAIRES BOO CARTER ON PARDON FOR DRAFT DEFIERS
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 24 Jimmy Carter was vigorously booed by hundreds of American Legion members here today after he told them he would issue a pardon to Vietnam War draft resisters if he should become President.

title: SUIT BY THRALL TESTS OHIO LAW
description: A suit filed against Ohio by the Thrall Manufacturing Company is one of the first attempts by a company to challenge the validity of state laws that seek to control mergers and acquisitions.

title: BILL ON ALIEN SPIES SENT TO THE SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities sent to the floor today legislation setting new guidelines for the use of domestic wiretaps and other kinds of electronic surveillance of foreign agents.

title: Hoffmann HearingToday Set on Army Proposal About West Point Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The House Military Personnel Subcommittee, apparently dissatisfied with aspects of the Army's solution to the West Point cheating scandal, decided today to call Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffmann before a special hearing tomorrow.

title: Marine Scientists Turning Their Eyes to Elephants
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.At the seaside Marine Biological Laboratory here, one of the world's leading centers for the study of creatures from the oceans, five scientists are focusing their research on elephants.

title: Pallottines Will Liquidate Many Assets
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Pallottine Fathers, a Roman Catholic missionary order has formulated an agreement with the Maryland Attorney General to liquidate many of their assets and drastically reduce their direct mail charity appeals.

title: Canadian Bankers Cautiously Welcome Revisions to the Bank Act
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 24Canadian bankers have cautiously welcomed the Government's proposed revisions to the Bank Act, which will increase both competition and controls in the industry here.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Gap Stores, a sevenyearold retail chain specializing in denim clothing, was charged yesterday in a class action suit in Federal court in San Francisco with issuing a false registration statement and other documents when it placed, a recent common stock offering.

title: School Project Set To Promote Golf
description: The National Golf Foundation, in an effort to promote the sport of golf, will begin a pilot program this fall to introduce the game to high school students.

title: Stock of GearhartOwen To Be Dually Listed
description: GearhartOwen Industries, an oil services company in Fort Worth, will become the second company to retain its Amex listing when it lists its stock on the New York Stock Exchange in the near future, the American Stock Exchange said yesterday. Varo Inc., of Garland, Tex., became the first dually listed stock last Monday.

title: Musical Going Up To Open Sept. 19
description: Going Up, a musical about the airplane, will be the third production of the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., scheduled for Broadway at the same time. It is expected to open at the Golden Theater on Sept. 19, joining the two other Goodspeed productions, Very Good Eddie and Shenandoah.

title: Big Success in Liver Transplants Forecast
description: In the next decade the success of human liver transplantation may surpass that of kidney and heart, one of the surgical pioneers in transplantation said yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: I'm going to enjoy thisI've just found a mayor as short as I am, Mayor Beame said with a smile as he met Moshe Tzahar of Tiberias, Israel, yesterday before a City Hall reception. The 5foottwo New Yorker is a year younger than his 72year old guest, who served in 1948 as Israel's first acting Prime Minister. New York was the last stop of an American tour for Mayor Tzahar and 35 other residents of Tiberias, a Biblical city with a current population of 40,000.

title: LEGIONNAIRES BOO CARTER ON PARDON FOR DRAFT DEFIERS
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 24 Jimmy Carter was vigorously booed by hundreds of American Legion members here today after he told them he would issue a pardon to Vietnam War draft resisters if he should become President.

title: Ayer Is Handling Drive For Da Pont Wall Tiles
description: They aren't called wall tiles but, in effect, that's what the new product called Flair Squares, made by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, is. And it has just gone into test marketing in Columbus, Ohio, and Fort Wayne, Ind.

title: Meat Prices Drop As Market Basket Costs Less Overall
description: With meat leading the way, the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City last week dropped 0.8 percent below the previous week's level, the Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: Fiscal Board Is Pressed To Halt Teacher Layoffs
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board came under pressure yesterday to try to stop the Board of. Education from laying off at least 3,000 more teachers and also awarding even limited salary increases to those teachers remaining behind in the school system.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A United States District Court judge, John F. Dooling Jr., dismissed a suit brought by an ad hoc civic group that had sought to prevent the demolition of the vandalized United States Pavilion on the former World's Fair grounds in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, Queens. Judge Dooling held that the plaintiffs had failed to show they were suffering some peculiar personal injury, that officials had vainly tried for years to find a new use for the building and that the court had no right to order them not proceed with the decision to demolish.

title: ACT NEEDED TO USE FEDERAL JOB FUND
Carter's Foreign Economic Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24United States international economic policy, said Marina Whitman the other day standing beneath some tall nine trees in Plains, Ga., is not an area of great partisan division there is a very wide range of consensus.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Superior Court Judge Charles S. Joelson of Paterson rejected yesterday three arguments by lawyers for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis to dismiss a 1966 indictment charging them with a triple murder. Judge Joelson said the New Jersey Supreme Court was aware of at least two of the arguments last March to dismiss the indictment, but decided instead to grant a new trial to Mr. Carter and Mr. Artis, who had served nine years in prison for the murder in a Paterson tavern. The two arguments referred to by Judge Joelson were that the indictment was based on the alleged perjured testimony of Alfred Bello, a key witness, and that evidence at a new trial would be considerably different than that presented to a 1966 grand jury. A final defense argument that the delay in giving the two defendants a new trial was caused by prosecutorial misconduct was also rejected by Judge Joelson.

title: Prices of Raw Sugar Continue to Decline With Quotations at 8.55 Cents a Pound
description: Raw sugar prices, which have declined dramatically in recent weeks, continued to ease yesterday, with domestic quotations falling 0.15 cent to 8.55 cents a pound and the world price sliding 0.10 cents to 9.75 cents a pound.

title: Child Care Fund Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) The Senate approved and sent to the White House today al reduced authorization for child care services designed to meet President Ford's objections. The bill, approved 72 to 15, would proVide $240 million more through the fiscal year 1977 for child care services under social services programs. Congteas earlier this year sustained Mr. Ford's veto of a hill that would lava authorived $375 million.

title: A $3.3 Billion Military Bill Is Sent to Senate by House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The House passed today a $3.3 billion military construction authorization bill to replace one that President Ford had vetoed.

title: Another Ethnic Treat
description: Explain to everyone what an empanada is, suggested Ruben Maseda, who, with his partner, Tony Bianco, operates Ruben's EmpanaGa Shop at 64 Fulton Street, corner of Gold Street.

title: Owner Allows a Peek At MillionDollar
description: A shiny gold piece known in numismatic circles as the milliondollar coin was displayed briefly in New York City yesterday by its new owner after an enigmatic 69year journey during which it passed from such people as an Egyptian king to a country doctor in Tennessee.

title: Abzug Labor Panel
description: Forty New York labor leaders set up a committee yesterday to show the amount of union support that Representative Bella S. Abzug had already obtained for her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate and to promote her cause among union members.

title: BRODERICK NAMED A FEDERAL JUDGE
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 24Vincent L. Broderick, a Democrat who was the New York City Commissioner of Police a decade ago, was nominated today for the Federal bench by President Ford.

title: Third Party Head Says Maddox Could Cut Carter's Vote
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (UPI)The chairman of the American Independent Party said today that he thought Lester G. Maddox would have a chance to beat Jimmy Carter in Mississippi, Louisiana and Tennessee if he entered the Presidential race.

title: Napoli and 8 Guilty of Operating $35MillionaY ear Betting Ring
description: James V. Napoli Sr., long Identified as a leading underworld figure, and eight confederates were convicted yesterday of operating a $35millionayear policy and horse race gambling operationsreportedly one of the largest in the nation.

title: Channing Will Star In Comedy
description: Carol Channing is scheduled to open on Broadway in midJanuary in The Bed Before Yesterday, one of three hits that the 90yearold playwright Ben Travers now has running in London.

title: MANILA TURNS DOWN U.S.QUAKEAID OFFER
description: MANILA, Aug. 24 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos today rejected an American offer of aid for the victims of last week's earthquake and tidalwave disaster in the southlern Philippines.

title: Emlyn Williams Booked at Yale
description: Emlyn Williams as Charles Dickens and Dylan Thomas Growing Up will be presented by the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven from Sept. 14 through Sept. 19. Both are solo performances by Mr. Williams.

title: Books of The Times
description: Back in 1932, when Charles Revson and his brother Joseph started Revson Brothers, the concern's only product, nail polish, was worn chiefly by actresses and whores, says the cosmetic king's biographer, Andrew Tobias. Fortythree years later, at Charles Revson's death, Revlon was a top300 corporation and selling over 400 shades of nail polish, plus 2 wellstocked dermatological pharmacopeia of other beauty products, from hair sprays to skin rejuvenators. Revson, whose general opinion of women was that they were liars and cheats, had made the painted woman respectable. Seeing millions of virginal fingernails he turned them scarlet.

title: Dole Attacks Carter on Pardon for Draft Evaders
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 25Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential nominee, took Jimmy Carter to task today before the American Legion's national convention here for having promised a blanket pardon to all Vietnam draft evaders.

title: Myron Orlofsky, 48, Lawyer, CoAuthor Of a Book on Quilts
description: Myron Orlofsky, a lawyer, author and art collector who from 1965 to 1975 was deputy director of the White Plains Urban Renewal Agency, died of a heart attack Tuesday after giving a lecture on quilts at Cornell University. He was 48 years old.

title: People and Business; Devitt Elected Head of MONY; Devitt Heads MONY
description: The trustees of Mutual of New York, the nation's 19th largest life insurance company, yesterday elected James E. Devitt as president and chief executive officer, effective immediately.

title: Badillo Supported by Rangel In Primary Fight With Velez
description: Representative Herman Badillo, who fades a hard fight in the Democratic primary for reelection, was endorsed yesterday by his fellow Representative, Charles B. Rangel.

title: Europe's Nuclear Turn
description: West Europe's lack of fossil fuel sources and its heavy dependence on Mideast oil led most countries there to step up plans for nuclear energy expansion even more than the United States in the wake of the 197374 oil embargo and fivefold oil price increase. But economic factors and public concern over safety, the environment and weapons proliferation now have led to a slowdown similar to that in the United States.

title: BEAM IS PRESSED ON NEW U.S. FUNDS; But Public Works Financing Has Yet to Pass Congress
description: As the House of Representatives debated in Washington whether to approve a $3.45 billion appropriation for local public works projects, two New York City politicians called on Mayor Beame yesterday to draw up immediate plans on how to spend the money.

title: CARTER SUPPORTED ON RELIGIOUS ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)  The Democratic platform of Jimmy Carter and Walter F. Mondale is vastly superior to that of the Republicans on issues relating to religious liberty and churchstate questions, Americans United for Separation of Church and State said today.

title: DAY AN BIDS U.S. CURB MIDEAST ARMS RACE
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 (AP)The United States should reduce military aid to Israel, hold down the Middle East arms race and work for a new ArabIsraeli agreement to end the formal state of war, former Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today.

title: Dodge Motorhome Recall
description: DETROIT, Aug. 25 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation annonuced yesterday that it was recalling 6,417 Dodge motorhomes built in the 1975 model year because of a technical defect that could cause the rear wheels to fall oft The Company notified owners of the motorhomes in question to bring the vehicles into their dealers for inspedtion and correction if necessary. Chrysler said the defect was discovered on the rear wheel chassis of its 1975model M500 Dodge.

title: White House Aide Named Chief Spokesman for Dole
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 25 (UPI)Larry Speakes has been shifted from the White House press office to the staff of Senator Robert J. Dole, President Ford's running mate, a White House spokesman said today. Mr. Speakes, who served as assistant Presidential press secretary, is now chief spokesman for the Kansas Senator's VicePresidential campaign.

title: JUDGE GIVES HOWE SUSPENDED TERM; Utah Representative Told To Pay Court Costs
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 25Representative Allan T. Howe, Democrat of Utah, convicted yesterday for a second time on a sex solicitation charge, was sentenced today to 30 days in jail and ordered to pay court costs.

title: No.Amer.Soccer League
description: SEMIFINAL ROUND LAST NIGHT NIGHT'S GAMES Minnesota 3. San Jose 1. TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAME Toronto 2, Tampa Bay 0.

title: Books of The Times; The Velazquez Hippopotamus
description: the only possibility of renewal lies in opening your eyes and seeing the presentday disaster, a disaster which can't be understood but which must be permitted to come in because it is the truth. The quotation is from Samuel Beckett, but it is used by Lorenza Trucchi to characterize the painter Francis Bacon, Like so many of Miss Trucchi's remarks in Francis Bacon, it is both melodramatic and apt. As she observes of Mr. Bacon in another place, the human body has perhaps never said more, never expressed events more bleak, more tragic or pathetic, by its mere but violent presence.

title: Juliana and Dutch Cabinet In Dispute Over Bernhard
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 25Queen Juliana, facing the most serious threat to the Dutch throne since World War II, is locked in a sharp dispute with the Government over allegations involving the business dealings of her husband, Prince Bernhard.

title: The Ties Don't Bind
description: The family is having increasing difficulty in caring for children and in raising children who can care. The evidence is clear: the suicide rate for young people 1524 has increased 250 percent over the last 20 years. Drug abuse, alcohol abuse, minor and violent crimes are increasing problems not just in poor black families, but in affluent white families, not just in broken families, but in seemingly Intact families, not just when mothers work, but also when they stay home.

title: Panel to Aid Saxe Defense In Jury Selection Process
description: BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP)A panel of four experts will be permitted to aid, the defense's jury selection in the murderbank robbery trial of Susan E. Saxe, scheduled to begin Sept. 15.

title: Jaworski Says Court Post Was Used as Bait in Watergate Job Talk
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Leon Jaworski says the bait of an appointment to the United States Supreme Court was dangled before him when he arrived in Washington to discuss his appointment as special Watergate prosecutor.

title: Air Force Sending Planes To Three NATO Countries
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Air Force has announced that it will send planes to three NATO countries for brief periods to give crews experience in the unique aspects of flying in Europe. Another purpose will be to give West German, Norwegian and British ground crews experience in serving United States military aircraft.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: By The Associated Press

title: DECISION DELAYED ON PENSION POST; Police Trustees Weighing Appointment of Lechner
description: Trustees of the New York City Police Department's pension fund deferred for four weeks yesterday a decision on whether to retain Melvin N. Lechner, the city's former Budget Director, as a $28,680ayear consultant.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Political Funds Raised in Senate Building
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Senator Jesse A. Helms, Republican of North Carolina, was the host of a fundraising cocktail party for Stanley C. Burger, a senatorial candidate from Montana, in a Congressional office here tonight, an apparent violation of Federal law for both men.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On the Convention, Candidates and Campaign

title: Drumgo, Acquitted in San Quentin Case, Is Freed
description: TAMAL, Calif. Aug. 25Fleeta Drumgo, one of three defendants acquitted in the San Quentin Six murder trial 13 days ago, was released from San Quentin Prison here at 8:50 A.M. Pacific daylight time today.

title: Amin's Infant Daughter Dies
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 25 (AP) President Idi Amin's 1yearold daughter has died in a Kampala hospital, Uganda Radio reported today. The report, monitored here, said the child died yesterday and would be buried today in Koboko, northwest Uganda. No cause for the death was given.

title: SEOUL AIDE ACCUSED OF ACCEPTING BRIBES
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 25A ranking legislator resigned and was arrested today on suspicion of taking $75,000 in bribes from businesses.

title: Gone Fishin In the Park?
description: It was 9 A.M. yesterday and 14 year  old Michelle Adams, who had arisen at 5 o'clock and made her way into the city from Jamaica, Queens, by subway, was comfortably seated under a tree at the Central Park Lake near 72d Street.

title: Business Briefs; U.S. Foreign Investments Lag; Bundesbank and Italy in Loan Talks; U.S. Opposes Boycott Tax Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The worldwide economic recession led to a slowdown in the rate of increase in United States foreign investments last year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Howe to Announce Plans
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 25 (AP)  Representative Howe said today that he would announce by Sept. 3 whether he would continue his campaign for reelection.

title: 39,884 See Fidrych Gain 15th Triumph
description: Mark (The Bird) Fidrych made his customary appearance in front of the Detroit Tigers dugout last night in Tiger Stadium after beating the Chicago White Sox, 31.The rookie righthander held the White Sox to five hits, raised his wonlost record to 155, retired the last 13 batters in hurling his 18th complete game in 21 starts. The victory was Fidrych's 11th in Tiger Stadium in 14 decisions.

title: Coaching is an Incurable Disease
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Aug. 25It was nearly 4:30 P.M. by the time the football players, done with classes and labs, began straggling onto the practice field.

title: Philip Morris Will Stay in New York; Philip Morris to Keep New York Headquarters
description: After more than a year of intensive studies of possible moves elsewhere, Philip Morris Inc., the nation's second largest maker of cigarettes, announced yesterday that would not only keep its world headquarters in New York City, but would even expand its operations here.

title: MERGER SOUGHT BY COPPER RANGE; Asks to Be Acquired, All or in Part, by Amoco Minerals
description: The Copper Range Company, a coppermining company hurt by the drop in copper prices last year, announced yesterday that it had approached the Amoco Mineral Company,subsidiary of the Standard Oil Cornpany (Indiana) for the possible acquisition by Amoco of all or part of Copper Range.

title: Protesters Against Speeding Tie Up 600 Autos
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 25 (AP)Stephen Long and five friends drove the 50 miles of Interstate 94 between Ann Arbor to Detroit today at 55 miles an hour, the legal speed limit.

title: CORRECTION
description: Dr. William R. Roy, the Democratic candidate in the Kansas Senate race two years ago, was incorrectly described as a Roman Catholic in a wire service dispatch published in The Times Aug. 20. Dr. Roy is a Methodist.

title: SENATE REJECTS ABORTIONS CURB; House Measure Forbidding U.S. Funds for Operations Returned to Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The Senate refused today to accept Housepassed legislation that would forbid the use of Federal money for abortions.

title: Rhodesia Teams Faces Inquiry On Passports; Rhodesians Face Inquiry on Passports
description: An official of the United States Department of State said yesterday that the presence of a Rhodesian national team in the Federation Cup tennis tournament in Philadelphia has embarrassed us very, very much. The official also said the team members  one male manager and four female playersmight face deportation if it is determined that they entered the country illegally.

title: EDWARD RAQUELLO, A RETIRED U.S. AIDE
description: Edward Raquello, a program officer for 26 years in the European field service of the United States Information Service until his retirement in 1968, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 130 East 93d Street and was 76 years old.

title: Bridge; Regional Play Opens Today At Great George Resort Hotel
Sports Today
description: GOLF

title: Peyser Seeks a Debate; Buckley Says No
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Representative Peter A. Peyser challenged Senator James L. Buckley today to a series of debates during the next three weeks as part of their primary contest for the New York Republican Senate nomination. Responding immediately, Senator Buckley refused to participate.

title: Francis Plimpton Is Named to Head City Guests' Unit
description: Mayor Beame yesterday announced the appointment of Francis T. P. Plimpton, a lawyer and former diplomat, as the unsalaried head of his newly created Commission for Distinguished Guests. The commission will assume the protocol and ceremonial functions of the former Department of Civic Affairs and Public Events.

title: CADETS' RETURN HELD UNCERTAIN; Academy and Army Officials Disagree on Likelihood of Their Readmission
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Army officials here and at West Point appeared today to disagree over the likelihood of the readmission of cadets found guilty in a cheating scandal who accepted a recently proposed oneyear period of reflection.

title: JOHN WENGER, 89, A SCENIC ARTIST; Designed Stage Settings for Opera and Theaters
description: John Wenger, a scenic artist] and watercolorist, who designed stage settings for the Metropolitan Opera Company and many other theatrical enterprises, died Tuesday at the New York Infirmary. He was 89 years old and lived in the Ansonia Hotel, 2109 Broadway.

title: Ford Names James Baker To Morton Campaign Job; James Baker Is Named to Morton's Post
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 25President Ford revamped his campaign organization today in An effort to solidify his political base in his conservative, minority party and reach beyond it to moderate and progressive voters.

title: Thai Defense Chief Resigns; Premier Assumes the Post
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 25 (AP)  Prime Minister Seni Pramoj took over the Defense Minister's post today after the resignation of Gen. Tawit Semiwong, who has been criticized for his handling of an exiled strongman's brief return.

title: TRIAL OF AMERICANS RECESSED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (AP)The trial of three Americans here on drugsmuggling charges was recessed today for lack of a witness and a document, but court officials predicted an end of the proceedings and a possible verdict tomorrow.

title: Nonaligned Parley May Help Sri Lanka's Premier With the Voters
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 22Fresh from the triumph of playing host to a glittering assortment of world leaders at the recent conference of nonaligned nations, Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike is soon to face another tough audience the voters.

title: STATE SET TO AID ORCHID FARMING; Certificates to Be Required by Growers in Effort to Control Virus
description: TRENTON, Aug. 25  New (Jerseys orchid industry, once the largest in the United States, will get the help of the State Department of Agriculture in a program to control plant viruses.

title: Ford Names Navy Aide
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 25 (UPI)President Ford said today that he was nominating John J. Bennett as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for installation and logistics, succeeding Jack L. Bowers, who is to resign on Saturday. Mr. Bennett, 52 years old, a native of Camden, N.J., had been for 20 months a Dep. uty Assistant Secretary of Defense.

title: CONFEREES START WORK ON TAX BILL; Seek to Complete Work by Labor Day Recess Meet in Public
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Senate and House conferees began today the long process of plowing through the manyskied tax bill, passing over most controversial provisions until later.

title: Liquor Sales Proposal Is Rejected in Americus
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 25 (AP)  Voters in Americus have turned down a proposal to allow sales of hard liquor by the drink in their townthe big city for residents of Jimmy Carter's hometown of Plains.

title: 21 Dio in Iran Collision
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 25 (AP) A passenger bus and a tank truck collided 54 miles north of Shahroud in northeastern Iran, killing 21 persons, the newspaper Kayhan reported today.

title: Yanks Victors In 19th by 54; Yanks Turns Back Twins in 19th, 54
description: For 5 hours and 26 minutes the Yankees and the Minnesota Twins played baseball last night and early today, and when they finished at 1:36 A.M., the Yankees had won, 54, on Mickey Rivers's twoout, runscoring single in the 19th inning.

title: Sweets Edison, ExBasie Star, Brings Trumpet to Hopper's
description: Harry (Sweets) Edison, one of the two trumpet stars of the original Count Basie Band in the 1930's (the other was Buck Clayton), has been an infrequent visitor to New York since he left Basie in 1950 and settled in California. But he is in town this week and next at Hopper's, the Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street, playing in a style that is a polished and witty refinement of the exuberant, flairing dash that made his work with the Basie band distinctive.

title: Blanda's Pro Football Career Ends After 26 Years
description: George Blanda's playing career in the National Football League, which began 27 years ago when he was a 22yearold rookie quarterback for the Chicago Bears,came to an end yeserday. Blanda, who holds league records for most seasons played, 26; most games played, 342, and most points scored, 2,002, was told by Al Davis, chief executive of the Oakland Raiders that he had been put on waivers. None of the N.F.L.'s other 27 teams claimed him for $100.

title: U.N. Calls for GreekTurkish Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25The Security Council urged Greece and Turkey today to resume negotiations to settle their dispute over the search for offshore oil in the Aegean Sea.

title: North Korea Offers Plan To Prevent New Incidents; NORTH KOREA ASKS TROOP SEPARATION
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 25Adopting what appeared to be an old American plan, North Korea today proposed a partition of the. Panmunjom truce site as a way to avoid incidents like the one last week in which two United States Army officers were killed by Communist guards.

title: Leaders of Black Jersey City Church Defend Handling of Meal Program
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 25The leaders of one of Jersey City's prominent black churches are irate over what they consider to be unfair attacks against it in the local press.

title: Khartoum, a City of Warrior Ghosts, Marches to Modern Beat
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 20A fisherman standing on the bank of the Blue Nile, just across from the Sudan Hotel, pulled out a 10footlong snake the other day. No one in the crowd that quickly gathered could identify it, but they all agreed it was poisonous. It was promptly thrashed to death.

title: Amnesty and Pardon Differ in Legal Use
description: Although amnesty and pardon are often used interchangeably, the two words nave different legal meanings. In common usage, though, this distinction is sometimes blurred.

title: GERTRUDE E. BOONE
description: Gertrude E. Boone, widow of Dr. William H. Boone, the director of radiology at Roosevelt Hospital at his death in 1966, died yesterday in a nursing home in Providence, R. I. She was 65 years old and had lived in Manhasset, L. I.

title: Conrail s New Look Is Largely a Matter of Degree.
description: CROTON, N.Y.There is a thoughtful young man who studied diplomacy at Johns Hopkins. There is a lovely young woman who looks as though she could vanish into an Irish travel poster. There are assorted college graduates and college dropouts, with degrees in affability if nothing else.

title: Latest Tests Link Nickel Compound To Legion Malady; Scientist Says the Latest Tests Suggest Nickel Carbonyl May Have Caused Disease That Killed Legionnaires
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 25 New tests on tissue specimens from victims of a mysterious ailment in Pennsylvania suggest that nickel carbonyl, a highly toxic substance, may have caused the outbreak, according to the scientist who conducted the tests.

title: SIMON AIDE ASSAILED FOR BOYCOTT LETTER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. demanded an apology today from the Secretary of the Treasury, William E. Simon, because of a letter written by one of Mr. Simon's staff members, which the Senator charged had blatant antiSemitic overtones.

title: GOLD
description: By The Associated Press

title: New York City Statistics Show A Slight Rise in Violent Crime
Chess:; Slow, Steady, Deadly Karpov Holds the Lead in Montilla
description: MONTILLA, Spain, Aug. 24Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union held the lead with 6 points after seven rounds of the Torneo del Vino here in the Don Gonzalo Hotel.

title: EXTENSION IS URGED ON REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) Representatives of state and local governments backed the Ford Administration today in urging Congress to extend Federal revenue sharing through Sentember 1982.

title: JURY BARS ACTION ON SUFFOLK AIDE; Refuses to Indict Police Head on Charges. Brought in 75 by the District Attorney
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 25The special state prosecutor investigating law enforcement officials in Suffolk County announced today that a grand jury had refused to take action on two charges against the Suffolk Police Commissioner that were leveled last year by the County District Attorney.

title: Corporation Affairs; Tenneco Unit and Navy Reach Accord on Ship; Grace's Pix Grows; I.T.T. Land Concern Must Back Claims; Mitsubishi Delaying Australians Ships; Rate Rise Approved; Clark Oil Charters Tanker to Subsidiary; Illinois Files Suit On Potash Prices
description: The Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, a subsidiary of Tenneco, said yesterday it had resolved a dispute with the Navy over the nuclearpowered guided missile Bruiser CGN41. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: What Price, Qaddafi?
description: In his long speech at the nonaligned summit meeting in Colombo last week, Libya's Col. Muammar elQaddafi emphatically denied supporting any terrorist activities except those involving the struggle of a people for independence. He blamed imperialism, international Zionism and racialism for the charges that he uses oil revenues to back hijacking, kidnaping and subversion.

title: Longshoremen to Fight ContainerCargo Ruling
description: Longshoremen and shipindustry employers in New York City and five other Atlantic Ports said yesterday that they would appeal to the United States Supreme Court a lowercourt ruling threatening the role of dock workers in the handling of containerized Cargo.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Thursday, August 26, 1976

title: HanoiSaigon Flights Set
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  Three regular weekly flights will serve the HanoiSaigon route, a spokesman for the Vietnamese civil airline announced here. So far, the flights between the two cities have generally been reserved for those with a valid reason for making the trip.

title: Reckoning in Africa: I
description: During the last two months, while Americans have been preoccupied with their own politics, events likely to be of much more lasting significance have been taking place half a world away. The disturbances in the black townships of South Africa, and the white reaction to them, have a profound import for world politicsand for one's view of human character.

title: Dean Witter Studies Merger With Surety
description: The Dean Witter Organization and the Surety Financial Corporation announced jointly yesterday the possibility of a merger of the two concerns.

title: Trenton Topics; Van Ness Asserts Funds From U.S. Are Misused
Man Who Faked His Death Found Guilty in Fraud Plot
description: A 38yearold man who had faked his death two years ago to Collect Social Security and insurance benefits was convicted in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday of conspiracy to defraud the Government.

title: Moynihan Rejects Isolation for U.S.; Hispanic Group Supports Mrs. Abzug
description: There is a fashionable notion about that America is a guilty nation that should withdraw from the world and concentrate on its own concerns, Daniel P. Moynihan said yesterday.

title: EARNINGS FALL 55% AT BIG BOARD FIRMS
description: The New York Stock Ex change reported yesterday that the aggregate net earnings of its member firms declined 55.6 percent in the second quartet over the 1975 period and 6.5 percent in the sixmonth period.

title: Pressmen Reach A 3Year Accord At News and Times
description: Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 has reached a new threeyear contract agreement with The New York Times and The Daily News, according to an announcement yesterday by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board.

title: Screen: J.D.s Revenge; Hoodlum's Spirit Takes Over Law Student
2 Jailed in Medicaid Fraud as a Warning; 2 CHIROPRACTORS RECEIVE 5 YEARS
description: Fiveyear prison sentences were imposed yesterday on two chiropractors who pleaded guilty to Medicaid fraud involving eight medical clinics that they owned or operated In New York City.

title: Volvo to Cut Back Its Exports to U.S.; VOLVO TO REDUCE ITS U.S. EXPORTS
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden, Aug. 125 (AP)Volvo, the Swedish manufacturer of luxury automobiles, said today that it would cut exports to the United States during the latter part of 1976 because of falling demand and large stocks of unsold cars.

title: People in Sports; Owens Proud of Latest Medal
France to Pursue Nuclear Deal With Pakistan Fought by U.S.
description: PARIS, Aug. 25One of the last acts of the outgoing Cabinet of Prime Minister Jacques: Chirac, who resigned today, was the announcement that despite American objections France would go ahead with the sales to Pakistan of a nuclearreprocessing plant.

title: GOLD AND POUND STILL DECLINING; Dealers Say Metal Could Go Below $100 by Sept. 15 Drought Hurts Sterling; GOLD AND POUND STILE DECLINING
description: LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP)The price of gold bullion tumbled further today in anticipation of next month's International Monetary Fund gold auction in Washington.

title: News Summary and Index; The Major Events of the Day
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 26, 1976

title: Emergency Has Cut Crime, Jamaican Authorities Say
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica. Aug. 25 (AP)Violent crime has decreased about 50 percent in the two months in which Jamaica has been under a state of emergency, the security forces high command has announced.

title: PIER WORKERS SEEK A JOBSAVING PACT
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 25 (AP) Talks are under way here on a new contract for 35,000 pier workers along the Atlantic Coast. The key issue is how to preserve jobs while the shipping industry adopts technology requiring less manpower.

title: New Look at Conrail Is Mostly a Matter of Degree
description: CROTON, N.Y.There is a thoughtful young man who studied diplomacy at Johns Hopkins. There is a lovely young woman who looks as though she could vanish into an Irish travel poster. There are assorted college graduates and college dropouts, with degrees in affability if nothing else.

title: JaiAlai Pelota Leaves Baseball in the Dust; JaiAlai Pelota Leaves Baseball in the Dust
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 24Over the years, the thousands of shots fired at the Remington Arms Company testing range never did any damage to the delicate equipment.

title: CORRECTION
description: Dr. William R. Roy, the Democratic candidate in the Kansas Senate race two years ago, was incorrectly described as a Roman Catholic in a wire service dispatch published in The Times Aug. 20. Dr. Roy is a Methodist.

title: Macy's and Gimbels to Open City and Suburban Stores on Sundays; Additional Day Is Expected to Produce Increase in Sales of 4 to 7 Percent; Macy's and Gimbels to Begin Opening on Sundays
description: Preparations by all three of New York City's largest retailersMacy's. Corvettes and Gimbelsto open on a Sunday for the first time this weekend have centered on staffing, training and expense needs. At the same time, the retailers are keeping a sharp eye on their competitors moves.

title: Thorbjorn PaustHanssen Of Autoliners Inc. Dies
description: Thorbjorn Paust  Hanssen, board chairman and president of Autoliners Inc., 80 Broad Street, steamship agents, died Tuesday while on vacation in Kristiansand, Norway. He was 62 years old and lived in Rye, N. Y.

title: Badger, Aide Under Motta, Is Named Coach of Bulls
description: CHICAGO Aug. 25 (AP)Ed Badger, an assistant under former coach Dick Motta, was given the top job today by the Chicago Bulls. Terms of a multiyear contract were not disclosed.

title: Peat, Marwick and Price Back S.E.C. in Accounting Dispute
description: Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company and Price Waterhouse & Company, two of the nation's largest accounting firms, disclosed yesterday they were siding with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the Government agency's dispute over how accounting rules should be formulated.

title: Covering Fine Furniture: Kilims, Art of Nomads
EYVIND JOHNSON, 76, 74 NOBEL NOVELIST
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 25 (AP)  Eyvind Johnson, a cowinner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1974, died here today in a hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: TV: Punishment and Reality of War Dramatized; The Threshold of Pain Examined on CBS; A Corrupted Vietnam Seen on Channel 13
description: The ability of the television factories to reduce potentially interesting ideas to dramatic drivel would appear to be second only to that of the Hollywood pornography factories. Today's textbook case is taken from The Tenth Level, a twohour drama special being presented on CBSTV at 9 this evening.

title: A SchoolLunch Caterer Admits Dumping of 16,000 Sandwiches
Graham Martin Nominated To Head Micronesia Talks
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 25 (Reuters)President Ford today named Graham A. Martin, the last United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, to conduct negotiations on the future political status of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.

title: MIKI WEATHERS ANOTHER STORM; Japanese Premier, Still in Office, Confers With Foes Who Seek His Ouster
description: TOKYO, Aug. 25  Prime Minister Takeo Miki appeared tonight to have weathered, at least for the moment, yet another concerted assault on his leadership of Japan's governing Liberal  Democratic Party.

title: LOCKHEED MOVES SOUGHT IN HOUSE; Harrington Asks Hearings and End to Loan Backing
description: Representative Michael J. Harrington has asked the House Banking Committee to hold hearings on the failure of the Emergency Loan Guarantee Board, set up to supervise Federally backed loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, to detect some $25 million in improper payments made by the company in recent years.

title: Jovial New Premier
description: PARIS, Aug. 25France's new Prime Minister, Raymond Barre, is a bluntspoken economics professor who is more widely known in Brussels than he is in Paris, even though he has long been consulted by French chiefs of state in time of economic trouble. Mr. Barre, who is 52 years old and is not affiliated with any party, exhibited his bluntness and independence in 1968 when he called on President de Gaulle and tried to talk him out of devaluing the franc after the decision had already been announced.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Aug. 26, 1976 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Council for Namibia11 A.M.

title: Art Farmer Finds jazz In Europe Challenging
description: What is life like for an American jazz musician who became fed up with life in the United States and moved to Vienna, from where he has traveled through Europe and to the Middle and Far East to play his fluegelhom professionally?

title: Pervasive  Corruption
description: The pervasive pattern of corruption which the City's Investigation Commission has uncovered during a 14 month investigation of the elevator repair division of the Housing Authority is only one more indication of the familiar practice that saps New York's economic strength.

title: Coast Nurses Strike Enters 7th Week; Outlook Dim
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 25A strike here by 1,800 registered nurses against 15 area hospitals has entered its seventh week with no settlement in sight.

title: Sutton Urges Ford to Speak Out on South Africa
description: Percy E. Sutton, the Manhattan Borough President, demanded yesterday that President Ford provide the world with moral leadership by speaking out immediately against the racial conditions in South Africa that have led to more than 250 deaths in recent weeks.

title: 2 SENIOR U.S. AIDES PAY VISIT TO KAUNDA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 25 (Reuters)Two senior United States diplomatic officials envoys met President Kenneth D. Kaunda here today at the start of an African tour intended to prepare for the next moves in American efforts to ease tensions in southern African.

title: Emily Schultze Holt Dies at 80; Was Counsel for Actors Equity
description: Emily Schultze, Holt, a prime mover in the organization of the American Federation of Radio Artists in 1937, and for many years counsel for the Actors Equity Association, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 25 East Ninth Street.

title: 13 Food Places Are Listed AFL Health Code Violators
2 Young Scholars Win Bonds in Bible Contest
description: EAST HANOVERWhat four things did Moses do to the golden calf?

title: Gail Pierson Wed to Seymour Cromwell
description: Gail Pierson and Seymour L. Cromwell, members of the Olympic Rowing Committee, were married yesterday afternoon in Natchitoches, La. The Rev. Frank Foret performed the ceremony in Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title: Mieczyslaw. Munz, 75, Is Dead; A Concert Pianist and Teacher
description: Mieczyslaw Munz, a former concert pianist who appeared with many of the world's leading orchestras, died yesterday of a heart attack in an ambulance as he was being taken to a hospital from his home at the Ten Park Avenue Hotel. He was 75 years old.

title: FRENCH PREMIER QUITS IN PROTEST AGAINST GISCARD; Chirac Says That President Didn't Give Him Means to Meet France's Problems; BARRE NAMED TO POST; Independent Economist Will le First NonGaullist to Head Cabinet Since 58; French Prime Minister Resigns In a Protest Against Giscard
description: PARIS, Aug. 25Prime Minister Jacques Chirac resigned today, charging that President Va'dry Gisaud d'Estaing would not allow him sufficient authority to deal with France's prob: lems.

title: SENATE UNIT CHECKS ON ROSELLI SLAYING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities is investigating on its own the murder of John Roselli, a reputed Mafia leader, seeking a link with Central Intelligence Agency plots to kill Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba and possible Cuban counterplots against President Kennedy.

title: Resort Owner Purchasing Biggest Atlantic City Hotel
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25The $7 million sale of Atlantic City's largest hotel complex, ChalfonteHaddon Hall, to Resorts International, a concern based in Miami that operates casinos in the Bahamas, is expetted to be announced at a news conference tomorrow mornine.

title: Mr. Carter Speaks Out
description: It took the kind of forthrightness that is in short supply in contemporary American politics for Jimmy Carter to tell an American Legion audience in Seattle that, if elected, he would grant a blanket pardon to Vietnam draft evaders. Quite predictably, he was booed for saying what simple decency dictatesthat it is time for the damage, hatred and divisiveness of the Vietnam War to be over.

title: Yonkers Says It Can't Rehire Teachers
description: YONKERS, Aug. 25Board of Education members met with city officials last night to decide how to carry out an arbitrator's order to rehire 300 dismissed teachers and discovered to their dismay that they could not do it.

title: PETROLEUM SUPPLIES UP FROM LAST YEAR
Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Nastase, Dibley in Flareup; Dibley Bows To Nastase In Flareup
Mausoleum Doors Stolen At EmanuEl's Cemetery
description: Bronze mausoleum doors and grilles and two funeral urns containing ashes were stolen from Temple EmanuEl's cemetery in Queens on Tuesday night or early yesterday morning.

title: CHINESE IN SAIGON FACE HEAVY TAXES; Communists Impose Rates of 80 to 100%, Retroactively
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  Cho Lon, the Chinatown in Saigon and long a center of shrewd businessmen, has been doomed by the authorities of newly unified Vietnam.

title: Jeannie Evert Ousted
description: HARRISON. N.Y. Aug. 25 (AP)Seventhseeded Jeannie Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., joined topseeded Terry Holladay on the sidelines today when Betsy Nagelson of Winnetka. Ill., scored a 3 6, 6.2, 6.2 victory in the first round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Westchester Country Club.

title: DUBLIN CONSIDERING STATE OF EMERGENCY
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 25 (UPI)The Government today asked Parliament to declare a state of emergency in the Irish Republic and enact strict antiterrorist laws as part of a new offensive against the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

title: Most Wall Street Leaders Back Ford; Money Raisers Role Changes; Wall Street's Leaders Mostly Favoring Ford
description: Wall Street, traditionally major source of financial support for political cainpaigns, is lining up fairly solidly behind President Ford as the 1976 Presidential race moves into its final phase.

title: SHELLING EASES IN BEIRUT AREAS; Fighting Goes On Elsewhere. as Arab League Reports Progress on Peace Plan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25The shelling of Beirut residential areas slackened today, but fighting continued in the suburbs and in other parts of Lebanon.

title: British Doctors in Pay Pact
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Bullmastiff Pup Sold to Watson Now a 136Pound Star
GOING OUT Guide
description: HORN OF PLENTY In a sightandsound burst of exotic music, galvanic gaiety and cellar atmosphere, the Cafe Feenjon seems to explodejoyously. You come out of this place into a Macdougal Street that seems quiet by comparison, which takes some doing on a Saturday night in Greenwich Village. Make that Sunday morning, at 2 A.M., with the Feenjon (a Turkish coffeepot) still percolating.

title: Carter Campaign Moving to Mollify Catholics After Dispute Over Democratic Party's Abortion Stand
description: Jimmy Carter's Presidential campaign has been moving in recent weeks to contain and counteract criticism from the nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy in the aftermath of the Democratic Convention's stand against a constitutional amendment to ban abortion.

title: Abercrombie Reports Loss Of $1 Million in Fiscal Year
description: Abercrombie & Fitch Comt pany, the ninestore retail chain that filed bankruptcy proceedings under Chapter XI on Aug. 9, reported yesterday a net loss of $1,016,695 for the fiscal year tended last Jan. 31 on sales of $23.8 million.

title: More Jobs and Higher Pay Seen
description: JuddFalk Inc., an executive recruitment concern specializing in advertising and marketing, has just completed its annual study of opportunities in the field. And would you believe that it predicts more jobs and higher salaries in advertising in the months immediately ahead?

title: Surgery for Nittany Lion
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Aug. 25 (UPI)Penn State's 1976 football hopes were dealt a severe blow today when it was learned that Duane Taylor, the star running back, would require surgery for a knee injury sustained during the summer. The surgery to repair the medial cartilage in the 5foot9inch, 202pound senior's right knee will be performed Friday by Dr. Alex Kalenak at the Hershey Medical Center in Hershey.

title: G.M. Raising Retail Price Of Average Car to $6,000; Sticker Cost of Typical Auto to Go Up 5.9%, or $338Chairman Says Buyer Will Accept Increase as Moderate; G.M. Is Increasing Retail Price Of an Average Car to $6,000
description: DETROIT, Aug. 25  The General Motors Corporation announced today that the average retail price of its 1977 model cars, including optional equipment typically chosen by consumers, would rise by 5.9 percent, or $338 a car.

title: Giants Drop Young After A Decade; Young Is Victim of Giants Move to Youth
description: PLEASANTVILE. N.Y., Aug. 25The Giants released Willie Young today and there were no press conferences, no speeches, no ceremonies.

title: 15,000 Israeli Nurses Strike
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 (UPI)Israel's 15,000 nurses went on a 24hour strike today to press for more money, forcing hospitals to go on an emergency basis. The nurses union complained that its members could not support themselves on the starting salary for a nurse in Israel, $218 a month.

title: Amex Prices Rise After 6 Declines; OTC Ends Mixed
description: After six sessions of declines, prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced while those on the overthecounter market ended mixed yesterday on moderate trading.

title: ATTICA INMATES TO VOTE ON PACT; Strike Goes On as Prisoners Consider a Broad Proposal Containing Concessions; Striking Attica Inmates To Vote on a Settlement
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 25 After two days of lengthy debate on inmate demands for reforms at Attica prison, corrections officials and inmate leaders recessed their talks tocliy while 1,980 prisonerg prepared for a cellblockbycellblciric vote on a proposed Settle input that officials hope will end a threedayold strike here.

title: New Jersey Briefs; Imperiale May Run Against Byrne; Clerks at Two Guys Stores Strike; Unemployment Ceiling to Be $104
description: State Senator Anthony Imperiale, the controversial legislator who rose to prominence during the 1967 racial disturbances in Newark, said he might run as an independent candidate for Governor if Governor Byrne planned to seek a second term.

title: Carey Names HigherEducation Panel
description: Governor Carey yesterday appointed a fivemember commission to propose a future course for all higher education in New York State, including the troubled City University of New York.

title: U. S. SENT 110 MEN TO CUT KOREA TREE; Pentagon, Giving Details of Action in DMZ, Says Troops Tore Down 2 Roadblocks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The Defense Department said today that 110 Americans and South Koreans were sent into the Korean demilitarized zone last Saturday to cut down the disputed tree where two American military officers had been killed by North Korean guards three days earlier.

title: Financial Survey of Colleges Finds Half in Poor Condition
description: About half of 2,163 institutions of higher learning examined in a new economic analysis of the nation's colleges and universities have been found to be in poor financial condition, according to a survey conducted for the magazine Change, a highereducation monthly.

title: AGNES FOWLER
description: Agnes Fowler, a former member of the board of trustees of the Seeing Eye Dog Foundation, died yesterday at her home in Salisbury, Conn. She was 85 years old.

title: Carey Welcomes Mondale, Predicts Victory in State
description: Senator Walter F. Mondale flew into New York last night to be greeted by Governor Carey with a prediction of a huge margin of victory in the state in November for the Democratic ticket.

title: Massive Protests
description: Thousands of demonstrators from France and neighboring countries clashed with police near Lyons last month while protesting the construction site chosen for France's SuperPhoenix, planned as the world's first large commercial fast breeder. Britain has ordered a fivemonth restudy of its breeder plans and the staggering problemsthat would be posed by the worldwide spread of plutonium, one of the most poisonousand explosivesubstances known to man.

title: Duveen, Recupere Victors In Turf Stakes at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 25  Duveen and Recupere, both ridden by Angel Cordero, captured the split divisions of the Seneca Handicap on the grass today at Saratoga. Duveen, close to the early pace set by Low Return, took the lead at the mile mark of the 1mile race and went on to a 4length verdict over Group Plan, the 95 favorite. Conceal II, a 201 shot, finished well to take the third spot, 6% lengths behind Group Plan.

title: NICKEL CARBONYL EASY TO PRODUCE; Possible Cause of Legion Deaths Used in Industry
description: Nickel carbonyl, which has been implicated as a possible cause of legionnaires disease, is one of the more toxic substances known and, according to experts, is relatively easy to produce under a variety of everyday conditions.

title: Still the Moon
description: The moon, though lately overshadowed by Mars, still poses many important unsolved scientific questions. Apparently, Soviet scientists are still in pursuit of the answers, as evidenced by the recent moon landing of the Luna 24 unmanned rocket. Its ingenious equipment proceeded to dig six feet below the moon's surface, take a soil sample, and then rocket that sample back toward earth for analysis on this planet. Similar Soviet devices brought lunar samples back to earth in 1970 and 1972.

title: Council Bill Seeks Added Noise Curbs
description: Legislation to curb noise levels in New York City was considered yesterday by the City Council's Environmental Protection Committee.

title: U.S. and Mexico to Battle Screwworm
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug, 25The United States and Mexico today took an important step toward eradicating from North America the screwworm fly, a parasite that causes millions of dollars worth of damage every year to cattle in Mexico and the American Southwest.

title: Who's Afraid of the Big Red Bear?
description: WASHINGTON  The deepening resistance to Soviet dominance of the international Communist movementexposed this summer in the conference of European Communist partieschallenges the antiCommunist basis of United States alliance policies. Rather than threatening to ostracize Western nations who allow Communists into their governments, we should be asking if the antiCorrununist coalition also has begun to outlive its usefulness and needs to start giving way to a less aligned pattern of world polities.

title: THEFT ARREST MADE IN A MURDER CASE
description: A 17yearold youth has been arrested and charged with robbing a young woman whose strangled body was found last Saturday in Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn.

title: DOW IS UP BY 7.90; G.M. VIEW A SPUR; Forecast of Record Sales in 77 for Industry Sparks a Late Buying Spree; Dow Rises by 7.90 to 970.83; Forecast on Auto Sales Is Spur
description: A late buying spree, spearheaded by the bluechip issues, enabled the stock market to register its first advance yesterlay in six sessions.

title: U.S. ACCEPTING 93 OF OFFSHORE BIDS; 8 Rejected in Sale of Leases for Atlantic Oil DrillingExxon Biggest Winner
description: The Interior Department announced yesterday that it had accepted 93 of the 101 high bids submitted by oil companies last Tuesday for the right: to search for oil and natural gas in the Atlantic Ocean off, the coast of New Jersey.

title: CARTER CONDEMNS THE FARM POLICY OF NIXON AND FORD; In Iowa Talk, He Says They and Butz Drove Hundreds to Declare Bankruptcy; Carter Condemns Farm Policies of Nixon and Ford
description: DES MOINES, Aug. 25 Jimmy Carter, the farmer from Georgia challenged today the Republicans traditional strength in America's midlands by bluntly attacking the agricultural policies of Richard M. Nixon and President Ford.

title: Mayor Wins in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 25 (UPI)Mayor Eben Hopson of Alaska's huge North Slope Borough has won the Democratic nomination for the state's seat in the House of Representatives. He will oppose the Republican incumbent Don Young, in the November election.

title: Issue and Debate; Con Ed Plan for SubMetering of Apartments Stirs Controversey
description: A new element has been introduced into the oftenstrained relationship between the Consolidated Edison Company and its New York City customers. The utility proposed recently that it stop doing business directly with 1.8 million city apartment dwellers who, up to now, have received a Con Ed bill each month.

title: House Democrats Renew Drive for StripMine Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The Democratic majority in the House of Representatives began another drive today to force past President Ford's probable veto a strong Federal law to regulate the strip mining of coal, one of the most bitterly fought environmental proposals of this decade.

title: Burt Reynolds Is Gator In Indecisive Crime Film
DEATH TOLL RISES IN SOUTH AFRICA; 19 Are Dead Over 3 Days in Wake of Zulus Battles. With Protesting Youths; Death Toll Rises in South Africa in Attacks by Zulus
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 25The death toll in the black township of Soweto rose today after a night of terror in which marauding Zulus drove scores OF other blacks front their homes and injured dozens of persons.

title: Parties to Meet Today On FordCarter. Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)  Representatives of President Ford and Jimmy Carter will meet with the League of Women Voters tomorrow to try to agree on a format for campaign debates.

title: SPANISH KING CURBS MILITARY IN POLITICS
description: MADRID, Aug. 25 (AP)King Juan Carlos has forbidden the 300,000 members of Spain's armed forces to take part in national political activity, in or out of uniform.

title: EMPLOYMENT GAINS IN NEW YORK REGION
description: Employment in the 18county New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area rose by 45,000 to 6.239 million between May and June, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. But over the year, between June 1975 and June 1976, the job total in the area fell by 99,000.

title: S.E.C. Says 6 Gained ln Equity Fraud Case; Alleges 5 Investment Advisers and Fund Profited From Inside Information; S. E. C. Asserts 6 Profited in Equity Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday allegations by its staff that five investment advisers and a major mutual fund were guilty of fraud when they profited from inside information three years ago that the highly publicized Equity Funding Corporation of America was itself built on a massive fraud.

title: Methodists Favor Talks
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 25, (Reuters) More than 2,000 Methodists from around the world, meeting here today, approved further international discussion with the Roman Catholic Church on common issues.

title: Schorr and 21 Subpoenaed In Release of Pike Report; House Ethics Panel Subpoenas Schorr and Others in Investigation of Release of the Pike Intelligence Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The House ethics committee voted today to issue Contrassional subpoenas for Daniel Schorr and three other journalists to compel their appearance at a hearing on the unauthorized disclosure of the Pike committee report dealing with activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Chlorine Price Raised in South By Olin and Diamond Shamrock
description: The Olin Corporation announced yesterday that it had increased the spot price of chlorine by $10 a ton to a price of $135 a ton for shipments from the company's Southernplants. The price for contract customers will be adlusted according to contract terms. Shipments of chlorine from Olin's Niagara Falls, N. Y., plant will remain at $140 a ton, f.o.b. plant.

title: Is Forrest Carter Really Asa Carter? Only Josey Wales May Know for Sure
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 25You could have fooled some of the people around here. They thought for sure that Forrest Carter, whose novel has become Clint Eastwood's current shootemtip movie The Outlaw Josey Wales, is the man they knew as Asa Carter, a speech writer for Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: Market Place; A Bright Spot Among Stock Averages
description: Of the 32 industry stock averages that Barron's tracks with issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, only the installmentfinance index rose to a new high last week.

title: Man Dragged by Car Dies
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP)A Freehold man died in the Princeton Medical Center today after being run over and dragged by an Auto last night on Route 33 in Monroe Township, the state police said. He was Scott Landes, 22 years old. The authorities said the auto had been driven by Pedro Ponce, 33, of Jackson Township.

title: Court Test Set on Rizzo Recall Petition
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25The legal dispute over petitions to recall Mayor Frank L. Rizzo was set today for courtroom argument next weekin time, if petition leaders win the argumentto put the question of Mayor Rizzo's removal on the ballot in the Nov. 2 election.

title: High Risk Individuals Finding Life Insurance Easier to Get
description: Joe Katz, who sells life insurance the same way he plays tennis  aggressively  could not have been happier if he'd just put away a tricky overhead for matchpoint. I did it, I did it, he shouted. Mr. Katz's firm, the HartenbergKatz Agency of Bridgeport, Conn., specializes in placing insurance on substandard or highrisk individualsgenerally persons with medical problems who have a rough time getting coverage in the open market.

title: The Bonhomme Richard Is Sought Off England
description: FLAMBOROUGH HEAD, England, Aug. 28 (Reuters)A costly underwater search is being made off the east coast of England for the Bonhomme Richard, the manofwar that, under the command of Capt. John Paul Jones, fought one of the memorable battles of American naval history.

title: Notes on People; Colson Tells Officials Of Inmates Despair
description: A wellknown former prisoner, Charles W. Colson, told the American Correctional Association yesterday that uncertainty, helplessness and paranoia afflict the inmates of the nation's prisons. The former special White House counsel to President Nixon, who worked in the laundry of a Federal prison while serving six months of his onetothree year sentence in the Watergate affair, said that disparity of sentencing was the greatest cause of despair for prisoners.

title: Unacceptable Risk
description: Sir Brian Flowers, chairman of Britain's Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution and one of Europe's leading scientists, recently warned his countrymen that the fast breeder was a billionpound step down a technological path which may later prove unacceptable or even catastrophic.

title: Bang How, 79, Represented Shanghai Commercial Bank
description: Bang How, a director of the Shangnai Commercial Bank and its representative office in New York until he retired in 1972, died Sunday in Hong Kong. He was 79 years old.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: Gambling Sought in Resort
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP)A group planning construction of a multimilliondollar resort complex at Mount Greylock in the Berkshires wants to include a gambling casino, if the Massachusetts legislature approves legalized betting. Backers of the proposed Greylock Glen at the base of the highest mountain in Massachusetts want to oplerate a casino or jai alai game, taccording to Joseph R. Dragone a group spokesmen.

title: FARM PRICES FALL ON CHICAGO BOARD; Soybean Futures Also Drop Near Permissible Limit
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)Farm commodity futures prices fell sharply again on the Chicago Board of Trade today and soybean futures closed with a decline near the permissible limit.

title: BRITISH ASK CONTROL OF GENETIC RESEARCH
description: LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) Strict controls on experiments in genetic engineering, where the characteristics of one organism are transferred to another, were set out today in a report by a British Government working party.

title: MRS. HENRY RINES; BROADCASTING HEAD
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., Aug. 25Mrs. Henry Bond Rifles, president and director of the Maine Broadcasting System, died last night in her home here. She was 89 years old.

title: SixCity Tour Canceled By Shakespeare Theater
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 25Still facing financial problems, the American Shakespeare Theater has shortened its season and canceled a tour of six cities this fall.

title: Sadat Nominated For Second Term; He Agrees to Run
description: CAIRO, Aug. 25  President Anwar elSadat today accepted a unanimous nomination by the Egyptian People's Assembly for second sixyear term of office, declaring that destiny wants me to carry on.

title: Gallup Poll Reports Ford Has Cut Lead Of Carter to 4939
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25President Ford, following his nomination victory at the Republican National Convention, has cut Jimmy Carter's early August lead of 23 points to 10, according to the most recent survey by the Gallup Poll.

title: Latest Tests Link Nickel Compound To Legion Disease; Scientist Says the Latest Tests Suggest Nickel Carbonyl May Have Caused Disease That Killed Legionnaires
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 25 New tests on tissue specimens from victims of a mysteriods ailment in Pennsylvania suggest that nickel carbonyl, a highly toxic substance, may have caused the outbreak, according to the scientist who conducted the tests.

title: Equity Pact Is Boon to Little Theater
TRAVEL GROUP ASKS SLUDGEDUMP CURB
description: BEESLEYS POINT, Aug. 25 (AP)The New Jersey Travel and Resort Association today called for sludgedumping farther out at sea and more monitoring of sludge barges from New York.

title: A Square Egg? Well..
description: The how of it all is a lot simpler to figure out than the why.

title: BONDS RESUMING RATEDROP TREND; Dip Evidenced by Levels on ShortTerm Commercial Paper and Bell Sales
description: The credit market's move toward lower interest ratesmove that stalled last weekgot going again yesterday. From short  term commercial paper rates in the money market out to a pronounced pickup in sales in the key I'llnois Bell Telephone Company debentures issue in the corporate bond market, there was solid evidence that the decline in rates had resumed.

title: 3 Indicted on Coast for Abduction Of 26 Schoolchildren and Driver
description: MADERA, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP)Three young men were indicted today on charges of kidnapping 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver last July 15.

title: News Summary and Index; The Major Events of the Day; International; National; Metropolitan
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 26, 1976

title: House Unit Approves Bill To Cut Peanut Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) A bill designed to reduce the Government's peanut subsidy program and to enable more farmers to produce the crop was approved today by the House Agriculture Committee.

title: Democratic Runoff Is Required For Albert's Oklahoma Seat
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 25A 37yearold Oklahoma state senator and the veteran chief aide of House Speaker Carl Albert will meet in a runoff primary Sept. 21 for the Democratic nomination from the Third Coneressional District.

title: 20 Militant Jews Arrested in Demonstration at OffLimits Hebron Hospital
description: HEBRON, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Aug. 25 Twenty militant Jews, most of them waving American passports, were arrested by Israeli military authorities today in this tense Arab city after they had demonstrated at an abandoned former Jewish hospital that had been declared off limits.

title: Advertising; Grocery Trade Promotion Study
description: Grocery manufacturers spend an estimated $3 billion a year on trade promotionsan amount understood to be higher than their spending on consumer advertising and consumer promotions combined. Yet it is generally believed that the measurement of these trade promotions has not been so effective as the other two categories.

title: Teton Dam Fund Passed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Senate gave final passagetoday to a bill to compensate victims of the collapse of the Teton Darn in Idaho. The Senate agreed to House changes Senate's original bill, sending it to the White House for signar ture. The cost of compensation and reconstruction was estimated at $331.5 million.

title: Portuguese Women Seek a Share In What Revolution Has Achieved
description: LISBON, Aug, 25Portuguese women find themselves in a Vacuum.

title: Metropolitan Briefs; ExCorrections Officer Is Indicted; 9 Hurt in SchoolBus Crash; 3,000 Welfare Rent Checks Missing; From the Police Blotter:
description: Special State Prosecutor John F. Keenan yesterday announced the indictment of Peter Rossi, a former New York City corrections officer, on charges of soliciting and receiving a bribe from an individual who had received summonses for traffic violations.
