Mr. Rossi, who is 46 years old, was dismissed from his job, which he had held for 19 years, earlier this month after a hearing by the Department of Correction, whose officials had been informed by Mr. Keenan of his investigation of Mr. Rossi.

title: Dance: The New American Machine; Has Auspicious Debut at Newport Festival; Works From Muticals to Be Preserved
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 25  A new company, opening a new dance festival in one of those towns that seem to have grown up with the ultimate promise of a festival in mindwhat could be more ideal? For Newport, R. I., does offer a festival, an almost perfect ambience, despite the lack of an adequate theater.

title: ELIZABETH THEOBALD
description: Elizabeth Theobald, chairman of the board of Theobald Industries, Kearny, N. J., died Tuesday in Plantation, Fla., where she lived.

title: Judge Bids Carey Widen Special Prosecutor's Role
U.S. Gains At Women's Net Event
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (UPI)The United States team, reduced to two players because of Chris Evert's hand injury, got maximum points today from Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals in defeating Yugoslavia, 30, to advance to the quarterfinals of the Federation Cup women's tennis competition.

title: Soybean Futures Up 20c a Bushel; Grain Price Mixed
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)A lastminute flurry of commercial buying set off short covering, and the combined efforts lifted soybean futures by the permissible limit of 20 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

title: Vietnam Veteran Releases Hostages And Gives Up in Ohio After 9 Hours
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 26  An armed Vietnam war veteran surrendered tonight to the police and freed nine hostages unharmed after holding them for nine hours in a suite, of offices on the 36th floor of the Terminal Tower Building.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: F.B.I. Aide Asks Sheriffs to Fight Against Bureaucrats and New Intelligentsia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26An official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has called on the warrior class of law enforcement officers to cry the battle alarm against Government bureaucrats, the new intelligentsia of the press and others who demean our heritage by their mindless control of our lives.

title: History of Lockheed Case
description: Since the Senate subcommittee on multinational corporations released documents last February showing that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had paid out $24.4 million to facilitate sales of its planes, the bribery scandal has had deep political repercussions around the world. Among the nations most deeply affected are the following:

title: Bangladesh Said to Try A Dutch Social Worker
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 26  A young Dutch social worker and freelance journalist is being tried in Bangladesh on charges of sedition, according to reports reaching here.

title: A Compromise Is Sought On Arms Sales to Saudis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and key Senators agreed late today to try to reach a compromise tomorrow on a controversial Administration plan to sell sophisticated bombs and missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)  The Federal Communications Commission today delayed for three weeks the announced discontinuance of common carrier communications services by the Data Transmission Company (Datran).

title: Georgian's Modification
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 26A day after promising to end embargoes on farm products once and for all, Jimmy Carter said today that under extreme circumstancessuch as a domestic crop failurehe would not hesitate as President to forbid the sale of American food crops to foreign countries.

title: Visiting Doctor Is Shot On Stroll Near Waldorf
description: A 43yearold doctor was shot in the arm by two teenaged robbers last night as he and his wife were walking a block from the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, the police reported.

title: Stock Market Indicators
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 26, 1976

title: Barre and Giscard Meet on Selection Of a New Cabinet
description: PARIS, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The new Prime Minister, Raymond Barre, conferred with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing today before selecting ministers for his Cabinet.

title: Catholic Policeman Slain In a Suburb of Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 26 (AP)A young Roman Catholic policeman in the mostly Protestant Royal Ulster Constabulary was shot to death today in a Roman Catholic suburb, the police said.

title: Pop Music: Good Rats Infectious
description: The Good Rats, the Long Island rock band that is at the Other End through Monday, may or may not finally make a national impact. One hopes they do, for they are about as amusing and infectious a bar band as this listener has heard in a long time.

title: Nastase Advances, With Dr. Richards
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 26The crowds cheered for Ilie Nastase and Dr. Renee Richards today, and with good reason after their quarterfinalround victories in the $60,000 Tennis Week open.

title: Nerve Gas to Be Drained
description: DENVER, Aug. 26 (UPI)A spokesman for the Rocky Mountain Arsenal said yesterday that 78,000 pounds of deadly GB nerve gas agent stored in an underground steel tank would he neutralized this fall. Col. John P. Byrne, arsenal commander, said a stockpile of 106 Honest John warheads had been drained of the nerve gas since the program was started last May. The missiles were declared surplus in 1973. He said the cost of neutralizing the GB nerve agent would be $20 million.

title: Icy Conditions Close Part of the Turnpike
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Aug. 26 (UPI)The police had to close one lane of the New Jersey Turnpike during the morning rush today because of icy conditionsbut not the winter variety.

title: Brooklyn To Relive Battle of 1776
description: CANNON will roar, muskets will crackle, fifes will whistle and drums will roll this week end as more than 1,000 colorfully uniformed American, British and Hessian troops fight it out anew for the vital Flatbush Pass.

title: MARKET PLUNGES IN SLOW TRADING; DOW IS OFF 10.39
description: The stock market plunged yesterday in slow trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing off 10.39 points to 960.44, its largest daily loss of the week.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CUTS SIZE OF CARS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 26  The General Motors Corporation unveiled today the first installment of the longheralded new array of scaleddown automobiles that the company hopes will meet the demands of the age of scarce and expensive energy.

title: Job Pact Reached By Longshoremen At 6 Atlantic Ports
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 26 (UPI)  Port employers and longshoremen in six major North Atlantic ports reached agreement today on a plan to increase job prospects and attract cargoes to waterfront facilities in light of a Federal court ruling negating container work protections in their master contract.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The sale of the controlling stock of the 1,000room ChalfonteHaddon Hall Hotel on the Atlantic City Boardwalk to Resorts International was announced at a news conference in the resort. I. G. Davis, president of Resorts International, a Miamibased resort promotion concern, that operates casinos in the Bahamas, and has supported casino gambling in Atlantic City, said his company was also planning to buy other local hotel properties and planned to build a 1,000room hotel on property already acquired. Anthony Rey, general manager of the hotel complex, said that 67 percent of the stock was being sold to Resorts International, pending approval by a family trust which he said was assured.

title: Morgenthau Seeks Letters On Lefkowitz Campaign
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau has obtained from the Onondaga County Republican Committee in Syracuse a list of contributors and has asked it specifically for any correspondence involving Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and his campaign for reelection.

title: Goldin Testifies 5 Hours In S.E.C.. Fraud Inquiry
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, spent nearly five hours in prilvate testimony yesterday before the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has been investigating allegations of fraud in the issuance of city bonds and notes in the last few years.

title: A Prince's RiseThen a Businessman's Fall
description: Not many careers were open to members of the minor German princely houses in the decades following the overthrow of the imperial Hohenzollern dynasty in 1918. They were eligible as mates for members of the diminishing number of reigning houses elsewhere in Europe. They could even go into business, particularly the kind of international business in which a princely title and an education would open doors.

title: August's Barometers
description: At the Republican Convention in Kansas City the other day, President Ford, in perhaps the most forceful speech of his career, told the delegates that the nation is on the march to full economic recovery and a better quality of life for all Americans. Despite President Ford's optimism, consumers and businessmenalthough only a few economists  are beginning to wonder whether the path to prosperity is, in fact, unobstructed.

title: Byrne Signs Bill Curbing Rape Testimony
description: TRENTON, Aug. 26Governor Byrne today issued a proclamation commemorating the 56th anniversary of the adoption of the 19th Amendment to the United States Constitution granting women the right to vote. He also took the occasion to sign a bill making testimony on a woman's prior sexual activity inadmissible as evidence in rape cases.

title: Rhodesians Reprieved?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service granted today what may be a brief reprieve from deportation Rhodesian tennis players who entered the country on British, the Netherlands and South African passports to play in the Federation Cup tournament in Philadelphia.

title: 2 More Seeking Nomination of Independent Party
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)John R. Rarick, former Representative from Louisiana and Robert Morris, a Texas newspaper columnist, jumped into the race for the American Independent Party's Presidential nomination, making it a threeway race.

title: A Churchill Is Starting to Earn His Stripes in ReadytoWear
description: A Churchill in trade? Why not, says Lord Charles George William Colin SpencerChurchill, who is the younger brother of the Duke of Marlborough, owner of Blenheim where cousin Winston Churchill was born.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue and Debate
description: Three of New York City's biggest retailers, taking action only 10 weeks after the 280yearold provisions of the blue laws were struck down, are poised for the first mass Sunday openings this weekend.

title: SEXLAW EXCEPTION IS BACKED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)The Senate voted 88 to 0 today to exempt fatherson and motherdaughter school activities from Federal sex discrimination.

title: 3 Incendiary Devices Exploded at 2 Midtown Stores
description: Three small incendiary devices went off at two Herald Square stores yesterday, causing minor fires and forcing the storesMacy's and Korvettes to close portions of floor space in the afternoon.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: Commodore Triumphs In Jump
description: BROOKVILLE, Aug. 26 Dennis Murphy, one of the stars of the United States Equestrian Team, rode Commodore to victory in, a preliminary jumper class today at the Nassau County horse show.

title: A Thousand Women Inquire About Jobs In Astronaut Corps
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 26, (UPI)A thousand women have informed the space agency that they may want to join the nation's allmale astronaut corps. And the men who run the nation's space program are de. lighted.

title: Lotte Lehmann Dies at 88; Diva and Lieder Specialist
description: Lotte Lehmann, one of the most illustrious operatic sopranos and lieder singers of her day, died in her sleep yesterday at her home in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 88 years old and had been in failing health for several months.

title: 2 More Die, Toll 28 In Mystery Ailment
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 26 The death toll from the mysterious disease in Pennsylvania rose today as two fatalities were reported among participants in the International Eucharistic Congress held in Philadelphia earlier this month.

title: In Memoriam
description: HIRSCHShella Lynn4/28/53 to 8/27/63. Forever lovedforever mourned. Mommy and Daddy

title: Labor Party Chairman Is Held in South Africa
description: CAPE TOWN, Aug. 26 Reuters)  The South African Press Association reported today that the national chairman of the South African Labor Party, the Rev H. J. Hendrickse, had been detained.

title: The Women of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 26  Senator Rebecca Latimer Felton only held office for one day but she has been remembered with 94 other women who have served in Congress.

title: State's Wineries Prepare for Harvest; 5 of the 12 Are Welcoming the Public
description: EGG HARBOR CITY, Aug. 26The state's 12 wineries are busily preparing for harvest before the end of the month, and five of the seven licensed to sell their product to the public are welcoming visitors to tour their facillities

title: Embargoes at Issue
description: DES MOINES, Aug. 26Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice  Presidential nominee, accused Jimmy Carter today of attempting to mislead Iowa farmers as to the Democrats' policy on foreign grain sales. But before the day was out Mr. Dole, also appeared to be somewhat at odds with the Republican platform and with President's Ford's own recent statements on the grain sales issue.

title: At the Movies
description: HOW DO YOU EXPLAIN COMEDY? asks Mel Brooks in exasperation. How do you explain Chopin? I hear a Chopin prelude and I faint. I swoon. How can a human being with hair in his nose, just like me, create those gorgeous silver melodies?

title: July Shipments Off 10.6% For Canadian Newsprint
description: Canadian mills shipped 735,535 tons of newsprint to all markets in July, down 10.6 percent from June but 13.1 percent more than in July 1975 when about 23 percent of Canadian capacity was affected by strikes for over half the month.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A pneumatic hammer operator was electrocuted and another was injured at the Jamaica construction site of the new subway in southeast Queens when the dead man's drill accidentally hit a 27,000volt feeder cable. The dead man was Nelson Ricks, 53 years old, of 511 McDonough Street, Brooklyn. James Evans, 57, of 1920 Union Street, Brooklyn, who was standing 10 feet way, was admitted to Queens General Hospital with burns of the left leg and shock. Both men worked for the Slattery Construction Company Inc. of 4636 54th Road, Maspeth, Queens.

title: G.A. Yarnell Weds Laurie Nussbaum
description: Laurie Ann Nussbaum and Gary Alan Yarnell, graduates of Cornell University, were married last evening at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club, where Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the Ceremony.

title: Management
description: When Jimmy Carter said he would control Government spending by bringing zerobase budgeting to Washington, he thrust the concept into immediate prominencemore prominence than it had ever known.

title: Price of Amex Seat Declines
description: A membership on the American Stock Exchange was sold for $40,000, down $10,000 from the previous sale July 16, the Amex said yesterday. Amex seats now are quoted at $32,000 bid, $55,000 asked.

title: Lea David freeman, 89;. Playwright Lived at Lambs
description: Lea David Freeman, a playwright and former continuity writer for Columbia Pictures, died last Sunday in the Touro Infirmary in New Orleans. He was 89 years old.

title: Today's Entries at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 (AP)Daisuki Araki pitched Tokyo's second nohit game in two days as the Japanese team defeated Puerto Nuevo, 4,0, today to advance to the final in the 30th Little League World Series.

title: U.S. Ambassador in Soviet Being Reassigned to Bonn
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Walter J. Stoessel Jr., Ambassador to Moscow while a controversy developed over microwaves beamed at the United States Embassy, is being reassigned to West Germany, according to officials here.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGSI

title: Market Place
description: It's too early to call it a new era yet, but the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange today round out their first week of modernday competition in providing separate markets for the same stock.

title: Yonkers School Board Is Facing New Decisions on Hiring Order
description: YONKERS, Aug, 26A city official and the Yonkers Federation of Teachers today confronted the beleaguered Board of Education wih two more decisions to make before the opening day of school.

title: Ford Up in the Polls
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Since the Republican convention in Kansas City, President Ford has gained 13 points in the Gallup Poll and now trails Governor Carter 39 percent to 49 percent, with about 12 percent of those questioned undecided.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 27, 1976

title: Man and Youth Seized in Ft. Lee Slaying
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 26Joseph C. Woodcock, the Bergen County Prosecutor, announced the arrest today of a man and a youth in New York City on charges of murdering Dominick Massaro, 24 years old, on Main Street in Fort Lee on Aug. 16.

title: A JURY CONVICTS DRUGRING FIGURE
description: Antonio Flores, described as the head of a major narcotics ring, was convicted yesterday on a charge of conspiracy to import 600 pounds of heroin into New York City from France.

title: A Grand Jury Calls 2 ExF.B.I. Aides In Burglary Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Two former high officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were summoned to appear before a Federal grand jury here today to explain their approval of illegal burglaries by bureau agents four years ago.

title: Tony Discovers Show Biz
description: When Capt. Anthony T. Abbatiello was under fire on Korea's bloody Pork Chop Hill, he promised himself that he got out with the standard complement of arms, legs and brains, he would never again attempt anything riskier than getting out of bed in the morning. Up to then he had never met anybody in the advertising business. Recently he did, and the next thing he knew he was sitting in a sulky sunrise wearing racing silks and driving a harness horse across the George Washington Bridge while auto horns blared, motorists cursed and his kindly old Sports steed threatened to leap into the Hudson of with sulky and driver attached. Then they The Times paced through the sepulchral thunder Lincoln Tunnel with trucks howling by, and finally up and down runways at Newark Airport alongside screaming jets. That, Tony has learned, is show biz.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: Morning

title: Reds Off Maine Ballot
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 26 (UPI)The Communist Party will not he on the Maine ballot in November, Secretary of State Mark Gartley ruled yesterday. Mr. Gartley said 4,031 persons who signed petitions for the party's Presidential candidate were not registered voters. He seemed to leave open the possibility of further consideration of charges of fraud and misrepresentation raised in the original challenge.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday:

title: LARGE EXPANSION SHOWN FOR WEEK BY MONEY SUPPLY
description: The nation's basic money supply rose $1.1 billion in the week ended Aug. 18, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The increase, larger than had been expected, cut short the credit markets' substantial advance.

title: M.S. Dunn, Dead in California; Was Pioneer in Protein Research
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (UPI) Max S. Dunn, a pioneer in amino acid and protein research and the first instructor of biochemistry at the University of California at Los Angeles in 1922, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Bel Air. He was 81 years old.

title: Americans in Drive to Aid Canterbury
description: LONDON, Aug. 26A number of prominent Americans, among them Henry Ford 2d, Walter Cronkite, Douglas Dillon, and three former Ambassadors to Britain, have joined to help salvage Britain's Canterbury Cathedral from 900 years of decay.

title: Saving the Schools
description: Teachers union president Albert Shanker has offered no doubt unintentionallythe most powerful argument yet to support the contention of the Educational Priorities Panel and others that funds set aside for teacher pay increases should be used instead to avert further teacher layoffs.

title: People in Sports
description: Al Oliver, the Pittsburgh Pirate outfielder, has accused the club of not taking his illness seriously, and his wife said the team gave her husband second class treatment.

title: New York City Units Link Lags to Cuts
description: Three municipal agencies said yesterday that they had been too overworked and understaffed to collect unpaid rents, to reply to a $6.4 million damage suit or to gather figures on waste in the leasing of space by New York City.

title: Newark Hit for 3d Night By Street Disturbances
description: Sporadic street disturbances continued forthe third consecutive night in Newark last night as groups of youths roamed about two neighborhoods, throwing garbage cans into streets and hurling bricks at buildings.

title: Seven Africans and a Briton Are Freed by President Amin
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 26President Idi Amin of Uganda announced today that he had released seven Africans who had been charged with attempting to assassinate him. A British businessman accused of spying was also set free.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Aug. 26, 1976

title: Lesson on Civil Rights
description: The latest report by the United States Commission on Civil Rights offers a useful reminder of long recognized facts that have recently been blurred by public acrimony or buried under the news of local incidents of protest and violence. The commission's message is that school desegregation can work and often does; that the process is moving forward peacefully in most the nation's school districts; and that peaceful progress is most readily attainable when community leaders understand their obligations to obey, and enforce, the law. It is precisely on this point that the commission levls sharp criticisms at President Ford for pursuing policies that undermine the desegregation process communities across the country.

title: Publishing: Mary Recalls Papa
description: There seems to be an inexhaustible fount of memoirs about Ernest Hemingway. The most recent one, by his son Gregory, appeared this spring, and before that one there have been accounts of life with Papa by other Sons, grandsons, sisters, former wives and friends. Gregory Hemingway's book was a small, pleasant surprise, but word of the second Hemingway memoir of the year has been bruited about for some !time now because it is by his fourth and last wife, Mary Welsh Hemingway.

title: HELMS CONCEDES PARTY WAS ERROR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Senator Jesse A. Helms, who last night sponsored a political fundraising party in a Congres sional building, apparently in violation of Federal law, conceded the error today and said that the party had original ly been set for a private club but that someone had switched the location.

title: Spain Bars Entry to Two Communist Party Leaders
description: MADRID, Aug. 28The Government, under strong pressure from ultraconservatives, has denied legal entry Into Spain of Santiago Carrillo, secretary general of the Communist party, and Dolores Ibarruri, known as La Pasionaria, the party's president. The two have lived in exile since the civil war.

title: Most of Velez's Campaign Gifts Came From Employees of Agencies He Runs
description: Campaign finance records filed by Ramon S, Velez, the City Councilman who is running in the Democratic primary against Representative Herman Badillo for the seat from the 21st Congressional District in the South Bronx, indicate that more than half of his campaign contributions have come from employees of two antipoverty agencies that he directs.

title: Art People
description: ONE of the most energetic people around London in the later years of World War II was Nikolaus Pevsner, a stillyoung exGerman scholar of art and architecture. Paper was short, in those days. Gas was shorter still. You couldn't go anywhere, and if you found anything to read it was printed on an oatmealsubstitute and ran to about 49 pages.

title: JURY INDICTS YOUTH IN STRANGLING CASE
description: A Brooklyn grand jury indicted a 17yearold youth yesterday for the strangulation murder of a woman whose body was found last Saturday in Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn.

title: Blue Ribbon Fair at Rhinebeck
description: An oldfashioned country fairwith 800 dairy cows, 300 chickens and 280 sheep competing for blue ribbonsis being staged this weekend at the Dutchess County Fair Grounds in Rhinebeck. N. Y.

title: How to Get There
description: Many roads lead to Prospect Park in Brooklyn, but the most direct is across the Manhattan Bridge and down Flatbush Avenue to Grand Army Plaza and the main entrance to the park. From Queens, use the BrooklynQueens Expressway, also to Flatbush Avenue. From elsewhere in Long Island, take the Long Island Expressway to the BrooklynQueens Expressway.

title: Reaping the Whirlwind in Southern Africa
description: South Africa's white society and its repressive government recently have been reaping what they have sown for years. Disorders have shaken the country for two months; upwards of 300 people are dead, mostly as a result of police gunfire; and in important areas of the country law and order seem to be breaking down.

title: The Trouble With Divestiture
description: HOUSTONSome members of Congress are supporting divestiture legislation which they say would help solve America's energy problems by breaking up the oil companies. But, instead of solving these problems, divestiture legislation will retard national progress toward the goal of improved energy selfsufficiency.

title: Phils Top Reds, 54, In 13th
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 (AP) Jay Johnstone scored from first base on a double by Garry Maddox in the 13th inning tonight, lifting the Philadelphia Phillies to a 54 triumph and their seventh victory in the last nine games against the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Blues Are Plentiful In Nearby Waters
description: AREA ABlues in the range of 8 to 12 pounds have been plentiful at Barnegat Ridge and along the beaches off Seaside Park, N.J. They'll take anything, stick your finger in the water and they'll go after it, was the report from Rick's Bait and Tackle Shop in Seaside Park. A lot of weakfish were reported around Point Pleasant where the Norma K. II, a party boat, made a good catch on Wednesday. In Barnegat Bay, crabbing is reported good and fishermen using metal lured have taken large numbers of snapper blues.

title: Excerpts From Dutch Premier's Speech
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from Prime Minister Joop M. den Uyl's speech in Parliament today on the inquiry into Prince Bernhard's involvement with Lockheed Aircraft. Included in it is a statement by the Prince.

title: Leventritt Film on CBSTV
description: A filmed report on this year's Leventritt Internationa Competition will be televised Sunday on 60 Minutes, the CBSTV news magazine from 7 to 8 P.M.

title: Michigan Plans to Bill U.S. For Cost of Fighting a Fire
description: SENEY, Mich., Aug. 26 (AP) The Michigan Department of Natural Resources has decided to bill the Federal Government for $100,000 for state firefighting costs because of a fire that is now sweeping through 19,000 acres of wilderness in Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 26, 1976

title: British Airways Optimistic Despite Concorde Losses
description: LONDON, Aug. 26In the first 10 weeks of its regular twiceweekly service from London to Bahrein, British Airways lost the equivalent of $2.3 million on the supersonic Concorde.

title: Georgian's Modification
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 26A day after promising to end embargoes on farm products once and for all, Jimmy Carter said today that tinder extreme circumstancessuch as a domestic crop failurehe would not hesitate as President to forbid the sale of American food crops to foreign countries.

title: Strife Between Zulu Workers and Strikers in Soweto Is Declining
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa. Aug. 26A tense calm appeared to have settled over Soweto tonight after three days of strife between Zulu dwellers in worker dormitories and antiGovernment demonstrators that led to the death of at least 21 persons and the injury of dozens.

title: Tangshan Teams Leave
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 26 (UPI) Chinese authorities have begun withdrawing some of the medical teams sent to Tangshan after last month's disastrous earthquake in the north China city, radio broadcasts monitored here said today.

title: Council Unit Debates Las Vegas Nights
description: Ten thousand Las Vegas nights grossing more than $100 million for charitable and religious organizations would be held each year in New York City under a proposed law, a City Council committee was told yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 27, 1976

title: A New 1826 Market Joins Boston's Downtown Revival
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26A 150yearold granite Greek Revival marketplace built to sell meat and produce reopened today amid jovial crowds, bagpipers and jugglers as the latest in this city's remarkable downtown renaisanceselling meat and produce.

title: A Powerful Schmidt Faces Severest Test
description: BONN, Aug. 26The strongest leader in the troubled West European community, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, is throwing himself into a difficult and close battle for reelection on Oct. 3.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today

title: Lincoln Center Goes Outdoors
description: This weekend is a historic one of sorts for Lincoln Center. For the first time in many years, its three major houses are dark. The Metropolitan Opera House and New York State Theater are briefly between seasons and Avery Fisher Hall is being renovated. Only the Vivian Beaumont is in operation. Nevertheless, the entertainment center is bursting with activity and every inch of its outside plaza and park space will be taken up over the weekend with the sixth annual Lincoln Center OutofDoors Festival.

title: Embargoes at Issue
description: DES MOINES, Aug. 26Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice  Presidential nominee, accused Jimmy Carter today of attempting to mislead Iowa farmers as to the Democrats' policy on foreign grain sales. But before the day was. out Mr. Dole also appeared to be. somewhat at odds with the Republican platform and with President's Ford's own recent statements on the grain sales issue.

title: Attica's Inmates Divided Sharply on Ending Strike
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 26Inmates appeared to be seriously divided over whether to accept or reject a proposed agreement to end their fourdayold strike at the Attica State Correctional Facility.

title: U.S. Inquiry on Food Plan Is Criticized
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, criticized the Justice Department yesterday for what he called the snail's pace of its investigation into the Summer Food Service Program for children and a lack of cooperation witll state and Federal officials administering the problemridden program.

title: Derailed Cars Being Cleared
description: DEVILS SLIDE, Utah, Aug. 26 (UPI)  Union Pacific Railroad crews worked today to clear 22 derailed ore cars from lines through Weber Canyon. The cars jumped the tracks yesterday at Devils Slide, twisting rails and spilling tons of iron ore. The cars were part of a 105car train hauling ore from Atlantic City, Wyo., to a United States Steel company plant in Orem, Utah,

title: Borg, Connors Gain in Tennis
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26, (AP)Bjorn Borg, the defending champion, and topseeded Jimmy Connors survived difficult threeset tests today and advanced to the quarter final round of the United States pro tennis championships at Longwood.

title: Rosenbaum Will Direct Ford's Effort in State
description: President Ford's reelection campaign in New York will be run by the state's Republican chairman, Richard M. Rosenbaum, officials at party headquarters in Albany said yesterday.

title: F.T.C. IS STUDYING ENERGY SUPPLIERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission said today that it was investigating whether oil companies and other energy suppliers received preferential treatment from banks and arranged to shut out competition.

title: McCarthy Issue in Court
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP)Supporters of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy went to court today to get his name placed on the November ballot as an independent Presidential candidate, but there was no immediate resolution of the case. Judge Joseph Mitchell of Superior Court suggested that lawyers confer in an attempt to reach an agreement, and they adjourned.

title: Dr. Smith Resigns Post
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Aug. 26 (AP)Dr. Albert E. Smith resigned today as athletic director at Eeastern Michigan University to accept a position at his alma mater, North Carolina A & T.

title: ANTONIO PALAZZO
description: Antonio Palazzo, a custom tailor, died last Saturday in Nassau County Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Williston Park, L. I.

title: AUTO OUTPUT TO RISE 11.3% IN SEPTEMBER
description: DETROIT, Aug. 26Barring any work stoppages, the American auto industry is scheduled to build 751,000 cars next month, up 11.3 percent from the 675,000 cars built last September, according to the trade paper, Automotive News.

title: A Happy Ending for Yankees' Late, Late Show
description: Oscar Gamble, his eyes decorated by purplish  red streaks from a case of pink eye, dressed slowly at his locker in the Yankee clubhouse and not very eagerly thought of what he had to do. He had to be at the eye doctor's office for an appointment in less than eight hours and then an hour after that he had to be back at Yankee Stadium to get the bus to Kennedy International Airport where the Yankees would leave for California.

title: Memorial Services
description: WILDMANFrederick S., Sr. Memorial service St. James Episcopal Church. Madison Ave. and 70th St., on Tuesday, Aug. 31, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Winsted Memorial Hospital, Winsted, Conn. 06098 or to St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Rally and Work Stoppag Back Strike at FranceSoir
description: PARIS, Aug. 26  French journalists heeded a call by their national confederation this morning for work stoppages to show solidarity with the strikers at the masscirculation afternoon paper FranceSoir.

title: Music: Marriner Conducts Mozart
description: CONDUCTING a chamber orchestra is something like driving a small sporty car. It takes a light hand on the controls and a keen responsiveness to small changes in speed and direction. Neville Marriner, who returned after a fiveseason absence to conduct the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Wednesday night, is a master at driving chamber ensembles. Those who own any of his British recordings with the Academy of St. Martin'sintheFields have the evidence hand.

title: Control Board Issues Warning On Teacher Pay Rise This Year
description: The executive director of the Emergency Financial .Control Board warned New York City yesterday not to grant wage increases to any teachers this year if, at the same time, so many other teachers must be dismissed that class sizes would be forced upward.

description: Associated Press, 1968

title: Training Site for Blue Jays
description: TORONTO, Aug. 26 (UPI)  The American League Toronto Blue Jays announced today they had reached a longterm agreement to hold their spring training camp in Dunedin, Fla., near Tampa. The expansion team begins play next year.

description: * As reporteus not adiusteu wr transrers ui loans to affiliated companies. ** Over 5100,000. RRegied.

title: No Welcome Mat For Marxist Scholars
description: An educational system reflects and bulwarks the society it serves. Higher education seeks, basically, to provide the cadre needed to supervise the functioning of the society.

title: Mets Home Tonight With Goals in Mind
description: The New York Mets open a ninegame home stand at Shea Stadium tonight, starting with the Los Angeles Dodgers, with 36 games left on their 1976 schedule. Their remaining objectives include:

title: Carter and Ford Diverge On Subsidies for Housing
description: Agreement on several major points but sharp disagreement on at least one key issue have already emerged in the views of Jimmy Carter and President Ford's Administration on housing and community development policies.

title: Suspect, 19, Arrested in Thefts Of Bronze Doors From Cemetery
description: The police arrested a 19yearold suspect yesterday in the theft of eight sculptured bronze mausoleum doors from Temple EmanuEl's cemetery in Cypress Hills, Queens.

title: Panels in Congress Vote to Restrict Nuclear Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Senate and House committees approved measures today intended to increase restrictions on the export of American nuclear materials and technology so as to prevent them from being used to make nuclear weapons.

title: Big Leak in Water Main Plugged After 10 Years
description: NEWARK, Aug. 26A leak that had been bleeding a troubled Lake Hopatcong water company kW eight to 10 years was fixed yesterday, and customers of the company were reported to be enjoying full service toaay for the first time in months.

title: Connecticut Disputes Philip Morris On Its Reasons for Remaining in City
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 26The decision of Philip Morris Inc., the cigarette manufacturer, to keep its corporate headquarters in New York City rather than move to Connecticut does not disturb officials in Connecticut as much as do the reasons cited by corporate officials.

title: RHODESIA CHARGES A CATHOLIC BISHOP
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 26The Government today charged a Roman Catholic Bishop, who is the most outspoken critic of its racial policies, with having failed to report the presence of nationalist guerrillas.

title: Books of The Times
description: CARMEN SANTANA is a stout, attractive, amiable Puerto Rican woman in her 40's. She lives in Brooklyn in a $170amonth apartment with her four youngest children and, like most New Yorkers, has trouble making ends meet on her income, which runs about $9,000 annually. A simple, placid woman who enjoys watching novetasSpanishlanguage soap operason television, she is still capable of temper when pushed around by one of the array of officialdom who loom in her life. She has given birth to a total of nine children by several husbands. one of whom she was legally married to; contraceptives, when she learned about them, failed her, and she has had her tubes tied. She once worked in a leather goods factory for $43 a week and as a numbers runner for much more, but has not worked for years for want of a babysitter she could afford, and because of chronic bronchitis. She is always paying for furniture on time, at exhorbitant interest, and buys food at a local bodega, instead of the supermarket, where it would be cheaper. The furniture is shoddily made and is wrecked by her children or worn out long before the payments are completed; in which case, she puts money down on a new set. Once, her daughter Casilda sold for $75 a set of furniture for which she and one of her husbands had paid $800 and on which they hadn't completed the payments; Casilda wanted her husband to prove his devotion by buying a new set. Two of Mrs. Santana's other children are on heroin and the younger ones are in trouble at school.

title: A Hotel From Bygone Days
description: The New Jersey shore, for all its appeal to middleclass families and its casual resorts where visitors can practically live in swim suits and Tshirts, still has touches of elegance.

title: Helen Humes Discovered Again at 63
description: When Helen Humes stands up beside the piano at the Cookery this weekend, squares her shoulders and lifts her high, buoyant voice to sing If I Could Be With You or You're Driving Me Crazy Or Gee, Baby, Ain't I Good to You or He May Be Your Man But He Comes to See Me Sometimes the restaurant's patrons are hearing a jazz singer who at the age of 63 is now being rediscovered for the umpteenth time. Miss Humes has been discovered and rediscovered for the last 50 years and apparently the process is not going to stop.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CUTS SEE OF CARS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 26The General Motors Corporation unveiled today the first installment of the longheralded new array of scaleddown automobiles that the company hopes will meet the demands of the age of scarce and expensive energy.

title: Lewis Michaux, 92, Dies; Ran Bookstore in Harlem
description: Lewis H. Michaux, whose National Memorial African Book. store was for 44 years a Harlem landmark, died of cancer Wednesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 92 years old and lived at 1270 Fifth Avenue.

title: 2 MANSON CULTISTS CAPTURED IN OREGON
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (AP)Susan Murphy a follower of Charles Manson, the convicted mass murderer, and another woman who escaped 13 days ago from a Federal prison in Los Angeles were captured today in Portland Ore., the Federal Bureau of Investigation here announced.

title: How to Chase the Weekend Blues
description: Some people say that they live for the weekends, when they can relax and have fun after a hectic workweek. But there are others who would just as soon forget that weekends exist. These are the people who suffer from what many psychiatrists call weekend depression.

title: Stage: Mondongo Is Papp Con Salsa
description: Outdoors, there are two Joseph Papps. One produces free Shakespeare at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. The other takes theater to the people in all the boroughs of New York. Mr. Papp's Mobile Theater Unit does not usually present Shakespeare, but it is Shakespearean in the sense that it is true popular theater. It speaks to the audience, directly, in its own language and music. It connects.

title: BIG TRADE DEFICIT IN JULY REFLECTS RISING OIL IMPORTS
description: The United States had its biggest monthly trade deficit in almost two years last month, largely because of increasing imports of petroleum, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Imports of all goods exceeded exports by $827.1 million in July.

title: Cyclist's Trip Round the World Is in the 3,000Mile Homestretch
description: On Aug. 8, 1974, Robert Morris left his Randolph, N. J., home to pedal around the world on his 10speed bicycle.

title: Beach Boys Riding Crest of New Popularity
description: The Beach Boys, who were in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., last night and will be at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City tomorrow night, Hartford on Sunday and the Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday, may not be turning out very interesting new songs these days, but they are more popular than ever.

title: CARTER AIDE SURE RIVALS WILL HOLD CAMPAIGN DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Representatives of the Ford and Carter campaigns reported substantial progress today toward an agreement on the schedule and format of the Presidential debates after a negotiating session lasting more than three hours.

title: Antiques
description: THERE'S A MANMADE STALACTITE CAVERN high above Broadway at Houston Street that represents salvation to hundreds of the country's antiqueglass enthusiasts whenever they have a problem. It is the Gem Monogram and Cut Glass Corporation, 623 Broadway, to which collectors go with their period crystal treasures when they need to have chips erased, cracks filled or parts replaced.

title: Amex and Counter Down; Crutcher Tops Active List
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter declined yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: Hurricane Heads Eastward
description: MIAMI, Aug. 26 (AP)Hurricane Emmy picked up strength today in the Atlantic Ocean as it continued eastward, away from the North American continent. At 6 P.M. the storm, with maximum winds of 100 miles an hour, was about 725 miles east southeast of Bermuda.

title: Amer. Soccer League
description: TONIGHT'S GAME Championship New York at Los Angeles.

title: Bridge:
description: If the opponents bid a game they apparently expect to make, it is generally wrong to double, unless the trumps will break badly for the declarer.

title: Advertising
description: Two executives of big agencies who are responsible for much of their companies' international advertising sat down recently (and separately) to talk about the subject they know most about. And both concluded that despite their fears late last year that 1976 would be difficult for overseas billings, the results thus far appear to be much better than expected.

title: More Mars Data Reported To Back Possibility of Life
description: Further evidence supporting the possibility that forms of life exist in Martian soil has been reported by scientists in Pasadena, Calif., on the basis of data from the Viking I lander.

title: AMERICAN DISRUPTS HIS MOSCOW TRIAL
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (Reuters)One of three Americans on trial here for drug smuggling caused confusion in the court today by talking of a mysterious death threat apparently made by overseas Chinese who had employed the Americans as couriers.

title: Rock Tracking in Central Park
description: Generations of New York children have grown up scampering across the rocks of Central Park, using them in games or for climbing up or sliding down. Even today, where modern playgrounds stand next to large outcrops, nature's rocks seem to get as much use as man's swings and slides on any weekend.

title: Sets Hope to Clinch Title in W.T.T.
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 26 (UPI)The New York Sets will attempt to wrap up the World Team Tennis championship tomorrow night in the third game of their three  of  five  game series against the Golden Gaters.

title: U.S. Seizes 18 Aliens Working Illegally
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26Federal authorities arrested 18 aliens today who they said were illegally working in South Jersey.

title: Roy H. Workman, 77, Dead Former I.T.T. Controller
description: Roy H. Workman, who retired in 1969 as controller of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died Wednesday in Paul Kimball Hospital, Lakewood, N. J. He was 77 years old and lived in Leisure Village East, Lakewood.

title: On Henry St., Its Pride and Problems
description: I wouldn't trade Henry Street for anywhere else in the world, said Don Parker, the festival coordinator of the ninth annual Henry Street Festival and a resident of Henry Street for eight years.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, August 27, 1976

title: Essex Fells Police Chief Indicted in Alleged Sale of Seized Gun
description: NEWARK, Aug. 26  An Essex County grand jury today handed up an indictment charging Police Chief William B. Mabee of Essex Fells with the sale of a confiscated .22 caliber revolver to a member of his denartment in October 1973.

title: Naber Captures 2 Races in Sweden
description: HELSINGBORG, Sweden, Aug. 26 (AP)  John Naber of Menlo Park, Calif., the fourtime Olympic goldmedalist, won two events today as a squad of American swim stars opened a European tour.

title: New York City Is Giving a New Twist To Placing Its Relief Clients in Jobs
description: The city administration has once again begun placing homerelief recipients in jobsbut this time they are simply working off welfare grants, instead of getting regular paid jobs.

title: 2D PACT REPORTED IN RUBBER STRIKE
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP)The United Rubber Workers union and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reached tentative agreement on a threeyear contract tonight that was expected to end the 128day strike at the company early next week, union and company spokesmen said.

title: WALDHEIM BARS SOUTH AFRICA PLAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim declared today that recent South African proposals for leading SouthWest Africa to independence by the end of 1978 fall far short of United Nations requests.

title: Mrs. Runyon Faces Six Challengers In 70th Assembly District Primary
description: On paper, Marie M. Runyon ought to be in serious trouble in her bid for a second term in the New York State Assembly. She is white in a district that includes much of central Harlem and is twothirds black. The top black elected officials in the area oppose her. She won two years ago by fewer than 200 votes. She has virtually no political organization and little money.

title: BRITISH PANEL URGES STATE POLITICAL AID
description: LONDON, Aug. 26A Government  appointed committee recommended today that Britain's political parties should receive state contributions so that they might function more efficiently. At present the parties depend on voluntary contributions and unpaid help.

title: 16 Are Injured by Missiles At West Side Carnival
description: Four police officers and a dozen otherf persons were in jured during a melee at a street carnival on the upper West Side last night involving scores of youths who threw bricks, bottles and at least two fire bombs at carnival workers and the police. None of the injuries was reported to be serious.

title: 2 More Die, Toll 28 In Mystery Ailment
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 26 The death toll from the mysterious disease in Pennsylvania rose today as two fatalities were reported among participants in the International Eucharistic Congress held in Philadelphia earlier this month.

title: Proposal to Limit Terms Seems Doomed
description: The agreement that striking inmates at Attica prison were voting on yesterday contains some proposals already under study by the Department of Correctional Services and other proposals that have been rejected in the last few years by the New York State Legislature.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: LIKE an ivycovered island awash in a sea of parkways and highrise, highdensity housing sits the tranquil Queens community of Forest Hills Gardens, home of the West Side Tennis Club. Every year about the beginlung of September the United States Open championships turn that serene island into the tennis capital of the world. As a sort of warmup, the Robert F. Kennedy ProCelebrity Tourney moves into the West Side's Forest Hills Stadium tomorrow.

title: Excerpts From the Official Report on Prince Bernhard
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Following, in unoffical translation, are excerpts from the conclusions Of the Dutch Commission inquiring into dealings between Prince Bernhard and Lockheed Aircraft and excerpts from other portions of the commission's report.

title: Drug Program Is Becoming a Restaurateur
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 26 Bruno's, one of Jersey City's bestknown restaurants until it closed four years ago, will reopen next month under the ownership of the Hudson County Drug and Alcohol Program.

title: KEY PHASE BEGINS IN SETTING BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Congress began the critical phase of its budgetmaking process today somewhat like the family making its final plans for spending next year without knowing for sure how much money will be coming in.

title: Volvo Distribution Shifted
description: The Volvo of America Corporation has taken over a nationwide Volvo distribution center and plans to complete work on a $150 million assembly plant in Chesapeake, Va. next spring, the company said yesterday. The announcement coincided with its Swedish parent's decision to out United States exports by year's end because of sagging demand and an inventory backlog.

title: OwensIllinois Increases Price of Glass Containers
description: OwensIllinois Inc. said yesterday that it would selectively increase the price of glass containers used in the food, beverage and drug industries by as much as 5 percent.

title: How Does a Dog Beat a Dog Day?
description: Not difficult, really, if you happen to be passing the fountain outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art. You just dive in, with canine insouciance. But don't expect the heat wave to go away: it will continue through tomorrow.

title: About Real Estate
description: Secondary financing for residential property is one of the more esoteric fields of real estate.

description: TRENTON. Aug. 26Senafor James P. Dugan of Bayonne, the Deniocratic state chairman, who fielded an uncommitted slate of delegates in the New Jersey Presidential printery on June 8, said today that Gov. Jimmy Carter's representative would not run the Democratic Presidential nominee's campaign in the state.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: A parent comes home from the hospital with a newborn baby, looks it straight in the eye, and often wonders what, if anything, is going through the infant's mind. Does the baby see the parent, or is it just aware of some kind of shapeless confusion?

title: ExGovernor Is Accused Of Fixing Potash Prices
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)A former Governor and four other exofficials of New Mexico joined Canadian provincial officers and American potash industry leaders in a pricefixing conspiracy that cost United States farmers millions of dollars, according to court papers filed here.

title: Jay Rothschild, 83, Dead; ExLaw School Professor
description: Jay Leo Rothschild, a lawyer for 60 years, died yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N. Y. He was 83 years old.

title: ... Uneasy Coalition
description: Even as Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's Prime Minister, Mr. Chirac made no bones about his ambition to run against him for the presidency in 1981. But his immediate objective is to rebuild Gaullist electoral strength and prevent a sharp decline in the number of Gaullist seats in the next National Assembly. The Gaullists, with 174 deputies, still hold the largest bloc of seats in the 490member Assembly.

description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter Designates OTB listing

title: Campaign Tied by Mrs. Abzug to Women's Equality
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug claimed Women's Equality Day for her own yesterday, telling a group of cheering women supporters that New York has never had a woman Senator in the 56 years since American women got the right to vote and that she wanted to be the one to overcome the injustice of an allmale Senate.

title: CARTER AIDE SURE RIVALS WILL HOLD CAMPAIGN DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Representatives of the Ford and Carter campaigns reported substantial progress today toward an agreement on the schedule and format of the Presidential debates after a negotiating session lasting more than three hours.

title: Sharp Turn in Paris...
description: The decision by French President discard d'Estaing to name Raymond Barre as Prime Minister amounts to the appointment of an economist to carry out a political task. Professor Barre's most urgent task, according to the announcement, is to be the combating of inflation without halting the country's recovery from its deepest recession since the 1930's. But it is also clear that his most important function will be to aidwhere his predecessor, Jacques Chirac, impededMr. Giscard d'Estaing in a political move to the left designed to head off a CommunistSocialist victory in the 1978 parliamentary elections.

title: Soweto Clash Shows Divisions of Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 26The rampage of migrant Zulu workers in Soweto that has left at least 21 dead this week was prompted by harassment by young demonstrators seeking to enforce a threeday strike, but behind the conflict lie deep  seated disagreements, even enmities, among the blacks themselves.

title: Stock Market Project By Weeden Completed
description: A $650,000 pilot project to demonstrate the feasibility of a national stock market system ha sbeen completed and will soon be ready for demonstration, Donald E. Weedon, chairman of Weeden & Company, disclosed yesterday.

title: Borough at War
description: In the musical department, tomorrow's concert, will feature the Chords Melody, the John Collins Band, the Fast, Sun and Startoon.

title: Facing Up to Vanities
description: If you drive straight through, Jack Heifner was saying, Dallas is only 26 hours from Broadway.

title: U.S. Panel Delays Ruling On CarterFord Debates
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Federal Election Commission put aside today a proposal to give the League of Women Voters approval to sponsor a series of televised debates between the Republican and Democratic Presidential and VicePresidential candidates.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: August is the month when sales are dribbling along at everybody's local nursery. If the owners could, they'd probably go on vacation. Most of their outdoor stock can't be transplanted well this time of year, and people are still too immersed in summer sunshine to feel like expanding their indoor !plant collection. But someone has to stay around to water all those nursery plants, so what the owners usually do, instead of going on vacation, is have a sale on gardening tools.

title: July's Chain Store Sales Up 8.4% Over '75 Month
description: Chain store sales last month were up 8.4 percent from July 1975, according to a compilation made by Chain Store Age magazine. For the first seven months of the year, sales were 11.8 percent ahead of the corresponding period of 1975.

title: HEAD OF HERSTATT AND 7 EMPLOYEES SEIZED IN GERMANY
description: BONN, Aug. 26 More than two years after the collapse of Bankhaus, I.D. Herstatt, in Cologne, the city's District Attorney arrested the bank's former chief officer and seven other former employees today on charges of fraud.

title: Gold Drops as Iran Rumor Roils Trade
description: The price of gold bullion continued to slide in London yesterday in late dealings. Earlier, the afternoon fixing by bullion merchants had shown a slight rise on the day.

title: Mustering the Spirit of Colonial America
description: Renowned for a distinct sound that is said to be able to shake green apples off the trees, fifers and drummers from around the old Colonies will gather in the tiny shoreline town of Westbrook, Conn., at 11 A.M. tomorrow km what they fully expect to be one of their more illustrious musters in the last 200 years.

title: Lotte Lehmann Dies at 88; Diva and Lieder Specialist
description: Lotte Lehmann, one of the most illustrious operatic sopranos and lieder singers of her day, died in her sleep yesterday at her home in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 88 years old and had been in failing health for several months.

title: Bohen Captures 3Way Playoff By Stroke for Met. Open Title
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 26Marty Bohen, a 34yearold professional golfer who has rarely won a tournament, sank a 25foot birdie putt at the third hole of a medalscore, threeman playoff and won the 61st Metropolitan Golf Association open championship today at Upper Montclair.

title: Soweto Clash Shows Divisions of Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 26The rampage of migrant Zulu workers in Soweto that has left at least 21 dead this week was prompted by harassment by young demonstrators seeking to enforce a threeday strike, but behind the conflict lie deep  seated disagreements, even enmities, among the blacks themselves.

title: Esmark Reports Its First Quarterly Decline in Earnings Since 1970
description: Esmark Inc., a diversified industrial company operating the world's largest meat packer, Swift & Company, reported yesterday a quarterly profit drop of 36.5 percent, its first since 1970, Earnings for the nine months to July 31 reached a record.

title: Restaurants
description: WASTED EFFORT is never a happy thing to contemplate When obviously huge amounts of time, money and effort have gone into new restaurants all to little avail from the standpoint of the food they serve, it is a sorry situation indeed. This week's report on two of the city's newest restaurants is less than encouraging, but not entirely hopeless.

title: A Revue of Hit Songs That Survived Flops
description: Hit Tunes From Flop Shows, a musical revue by the Atlantic Players which begins a threeweekend run in the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden tonight at 8 P.M., is just what it purports to be. The tunes the Atlantic Players will be singing are not just hits, they are among the bestknown and best loved songs from the last 75 years of Broadway musicals. But without exception they came from shows that received dour reviews and were dismal disasters.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission today rejected.a proposal of the New York Stock Exchange to change theeXchange's rules affecting foreign membership and membership by bank subsidiaries. The S.E.C. said the rule proposals appeared to be anticompetitive and against the intent of Congress.

title: The Ordeal of Fatty Arbuckle
description: In 1921, Roscoe (Fatty) Arbuckle was one of the greatest movie stars in Americacertainly the most popular comedian. He had signed a three  year contract with Paramount Pictures that guaranteed him a million dollars a year. He had just completed the remarkable feat of making three featurelength films simultaneously  that is, shuttling from one to another during the filming. That September, there were six Fatty Arbuckle movies playing in Los Angeles and six in New York, as well as 27 tworeclers. The 266pound comedian was a formidable talent; he moved with gazellelike grace, yet was so strong that in a World War I publicity stunt he stood immobile against a pushball while 25 Marines tried to push it.

title: Tokyo Lockheed Inquiry Bars Summoning of Former Premier
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP)A parliamentary committee investigating the Lockheed bribery scandal rejected an opposition demand today that the indicted former Prime Minister, Kakuei Tanaka, and the secretary general of the governing LiberalDemocratic Party be called to testify in the case.

description: (In pounds sterling per metric ton)

title: The Labor Scene
description: If the Democrats have their way, unemployment will he the biggest issue in the election campaign. But two of the nation's foremost labor market analysts insist that the argument is over statistics that long ago lost their validity as economic indicators for determining Government policy.

title: Late Summer Is Prime Time at Jersey Shore
description: Ever since the LeniLenape Indians first cut the trails that eventually became major highways to the New Jersey coast, the state's shore resorts have been meccas for family fun.

title: A New 1826 Market Joins Boston's Downtown Revival
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26A 150yearold granite Greek Revival marketplace built to sell meat and produce reopened today amid jovial crowds, bagpipers and jugglers as the latest in this city's remarkable downtown renaisanceselling meat and produce.

title: Lockheed's Chairman Saddened by Report
description: The head of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that he was saddened by the report of the Dutch Government inquiry that criticized Prince Bernhard for what was termed his unacceptable relationship with the company.

title: Strike Fails To Impede Spa Racing
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26Jockeys at the Saratoga thoroughbred racing track carried their own saddles for the second straight afternoon today as negotiations between the New York Racing Association and Teamsters Union 814, representing jockeys' valets, stalled.

title: People and Business
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss protested to the Japanese ambassador yesterday that Japan was rigging the exchange rate of the yen to keep it artificially low against the dollar.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: TV Premium Offer Ban Dropped
description: The Federal Trade Commission has decided to drop its proposed ban on premium offers in TV ads directed to children. It will concentrate instead on monitoring ads containing such premiums to insure that they are not used in an abusive way..

title: 2 More Seeking Nomination of Independent Party
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)John R. Rarick, former Representative from Louisiana and Robert Morris, a Texas newspaper columnist, jumped into the race for the American Independent Party's Presidential nomination, making it a threeway race.

title: W.B.A. Elects Cordova
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)  Elias Cordova of Panama was reelected today to a third term as president of the World Boxing Association during the organization's weeklong meeting here.

title: Capturing the Image Of Dream Houses That Already Exist
description: More than once, Jack Moment has had to dive into the bushes when the husband of the lady of the house came home. Mr. Moment, however, is not a lothario. He is a house painter.

title: Mondale Backs Israel and Aid to Cities
description: In his first day of campaigning in New York, Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Vice  Presidential nominee, called for a bipartisan guarantee of Israel's existence and pledged that a Carter administration will not turn our backs on New York and other American cities.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Cornell Fares Well In the Bond Market
description: The Big Red of Cornell did pretty well in the bond market yesterday.

title: Ford and 3 Guests Dining With Strategy as a Topic
description: VAIL, Colo.. Aug. 26President Ford devoted his attention here today to patching wounds in the Republican Party and Ford campaign hierarchies.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Dalai Lama Ends Retreat
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The Dalai Lama, the exited Buddhist leader of Tibet, left here today on a 17day tour of the border district of Ladakh, ending a retreat of more than three months in the Himalayan town of Dharmsala.

title: DEMOCRATS ASK HOWE TO QUIT RACE
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 26 Utah's State Democratic Executive Committee tonight asked Democratic Representative Allan T. Howe to step down as a candidate for reelection from the Second Congressional District after his conviction on Tuesday on a sex solicitation charge.

title: Broadway
description: ARTHUR MILLER'S new play, The Archbishop's Ceiling, will open in New Haven, but this is not the traditional preBroadway, outoftown tryout where the playwright is locked in a hotel room rewriting the firstact curtain. There are some casting problems but The Archbishop's Ceiling is scheduled to open Dec. 17 at the Long Wharf, a regional theater. It will be staged by Arvin Brown, the company's Artistic director, and it will run only for one month. If the play is successful, as David Rabe's Streamers was last year at the Long Wharf, then it may come to New York.

title: Riggins Adjusting To Redskins' Style
description: Jets fans finally will see a running back they can recognize tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Orantes, Evert Open Doubtfuls
description: Suppose they held the United States Open tennis tournament, and nobody came?

title: Roselle Woman Wins $250,000 in Lottery
description: OCEAN CITY, Aug. 26 (AP) Mary Kelleher of Roselle won $250,000 in the Jersey Jackpot lottery today.

title: Met Show Proves Prints Are Art
description: IT'S an interesting historical fact that the first museum show of the fall season, should be of modern American prints at the Metropolitan Museum, and that we should all go there in the knowledge that we shall find major artists at full stretch. It's a safe bet that in such circumstances some of the things on view will rank with the best that has been done by Americans in any medium over the last 20 years. That's something that we now take for granted.

title: House Panel Studies a Bill Allowing ClearCutting in U.S. Forests
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26(AP) The House Agriculture Committee is looking over legislation that would once again open national forests to the clearcutting of trees by private companies under Government permits.

title: Women's Equality Day Declared by President
description: VAIL. Colo., Aug. 26 (AP) President Ford has declared today Women's Equality Day, and asked states that have not done so to ratify the equal rights amendment.

title: Sikes, at 66, Leads By Shot at Akron
description: AKRON, Ohio (AP)Dan Sikes, a graying, 45yearold veteran of the tour, missed the rain through the luck of the draw, carded a sixunderpar 66 today that set the pace in the firstround of the $200,000 American Golf Classic.

title: Alaska Interstate in Pact To Buy McAlester Fuel
description: The Alaska Interstate cornpany of Houston announced yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the McAlester Fuel Company of McAlester, Okla., for cash and notes totaling $39.4 million. Under terms of the agreement, Alaska Interstate will pay $9.3 million in cash and the balance in 7.5 percent installment notes.

title: PAUL W. HAVENER
description: Paul William Havener, an investment broker, died Wednesday of a heart attack He was 67 years old and lived at 111 East 88th Street.

title: ExConnecticut Aide Sues, Charging Political Dismissal
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 26 (AP)A former Connecticut Labor Commissioner who was laid off as a state mediator last January has sued the state, asserting that he lost his job because he was a Republican.

title: Ellen Duffy, Longtime Trustee Of Barnard College, Dead at 90
description: Ellen O'Gorman Duffy, a trustee of Barnard College from 1931 to 1954 and former president of the Women's University Club of New York, died Wednesday while visiting in San Diego. She was 90 years old.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERMildred. Beloved mother of Barbara Wolfa & Paul. Dear sister of Rove Chwatsky & Lou Gold. Cherished grandmother. Services Friday 10 A. M. at Gutterman's Nassau Meinorial Chapel Long Beach Rd., ar Grey..done, Rockville Centre,

title: BIG TRADE DEFICIT IN JULY REFLECTS RISING OIL IMPORTS
description: The United States had its biggest monthly trade deficit in almost two years last month, largely because of increasing imports of petroleum, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Imports of all goods exceeded exports by $827.1 million in July.

title: Notes on People
description: The unexpectedly sensitive subject of grits returned to nettle Joan Mondale yesterday.

title: Remember Last Year's Nostalgia?
description: The troubles of today make me want to return to the past, with all its purity, innocence, niceness, says Paul Saryian, the mastermind of this weekend's Nostalgia Convention at the Staler Hilton Hotel, the second annual event of its kind.

title: The Pop Life
description: WHEN IT COMES TO SMARTS, disco music doesn't enjoy a terribly good reputation. In fact, it's loftily dismissed as mindless by many rock partisans whose own music was similarly dismissed only a few years ago.

title: DUTCH PRINCE QUITS POSTS AS INQUIRY BOARD ASSAILS HIS LINKS WITH LOCKHEED
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 26Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands resigned virtually all his military and business posts today after a Government commission strongly criticized his unacceptable relationship with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Drought in Britain Causes the River Thames to Leak
description: LONDON Aug. 26  Denis Howell, the minister who is recting Britain's battle against a drought for which no one here can find a precedent, said today that the Thames River, was leaking.

title: R.B. GOODEN, 101, ANGLICAN BISHOP
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI)Bishop Robert B. Gooden, believed to have been the oldest active Anglican bishop in the world, died Tuesday. He was 101 years old.

title: No.Amer.Soccer League
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAME

title: Airline Stock Deal Set By Laurence Rockefeller
description: MIAMI, Aug, 26 (UPI)Eastern Airlines announced today that Laurence S. Rockefeller, holder of all 216,736 shares of its $3.75 convertible preferred stock, had agreed to exchange it for 800,000 shares of its common stock.

title: Music: Dirt Band
description: The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band has been performing country rock for 10 years now, without ever really emerging into the music's forefront. Their Will The Circle Be Unbroken, a threerecord album with a cast of guests that reads like a country music hall of fame, earned them the affections of the rootsconscious progressive country community, but its success was due to the guests as much as to the musicians in the band.

title: Canadian Company Plans an AllElectric Steel Plant Along the Delaware in New Jersey or Pennsylvania
description: CAMDEN, Aug. 26CoSteel International Ltd. of Whitby, Ontario, plans to build a $100 million allelectric steel manufacturing plant on the lower Delaware River, either on the New Jersey or Pennsylvania side, a spokesman for the company said today in a telephone interview.

title: Brazil Hopes Offshore Oil Provides SelfSufficiency
description: CAMPOS, Brazil, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Brazil, its economic development seriously affected by the steep rise in oil prices, is hoping that offshore fields near here will help it achieve selfsufficiency in oil during the 1980's.

title: Bus Kidnapping Arraignment Is Delayed
description: MADERA, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI)  Three young men accused of kidnapping a Chowchilla school bus driver and 26 children made a brief appearance in court today as their arraignment was postponed until Sept. 22. Bail was continued at $1 million each.

title: Manila Captures a Red Guerrilla Leader
description: MANILA, Aug. 26The longhunted commander of the Communist guerrilla movement in the Philippines was captured today with nine of his aides, and President Ferdinand E. Marcos said that as a result the Communistled rebellion was virtually eliminated.

title: Corporate Country
description: Refuting defeatist pessimism over New York's economic future, Raymond Horton, staff director of the Temporary Commission on City Finances, predicted in a City Club address last January that the city's fortunes would begin to turn within four or five years as production costs stabilized here and continued to soar elsewhere. The considered decision of Philip Morris, Inc., the nation's second largest manufacturer of cigarettes and No. 74 on Fortune magazine's list of 500 leading companies, to maintain and expand its world headquarters here offers encouraging evidence that Professor Horton's hopeful forecast may be realized much sooner than he had anticipated.

title: Buckley and Peyser Headquarters Equal in Enthusiasm, if Not in Resources
description: In a sprawling, airy office on the eighth floor of 545 Fifth Avenue, at 45th Street, stack upon stack of computerized voter lists wait near the banks telephones. Cardboard cartons full of the candidate's paperback book are piled outside the press secretary's cubicle. The detailed accountant's sheets on the campaign manager's desk show an income of more than $1 million.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Sex Tests For Open Under Way
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27Many of the women tennis players who are here to compete in the Federation Cup took a chromosome test today that is required of all women entrants in the United States Open tennis tournament. The test, which determintes the sex of the subject, was administered in Room 701 of the Hilton Hotel by Dr. Robert Grossman and his assistant, Elliot Hershman, who are affiliated with the Institute of Sports Medicine and Athletic Trauma of Lenox Hill Hospital in New York.

title: Giants, Packers Rebuilding In Shadow of Past Rivalry
description: LEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 27Once, when the Packers were the giants of the National Football League and the Giants were pretty big, too, even a preseasonmeeting would have created a sellout in Green Bay. It still does.

title: AIR PURCHASE SET BY TRANSAMERICA
description: The Transamerica Corporation, a diversified holding company, said yesterday that its board had authorized the purchase of 2 million shares of its common stock to enable it to cornplete a taxfree acquisition of Saturn Airways by Trans International Airlines, a Transamerica subsidiary. Negotiations for the acquisition started two years ago, and revised terms were announced last June 18.

title: Bridge:
description: The basic guideline for leading against grand slams is to choose something safe. But there are rare occasions when this principle should he ignored, and the opening leader should select something unsafeor apparently unsafe.

title: DALEY DENIES SPYING ON ANTIWAR GROUPS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP)Mayor Richard J. Daley has said under oath that, to the best my recollection, he never ordered the Chicago police to spy on his political opponents or civil rights or antiwar groups.

title: France Faced With Political Crisis Over Constitutional System
description: PARIS, Aug. 27The apparent ease with which President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France has overcome the Government crisis after his falling out with the former Prime Minister. Jacques Chirac, veils deep political trouble ahead for France. French commentators and politicians have been hinting at it publicly, but most have refrained from measuring the dangers aloud. A few, however, have spoken of the fate of the Fifth Republic being at stake and Le Monde's veteran analyst, Pierre VianssonPonte, went so far as to predict that historians would mark last Wednesday, the date of Mr. Chirac's resignation, as the end of the regime established by General Charles de Gaulle amidst a threat of civil war in 1958.

title: Radio
description: 66:53 A.M., WNYCAM. Works of Gabrieli, Senn, Caroubel, Paix, Le Roy, Neusidler, De Sermisy and Uataille.

title: Sets Win Team Tennis Title With 3113 Rout for a Sweep
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Aug. 27 In an atmosphere devoid of the requisite ingredients of a championship seriesfrenzied fans, banners and competitionthe New York Sets swept the Golden Caters, 3113, tonight for their first World Team Tennis title in the threeyear history of the league.

title: Relapse in Midtown
description: In an all too brief interlude, while the city played host to the Democratic National Convention, the local authorities managed to make midtown safe and fit for those who work and play in that vital patch of metropolitan life. The welcome respite seems regrettably to have ended almost as soon as the last delegates returned to their home communities with glowing accounts about New York's hospitality and peacefulness.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A thunderstorm and lightning blacked out several thousand customers in Fairfield County early yesterday, the Connecticut Light and Power Company reported. A spokesman said the communities were Wilton, Norwalk, New Canaan and Westport. Lightning struck a number of transformers and in Westport, a falling tree tore down electric wires.
