description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 28 (UPI)Two State Department officials said they had a clearly constructive discussion today with President Julius K. Nyerere on southern Africa. Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs William D. Rogers and Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs William E. Schaufele Jr. met with President Nyerere at his home outside Dar Es Salaam.

title: ARMADILLO BALKS LEPROSY STUDIES
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28  The World Health Organization's fight against leprosy is being impeded by the refusal of the armadillo, the small animal with a selfgrown coat of armor, to breed in captivity.

title: Shutting of Nuclear Plants Asked for Study of Waste
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP)  An environmental coalition has asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to shut down all atomic generating stations in Pennsylvania and four in New Jersey while the problem of nuclear waste disposal is studied. The Environmental Coalition on Nuclear Power asked for the moratorium Thursday in Washington.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The best thing to take into a movie is nothing. A sweater for the airconditioning; glasses if they are needed for seeing, and possibly dark glasses for looking attentive while asleep. What is of very little use, and usually harmful, is anticipation. It has ruined any number of movies for people who have gone depending on enthusiastic reviews, word of mouth or a previous happy experience with something made by the same director or with the same actor. If any attitude is to be carried in past the box office, it should be foreboding.

title: Results in British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: How to Trip Up Thieves on a Trip
description: In 1775 an anonymous observer of social conditions penned a plaintive verse for The Pennsylvania Gazette: Lost is our old simplicity of times; the world abounds with laws, and teems with crimes. Two hundred years later the situation has hardly improvedespecially for travelers. They fall prey to burglars and sneak thieves when they leave their homes vacant, their automobiles unattended, their hotel or motel rooms unoccupied and their baggage unguarded. They can, of course, guard against large financial loss from burglary or theft by carrying traveler's checks and having some form of insurance protection a homeowner's or tenant's policy, a travel policy, baggage insurance or individual riders on jewelry, furs and camerasbut these will not compensate for the inconvenience suffered. MEL MANDELL is the author of Being Safe and The Handbook of Business and Industrial Security.

title: Plea Entered in Chessie Case
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 2S (UPI) Ashby Leach, the decorated Vietnam veteran who held 10 persons hostage at gunpoint for nine hours Thursday on the 36th floor of the Chessle Railroad system tower, pleaded not guilty today to charges of kidnapping, extortion and felonious assault before Judge James Mulcahy in Cleveland Municipal Court. Bond was set at $450,000. Mr. Leach, 30 years old, of Huntington, W. Va., was expected to face a psychiatric examination.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: It came to be known as the infamous Polk County pot plane, the fourengine DC4 cargo plane that landed on an August night last year in the piney woods outside Cedartown. Ga., carrying 3,200 pounds of marijuana and 85 kilo bricks of hashish. The criminal case appeared simple enough, and it did not take long to round up 14 suspects.

title: 2 AIR FORCE JETS CRASH, KILLING 39
description: Two giant United States Air Force StarLifter transport planes, both attached to an airlift wing based in New Jersey, crashed in separate accidents yesterday while trying to land in Britain and Greenland. At least 39 of the 45 persons aboard were killed.

title: POLITICS
description: AT a time when his neighbor, Edwin M. Schwenk, the Suffolk Republican chairman, is publicly agonizing over Whether to attempt to retain his county leadership, Joseph M. Margiotta, probably the most powerful man in Nassau County today, is expanding his political horizon.

title: Pro Football Preview: TV Curb Is Sought
description: This largess may be coming to an end. What happens in the National Football League's 57th season, which begins in two weeks, will help to determine if pro football need force fans into the stadiums, where ticket prices average $11, by curbing television; or give way to increased television for income purposes with the prospect of stadiums becoming studios.

title: Yachting Results
description: AT GREENWICH COVE R.A.

title: Fairest of the Fowl
description: THE wind birds are back. Flocks of sanderlings, heading west, skim over the surf. Back behind the dunes, plovers, sandpipers, curlews, godwits, yellowlegs, oystercatchers, turnstones and skimmers congregate on the mudflats and make Suffolk County in late August and early September a mecca for birdwatchers.

title: Getting a Fix on Fall Books
description: Though we may still be jellied in August torpor, publishers' thoughts have already turned avidly to fall. The fall publishing season stretches from early September through the first December slush, or, in the publishing calendar, that span of time between the summer doldrums and the Christmas dollars.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Whatever the course of the 197677 music season, nothing is going to eclipse in excitement the opening two weeks. At best, visiting opera companies are a scarce commodity. Think of the expense! But the impossible has happened. Two, of the major opera companies in the world are making a simultaneous visit to the United States, both for the first time.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Casino Gambling: Other Side of the Coin

title: CTI Offers Jazz at Schaefer Festival
description: CTI, the record company directed by the veteran producr Creed Taylor, presented the first of two evenings of summer jazz on Friday at the Schaefer Festival in Central Park. Rain began to pour down just when the concert was getting under way, filling the concrete Wollman Rink with water, but the musicians played on and the large crowd stayed and listened.

title: American Conference: Dolphins Primed for a Return to Playoffs
description: The Dolphins missed the playoffs last year, the first time in Don Shula's six seasons as coach, but by how much? By margin of a field goal in overtime to the Colts with a third stringer, Don Struck, at quarterback. The wonlost record, 104, was the same as Baltimore's but the Colts beat Miami twice to break the tie and win the division.

title: The Thirteenth Tribe
description: The Khazar Empire and Its Heritage. By Arthur Koestler. 255 pp. New York: Random House. $8.95.

title: Farm Wages Up 10.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI)Wages for hired farm workers last month were up 10.5 percent froth a year ago. The Agriculture Department's crop reporting board said a survey in the week ended July 17 showed wages averaged $2.53 an hour compared with $2.29 a year earlier. The survey showed 5.474 million people working on farms last month, down 1 percent from a year earlier. The number of hired farm workers employed last month Was estimated at 2.091 million, up 5 percent from a year earlier.

title: Albany Says It Can't Determine Effect of Federal Funds It Spent
description: ALBANY, Aug. 28 (AP)The state's budget director knows how he spent $237 million in Federal revenuesharing funds. But he says it is impossible to determine what effect those funds had.

title: MISSISSIPPI EXAIDE IS INDICTED IN THEFT
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 28E. L. Boteler Jr., who resigned as state highway director on July 23, has been indicted by a grand jury and charged with embezzling $200,000 in highway funds.

description: FOR years, oldtimers on Long Beach Island have been talking about treasure somewhere out there in the offshore waters of the Ocean County resort. They remind skeptics that Captain Kidd once plied the coast, and they retell over driftwood fires the story of the curious affair at the Egg Harbor LifeSaving Station.

Koch of Manhattan and S. Stanley Kreutzer, counsel to the city's Board of Ethics.

description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, hoping to turn a recent winning spurt into a fullfledged drive to the top of the National League's Western Division, hardly behaved like a contending team yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: John Handy Plays With Electric Band At the Bottom Line
description: Riding on the momentum of a hit record, Hard Work, John Handy, the alto saxophonist, is making his first appearance in New York in eight years at the Bottom Line through tonight.

title: PEOPLE
description: The word got around fast about the nature of a new course that Dr. Bernard Reiner plans to teach this fall at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Rutherford, and the demand for the class was so intense that it had to be moved from a classroom to a large lecture hall. The course is Sports in America as Social History, and Dr. Reiner, a former sportscaster and basketball coach turned historian, will seek prove baseball, football, boxing and other sports are keys to learning American history. Warming to his subject, Dr. Reiner said recently: Sports have signaled the trend in politics and indicated the shifts in economic and population growth. Sports have been a barometer of the times. And so, is there some hidden meaning in the fact that President Ford was a football star? Or that Jimmy Carter plays softball? Perhaps Dr. Reiner will tell.

title: Weddings
description: FriedmanSacks

title: Synthesis of Working Gene Hailed as a Major Advance
description: Leading genetics researchers hailed yesterday news of the first synthesis of a complete and functioning gene as a significant step toward understanding how these basic units of heredity regulate themselves to influence the health or illness of organisms.

title: Poll Shows Bernhard Is Still Liked by Dutch
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 28 (AP) Dutch television said today a poll indicated that the Lockheed scandal had not changed the high regard in which the Dutch people hold Prince Bernhard, but that most felt the Queen's husband should no longer perform official functions.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: For the next two weekends, some firstrate tennis instruction will be available right in your home.

title: Archeologists Raise 1700's Sailing Ship In S. Carolina River
description: OATLAND, S.C., Aug. 28 (UPI)Archeologists raised a Colonial merchant sailing ship from the Black River today, the oldest vessel ever salvaged intact in the Western Hemisphere.

title: PEOPLE
description: The 10member governing body for the State University at Stony Brook has two new members. Under his authority to appoint nine of the members of the body known as the Stony Brook Council (one nonvoting member is elected by the students, Governor Carey has named Dr. R. Christian Anderson to the post of chairman and has appointed Andrew E. Ullman a member of the council. Dr. Anderson, who is assistant director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, makes his home in Brookhaven. He succeeds George P. Tobler of Smithtown as the council chairman. Mr. Ullman, a lawyer In Northport, makes his home in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: Local Courses For Green Thumbs
description: School bells will ring for gardeners this fall when botanic gardens, arboretums and garden centers begin noncredit courses in adult education programs. Subjects will range from growing house plants to paleobotany. Registration is in advance and fees vary with the number of classes amd materials necessary. Reduced course fees are usually available for those who are members of the sponsoring organization.

title: ART

Like the madeleine cookie, whose taste prompted Marcel Proust to reconstruct his youth in a magnificent literary work, the carrousel sparks remembrances too  of carnivals, midways, sideshows, trained animals and succulent sweets.

title: Paperbacks
description: GEORGE SAND, by Curtis Cate. (Avon, $2.75.) A masterful reconstruction, by an American, of the life of the 19thcentury French writer whose long, romanticgothic career now seems more interesting than her fiction.

description: Lawrence Sanders's new book, THE TANGENT OBJECTIVE (Putnam's, $8.95), has one of those titles that can mean anything, though usually it has connotations of espionage. In this case, however, the title refers only to the name of the leading character, one Peter Tangent, an oil company executive who specializes in Africa.

title: Summer Bowing Out On a Festive Note
description: TWILIGHT now comes earlier and school bells will soon ring, both signs that summer is getting ready to fade into its last long weekend. The traditional threeday Labor Day holiday is just a flip of the calendar away, and happy hours spent at the state's beaches, lakes and campsites will become just a memory, at least until next

title: Agency Calls Gains In Cigarette Output Lowest in 14 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI)  The production of cigarettes worldwide is still growing this year, but health concerns and cost factors are holding the growth rate to the lowest in 14 years, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: Architecting the Parks
description: FOR the first time in several decades, architects are playing a major role in the development and construction of small parks in many North Jersey communities.

title: MAX ROSENBERG
description: Max Rosenberg, a former New York City attorney who specialized in immigration matters, died yesterday at the age of 82.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: My bedroom closet is directly over the laundry roots in my unfinished basement so the closet smells damp and develops mildew when the door is kept closed. The basement is damp, especially the floor, but I don't want to improve the basement. Is there a way of lining the closet to be impervious to the moisture coming up from the basement below? Mrs. J. V., Great Neck, N.Y.

title: P.L.O. GIVES CALL FOR MOBILIZATION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 28The Palestine Liberation Organizaton announced today that it was ordering general conscription of all Palestinians between the ages of 18 and 30

title: Miss Tillinghast to Wed

title: Where the 14 DriveIns Are
description: Admission to all but one of the 14 driveins on the Island is $2.50 per person and children under 12 are admitted tree. The exception is the Smithtown AllWeather Drivein in Nesconset, where the price is $3 per car, no matter how many passengers are jammed inside.

title: Deborah Dodenhoff Wed to Lawyer
description: Deborah Anne Dodenhoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Dodenhoff of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to John Cullen Purcell, a widower and son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Purcell, also of Scarsdale.

title: Where Are Today's MastersAnd Tomorrow's?
description: EVERY season in the arts brings high hopes of spectacular achievement and stunning discovery  the hope, above all else, of the big, transfiguring experience that sweeps everything else in its path and leaves us, exhilarated and even a little dazed, looking at the surrounding scene with new eves. For the experience of art, the experience of all the arts, is dynamic, refusing to remain fixed or at rest. There is a reason, after all, why we speak of movements in the arts. The life of art, like life itself, grows, develops, declines, renews itself, and continues, whether for good effect or bad, on its headlong course. It is constantly producing new offspring  some legitimate, some not; some of mysterious parentage, some stillbornand it is the energy of the effort, the sheer momentum of creative possibility and production, that engages and bedazzles and even exhausts us before we pause to consider what it is, indeed, that has elicited this eager and untrammeled response.

title: Dr. Helen Smits Becomes Bride
description: Dr. Helen L. Smits, associate administrator of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, was married at noon yesterday to Roger B. Le Compte, executive assistant to the president of the Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: LAST spring, I visited four of the public schools I had attended while growing up in Newark. I walked in off the street, unknown and unchallenged by either security guards or teachers, and simply wandered about, peeking into classrooms. My former teachers (we didn't need security guards) either were dead or retired, and knew me.

title: Captives of melodrama
description: After years of insisting that they don't influence events but merely hold a mirror to them, television newsmen are beginning to show a new candor about their role in the political process. Consider, for example, what Roger Mudd had to say last Jan. 19 on the CBS Evening News in the course of discussing the results that would be forthcoming from the caucuses being held throughout Iowa that day:

title: L.P.G.A. Changes Are for the Better
description: A year has passed since the Ladies' Professional Golf Association underwent a major remodeling process. The reorganization has taken the form of a new executive structure working out of a new location. A commissioner, Ray Volpe, was appointed to succeed the executive division, made up of players from the tour, which had previously governed the L.P.G.A. The association headquarters was moved from Atlanta to New York.

title: Environment
description: The town of Ramapo, N.Y., and the city of Petaluma, Calif., are destined to be remembered as early cases in what is likely to he a protracted legal war over the power of municipalities to regulate their growth. The outcome of the controversy may significantly influence patterns of residential development throughout the United States.

description: DURING a time of continuing public attention on the increasing cost to taxpayers of Congressional junketing, the Long Island delegation is going the other waysaving money by staying home.

description: 1976, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Dally Racing Form)

title: An eye for color
description: Ronnie Gold has been aware of color and design for as long as she can remember. They were the focus of her studies at New York's High School of Art and Design in the early 60's and later at the University of Colorado, where she majored in fine arts. She's also always loved beautiful clothers. Now 28 and a New York fabric designer (at Galleon Fabrics, which designs for sportswear houses like John Meyer and Bobbie Brooks), she still wears the classic clothes she wore even in high school, when everyone else was wearing bluejeans. Aline skirts, wool pants, Shetland sweaters (she owns about 30) fill many a closet, of course, but because of her eye for color and design Ronnie's look exceptional.

title: Joe McCarthy Remembers
description: The telephone rang the other day in a house in Tonawanda in upstate New York, and 89yearold Joe McCarthy answered it and said: I'm pulling for them. Once a Yankee, always a Yankee.

title: Karpov and Fischer Meet To Discuss a Title Match
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and his American predecessor, Bobby Ficher, met secretly in Cordoba, Spain, last week to resume discussions for a possible title match. They began talks about a match in Tokyo a month ago.

title: Bedding Down in the Outskirts
description: LONDON  The advertisement for the Cunard International Hotel here begins 644 twinbedded, airconditioned rooms with private bath. Restaurants, coffee shops, bars, meeting rooms, discotheque. Complimentary bus service to the Piccadilly area ...

title: The World
description: Jacques Chirac, long at odds with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, has resigned as France's Prime Minister and been replaced by economist Raymond Barre. The immediate effects of the change are political, and can be dealt with; the longrange effects may prove more significant because they involve whether the staggering French economy can be repaired and whether the French Constitution can work when the President and the Parliament are at odds.

title: Barry Stewart Married To David Richard Grace
description: Barry Martin Stewart, daughter of Mrs. William H. Osborn Jr. of Glen Head, L.L, and James Stewart of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to David Richard Grace, son of Mrs. David Ralph Grace of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Mr. Grace.

title: The Circus Is Coming! The Circus Is Coming!
description: CELIA GUIDA stays in town only one day. But when she's gone, everyone knows that she's been there. If they don't, the 29yearold woman knows she hasn't done her job.

title: Sexpionage
description: The apparent purpose of this skimpy little book is to warn patriots not to look for Reds under the bed but in it. According to David Lewis. those with access to information of interest to the Soviet Union now stand in serious danger of seduction by stunningly beautiful K.G.B. agents trained to please in, all the erotic arts, no matter how perverse. Furthermore, resistance is useless. Using mindbending drugs if necessary, the agents have ways of pulping the sternest moral fiber into helpless concupiscence, so that the victims of this Russian badger game may not even realize what has happened to them until presented next morning with a set of compromising photographs and an invitation to cooperatethe alternative being a free delivery service of prints to wives (or husbands), employers and appropriate government security agencies.

title: Miss Reynolds Wed To S. M. Hinckley
description: Elizabeth Tyler Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Reynolds 3d of Middletown, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Stephen Mark Hinckley, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles T. Hinckley of Hardwick, Mass.

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (UPJ)Only now is the full story emerging of the great Teddy Bear Caper at Crocker National Bank, but it carries a message for those who would mix bears, money, children, depositors, tellers and bank vice presidents.

description: PEKING, Aug. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)  One month after the earthquake that devastated Tangshan, 100 miles east of Peking, the capital itself has become a giant building site and is concentrating its efforts on speedy reconstruction of the dwellings that were damaged or destroyed.

The pride of Detroit's new trolley fleet will be No. 247, an open car with clanging bell and jouncing ride that was discovered in Portugal and has been restored by a group of Long Island experts and craftsmen.

title: Amending the Law of the Sea
description: THE United States Congress is beginning to make waves in the fishing industry. It recently approved a bill extending to 200 miles the country's territorial waters to control foreign fishing fleets. And the Senate has begun an extensive study, called the Eastland Fisheries Survey, to gather advice from recreational and commercial fishermen and to apply it toward the formation of a national policy on fishing.

title: Answers/Questions
description: BROWNED IVY [Aug. 15] A: M.F., Manhattan, noted that the English ivy planted around the base of their street trees has turned brown around the edges. She asked why this is happening and what to do about it. The browning the ivy leaf edges could be caused by: dogs; residue in soil from salt used on sidewalks to melt winter ice; pollution from street traffic. Adequate watering during dry spells to help flush soil and rinse foliage plus application of a high nitrogen fertilizer are two possible remedies. Ed.

title: LIMITS ON APLANTS FACING LAWSUITS
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28Legal problems are plaguing both proponents and opponents of proposals on atomicpower restrictions that will be on the ballots of as many as six states in November.

description: Along with scores of special and super programs, the three networks will be introducing a total of 25 new weekly series, most of which will make their debut during the week of Sept. 19. These new series are:

title: The Bicentennial Spectacular Didn't Hurt
description: Like a modern day Lazarus, Mayor Beame seems to be emerging from one of the worst years in New York's history as if the city had not narrowly avoided bankruptcy, had not laid off, or frozen the wages of, tens of thousands of city workers, had not drastically cut services, and as if he himself had not been forced to surrender much of his power to a statedominated Emergency Financial Control Board.

I also need response from political prisoners who have served in any kind of prison environment.

title: Splashy Backyard Accessories
description: AFLAGSTONE and herringbone  patterned brick path winds through the yard past the octagonshaped fountaincomplete with statue and birdbathtoward an azure, teardrop shaped swimming pool. A waterfall pours into the pool from a second, smaller one nearby. Exotic shrubs, bushes and bonsai trees at the pools' edges cast shadows on the deep blue water. Pink stone benches line the brick, stone and pebble patios that surround the pools and an expanse of lush, green lawn stretches beyond toward a stand of trees.

title: Alisa Heyman Engaged
description: The engagement of Alisa Jo Heyman to Jay Soshnick has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Heyman of Woodmere, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Soshnick of Jamaica, Queens.

title: Disdain for Giscard
description: PARISWhen Valry Giscard d'Estaing decided to face down exPremier Jacques ChabanDelmas, in the spring of 1974, and to seek to become the French Fifth Republic's first nonGaullist President, the political hatchet man who chopped down ChabanDelmas's Gaullist base was Jacques Chirac.

title: In Cairo, Arab World's Sin City, a More Conservative Islamic Mood Is Apparent During Ramadan
description: CAIRO, Aug. 26The sheiks could not find the thin crescent of the new moon in the sky over Egypt Wednesday night. It was discerned over Saudi Arabia, however, so Sheik Mohammed Khater, the mufti of Egypt, ordered the firing of the cannon from the Citadel to signify the beginning of Ramadan.

title: A gunfight in the critics' corral
description: The more popular the art, the more ponderous the critical scholarship that attaches itself to it. This is not quite a sufficient rule, but as a rule of thumb it has its uses.

title: WEST SIDE ROAD IS MOVING AHEAD
description: The plan to begin dismantling a onemile section of the old elevated West Side Highway this fall has moved another important step toward receiving 90 percent Federal financing.

title: Food
description: People have always thought that lobster is too expensive. In 1885, The Lewiston (Me.) Evening Journal noted that fishermen were getting 10 cents a lobster, the public was paying only 10 to 12 cents a poundand people were still complaining about high prices. Right now, lobsters are as inexpensive ($4 a pound) and as plentiful as they will probably be for the rest of the year. Hence, a pair of lobster disheslobster in cognac and cream sauce and lobster with tomatoes and tarragon, the latter to be served with spaghetti.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE woman on the telephone said: Oh, we don't take reservations. That could mean one of two things: Plenty of room or so much business that reservations were meaningless. Alas, the second turned nut to be true.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: Passaic River: It's No Wonder of the World, but
description: IT CANNOT be said that the Passaic River touches all of our lives, but it certainly can be said that it touches a lot of our state. Statistically, it even isn't one of the wonders of the world. The atlas published by the Encyclopaedia Britannica contains a list of the longest rivers on earth; a total of 179 are named, but not the Passaic.

title: Miss Sullivan Wed To James Brundige
description: Mary Susan Sullivan and James Worthington Brundige, graduates of Vassar College, were married yesterday afternoon in Summit, N. J. The Rev. Robert V. Morris performed the ceremony in Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: What's Behind Those BillionDollar Oil Lease Bids?
description: Sixty of the nation's largest oil companies got the word last week on who had won the kitty in the latest hand in the multibilliondollar poker game otherwise known as looking for oil.

title: The Secret of a Boxing Knockout as Expounded by a Belgian With a Strong Neck
description: With all the controversy about brain damage in boxing, nobody seems to have actually found out what causes a knockout.

title: Judging a Buyer by His Book
description: THREE highschool girls huddle between the poetry rack and the Gothics in the back of the bookstore, trying not to gawk at Dustin Hoffman. The actor, who is being waited on at the counter, has come to pick up an order of books for movie research.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Do the Democrats have an economic issue? The public opinion polls indicate that economic problems head the list of voter concerns. At the same time they point to more interest on the part of voters in the character of the candidates than in their specific stands on issues or programs. Also, we are told that voters, particularly the younger voters and the liberal voters, perceive the economic questions not only to embrace growth, jobs and income but also to include urban problems, the environment and resource conservation. Finally, there are some indications that more austerity in public finance is becoming fashionable, especially among the liberal establishment.

title: Diane Weiner Is Bride
description: Diane Ellen Weiner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest M. Weiner of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Gary D. Hirsch, son of Mrs. Benjamin Hirsch of New York and the late Mr. Hirsch. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

title: Miss Darragh Wed To Glenn Williams
description: Norma Kathleen Darragh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gerald Darragh of Chappaqua, N. Y., was married there yesterday morning to Glenn Douglas Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey W. Williams of Smithtown, L.I.

title: A master of science fictionand more
description: Stanislaw Lem is a Polish writer of science fiction in both traditional and original modes. Seven of his books have been published here since 1970, mostly by The Seabury Press, in small printings, and his reputation has been slow in developing. Elsewhere in the world his books sell in the millions, and he is regarded as a giant not only of science fiction but also of Eastern European literatureas well he should be. Lem is both a polymath and a virtuoso storyteller and stylist. Put them together and they add up to genius.

title: The Arts in America: Optimism Tempered by Need
description: AS a nation, we have just started our third century. As people, we naturally go back the full evolutionary cycle to the first binary fission of that originally adventurous amoeba. Our ethnic patterns include everything, yet contain nothing. We are a melting pot that never melted into anything more substantial than anger; yet, our ethnic and racial strains, the pioneer spirit of a new civilization taking over, sometimes cruelly, often by force and genocide, an underpopulated continent, and a fundamentalist belief in a new world in which anything was possible, will always color the American view of life, whether we came here to better ourselves or whether we came here as slaves.

title: Joyce Smith, ExTV Producer, Wed to William Peters, Lawyer
description: Sheila Joyce Smith, who received a master's degree in education in June from Harvard University, was married yesterday afternoon in Greens Farms, Conn., to William R. Peters, an associate with the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell.

title: Picture Credits
description: 17ILLUSTRATIONS BY CHRISTIAN PIPER, PHOTOGRAPHS BY ANDREW J. SCHNEIDER

title: John Odden to Wed Jennifer Swan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. C. Swan Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Pickells Swan, to John Hansen Odden, son of the late Dr, and Mrs. Loren Hansen Odden of Princeton, N.J.

title: Mexican Consul Is Robbed
description: The Mexican consul and his wife were assaulted and robbed at 4:30 A.M. yesterday in New York City by three women who escaped with $40 and miscellaneous papers, the police said. The robbery occurred on 48th Street between Madison and Park Avenues. The consul, Carlos Walter, and his wife, Gloria, told the police they had suffered certain injuries but they refused medical attention.

title: Dole Samples Life as a Running Mate
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 28The long campaign trail to November began to unwind this week in front of Senator Robert J. Dole.

title: WORKERS ARE SET TO GO TO HOFSTRA
description: Sam Jerr Katz, a 63yearold worker at Gotham Knitting Mills in Queens, is getting ready to go to college next month.

title: ECONOMIC THREATS PREOCCUPY SPAIN
description: MADRID, Aug. 28Economic unrest spurred by continued business recession, unemployment and inflation is posing such a threat to plans for peaceful political change that the Government has devoted three successive Cabinet sessions to relief measures.

title: College Football Preview: Battle of Runners
description: Step by step and yard by yard, the runs of Ricky Bell and Tony Dorsett will be carefully catalogued and compared during the 108th college football season that starts this week with a smattering of games.

title: A $5 Million Pebble, A Mahler Festival And Operas Galore
description: On the evening of Oct. 19 a $5 million pebble will be dropped into the murky pond that is the current New York musical scene. That is the night when the New York Philharmonic plays its first concert in a drastically remodeled Avery Fisher Hall. The event is certain to make ripples if not waves that will affect our musical life for many years, and not much else promised for the coming seasor can compare with the Fisher Hall drama for suspense or longrange significance. The man in the spotlightand on the spotis Cyril M. Harris, the acoustical expert who was given virtual carte blanche and $5 million of Avery Fisher's money repair the sound of the hall that since its opening in 1962 has been an embarrassjog blemish on Lincoln Center's haughty face. The event is certain to make ripples if not waves that will affect our musical life for many years, and not much else promised for the coming seasor can compare with the Fisher Hall drama for suspense or longrange significance. The man in the spotlightand on the spotis Cyril M. Harris, the acoustical expert who was given virtual carte blanche and $5 million of Avery Fisher's money repair the sound of the hall that since its opening in 1962 has been an embarrassjog blemish on Lincoln Center's haughty face.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today Nassau County, C. W. Post College show grounds, Northern Boulevard, Brookville, L.I. Grand prix for jumpers, amateurowner hunters, ponies. 2:30 P.M.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Address by Rabbi Edgar F. Magnin.

title: Veto Battle Ahead
description: Early agreement can also be expected from a conference committee on the exact size of an approximately $3.5 billion appropriation to finance a public works program by state and local governments. President Ford vetoed the authorization for this program but Congress passed it over his veto. Mr. Ford is likely to reject this bill when it reaches him, but Congressional Democrats are confident that they will again override.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: With the Bicentennial, we are beginning to look at this country with a mix of perspective and poignancy; the New World grows old, and so do its cities, plans and dreams. The raw frontier town has become the decaying urban core, its one lasting amenity often the public park set aside in forgotten battles a century ago.

title: Who's Who at the Page One Party
description: 1. Liza Minnelli

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AROUND of golf in the very early morning is always a special challenge, with both nature and the golfer himself compounding the difficulties. Hands feel thick on the grips, fingers stubby and insensitive. The course plays long, as golfers say, for the grass is slow in the morning dew and the air is heavy with moisture.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SOMEBODY's been stepping on the gold bugs. In 197374, the bugs ran wild, when world economies were ravaged simultaneously by steep inflation and deep recession. In those days, the purchase of gold (and goldmining stocks) gave a sense of security to people whose worries ranged from the mere cost of living to the collapse of capitalist society. The price of gold, reflecting those fears, rose to almost $200 an ounce. This was nearly six times the fixed price of $35 that long anchored the world monetary system.

title: Debts Worrying Idled Rubber Workers As Unexpectedly Long Strike Nears End
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 28When the 60,000 members of the United Rubber Workers union struck the nation's major tire and rubber makers, most people here expected to see an enthusiastic strike of four to six weeks, then back to work.

title: Government in Peru Stepping Up Its Efforts to Halt Subversion and Increase Production
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 28 (AP)The military Government of Peru is stepping up efforts to halt subversive activity, increase production and stimulate the revolution it began eight years ago.

title: 2d Harlem Day Festival Stresses the Positive
description: Hoping to focus attention on the positive things within Harlem, the community held its second annual Harlem Day Festival yesterday.

title: Ferrari Boycott Is Ending In Dutch Grand Prix Today
description: Today's Dutch Grand Prix will end Ferrari's onerace boycott of the Formula One circuit, even though earlier this month it said it was finished for the remainder of 1976 because of appeal rulings unfavorable t to the Italian Marque. The real problem, though, according to various reports, was that Ferrari was unable to find a frontline pilot to take the place of its injured star, Niki Lauda of Austria.

title: For Mexican Food at Home, Just Yell  XIK!
description: WHEN Kathleen Haven caters a dinner, it is seasoned not only with exotic spices but also with the fruits of careful research. Her specialties are the foods of Mexico, South America and southeast Asia, which she has sampled on location during travels with her husband, Douglas Newton, director of the Museum of Primitive Art in New York. She has also studied with experts on Mexican cookery, including Diana Kennedy.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  CorvaIr Society of America concours judging at Interlaken Inn, Lakeville, Conn. 11 A.M.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment to require the Postal Service to give 60 days notice before closing a post office, which passed, 60 to 13, Aug. 23.

title: CORRECTION
description: The calendar of forthcoming cabaret events on page 15 of today's Arts and Leisure Section lists the start of the Broadway songwriters series at the Ballroom, 458 West Broadway, as Sept. 13. The series has been postponed to Oct. 5.

title: College Football: Pitt, Maryland and Michigan Teams to Watch
description: Joe Paterno has never looked over his shoulder to see who is catching up. His Penn State Nittany Lions have been supreme in the East for eight of his 10 years as their coach. But maybe this time Paterno will see someone catch up and pass him in the East.

title: Working With Wood Moldings
description: Although most people are familiar with how wood moldings are used for finishing joints around window and door frames, joints where walls and ceilings meet, and joints where walls meet windows, doors, floors and other builtins, many do not realize the possibilities inherent in using moldings to change the appearance of many otherwise flat and dull looking surfaces, or add a decorative finishing touch to various home remodeling and building projects.

title: AMERICAN PARTY COMPLETES TICKET
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28  The American Independent Party, rebuffing efforts to modernize its conservative image, completed a ticket today of Lester G. Maddox, the former Governor of Georgia, and William E. Dyke, a onetime Mayor of Madison, Wis., and Republican nominee for the Wisconsin Governor's office in 1974. The two men will run tor President and Vice President on party themes of segregation, isolationism and repeal of big government.

title: Residents Protesting Noise At Site of Nuclear Plant
description: SEABROOK, N.H., Aug. 28 (AP)Besides the controversy about building a nuclear power plant here, residents are disturbed by the construction noise.

title: DINING OUT
description: A GREAT deal happens between Brooklyn and Great Neck. The suburban branch of this venerable old establishment was a disappointment. Admittedly, we had not visited the original, near the Williamsburg Bridge, in a number of years. Perhaps both have become standardized. In any event, Great Neck is our terrain, Williamsbure is not, and here we are on Northern Boulevard.

title: Diane Sharkey Bride Of T. A. Crowley Jr.
description: Diane Elizabeth Sharkey, the compensation manager with Salomon Brothers, investment bankers, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Aloysius Crowley Jr., a product manager in the marketing division of Becton, Dickinson & Company of Rutherford, N.J., manufacturer of healthcare products.

title: The Potential for AllOut Conflict Is Great
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaFrom the Western Mediterranean to the Red Sea to the Cape of Good Hope, a triangle that virtually encompasses the entire African continent, armed conflict and the threat of conflict are sapping natural and human resources, costing billions of dollars and deterring essential economic and political development. What, then is the current state of these conflicts throughout Africa, what are the reasons for the disputes and what does the future forebode?

title: On the College Trail
description: FOR the fourth consecutive year more young women than young men among last June's New Jersey's highschool graduates are planning to continue their education in the fall.

title: STRIKE BY 22,000 ENDS AT GOODYEAR
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 28A 130  day strike against the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire manufacturer, by 22 000 members of the United Rubber Workers of America ended this afternoon.

title: Eyes on New York
description: Strictly city sportswear: softly bloused tops and tailored wool pants by The Beene Bag. Refined sweatshirt, left, in ribbed jersey tweed, $84: herringbone  tweed pants, $102; howtie shirt, $70. Designer Sportswear third floor, Bergdorf Goodman. Pullover sweater, right, with pouch pocket, in handknitted wool, $108: pants, $92; shirt, $70. Studio 111 third floor, Altman's. Tweed caps, Brooks Brothers. String and leather shopping hag, Roots. Binoculars, Abercrombie & Fitch.

title: Edwin Gilbert, 69, Scriptwriter, Dramatist and Novelist, Is Dead
description: Edwin Gilbert, a writer whose versatility brought him commercial success as a dramatist, scriptwriter and novelist, died Tuesday at his home in Cannes, France. He was 69 years old.

title: Dorothy Daly Wed to Dr. John Van Dam
description: Dorothy Ann Daly, daughter of Dorothy Bird Daly of Washington and Wainscott, L.I., and the late Charles Bernard Daly, was married yesterday afternoon in East Hampton, L.I., to Dr. John Nicholas Van Dam. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Culver Van Dam of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J.

title: J. K. Kelemen Weds Miss Crawford
description: Carol Louise Crawford and Jeffrey Kenneth Kelemen of South Deerfield, Mass., graduates of St. Lawrence University, were married yesterday afternoon in Moorestown, N. J. Mayor Jeffrey S. Brown of Merchantville, N. J., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Kelemen, parents of the bridegroom.

title: New Bernhard Portrait: Scheming and Indecisive
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 27 A new portrait emerges of Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands from the Government inquiry into allegations that he accepted bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. He is viewed, at different times, as petulant, weak, indecisive and scheming.

title: CULTURAL CENTER FOR PUEBLOS OPENED
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 28 The $2.3 million Indian Pueblo Cultural Center, designated by the leaders of the 19 pueblos in northern New Mexico as a showcase for their heritage and traditional arts and crafts, was dedicated and officially opened here today.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: To Decide As Individuals

title: Fire Kills 31 Horses at Ohio Track
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP)At least 31 standardhred horses were killed today in an early morning fire at Raceway Park. A spokesman for the track said the fire broke out at 5:30 A.M. and destroyed four of the 19 stables at the track. No track employees were injured, but several horses were still missing. The stables have facilities for up to 600 horses. The cause of the blaze has not yet been determined, and no damage estimate has been set.

title: The Invincible
description: Translated from the German by Wendayne Ackerman. A Continuum Book. 183 pp. New York: The Seabury Press. $6.95.

title: Managers Continue to Pick Up Stakes
description: The last thing I want to do right now is to move to another Godforsaken chemical plant in the middle of nowhere, complained the 32year old chemical engineer who's been told to move to a remote part of Wyoming.

title: FORMER LOBBYIST IN VILLAGE RACE
description: An Albany lobbyist who lost his job after the Assembly made him the subject of a rare resolution of disapproval last year is now trying to return to the Capitol with an unbreakable twoyear contractas an Assemblyman himself.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Watching the reporters take off in battalion strength for Plains, Ga., this summer to search for the roots of Jimmy Carter, I finally realized why I have always shrunk from running for President. Splendid though the honor would be, I wouldn't dream of subjecting my home crossroads to the indignities which necessarily occur when the press descends in force to do its sociological study of the candidate's roots.

title: Hopeful Is Taken By Banquet Table
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., Aug. 28C. V. Whitney's favored Banquet Table and his jockey, Jean Cruguet, had a profitable reunion today at the closing session of Saratoga's 24day meeting when they combined to capture the 72d running of the Hopeful Stakes.

title: Jersey Complex Opens Trot Track Wednesday
description: EAST RUTHERFORD N. J., Aug. 28Court battles have been won, swampland transformed, critics outflanked. The next sound you hear from New Jersey's $340 million Sports Complex will he the sound of cash registers.

title: An Alaskan Mayor Wins Democratic House Race
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 28 (AP)The tabulation of absentee and questioned ballots today gave Eben Hopson, the ailing Eskimo mayor of Alaska's vast North Slope borough, the Democratic primary nomination for the House of Representatives.

title: Campfire Girls Moving West
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 28 (AP)Directors of the national board of Campfire Girls Inc., have voted to move the organization's corporate hedquarters from New York to Kansas City, Mo. The supply division in New York and the national service center in Englewood, Colo., will also be relocated to Kansas City, the directors said. Clifton E. Woodcock of Detroit, chairman of the board, said it would be less expensive to operate headquarters in Kansas City than in New York. He added that travel time and money would be saved by having the headquarters in a more central location.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: A fashion connoisseur
description: According to Jane Griner. 34, she can look almost like a model if she wants to. Mostly she doesn't want to She was a model in the 60's, an Eileen Ford highfashion one, running off In Paris all the time to do the collections for French Vogue. Now she and her husband, Norman, a director of TV commercials, and their two daughters (5 and 7 time settled into their sixfloor Upper East Side town house, and life is a very familyoriented thing.

title: By ARI L. GOLDMAN
description: MASSAPEQUA FOR the first time since he came back from Vietnam eight years ago, Ron Kovic is at peace with himself, his community and with his country. The war robbed him of his youth. A bullet in his spinal cord meant that he would never play baseball again, never wrestle, never jump over fences, never run along the beach holding a girl's hand. Paralyzed from the chest down, he would never walk again.

title: Seoul Sentences Expected To Intimidate Park's Foes
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 28 Harsh prison sentences given today to 18 prominent South Koreans, including a former president of the country, an expresidential candidate, professors, priests and other clergymen, are expected to further intimidate the already badly weakened opposition to President Park Chung Hee.

title: SHOP TALK
description: FOR some people, setting the table is a chore; for others, it's simply a practical prologue to the daily meals. And then there are those for whom it's a creative challenge, a grand project of design and imagination.

title: Darnell StockCar Victor
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 28 (AP)Ray Darnell of Deerfield, Ill., took the lead on the 79th lap and won the 100mile national championship United States Auto Club stockcare race today on the mile dirt oval at the Du Quoin State Fairrounds. Darnell's time was 1 hour 4 minutes 58 seconds and his share of a $20,618 purse was $3,711.

title: Peace Restored at Disputed Portuguese Farm Estate Now Divided Between Workers and ExManager
description: ODEMIRA, PortugalThe 66yearold tenant farmer proudly showed visitors around his rice fields and said, We won our rights, but it had to be done by force.

title: The New Muckrakers
description: Ten years ago, with another New York Times reporter, I stood at a counter in the grimy Surrogate's Court of Manhattan reading through the handwritten volumes of wills probated in New York since the 17th century. The names of the deceased were recorded chronologically, in the order of the filing of their wills, and next to each name were two numbers. Finding those numbers was the essential first step in locating the public records of the courtapproved fees of courtappointed attorneys acting as guardians for minor and unknown heirs. The last stepin a search for politicallyfavored lawyers earning hundreds of thousands of dollars, sometimes with almost no workinvolved negotiations and formcompleting with an old, slow and surly man who would then disappear for hours at a time.

title: Rhodesia Shows Proof Raided Camp Housed Rebels
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 128The Government exhibited (today what it called irrefutalIble evidence that the Mozambican camp it raided on Aug. 8 was a guerrilla base and not a center for refugees.

title: Dole's I.T.T. Role Could Be Fall Target
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Robert J. Dole, the junior Senator from Kansas and former chairman of the Republican National Committee, survived the political devastation of the Watergate and I.T.T. affairs apparently unscathed.

title: PRAISE IS LEGACY FROM CONVENTION
description: New York City in Julyhospitable beautiful and exciting. That was virtually the unanimous opinion of 100 delegates to the Democratic National Convention in Madison Square Garden who took the time afterward to write Mayor Beame from all over the United States and from as far away as Hawaii.

title: Abandoned In Suffolk
description: SUFFOLK County conveys the promise of a good life to many who come to play in ocean and sound. They return to stake out their third of an acre, only to find that the good life is illusory.

title: Connors Is Eliminated By Ramirez
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 28 (AP)Raul Ramirez of Mexico snapped Jimmy Connors' 22match winning streak tonight by beating the topseeded player, 63, 3.6, 63, in the quarterfinals of the United States pro tennis championships at Lonrwood.

title: The WouldBe Governors
description: ALTHOUGH the primaries are still many months away, some nine or 10 possible candidates for Governor are already in sight. They're like robins lined up on telephone lines, waiting to see who takes to the wing first. This is likely to be a 43yearold Democrat, Joseph A. Hoffman, the state's Commissioner of Labor and Industry; he's kept it no secret that he will be a candidate, even if his boss, Governor Byrne, decides to try for a second term.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Salaries for lawyers starting in on the bottom rung of New York's top law firms have just rolled up to a new level. The going rate for associatesthe current title for what used to be called law clerksis now $25,000 a year at the leading Wall Street and midtown firms. This represents an increase of about $2,500 from the salaries of last year's recruits.

title: GOLDIN CRITICIZES PURCHASING RULES
description: New York City's purchasing practices were criticized yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who urged that a longer period of time be allowed between submission of bids and delivery of goods or services to encourage more vendors to compete for city contracts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Style
description: Soon the summer crowds will have left, and history buffs following a locally laid out walking tour in Cape May County, N.J., can pause before Stop 5 and reflect. The building is in North Wildwood, just down the street from the ocean. Officially, it is Cape May Fire Control Station 23, having been built by the United States Army Corps of Engineers for submarine detection during World War II.

title: Design
description: The essence of porches, or verandas, is that they at once enclose and do not enclose. They provide protection from the elements and yet are open to them; their occupants are inside and yet arc also outside. It is this sense of being able to have it both ways that has made the porch a feature common throughout the history of architecture in circumstances ranging from the grandeur of palace porticoes to the modesty of tiny verandas attached to country cottages.

title: Broadway Will Be Booming With Drama
description: The new theater season should be profitable for producers. It may be rewarding for theatergoers. It will be expensive for everybody. Much of the season will be familiar; some of it may even be exciting.

title: Some Theatrical Highlights
description: For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/ When the Rainbow is Enuf by Ntozake Shange. Booth, Sept. 15.

title: Soviet Lofts 3 Satellites
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28 (UPI)The Soviet Union has launched! three artificial earth satellites of its Cosmos series in three days to carry out space research, the official press agency Tass said today.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Ann Clark Married to George Sherwood
description: Ann Adams Clark, an assistant in research at Yale University's Medical School, and George Bradford Sherwood, a Ph.D. candidate in physics at Yale, were married yesterday afternoon in Cooperstown, N.Y. The Rev. John Sise performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. Mr. and Mrs. Bernard E. Clark of Cooperstown are the parents of the bride, and Mr. and Mrs. John H. Sherwood of Columbia, S.C., are the parents of the bridegroom.

title: Out on the town
description: To get in on the act with rock singer Elliott Murphy at The Bottom Line, the thing to wear is a sweatery tunic over silky pants or a shirt. The black cashmere sweater and red crepe de chine shirt by Stephen Burrows, $150. Boutique. second floor, Martin's. The bareback halter in a woolandrabbithair blend with blue crepe de chine pants by Concept VII, $150. Designer Shop, third floor, Altman's. Shoes, Goody Two Shoes. When the limousine breaks down, the thing to do is take a doughnutandcoffee break. The party will wait for the glamour girls. Their softly bloused dresses by Oscar de la Renta. Yellow hammered satin with slit skirt, $1,100. Al Elizabeth Arden Salon, end of next month. Cuff bracelet by Eva Graham. Satinstriped violet chiffon with sewnon rhinestone necklace. $700. Designer Shop third floor. Altman's, end of next month. Bracelets, P. C. Designs. Man's dinner suit by Polo.

title: On the Cabaret and Jazz Agenda
description: CABARETS

title: Shaky House of Orange
description: THE HAGUEIt began in the early 1960's when Lockheed Aircraft Corporation offered a Jetstar to Prince Bernhard to cement the company's ties in the Netherlands. It developed when the Germanborn Prince received $100,000, and possibly far more, to spend on unnamed acquaintances. It reached a peak two years ago when the Prince, in a handwritten letter to Lockheed officials, said that after a hell of a lot of pushing and pulling, it now seemed as if the Dutch Government was about to buy some Lockheed antisubmarine aircraft, and it might be a good idea if he worked as an agent, on a percentage basis, for Lockheed. The Prince suggested an initia?? commission of $1 million, ostensibly for the World Wildlife Fund, which he founded.

title: Awards Givers Are Running Low On New Work
description: Imagine a drama critic without plays to review. Or a movie critic without films. Or a dance critic without ballets. Or an architectural awards jury without new building projects.

title: Eyes on New York
description: The fashion spirit of '76 rings out loud and clear. Sportswear has come of age, and American designers are doing it better than anyone else. For fall, they're playing two major themes: tailored and rugged. For the tailored look, they've been inspired by the landed gentry of our British heritage; for the rugged outdoor clothes, they've looked to our own pioneersthe homesteaders, whalers, lumberjacks, aviators and astronauts. Out of these varied elements comes a mix that the whole world labels the AllAmerican look.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: With a little luck, an awareness of the night sky and a realization of how relatively easy it is to take darksky shots, any photographer can take interesting and unusual pictures of stars and other celestial bodies on a clear night. Neither extensive knowledge nor expensive equipment is needed, yet in the process one can experiment with doing some really creative work in an area that is normally given over to primarily scientific interests.

title: The Shadow Government
description: Washington has acquired a satellite bureaucracy of consultants the way the British are said to have acquired their Empireby inadvertence. The system of contractingout basic government functions has grown chaotically alongside of burgeoning Federal programs. Though not in the Constitution, the modern consultant system is as surely a fixture of invisible government as the C.I.A., and it seems a nicer way to make a living.

title: Giscard Asks Team Effort by Cabinet
description: PARIS, Aug. 28President Valry Giscard d'Estaing told the newlyformed French Cabinet at its first meeting today that it must behave as a team and press for reforms with conviction and ardor.

title: Japanese Nine Wins Boys Title
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug28 (AP)  Tokyo took advantage of six wild pitches and five errors today and posted a 103 victory over Campbell, Calif., in the final game of the Little League world baseball championship.

title: Canada: More At Stake Than The Language
description: OTTAWA  Frenchspeaking airtraffic controllers of Quebec Province announced on Thursday that they will seek federal recognition as a separate aviation union, breaking their present affiliation with the Canadian Air Traffic Control Association, the national union with a majority of Englishspeaking members. The Quebec controllers have gone so far as to enlist the support of larger Frenchspeaking labor groups, including the militant Quebec Teachers Federation, making this the latest in a series of confrontations over language that, in the words of Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau, have raised serious issues of national unity.

title: MADDOX, McCARTHY SEEK TO BAR DEBATES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Lester G. Maddox and Eugene McCarthy, two longshot candidates for the Presidency, are attempting to block the proposed television debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter unless they are included.

title: Forest Fire in Wisconsin Destroys 24 Summer Homes
description: NECEDAH, Wis., Aug. 28 (UPI)A forest fire swept over about 3,600 acres of land today and destroyed at least 24 summer homes east of here, Fire Chief Harry Carter of Necedah said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 28 (UPI)William A. Shea, an attorney who was instrumental in bringing the Mets into New York as an expansion club, was elected president today of the Little League Baseball Foundation. Shea, a former vice president of the foundation, was elected at a special meeting of trustees in conjunction with the 30th annual Little League World Series. He succeeds James A. Farley, who died last June 9 after serving as president for 15 years.

title: SHUTDOWN FACED BY 11 HOSPITALS
description: Eleven voluntary and proprietary hospitals have been notified by the State Health Department that the agency was cosidering closing them entirely or in part in an effort to control costs by eliminating unneeded beds.

title: A Dance Calendar
description: Sept. 313New York Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: Celebrities Cavort on Court
description: Put a tennis racquet in the hands of a celebrity, team him with an established pro for a charitable cause and the result is an entertainment that drew 15,000 spectators to Forest Hills yesterday.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, August 29, 1976

title: U.N. Report Casts Doubt On South African Survival
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28 (UPI)A United Nations report has given South Africa only another 10 to 15 years of survival unless it abandons its system of apartheid, which the report charged is supported by the United States.

title: Stacy Valdes Wed in France
description: Stacy Terhune Valdes, daughter of Mrs. Donald Mackie of Princeton, N.J., and John Terhune Valdes of West Palm. Beach, Fla., and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday in France to Francois Lorenceau, a shipbroker with Barry Rogliano Salles in Paris.

title: Bangladesh Gives Pledge On Trial of Dutch Citizen
description: The Bangladesh Embassy in Washington said yesterday that Peter Custers, a Dutch social worker and freelance journalist arrested on sedition charges, would be assured every safeguard for a fair trial.

title: Rachel Simon, a Designer, Married
description: Rachel Simon and Laurence Garrick, founders and operators of the High Beam Design Corporation in Woodstock, N. Y., producer of architectural, interior and Industrial designs, were married yesterday afternoon in Saugerties, N.Y. Justice of the Peace Kevin Sweeney performed the ceremony at the home of Stephen Baker, a friend of the couple.

title: Broncos Conquer Cardinals
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP)Otis Armstrong dashed 81 and 2 yards for touchdowns in the second half tonight as the Denver Broncos rallied for a 2117 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals in a National Football League preseason game.

title: F. Graham Luckenbill 2d Weds Julia Olson, Wheaton Alumna
description: St. James Episcopal Church in Danbury, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Julia O??son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Olson of New York and Brookfield, Conn., to F. Graham Luckenbill 2d, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Luckenbill of Danbury.

title: Westchester's Dart Sniper Strikes Again
description: The mysterious sniper who has attacked nearly 20 women in Westchester County this summer with a dartgun has struck again after almost a month of inactivity, the Yonkers police said yesterday.

title: Janet E. Moore Becomes Bride
description: Janet Elizabeth Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gale Moore of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to William Reinhart Hanlon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hanlon of Riverhead, L.I. The Rev. Henry Mansell performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul.

title: The Networks Are Banking On The Super Programs
description: Television seasons are always billed as new, even though everyone knows by now that a new season is usually only an echo of the last one. Yet, momentous changes in programming do occur, and they have a history of coming at five or six year intervals. The last was in 1971 with the introduction by CBS of All in the Family, the show that changed the mores of primetime television and elevated the artistic and maturity levels of situation comedy. By the calendar, television is due for another molting, and it appears to be coming this fall.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  After a year of quiet deliberations, the National Commission on Supplies and Shortages is preparing to write a report that will lay muchhut not allof the blame for the nation's 197274 shortages of raw materials at the Government's doorstep.

title: The Volatile Pop Field Is Bubbling
description: The 197677 season in popular music is likely to be marked by the usual deluge of records and the customary round of concert toursboth grand and timidly hopeful. Locally, there will be the return of Howard Stein to the promoting wars and a curi??us flipflop of locales between Mr. Stein and Ron Delsener, who is currently the city's most active promoter.

title: Upcoming Classical Records
description: Beethoven: Missa Solemnis; Harper, Baker, Tear, Sotin; London Philharmonic, Carlo Maria Giulini, cond. Angel.

title: Real Estsle
description: Gino's Inc. net worth $42 million. $75,000 cash above mig per locstion. 10% return + overages, fully sheltered.

title: Opera and Concert Calendar
description: Sept. 1  City Opera's season opens with Turandot.

title: Making Hash, Not Hay
description: Trying to make political hay in the farm belt, first Gerald Ford, then Jimmy Carter, then Bob Dole made hash of the subject of embargoes on American farm exports. And none of them touched on the real issuethe need for the development of adequate grain reserves in this country.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONBen, beloved husband of Bertha (nee Green), devoted father of Mickey and Bill Spitainy, loving grandfather of Richard SeitaMy and Jill Baton. Cherished greet grandfather of Melissa, Amanda and Blythe. Services on Sunday, August 29, 2 P.M. ar The Riverside Westchester, 21 West Broad Street, Fleetwood, Mt. Vernon.

title: Keeping Alcoholics on the Job
description: A NEW state task force will attempt to convince industry that it pays to try to rehabilitate the employed alcoholic, of whom there are an estimated 300,000 in New Jersey alone.

title: Bridal Oct. 10 For Liza Vann
description: Liza Vann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Vann of Durham, N. C., plans to be married Oct. 10 to Cameron Outcalt Smith of New York.

title: Diners: Elite Meet To Eat There, Too
description: MORE often than not, the summer night in New Jersey is thick with humidity, the vapors of which somehow veil city street lights in an eerie cloud. In industrial areas such as Linden, Newark and Sayreville, the uncomfortable moisture mingles with fumes belched out by distilleries and refineries that further burden the sweating motorist or city porchklatchers with queer and wretched smells.

title: This Season the Old Is Making News
description: What's new on the art scene this fall is mostly what's old, and in at least one case it is very old indeed: 302,000 years, by a rough count.

title: Redcoats Win Again in Brooklyn
description: The day will be ours, Maj. Thomas Pieper said yesterday as he surveyed his redcoated troops of the 23d Regiment of Royal Welch Fusiliers on the Long Meadow in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Make mine Manhattan
description: There is a rumor going about That skirts we in, and pants are out, That Fashion will no longer brook The old, androgynous denimlook, That lovely legs will steal the scene, But not in trouser, slack, or jean, For Unisex is finally throughI wonderis the rumor true?

title: Hockey Teams of 6 Nations Open Play Thursday
description: A twoweek international tournament, which could have as great an impact on the development of North American hockey as did the National Hockey League's expansion in 1967, begins Thursday on this side of the Atlantic. The Canada Cup tourney will bring together for the first time perhaps the six best professional and amateur squads in the world.

title: Congress Under Pressure
description: As the 94th Congress enters what is likely to be its final month, it is under pressure from an accumulated backlog of work, inescapable legislative deadlines, and the atmosphere of a closelyfought national political campaign. From full employment bills to health insurance, from education appropriations to day care, and from abortion to gun controlunresolved issues demand decisions. But the 94th has been stalemated by the power struggle between a Republican President and a Democraticcontrolled House and Senate. Two years of veto battles have drained the zest, and left both majority and minority parties on Capitol Hill passively awaiting the outcome of the November election.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  K.C. of Northern N.J. allbreed, Bergen Mall, Paramus, N.J.; 1,447 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Hospitals Warned of Explosives Formed in Plumbing
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 28 (UPI)Federal health officials warned today that it was possible that explosives more dangerous than nitroglycerine had been formed by chemical reactions in the plumbing of more than 15,000 hospital and clinical laboratories in the United States.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in the Arts and Leisure Section:

title: Tour Earnings
description: P.G.A. GOLF

title: Louise Eastman Bride
description: Louise Lindner Eastman Jr. daughter of Lee V. Eastman of New York and East Hampton L.I., and the late Louise Lindner Eastman, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles H. Weed Jr. He is the son of Mrs. George Wright of Milton, Mass., and the late Dr. Weed of Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Brian S. Kopke of the Unitarian Church in Southold, L.I., performed the ceremony at the Eastman home in East Hampton. The bride graduated from Smith College and her husband from Harvard.

title: GARDENING
description: WITH the end of summer comes lawn seeding and renovation time. The cool season grasses planted in our area are moving into a period of temperatures optimum for their growth. The temperatures are gradually becoming cooler, especially at night, and the fall rains will soon arrive to encourage growth.

title: Southern Africa, Once a Zulu Kingdom
description: JOHANNESBURGWhile relatives of the black strife in Soweto last week buried their dead, a huge throng gathered on a plot of scrubland to cheer Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, the Zulu leader, as he pleaded for blacks of all tribal origins and political persuasions to unite in the struggle against apartheid.

title: Sudanese Says Nimeiry Executed 232 in Secret
description: KUWAIT, Aug. 28 (Reuters) A former Sudanese Minister of Health has been quoted as accusing President Gaafar alNimeiry of having executed over 300 people in the aftermath of last month's abortive coup in Sudan, many more than officially reported.

title: LAIN ON KIDNEY AID IS TERMED UNFAIR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 28Two pioneers in the development and use of the artificial kidney say the Government could save millions of dollars a year by allowing patients to manage their own treatment at home rather than going to hospitals or special centers.

title: Jumper Title To Gelding, 9
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 28 With Joy Slater riding, Wile E. Coyote, a mount who becomes steadier as he gets older, captured the amateurowner jumper championship today at the Nassau County horse show.

title: Labor Talks Are Under Way
description: Through most of the three decades since World War II, model changes in national collective bargaining have borne the same made in Detroit stamp as have model changes in automobiles. The wage patterns set in negotiations between the United Auto Workers and the Big Three auto companies have percolated through the economy, fixing pay increases for millions of workers and helping to determine the pace of inflation.

title: Karen Suman Will Return to Action at Forest Hills
description: Her daughter, Shelley, is 13 years old and doing nicely, thank you. Her husband, Rod, is secure selling insurance. So when Karen Hantze Susman started thinking about what she wanted to do, at age 33, her first thoughts naturally drifted to tennis.

title: Nets Open In N.B.A. On Coast
description: The Knicks will open their National Basketball Association season on Oct. 21 at Madison Square Garden, and the Nets, one of the four new teams in the league, will start one day later on the West Coast.

title: Nora Finnegan Plans Marriage
description: Dr. and Mrs. John G. Finnegan of Rye, N.Y., and Dedham, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nora Finnegan, to Donn C. Dolce, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Dolce of Rye and Wolfeboro, N.H. A December wedding is planned.

title: Mr. Kissinger Will Visit the U.N. This Week, but the Conference Is Unlikely to Budge
Susan Ward Married
description: Susan Elizabeth Ward, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. R. Wendell Ward of Maplewood N.J., was married there yesterday to George Svend Protopapadakis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kyriakos Protopapadakis of Bickley, England. The Rev. Gustavus Warfield performed the ceremony in the Prospect Presbyterian Church.

title: C. W. Bailey Jr. Weds Anne Taliaferro
description: Anne Hollis Taliaferro and Charles W. Bailey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bailey of Princeton, N. J., and Cotuit, Mass., were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Walton Taliaferro of Harrisonburg, Va.

title: O great Cheops, what bath thy offspring wrought?
description: As I write, a plastic Pyramid Energy Generator sits close to my typewriter, generating. My fingers fly over the keys and brilliant insights and flashing phrases race onto the paper. But then, they always do. I cannot thank the pyramid. More proof of its power is needed.

title: STAMPS
description: The men responsible for the American Revolution have, for some reason, not had the representation on commemoratives from foreign countries as the momentous events or concepts for which the. Revolution was fought This is not to say, in this continuing report on the great omnibus Bicentennial issue in which the whole world seemed to join, that there have not been sets from some nations with personalities abounding, including one massive issue that, despite keen competition, has to be awarded the palm for the most garish stamps put out for America's 200th birthday.

title: Out From Under Wraps
description: Tucked away for half a century or so as the lining of those famous British raincoats, Burberrys', plaid has given up making a fashion understatement and is having something of a comingout party.

title: The Island's DriveIns Keep On Rolling
description: DRIVEIN movie theaters. You can drink there, smoke there, propose marriage there, babysit there, or eat to your heart's content there.

title: OFFICIAL SCORES F.B.I. MAN'S ROLE
description: MIAMI, Aug. 28A Florida prosecutor has formally complained to the Federal Bureau of Investigation about what he described as the outrageous, disgraceful and injurious conduct of one of the bureau's agents here.

title: G.O.P. Scored on Education
description: PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Aug. 28 (UPI)  Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, charged Republicans today with showing a deep hostility to Federal aid for education in their campaign platform. Mr. Muskie also told a teachers' group that the Congressional budget provided $3 billion more for education than President Ford's budget.

title: Dancers Get Themselves Together
description: The prize for the best unconfirmed rumor of the new dance season goes to the report that Margot Fonteyn, Maya Plisetskaya and Alicia Alonso will team up at the Uris Theater. The idea has reportedly been vetoed by one of the members of the Old Girl network. Nonetheless, this pooling of talents would be a perfect symbol for the way the 197677 dance season is taking shape.

title: Gardeners Get Help From The Experts
description: NEW HAVEN, CONN. When Maishe Dickman saw the condition of the soil at the New Haven site he had picked for a community garden project he was starting last April, he knew he needed some help. He sent a soil sample for testing to The Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, which is located here. In return he received far more professional help than he expected with the result that the garden is now thriving.

title: Why No Room At the Top For Blacks?
description: AFTER more than a decade of public service as a State Assemblyman from Newark, a period spanning the administrations of three Governors, I must reluctantly declare that New Jersey is guilty of de facto discrimination against black, Hispanic and innercity residents in many respects.

title: Westchester, With 2,779 Dogs, Tops List of Weekend Shows
description: Labor Day weekend signals a return to the dog show circuit for metropolitan fanciers. Many owners, who preferred not to campaign their dogs during the extremely hot weather, are back and four shows, starting Friday, have drawn a total of 7,898 entries. Westchester, the East's blueribbon outdoor event, heads the list, with 2,779, followed by Somerset Hills, with 1,996; New Brunswick, 1,577, and Tuxedo Park, 1,546. The 59th edition of Westchester is being held next Sunday at Lyndhurst, a national trust on Route 9, in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Headliners
description: The Point Man

title: Trick Saigon Raid Described in Detail By Hanoi General
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  Captured Americanmade fighter  bombers were used in a trick strike on Saigon's Tan Son Nhut Airport in the last days of the fighting for the city, according to the general who commanded the North Vietnamese forces.

title: Along Party Lines
description: Although the traditional Labor Day starting date has not yet arrived, the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominees and their running mates have begun campaigning in earnest, both sides voicing the themes hinted at in their party conventions.

title: Prophecy...
description: The following are excerpts from Alan Paton's novel about South Africa, Cry, the Beloved Country, written in 1948:

title: Simplicity Stock Options Too Much for the Judge
description: During the prolonged bear market of recent years, many executives found themselves unhappily owning worthless stock options. As a result, a flurry of revised stock option plans was noted on the corporate scene with older, higherpriced option plans being canceled and new options priced at considerably lower levels being granted as incentives for top management.

title: Storm Halts Play In American Golf
