description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) Ray Floyd birdied the 12th hole and moved into a share of the lead today just before play was halted in the stormdelayed, uncompleted third round of the $200,000 American Golf Classic.

title: Hope Stewart Luke Affianced To John Hetherington, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Anderson Luke of Bedford, N.Y., and West Chop, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hope Stewart Luke, to John Warner Hetherington, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kells Hetherington of Forest Hills, Queens. A November wedding is planned.

title: Hair From Survivors of the Pennsylvania Epidemic Being Tested for Possible Traces of a Toxic Substance
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 28Strands of hair from survivors of the mysterious disease that has killed 28 people in Pennsylvania are being tested in a physics laboratory in Massachusetts to help find the cause of the epidemic.

title: 1:57 15 Mile Paced By Rambling Willie
description: YONKERS, Aug. 28Rambling Willie, the evenmoney favorite, opened his bid to win paces tonight at Yonkers Raceway and Wednesday night at the Meadowlands in New Jersey by defeating Handle With Care here in the blistering mile time of 1:57 1/5.

title: Rights Unit Offers Legal Aid on New Law
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would be willing to provide legal aid to anyone who answered noeven if that answer was a liewhen asked about any arrest record on an application in this state for employment, insurance, credit or a license.

title: Resale of Trucking Permits Target of Inquiry in House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28In 1964, a piece of paper from the Federal Government, a license to ship goods to Ohio and West Virginia, was sold by one private trucking company to another for $260,000. Nine years later, the same piece of paper was sold to a third company for $860,000.

title: Play Third Base and Live
description: Every time a life insurance company flings up another skyscraper like the Prudential Building in Boston or John Hancock Center in Chicago, it is a reminder that the money for these majestic towers comes from making book on people's lives. The insurance company bets you that you will live longer than its agents have suggested, and it wins because it is strictly a chalk player. The horse player who ruins his eyes poring over past performances is a mere beginner alongside the actuaries who study form on people.

title: Inside an Outdoor Antiques Show
description: It's a summer Saturday, 4 A.M., and Frank and Lili Jensen are up and about their home in Litchfield, Conn. The station wagon had been loaded the night before, and by 5 A.M. they are on their way to the Bicentennial Antiques Sale in Redding.

title: SEIZURE OF SMUT VOIDED BY COURT
description: A procedure that the Government uses to confiscate allegedly obscene material has been declared unconstitational by a Federal Judge in Manhattan.

title: Stuffy Abercrombie's Gets Sale Relief
description: It's just like Christmas, said a customer to a salesman yesterday during the first day of Abercrombie & Fitch's milliondollar reorganizing sale. Yeh, the salesman replied sardonically, the last Christmas.

title: Conservationist Cause Defended
description: MORRISTOWN THE New Jersey Conservation Foundation, one of the leading environmental groups in the state, has challenged contentions by some sectors of the business community that mandatory compliance with environmental  protection laws has led to a sharp decline in the state's economy and rising unemployment.

title: What's Doing in the THAMES VALLEY
description: ESCAPE ROUTE  The great street paved with water was how the poet John Muefield described the River Thames. For Londoners it represents escape from city pressures; for visitors it is a leisurely route out of the capital and into the countryside. The great street rises in the Cotswolds. Toward its source are lovely meadows near Lechlade; from there to Oxford, u the river winds past occasional villages, are lonely willows, isolated houses. For superb scenery, the best stretch is Maidenhead to Marlow. For villages and old market towns, Reading to Oxford. And near the center of London is the splendid Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew.

title: U.S. GIVES TERMS FOR PARTITIONING PANMUNJOM SITE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 28 The United States told North Korea today that it would consider a North Korean proposal that the Panmunjom truce village be partitioned. The Americans insisted, however, that the safety of United States guards within the joint security area would have to be firmly guaranteed.

title: Issues May Get Lost
description: WASHINGTONOnly a spoilsport would say so, but the enthusiasm that the prospect of Presidential debates arouses among civic leaders, editorial writers and other rightthinking citizens is not always easy to understand. The precedents, such as they are, suggest that this form of political theater has its drawbacks.

title: Mailbox: On South Africa
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.N. Reports Slavery Exists In Africa and Latin America
description: GENEVA, Aug, 28 (UPI)Slavery is still widespread in Latin America and Africa, according to a United Nations report.

title: Richards Bows to Foe, 17
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 28So what was all the fuss about? A stocky, 17yearold high school senior named Lea Antonoplis beat Dr. Renee Richards in the semifinals of the $60,000 Tennis Week open today.

title: But Since Attica I, There Have Been Changes
description: The inmate strike at Attica prison is a peaceful reminder that almost five years of reform, some genuine, some cosmetic, have been all but overwhelmed by factors that state prison officials have been either unable or unwilling to change. The years since the 1971 uprising that took 43 lives have shown that the lessons of Attica not only exacted a terrible price but also are easily forgotten.

title: Ann Fessenden Chase Is Married
description: Ann Fessenden Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Rodgers Chase of Pleasantville, N. Y., and Rockport, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to John Winthrop Ballantine Jr., son of Lucia H. deGrazia of Princeton, N. J., and Mr. Ballantine of New York.

title: Hyatt, Korshak, Las Vegas and the Teamsters
description: In 1969 a senior Hyatt executive said the company had no interest in Las Vegasthat the gambling capital didn't fit the Hyatt image.

title: METHODISTS ELECT NEW TOP LEADERS
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 28 (AP)The 450member Methodist World Council elected the governing body today that will rule its member churches for the next five years.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: LOS ANGELES (N.)

title: Drought Leads Raleigh, N.C. To Ban Some Uses of Water
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 28 (AP) A ban on nonessential uses of water that had been in effect on a voluntary basis became mandatory in Raleigh today as a drought continued to lower the flow of water in the Neuse River, where the city gets most of its water.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors can still catch a large measure of the excitement at the world's greatest coin show todaythe final day of the 85th national convention of the American Numismatic Association in the Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 52d Street. Admission is free and the show is open to allmembers of the A.N.A. and nonmembers alike from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: GARDENING
description: NEW JERSEY gardeners planning to plant peonies this fall should consider the sites carefully beforehand. Peonyplanting is a big chore that neeel be done only once in a lifetime.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 29, 1976

title: 14 Presidential Aspirants Spent $70 Million in Races
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Presidential candidates of both major parties, supported for the first time by Federal subsidies, spent about $70 million on their preconvention campaigns this year, an increase of onethird over estimates for the 1972 election.

title: Jingo: Not as It Sounds
description: Proclaimed experts on United States politics pretend to detect weakness in support for Jimmy Carter's Presidential candidacy among American Jewish and Catholic voters. With no personal pretension to such expertise myself I cannot judge the validity of such estimates.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THE quest began for David Metz about 20 years ago, when he and his wife bought their house in Freehold. The buildings had a good bit of age in them and the Metzes thought they should be filled with old things, and so they began reading antiquecollecting magazines and newspapers, nosing through flea markets and visiting antique shows, picking up a bit of glass here, a piece of furniture there, some lace, an old oak box.

title: Professional Football
description: American Conference EASTERN DIVISION

title: Drinking on TV Opposed
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 28 (UPI)Mrs. Charles 0. Morris of Atlanta, director of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, urged the group's members today to write letters to the major television networks urging them to curb programs that show people drinking.

title: Mr. Ford Is Developing the Underdog Role
description: VAIL, Colo.It may have been the rarified air. President Ford's drives soared farther than normal on the golf course. His serves had more zing on the tennis court. And in politics as well, after nine days of campaign strategy planning at 8,200 feet above sea level in the Rockies, he seemed free of the gravitational pull of reality. The underdog President thought he could win.

title: Focus on the face
description: What with hoods, babushkas, tight little caps and peasant shawls promised for fall, a woman mightlike (lamlet's Ophelia get herself to a nunnery. Not much of her is going to show by day except possibly the lessthanperfect oval of her face.

title: Judith Cutler Bride of Bank Aide
description: Judith Elizabeth Cutler and Philip Michael McGoohan were married yesterday at the North Shore Congregational Church in Milwaukee by the Rev. Harry W. Clark. He was assisted by the Rev. John P. Raynor, president of Marquette University.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT was one of those let'slookforsomething  different days, and we all piled into the car headed for we didn't know where. Our choice finally narrowed down to either a visit to Brookhaven and the world of tomorrow or to the Old Bethpage Village Restoration and the world of yesterday.

title: Czechs Assured on Prices
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  President Gustav Husak pledged today that basic consumer prices would not be in creased next year despite harvest setbacks. He denied reports that poor results in the potato and sugarbeet crops and a lag in the wheat crop would cause higher prices and shortages. This is not true, he said.

title: Summer Goes Out in a Blaze of Activities
description: THE summer of '76the year of Belle and beach blobswill go out on an upbeat note, with a Labor Day weekend filled with enough variety to suit the most rarified tastes.

title: The Last Empire
description: It seems almost incredible that some of the photographs in this beautiful book were taken a decade before the Great Mutiny of 1857, that several record the devastation of the Mutiny itself and that many others are works of art. The photographersSamuel Bourne in particular  must have known the strangely lighted aquatints of Thomas and William Daniell, whose Oriental Scenery was issued serially between 1795 and 1808. Painting in India didn't die; it was recreated by British photographers who, like Bourne, marched for miles into the hills with 42 porters22 of them carrying photographic equipment  and who might wait for weeks for the wind to die dovin or for a man to appear on a mountain road to give perspective to the composition.

title: Turnaround on Seventh Avenue
description: Designer Calvin Klein was lounging in Palm Springs last winter when he noticed a terrificlooking womana woman he would like to see wearing his designs. The next day he spotted her again, stepping out of her RollsRoycewearing a Tshirt that read Calvin Klein across one ann. A few years ago it would have been an Yves Saint Laurent or a Cour reges, he observes. America is finally catching on to American fashion.

title: 3 Skippers .Undefeated in Race Week
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 28Only three skippers emerged unscathed today as 160 boats sailed in the third race of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 44th annual Race Week.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The new season is going to have its own character, but there's no way of saying what that character might be until it's all over and done with. To tell the truth, I don't even like to think about a season ahead of time. If you think about what's announced for production, what's most likely to succeed, what the newest vogue or the dominant strain may prove to be, you wind up looking for those successes, that vogue, that dominant strain as you to the theater, expecting the theater to confirm the conclusions you've reached in your head. Which means that, in part at least, you're falsifying what you see before you see it, forcing it into prearranged small packages that have precious little to do with the realities at hand. Better, I say, to conclude nothing until the curtains come downand then see what's hit you.

title: The Filming Of the West
description: Jon Tuska's enormous account (the book comes in at 10  by 7 inches and is almost all text) of the making of westerns from the time of The Great Train Robbery (1903) to the present makes no claim for itself as criticism; but as a straight whowhatwherewhenhow report, it does intend to offer the reader a sense of history, a sense of how the western took shape and changed shape. Instead it is a lump: a mountain of anecdotes, plot summaries, life stories, reminiscences, budget reports, stills, publicity photos and hagiographic detritus, which, when seen whole, seems to have little or no significance.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: MATAPEDIA. QuebecAlthough my hands were steady, there was an inner fluttering as I cast my first fly across the roily waters of the Patapdia Pool on the Restigouche River.

title: Poetry here, hot off the press!
description: As we walk along Shattuck Avenue in the early afternoon, my companion, a poet named Bruce Hawkins, extends a copy of a paperback called Berkeley Poets Cooperative/9 toward the people we meet. Most of them won't look directly at us and shake their heads or mumble something as they hurry past. If they show a flicker of interest, Hawkins asks quietly, Poets Coop? After watching his technique for a while, I do the same with one of the books I'm carrying. We walk through a coffee shop called Smokey Joe's and another called Oleg's, displaying our books at the tables. No sales.

title: Rate Break for Aged?
description: TRENTON THE Legislature and state publicutility officials are wrestling with a proposal to provide lower utility rates for the elderly and the poor, but the idea is proving difficult to pin down.

title: Letters
description: Since the caption proclaims At Age 44, Sears Mail Order House Is in Its Prime, one is led to speculate about this vanishing aspect of Americana. Unlike the Edsel automobile, it did have its day in the sun; purchasers (as sales figures indicate) found it more than acceptableat least for a time.

title: Too Controversial?
description: Under the gun of the election, Congress seems sure to postpone such controversial issues as national health insurance, gun control, postcard voter registration, divestiture by oil conglomerates, and S1, the revision of the Federal criminal code. Any one of these measures is sufficiently complex to provoke a possible Senate filibuster that would kill most of the available time between now and the expected Oct. 1 adjournment.

title: STRIKE AT ATTICA SEEMS TO BE OVER
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 28The sixday strike at Attica prison appeared to be over today after inmates began to return to work in normal numbers.

title: Superstars and Varied Repertory On New Disks
description: Was it only a few years ago that the doomsayers were predicting the quiet demise of classical records? No one could make a profit on the things, we were told, the market was shrinking, rock was taking over. Those were the days of the classical crisis  costcutting programs, a lackadaisical approach to artistand repertory planning and the specter of a greatly reduced selection for the record year.

title: Taking on the tide
description: No one who knows Spurgeon Milton Keeny believes that, even at the age of 83 and after more than a quarter of a century traveling through Asian villages talking about babies and birth control, he is serious about his threats to retire. I'll always believe in children, but preferably two to a family, he says, and when they're born they should stay alive and healthy. You've got to prove your point by going around and showing people that family planning works.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Firstyear law students are taught that property is not a thing but a collection of rights analogous to a bundle of sticks, Recent developments in California and New York have raised the question of how many sticks the government can take away and still leave the property owner in possession of the bundle.

title: A Banking Ballad From County Jail
description: MADISON, Wis.Each day a bit before dawn, John T. Stone rises to begin his day as a prisoner at the Dane County Jail here. He sweeps the floors, distributes and cleans the inmates' razor blades, serves meals and carries out the trash.

title: Black and White Coalition Urges N.A.A.C.P. Board to Settle Feud With Wilkins
description: A coalition of prominent Americans, blacks and whites, has urged the board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to settle without additional public debate its smoldering and potentially destructive feud with the organization's longtime director, Roy Wilkins.

title: Sally Sanford Wed to Lowell Smith
description: Sally Allis Sanford, daughter of Mrs. Berry Sanford of Hamden, Conn., and Charles Hamilton Sanford of Southport, Conn., was married in New Haven yesterday afternoon to Lowell Sanborn Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Lincoln Smith of Concord, Mass.

title: FOREST HILLS: THE GREATEST SHOW IN U.S. TENNIS
description: The United States Open Tennis Championships are unique among great American sports spectacles for the duration and range of their drama. The Superbowl lasts for three hours, the Indianapolis 500 for about the same time, the Masters golf tournament for four days and the World Series for seven games at most But the U.S. Open is played out on the graygreen courts of the West Side Terms Club in Forest Hills. N.Y.. over 12 days (and eight nights) with almost 400 separate singles and doubles contests.

title: BIG APPLE IS HOST TO TRAVEL AGENTS
description: More than 200 travel agents descended this weekend upon New York (always referred t.), on such occasions, as the Big Apple) for three days of touring, showgoing speechattending and eating.

title: Depression GlassIt Is No Longer Considered Junk
description: From about 1920 until just before the start of World War II one could buy colorful glass dishes, bowls, cups, ashtrays and other items of machinemade cast glass for just a few cents each at fiveandtencent stores, variety stores and chain stores. At the height of their popularity during the Depression years these massproduced pieces of glassware were even given away free in boxes of cereal and other foods, as well as by gas stations and movie houses who used them as premiums in an effort to gain new customers.

title: Noteworthy Movies on the 197677 Schedule
description: September

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Education has prepared guidelines for the use of underutilized space in the city's public schools by municipal agencies and qualified community  service organizations, following enactment of a new state law permitting such use during daytime hours. The City Planning Commission estimates that city agencies and community groups in one school district it studied, covering Staten Island, could cut rental costs from an average of $4.20 a square foot annually for space now used in private buildings to $2.50 a square foot for shared space in schools.

title: CHESS
description: There is no blunder so crude, so obvious, that it cannot be perpetrated in the tensionpacked late rounds of an important tournament. I don't mean the kind of catastrophe that crops up in an extreme time pressure emergency, such as five seconds for a dozen moves, for that requires no explanation.

title: BRIDGE
description: In chess tournaments it is customary to award a brilliancy prize to the player of the best game from a total that is usually less than 100. The task of making a similar award at a national bridge championship would be virtually impossible, since more than a quarter of a million deals are played.

title: Detroit News Appoints Giles
description: DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP)The appointment of William E. Giles, the 49yearold founding editor of The National Observer, as executive editor of The Detroit News was announced today. Mr. Giles had been serving as Distinguished Editor in Residence at Baylor University in Waco, Tex. After completing 25 years with The National Observer.

title: 2 Yonkers Drivers Draw Suspensions
description: YONKERS, Aug. 28 Yonkers Raceway judges handed stiff suspensions today to Anthony Del Priore (15 days) and Anthony Santeramo (10 days). Del Priore was charged with driving Stacy Adios with indifference on Aug. 20 compared with last night when he won the second race.

title: Redskins Top Jets; Giants Win, 2016
description: Youth was served at Yankee Stadium last night and the Washington Redskins picked it clean.

title: Ionian Island Is Domain Of a Rich Greek Family
description: CEPHALONIA, Greece Andrew Vergotis was relaxing on his yacht the other day when his brother caned with an urgent message. Someone is digging up the beach, he was told, call the police and get them to stop it.

title: RIGHTIST TERROR STIRS ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27Bombings and kidnappings attributed to rightwing extremists in Argentina have increased public demands for effective measures by the milltary authorities to control this form of political terrorism.

title: A Crowd of 49,572 Caps Kicks' FairyTale Season.
description: It's been too much of a Cinderella year for the Minnesota Kicks, the North American Soccer League franchise that generated success in the stands and on the field after moving from Denver. That Cinderella parallel became more striking last Wednesday night in Bloomington when Ade Coker's shoes were missing after the Kicks reached Soccer Bowl76 by defeating San Jose, 31, for the Pacific Conference championship. The victory sent a number of enthusiasts in the crowd of 49,572 into a frenzy. They tore up pieces of turf at Metropolitan Stadium and one or two fans took Coker's shoes as souvenirs.

title: Letters
description: Goring the ox

title: A Pekingese Is Named Best Of 1,413 Dogs in Jersey Show
description: NEWTON, N.J., Aug. 28 In a sylvan setting on the grounds of St. Paul's Abbey, a fawn Pekingese was named best of 1,413 dogs today at the Newton Kennel Club's 33d fixture.

title: U.N. YEARBOOK GIVES POPULATION TRENDS
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 28 (Reuters)The tiny Republic of San Marino in the Italian Apennines has the world's lowest infant mortality rate, while on Norfolk Island in the South Pacific birth itself is something of a rarity, according to the 1975 edition of the United Nations Statistical Yearbook just published.

title: Rep. Chisholm Battling Wright In Showdown Race in Brooklyn
description: After years of sparring through surrogates and contesting each other's candidates for party and state offices, Representative Shirley Chisholm and Councilman Samuel D. Wright are now in a headtohead race for the 12th Congressional District seat. With it goes the position of political leader of the mostly black and Puerto Rican central Brooklyn area.

title: Bill Collectors Defensive About Harassment Issue
description: A New Jersey motorist we'll call Al felt both his voice and his blood pressure begin to rise the minute he answered the telephone. It was the third such, call he'd received from the collection agency in as many weeks. The voice on the other end was different this time, but the message was the same: Hand over $356 and change in overdue parking violations and fines, or the City of New York would get a judgment against him.

title: List of Physicians Receiving at Least $100,000 in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Following is a list of physicians in individual practice named by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare as having received at least $100,000 last year from the New York State Medicaid program. The names, addresses and amounts are contained in a report by the Subcommittee on LongTerm Care of the Special Senate Committee on Aging.

title: Axelson Is Little Changed by Heat of Fiscal Crisis
description: His hair is not discernibly grayer. His temper remains mostly under control. He has not become noticeably addicted to headlines, television interviews and bureaucratic intrigue.

title: Arab Disunity Gives Israel A Respite on Its Frontiers
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 29Israel's heavily guarded borders are calmer and more open now than at any time since the end of the 1973 Middle East war.

title: Katherine Sproehnle, 81, A Writer for Magazines
description: Katherine Sproehnle, a writer who contributed to The New Yorker, Vanity Fair, Saturday Evening Post and other magazines, died yesterday at her home, 700 Park Avenue.

title: Peking Praises Father Who Let Children Die
description: PEKING, Aug. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)China's official party newspaper has praised the actions of a father who, instead of rescuing his two children during the Tangshan earthquake on July 28, left them to die and saved an old party cadre instead.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A reader from Cambridge, Mass., respectfully demands a diagnosis concerning the fine points of fish cookery.

title: Ocean Researchers See Threat in the Law of the Sea Conference
description: In 1779, Benjamin Franklin, convinced that the study of the seas transcends national considerations, wrote a pass for an English explorer's ship instructing captains of American naval vessels not to consider Iher an enemy.

title: Humanistic Psychologists at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, Aug. 29 Whenever the Association for Humanistic Psychology, a worldwide organization that emphasizes selfrealization, creativity and the uniqueness of human life, holds its annal convention, the emphasis is on exploring new methods and experiences, as this year's 2,000 participants, including Timothy Leary, demonstrated at Princeton University this weekend.

title: CHARLES CODMAN CABOT
description: NORTH HAVEN, Me., Aug. 29 (AP)  Charles Codman Cabot, former associate justice of the Massachusetts Superior Court and Chairman of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority from 196669, died yesterday at his summer home. He was 75 years old.

title: Energy Conservation...
description: The 18nation International Energy Agency in Paris recently reported that the member country with virtually the worst record in conserving energy was the one that conceived the I.E.A. in 1974 to reduce the vulnerability of the industrial nations to another Arab oil embargo or price increase. That country is the United States, which has substantially increased both its dependence on imported oil and the proportion coming from the Arab nations.

title: Arab Disunity Gives Israel A Respite on Its Frontiers
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 29Israel's heavily guarded borders are calmer and more open now than at any time since the end of the 1973 Middle East war.

title: Attica Prison Returns to Normal Routine With Some Uneasiness
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 29  Inmates at Attica prison appeared today to have returned to normal religious, recreational and work schedules for the first time since their sixday strike began last week. But there were reports that it was an uneasy peace.

title: Emanuel Schlossman, 77, Retired Furniture Dealer
description: Emanuel Schlossman, who retired in 1966 as president of Schlossman Inc., a metropolitanarea furniture chain that pioneered in the credit field when it was founded in 1888, died Saturday night in his home, 930 Fifth Avenue. He was 77 years old.

title: Concert Turns Into Melee
description: WARREN, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) Three teenagers were hospitalized and six Cleveland area men were arrested early today after a brawl at a rock concert at the Trumbull County fairgrounds, the authorities said. The Mosquito Dam Jam turned into a wild melee about 9:30 P.M. when the 12hour concert was called off because of rain.

title: WILLIAM FORRESTER
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug 29William Forrester, who retired in 1971 as associate business manager and personnel director of The Pittsburgh Press, a ScrippsHoward newspaper, died today in St. Clair Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old. He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Thelma Ruth Cassel Forrester, two daughters, two sons, a brother, a sister, and three grandchildren.

title: Fire at Fraternity Kills Five Members At a Kansas School
description: BALDWIN CITY, Kan., Aug. 29 (UPI)A fire apparently caused by careless smoking raced through the Kappa Sigma fraternity house at Baker University early today, killing five members, including the student who called the fire department.

title: KennedyNixon Debates a Key To What '76 Clashes May Hold
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The television networks presented them as The Great Debates, but at the time, a number of critics asked what was so great about them and whether they were even debates.

title: Harrises' Sentencing Today
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) William and Emily Harris were reported in very, very good spirits as they awaited sentencing tomorrow on convictions of kidnapping and robbery. Their defense lawyer, Mark Rosenbaum, said he and other lawyers were surprised at the, Harrises' positive mood after verdicts were returned Aug. 9 in the case involving their onetime fugitive traveling companion, Patricia Hearst.

title: Football and the Airborne Dollar
description: In the early days of radio broadcasting of sports events, owners of baseball teams viewed the new medium with the same combination of suspicion and fear they felt toward psychiatry, people with foreign accents and Prohibition whisky. Baseball was the only major professional game in this country then. Some clubs, declaring that only an imbecile would give away the product he was trying to sell, barred microphones from their parks. Others, like the St. Louis Cardinals, experimented. The Cardinals, who were the first to schedule doubleheaders for most Sundays, blanketed the countryside around St. Louis with radio coverage of weekday games and cut off the broadcasts on Sunday. Just as the National Football League would build up attendance in later years by televising road games and blacking out the games at home, the Cardinals' policy brought many thousands from surrounding areas into town on Sundays. When radio found it could sell playbyplay coverage to sponsors, it agreed to buy its way into the parks, and a judicious application of cash helped allay the owners' fears. Eventually radio and TV became a major source of income. They also made new fans, and if they helped destroy the minor leagues the majors didn't care.

title: Ted Brown Quartet Presents Lennie Tristano's Jazz Sounds
description: The long, rubbery, rising and falling lines associated with Lennie Tristano's jazz groups 25 and more years ago but rarely heard since then were floating through Willy's, 7 West Eighth Street, this weekend. They were coming from a quartet led by Ted Brown, a tenor saxophonist who was a student of Mr. Tristano and a follower of the two leading Tristano saxophonists, Lee Konitz and Warne Marsh.

title: Religious Conversion Is Cited by Cleaver
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)  Eldridge Cleaver said today that he had experienced a religious conversion to Christianity while he was in exile aboard for seven years, and was now a person with a heart full of good will.

title: ROSE G. LACHER
description: Rose G. Lacher, for 25 years president of Lacher Blouse Company, 525 Seventh Avenue until its liquidation 10 years ago, died Saturday in her home, 2 Fifth Avenue, after a short illness. She was 70 years old. She is survived by three sisters, Lola Rivlin, Mignon Bloom and Ada Freiberg.

title: Old State House Drive Opens
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 29 (UPI) A group that wants to renovate the Old State House in Hartford has launched a $1.7 million fundraising drive. The Old State House Association said yesterday it has received pledges totaling $355,000, but it needed more to restore the 180yearold building to its former glory as the seat of Connecticut's earliest legislative sessions.

title: FLORENCE K. MORRISON
description: Florence Keane Morrison, mother of Henderson W. Morrison, administrative judge of Nassau County Court, died Saturday in Grover Hermann Hospital, Callicoon, N.Y., after a lingering illness. Mrs. Morrison lived in Long Eddy, N.Y., and was 80 years old.

title: Moynihan Accuses Rep. Abzug of RuleorRuin Stand
description: Daniel P. Moynihan accused Representative Bella S. Abzug yesterday of a ruleorruin attitude after she said she would not support him if he won the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York.

title: White House Incident
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) A woman who said she wanted to see President Ford was jailed today after climbing the White House fence, the District of Columbia police said. A police spokesman said that Helen Tuchalski, 29 years old, of Norwood, Mass., climbed over the fence after being refused admittance at the gate. The incident occurred just after midnight.

title: U.S. Influence on Iran: Gigantic and Diverse
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29United States policies, products and personnel have had an enormous impact on this ancient Middle Eastern kingdom in recent years, largely through the sale of substantially more than $10 billion in Americanmade military equipment to the Iranian regime since early 1972.

title: HOTEL BUYERS BET ON GAMBLING VOTE
description: ATLANTIC CITY. Aug. 29Apparently prompted by the possibility of casino gambling in the future, five businessmen have concluded a deal with an insurance company, Mutual of New York (MONY), for the purchase of the Ambassador Hotel, once the monarch of the boardwalk but now deteriorating from disuse for the last 10 years.

title: Even if Label Says Washable, Is It Better to Dry Clean?
description: Pasted to a window or a wall in most drycleaning establishments is a sign that reads, Everything Dry Cleans Better. But as the racks of drycleaning failures in the laboratory of the Neighborhood Dry Cleaners Association show, some garments can't be dry cleaned at all.

title: . . Or 1977 Oil Crisis
description: A new energy crisis with an oilsupply squeeze and sleep price increases appears to be shaping up for next year and gives even greater urgency to major conservation measures. A study by oil economist Walter Levy predicts that the reviving world economy will bring a surge in oil demand that could require OPEC shipments at the projected 1980 rate of 34.2 million barrels a day by mid1977. OPEC production now is only 29.3 million barrels a day, about 5 million barrels a day below next year's needs.

title: Sea Law on the Rocks?
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger last year described the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea as one of the most comprehensive and critical negotiations in history. Failure to agree on a new body of oceans law, the Secretary warned, will lead to unrestrained military and commercial rivalry and mounting political turmoil.

title: ROCKEFELLER SCORES PLATFORM OF G.O.P.
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., Aug. 29 (AP)The national Republican platform does not reflect the views of President Ford, Vice President Rockefeller said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A Synagogue Rises From Ashes
description: Some 100 Orthodox Jews who had worshiped in makeshift quarters for five years dedicated their new, onestory synagogue in the heart of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: RANDOM SHELLING FEARED IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug, 29Shells and rockets felt on residential areas here today, reviving fears that indiscriminate bombardment of civilians would resume.

title: Senator Moss, Posing as Ragged Patient, Sees Medicaid Abuse in New York City
description: The Senator, Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, who is chairman of the Subcommittee on LongTerm Care, got a Medicaid card and visited the East Harlem Medical Center at 145 East 116th Street.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LINCOLN CENTER, Mass.  My Northernborn friends have been celebrating the Democrats' nomination of Jimmy Carter as a signal that at last the South is ready to return to the Union. Putting aside the bitterness of the Civil War and the burden of race, Southerners of Carter's generation are, supposedly, representatives of a New South, a South that accepts and emulates the values of the North.

title: Giants Still Have Room To Improve
description: In the earlymorning fog yesterday, the Giants booed New Jersey, but even after an unscheduled landing in their new home state, they were flying high.

title: Wolfson Challenged On Legal Expenses
description: Two minority shareholders of the MerrittChapman & Scott Corporation have charged Louis E. Wolfson, the entrepreneur, with illegally drawing $1.3 million in expenses from the company, mainly to cover the costs of defending a criminal action filed against him by the Securities and Exchange Commission

title: LEE TALLEY
description: Lee Talley, retired chairman of the CocaCola Company, died Saturday at his home in St. Michaels, Md. He was 75 years old.

title: Time Magazine Poll Shows Ford Closing In on Carter
description: President Ford, fresh from his victory at the Republican National Convention, has narrowed the gap against the Democratic Presidential nominee, Jimmy Carter, according to an opinion poll released yesterday by Time magazine, the Reuters news agency reported.

title: Praise the Lord Club Brings Gospel to TV
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 27  The Rev. James Bakker, splendid in a vested robin'seggblue suit and standing against a blue velvet background, perfect for the television cameras grinding noiselessly about him during the taping of his gospel talk show, ended the day's session with a faith healing among the studio audience.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: Two out when winning run scored.

title: Manila Acts on Fuel
description: MANILA, Aug. 29 (Reuters) The Philippines Government today began a campaign to persuade motorists to give up their cars for one day a week to save bills for fuel, all of which is imported.

title: Memorial Services
description: WILDMANFrederick S., Sr. Memorial service St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave, and 70th St., on Tuesday, Aug. 31, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributtons may be made to Winsted Memorial Hospital, Winsted, Conn. 06098 or to St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Argentina Expected to Ban Nazi Tracts
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29Argentina's military Government has decided to ban the publication, distribution and export of antiSemitic Nazi literature, a profusion of which is now circulating freely here, according to a high official source.

title: French Bishop Defies Pope by Saying Latin Mass
description: LILLE, France, Aug. 29A controversial French bishop, suspended by the Vatican last month for opposing Roman Catholic Church reforms, celebrated a traditional Latin mass before 6,000 followers in a sports arena here today in direct defiance of Pope Paul VI.

title: 7% Rise in Output Indicated by China
description: HONG KONG  China's Indusrial output grew 7 percent in the first half of this year, newly published official statistics indicate, a performance that analysts here consider good though somewhat below the remarkable average that Chinese industry has achieved in recent years.

title: Viking 2 Taking Pictures To Help Plot Landing Site
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI)Viking 2 started taking pictures of the frozen volcanic waste of the Martian Plains of Utopia today so its Sept. 3 landing site could be plotted. The landing target was to be chosen tomorrow.

title: Barbara Seuling Wed to M. B. Gerrard
description: Barbara Ellen Seuling, a candidate for a Master of Laws degree at the New York University School of Law, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Burr Gerrard, a consultant to the Council on the Environment of New York City and a RootTilden Scholar at the N.Y.U. School of Law.

title: Miss Palmer Takes Denver Golf by 2
description: DENVER, Aug. 29 (AP)Sandra Palmer, who took the lead with four straight birdies midway through the final round, sank a 20foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today and won the National Jewish Hospital open. Miss Palmer, aware that her lead had been cut to a stroke by Pat Bradley, who was one hole behind, dropped the long downhill putt to clinch the $7,000 firstplace prize. Her final round of fiveunderpar 67 gave her a 54hole total of 20610 under parand a twoshot victori.

title: Suburbs Fighting Back as Crime Rises
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28After his home in suburban San Francisco was broken into three times in eight days earlier this year, Harold Calder organized the Crocker Neighborhood Association and set up a program that has stirred controversy while cutting down crime.

title: Zarate Keeps Bantamweight Title
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP)Carlos Zarate, the World Boxing Council bantamweight titleholder, knocked out Paul Ferreri of Australia in the 12th round of their scheduled 15round bout last night before a crowd of 10,826 at the Forum.

title: Rock Concerts Canceled
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI)Rock music concerts at the California State Fair have been canceled because of two days of violence that left 60 persons injured, state officials said. Herbert Rhodes, director of the California Department of Parks and Recreation, said that the decision, which became effective last night, was the result of two nights of disturbances by youths throwing rocks and bottles.

title: Police Deride Superman Image of TV Lawmen
description: It is Sunday night and the opening scenes of another episode in the adventures of Lieutenant Columbo is unfolding on the television screen.

title: Advertising
description: Three students at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration have just completed summer jobs at three large New York advertising agencies. What they learned from the agencies (and what the agencies learned from them) could have significant implications on Madison Avenue's hiring policies regarding holders of M.B.A. degrees in general and those from Harvard in particular.

title: Paris Drought Broken
description: PARIS, Aug. 29 (Reuters)Heavy rain fell in Paris today for the first time in six weeks. Thunderstorm also broke out in other parts of France, causing flash floods.

title: Grahams One, Two In Golf
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP)  David Graham carded a threeunderpar 69 and scored a fourstroke victory today in the stormdelayed American Golf Classic.

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Several pieces of the sort of legislation generally regarded as anathema by businessmen and a blessing by consumers, after months (and even years) of fighting and negotiating among the principals, will face their final tests for enactment in Congress in the next few weeks.

title: NEW TESTS SEEK EPIDEMIC'S CAUSE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 29scientists at the University of Connecticut Medical School have begun a crucial new series of tests to determine if nickel carbonyl, a highly toxic chemical, caused the epidemic that has killed 28 persons and sickened 150 others in Pennsylvania.

title: 12 Senior Congressmen From South Are Retiring
description: MONROE, La., Aug. 28Representative Otto E. Passman is one of a dozen senior Congressmen from the South who will not return to the House next year.

title: Ruta Gerulaitis Loses
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 29 Beth Norton of Fairfield, Conn., who was seeded fifth, won the Women's Tennis Association invitation tourney today, defeating Ruta Gerulaitis, 16, 75, 63, in the final at the Westchester Country Club. Miss Norton, 19 years old, earned $1,800 and Miss Gerulaitis, 20, won $1,000.

title: THOMAS J. FLAVELL
description: Thomas J. Flavell, a vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union and manager of its Local 169 here, died Friday in Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 1108 New Hyde Park Road, New Hyde Park, L. I.

title: Hunt Wins Dutch Auto Race
description: ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Aug. 29 (AP)James Hunt, driving a McLaren, celebrated his 29th birthday today by winning the Dutch Grand Prix for the second straight year. He averaged 113.34 miles per hour for the 198mile race.

title: Linda J. Adler Wed in Capital
description: Linda Jane Adler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Adler of Bethesda, Md., and Steven Charles Fischer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Fischer of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married in Washington yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Joshua O. Haberman at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: * Modifled sulky.  Also eligible.

title: JAMES F. MALONE JR.
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29James F. Malone Jr., a former Allegheny County District Attorney and a power in Pennsylvania Republican politics for more than 30 years, died today at the Fair Winds Manor, a nursing home, in Sarver, Pa. He was 72 years old.

title: Spain Is Imposing Press Censorship On Reform Plans
description: MADRID, Aug. 29Prime Minister Adolfo Surez Gonzlez angered the Spanish press today by imposing censorship on official plans for political reform.

title: Dry Trot Held at Complex
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 29I'm sick, a smiling horseplayer said today as he cashed another fistful of tickets at the new Meadowlands track.

title: Submarine Skippers of Opposing Sides Meet and Reminisce About World War II
description: HACKENSACK  In July 1943, we were in Chesapeake Bay laying mines. I remember one very clear night standing on deck with a pair of night glasses and seeing very clearly the light around Washington, D.C.

title: Smith's Early Clout Beats Seaver, 21
description: Some more of the same was what Tom Seaver called the Mets' 21 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: TALKS ON TODAY OVER MUSIC HALL
description: With only two days to reach contract agreenients, the Radio City Music Hall and its union employees will begin intensive negotiations today in an effort to avert a threatened permanent shutdown of the theater.

title: Kazi Nazrul Islam Dies; Bangladesh Poet Was 77
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Aug. 29 (AP)Kati Nazrul Islam, one of the foremost poets of the 20th century on the Indian subcontinent, died today in a hospital here. He was 77 years old.

title: Most Reagan Aides Are Saying No to Job Offers From Ford Camp
description: President Ford's campaign has had only indifferent success recruiting the Ronald Reagan operatives who made it such a long and hard contest for the Republican nomination.

title: CoStar in Television Series Found Dead in California
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI)Mary Anissa Jones, 18 years old, who played Buffy on the television series Family Affair, was found dead in the home of a friend yesterday, the San Diego County Coroner's office said.

title: TwoChina Talks
description: None of the nations that emerged divided front World War H and its aftermath, has made as little progress toward a settlementor even discussion of a settlement as China and Taiwan. Both Peking and Taipei behave as if their civil war were still under way, although no significant military action has occurred for many years, and both claim legitimacy as the government of all of China.

title: U.S. Ship's New Zealand Visit Sets Off a Strike and Marches
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 29The visit of the United States nuclearpowered warship Truxtun to New Zealand has sparked demonstrations, sabotage and a major clash between the Government and port unions.

title: Top Award To Afghan At Paramus
description: PARAMUS. N.J., Aug. 29Ch. Sandina Sparkling Champagne is an August dog. The 2yearold silverbrindle Afghan won his first bestinshow award in the United States and his third on the continent today, and they all took place this month. His victory was earned at the 33d fixture of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey in the underground parking garage of the Bergen Mall.

title: Robin C. Pforr Student's Bride
description: Robin Chalmers Pforr and Ronald James Haralson were married yesterday afternoon in the Mountain Brook Presbyterian Church in Birmingham, Ala., by the Rev. August M. Kling.

title: MORE CRIMINALS BEING SENT TO JAIL
description: Judges in New York State are sending more convicted felons to state prison, according to an analysis by the Division of Criminal Justice Services to be submitted today to Governor Carey and the Legislaure.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: BUDGET BODY SEES STABLE NEW YORK
description: Mayor Beame and his budget aides received a kind word from an unexpected source yesterday when the Citizens Budget Commission said, in issuing its annual fiscal summary, that the city appears to be in the process of transition to a more stable future.

title: Steelworkers' Chiefs Avert Split on Top Union Post
description: LAS VEGAS. Nev., Aug. 29John S. Johns, international vice president of the United Steel Workers of America, withdrew today as a candidate for the union's presidency, ending the threat of a damaging split that would aid the expected rankandfile challenge by Edward Sadlowski of Chicago.

title: SIMON S. NEUMAN
description: Simon S. Neuman, chairman of Publicker Industries Inc., distillers of beverage and industrial alcohol Products, died yesterday in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 76 years old and was a resident of Wayne, Pa.

title: Joseph Baumgold Is Dead at 68; Ran DiamondImport Company
description: Joseph Baumgold, the president of Baumgold Brothers Inc., one of the nation's leading diamond importers and cutters, died Saturday at his Fifth Avenue home after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: China, Lacking Recognition, Holds Down U.S. Trade
description: Trade between the United States and China will remain at its current low level until the United States Government recognizes the Peking regime, according to Christopher H. Phillips, president of the National Council for U.S.China Trade. The council is a nonprofit organization of several hundred American companies based in Washington and devoted to promoting trade with China.

title: Who's to Blame for the Ruined Clothes?
description: On the fourth floor of the nondescript office building at 116 East 27th Street is an inelegant room where a fashion show of sorts can be seen by invited guests only. Some of the fashions on display there come from designers with famous names while others carry less elegant labels common among the general populace. All, however, are shown without benefit of mannequins because some of these clothes can stand on their own. Literally.

title: Nastase Overwhelms Tanner in Final
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 29Ilie Nastase was in rare form today, playing the type of tennis that wins tournaments and respect.

title: Deaths
description: BACONMildred E., on August 28, 1976 in New Canaan, Conn., beloved mother of Barbara Horton Kennedy and Arthur J. Horton, loving grandmother of David H. Konneoy and Lynn K. Olsen. Friends may call at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12 St., Garaen City, Monday, 7.9 P.M. Services Tuesday, 1 P.M. at the Fairchild Chapel.

title: Canada, Sweden Win
description: Canada defeated Chile, 30, and Sweden beat India, 21, at the start of the eightnation Stevens Cup senior team, tournament at Tennisport yesterday. The United States, which is represented by Vic Seixas and Hugh Stewart, has won the cup every year since its inception in 1964.

title: FILM BY TRUFFAUT TO OPEN FESTIVAL
description: The 14th annual New York Film Festival will be held Oct. 1 through 17 at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center, with 19 programs from 10 countries, according to Martin E. Segal, president of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: KUWAIT PARLIAMENT AND CABINET ARE OUT
description: KUWAIT, Aug. 29 (AP)The Kuwaiti Cabinet resigned today over a dispute with Parliament, which was dissolved by a decree from Kuwait's ruler, Sheik Sabah alSalem alSabah.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Apartment Construction Is Slow
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29Surprisingly sluggish demand for apartments in many parts of the country has sent housing economists searching for possible basic changes in the life style of younger Americans who would normally be forming their own households and moving into apartments now.

title: Reckoning in Africa: II
description: The frank language of white supremacy in South Africa has been officially replaced by such terms as apartheid (separateness) and more recently the blander separate development and separate freedoms. All are intended to convey the Government's basic political theory: that the black majority will have rights only in small tribal homelands while the whites keep total control of 87 percent of South Africa.

title: FORD, IN REVERSAL, TO ASK $1.5 BILLION TO EXPAND PARKS
description: OLD FAITHFUL, Wyo., Aug. 29President Ford, altering Administration policy, proposed today that Congress spend $1.5 billion over the next decade to expand the nation's public parklands.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
GOING OUT Guide
description: PENTHOUSE SERENADE One of the real lookanddrink joys of New Yorkyou can also dine in style hereis Mitchell's Place, atop the Beekman Hotel, at 49th Street and First Avenue. We guarantee you'll halt in your tracks momentarily as you step from the elevator onto the 26th floor and glimpse the background panorama.

title: Robert Frost Gets His Road and His Day in Vermont
description: RIPTON, Vt., Aug. 28This was not the kind of day one would have been likely to put on a postcard. It rained in northern Vermont, and even in the afternoon, when a little sun broke through, the only mountain a person could see was the one directly underfoot.

title: A Garden on a Small Plot of Water
description: SOUTH SALEM, N.Y.One of the wonders of Truesdale Lake is the floating gardens of Nita and Bill Opitz, ripe with parsley, radishes, cucumbers, broccoli, tomatoes and onions.

title: Some Were Reservists And Many Were Young
description: Capt. Kenneth M. Burkhart once thought he would become a priest, but gave up his studies to join the Air Force. He served six years, three times in Vietnam, and won the Distinguished Service Cross among other awards.

title: Big Slate of New Issues Tests LowRate Trend
description: The taxexempt bond market this week faces an exceptionally heavy schedule of newissue sales, and the big volume will almost certainly test the trend toward lower interest rates that has now lasted two months. According to The Bond Buyer, $954 million of state, city and other local government bonds are scheduled for sale, through competitive bidding and noncompetitive negotiation, over the next five days.

title: U.S. Influence on Iran: Gigantic and Diverse
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29United States policies, products and personnel have had an enormous impact on this ancient Middle Eastern kingdom in recent years, largely through the sale of substantially more than $10 billion in Americanmade military equipment to the Iranian regime since early 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Hills Group Collects and Recycles Eyeglasses for Needy
description: SHORT HILLSIn 1932, when recycling was hardly a household word, Julia Terry, a Short Hills philanthropist, decided that discarding old eyeglass frames was a terrible waste. She also discovered, through her volunteer work in new York City, that eyeglasses were a luxury the poor frequently could not afford.

title: Colon Wins 13.1Miler
description: Tony Colon, 1,500meter champion of Puerto Rico, won the Puerto RicanHispanic Sports Council halfmarathon, a 13.1 mile race in Central Park roadway yesterday with a time of 1 hour 8 minutes 55 seconds. The 24yearold Colon, a former Manhattan College star running for the New York Athletic Club, beat 33yearold Dr. Norb Sander of the Millrose A.A. whose time was 1:10.15. Bill Bragg, of the N.Y.A.C. was third in 1:11.40.

title: Justice Agency, Senate Panel Get Files Indicating PriceFixing of Uranium
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Justice Department and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have been given copies of documents that appear to prove the existence of an international cartel that has been fixing the price of uranium since late 1971.

title: TENSION IN AEGEAN IS PARTLY DEFUSED
description: ATHENS, Aug. 29Greece and Turkey have cautiously accepted a Security Council resolution urging them to show restraint and resume negotiations on their dispute over mineral rights in the Aegean Sea. A time and site are now being discussed and talks could begin next month.

title: U.S. FINDS TAIWAN DEVELOPS AFUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Taiwan is developing the capacity to create an atomic bomb one day as a result of a new program there to reprocess spent nuclear reactor fuel, United States officials said today.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Today's Entries at Belmont

title: FRAUD AND WASTE IN MEDICAID FOUND IN SENATE REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 A Senate investigation of the 10yearold Medicaid program in eight cities has found rampant abuse by both providers of health services and recipients, and has determined that Federal action is needed to correct what was termed the program's abysmal administration at all levels of government.

title: Burma to Free 1,600
description: RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 29, (AP)The Government has announced general clemency for the more than 4,500 persons jailed for rioting in connection with the burial of former U Thant in 1974. It said the amnesty would allow almost 1,600 prisoners to go free and more than 2,900 others would have their sentences reduced.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The body of a Point Pleasant man who jumped from a bridge over Barnegat Bay to fulfill a childhood dream, has been recovered by the police. The body of James Welles, 22 years old, was discovered near the scene of his leap from the Route 35 bridge between Brielle and Point Pleasant. The police said Mr. Welles had removed his wallet and shoes, told a companion he would fulfill a childhood dream of leaping from th ebridge and then jumped into the bay. The men had been drinking at a tavern before the incident, the police said.

title: Preseason Football
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for weekfollows:

title: Solomon and Borg Gain Tennis Final
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 29 (UPI)  Harold Solomon defeated Raul Ramirez, 46, 62, .6.2, 75, tonight, earning the right to play Bjorn Borg in the final of the $125,000 United States pro tennis championship. The final is tomorrow night.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: State Calls In 1,000 New York City Physicians to Discuss Medicaid Billings
description: The New York State Department of Social Services is calling in more than 1,000 New York City physicians of 14.000 participating in the Medicaid program here to discuss questionable billings and referrals.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Boit Wins at 800 Meters; Bayi Fifth
description: RIETI, Italy, Aug. 29 (UPI)Kenya's Mike Boit won the men's 800meter run, and Dwight Stones of the United States tools the men's high jump, at the Rieti international track and field meet today. Boit clocked 1 minute 44.96 seconds in a race billed as a longawaited duel with Tanzania's Filbert Bayi, who started badly and finished a poor fifth in 1:48:95. Stones cleared 7 feet 4 inches to win on fewer misses.

title: Miss Kohn Bride Of Steven Launer
description: At Temple Rodeph Sholom in Bridgeport, Conn., last evening, Merryl Lisbeth Kohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kohn of Fairfield, Conn., was married to Steven Ira Launer, son of Edith R. Launer, also of Fairfield, and the late Leonard Launer.

title: Commodities
description: Cocoa futures traders face their annual showdown this weekthe midpoint of the vital, twomonth growing period for the main crops of Ghana and Brazil, the two key sources of the cacao beans.

title: New Pact With Firestone Ratified by Rubber Union
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 29 (UPI)  The United Rubber Workers (union ratified a new master contract with the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today as other union members returned to jobs at Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plants across the nation at the end of a 130day strike.

title: Big Stores Joining in Sunday Retailing
description: Sunday shopping on a mass basis came to New York City and the metropolitan area yesterday when four of the largest retailers opened their doors, most of them for the first time, on Sunday. The joint effort drew many residents and tourists and brought the participation of scores of smaller retailers and fastfood restaurants.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: U.S FINDS TAIWAN DEVELOPS AFUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Taiwan is developing the capacity to create an atomic bomb one day as a result of a new program there to reprocess spent nuclear reactor fuel, United States officials said today.

title: BETTY FORD SEES VERY TOUGH RACE
description: VAIL Colo., Aug. 29 (AP)Betty Ford predicts a very tough campaign between her husband and the Democratic Presidential candidate, Jimmy Carter: in which President Ford's pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon will be made an issue by the Democrats.

title: About New York
description: He had a secret. He had been carrying it around for weeks, a pomegranate full of tiny, nourishing possibilities.

title: U.S. Women Take Tennis Cup Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29  Call it The Implausible Dreamnot impossiblethat, Billie Jean King, who has been retired from tournament singles play for more than one year, and Rosemary Casals, who has not won a singles tournament in three years, should make the United States women's team the best in the world.

title: Yanks Fall, 54, To Angels in 11
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 29 Thurman Munson, who was hit in the head by a Nolan Ryan fastball and lived to tell about it, bounced back today and nearly became a hero. Nearly. Just as the Yankees nearly won.

title: Pirates Win in 11th With Candelaria
description: No, I wasn't tired, although I never pitched 11 innings before, said John Candelaria, the Pittsburgh lefthander after going into overtime to earn a 32 victory over the San Francisco Giants yesterday. It was his first start at home since his nohitter in Pittsburgh on Aug. 9.

title: French Bishop Defies Pope by Saying Latin Mass
description: LILLE, France, Aug. 29A controversial French bishop, suspended by the Vatican last month for opposing Roman Catholic Church reforms, celebrated a traditional Latin mass before 6,000 followers in a sports arena here today in direct defiance of Pope Paul VI.

title: Dancers Countess First in Matchmaker
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 (AP)Chris McCarron rode Dancers Countess to victory in the $125,000 Matchmaker Stakes last night. The triumph by the 4yearold owned by G. M. Holtsinger earned Holtsinger's stable stallion service to What A Pleasure, a service valued at $75,000. What Pleasure was syndicated for $8 million.

title: Players Will Vote On N.F.L. Contract
description: A final effort before the start of the National Football League's season on Sept. 12 will be made this week to reach a labor agreement between the owners and players. The executive committee of the National Football League Players' Association will meet in Chicago tomorrow to vote on acceptance of the owners' latest final offer of a contract.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Leslie Waters Wed To Victor Lewkow
description: Leslie Waters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Waters of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Victor Lewkow, son of Herman Lewkow of Phoenix and the late Carolyn Cuttler Lewkow. The ceremony was performed at the Flushing (Queens) Jewish Center by Rabbi Benjamin Haimowitz.

title: Betsy Jolas Winning Recognition in U.S.
description: Betsy Jolas did not, as she recalls it now, lead the life of an ordinary child For one Thing, James Joyce was in the habit of dropping by her house in France and singing Mendelssohn duets with her mother. I would play the piano for them. Then Joyce and my parents would sit about and correct his manuscripts and proofs. Joyce was like a grandfather to me in those times. In the summer of 1940 especially, my last months in France until the war was over, we saw him constantly.

title: Moscow Asks Syria to Leave Lebanon
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29  The Soviet Union has begun publicly pressing Syria to withdraw its troops from Lebanon and cooperate with its natural allies, the Palestinian and Lebanese leftists whom it has been fighting since late last spring.

title: Raiders Pin A 149 Loss On 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP)Ken Stabler threw two 5yard touchdown passes in the second quarter today as the Oakland Raiders defeated the San Francisco 49ers, 149, in a National Football League preseason game.

title: Harris Out 6 Weeks
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (UPI)James Harris, one of the Los Angeles Rams' quarterbacks, fractured his right thumb in an exhibition game last night and will be sidelined for about six weeks.

title: DR. JOEL HARTLEY, CLINICAL PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Joel Hartley, clinical professor of orthopedic surgery at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and an attending orthopedic surgeon at Mount Sinai Hospital, died in the hospital yesterday. He was 66 years old and lived at 8 East 96th Street and South Salem, N.Y.

title: Z. M. Dagar Shows Skill and Subtlety In Indian Music
description: Z. M. Dagar's recital at the Washington Square Methodist Church on Saturday was the most profound evening of Indian instrumental music this reviewer has had the pleasure of attending. The church was hot and steamy, but with the audience seated on cushions and crowding up against the stage it was admirably intimate. In these circumstances, knowledgeable listeners were able to offer Mr. Dagar active encouragement, and he responded with an impressive display of skill and subtlety.

title: Big Stores Joining in Sunday Retailing
description: Sunday shopping on a mass basis came to New York City and the metropolitan area yesterday when four of the largest retailers opened their doors, most of them for the first time, on Sunday. The joint effort drew many residents and tourists and brought the participation of scores of smaller retailers and fastfood restaurants.

title: FORD, IN REVERSAL TO ASK $1.5 BILLION TO EXPAND PARKS
description: OLD FAITHFUL, Wyo., Aug. 29President Ford, altering Administration policy, proposed today that Congress spend $1.5 billion over the next decade to expand the nation's public parklands.

title: Park Fiesta Gives Taste of Puerto Rico
description: A little bit of Puerto Rico came to Central Park yesterday, bringing joy and memories to thousands of former residents and their children. The 12th annual Puerto Rican Folklore Fiesta filled the mall with mariachi bands, popular theater and other aspects of their favorite island in the sun.

title: Burger King Account Is Awarded to J.W.T.
description: The winner and new agency for the Burger King account, with billings of $25 million a year, is the J. Walter Thompson Company. The account will move Wednesday from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, which had it since 1968.

title: Miss Kantrowitz, Reporter, Wed
description: Barbara Kantrowitz and Daniel Hertzberg, reporters on Newsday's Nassau staff, were married yesterday afternoon at Pierce House in the town park, Lincoln, Mass., by Rabbi Gary Johnson.

title: U.S. List of Those on Jets
description: Following is the list of the dead and the survivors in the crashes in Britain and Greenland on Saturday of two United Statees Air Force planes. The list was issued at McGuire Air Force Base, N.J., where both planes were based.

title: Jets Commit Football Sins of Youth
description: Wearing fresh outfits, like children returning to school, the Jets go back to the practice field today to prepare for their final preseason game.

title: Lynne Kramer Bride Of Frederick Eisenbud
description: Lynne Adair Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kramer of Laurel Hollow, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick Eisenbud, son of Mr. and Mrs. Merril Eisebud of Sterling Forest, N. Y. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the garden ceremony at the Kramer home. Cantor Norman Swerling assisted.

title: WARD IN NEWARK SEEKS TO SECEDE
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29  The Revolutionaryera cry against taxation without representation is being echoed by a number of angry residents of this city's heavily taxed East Ward, and like the overtaxed Colonists who tried to solve their problems by breaking ties with Britain 200 years ago, the East Warders want to secede from New Jersey's largest city.

title: Praise The Lord Club Brings Gospel to TV
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 27  The Rev. James Bakker, splendid in a vested robin'seggblue suit and standing against a blue velvet background, perfect for the television cameras grinding noiselessly about him during the taping of his gospel talk show, ended the day's session with a faith healing among the studio audience.

title: Suburbs Fighting Back as Crime Rises
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28After his home in suburban San Francisco was broken into three times in eight days earlier this year, Harold Calder organized the Crocker Neighborhood Association and set up a program that has stirred controversy while cutting down crime.

title: It's On to Belmont For Racing Today
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29It was on to Belmont Park today as horsemen, track personnel and New York Racing Association officials deserted this historic racing community en route to a 40day meeting at the Long Island facility starting tomorrow.

title: South Africa Will Revise Plan For Territory, Paper Reports
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 29South Africa will adjust the plans announced for the independence of SouthWest Africa in an attempt to head off United Nations sanctions, according to a report published here today.

title: Rockwell Said to Push B1
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) The Rockwell International Corporation, a major defense contractor, is encouraging employees to write letters to Congress urging construction of the B1 bomber, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Pregnant TeenAlters Get Help
description: NEWARKA program for pregnant teenagers that permits them to remain with their babies in a governmentrun residence for up to three years is under way here.

title: Precious Fella Takes Prix d'Ete
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 29 (AP)Precious Fella, driven by Gary Cameron, captured the $163,700 Prix d'Ete pace today before 19,000 fans at Blue Bonnets Raceway. Precious Fella, owned by Oscar and Michael Kimmelman, Mort Feder, Ian Baird and Del Cameron of Pinehurst, N.C., earned place with a secondplace finish in the second division of the stake's preliminary round earlier in the afternoon. Keystone Ore, winner of the first division heat, finished second in the final. Wolf Pack, the winner of the second division, placed third.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz filed suit in State Supreme Court, Manhattan, seeking to enjoin the use by two Connecticut companies of the Great Seal of New York State. Mr. Lefkowitz charged that the companies, International Silver and American Archives, both of Meriden, had used the seal without authorization. The companies, the suit said, produced Bicentennial commemorative pewter plates that used the seal along with those of the 12 other original states. The prates, according to the suit, realized more than $1 million for the companies. A 13 Original Colonies Spoon Collection, which also used New York's seal, earned more than $62,000 for the companies, according to Mr. Lefkowitz. He asked that the companies be enjoined from using the seal and that they be ordered to pay to the state all profits from use of the seal.

title: Radio
description: 7:30.8:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Sonata for Flute, Harpsichord, and Cello No. 22, Biavet; Piano Concerto No. 3, Mozart; Violin Sonata No. 1, Bach; Four Regimental Marches, Amalie; Two Etudes, Chopin; Concerto in A, Vivaldi.

title: ExBritish Minister Is Reported Linked To Lockheed Bribe
description: LONDON, Aug. 30 (Reuters) Two British newspapers reported today that a former Lockheed sales executive had charged that a former British cabinet minister had received a $1 million bribe to promote sale of the American company's aircraft here.

title: Britton, Hooker Advance in Golf
description: Bill Britton, 20 years old, shot a 73 yesterday, as did Al Hooker, a Staten Island detective, as both qualified for the finals of the New York City Public Links golf championship.

title: Bridge
description: Several topranked New York experts were among the winners in the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Championships at McAfee, N.J., during the weekend.

title: Lowenstein's Bid for House Aided by Governor Brown
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California spent the day campaigning in Nassau County yesterday for Allard K. Lowenstein, who is running for the House of Representatives.

title: Paul Taylor and His Dance Troupe Are on a Brilliant Creative Binge
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 The 1976 American Dance Festival, which this year has been divided between New London, Conn., and Newport, ended here last night with a second program by the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: New Toy Confiscated: Blowguns That Kill
description: ROCKY HILL, Conn., Aug. 29 (UPI)The police have added two unusual weapons to their stockpile of confiscated armsfivefoot blowguns capable of piercing a halfinchthick sheet of plywood.

title: EXF.B.I. AIDE SEES SCAPEGOAT ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29W. Mark Felt, the former associate director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, suggested today that he might become a scapegoat in the Justice Department's investigation of several burglaries carried out by bureau agents in recent years.

title: State A.F.L.C.I.O. to Map a Bigger Political Role
description: Delegates representing the 2,000,000 A.F.A.C.I.O. members in the state will meet at Kiamesha Lake tomorrow to develop plans for steppedup political activity in the fall campaign.

title: Books of The Times
description: Late Victorians in England talked endlessly about the vice that dare not speak its name. No, the namehomosexualitywas little used in polite society, but they did chatter a lot about abominable offences, loathsome habits and gross indecency, which were code phrases for the word they could not quite bring themselves to utter. The talk was especially vivid on two occasions; the prosecution of Oscar Wilde and, earlier, when participants in the socalled Cleveland Street scandal were being prosecuted.

title: Freedom Train in Trenton
description: TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 29 (UPI)The American Freedom Train, the brainchild of a New Jersey commodities broker, is scheduled to roll into this state capital tomorrow for a threeday visit. The train's 15 cars hold historical American documents and an audiovisual montage of 200 years of American life. The train, which is on a 17,000mile, 21month Bicentennial tour of 80 cities in 48 states, will be on display at Cadwalader Park during its stay here.

title: FRAUD AND WASTE IN MEDICAID FOUND IN SENATE REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29A Senate investigation of the 10yearold Medicaid program in eight cities has found rampant abuse by both providers of health services and recipients, and has determined that Federal action is needed to correct what was termed the program's abysmal administration at all levels of government.

title: 25 Charged in Labor Dispute
description: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Aug. 29 (UPI)  Twentyfive persons were charged yesterday with contempt of court after picket line violence at the nearby Goodyear Atomic Corporation plant, a uranium enrichment plant. One minor injury to a deputy sheriff was reported. The arrested pickets were, charged with contempt for violating a restraining order granted the corporation by a Pike County judge.

title: Miss Gitelman Bride of Shalom Brilliant
description: Cynthia Duke Gitelman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Gitelman of Seaford, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Shalom Brilliant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Brilliant of Bayside, Queens, Rabbi Louis Bernstein performed the ceremony in Temple Torah in Little Neck, Queens.

title: HELEN HECHT
description: Helen Hecht, president and chairman of Hecht, Egan & Nash Inc., a Westchester real estate concern, died Saturday in Northern Westchester Hospital. The wife of Fels Hecht, an interior decorator and builder, she was 65 years old and lived on Lawrence Farms Crossway, Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: DROP IN FUTURES LED BY SOYBEANS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP)Prices of soybean futures declined by more than 15 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today and strongly influenced lower prices in other from commodities.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday stated incorrectly that City Councilman Ramon Velez did not attend the 12th annual Puerto Rican Folklore Fiesta on Sunday in Central Park, which was attended by Representative Herman Ba. dillo. Mr. Velez, who is op. posing Mr. Badillo in the Democratic primary, was at the fiesta for two hours, according to his office.

title: Ford to Make Ware Offer
